title: JUVENILE OFFENDERS DISCOVER THE WORLD ON STAGE
description: As the actors assembled on the small wooden stage for their performances, it was clear that it would be a memorable occasion for both the players and the audience.

title: CORRECTION
description: In a review of the 1954 ''A Star Is Born'' on March 18, the distributor was misidentified. The video cassette is distributed by Warner Home Video. In the March 18 review of ''Tchaikovsky Competition: Violin and Piano'' it was stated that in 1982 no first prizes were awarded for either instrument. First prize for violin was shared by Viktoria Mullova and Sergei Stadler, both from the U.S.S.R.

title: COMPUTER ADVICE AIDS POLITICAL CANDIDATES
description: SOUTHERN California is known for its microchips. Southern Connecticut is rapidly becoming known for a different kind of computer product - campaign advice.

title: COUPLES LEADS T.P.C. BY TWO
description: Fred Couples kept his two-stroke lead in the $800,000 Tournament Players Championship after the third round today. But the group in close pursuit today was quite different from Friday's - and quite impressive.

title: Peru
description: To the Editor: I agree with Donald M. Sledz (Letters on Travel, Feb. 12) about the economic difficulties of Peru and the kindness and charm of the people.

title: SUNDAY, APRIL 1, 1984;  International
description: The U.S. will lend Argentina $300 million as part of a larger financial rescue effort, Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said. He said the loan was being made to help avert a crisis for the new democratic administration of President Raul Alfonsin. (Page 1, Column 6.) A slash in West Europe's milk output and a reduction in its farm prices was agreed on by the European Economic Community in a move to put its finances on a sounder footing. It was the first such agreement on agricultural policy in the 20-year history of the Common Market. Increasing farm spending has pushed the group to the brink of insolvency. (1:4.)

title:
ART;
AWARD WINNERS SHOW COLORFUL PAINTING AND COOL SCULPTURE
description: The third of the three awards exhibitions that resulted from last year's annual juried show sponsored by the Smithtown Township Arts Council is now on view at the council's headquarters in Mills Pond House in St. James. Paintings and works on paper by Joan Branca and the sculpture of Nick Micros reflect quite different sensibilities, yet the works coexist comfortably in an uncrowded presentation that enhances the show's impact.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Sunday on the Caribbean off season, gave an incorrect off-season rate for seven nights' stay at the Leyritz Plantation inn in Martinque. The rate is $160 per person, based on two people in a room.

title: AT 25, STATION KEEPS ITS IMAGE
description: NEW HAVEN

title: THE IDEOLOGICAL ELECTION
description: Yes, America is getting a raw deal from big Government, which has indeed sometimes been a force for evil rather than good, but neither the Democrats nor the Republicans have the ideological basis or desire to change this tragic situation. As Richard Reeves astutely points out, Republicans and ''conservatives'' link American individualism to economic freedoms, while to Democrats and ''liberals,'' it means social and cultural freedom.

title: DEFICIT REDUCERS ARE OUT FOR BLOOD, BUT IS PENTAGON A STONE?
description: Before the House and the Senate can approve a deficit reduction package this year, the Democrats will have to square off against the Republicans and the Reagan Administration over the size of the military budget.

title: HOLDOUT NEARLY RUINED ARGENTINE DEBT DEAL
description: Hundreds of millions of dollars had already moved into the New York banks by 5 P.M. Friday, but it remained unclear whether the $500 million international rescue operation for Argentina was going to succeed because there was a holdout. Lloyds Bank of London still had not said it would take part.

title: THE IDEOLOGICAL ELECTION
description: While Richard Reeves's article accurately identified Ronald Reagan's ironic populist appeal - against that very ''Government'' itself which he heads - it failed to stress his much less remarked achievement in paradox.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Consumers and the Market

title: NEW RIDES TO MARK PLAYLAND OPENING
description: RYE AMUSEMENT parks in early spring seem out of place, like migrating birds that forgot to fly south. Yet, last week, there was promise of a new season at Playland.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest: NOTHING STICKS LIKE A SHADOW. By Ann Tompert. Illustrated by Lynn Munsinger. Houghton Mifflin. $12.95. (Ages 4 to 8) With the advice of a number of friends including Beaver and Woodchuck, Rabbit unsuccessfully tries different ways to get rid of his shadow.

title: NEW ROCHELLE HONORS ARTURO TOSCANINI
description: NEW ROCHELLE '' HE was like a father, the Maestro, a man who expected the best from you - and got it. And yet he never asked anything of you that he wouldn't demand of himself. To him music was life, and it was up to you to bring all your music to life.''

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINIONS;
PROSPERITY RESTS ON OUR SCHOOLS
description: WHEN the General Assembly, at the urging of Governor O'Neill, enacted a new form of governance for Connecticut higher education 20 months ago, it was essentially seeking a new educational architecture that could respond to a rather daunting host of objectives. Most agreed that change was necesssary, not all agreed as to what should come first.

title: TO SOLVE THE PROBLEM OF STRAY DOGS
description: I represent a group called PAWS (Pioneers for Animal Welfare Society), chartered by state and Federal agencies as a not-for-profit organization. We have been in existence for over 10 years, during which time our relations with most of the municipal animal shelters in this area have been cordial and fruitful.

title: NEW YORK DEMOCRATS GAIN BLACK AND HISPANIC VOTERS
description: The number of Democrats eligible to vote Tuesday has surged in predominantly black and Hispanic sections of New York City since the last statewide primary in 1982, according to an analysis of Board of Elections records.

title: U.S. Prisons 28% Overfilled
description: With the Federal prison population at a record high, the Government's prison chief says an immediate expansion of facilities is needed. Norman A. Carlson, the prison director, said Thursday that the prison population had reached 31,262, 28 percent above capacity.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Boots, Handbags And Shoes on Sale The Shoe Chalet in Yonkers, which specializes in leather boots, dress and casual shoes and handbags in all price ranges, has a sale room with many prices to half off or beyond, dropping prices from $64 to $20 or $25 on many closed and open shoes for all seasons.

title: MONDALE SPANS NEW YORK STATE IN CAMPAIGN FOR VOTES IN PRIMARY
description: Walter F. Mondale campaigned up and down New York State yesterday in a bid for votes in the final days before the state's Democratic Presidential primary Tuesday.

title: WEDDING IS PLANNED BY KAREN EPPLER
description: Mr. and Mrs. Klaus Eppler of New York and Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Karen Eppler to Benigo Ramon Sanchez , a son of Dr. and Mrs. Nestor Ramon Sanchez of Ravernier and Carol City, Fla.

title: THE TAILORED LOOK WITH A SOFT TOUCH
description: Women's fall clothes may be moving in a decidedly masculine direction these days, with ties, white shirts and blazers being adapted to the feminine form. But that doesn't mean the clothes have to be stiff, tailored or even masculine.

title: MORGAN STANLEY FIGHTS FOR NO. 1
description: THE ties between Exxon and Morgan Stanley, premier names in oil

title: A PERIPATETIC CLERIC'S PERSONAL MUSEUM
description: PICTURE this: an ordinary house in Rockville Centre, the home of an 84-year-old retired Methodist minister who spent 60 years traveling the world. Inside, however, are not just the souvenirs and photographs of someone who loves travel, but a virtual museum.

title: Article 091723 -- No Title
description: The Ideological Election

title: Afghan Is Best
description: A 7-year-old Afghan bitch, Ch. Coastwind Antiophe, owned by Jay Hafford, Tom Moorehouse and the Coastwind Kennels, was named best today at the Bronx County Kennel Club's 62d show in Nassau Coliseum. It was the first top award for the brindle hound, who has six specialties to her credit.

title: To Solve the Problem Of Stray Dogs
description: Thank you for the depressing yet accurate and informative article ''Efforts Increase to Save Unlicensed Dogs'' (Feb. 19). The problem of stray dogs is indeed frustrating, and unfortunately most people feel there is little they can do to help.

title: No Headline
description: Sanka Knox, 78, Dies; FormerTimesReporter

title: TO SOLVE THE PROBLEM OF STRAY DOGS
description: The article contained the quote ''It's not a dog problem; it's a people problem.'' Precisely. The reality of the homeless, hungry, frightened, often tormented dog or of the equally pathetic if less visible dog chained to a post - sometimes with a delapidated ''shelter,'' sometimes without - is a tragic contrast to the sentimentality about dogs that pervades the media and pet food advertising.

title: Home Clinic; EXTRA DUTY FOR CIRCULAR SAWS: CUTTING METAL AND STONE
description: -it-yourselfers who own and regularly use a portable circular saw for cutting lumber and wood panels are familiar with the fact that there are specially hardened, carbide-tipped blades available that will cut through nails hidden in lumber, many do not realize that these electric power saws can also be used to cut marble, stone, brick and most other masonry materials, as well as metals such as iron, steel, aluminum or brass.

title: CUING THE DEFENSE
description: Suppose that some superb marathon runner of the future arrives in the Olympic stadium with a lap to complete. Looking at the clock, he sees that he will easily break the two-hour barrier, and slows a little to acknowledge the plaudits of the crowd. But after the finish he is told that the official clock was inaccurate and he has missed the target by six seconds.

title: Theater; AUTHOR AND PROFESSOR RETURNS TO STAGE
description: FOR fulfillment, David Garfield says he needs a foothold in acting and academia, with an occasional side trip to authorship. Mr. Garfield is in his fourth year as an associate professor of theater arts at the State University of New York at Purchase, where he is also chairman of the newly formed acting board of study, which deals with curriculum revision. Last Monday, he opened as the co-star of a two- character Off Broadway play, ''The Actors' Delicatessen'' at the Provincetown Playhouse in Manhattan.

title: STREET LIFE BY MARK TOBY-AND A DECADE OF DRAWINGS
description: WASHINGTON, D.C.

description: PRINCETON

title: HEALTH & MEDICINE
description: A NURSE with a private psychotherapy practice has sued Community Memorial Hospital in Toms River because she was not allowed to continue counseling a teen-age patient while the teen-ager was being treated in the hospital for a drug overdose.

title: FEASTER'S CHOICE IN TOKYO
description: JACK PLIMPTON AND RUSSELL MARCUS are the authors of ''The Guide to Japanese Food and Restaurants,'' forthcoming in June (distributed by Charles E. Tuttle Company, Rutland, Vt.), and directors of the Japanese Gourmet Dining Association in Tokyo.

title: PINELANDS REGULATION: 2 STATE VIEWS DUE
description: WHEN the state's Pinelands Commission was created under the 1979 Pinelands Protection Act, builders, developers and local officials protested that growth in South Jersey would be stifled.

title: YALE'S WAY
description: To the Editor:

title:
Art;
A TRIBUTE TO VIRTUOSO IN CERAMICS
description: TRENTON OSTENSIBLY, ''The Diversions of Keramos'' at the State Museum here is a survey of American clay sculpture from 1925 to 1950; ultimately, it is a moving tribute to one artist, Waylande Gregory (1905-1971), a neglected virtuoso in ceramics who greatly influenced New Jersey's cultural life during the period.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS
description: Distressed by problems at a school in Alcoa, Tenn., where her 13-year- old son was enrolled, Jacquelyn B. McClary ran in a nonpartisan election and won a seat on the local school board. She lost her job as a reporter on The Knoxville News-Sentinel as a result.

description: To the Editor:

title: CREDENTIALS OF 400 DOCTORS IN STATE BEING STUDIED
description: An investigation into the sale of fraudulent medical credentials has expanded to include 400 doctors in New York State, the head of the state inquiry announced yesterday.

title: Board Agrees To a Hearing for Alvarado
description: Anthony J. Alvarado will get his day in court - so many days, perhaps, his lawyer said last week, that the New York City Schools Chancellor's contract could expire in June 1985 before the Board of Education decides his fate.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
GOOD NEIGHBORS AT PILGRIM STATE
description: According to Dorothea Lynde Dix, a 19th-century social reformer, ''moderate employment, moderate exercise, as much freedom as is consistent with the safety of the patient, and time spent with cheerful society should be sought for the care of the mentally ill.''

title: Jann Dickerson Plans To Be Married in June
description: The engagement of Jann Dickerson to Frank Bailinson Jr. has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Keith W. Dickerson of Wayzata, Minn.

title: IN SHORT
description: FICTION

title: 800,000 Chicago Arrests Voided by Federal Judge
description: Federal District Judge Prentice H. Marshall has ordered the City of Chicago to erase from the record 800,000 to a million disorderly conduct arrests, mainly involving blacks and Hispanic people, over at least the last five years.

title: HART AND MONDALE ARE CLOSER ON CENTRAL AMERICA
description: Gary Hart and Walter F. Mondale, who have clashed sharply over the use of American power abroad, recently have expressed strikingly similar views on the use of American forces in Central America. Each contender for the Democratic Presidential nomination says his position has been adopted by his rival.

title: CORPORATE CHIEF PONDERS 'DRUG LAG'
description: ''The people of other countries are getting the benefits of health innovations several years before we get them in this country,'' Edmund T. Pratt asserted. ''That's what's known as the drug lag.''

title: A FAMILY-RUN INN IN SAYVILLE
description: -star restaurant with two-star potential. The menu of Italian, French, Continental, new American and Oriental specialties is extremely lengthy and ambitious, so it is not surprising that the preparation can be inconsistent. Although the cooking is serious and done to order, seasonings have been off-base at times, a number of the ingredients could stand improvement and the presentation is sometimes clumsy.

title:
Dining Out ;
STURDY FARE ACROSS THE RIVER
description: ROMOLO'S has presided in Congers since 1979, when, apparently, it took the advice of Horace Greeley, left the premises called Colesseo di Roma in Mount Vernon and headed west across the river. As its name suggests, the restaurant offers Italian cuisine in the old tradition - sturdy, stick-to-the-ribs food in unstinting portions. Few places in the area have a management and waiting staff so willing and concerned with the diner's well being. No wonder weekend dining is by reservation only.

title: Jane J. Sanders To Wed in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Norman Sanders of West Nyack, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jane Jonas Sanders, to Leland S. Englebardt 2d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley L. Englebardt of Westport, Conn. A fall wedding is planned.

title: Broadcast TV
description: The series ''The Golden Age of Television'' brings back drama productions from the 1950's, when TV was live and supposedly more imaginative and exciting. Memory can often exaggerate, of course, but there are enough examples extant to demonstrate that, at least occasionally, the age could indeed be golden.

title: A VICTORY OVER MENTAL ILLNESS
description: Nearly all her life, Marie Balter has been coping with mental illness, but in recent years it has not been her own. Out of a basement office she now administers several community mental-health services for this northern suburb of Boston.

title: Miss Winseck to Wed J. M. Hartman May 12
description: A May 12 wedding is planned by Sandra Jean Winseck, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick R. Winseck of Huntington, L.I., and J. Mitchell Hartman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Hartman of Strasburg, Pa.

title: WOLF TRAP'S NEW HALL OPENS IN JULY
description: F ilene Center, the Wolf Trap Festival's major theater which was destroyed by fire two years ago, will open, completely rebuilt, at an as yet unspecified date in July, according to Carol Harford, president of the Wolf Trap Foundation for the Performing Arts. The work, which was originally scheduled to be finished by the beginning of June, has been delayed by bad weather, Miss Harford says.

title: NEW ARENAS FOR A CABLE GIANT
description: Steve Knoll frequently reports on cable television.

title: A DISASTER DRAMA MIXES TERROR AND INSPIRATION
description: E ager for ''properties'' that might translate into prime-time entertainment, television producers - responding to audiences' increasing interest in real-life dramas - have become inordinately fond of factual material, the kind of stuff that can carry the legend ''based on a true story.'' Biographies, of course, have been obvious candidates for electronic reshaping, ranging from the recent tale of a female reporter who impersonated a male in ''Her Life as a Man'' to such more elevated projects as the forthcoming ''George Washington'' and ''Pope John Paul II.'' But equally in demand are the crisis stories that often make national and even international headlines. ''Missiles of October,'' for instance, offered a countdown version of John F. Kennedy's handling of the Cuban missile threat. ''Raid on Entebbe'' traced the heroism of the Israeli military in a daring escape plan. More recently, in a combination of the biography and crisis forms, ''Sadat,'' starring Louis Gossett, Jr., generated headlines of its own when the Egyptian government banned the film because, among other things, the title role was played by a black actor. In any event, it is getting to the point that any newspaper story involving a crisis or disaster of some sort prompts the reader to wonder which TV producer got there first with the fattest contracts for dramatization.

title: The Protection Of Drinking Water
description: Wayne Prospect's ''The Right to a Drink of Water'' (Opinion Page, Feb. 19) is a fine expression of the most significant problem facing Long Island today. As a Nassau resident, I see the same problems he describes, but with a different set of actors.

BUSINESS FORUM;
A CALL FOR HIGHER TAXES ON GASOLINE
description: AFTER a decade of energy mismanagement by the Federal

title: NIXON GOES TO LOOK AT PLANS FOR LIBRARY HOUSING HIS PAPERS
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon, touring the site designated for his Presidential library Friday, said he doubted that the construction of the facility would improve the image of his Administration.

title: GHANA TALE OF PROGRESS AND FAMILY
description: ''Kukurantumi: the Road to Accra,'' a co-production of Ghana and West Germany, is a comparatively lively, good-humored film about a very sad subject - the breakdown of family relationships under the pressures of what's called progress. The film is the first feature to be directed by King Ampaw, a Ghana film maker trained in West Germany and Austria and now a director with the Ghana Broadcasting Corporation.

title: Marcia Bond Is Engaged To William James Boyle
description: Mary Marcia Bond and William James Boyle, graduates of Wake Forest University, plan to be married May 12. Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Bond of Greensboro, N.C., have announced their daughter's engagement to a son of Mrs. Michael Caponegro of Colts Neck, N.J., and the late John Vincent Boyle.

title: FILM DEPICTS LIFE IN 'BRASS VALLEY'
description: ON the surface, ''Brass Valley,'' a new documentary about the rise and fall of the Naugatuck Valley's once- booming brass mills, is the work of three Connecticut labor historians.

title: MISS TRAVERS SETS RIDGEFIELD CONCERT
description: MARY TRAVERS recalls the day last year when her 17-year-old daughter Alicia said with a note of surprise, ''You know, Mom, you're a social activist.''

THE LIVELY ARTS;
DRESSING ACTORS IS NOT ALL FRILLS
description: If Sigrid Insull has done her job

description: CHILDHOOD

title: HUNTING METAPHORS AND NAZIS
description: Norma Rosen's novels include ''Touching Evil'' and ''At the Center.'' INVISIBLE MENDING

title: CONNORS TOPS ARIAS IN 3-SET SEMIFINAL
description: Jimmy Connors fought off Jimmy Arias, 3-6, 6-3, 6-4, today in the semifinals of the $265,000 Paine Webber Classic tennis tournament.

title: KORCHNOI'S TIMING
description: Sometimes when you need it most you just don't have it, and when you could possibly do without it, you have a surfeit. That is the predicament Viktor Korchnoi has lately found himself in.

title: MICROWAVE STANDARDS ARE SOUGHT
description: THE General Assembly will soon consider a bill that says how much microwave radiation is too much, an issue concerning a number of Connecticut communities.

title: BLIND WOMAN IS A TOP SKIER
description: NEW LONDON BARBARA LEWIS was a child in Atlanta when doctors discovered that the retinas were not developing properly in her eyes. Today, she is legally blind, but her handicap has not held her back. Miss Lewis, a second-grade teacher at the Mary Morrisson elementary school in Groton, earned a bachelor's degree from Spellman College in Atlanta and a master's degree from the University of Pittsburgh.

title: EARLY MANIFESTATION A CLUE TO DISORDER
description: HADDONFIELD VICTIMS of autism are not mentally retarded or schizophrenic, nor is their condition a result of childbeating or parental neglect.

title: DANCE: PACIFIC NORTHWEST BALLET
description: It was pleasant to watch Pacific Northwest Ballet on Wednesday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, for its dancers have been carefully trained by its directors, Kent Stowell and Francia Russell. Yet this artistically growing company from Seattle does appear to be suffering from growing pains.

title: Baton Elbow
description: Zubin Mehta , who has conducted more concerts than you can shake a stick at, paid a price for it last week.

title: No Headline
description: ''NORWALK would probably win the Diverse City Award for the State of Connecticut - if there was one,'' said its three-term Mayor, William A. Collins. ''That makes it a really nice place to live for those of us who cherish diversity, but it also makes it difficult for Norwalk to develop a strong image.''

title: Personal and Political
description: To the Editor:

title: SOVIET ECONOMIC PLANNERS ARE MOVING INTO THE CLASSROOM
description: The Soviet press last week concluded one of the most freewheeling public debates ever held in the Soviet Union over a piece of proposed legislation. At issue is a thorough reorganization of the entire Soviet school system - almost 50 million students in 150,000 schools - with the goal of channeling many more youths into the labor force. The basic problem, noted for some time now, is that under the dictatorship of the proletariat, hardly anyone wants to be a proletarian.

title: Latin Debt
description: To the Editor:

title: IT'S POLITICS AS USUAL -- AT LONG LAST
description: For about six months after a spiritless Menachem Begin resigned as Prime Minister early in September, something of a political slumber descended on Israel.

title: A Home Team For Brooklyn
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
About Westchester ;
AN EAR TO THE STARS
description: THE pupils sit in a science classroom at Edgemont High School, their attention held by the teacher lecturing to them. Behind this soft-spoken, easygoing woman is a blackboard covered with equations, but she does not refer to it. She points, instead, to a list of symbols she has drawn on white paper, symbols as esoteric as hieroglyphics to those not familiar with them.

title: BruceFriedlichWeds
description: Bruce Friedlich, president of the New York advertising agency of Henderson Friedlich Graf & Doyle, was married yesterday to Karla Luddecke O'Sullivan. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Randy Lehman-Becker, a Unitarian minister, at the Shelter Island, N.Y., home of Waldo Kraemer, the bride's great- uncle.

title: COUNTY TO SPONSOR HEALTH WALKS
description: ON Saturday, just a week before the official fifth anniversary of the New York Walkers Club, its founder and president, Howard Jacobson, will lead a group of county residents on an inaugural health walk.

title: French Favored In Ocean Solo Race
description: Solo sailors representing 20 nations will cast off from Plymouth, England, on June 2 and race 3,000 miles to Newport, R.I., in the sixth Observer/ Europe 1 Single Handed Trans-Atlantic Race. The preliminary entry list released recently indicates that the 105-boat fleet will contain some of the most innovative yachts in unlimited racing, as well as some colorful competitors.

title:
Dining Out;
FRENCH ATMOSPHERE IN FORT LEE
description: -page advertisements in New York magazines and newspapers heralding ''a great French restaurant on the Rive Droite,'' and even rumors of a $3 million expenditure, the hype for Fort Lee's new extravaganza of a restaurant has been remarkable.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE LITTLE DRUMMER GIRL, by John le Carre. (Bantam, $3.95.) '' 'The Little Drummer Girl' is about spies as 'Madame Bovary' is about adultery,'' William F. Buckley Jr. said in his review of a ''mature, inventive and powerful book about terrorists-come-to-life'' that has an interesting, provocative moral focus. Central characters in this best seller include Charlie, a young English actress; Kurtz, an Israeli intelligence officer; Joseph, a veteran of the Israeli special forces; and a Palestinian known only by the distinctive bombs he builds, which are used to kill Jews. ADVENTURES IN THE SCREEN TRADE: A Personal View of Hollywood and Screenwriting, by William Goldman. (Warner, $9.95.) The novelist William Goldman, who dealt shrewdly and entertainingly with the Broadway theater in ''The Season'' in 1969, has become an experienced screenwriter who ''knows a thing or two about how the movie business operates, and he reveals plenty of it here,'' as Janet Maslin's review noted. This edition has been expanded to include the screenplay of ''Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid'' and Mr. Goldman's comments on its strengths and weaknesses.

title: SWALLOWS RETURN TO LAMBERTVILLE
description: LAMBERTVILLE ALTHOUGH their return each spring does not inspire the same flights of romantic fancy as does that of the birds at the San Juan Capistrano Mission in California, New Jersey's cliff swallows have begun arriving at their nesting sites in this Hunterdon County community.

title: POISED FOR THE PERSIAN GULF
description: Richard Halloran, a member of The Times's Washington bureau, covers military affairs. PROMPTLY AT 8:30 EVERY weekday morning, Lieut. Gen. Robert C. Kingston, commander in chief of the United States Central Command, strides into a briefing room at his headquarters at MacDill Air Force Base in Tampa, Fla., and asks his staff to be seated. An intelligence officer, standing at a lectern beside a large wall screen, flicks a switch to display a map of the region around the Persian Gulf. He runs quickly through the action of the previous 24 hours in the war between Iran and Iraq. Another flick brings up a satellite photograph of a new Iranian troop deployment. A chart provides fresh detail on the 115,000 Soviet troops in Afghanistan, or the 25 Soviet ships in the Indian Ocean, or Soviet advisers in Ethiopia. The context in each case: threats to the industrial world's largest source of oil.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The crisis moment has passed. We wanted to avert the crisis of government that would have acceeded in Argentina.

title: Q AND A
description: The Shadow of Eviction Question:

title: Antisatellite Weapons Study
description: President Reagan's proposal for an antisatellite weapons system has produced hot debate in Congress and among scientists. A White House report that will be delivered to Capitol Hill tomorrow - right on deadline Congress set last year - reflects months of bitter struggle within the Administration as well.

title: HOW TO CHOOSE A CD PLAYER
description: When the laser phonograph burst on the scene just a year ago, it was a technical showpiece, a musical revelotion, and a prestigious toy. But it was not really a consumer item in the sense of having broad market appeal. Only the most hard-bitten and well-heeled aficionados were willing and able to plunk down the $1,000 or thereabouts as the price of admission to the promised land of laser sound--especially since the musical repertory initially available on laser disks was woefully meager.

title: U.S. LOSES LEAD IN ATOM-POWER TECHNOLOGY
description: The United States has turned away from nuclear power so decisively that it has forsaken its global dominance of the technology, according to experts in this country and abroad.

title: LIGHT-OPERA LOVER
description: Carol Sternhell teaches journalism at New York University. AT THE BORDER

title: INDIAN POINT INQUIRY COMING TO AN END
description: PEOPLE with long memories think of last week as the fifth anniversary of the nuclear accident at Three Mile Island in Middletown, Pa. But the neighbors of Indian Point remember that event for another reason: it is the incident that prompted the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to begin an ''expedited'' evaluation of whether Westchester was too densely populated to be a site for a nuclear power plant.

title: HE'S NO MERE NAYSAYER
description: Sylviane Gold , a freelance critic, won the George Jean Nathan Award for dramatic criticism in 1982. THEATER CRITICISMS

title: CHURCHES BECOMING HOME TO CENTRAL AMERICAN EXILES
description: From California to Vermont, hundreds of normally law-abiding Americans are knowingly breaking the law. In churches, monasteries and synagogues, they are harboring illegal aliens who have fled the violence in Central America.

description: -- Secretary of State George Shultz has been complaining insistently about Congressional reins on the Administration's foreign policy.

description: Laura Sara Donnelly, a research a ss istant for NBC in Washington, and Adrian Clemens Taylor, an associate producer for National Public Radio, also in Washington, plan to be married in August.

description: A costly brand of imported eyeglass frames had become so popular here that young people whose sight needed no correction were wearing them anyway, often without lenses.

description: When it comes to environmental protection, Suffolk has been one of the most active counties in the country. So it was not out of character when the county last week became the first in New York to get tough on one type of air pollution - smoking.

description: Gail Warshofsky Lapidus, professor of Soviet politics at the University of California at Berkeley, is the author of ''Women in Soviet Society.'' She is currently working on a study of Soviet nationality policy. THE FACES OF CONTEMPORARY RUSSIAN NATIONALISM

title: CONGRESS ACCORDING TO BAKER
description: When I first entered the United States Senate in 1967, I was variously described as my father's son, as my father-in-law's son-in-law, and as a ''wealthy young lawyer.''

title: June S. Kuvin and Steven I. Volk to Marry in June
description: Dr. and Mrs. Seymour F. Kuvin of Livingston, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, June Saxe Kuvin, to Steven I. Volk, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Volk of Fort Lee, N.J., and Sarasota, Fla. The wedding is to be in June.

title: Gomez Takes Title on Points
description: Wilfredo Gomez of Puerto Rico won the World Boxing Council featherweight title tonight with a furious display of boxing skills that earned him a unanimous decision over Juan LaPorte of New York.

title: ENLIGHTENMENTS; Educator of the Spirit Less visible but just as important to the civil rights movement as any political operatives were the leaders who offered inspiration and education. Dr. Benjamin E. Mays, who died Wednesday at the age of 89, was one of the best of these. He was the child of South Carolina sharecroppers, and decided early that the life of the spirit and of the mind were complementary and suitable to his talents. Dr. Mays was ordained a Baptist minister and became dean of Howard University's School of Religion. As vice president of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ, he preached throughout the country. He struggled to integrate all-white colleges but also championed predominantly black schools like Morehouse College in Atlanta. There, for 27 years, he inspired a new generation. His most prominent student was Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., who referred to Dr. Mays as ''my spiritual mentor and my intellectual father.''
description: Teacher and preacher: It was a noble and powerful combination.

title: ; Don't Fund Women On Performance
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Halting the Exodus Of Teachers
description: It does not take a marriage counselor to realize that the divorce rate has been on the increase. Couples dissolve marriages for so many reasons it would be impossible to enumerate them all. Sharp divorce lawyers now advertise daily in newspapers. For little more than one month's rent, you can walk away from a marriage, contest a divorce, seek child custody or have all of the above, including a trip abroad if it all gets too difficult.

title: Mets Caught Napping
description: In the bottom of the fourth inning Friday night, in an exhibition game against the Minnesota Twins, the Mets were retired on two outs. That's right, two outs, not three.

title: THE PARIS OF AFRICA
description: MARYLIN BENDER writes on aviation and other business topics from New York.

description: People who must ask the price of the Cadillac Fleetwood Brougham probably can't afford one. People who don't need to ask may not care.

description: President Reagan's Commission on Strategic Forces has issued a report that is critical of the arms control approaches of both the Reagan Administration and its detractors.

title: E. B. Cohen Engaged To Miss Habousha
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Hayim V. Habousha of Forest Hills, Queens, of the engagement of their daughter Farha-Nadine Habousha to Edward B. Cohen, the son of Herbert S. Cohen of New York and the late Arline W. Cohen. The wedding is to take place July 8.

title: MAJOR NEWS IN SUMMARY ; U.S. and FranceLeave LebanonOn Its OwnThe American pullout from Lebanon became complete last week with President Reagan's announcement that the United States was ending its participation in the multinational force. The 2,000 marines who had been standing by on ships since evacuating Beirut in early February were due to leave Lebanese waters, along with the battle group supporting them, and resume normal operations in the Mediterranean.
description: The French, the only peacekeeping contingent left ashore, also pulled out virtually all of their troops. Despite Mr. Reagan's insistence that the United States was not abandoning Lebanon, the Lebanese were essentially on their own with little hope of finding a political solution to the interfactional fighting that was tearing the country apart.

title: COPING WITH HARDSHIPS ON THE WAY UP
description: MANY successful managers get used to being part of the action, making quick decisions, and guessing right as they accumulate a string of successes. Hardships are the other side of the coin. Simply put, hardships are mistakes, failures, and misfortunes. Nearly half of the top executives in our study recalled a significant hardship event that had contributed to their career development.

title: FROM ASSURED DESTRUCTION TO ASSURED SURVIVAL
description: -15- launched Miniature Vehicle ASAT (anti-satellite) and recent C.I.A. disclosures indicating that the Soviet Union is intensifying its missile defense efforts suggest that an era of superpower nuclear confrontation in space is quickly approaching. At least one scenario for such confrontation is especially worrisome. Both the U.S. and the U.S.S.R. are actively investigating use of space- based directed and hypervelocity kinetic energy weapons, the so-called ''Star Wars'' technology, to provide defense shields against exo-atmospheric weapons like ICBM's and SLBM's. President Reagan, in a March 23, 1983, speech, offered the hope that such a system could provide a purely defensive solution to the arms race and make the concept of mutual assured destruction obsolete. Critics contend that the design goal of 99.9 percent effectiveness is unrealistic, under crisis conditions, for so complex a system and that a significantly less effective shield, because of overkill, would have dubious value. They also claim that a wide range of comparatively inexpensive countermeasures would be available to thwart the system. Possession, by either side, of an impregnable exo-atmospheric shield could be viewed as a guarantor of either peace or war. Our concern lies elsewhere, however. One scheme for a space-based defense system would entail a minimum of 400 shuttle launches for deployment, and any system now being considered is likely to compare in expense with at least one leg of the existing U.S. nuclear triad. If deployed over a period of years, an exo-atmospheric shield would present an opponent nation with a highly vulnerable target.

title: ADMIRAL REPORTS MISSILE SHORTAGE
description: The Chief of Naval Operations, Adm. James D. Watkins, says his service has a critical shortage of missiles, torpedoes and other munitions and has assigned high priority to filling that gap in the 1986 military budget now being drawn up.

title: Joanne King Engaged To Andrew H. Gersten
description: Mr. and Mrs. Warren J. King of Winnetka, Ill., and Rancho Mirage, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter Joanne Wallace King to Andrew Harry Gersten, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Gersten of Amherst, Mass., formerly of Tenafly, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title: Frank J. Carr Jr., Barbara Cancro To Marry in July
description: Dr. and Mrs. Ralph Cancro of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Barbara Ellen Cancro to Frank J. Carr Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Carr of Greenwich, Conn. A July wedding is planned.

description: Debra Lynn Michalson, a daughter of Robert L. Michalson of New York and Claudia Michalson of Scarsdale, N.Y., plans to be married May 6 to Michael Norris.

title: Use of Mediation In Divorce Cited
description: The bleak picture for children of divorce, as presented in the article by Steve Margeotes (Opinion Page, Feb. 19), describes one type of experience as if it were and will be true for every child of divorce. His article is misleading, since it does not acknowledge that there are alternatives to the ''visitation ritual'' he describes.

title:
STAMPS;
FOR NATIONAL ARCHIVES
description: The 50th anniversary of the National Archives, the repository of the nation's cherished charters of freedom and many other official documents that trace the course of its history, is being marked by a new commemorative being issued April 16 in Washington, D.C. The institution is also a storehouse of the nation's past, including old maps and charts, photographs, motion picture films, sound recordings and tapes.

title: AQUEDCUT OPENS WITHOUT A STAKES
description: There was no Gotham Stakes at Aqueduct race track yesterday, thanks to the storms earlier this week that turned the track into a mud puddle and prompted nervous track officials to push the prestigious race back a week. But it was typical of Aqueduct's bad luck with the weather this year that the track had dried out to perfect condition by post time for the phantom Gotham, and the race could easily have gone off as planned.

title: CARVING OUT A HUMAN WASHINGTON
description: Noah James writes frequently about the performing arts.

title: No Headline
description: IF the ''stars of tomorrow'' have finally arrived, it is high time. The Mets have finished last or next to last for seven straight years, and even they concede that they are running out of promises.

description: To the Sports Editor:

description: THE FAT GIRL

title: TARZAN: BACK FROM OBLIVION
description: W ith the arrival of ''Greystoke: The Legend of Tarzan, Lord of the Apes,'' the fine new film by Hugh Hudson (''Chariots of Fire''), it's apparent that Edgar Rice Burroughs's fictional wild child is as resilient as he is resourceful, and that in one fashion and another he will probably outlive us all. Three years ago, after the release of John and Bo Derek's camp classic, ''Tarzan, the Ape Man,'' I thought the end had come.

title: REVEALING ISRAEL IN DANCE
description: JERUSALEM A fter 40 up-and-down years in the dance business, Yonatan Karmon is still true blue and white, and still exporting ensembles that embody a vibrant, optimistic Israel often overshadowed by the Lebanon war and 200 percent inflation.

title: Miss Hall Is the Bride Of John Charles Pope
description: Bonney Underwood Hall, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Tracy Hall of Huntington, L.I., was married yesterday to John Charles Pope, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. C. Pope of Nutley, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Melvin A. Hawthorne, director of chapel activities at the Church Center for the United Nations, performed the ceremony at the center.

title: HART ADVOCATES JOINT EFFORTS TO DRAFT STRICTER GUN LAWS
description: Senator Gary Hart called yesterday for ''reasonable people'' to try to negotiate Federal gun control legislation that would satisfy opponents and proponents.

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: The Italian violinist Uto Ughi is no typical debutant, even though he indeed made his New York recital debut Friday night at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Mr. Ughi is 39 years old, has concertized extensively in Europe and the United States, made several records and plays the 1701 ''Van Houten'' Stradivarius reputed to have been the property of Rodolphe Kreutzer, of Beethoven's ''Kreutzer'' Sonata fame.

description: A MASTER OF THE KEYS

title: IRAQI SHIITES INURED TO WAR'S DEATHS
description: So holy is this city to Shiite Moslems that Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini spent 14 years of his exile from Iran in a shabby house here, a few paces from the great golden dome and twin minarets of the shrine of Imam Ali.

description: Mr. and Mrs. John Oliver 3d of Canton, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Amy Oliver to Frederic Fuller Wesson, a son of Mrs. Rufus Wesson of Honeoye Falls, N.Y., and the late Mr. Wesson.

title: STATE TAKES OVER ENFORCEMENT OF ALL RENT CONTROL
description: At a minute after midnight tonight, the state will begin overseeing the regulation of nearly 1.2 million rent-controlled and rent-stabilized apartments, 90 percent of which are in New York City.

title: Domestic Trade Minister Dies in Crash in Poland
description: Zygmunt Lakomiec, Poland's Minister of Domestic Trade and Services, was killed today when his car collided with a gasoline truck in a blizzard, the official press agency P.A.P. reported.

VIEWS OF SPORT;
A FEW OF RAY MEYER'S FAVORITE THINGS
description: IREALIZE that DePaul's loss to Wake Forest in the Midwest Regional semifinals

title: STRATEGIES IN FINDING RENTALS
description: A rise in the number of elderly people in the New York metropolitan area is resulting in the creation of more subsidized rental apartments for them in many communities.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Some passages from current and recently published books that we find particularly appealing.

title: Tornado Relief Flows To the Carolinas
description: Americans and their Government joined today in efforts to help North and South Carolinians to recover from tornadoes that took more than 60 lives Wednesday night.

title: THE 'HOT' ITEMS REALLY ARE
description: HUNAN GARDEN is fast becoming a new industry, with branches in Greenwich, Westport, Stamford and now Norwalk. What makes this small group different from a chain is that there seems to be considerable autonomy from location to location, suggesting that the chef in each place contributes his own special style.

title: Poet's LaurelsIt is difficult to imagine anyone more deserving of immortality than a man who has successfully blended poetry and politics. Thus it was rather fitting that
description: Leopold S. Senghor was installed last week as a member of the French Academy. Mr. Senghor, whose writings have often brought him mention as a candidate for the Nobel Prize in Literature, was President of Senegal from its independence from France in 1960 until his retirement in 1981. The Academy's 40 life members, known as the immortals, are charged with defending French language and culture and work regularly on a definitive French dictionary. The 77-year-old Mr. Senghor, who writes in English and French as well as his native Serer, became the group's first black member in its 349-year history, replacing the late historian, Antoine de Levis Mirepoix.

title: Chicago Bowler Wins
description: Dale Eagle of Chicago, who won his first professional tournament nine years ago, gained his second today by defeating top-seeded Art Trask, 232-199, in the final of the $125,000 Fair Lanes Open.

title: Marcos Contends With a Ghost
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos kicked off his campaign to retain control of Parliament last week with a murdered opposition leader very much on his mind. An issue likely to be prominent in the May 14 legislative election is how and by whom Benigno S. Aquino Jr. was assassinated as he stepped off a plane last August after three years of self exile.

title: HUNGARIAN 'PRINCESS'
description: Pal Erdoss's ''Princess'' is an ironically titled film if ever there was one; its heroine is addressed as ''princess'' only once during the course of the story, and then by a weak-kneed, apologetic boyfriend who has failed to protect her from rape. Jutka (Erika Ozsda) is anything but the privileged creature of the title. A tough, lonely teen-age girl who has come to Budapest to work in a textile mill, Jutka becomes the focus of Mr. Erdoss's examination of courtship rituals, teen-age mores and motherhood.

OUTDOORS;
BY FOOT, SKI AND CANOE IN THE KAATERSKILL RUSH
description: THOSE driving through the

title: No Headline
description: The Yankees made club history today when they decided to add a ''kiddies' corps'' to their opening-day roster. Manager Yogi Berra said that two 18-year-old players born in the Dominican Republic, Jose Rijo and Stan Javier, would be on the 25-man roster.

title: 2 MOTHERS BEGIN SPINA BIFIDA GROUP
description: SPINA BIFIDA, a birth defect in which the vertebrae of the spine and spinal cord are improperly formed, occurs in about one of 1,000 births. Despite its prevalence, little information is readily available about the defect.

title: STAGE: 'FLIGHT OF EARLS,' ABOUT IRISH REBELLION
description: For the Earls of County Tyrone, violence is a family tradition. It can be traced back 400 years, and it is also a way of life (and death) in 1971 with the three adult Earl sons. They are allied in their hatred of the British and in their conviction that any means is justified in pursuing their desired end. In the case of Christopher Humble's ''Flight of the Earls,'' the objective is the assassination of the Irish Prime Minister.

title: RUNNING INTO A BLOCK OFF-ICE
description: Despite the four-time Stanley Cup champion Islanders' impressive win the previous night, the coach, Al Arbour, was putting his team through a seemingly relentless morning practice, as if to show his troops that it was time for them to switch into their annual playoff mode.

title: Cable TV
description: Some potent film fare is tucked away on cable this week - a whodunit by a top British author, a Roaring Twenties spoof from Australia and a rousing old Kipling adventure for the family. And all ages can savor two fine animal documentaries.

title: PARABLE FROM THE COFFIN
description: THE RELATION OF MY IMPRISONMENT

title: Phases of the Political Moon
description: America's attention span is now about nine days. If you doubt it, think back to Feb. 27, the day before the New Hampshire primary and recall how many phases the Democratic Presidential campaign has passed through in 34 days.

title:
Speaking Personally;
BENEATH MOTHER LOVE'S ROMANTICIZATION IS THE TRUE INSTINCT
description: VERY often, perhaps because of communication being so pervasive, we learn of other people's feelings; sometimes these revelations are very helpful because they reflect our own.

title: NETTLES APPROVES TRADE TO PADRES
description: Graig Nettles, who had been a Yankee as long as George Steinbrenner, gave his approval today to a trade to San Diego that was received with mixed feelings by his teammates. Dave Righetti, one of Nettles's closest friends on the team, took the trade the hardest, reacting bitterly to what he perceived as his involvement in the move.

title: HAIG CONTENDS U.S. FAILED IN LEBANON
description: Former Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. asserts that in 1982, the White House wrecked ''a breakthrough'' agreement for a simultaneous withdrawal of Palestine Liberation Organization, Syrian and Israeli forces from Lebanon.

title: Alice Celia Henry Becomes a Bride
description: Alice Celia Henry, a vice president and senior advertising copywriter at Ogilvy & Mather Inc. in New York, and Dr. Wayne Graham Whitmore, an ophthalmologist on the staffs of the New York Hospital and the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital, were married yesterday at the Tillman Chapel of the Church Center for the United Nations. The Rev. Karl W. Gillmeister of the Presbyterian Church of the Covenant in New York performed the ceremony.

title: DUARTE COULD WIN AT POLLS, LOSE A NATION
description: SAN SALVADOR O NCE again, Salvadorans trudged for miles over the country's dusty roads and stood bravely in line to vote last week. Despite the slow count, it was almost immediately apparent that none of the eight Presidential candidates would receive the needed majority. The electorate was faced with a straight choice between two sharply opposing political attitudes represented by Jose Napoleon Duarte, the Christian Democratic leader, and Roberto d'Aubuisson, head of the far right Nationalist Republican Alliance.

title: ARTIST SCULPTS A 'SOFT' CITY
description: HE works best when listening to the radio or watching his favorite soap opera. He compares his brain to a stove - ''Things are always cooking in front and simmering in back'' - and uses such words to describe himself as ''compulsive,'' ''slightly nuts,'' ''complicated'' and ''playful.''

title: PUT SCHOOLS ON THE ROAD
description: '' A NATION AT RISK'' is a best seller at the Government Printing Office. President Reagan and his Democratic opponents are using its conclusions for political fodder; the education community is restive.

title: Deborah Resnikoff to Wed
description: The engagement of Deborah Ann Resnikoff, a psychiatric social worker, to Dr. James W. Dimon, a psychiatrist, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Morris Resnikoff of Southbury, Conn., parents of the bride-to- be. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Watkins Dimon of Columbus, Ga. A June 24 wedding is planned.

title: OPERA: VERDI'S 'DON CARLO' AT THE MET
description: Opera is such a complex enterprise that it is a wonder anything ever goes quite right. But now and then, just often enough to keep faith alive, the pieces all fall into place and something remarkable and almost inexplicable happens. That was how it was Friday night at the Metropolitan Opera, where the season's first ''Don Carlo'' set off sparks and flares intermittently all evening and then burst into flames in the Grand Inquisitor scene, the dramatic and musical crux of this grandest of Verdi operas.

title: GERMAN VIEW OF SEXES
description: On a whim, the heroine of Doris D"orrie's ''Straight Through the Heart'' goes to an estate sale and tries to sweet-talk a man into selling her his refrigerator. On another whim, she dyes her hair bright blue. The unlikely upshot of these two minor occurrences is a proposition from the middle-age dentist who has been selling his late mother's possessions that she move in with him, on a basis that is nothing if not provocative and highly unusual.

title: Anne Yost Is the Bride Of Thomas Ryan Offer
description: Anne Patricia Yost, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred D. Yost of Whitestone, Queens, and Pompano Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Thomas Ryan Offer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard F. Offer of Lynbrook, L.I. The Rev. Patrick T. Sullivan performed the ceremony at Holy Family Roman Catholic Church in Flushing, Queens.

title: ISLANDERS CLINCH DIVISION TITLE
description: Mike Bossy and Billy Smith hugged each other at the final buzzer tonight as the Islanders skated off with first place in the Patrick Division, edging the Washington Capitals in a tense, tight game, 3-1.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS
description: There have been bell alarm clocks, buzzer alarm clocks and music alarm clocks. Enter now the scent alarm clock, which raises the slumberer to consciousness on a cloud of perfume.

title: NEW DIRECTORS/NEW FILMS;; A COMEDY ABOUT NEW JAPANESE MIDDLE CLASS
description: ''Everybody in my family is too much,'' says a voice on the sound track as, during the opening credits, we see the members of that family lined up, side by side, at the narrow, possibly imported Scandinavian dining table, noisily slurping their food and sticking elbows and arms into each other's faces. They are only four - father, mother, older brother and the hero-narrator, Shigeyuki, a misunderstood teen-ager - but they look like the figures in some dreadful, bourgeois parody of The Last Supper.

description: The State Legislature passed a new budget today that increases spending by more than $2 billion in a broad range of areas, including education, prisons and housing for the homeless.

description: Senate

description: The plan for an expressway to give commuters in southwest Nassau quick access to New York City's major highways is again inching toward completion - 38 years after it was first proposed.

title: AMERICAN LEAGUE 1984
description: The following American League preview was prepared and written by Murray Chass. The order of the teams reflects the predicted order of finish, with the Yankees picked for fifth in the East.

title: THE BIRTH OF LEW ARCHER
description: T. J. Binyon is a Fellow of Wadham College, Oxford. His first novel, ''Swan Song,'' will be published later this year. ROSS MACDONALD

title: SUN BELT IS FAVORED BY RULES ON FEDERAL MASS-TRANSIT AID
description: The Reagan Administration intends to provide aid to mass-transit facilities under criteria that favor growth areas of the West and South and assign little weight to the potential for urban development.

title: 'Boycott Generation' Keeps Swimming
description: As recently as a decade ago, American swimming was strictly for the young. Almost all the men retired from the sport after college, and many women quit after high school.

title: 3 Ski Patrolmen Killed in Avalanche
description: Three ski patrolmen died in an avalanche today after they tried to start a controlled snowslide in the Aspens Highlands ski area.

title: Kathleen J. Rohn Weds a Diplomat
description: Kathleen June Rohn, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fred H. Rohn of Madison, N.J., was married yesterday to Yvon Jean Pierre Le Dain, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Jacques Le Dain of Angers, France. The Rev. Andrew Smith performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Christ the King in New Vernon, N.J.

title: THE VERDICT ON JURIES
description: Irving R. Kaufman is a judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

title: THE PHILHARMONIC MARKS SOME MUSICAL BIRTHDAYS
description: T he 300th birthdays of J.S. Bach and George Frideric Handel both occur next season, as you no doubt have been already warned. So does the 100th birthday of Alban Berg. At first glance, this might seem the perfect windfall to ease the problems of music directors who must face the complex annual challenge of piecing together programs for their organization's seasons. The need to pay tribute to three such major figures, two of whom have left large, almost inexhaustible reservoirs of music to choose from, would seem to give any program planner a running start.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Two disparategroups recently evaluated the State University of New York at Stony Brook - the Middle States Association of Colleges and Schools and the Italian Parliamentary Committee on Public Instruction and Fine Arts.

title: Jane Greenwald Weds L. A. Wein
description: Jane Greenwald, a project director with Decisions Center Inc., a market research company in New York, and Lawrence A. Wein, an option arbitrage trader with Gruntal & Company, also in New York, were married last night at the Water Club in Manhattan. Rabbi Dennis Math, assisted by his wife, Cantor Ellen Math, performed the ceremony.

title: A COMEDY ABOUT NEW JAPANESE MIDDLE CLASS
description: ''Everybody in my family is too much,'' says a voice on the sound track as, during the opening credits, we see the members of that family lined up, side by side, at the narrow, possibly imported Scandinavian dining table, noisily slurping their food and sticking elbows and arms into each other's faces. They are only four - father, mother, older brother and the hero-narrator, Shigeyuki, a misunderstood teen-ager - but they look like the figures in some dreadful, bourgeois parody of The Last Supper.

title: FROM ECONOMIC THEORY TO HARVARD DON
description: ''Helen of Troy's face launched a thousand ships. Not many Ph.D.'s theses can be said to have launched even a hundred articles; but Michael Spence's certainly comes close.'' - Remarks by the American Economics Association in December 1981, when it selected Mr. Spence as the nation's outstanding economist under 40.

title: A GREEK TREASURE IN FRANCE
description: PAUL LEWIS is a correspondent in the Paris bureau of The Times.

title: THE HAIR CLIP
description: EVERY SPRING, HAIR stylists will attest, women get the urge to trim their tresses, a perfectly obvious reaction to the change of seasons. This year, however, the raising of the hair hemline promises to reach epidemic proportions.

title: Aid for Students Vs. Tax Breaks
description: Tax breaks and student loans have long been Government means to help Americans pay for college. The Reagan Administration's approach has been to try tightening eligibility requirements for student loans while supporting additional tax relief for families with college students. Partly as a result, during academic years 1980 through 1984 the inflation- adjusted value of student aid from all sources (mostly Federal) fell more than 20 percent.

title: A LIVELY NEST OF HERETICS
description: Pauline Maier teaches history at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and wrote ''The Old Revolutionaries: Political Lives in the Age of Samuel Adams.'' A GLIMPSE OF SION'S GLORY

title: Latins Help End Argentine Crisis
description: Latin American solidarity came to the rescue of debt-ridden Argentina last week, just in time to make the Saturday night deadline on interest payments due American banks. A $500 million short-term loan package was put together after frenzied negotiation; Mexico, Venezuela, Brazil and Colombia, big debtors themselves, will account for $300 million of it. Argentina dug into its reserves for $100 million and $100 million was contributed by an international banking consortium.

title: ;  Map Adds Data To 'Cow Neck' History
description: Mary Minturn's article, ''Streets Have Roots, Too'' (Opinion Page, March 18), was based upon some excellent and difficult research. However, she overlooked one important document, the Gate Rights Map of 1709, which shows the early property owners of the Port Washington Peninsula, once called Cow Neck.

title: Drunken Driving Term: Pay Widow for 30 Years
description: A doctor who admitted being drunk when he was involved in an automobile accident in which a man was killed must pay the widow $25,000 a year for 30 years and donate a pint of blood every two months for five years.

title: IT'S STILL A PENTAGON BUDGET
description: The new Reagan budget plan, which is supposed to help reduce the Federal deficit, has been portrayed by the Administration as a balanced mix of defense and domestic spending reductions. The balance, however, is hard to find.

title: Pull New York Out of Its Ruts
description: You can feel it everywhere and see it best along the East River F.D.R. Drive. For at least 15 winters, icicles have dangled from the underside of the Drive's lanes, a clear symptom of the decay of New York City's major roads and streets, of the appallingly slow response by those responsible for repair and of the unconcern of political leaders.

title: CORPORATE CUPOLA
description: Now under construction at 1 Elm Street in downtown Stamford, Conn. is a contemporary-style 10- story building to which the designers have added a distinctly traditional touch.

title: Food; SPRING ONIONS, GREEN SHOOTS INCLUDED, GET A STARRING ROLE
description: ANOTHER name for scallions is spring onions. This is because these are the first onions of the season, pulled from the ground with their long green shoots before the bulb end has developed beyond a delicate, immature knob. title: BASKETBALL'S SIXTH MAN

To me and thousands of others who marveled at McGuire's playmaking skills in the old Garden, at Eighth Avenue and 50th Street, Dick was the original sixth man. His ability to lead the fast break, with his dazzling pin- point passing, made him a truly outstanding sixth man who fitted Alex Ward's description as ''someone who can immediately have a major impact on a game.'' THOMAS J. FITZGERALD Malverne, N.Y.

title: 100 YEARS AFTER HIS DEATH, KARL MARX IS LIVELIER THAN MARXISM
description: -THREE, the centenary year of Karl Marx's death, is over. The faithful gathered, universities held seminars and the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization arranged a December round table in Paris. Books poured off the presses but excited no one. Yet the faithful, one would have thought, had much on their side. When the greatest thinker in the history of socialism (the competition is not very great, but Marx was) died in London in March 1883, 11 people attended his funeral. Today, half the population of the world is led or governed in his name. In the first months of 1983, the world was still in recession. The international financial system was under severe strain; what Marx called ''the reserve army of the unemployed'' had grown to 30 million in Western developed countries. ''Bourgeois'' civilization and the power of private property were under attack internally and externally - if not by the working classes, then by teachers, minorities, women, environmentalists, pacifists, former colonial subjects and the poor everywhere. Conservative reaction there may be, at least at the ideological level - but bourgeois civilization, the world of self-confident liberal individualism, is dying, if not dead. We stand on the threshold of a new era which is not that envisioned by Marx and which has found no student or forecaster of Marx's stature.

title: ETHNIC DIVISIONS SURFACE IN THE CAMPAIGN
description: It has been a long time since ethnic, racial and religious divisions have been so pronounced in a Presidential campaign. As the contest to select a Democratic opponent to President Reagan passes its halfway mark, the forces bringing the conflicts to the surface seem far from spent.

title: THE WORDS AND MUSIC OF STEPHEN SONDHEIM
description: ON THE WALL OF STEPHEN Sondheim's study, amid the classical records and linguistic journals, there is a photograph of a man looking at a painting. The man is Sondheim and the painting is ''Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grand Jatte'' by Georges Seurat. The photograph captures Sondheim during the rare public moment of a creative process that usually transpires in the privacy of his study, in the ultimate privacy of his mind. Sondheim is staring into Seurat's world - just as Seurat, brushes in hand, once stared at the Parisians in the park on the Grande Jatte - in order somehow to convey that world, to tramsute it into words and music. The terminus of those efforts is ''Sunday in the Park With George,'' the Sondheim-James Lapine musical that opens April 23 at the Booth Theater. In a subliminal way, the show may be the closest Sondheim has ever come to an autobiographical work, because it turns on the idea of imagination, of creativity itself.

title: STANDING HIS GROUND
description: I HAVE BRUISED A KNUCKLE AND bloodied another man's nose, but I am not, by most measures, a fighter. The last time I broke the peace was more than a decade ago in a small restaurant on the west slope of the Rocky Mountains in Colorado. My stepfather had encountered an old nemesis. Words were exchanged and the distance between the two narrowed. I stepped in to play the peacemaker and ended up throwing the first punch. For the record, my target, a towering 230-pound horseman, easily absorbed the blow and then dispatched the gnat in front of him.

title: VERBATIM: ON TIMES SQUARE Conflicting opinions as hearings began last week on the plan by New York City and New York State to rebuild Times Square: ''I do strongly feel that of all the things that have taken place since I became involved in these issues 25 years ago, this is the worst that has ever emerged. The office towers would be great, gray ghosts of buildings, shutting out the sun and turning Times Square into the bottom of a well. I think it will mean the destruction of Times Square as we know it. It's just going to gut the life out of Times Square, and we will never see it again.'' Brendan Gill,
description: Chairman of the New York Landmarks Conservancy ''Some will be concerned about traffic, sky-exposure planes, bulk, pedestrian flow, architectural or configural esthetics, sincerely concerned. I submit that these considerations are minor when compared to the human need, indeed, the human right to be free from the crime, the depravity, the corruption, the pain and the fear which are rooted on 42d Street and from there, extend their polluted tentacles to the adjoining streets, to the residents, the tourists, the workers, the theater patrons who use them.'' title: No Headline
description: SAMUEL SLATER was a sneak. title: WHAT HAPPENS WHEN A PUBLIC UTILITY GOES BANKRUPT?
description: For the first time in recent memory, the lights could go out on a major American utility. The Long Island Lighting Company, struggling to complete its $4.1 billion Shoreham nuclear power plant, has taken extraordinary actions in recent weeks to avoid bankruptcy. Lilco replaced its board chairman; the new chairman, Dr. William J. Catacosinos, then laid off almost 20 percent of the company's employees and canceled common stock dividends.Even so, Dr. Catacosinos said, the utility faces a $100 million cash shortfall this year. Shut out of conventional financial markets, Lilco could run out of money soon, he said. ''The truth is that we are in trouble and it's serious,'' the new chairman said in an appeal for special aid from Albany.

ELECTRIC UTILITIES: A SHAKY NEW WORLD
description: ONCE the bedrock of the small investor's portfolio, some electric utility stocks have recently taken on the consistency of quicksand. Current wisdom on Wall Street is that the electric utility sector contains a few highly risky investments, primarily because of costly nuclear power construction projects. In fact, for the first time since the 1930's, experts and investors alike are beginning to wonder if even sacrosanct preferred dividends of some utility stocks may be shaky.

title: Plane Delays
description: To the Editor: Not all the pitfalls of plane travel are connected with charters (Practical Traveler, Feb. 12 and 19). On Dec. 26, my wife, daughter and I were scheduled for a direct flight on Avianca from Kennedy International to Cartagena, Colombia. Scheduled time: three hours and 55 minutes. Scheduled departure: 10 A.M. We arrived in Cartagena at 1:30 A.M. on Dec. 27. As if that wasn't bad enough, the return flight was worse: a two-and-a-half-hour bus ride to a neighboring city to a plane that couldn't take off in Cartagena. The flight was overbooked by 12 people - all standing in the plane with boarding passes and refusing to get off - until armed police arrived. Result: a 10 A.M. Colombian departure getting us through customs at 1:45 the next morning.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINIONS;
A TEACHER FINDS HEART OF TEACHING
description: SEVERAL years ago a student came to my office for some help with statistics. It was a bad day, and I found myself becoming annoyed at her apparent ignorance of elementary arithmetic operations, procedures I felt she should have learned in high school. Finally, I was no longer able to contain my irritation, and I blurted out the accusation that she should already know the material. At that moment, she looked at me and in a tone of pure objectivity, said, ''Dr. Lawry, I really don't think your remark is very helpful.''

title: SWEET CHARLOTTE
description: RECENTLY, WE were asked if we could pinpoint the origin of the dessert known as a charlotte. I turned to that ''bible'' of classic French cooking, ''Dictionnaire de l'Academie des Gastronomes,'' a double volume first printed in Paris 21 years ago.

title: EGYPT
description: To the Editor: Judith Miller's interesting article gives the classical name for Cairo, el Qahira. Travelers, however, seeking the Cairo road in, say, Alexandria, would have better luck if they used the colloquial name, Masr (or Misr).

title: CO-OP FOR CON ED
description: Over the past few years a large body of laws has been passed to protect the rights of tenants when rental buildings are converted into cooperatives or condominiums. Now those laws have come to the aid of one of the city's largest corporations in its effort to buy the apartment it has leased since 1970 at 10 West 66th Street for corporate directors and guests.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: -SCHOOL officials in Newark have developed for teachers a curriculum guide for a subject that has long been taboo: incest. The 57-page guide is a result of almost two years of work by a multidisciplinary Committee on Child Abuse and Incest.

title: No Headline
description: Laurie Schulte Betrothed

title: A New Meadowlark
description: Meadowlark Lemon, who for 24 years delighted basketball fans as a member of the Harlem Globetrotters, totes a Bible nowadays while touring with his own team, the Bucketeers. ''I could never imagine myself walking around with a Bible under my arm and tracts in my pocket, speaking to people about God,'' Lemon said in Omaha, Neb.

title: LOSERS TO CHALLENGE OTTINGER AIDE IN THE PRIMARY
description: THE political drama that has been presented to Democratic leaders in the 20th Congressional District for the last three months will go on the road this spring and summer, it became evident last week, with candidates seeking to replace Representative Richard L. Ottinger reaching for bigger audiences.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CARIBBEAN CARNIVALS, ENGLISH COUNTRYSIDE
description: Season to Revel Drawing Near In St. Martin In the annals of royalty, the reign of King Moumou is brief. Each year he appears - figuratively, anyway - as the master of the revels that go by the name Carnival on half- Dutch, half-French Caribbean island that is St. Martin, On the 37-square-mile island, Carnival means music from steel bands, the high-spirited parades known as jump-ups, costumed revelry, the aroma of chicken and pork and goat roasting over open fires, and games of chance.

title: Teamwork Spurs Tennessee Women
description: After Tennessee lost to Alabama, 85-66, in the Southeastern Conference women's basketball tournament March 3, Coach Pat Head Summitt's assistant at Tennessee met with the team.

title: Evacuation Is Begun From Cruise Ship on Bar
description: Hundreds of passengers who were evacuated from a cruise liner that ran aground off Grand Cayman Island began arriving in Miami today after more than two days of rescue efforts failed to budge the ship.

title: Korean Keeps Title
description: Chang Chong Koo of South Korea retained the World Boxing Council light-flyweight title with a unanimous 12-round decision over Sot Chitalada of Thailand tonight.

title: A WAR STORY TOLD IN OIL
description: TODAY'S method of news coverage of faraway battles had its beginning in World War II, when press photographers advanced alongside troops, photographed the action, then dispatched the negatives by the first available airplane or ship.

title: EX-COLONY TOWN BALKS AT CELEBRATION
description: THE division of the original Saybrook Colony in the 17th century was a ''loving parting,'' documents of the time state.

title: PUBLIC BUDGET MAKING HAS PERSONAL ASPECTS
description: In the grandest sense, it was said to be a ''legislative budget'' - one written by the lawmakers themselves and imposed on the Governor.

description: CELEBRATING SPRING

title: BABY BOOMERS
description: It was inevitable that the baby-boom generation of the 1950's would eventually come to power in America, and it did. Life was bound to be different when they took over, but I was ready to adjust. ''Youth must be served,'' they say. I was prepared to serve it cravenly.

title: EARLY INSTRUMENTS HAVE A CHANCE TO WEAVE THEIR SPELL
description: Edward Schneider writes frequently about recorded music.

description: IN a major critique of the City Planning Commission's proposals for rezoning the Upper

title: Never Call Retreat
description: William Safire's article ''Never Call Retreat'' (On Language, Feb. 26) tells much about the games people play to preserve their image.

title: Liverpool Regains Lead By Defeating Watford
description: John Wark, Liverpool's new midfielder, scored in his debut today as the defending English League soccer champions won, 2-0, at Watford and went back to the top of the First Division standing.

title: PICTURES THAT POKE FUN AT POWER
description: W alking into Barbara Kruger's show at Annina Nosei Gallery is like walking into a lecture 10 minutes late: you immediately feel engulfed by reprobation. The photographs - montages, really, with words built into them - chasten you with an imperious voice. ''You are giving us the evil eye,'' they say, ''Your money talks,'' ''You are the cost of living.'' With these didactic, remonstrative messages come images culled from the past, their half-tone dots enlarged to the size of thumbnails. Behind the blocked-in type that says ''Your money talks,'' a man leaps from an exploding house. In a vertically disposed triptych with the words ''Money can't buy me,'' the visage of a youthful J. Edgar Hoover shares space with an outsized revolver.

title: YOUNG, UNLIKELY MILLIONAIRE, PUTS 'MADNESS' BEHIND HIM
description: MANHATTAN BEACH, Calif.

title: HEADLINERS
description: Jersey Bounce Even by New Jersey standards, the political demise of former Atlantic City Mayor Michael J. Matthews has been remarkably thorough. Last week, less than a month after he was turned out of office in a recall election, Mr. Matthews was indicted on charges that he attempted to extort $668,000 from two businesses that were actually undercover operations set up by the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Mr. Matthews, who served 21 months of his four-year term as Mayor, was also charged with accepting payoffs from organized crime figures.

description: The commander of the Honduran armed forces, an officer regarded as one of Washington's staunchest allies in Central America, resigned today and left the country, Honduras announced.

title: ZOO SEEKS HELP IN BREEDING EAGLES
description: WEST ORANGE A PANEL of eagle experts will meet at the Turtle Back Zoo here Wednesday to evaluate the zoo's plans to breed eagles in captivity and have the offspring released into the wild.

title: VIRGINIA FALLS IN 49-47 DUEL
description: The Houston Cougars had waited a year to show that the nightmare they experienced in Albuquerque last season had been nothing but a bad dream. Today the Cougars overcame their mistakes and stopped Virginia's surprising comeback to earn another chance at the national championship.
