description: Ray Meyer was accepting the trophy in Seattle for having been selected basketball coach of the year by The Associated Press when he looked across the dais at Michael Jordan, the player of the year. ''Michael,'' Meyer said wistfully, ''there is only one thing you did wrong.

title: TOP U.S. RIGHTS AIDE ACCUSES PRESS OF DISTORTION
description: The Reagan Administration's chief human rights spokesman has asserted that the public gets a distorted view of rights violations around the world because news organizations report abuses in nations that the United States supports and ignore those in countries it opposes.

title: CRITICS QUESTION EXPERIENCE OF REAGAN'S CHOICE FOR JUDGESHIP
description: J. Harvie Wilkinson 3d, President Reagan's choice to fill a Federal appellate court vacancy in Virginia, is in many ways an unorthodox candidate for the bench.

title: On Developing Poxabogue Pond
description: Michael Held of Oyster Bay (Letters to the Editor, Feb. 5) does not seem to understand the strength and breadth of the opposition to his proposed placement of 18 houses on 37 acres at fragile Poxabogue Pond. He writes as though Henrik Krogius and Eugene Burnikel were his main critics and their scenic views across the pond the main issue.

title: A VIETNAM WAR BOARD GAME CREATED BY PRINCETON SENIOR
description: Late last spring, when Nicholas Karp had to submit a topic for his senior thesis at Princeton, he told the classics department he would like to design a board game simulating the Roman war of 49 B.C. between Julius Caesar and Pompey the Great.

title: LOS ANGELES PRESSING INQUIRY INTO SEXUAL ABUSE OF CHILDREN
description: To the children at the Virginia McMartin Preschool, it was ''The Hollywood Game'' or ''Naked Movie Star.''

title: Bankruptcy Law Extended
description: President Reagan signed a 30-day extension of the nation's bankruptcy law today to prevent Federal bankruptcy courts from going out of business at the end of the day. Under the measure approved by Congress Friday, Federal bankruptcy courts will remain in operation until midnight April 30 while the Senate and House work on permanent legislation.

title:
Art;
PHOTOGRAPHER RECALLS MARTHA GRAHAM YEARS
description: '' WHEN I first met Martha Graham, nearly 50 years ago, she was charming, intense and thoughtful; she did not boast or show off,'' recalled Barbara Morgan, who added, ''Martha has never changed.''

title: ENLIGHTENMENTS; Greek Tables Turned
description: Though it pretends to independence, Greece's largest newspaper, Ethnos, is actually an ''agent of influence'' of the Soviet Union, according to Paul Anastasiades, a part-time correspondent of The New York Times. When his book documenting his case appeared, Ethnos brought criminal libel charges against him.

title: DO MOVIES PREDICT THE PUBLIC MOOD?
description: W hen the laser phonograph burst on the scene just a year ago, it was a technical showpiece, a musical revelation, and a prestigious toy. But it was not really a consumer item in the sense of having broad market appeal. Only the most hard-bitten and well-heeled aficionados were willing and able to plunk down the $1,000 or thereabouts as the price of admission to the promised land of laser sound - especially since the musical repertory initially available on laser disks was woefully meager.

title: PROTEAN AND SURREAL

title: MEXICO SEEKS CLOSER TIES AMONG LATIN NATIONS
description: Mexico is promoting tighter policy coordination between key Latin American governments, apparently in the hope of putting pressure on Washington to adopt more flexible policies toward the Central American conflict and Latin America's economic crisis.

title: HELP FOR BIZARRE EATING PATTERNS
description: '' When I came back from diet camp, my friend said, 'You look so great.' I said, 'I'm having trouble keeping it off.' She told me, 'Throw up.' That was the first time I heard of it.''

title: ADMISSION TO COLLEGE: THAT EXTRA EDGE
description: ''This entire business of college admissions has become absurd,'' I said to my husband. ''Imagine, some parents are actually hiring tutors to help their children prepare for the achievement tests.''

title: 300 FRENCH TROOPS LEAVE LEBANON, CLOSING OUT THE MULTINATIONAL FORCE
description: Three-hundred French soldiers, the last members of the multinational force, left Lebanon today.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEW
description: When Howard University, a predominantly black institution, dismissed Antonio Planells, a white teacher of Spanish, he sued the school in Federal District Court in Washington, charging racial discrimination.

title: Miss McCormick Planning to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Ann McCormick of Glen Rock, N.J., of the engagement of her daughter Sheila Marie McCormick to Neil William Culligan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Culligan of Franklin Lakes, N.J.

title: A FRESH LOOK AT THE OTHER HAYDN
description: Paul Turok writes frequently about recordings. BY PAUL TUROK T o his 18th-century contemporaries, Michael Haydn must have seemed fortunate indeed. Rescued at the age of 7 from the respectable obscurity of his origins in a border village on the Austro-Hungarian frontier by evincing enough recognizable talent to gain him a place at the choir school of Vienna's St. Stephen's Cathedral, he had exemplary success as a student and young performer; upon completing his studies he immediately obtained an honorable professional post (thus avoiding the years of penurious freelancing in Vienna that his elder brother was then enduring), which eventually led to his employment as purveyor of symphonies, masses and other musical entertainments to the Archepiscopal Court of Salzburg, a highly important provincial capital.

title: DEMOCRATS SEE L.I. AS AS KEY IN PRIMARY VOTE
description: Long Island and othersuburban Democrats could be the ''swing'' vote in the Democratic Presidential primary next Tuesday. The primary is critical in a potentially protracted contest for the nomination.

description: IT'S the tone that makes the music and it's the tag

title: Marion P. Mundy To Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. William G. Mundy of Weston, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter Marion Perry Mundy to Bradford Cooke, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George B. Cooke of Babylon, L.I. The wedding is planned for June 30.

title:
Gardening ;
HOW TO CULTIVATE FRUIT TREES
description: PRODUCING one's own food has become more popular of late than at any time since the days of the World War II victory gardens. While this interest has been more evident in vegetable gardening, fruit plantings have also increased in popularity. This trend has been enhanced by the increased availability of dwarf fruit trees in sizes compitable with today's smaller properties.

title: IS MAMET THE BARD OF MODERN IMMORTALITY?
description: A t last it has happened. Seven long months into the Broadway season, an American playwright has ventured out of the doll's house, toy box, or wherever his contemporaries are mostly to be found snugly sequestered, into the big, bad world where deals are struck, money is made and men are ruined. Not only that, he has brought to his tale of dog- eat-dog the bite it needs and deserves. ''Glengarry Glen Ross'' is the harshest, meanest work David Mamet has yet produced: a scabrous, seamy, charmless, funny, brilliant and unmissable play.

title: TUCKED AWAY, YET ANOTHER SISTINE CHAPEL
description: LOUIS INTURRISI teaches English at the University of Rome. Michelangelo's Sistine Chapel is not the only chapel in the Vatican museums in which one of the Sixtus (Sistine) Popes has left a mark on history. The other Sistine chapel may be named after Nicholas V, who made it his private chapel, but the Pope depicted in the frescoes covering the walls is Sixtus II, even if, out of deference to its owner, he was made to look more like Nicholas V than himself. The surprising thing about this chapel, which was decorated with exquisite intelligence by Fra Angelico in 1447, is that it is, more often than not, empty of admirers, even on weekends when there is usually a standing-room-only crowd in the other Florentine artist's more widely known chapel on the floor below.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: DETECTIVE Richard Pelliccio of Tarrytown wants to play tag with the children of his village - but he says it is not a game.

title: LUIGI BARZINI, ITALIAN AUTHOR, DIES AT 75 IN ROME
description: Luigi Barzini, the Italian author and journalist, died Friday of cancer at his home in Rome, his family announced today. He was 75 years old.

description: The Knicks got some inspiration tonight from their captain, Bernard King. But they did not get a victory.

description: KAY ELDREDGE is a writer who lives in New York.

description: John D. Ward, director of the Colorado Division of Mines, is being recommended to the President for nomination as director of the Interior Department's Office of Surface Mining, Interior Secretary William P. Clark said Friday. Mr. Ward, who holds degrees in mining engineering and law, would succeed James R. Harris, who has resigned.

description: MONTCLAIR A CONTINUING No"el Coward renaissance is routinely served by Stuart Howard's staging of ''Blithe Spirit,'' which ends a lusterless season at the Whole Theater.

title: PRAGUE PLODS ON WITH MEMORIES OF '68
description: In Czechoslovakia's lovely capital, people listen to Western radio stations and catch West German television when possible. When they compare their gently slipping living standards with neighbors', the people of Prague measure themselves against chic Vienna or Frankfurt, not flashy Budapest or dowdy East Berlin. They think of themselves as Central Europeans, not Eastern Europeans.

description: trimmed house converted into a shop on a business street in Lambertville hardly seems the setting for ''a final desperate act.''

title: NEW CAMERAS OFFER GREATER EXPOSURE CONTROL
description: Several camera manufacturers have recently introduced a new generation of ''user friendly'' models that offer more complete control and greater exposure accuracy than has ever been available before. In the past, for example, most cameras offered a choice of only two operating modes - either automatic or manual exposure control - but some of the newest models offer as many as four different operating modes.

title: ART IMITATES LIFE
description: New York City's rental-apartment squeeze is no laughing matter to those in a desperate search for a place to live, but media-arts students at the School of Visual Arts have, as a study assignment, taken a humorous look at the problem of finding a home in the city. Their wry comments on the situation, in the form of posters and paintings, go on display this Thursday at the Master Eagle Gallery in Manhattan.

description: I

description: While it is important to have a good sixth man, a quality N.B.A. team must have greater overall depth (a second unit) to win consistently and have something left for the playoffs (''Basketball's Elite Corps: The Sixth Man,'' by Alex Ward, March 4). A more appropriate title for an article discussing unheralded reserves might have been ''The Second Unit.''

title: ACID RAIN STUDIES LAPSE IN CANADA
description: At a time when the Canadian Government has been sharply critical of what it regards as United States inaction on curbing acid rain, it appears to be letting several major research efforts of its own lapse.

title: THE REGION ; Denying an Edge To Criminals
description: After technology made bulletproof vests more comfortable and effective, the New York City Police Department made sure that every member of its force had one. As the police quickly found out, however, the vests also suited criminals.

title: TRIAL OPENS IN FORT DIX MEDICAL FRAUD
description: CAMDEN ABRAHAM V. K. ASANTE went on trial here last week on charges of being an ''imposter'' who caused permanent brain damage to a patient at the Fort Dix hospital by posing as a licensed anesthesiologist.

title: SWALE WINS FLORIDA DERBY
description: Swale, coming back from a disappointing third-place finish in the Fountain of Youth Stakes two weeks ago, took the lead on the second turn today and then held off Dr. Carter, the favorite, by three-quarters of a length to win the $300,000 Florida Derby at Gulfstream Park.

description: Since it was founded in 1936 as the Steel Workers Organizing Committee, the United Steelworkers of America has had just four presidents: Philip Murray, David McDonald, I.W. Abel, and Lloyd McBride.

description: Most seasoned travelers know, and all unseasoned travelers suspect, that when it comes to choosing hotels or motels there are unwritten rules.

description: Newspaper Guild picket lines appeared at The New York Post yesterday as 400 editorial, advertising and accounting employees struck the paper in a dispute over a management effort to cut the costs of a three-year contract extension.

This trend has been enhanced by the increased availability of dwarf fruit trees in sizes compitable with today's smaller properties.

title: STATE TECHNOLOGY GRANTS HALFWAY THERE
description: TRENTON THE Governor's Commission on Science and Technology passed the halfway mark last month in its program to dispense more than $4.2 million in equipment grants to emerging centers for academic and industrial research.

title: Ovett Is Beaten Again In the 1,500 by Hillardt
description: Steve Ovett of Britain, the world-record holder, lost his third straight race at 1,500 meters today when Michael Hillardt beat him to the tape by 2 meters at the Australian championships.

title: ACTRESSES OF SPECIAL GRACE
description: W hat do you mean when you say that an actress graces a part? I suppose you mean, on the most obvious level, that she seems easy, relaxed, unpushy in the role. When she moves, she seems to move effortlessly; in repose, she is pleasantly poised; speaking, she makes her points deftly but when she is done she leaves an unexpected trace of music in the air. Many actresses can do such things wondrously, stroking the scenes in which they appear as though there were so many Persian cats. It's scarcely surprising that bewitched audiences should purr.

title: 1,000 Tanzania Animals Die
description: Nearly 1,000 animals, including elephants, buffaloes and rhinoceroses, have died of anthrax in Lake Manyara National Park in Tanzania over the last 10 days, the official Daily News said today.

title: ARGENTINA FACES ANOTHER DEADLINE
description: Argentina teetered on the brink. A last-minute loan for $500 million, put together by United States officials, appeared imminent late Friday to save Argentina from becoming the first nation since the eruption of the foreign debt crisis to have its loans declared nonperforming. The emergency loan would allow Argentina to pay some of the $650 million in interest that must be paid by this weekend if United States banks are to avoid a sharp reduction in first-quarter earnings. In the talks leading up to the loan agreement on Friday, Argentina's blunt-talking Economics Minister, Bernardo Grinspun, said the banks' accounting problems were not his concern. His nation, now $47 billion in debt, has an estimated $1 billion in reserve, but Mr. Grinspun wants to use the funds at home, and put off payments on the nation's foreign debt until later in the spring, at the earliest. The Bank of Boston said that if it had to declare its $100 million in loans to Argentina as nonperforming, its first-quarter earnings would suffer ''substantially.''

title: MORE UNCOMMITTED
description: Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale showed surprising strength in Democratic caucuses in Kentucky today, a result that may spoil Gov. Martha Layne Collins's hopes of leading a largely uncommitted delegation to the Presidential nominating convention.

title: Bulgarians Link U.S. To Angola Rebel Raid
description: Bulgaria said today that the United States and South Africa were linked to a rebel raid in southern Angola last week, when Bulgarian and Portuguese citizens were taken hostage.

title: DEVELOPING OFFICE SPACE NOW COSTS $ 250 A SQ. FT.
description: COMMERCIAL office construction costs continue to be extraordinarily high in New York City. Land is expensive, the logistics are difficult and municipal regulations often place burdensome constraints on developers and contractors.

title: FLUSHING REHABILITATION RAISES COST PASS-ALONG ISSUEz
description: ON high ground above the Van Wyck Expressway in Flushing, Queens, a garden-apartment community called Hyde Park Gardens sprawls across 32 acres of landscaped ground.

title: Dance
description: Is it dance? athletics? ritual combat? All three combine when Elizabeth Streb dances, as she will Thursday through Sunday at the White Dog Performance Studio in SoHo. The names of the dances alone - ''Runway,'' ''Target,'' ''Whiplash,'' ''Marathon Dance'' and ''Backboard'' - suggest their distinctive mix.

title: ART: SHOW OF 'AMERICAN PAINTING 1760-1910' IS BATHED IN PARISIAN LIGHT AT GRAND PALAIS
description: Few things in the official history of American art have been more eagerly awaited than the arrival at the Grand Palais in Paris of the exhibition known as ''A New World: Masterpieces of American Painting 1760-1910.'' First at the Boston Museum of Fine Arts, where Theodore E. Stebbins Jr. was in charge of its organization, and later at the Corcoran Gallery in Washington, it was an outstanding success on two quite different counts.

title: HOW AN UNEASY ALLIANCE HELPS SHAPE BROADWAY
description: O ne day last May, Sam Cohn invited Bernard Jacobs to lunch. It was the first time that the talent agent and the president of the Shubert Organization - two of the most powerful men on Broadway - had spoken in months. Mr. Jacobs accepted the invitation on one stipulation: They would not dine at either the Russian Tea Room, which is Mr. Cohn's turf, or Sardi's, which is his. They compromised on Joe Allen's.

title: Faulkner Poems Enjoy a Little Later Success
description: William Faulkner won the 1949 Nobel Prize in Literature and has long been recognized as a giant among American authors of fiction, but he himself admitted that his abilities as a poet were more modest by far. In 1923, refusing to subsidize the printing of his love poems, he told a publisher, ''I see they aren't particularly significant and one may obtain no end of poor verse at a dollar and twenty-five cents a volume.''

title: CRIME
description: The trouble with mysteries featuring priests or nuns is that the central characters have God on their side. Which means that the outcome can be predicted in advance. Nuns especially have to be infallible; who ever encountered a nun in fiction who was not working with divine guidance? Authors, knowing these facts, wiggle desperately to get out of the dilemma. Very few have succeeded, not even G. K. Chesterton, whose Father Brown sees through everything with a superiority so humble it is infuriating.

title: GROUP BIDS CHANGE IN MARRIAGE LAW
description: -BASED group organized to inform women about their legal rights is seeking support to amend a provision of the state's matrimonial law that it says has created significant problems for women.

title: Weinberger Confers With Military in Greece
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger, concerned with longstanding problems in Greek-NATO relations and the status of American military bases in Greece, met with senior Greek military officials today.

title: Decorations All Around
description: It wasn't exactly hell in the trenches of Ft. Bragg, N.C., and along the bleak corridors of the Pentagon during the Grenada invasion last year.

title: GEORGETOWN, WITH RALLY, AND HOUSTON GAIN FINAL
description: Sometimes, their best quality is lost in the controversy that surrounds them and gives the impression that the Georgetown Hoyas win simply by huffing and puffing and bullying their opponents. But the Hoyas are more than bluster, as they proved again today. They are relentless, especially on defense, a part of the game that is an afterthought for some teams but is Georgetown's life-support system.

title: SMYSLOV LOSES TO KASPAROV IN 9TH GAME OF CHESS MATCH
description: Gary Kasparov of the Soviet Union surged to a three-point lead in the final candidates chess match with his countryman Vasily Smyslov by winning the ninth game yesterday. The score is now Kasparov 6, Smyslov 3.

title: A CONDOMINIUM COLONY WITH A RURAL TOUCH
description: An 82-acre piece of property in northeastern Westchester County that once served as a working farm is the site of a condominium community now under construction.

title: President Takes Credit For Women's Job Gains
description: President Reagan said today that job opportunities for women ''are popping up like springtime tulips'' because of the economic expansion his policies have created.

title: SQUATTERS ARE TOLD TO LEAVE RAMSHACKLE JERSEY BOAT CLUB
description: A Superior Court judge has ordered the squatters who built a marina of shanties, docks and a boardwalk on a state- owned waterfront site here to leave by May 15.

This essay is from ''The Phenomenon of Change,'' a collection of pieces by various authors to be published by the Cooper-Hewitt Museum, distributed by Rizzoli.

title: A Wedding in October Being Planned ByLisaDeCraneandAlvaroSaralegui

title: CONSUMER RATES

description: Amy Jocelyn Fromer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Michael Fromer of New York, was married yesterday to James Bruce Coane, the son of Beatrice Coane of Trenton and Sarasota, Fla., and the late Dr. Milton Coane.

description: -smoking product, Nicorette, has been marketed to physicians in the state since March 5, and now is available by prescription at drugstores. It is a chewing gum designed to help ameliorate withdrawal symptoms.

description: THE recent $1.5 million legacy from Fonrose Wainwright Condict to Wainwright House in Rye is expected to improve significantly the human-development center's financial situation, providing funds for both physical improvements and new programs.

The three-day auction will be the first of three segments in the sale, which is being conducted jointly by Numismatic Fine Arts Incorporated of Beverly Hills and Bank Leu Limited of Zurich, Switzerland.

title: Modified Stand On Aid and Bias
description: The newly reconstructed United States Commission on Civil Rights differed with its architects in the Reagan Administration last week, but it seemed more a matter of degree than kind. By a 5-to-2 vote, the panel recommended that Congress allow Federal authorities to penalize an entire college or university for discrimination even if just one program was guilty of it.

title: THE OLD PARTY'S OVER
description: Next Tuesday's Presidential primary in New York raises again one of the most perplexing questions concerning American politics today - the rise of a new independence within the party system.

title: STATE SEEKS MORE DATA ON AUTISM
description: HADDONFIELD UNTIL recently, experts dealing with autism were as much in the dark about the number of victims as they were about its causes. A disorder that generally appears in very young children, autism is associated with bizarre behavior, impaired language development and an inability to interact socially.

title: UNSETTLED OUTLOOK

title: MORE IN MINORITIES STUDYING MEDICINE

title: BRETT OUT 6 WEEKS WITH INJURED KNEE
description: George Brett, who has a career average of .316 and hit .333 in exhibition games this spring, will be out six to eight weeks with a partial tear of a ligament in his left knee, the Kansas City Royals said today.

description: The Government of El Salvador has dismissed a New Orleans-based diplomat who it said had implicated Salvadoran military and civilian leaders in acts of terrorism.

title: CHICAGO WAS ONCE AMERICA'S BALLET CAPITAL
description: W ith the recent death of Bentley Stone at the age of 75, Chicago has lost a respected dancer, teacher and choreographer. As a student in Chicago in the 50's, I saw Mr. Stone in works by himself and other choreographers. It was late in his dancing career, yet I found him an expressive stage presence. However, it is not sentiment alone that makes me now declare him to be a product of a golden age of Chicago ballet.

description: Engineers, architects and construction crews here are preparing for a race against time that they say has no parallel in the nation's peacetime history.

title:
WESTCHSTER OPINIONS;
TO MITTENS, WITH LOVE
description: HE was there for us at the beginning just as we tried to be there for him at the end. That cold day five winters ago was a steppingstone in our lives - a new house at a price much higher than we could really afford. And it would require a further investment of our time and money to be what we wanted in a home. So, naturally, we were pessimistic about the future and more than a little scared.

title: School-Prayer Issue Called Irrelevant
description: Prayer in school has to be the most incredibly irrelevant issue in the headlines today. There are too many things wrong with it.

description: From his apartment window, Robert Gayer, a Queens bus driver who loves trains (''They call me Choo- Choo Bob''), watched with excitement yesterday as the No. 7 train pulled into the Flushing station and then headed back toward Times Square. It was 8:35 A.M. Mr. Gayer told his 7-year-old grandson to finish his breakfast and get ready for the next run.

title: NOTES FROM NEWFOUNDLAND
description: Douglas Martin is a correspondent for The Times based in Toronto.

title: A GOOD SUBMARINE IS HARD TO FIND
description: When a Soviet submarine rose undetected from the Sea of Japan recently and smacked the bottom of the aircraft carrier Kitty Hawk, there were other red faces than those at the helm of each vessel. The United States Navy has spent a fortune on keeping enemy subs from coming within miles of its big carriers, let alone lolling under them like clumsy whales.

description: Elio Bacaro Garcia, an exile from Cuba who attempted to take a plastic bottle of gasoline onto an airliner in September, was sentenced Thursday to 25 years in prison on a Federal charge of air piracy.

description: Mexico took the lead in organizing the emergency financing package for Argentina, according to United States and Latin American officials close to the proceedings.

title: Self-Criticism At U.S.I.A.
description: When the United States Information Agency's blacklist of speakers came to light two months ago, top agency officials said it was all a ''terrible mistake.'' They blamed ''mindless gnomes in the bureaucracy'' for creating the list, which contained the names of 95 Americans banned from an overseas speaking program.

title: 'SHIVAREE': NEW BUT OVERWRITTEN
description: PERHAPS every playwright must give in to the urge to write that one play about first love, a pure love yearning to burst beyond practical bounds.

description: State Senator Gerald D. Klezcka, a Democrat, will face Robert V. Nolan, a Republican, in Tuesday's special election to fill the Fourth Congressional District seat left vacant by the death of Representative Clement J. Zablocki.

title: NOT SURE BETS
description: WASHINGTON F OR the Reagan Administration, which visibly raised American stakes and involvement in Central America three years ago, last Sunday's presidential election in El Salvador was both a vindication of policy and a cause for new infusion of American aid and assertiveness. But the immediate effects were less clearcut. Critics were inclined to pause and resist more aid at least until the election result was definitive - a runoff is required in a month - and were, at any rate, concerned about the signs of widening military activity and risks.

title: Jamie Glashow Is Married
description: Jamie Lynn Glashow, president and founder of the Energy Design Group, an engineering consulting concern in Manhattan, was married yesterday to Randy Ian Pardell, a member of the class of '84 at the New York University School of Medicine. Rabbis Solomon Rothstein and Andre Unger officiated in the Terrace Room at the Plaza. The parents of the couple are Dr. and Mrs. Jules Glashow of Upper Saddle River, N.J., and Dr. and Mrs. Bernard Pardell of Englewood, N.J.

title: Jill Edelston the Bride Of Heywood H. Adler
description: Jill Milgrim Edelston of New York and Stratton Mountain, Vt., a daughter of Joan Milgrim Edelston of New York and Gilbert Edelston of Pleasantville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Heywood Henry Adler, a son of Elias Adler of White Plains and Pompano Beach, Fla., and the late Ruth Sleeper Adler. Rabbi Murray Grauer performed the ceremony at the Town Club in Manhattan.

title: Mubarak and Arafat Meet
description: President Hosni Mubarak and Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, have held talks in Conakry, Guinea, where they were attending the funeral of President Ahmed Sekou Toure. The meeting was announced here today after President Mubarak's return. The two men last met in December after the expulsion of Mr. Arafat from Tripoli, Lebanon.

description: DREAMING OF HEROES

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION ;
NEEDED: A NATIONAL SILLINESS DAY
description: DON'T look now, but there is newsprint all over your face. April Fool! Silly, isn't it? Yes, but for my money, I have always loved April Fools' Day. I will even go so far as to say I wish they would make it a national holiday. Give everyone the day off. A day to slow down, be silly, carefree. A day to forget the mortgage payments, the school loan. Get outdoors (I would order that day to always be sunny) and have a good time.

title: SALVADORAN PROD TO VOTE
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR OPENERS, REVELING IN THE LEVELS OF THE GAME
description: This is the time of year, Swinburne wrote, when ''winter's ruins and rains have ended'' and ''blossom by blossom, the spring begins.'' But to a lot of people, it is the return of baseball, not the blossoms, that marks the change of season. Pitch by pitch, the summer begins. The season that opens tomorrow in Cincinnati, Baltimore, Kansas City and Anaheim, Calif., will be the 109th for the National League and the 84th for the American. This will be a noteworthy year in several respects. It will be the last for Bowie Kuhn as commissioner, and the first for Peter Ueberroth, who will succeed him after the Olympics, which he is running. Pete Rose, who will reach his 43d birthday in two weeks, is 201 hits short of Ty Cobb's record of 4,191. And the game itself can set a record if the major leagues top last year's attendance of 45,540,338. Baseball has done more than move people through its turnstiles, though. For more than a century, it has moved them to frame in memorable words their fascination with a game that Casey Stengel once described this way: ''I had many years when I was not so successful as a ballplayer, as it is a game of skill.'' With its stars, too, of whom Tommy Lasorda said the other day: ''These players today have driven a lot of managers to drink. But these guys have driven me to give it up.''

title: UNVEILING THE SECRETS OF NETSUKE
description: J apanese netsuke - palm- sized toggles devised to secure pouches, purses and boxes to pocketless kimonos - have been acquired since well before World War I by an elite corps of collectors in the West. Over the last 15 years, however, the antiques collecting boom and an ever increasing curiosity about all things Oriental have dramatically changed the field. Today, hundreds of enthusiasts - many of whom are serious, scholarly collectors - buy, arrange exhibitions and attend conventions the world over.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Roger Neilson, hired to coach the Los Angeles Kings two months ago, is about to be released by the National Hockey League team, according to a report in The Toronto Globe and Mail. . . . Mike Newell , who ran the basketball team at the University of Oklahoma while Coach Bill Tubbs was recovering from a jogging accident in the 1982-83 season, is reportedly leaving the school to become athletic director and head coach at the University of Arkansas-Little Rock. . . . With less than three weeks remaining in the National Basketball Association season, Larry Bird of the Boston Celtics and Isiah Thomas of the Detroit Pistons are locked in a tight race in the Seagram's basketball player of the year competition.

title: Big Day for Landry
description: Tom Landry , the normally stoic coach of the Dallas Cowboys, was moved by the display of affection, the stack of gifts and the cheers and applause of about 3,000 people in a ceremony dedicating a high school football stadium in his name. Among the gifts presented to Landry by residents of his native Lower Rio Grande Valley near Mission, Tex., was a painting of his late parents, Ray and Ruth Landry.

title: MAJOR NEWS IN SUMMARY ; Confronting theMeese Factor
description: President Reagan complained last week that House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. and other Democrats who have taken to tarring ''sleaze factor'' across the Oval Office door were being unfair.

title: THE DEMOCRATS BARE EMOTIONS, KNUCKLES
description: The exchanges between Walter F. Mondale and Gary Hart have been getting hotter for some time. Last week, in one of the series of nationally televised debates that some strategists regard as the major force in raising the emotional temperature of the the 1984 nomination struggle, the Democratic Presidential aspirants seemed to drop any effort to draw a line between political differences and personal dislike.

title:
DINING OUT;
FRENCH ATMOSPHERE IN FORT LEE
description: -page advertisements in New York magazines and newspapers heralding ''a great French restaurant on the Rive Droite,'' and even rumors of a $3 million expenditure, the hype for Fort Lee's new extravaganza of a restaurant has been remarkable.

title: One More Try, One More Failure
description: The 10 members of the European Economic Community returned to the negotiating table last week but their third effort at a budget agreement in seven months came to nothing. Once again it was Britain's demands for a cut in its contribution to the budget that caused the breakup, increasing concern for the future of Western Europe's great experiment in integration.

Last week, notwithstanding Baghdad's rejections of the charges, United States intelligence sources cited what they called incontrovertible evidence that Iraq had resorted to chemical weapons and was preparing to mass produce them.

title: Those Who Fell Through The Safety Net
description: With its customary neutrality, the General Accounting Office last week delivered the first of a series of reports on how people on welfare were affected by the Reagan Administration's social policy. The study by Congress's investigative arm found that the restructuring of welfare passed by Congress at the President's urging in 1981 did what Mr. Reagan said it would do - save money ($93 million a month, or 9.3 percent) and reduce caseloads (by nearly 500,000, or 13.7 percent).

title: FAMILY IS FOCUS OF 'THE MIDDLE AGES'

It was the first of Mr. Gurney's plays to win him wide recognition as a writer and chronicler of life among a specific upper economic class of Americans.

They said he had fallen from a third-floor window but declined to give more details.

At the same time, the disagreements, modest as they may be, seem almost visceral, rooted in the men themselves. The program, ''Secretaries of State in Conference,'' will be seen on Channel 13 at 9:30 P.M.

title: SOCIAL SERVICE NEEDS FUNDING: A CASE IN POINT
description: To the Editor:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Air Canada has appointed Guy Chiasson vice president-U.S. and Southern Region.

title: LOST COPY OF 'DAY OF INFAMY' SPEECH FOUND
description: A 43-year-old mystery - what happened to the reading copy of the famous speech that President Franklin D. Roosevelt delivered to a joint session of Congress on Dec. 8, 1941 - has finally been solved.

title: STRIKING OUT
description: In my old Bronx neighborhood, only baseball fired the imagination. Most of us were Yankee fans, of course, but there were, for some (still) unfathomable reason, Dodger and Giant fans, too. A few oddballs rooted for the Cardinals and Tigers - this defied reason and understanding. Summer nights, we gathered at the corner candy store to await the early editions of The Daily News and The Daily Mirror so that we could find, in the box scores, new ammunition for the endless debates: Rizzuto vs. Reese, Berra vs. Campanella, Mantle vs. Mays.

title: WINDS OF CHANGE
description: ''Keep plugging away on your amendment,'' President Nixon told Senator Mike Mansfield in 1969, ''it gives me a club to use on the Europeans.''

title: DENT PUT ON WAIVERS
description: The Texas Rangers put the veteran shortstop Bucky Dent on waivers today and sent the second baseman Mike Richardt to their American Association farm club in Oklahoma City.

title: The Mirage of Space Defense
description: In his ''Star Wars'' speech a year ago, President Reagan challenged scientists and engineers to design a space-based defense against Soviet missiles to ''give us the means of rendering these nuclear weapons obsolete.'' An expert panel has now given a forceful response: For the foreseeable future, a total shield is technologically impossible.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: -fashioned feeling to the little shop on East 65th Street at No. 19, between Fifth and Madison (535-6717). A walk past the window and through the door takes the visitor back to different times, different tempos, different tastes. Rita Ford, as it is called after its founder and proprietor, deals in music boxes, antique and new. It is one of the more delightful specialty houses in town.

title: PRIMARY VOTE A KNOTTY ONE IN NEW YRK
description: New Yorkers who vote in tomorrow's Democratic Presidential primary will be confronted by a confusing ballot.

title: Bomb Blasts Disrupt Power To Half of Chile's Population
description: Bomb explosions knocked down at least three utility towers tonight, darkening Santiago and a 700-mile stretch of central Chile, the police said.

title: FOES OF ABORTION EXAMINE STRATEGIES OF N.A.A.C.P.
description: Opponents of abortion must follow the example set by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People if they are to win a reversal of the Supreme Court's 1973 decision legalizing abortion, legal experts said here this weekend.

title: CONGRESSIONAL WIVES TAKE ON DELICATE ISSUE
description: For more than five years, a group of Congressional wives has quietly pursued a cause. The women write letters, make speeches, hold silent vigils in front of the Soviet Embassy and meet with dissidents in Moscow and Russian emigres in Washington.

title: NOTED SCHOLAR THRIVES AT COMMUNITY COLLEGE
description: Dr. N. John Hall spends two or three days a week in the Bronx and much of the rest of his time in the 19th century.

title: NEWS SUMMARY ;  MONDAY, APRIL 2, 1984 International
description: The question of whether to move the United States Embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem is an issue that appears to have caused considerably less excitement in Israel than in the American Presidential campaign. Israeli officials are approaching the issue with extreme caution and are wary of making any comments that could be construed as interference in American politics. They have limited themselves to formal policy statements that Jerusalem is their capital and the logical place for any embassy. (Page A1, Column 5.) Israeli artillery units fired on positions in the Syrian-held territory in the Bekaa region of eastern Lebanon. It was the first such shelling in months. A cease-fire was generally holding in Beirut, where there was only sporadic shooting. (A3:1.)

title: PEABODY AWARDS GIVEN
description: The CBS News ''60 Minutes'' segment on the life sentence of Lenell Geter, and the series ''Vietnam: A Television History'' by WGBH-TV and two co-producers are among the winners of the George Foster Peabody awards.

title: STAGE: 'THE HARVESTING' AT CIRCLE REP
description: THE Circle Repertory Company, which has already produced one flat crime melodrama this season (''Full Hookup''), has now made the mistake twice. ''The Harvesting,'' a new play by John Bishop, commits almost the same sins as its predecessor. Here again we have an incompetently told whodunit in which the audience knows who did it (and why) long before the dull-witted authorities wise up. And, as in ''Full Hookup,'' we're asked to accept sociological pretensions in lieu of drama. Having run out of story by intermission, Mr. Bishop fills out the evening with windy, knee- jerk ruminations about such subjects as the Vietnam War, racial friction and the despoiling of America.

title: THE BIG MEN TAKE CENTER STAGE ; OLAJUWON EAGER TO PLAY
description: They were brought together by opportunity, and by basketball, and their universities, and the National Collegiate Athletic Association. But at first, when Akeem Olajuwon, who had come to this country from Lagos, Nigeria, first met Patrick Ewing, who had come from Jamaica, they were brought together by the recorded music of Peter Tosh.

title: DAMAGE FROM POLLUTANTS IS CITED
description: Acid rain as well as other air pollutants have been linked to billions of dollars of forest damage throughout Europe and North America and threaten to destroy entire forest systems, according to a new study by the Worldwatch Institute.

title: MEESE AFFAIR'S STAKES
description: Much more is at stake in the Edwin Meese affair than whether one individual becomes or does not become Attorney General. At stake are the basic standards of honor and morality to which we will require our public officials and teach our children to conform. On trial are the Senate Judiciary Committee, the Senate and even ourselves.

title: Hunters Retaliate
description: The hunting fraternity has long been troubled by highly organized campaigns against the sport, and in recent years has launched various counterattacks. Among those has been a move by the National Shooting Sports Foundation of Riverside, Conn., to introduce a pro-hunting filmstrip, ''Un-endangered Species,'' at junior and senior high schools.

title: WATERSHED SEEN IN ARGENTINE LOAN
description: The $500 million rescue of Argentina that was completed this weekend represents a watershed in the three-year imbroglio over the onerous debts of the developing world, many international financial experts say.

title: FOREIGN STOCKS OUTSPACE U.S. MARKETS
description: Contrary to Wall Street's experience, the first quarter was a good one for most major foreign stock exchanges.

title: RETROACTIVITY OF TAX BILLS DRAWS FIRE
description: Two bills recently passed by the tax-writing committees of the House and the Senate are commanding significant changes in business and investment activity - even though the measures have yet to become law.

title: MacAndrews & Forbes Completes Realignment
description: Robert T. Carlton has been named to the newly created post of vice chairman and chief operating officer of MacAndrews & Forbes Holding Inc. and its MacAndrews & Forbes Group Inc. subsidiary.

title: A $500 Million Error Made in State Budget
description: One day after the New York State Assembly gave final approval to the state's $35.6 billion budget, Arthur J. Kremer, the chairman of the body's Ways and Means Committee, has called for a change in spending.

title: Interco Is Winner Of San Luis Rey
description: Interco held off the challenge of Gato Del Sol by a neck and won his sixth consecutive stakes event today in the $217,200 San Luis Rey Stakes over the grass course at Santa Anita.

title: EWING UNDER PRESSURE
description: He is uncomfortable in the spotlight, a reluctant participant in the publicity buildup surrounding a championship game. These are traits that Patrick Ewing's predecessors shared too. From the time basketball's big men are in high school, they are pursued, gawked at, fawned over and dissected like a common laboratory experiment.

title: ISRAELIS CAUTIOUS OVER U.S. EMBASSY
description: The issue of whether the United States Embassy should be moved from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem appears to have stimulated considerably less excitement in Israel than it has in the American Presidential campaign.

title: PURCHASING AGENTS CITE SLOWER GROWTH
description: The economy continued to grow in March, though at a somewhat slower rate, the National Association of Purchasing Management said yesterday.

title: Philharmonic Reports Program Changes
description: The New York Philharmonic has announced further details of the substitute conductors and programs while Zubin Mehta, its music director, recuperates from elbow surgery.

title: RANGERS EXPECT FEW SURPRISES
description: Surprises, by now, will be few.

title: THE BETTER PATH TO A BUDGET AMENDMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: GENERALS TRIUMPH, 26-10
description: Steve Young made his professional debut for the Los Angeles Express an encouraging one today. He completed 19 of 29 passes for 163 yards and at times ran the offense as if he had been a part of it for years.

title: OPERA: '84 MET FINALISTS
description: THE people at the Metropolitan Opera have found an admirable way of handling music competitions - they simply don't finish them. Thus all 11 of yesterday afternoon's finalists in the Metropolitan Opera National Council's 1984 Auditions were winners; and their performances on the Met's stage took the form of a celebration, not the final hand-to-hand combat which characterizes so many such events.

title: ECONOMIST, UNBOUND, SOUNDS ALARM
description: For more than eight years as director of the Congressional Budget Office, Alice M. Rivlin kept her opinions to herself.

title: A STRING OF BAD LUCK FOR KING
description: The odds on a player's dislocating the middle finger on each hand in pro basketball games 10 days apart are probably incalculable.

title: Correction
description: A caption Saturday under a front- page picture with an article about a Federal racketeering indictment incorrectly identified the man escorting Paul Castellano, one of the suspects. He was Kenneth McCabe, a detective from the Brooklyn District Attorney's office squad.

title: CAMPAIGN NOTES
description: Candidates Are Invited To Pay Hearing in House

title: JACKSON CALLS FOR 'NEW DIRECTION' TO EASE THE 'MISERY INDEX'
description: In a day of church and television appearances, the Rev. Jesse Jackson said yesterday that his Presidential campaign would continue to focus on what he called the ''misery index'' and the need to redirect the nation's resources.

title: ELDERLY MIGRATING TO CITIES ACROSS U.S.
description: Increasing numbers of the elderly moved to metropolitan areas during the last decade, a new analysis of Census Bureau data shows. The trend is a significant reversal of a longstanding tendency toward migration of those over the age of 60 to small towns and rural regions.

title: MILLIONS OF TICKETS UNSOLD
description: Millions of tickets are still available for the Olympics here this summer, and officials say that even those visitors who arrive without tickets when the Games are under way will probably still be able to see an event.

title: Biologists Set to FollowWhooping Cranes' PathCORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., April 1 (UPI) - The world's largest flock of whooping cranes begins its migration from a nearby wildlife refuge to Canadian nesting grounds this week, and they will have company.
description: Tiny solar-powered transmitters have been attached to some of the young cranes. Biologists from the Federal Fish and Wildlife Service and Texas A&M University plan to follow those signals along the 2,600 miles to Canada's Wood Buffalo National Park.

title: Sudan Says It Blocked A Plot to Stage a Coup
description: President Gaafar al-Nimeiry, faced with insurgents in the south and hostilities with neighboring Libya, said a coup against his Government was to have begun Saturday but that authorities intervened.

title: ARCHBISHOP IAKOVOS MARKS 25 YEARS
description: In an ecumenical service filled with stirring music, generous words of praise and warm feelings of thanksgiving, Archbishop Iakovos yesterday marked his 25th year as head of the Greek Orthodox Church in North and South America.

title: ANDRETTI TRIUMPHS IN INDY-CAR RACE
description: Mario Andretti, driving a newly developed Lola T-800 powered by a turbocharged Cosworth engine, today won the $550,000 Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach.

title: A SALVADORAN JOURNALIST IS SLAIN SAN SALVADOR, April 1 (Reuters) - A former member of El Salvador's Central Election Council, who resigned before last week's voting, was shot and killed Saturday night. Leftist rebels took responsibility.
description: The former official, Rafael Hasbun, a conservative newspaper columnist, was shot dead as he entered his office in central San Salvador, officials at the city morgue said.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''By including the other Latin Americans in this, we have at least paid lip service that the debt situation is really political.

title: The U.N. Today April 2, 1984
description: SECURITY COUNCIL

title: Checks Bounce, Banks Float
description: Is there anyone in America with a checking account who hasn't snarled at how many days are required for a deposited check to clear? It takes three days, a week - sometimes longer - before you can pay any bills from a deposit without worrying about an overdraft.

title: Mark Thatcher Explains Why He Decided to Take U.S. Job
description: Mark Thatcher, son of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, was quoted as saying today that he was moving to a new job in the United States to avoid further embarrassment to his mother.

title: NATO ISSUE: WHEN TO LET ITS SHIPS FIRE
description: Military Analysis

title: Sobriety Proposal Gets Little Notice in Florida
description: Donna Curley Hearn's effort to sober up Boca Raton for a week drew national attention but little compliance from the town's residents, it was reported today.

title: MISSILE SYSTEM CHANGE SEEN AS THREAT TO TREATY
description: After two decades of development to be the Army's frontline antiaircraft weapon, the Patriot missile system is being transformed to be able to shoot down Soviet missiles, according to Defense Department officials.

title: Entertainment Events Music
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Verdi's ''Don Carlo,'' 7. ACADEMY OF ST. MARTIN-IN-THE-FIELDS OCTET, Carnegie Hall, 8. AFTER DINNER OPERA, lecture-concert with Lee Hoiby (''Something New for the Zoo''), Lincoln Center Library-Museum, 4.

title: BRAZIL'S ARMY REGIME RULES OUT DIRECT ELECTION OF PRESIDENT IN '85
description: The head of Brazil's military Government has ruled out direct election of the country's next president, but has promised that the successor of that president will be chosen freely.

title: FOR TWO METS, LESS PRESSURE IN '84
description: A year ago, on the eve of opening day, the Mets had a journeyman right fielder in their starting lineup and a fallen star at first base.

title: 4 TEAMS FIGHT FOR SURVIVAL IN GRAND NATIONAL CONTEST
description: Four star-studded groups of New York and Long Island players fought in the semifinals of Grand National Team competition at the Beverly East Club in New York City yesterday, after surviving the quarterfinals on Saturday.

title: ALLIED MILITARY SPENDING INCREASE URGED IN TRILATERAL DRAFT REPORT
description: A draft report of the Trilateral Commission made public today said allies of the United States must assume a greater proportion of the burden of Western military spending.

title: MANY CUT POWER USE IN RATE PROTEST BUT FLORIDA UTILITY SEES LITTLE EFFECT
description: About 11 o'clock this morning John Schlesinger, a retired New York City school teacher living in the sprawling Jade Winds condominium in North Miami Beach, shut off nearly all his electricity.

title: FUTURES
description: Influencing Cash Markets

title: REAGAN INTERVENES TO SPARE SHELTER IN CAPITAL
description: Responding to the intervention of President Reagan, his Administration has backed away from a plan to close and sell a 1,000-bed shelter for the homeless in downtown Washington.

title: MAJOR SECURITY EFFORT IS PLANNED TO HEAD OFF TERRORISM AT GAMES
description: The traditional hardware of Olympic competition includes the baton, the stopwatch, the balance beam and the starting block.

title: Polish Bishops Say Cross Is Symbol of Nationalism
description: Poland's Roman Catholic bishops, fighting Government efforts to restrict the public display of crucifixes, today defended the cross as a symbol of Polish nationalism and the country's Christian culture.

title: No Headline
description: -Official of Newsday

title: POP SINGER'S FATHER FACES CHARGE
description: Marvin Gaye, who blended the soul music of the urban scene with the beat of the old- time gospel singer and became an influential force in pop music, was shot to death today.

title: Bank of Boston Awaiting Data
description: The last-minute financial moves to head off an Argentine default came just as the Bank of Boston Corporation prepared to place a third of its $300 million interest exposure in that country on a nonaccrual basis, a bank official said yesterday. Barry M. Allen, first vice president of the bank, said, ''Now everything is up in the air, but we really don't have to do anything until the bank's accounts for the quarter are analyzed and this normally takes about 10 to 12 days after the end of a calendar period.''

title: INDIA WILL GRANT SIKHS NEW STATUS
description: The Government, faced by the threat of growing protests by Sikhs, has announced that it will amend the Constitution to recognize Sikhism as a separate religion.

title: NEARING RECORD, ABDUL-JABBAR PLAYS WITH JOY
description: THE two combatants attempted to settle in. It wasn't easy. For at 7 feet 2 inches and 232 pounds and 6-11 and 225, respectively, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar and Bill Walton are very large.

title: NANCY JACKSON WED TO GARY H. BRANDEIS
description: Nancy Elayne Jackson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Jackson of Bayside, Queens, and Lake Worth, Fla., was married yesterday to Gary H. Brandeis, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Otto Brandeis of Wilkes-Barre, Pa. Rabbis Israel Kestenbaum and Theo Jungreis performed the ceremony at Congregation Ohr Torah in North Woodmere, L.I.

title: MORE STREET CLEANING FOR THE PRICE OF LESS
description: To the Editor:

title: A BREAKTAKING CONFRONTATION IN FINAL
description: Scouting Report

title: POLITCAL INTERVIEWS: 2 SIDES AMBIVALENT
description: It is late at night, after an important primary election. Click. There is Senator Gary Hart talking to Peter Jennings on ABC. Click. Now he is being interviewed by Dan Rather on CBS. Click. There he is with Tom Brokaw on NBC. The following morning, the nimble-fingered viewer tunes in again. Click. Mr. Hart appears on ABC's ''Good Morning America.'' Click. There he is is on NBC's ''Today'' show. Click. Now he is on ''The CBS Morning News.''

title: Cosmos In Final
description: The Cosmos reached the championship series for the indoor title in the North American Soccer League with an 8-7 victory tonight over the Chicago Sting.

title: Pravda Accuses U.S. Of Destroying Detente
description: The Communist Party newspaper Pravda accused the United States today of doing nothing to reduce international tension and said the Reagan Administration was destroying detente.

title: FRED BROWN LOOKS AHEAD
description: SEATTLE

title: WITH LAUGHS AND LESSONS, BOB HOPE LEADS THE CLASS
description: The subject was one-liners, sight gags and stand- up routines. The professor was Bob Hope.

title: ON THE HISTORY OF A CONTROVERSIAL PARKING LOT
description: To the Editor:

title:
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
A Giver Gets a Party
description: To raise money for the fledgling

title: CONSENSUS ON SPENDING
description: The $35.6 billion state budget enacted Saturday by the Legislature dramatizes the consensus that has developed in both major political parties here in support of the current size and cost of state government. ''We're not spending it out of line,'' Warren M. Anderson, the leader of the Republican majority in the State Senate, said early Saturday after the Senate completed work on the budget. ''And we're spending it the right way. We're putting it where it will do the most good.''

title: U.S.C. Wins Title
description: Midway through the second half of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I women's basketball championship today, Coach Linda Sharp of Southern California looked down her bench and told Cynthia Cooper to go into the game and score.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a Tokyo dispatch on March 23 incorrectly characterized Japan's trade and foreign aid relationship with China. China was the top recipient of Japanese foreign aid in 1982; the United States is Japan's principal trade partner.

title: EXCERPTS FROMM TRANSCRIPT OF INTERVIEW WITH JACKSON, HART AND MONDALE
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript provided by television channel WNBC in New York of the interview conducted yesterday by Gabe Pressman with Senator Gary Hart, the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Walter F. Mondale: Mr. PRESSMAN: Let's get to what a lot of time has been spent on, in this campaign, and that is, I guess, for want of a better phrase, the ethics of political campaigning. Mr. HART: Mr. Pressman, I have really tried very hard not to attack anyone, in this race, including the four or five who have now departed. The issue in this contest is the future versus the past, and which of us has the best policies for our future, and what they ought to be, in great detail. Fritz and I have gone back and forth on the question of the beef. I am - I know the beef is there in books and articles and a lot of other things. That's what we ought to be debating. I think there is a tendency, in traditional politics, to focus on narrow issues of the past, to avoid the hard work and difficult work of debating the issues of the future and policies of the future.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Price Waterhouse Fills Planning Post

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE UNBEARABLE LIGHTNESS OF BEING. By Milan Kundera. 314 pages. Harper & Row. $15.95.

title: RANGERS SHUT OUT WHALERS
description: The Rangers' regular season effectively ended more than a week ago, when they cemented themselves into fourth place in the Patrick Division. After that, they were waiting to find whom they would oppose in the opening round of the playoffs and waiting to find who would be their goaltender.

title: Joe Evins, Ex-Representative
description: Former Representative Joe L. Evins, Democrat of Tennessee, who served 30 years in Congress and was for many years the dean of his state's Congressional delegation, died after a heart attack Saturday. He was 73 years old.

title: DANCE: PAUL TAYLOR
description: THE Paul Taylor Dance Company presented a dream of a program on Wednesday at the City Center Theater. It was Mr. Taylor in a mostly contemplative mood to start, but the program also featured a lushly pretty new work and three dances that are Taylor landmarks in their way.

title: Debt Issues
description: * E.F. Hutton Credit Corp., a unit of E.F. Hutton Group Inc., filed an offering of $100 million in series C notes due 9 months to 15 years from date of issue, through E.F. Hutton & Co.

title: HART EATS SOME PASTA, THEN GOES FOR A RUN
description: Campaigning for the Democratic Presidential nomination on a sunny Sunday in New York City means eating a plateful of pasta on Grand Street and then getting into a limousine to drive to Central Park for a half-mile run.

title: GENERAL A 'GUEST' OF COSTA RICANS
description: Costa Rica's Foreign Minister said today that the ousted armed forces commander of Honduras ''was brought'' to this country late Saturday morning aboard a Honduran Government plane and ''is now a guest here.''

title: Nevada Casino Workers Prepare for Strike
description: Contract talks broke off today hours before a midnight strike deadline set by 30,000 hotel and casino workers.

title: NEW RISES SEEN IN '84 STEEL PRICES
description: After declining throughout 1982 and much of 1983, steel prices are finally gathering strength, and analysts predict increases through the rest of the year, perhaps as much as 10 percent.

title: DERBY OUTLOOK UNCLEAR
description: Woody Stephens checked into a Cincinnati hotel Saturday afternoon, determined not to leave his room for the next 24 hours. The 70-year-old trainer had cracked a rib in a fall at his Miami apartment last month and had not been sleeping well since. His powerful stable had been earning plenty of money, but its brightest stars, the 3-year-olds Devil's Bag and Swale, had been convincingly beaten in major prep races for the Kentucky Derby, for which they were no longer the favorites. Stephens needed a rest.

title: POP SINGER'S FATHER FACES CHARGE; HE KEPT FANS GUESSING
description: Marvin Gaye, an internationally popular singer, songwriter and musician, always liked to keep his fans guessing. ''I've made it a point not to follow in my own shadow,'' he remarked less than a year ago, shortly before winning two Grammy awards for his 1983 hit ''Sexual Healing.'' And his career, which began in the late 1950's when Mr. Gaye joined a former street-corner vocal group called the Rainbows, had more than its share of surprising twists and turns.

title: Iowa Republican Seeks Re-election to Senate
description: Senator Roger W. Jepsen, a Republican, has made his candidacy for re-election official.

title: MUBARAK HOPES TO RESTORE MOSCOW TIES
description: President Hosni Mubarak says he hopes to restore full diplomatic ties with the Soviet Union soon, the Middle East News Agency reported today.

title: TREVINO IS SECOND
description: Pursued by three of the world's best golfers, Fred Couples never backed away from the challenge today despite some difficult moments. Instead, it was Tom Watson, Seve Ballesteros and Craig Stadler who seemed to back off as the 24-year-old Couples calmly played his way to victory in the $800,000 Tournament Players Championship to win the biggest individual cash prize in the history of the PGA Tour - $144,000.

title: LAW-AND-ORDER GROUPS OPPOSE AN OREGON JUSTICE
description: Justice Hans Linde, a national leader in a movement of state appellate judges toward greater reliance on state rather than Federal constitutional provisions, has become the target of law-and-order groups in Oregon that oppose his re-election to the State Supreme Court.

title: HARRY H. ENGEL
description: Harry H. Engel, a developer of Pablum baby cereal, has died at the age of 82.

title: U.S. EMBASSY IN ISRAEL AS AN ISSUE IN CAMPAIGN
description: Today's joint appearance in Manhattan of the Democratic Presidential candidates once again raised the issue of whether the United States Embassy in Israel should be moved from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem, the city that Israel has regarded as its capital for 35 years.

title: JACK AND JILL: STAYING IN TOUCH
description: First there was ''Swing Low, Sweet Chariot.'' Then, ''Michael, Row the Boat Ashore.'' The young voices on one side of the room at the Concord Nursing Home in Brooklyn blended with the sometimes unsteady harmonies of the elderly, some in wheelchairs.

title: EXILE OF GENERAL IS LAID TO FRICTION IN HONDURAN ARMY
description: The commander of the Honduran armed forces was ousted Saturday because a group of younger military officers were unhappy with his autocratic leadership style and his plans to restructure the army, according to Honduran officials.

title: OUTDOORS: SUN AND FRIENDSHIP WARM OPENING DAY
description: ROSCOE, N.Y.

title: FEW TRENDS IN STOCK TRADING
description: A stock called Midlands Energy, an apparently strong takeover candidate, was the first quarter's best performer on the New York Stock Exchange, despite a dismal market over all.

title: DIVERSE GROUPS WOO PRIMARY VOTERS
description: From the union workers talking to passers-by in Times Square to the homosexuals passing out pamphlets in Greenwich Village to the feminists setting up voter-registration tables on the Upper West Side, hundreds of New Yorkers have been campaigning for the Democratic Presidential candidate who they think represents their group, their views.

title: Top Saudi Religious Aide Criticizes Travel to West
description: Saudi Arabia's top religious figure today condemned frequent visits by young Saudis to the United States and Europe as a serious threat to the Islamic faith.

title: What Price Integrity?
description: In the minds of some corrupt college athletes, some compromises with integrity are not as bad as others. At least that is one insight offered by Rick Kuhn, the former Boston College basketball player who is serving a 10-year sentence for participating in a game-rigging conspiracy to benefit gamblers during the 1978-79 season.

title: The Candidates on Key Issues   U.S. ROLE ABROAD
description: MONDALE

title: IN THE MEN'S WORLD OF A BRITISH UNION, SHE'S THE BOSS
description: Years ago, when she was just starting as a trade union official, a business executive offered Brenda Dean a drink before they sat down at the bargaining table.

title: ISLANDERS PASS UP A PARTY
description: With neither champagne nor a late-night dinner did the Islanders celebrate their first-place finish.

title: Panthers Win, 26-10, but Lose Carter
description: The unbeaten Michigan Panthers defeated the San Antonio Gunslingers, 26-10, today but lost their star wide receiver, Anthony Carter, with a broken left arm.

title: AGENCIES EXPAND TO MARKETING;
description: FOLLOWING an industry trend,

title: WISCONSIN'S 76-YEAR-OLD OPEN PRIMARY YIELDS TO CAUCUSES
description: Seventy-six years of open Democratic Presidential primaries in Wisconsin give way this week to party caucuses, a system that Gov. Robert M. LaFollette Sr. fought bitterly at the turn of the century.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: A defensive player in the National Football League, in pursuit of a ball-carrier, steps out of bounds but continues to run alongside him. He finally brings him down. Is this legal? Can an offensive player go out of bounds and still return and take part in a play?

title: Fund Manager Turns Cautious
description: WITH the stock market showing no clear direction in recent weeks, a number of money managers have adopted a fairly cautious investment attitude. A typical example is Wright Investors' Service, based in Bridgeport, Conn. ''We are continuing a 20 percent to 30 percent cash reserve in equity accounts,'' the firm stated, ''while passively accumulating reserves of up to 25 percent in fixed-income portfolios.''

title: No Headline
description: A Delegate Update caucuses in Kentucky and the Virgin Islands. ''Other'' represents the 35 delegates pledged to Mayor Harold Washington of Chicago.

title: A 10-VOLUME LOOK AT GARVEY
description: Robert A. Hill, a historian, is in the midst of a vast publishing project that he believes will increase the understanding of Marcus Garvey as not only a black nationalist leader in the United States, but as a significant influence on Africa's political history.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, APRIL 2, 1984

title: MONDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Mets vs. Reds at Cincinnati. The 1983 last-place teams in the Eastern and Western Divisions meet in the National League opener. Mike Torrez will pitch for the Mets against Mario Soto. This is the fifth opening-day assignment for Torrez as a Met; he is 2-1, with one no- decision. (Television - Channel 9, 2 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 2 P.M.)

title: Crew Safe After Ship Fire
description: A seismic research vessel caught fire in the Gulf of Mexico today, forcing the 27-member crew to abandon ship. The Coast Guard reported no serious injuries and said the crew was picked up and taken to safety.

title: 'SALESMAN' BECOMES 2D-BEST-SELLING PLAY
description: ''Death of a Salesman,'' which opened March 29 to rave reviews, sold more than $300,000 worth of tickets this weekend, making it the second- best-selling play of the season, behind only ''The Real Thing.''

title: LINKS WITH THE STATE STRESSED BY MONDALE
description: Describing himself as a proven friend of New York, Walter F. Mondale campaigned yesterday in the balmy April sunshine through city and suburb.

title: BULLETS RALLY FOR VICTORY
description: Jeff Ruland, with 29 points, including 12 in the last quarter, led the Washington Bullets to a 102-98 uphill victory over the Dallas Mavericks today in the National Basketball Association. Their fourth straight loss dropped Dallas two and one-half games behind first-place Utah in the Midwest Division.

title: TV REVIEWS ; 'SINS OF THE PAST' HAS MANY TYPES
description: TELEVISION writers are always trying to devise plots that will encompass the biggest number of contrasting ''types'' within a single situation. The effort has something to do with expanding story possibilities and establishing broad audience identification. Say this for ''Sins of the Past,'' tonight's television movie on ABC-TV at 9 o'clock: Its plotting angle is not your ordinary ''old man-young man- sexy secretary'' stuff. The assorted women in this flick have one unusual thing in common. They are all former prostitutes who 13 years earlier, fed up with greedy pimps, formed their own call-girl cooperative. The free- enterprise initiative in television is apparently unlimited.

title: No Headline
description: The Treasury market faces a month of relatively light activity, with few financings except for the Monday auctions of three- and six- month bills.

title: SAY IT AIN'T SO, PAT
description: Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York is one of the smartest members of the United States Senate. Unusual for an intellectual, he also operates effectively in the legislative process. He has made himself an influential figure in the Senate.

title: HOW THE POOR AND ELDERLY FARE UNDER REAGAN
description: To the Editor:

title: A Fan's Fan
description: In the general erosion of language, few words have lost as much of their force as the diminutive ''fan,'' a term applied nowadays to anyone who watches so much as a single sports event on television.

title: UNIFICATION CHURCH IS STARTING A PUBLISHING HOUSE
description: THE REV. SUN MYUNG MOON'S Unification Church has started a book publishing company in New York whose editorial board includes prominent scholars associated with some of the nation's leading universities.

title: Makes Team, Ages a Year
description: Contrary to initial belief, the Yankees do not have two 18-year-old players on their opening-day roster. They have one, Jose Rijo.

title: JARDINE MOVING PLAN IS JOLT TO HONG KONG
description: After Jardine Matheson, the Hong Kong trading company, disclosed last Wednesday that it planned to move its legal residency to Bermuda, The Hong Kong Standard likened the shock to hearing that the Queen of England was emigrating to Australia.

title: GORDON H.PIPER WED TO DIANE BUCHBINDER
description: Diane R. Buchbinder , a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Saul Buchbinder of Milton, Mass., was married there yesterday to Gordon H. Piper , the son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin N. Piper of Wyckoff, N.J. Rabbi Jerome Weistrop performed the ceremony at Temple Shalom.

title: AFGHAN REBELS REPORT SOVIET SHIFT TO MORE AGGRESSIVE USE OF TROOPS
description: Afghan rebels assert that the Soviet Union has stepped up its bombing of villages and guerrilla supply routes in Afghanistan in a spring offensive against anti-Government forces.

title: PENSION BILL SPLIT HOUSE COMMITTEE
description: Representative Matthew J. Rinaldo says that when he had to choose between gender-free insurance tables and what he saw as a way to continue lower car insurance premiums for women, he voted for the latter.

title: Clinton of Arkansas Trying Again for 2d Term
description: Gov. Bill Clinton, a Democrat, Saturday announced his bid for re-election, in his second effort to succeed himself.

title: BALTIMORE STARTS LEGAL BIDS TO RETAKE COLTS FRANCHISE
description: When the moving vans pulled out of the Baltimore Colts' training center early Thursday and headed for Indianapolis, few tangible reminders of the football team's three decades in town remained.

title: LEONARD BERNSTEIN SHOWS 3 TALENTS
description: LEONARD BERNSTEIN is a man who conducts, plays the piano and likes to talk about music, and in tonight's ''Great Performances'' telecast on Channel 13 at 8, he does all three with obvious zest. In fact, listeners will see almost every side of this many-sided man except his composing.

title: No Progress Is Reported In Talks on Post Strike
description: Negotiations between The New York Post and 400 striking members of the Newspaper Guild continued into the early morning today as the newspaper missed publication of its first three editions.

title: EL SALVADOR ANNOUNCES OFFICIAL ELECTION RESULTS
description: El Salvador, announcing the official results of last week's presidential election, said Jose Napoleon Duarte, leader of the centrist Christian Democrats, finished first with 43.4 percent of the vote.

title: Likud to Choose Candidate
description: The Likud bloc candidate for the July 23 elections will be chosen April 12 by the Central Committee of Herut, the top party in the governing bloc, it was decided today. The date was set by Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and his Herut colleagues after Ariel Sharon, a Minister Without Portfolio, told them he could not be dissuaded from running.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Rouse Founder, Near 70, Leaving Chairman Post

title: COPY/Dividend Meetings for Monday's paper/McCue/Fin News
description: Dividend Meetings

title: Bridging Generations With a Tape Recorder
description: Some children took parents and

title: Devils Drop Finale
description: The Devils closed their second season at Byrne Meadowlands Arena today in familiar fashion, losing to the Boston Bruins, 3-1, for their eighth consecutive defeat.

title: JANET SMITH WED TO MICHAEL PITTAS
description: Janet Marie Smith of New York, the coordinator of architecture and design for the Battery Park City Authority, was married yesterday to Michael John Pittas , the director of the design arts program of the National Endowment for the Arts in Washington. The Very Rev. Dean James Parks Morton performed the ceremony at the St. Ambrose Chapel of the Episcopal Cathedral of St. John the Divine in New York.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A caption from The Associated Press under a front-page picture on Oct. 15 incorrectly described a view of dust rings around the sun. It was an artist's conception based on a computer-enhanced photograph made during a solar eclipse in 1983.

title: SLATER ELECTRIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Navy Withholds $850 Million in Missile Contracts
description: The Navy announced today that it was withholding $850 million worth of missile contracts from Texas Instruments until the company offered an acceptable performance warranty.

title: Topics ; Precision / Revision ; Shape of the Future The Campbell Soup Company wants to stay modern and profitable, even if that means abandoning its famous red-and-white soup can. The can, an official says, ''isn't as user- friendly as it used to be,'' and the company's looking for a package as up-to-date as his language. Some possibilities so far are an aluminum foil pouch, a cartonboard box and a plastic bowl.
description: There's no stopping progress, not when the vaunted Japanese are scooping up the soup business in this country in styrofoam cups. And the chances are that the final choice Campbell makes will bear a familiar- looking label.

title: DANCE:PAUL TAYLOR REVIVES 1982 'LOST, FOUND'
description: THE Paul Taylor Dance Company still has two more weeks at the City Center, and while Mr. Taylor's two unusual premieres of the season have kept the public buzzing, his recent repertory pieces shine as brightly as ever.

title: ASTRONOMERS REHEARSE FOR HALLEY'S
description: Through the slot in the observatory dome the astronomers saw the first star appear in the southern twilight. The sun had set. Earth had cast its shadow briefly out beyond the eastern horizon, creating a faint pink rim in counterpoint to the sun's more dazzling farewell. And now, clear as could be, there was the dog star Sirius, herald of night.

title: Report on Lima Prison Riot
description: An investigator for the Attorney General's office says corrupt guards and prison officials allowed arms to be smuggled into a Lima prison where a riot by inmates last week resulted in the deaths of 22 prisoners. The investigator, Antonio Palomino, said he had found no evidence to support suggestions by the Government that the riot was inspired by the Maoist guerrilla movement Shining Path.

title: Lava Flow Erratic, But Hilo Is in Peril
description: A 17- mile flow of lava from the Mauna Loa volcano moved steadily toward Hilo today, but its erratic crawl made it impossible, officials said, to predict whether or when it might reach Hawaii's second largest city.

title: RITE AID CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 3
description: b-After a gain on the sale of a partial interest in Super-Rite Foods Inc. of $12,094,000 for the quarter and year. c-After a gain on the sale of a partial interest in Superdrug Stores PLC. of $5,093,000 for the quarter and year. The share earnings reflect 2-for-1 stock split paid Jan. 30, 1984. All results restated to account for Super-Rite Foods Inc. on the equity method. The latest periods included 14 weeks and 53 weeks for the quarter and year, respectively, compared with 13 weeks and 52 weeks for year- ago periods.

title: COUNSEL IS NAMED FOR MEESE INQUIRY
description: A three- judge panel today named Jacob A. Stein to conduct a broad investigation of charges against Edwin Meese 3d, the counselor to President Reagan and Mr. Reagan's nominee for Attorney General.

title: Welcome for Colts
description: A crowd estimated at 20,000 by Mayor William Hudnut welcomed Robert Irsay and other team officials yesterday to the Colts' new home, the Hoosier Dome in Indianapolis. The welcoming ceremonies were delayed briefly because of the size of the crowd, considerably bigger than city officials had expected, that streamed into the new stadium.

title: SOVIET TRADE EMPHASIS SHIFTED TO EUROPE IN '83
description: The Soviet Union, as part of an apparent reorientation of its trade among the leading industrial nations, strengthened its commercial ties with Western Europe last year.

title: Dr. Boris M. Levinson Dead; Aided Disturbed Youngsters
description: Dr. Boris M. Levinson, a psychologist who theorized that permitting emotionally disturbed children to care for pets had therapeutic benefits, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at the Blueberry Treatment Center for Seriously Disturbed Children in Brooklyn. He was 76 years old and lived in Elmhurst, Queens.

title: WATERS INSTRUMENTS INC reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
BRAZIL HOPEFUL ON INTEREST BURDEN
description: Brazil hopes to cover $12 billion in interest payments due on its foreign debt this year without resorting to new borrowing abroad, foreign bankers and local officials said today.

title: ABOUT ALLEGATIONS AGAINST A FORMER C.I.A. AIDE
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; Magazine For Parents In Premiere
description: PITMAN LEARNING of Belmont, Calif., whose roots go back over a century to Sir Isaac Pitman, inventor of the shorthand system, has just begun to publish its first consumer magazine after covering the doings of educators since 1937.

title: PATRICK PETROLEUM CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
