description: b-After a loss from coal company operations of $3.6 million and a loss on the disposal of the coal company of $17.8 million. c-After a loss from coal company operations of $770,000.

title: STRIDE RITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 2
GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: NEW LEASH ON LIFE There are qualities, apparently, that dogs and their owners should share, if not 50-50, at least largely. Perhaps you have never considered compatibility as a factor when acquiring a canine, but there are those who believe it will make life easier for both of you. Such a consideration will be in the forefront at the Bide- a-Wee Home Association's Manhattan pet-adoption center, 410 East 38th Street (532-6358), today from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M.

title: Cadillac's Prices
description: The General Motors Corporation raised the price of its new, front-wheel drive Cadillac DeVille by $344, to $17,472, and cut the price of the bigger, redesigned Cadillac Fleetwood. The Fleetwood will now have a sticker price of $20,402, down $37 from its previous price.

title: CINTAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Coffee Quota Talks Begin
description: Coffee- producing countries plan preliminary discussions of new export quotas at a two-week meeting of the International Coffee Organization that began today, Colombia's top coffee official said here. Final decisions are not expected yet, according to the official, Jorge Cardenas.

title: Airline's Chief Resigns
description: Michael E. Levine has resigned as president and chief executive of New York Airlines, the company said yesterday. The carrier, which specializing in low-cost, short- to medium-haul service, is a subsidiary of the Texas Air Corporation. Mr. Levine joined New York Air in early 1982. The company said he would return to his academic and consulting career, and would continue as a consultant to New York Air.

title: REAGAN SEES AN INNING
description: Harold Baines drove in three runs, and LaMarr Hoyt pitched the Chicago White Sox to a 5-2 victory over the Baltimore Orioles today in an American League opener attended by President Reagan.

title: SUPREME COURT ROUNDUP ; JUSTICES SAY TEST ON SUSPECTED NARCOTIC NEEDS NO WARRANT
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that the police do not need a search warrant to conduct a chemical test on a suspected narcotic that has been discovered and brought to them by a private party.

title: U.S. SHIP HIT BY SOVIET FLARES
description: A Soviet antisubmarine carrier patrolling in the South China Sea last weekend fired eight flares at a United States frigate, several of which hit the American vessel, Defense Department officials said tonight.

title: IRAQIS PLIANT IN A COUNTRY RULED BY FEAR
description: The cost of Iraq's stalemated war with Iran and a worldwide decline in oil prices have depressed the boom economy here and turned Iraq into a debtor nation living on deferred payment of its import bills, buying food on credit and reducing foreign purchases, except for arms, to a minimum. The standard of living is declining.

title: INDUSTRY DRAFTS TOXIC WASTE MOVE
description: A coalition of environmentalists and leaders in the chemical industry is forming a private company to accelerate efforts to clean up toxic wastes. The group says it fears the Government's program may ''drag into the next century.''

title: I.M.F. MEDICINE
description: In the negotiations that led to the deal worked out last week to help Argentina meet the interest payments on its international debt, President Raul Alfonsin cited concerns for his country's economic growth, stability and democracy. The deal may give Argentina some breathing space, but it does not answer lingering questions about how third world countries will service their debts. And in this, the International Monetary Fund deserves more credit than it usually gets.

title: INTEREST RATES RISE MODESTLY
description: Interest rates rose modestly yesterday as weak investor demand and fear that the Federal Reserve might tighten monetary policy led to lower prices for short-term and long-term debt securities.

title: BLOUNT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
BACKERS RETHINK EFFORT TO SHIFT ISRAEL EMBASSY
description: Several backers of a bill to move the American Embassy in Israel to Jerusalem said privately today that they expected to avoid a direct confrontation with the Administration by making the legislation a ''sense of the Congress'' resolution. Such legislation is not sent to the President for his signature and is not binding.

title: Agency Stock Split
description: Ogilvy & Mather International, the fourth-largest United States agency, which is also a public company frequently recommended by analysts, announced Friday that it is splitting its stock 2-for-1 on May 31 for shareholders of record on May 11. The agency went public in 1966 and this is its third stock split. It split 3 for 2 in 1972 and 2 for 1 in 1978.

title: IRANIAN SAYS HIS COUNTRY IS ABLE TO MAKE ITS OWN CHEMICAL ARMS
description: Iran is capable of producing its own chemical weapons and may retaliate if Iraq continues its use of such weapons, Iran's delegate to the United Nations said today.

title: STARRETT HOUSING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary tax credit of $475,000. c-Includes an extraordinary tax credit of $660,000.

title: THE BEST OF EUROPE'S FASHIONS
description: London has awakened. The fashion industry is on a giant roll, with some of the energy and enthusiasm of the 1960's returning to ignite the 1980's. Some of the young graduates of England's excellent design schools have formed their own businesses instead of emigrating to Italy or New York to work for other companies. The well-known designers, such as Jean Muir, Zandra Rhodes and Sheraton Barnett, were at their peak during the fall and winter shows just completed. As Miss Muir observed after her show, ''I didn't want to let London down.''

title: DUEL THAT WASN'T
description: SEATTLE

title: MAGNETICS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
French Price Rise Slim
description: Wholesale prices in France rose three-tenths of 1 percent in February after a revised increase of 1.7 percent in January, the National Statistics Institute said today. The figures measure prices of raw materials and semifinished industrial products.

title: NIGERIANS SUSPECTED OF LINK TO WIDE PATTERN OF WHITE-COLLAR FRAUD IN U.S.
description: For the last several years, loosely organized rings made up mostly of Nigerian nationals have been suspected of involvement in a widespread pattern of white-collar criminal fraud by various Federal and local law-enforcement officials.

title: TOO MUCH TO ASK OF A STEEL PRODUCER
description: To the Editor:

title: PORTABLE THAT TRAVELS TO THE STRANGEST PLACES
description: -kept secrets in the burgeoning portable computer field is the Commodore SX64. Completely compatible with the standard 64, now a classic, the SX64 at $900 (often discounted to about $700) is one of the better buys in computerdom.

title: A.T.& T. ASKS U.S. TO LIFT REGULATIONS
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company asked the Government today to effectively remove most regulation of interstate telephone service and to let the company's prices and services be governed by market forces.

title: CARDIFF EQUITIES CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,316,000 for the latest year and $13,156,000 for the previous year.

title: CHINA REPORTS RETALIATORY SHELLING OF VIETNAMESE BORDER POSITIONS
description: China said its artillery gunners shelled Vietnamese frontier forces today, wrecking a command post and two gun emplacements in retaliation for what it called Vietnam's repeated provocations along their border.

title: New York PrimaryHistory
description: New York has been fertile ground for Presidential hopefuls - Nelson A. Rockefeller, W. Averell Harriman, Thomas E. Dewey, Franklin D. Roosevelt, Alfred E. Smith and Theodore Roosevelt in this century alone. Despite that history, the New York Democratic and Republican Presidential primaries have often been overshadowed by those in smaller states, largely because the New York primaries came late in the primary season.

title: People
description: * Skye Hallberg, manager of Young & Rubicam's San Francisco office, named a senior vice president.

title: $12 Million Project At Newark Station
description: N.J. Transit officials have announced plans to spend more than $12 million over the next several years to improve Pennsylvania Station here.

title: CHEATING ON EXAMS FOR DOCTORS CAUSES ALARM
description: Increasing evidence of widespread cheating and

title: GREENE NOVEL, WRITTEN IN 40'S, TO BE PUBLISHED
description: A Graham Greene novel about the French Resistance, written almost 40 years ago for Metro Goldwyn Mayer and discovered in the studio's archives two years ago, will be published next year in England.

title: CAR BOMB HITS SOUTH AFRICA CITY
description: A car bomb exploded today during the early morning rush hour in the South African port of Durban, the police said. The South African Press Association news agency said five people were killed. The explosion, close to the seafront at a time when commuters were on their way to their offices, was the most dramatic incident of its kind since last May, when a car bomb went off outside a military headquarters in the capital, Pretoria. A police spokesman said no one had so far claimed responsibility for the blast. Suspicion, however, is bound to center on the outlawed African National Congress, the most prominent of the exiled groups opposed to South Africa's policies of racial separation. The organization recently suffered a crushing blow when Mozambique, its main black-ruled ally and rear base, signed a nonaggression treaty with South Africa, pledging to withdraw support for its military activities. The explosion today, police officials said, may have been designed to show that the Congress is still a force to be reckoned with. The African National Congress office in Lusaka, the Zambian capital, had no immediate comment on the explosion. Witnesses in Durban said the bomb exploded close to the offices of the South African Indian Council. That organization has agreed to participate in limited political reforms offered by the white minority Government to the Indian and colored, or mixed race, communities in South Africa but not to the black majority. The witnesses said they saw at least three bodies on Durban's streets, along with many injured.

title: IDAHO CONGRESSMAN IS CONVICTED OF HIDING FINANCIAL TRANSACTIONS
description: Representative George Hansen was found guilty today of failing to report $333,978 in personal loans and other transactions on financial disclosure documents.

title: Science Group to Cite Expert On Oceans and Populations
description: The National Science Foundation has announced that Dr. Roger R. Revelle, professor of science and public policy at the University of California at San Diego, would receive the foundation's fifth Vannevar Bush Award for ''outstanding contributions'' in oceanography and population science. The award, which is made from time to time, will be presented May 9 in Washington.

title: An Unhappy Goalie
description: The veteran goaltender Tony Esposito refused to play in a regular- season finale Sunday night, an act that may have spelled the end of his career with the Chicago Black Hawks. The development was the latest in a season-long feud between Esposito, who will be 41 later this month, and Coach Orval Tessier.

title: BUILDING OUTLAYS UP SHARP 6.9%
description: Spending for new construction, driven by continuing strength in the housing industry, soared by 6.9 percent in February, the largest monthly increase in almost four decades, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: MAYOR CRITICIZES M.T.A.'S CAPITAL PLAN
description: Mayor Koch said today that he doubted whether the Metropolitan Transportation Authority was making the best use of its $8.5 billion capital plan.

title: ON MILITARY:DEBATING FRILLS AND FUNDAMENTALS
description: The political rise of Senator Gary Hart has focused attention on a school of thought about military affairs that asserts the Pentagon has become too absorbed in spending money and buying weapons and is too unconcerned with ''what will win in war.''

title: Primary Politics: The Contract . . .
description: While the polls and pundits are uncertain about how New York's Democrats will vote in today's primary election, there is one shining political constant - the contract.

title: SENATE DEFEATS BID TO CUT SALVADOR AID REQUEST
description: Senate liberals, appealing for Congress to await the outcome of the Salvadoran presidential runoff before sending that country substantial new military aid, failed today in two attempts to cut the size of an emergency aid package for El Salvador.

title: Egypt-Cyprus Ties Restored
description: Egypt and Cyprus agreed today to restore diplomatic relations, which were severed in 1978 after an Egyptian writer was killed in Nicosia. Foreign Minister George Iacovou of Cyprus met with President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt and said later, ''We have agreed in principle to re-establish diplomatic relations in the very near future.''

title: UTILITY SAID TO BE FACING BANKRUPTCY
description: An independent auditor for the Public Service Company of New Hampshire, the lead builder of the Seabrook nuclear power plant, said yesterday that unless the company found additional sources of credit in the next three weeks, it might be forced into bankruptcy and find itself ''unable to continue in existence.''

title: Suzuki Ships Cars to G.M.
description: The Suzuki Motor Company has shipped the first load of 1.0-liter subcompact cars for the General Motors Corporation, a Suzuki official said today.

title: 2 T.V. SERIES ON WOMEN DO WELL IN PRIME TIME
description: Two weekly prime-time series featuring women living in New York have attracted big audiences since they were introduced on CBS-TV's Monday night schedule two weeks ago.

title: MISSION WEST PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $272,000 for the latest quarter and $138,000 for year-earlier period.

title: THE LEGACY OF A SURVIVOR
description: THE Klein family, profiled in Steve Brand's film ''Kaddish,'' has been powerfully influenced by the legacy of a father, Zoltan, who survived the Holocaust and who raised his son, Yossi, in its shadow. Zoltan, who died when the filming was partially completed, is implicitly at the center of Mr. Brand's film, while the highly articulate Jewish activist Yossi is its dominant spokesman. Using interviews, home movies, glimpses of the Kleins at various stages in their lives, Mr. Brand makes a comprehensive attempt to tell Zoltan's story and to explain how it has shaped Yossi's attitudes. He also captures a strong sense of the son's love for his father.

title: THE BATTLE OVER WAR
description: There are clear signs that Congress and the President may be heading for a new struggle over the War Powers Act. Last year the battleground for this institutional rivalry was Lebanon; this year it seems likely to be El Salvador and the neighboring countries of Honduras and Nicaragua. In recent days the Reagan Administration has renewed its accusations that Congress was using the War Powers Act to undermine the executive's ability to make foreign policy. But lawmakers from both parties argue that events in Central America last week graphically demonstrated the need for a Congressional check upon foreign policy initiatives by the executive branch.

title: FLIP-FLOP IN LEBANON
description: Despite his efforts to conceal it in lofty diplomatic language, Ronald Reagan's flip-flop in Lebanon is visible to anyone who wants to look. But does anyone really want to look? Or will Mr. Reagan, with an engaging smile and an old soft-shoe, once again dance away from responsibility?

title: Corroon & Black Gets Ingram Bid
description: The Corroon & Black Company said it had received an unsolicited letter from Ingram Industries offering to buy all of Corroon's shares for $31 each.

title: Pinhole Photography
description: When Marianne Engberg, a

title: TRAFFIC WOES HAUNT OLYMPICS
description: In hopes of averting paralysis of much of this city during the Olympic Games, traffic engineers here are developing a grand strategy based on a simple idea: the bus.

title: CULT/CURTIS C13 A Restless Philanthropist
description: CIVIC-MINDED community leaders, ever on the prowl for new big contributors to their various causes, are pursuing 47-year-old Leslie H. Wexner these days, and no wonder. The Ohioan, who yesterday made a tender offer for Carter Hawley Hale Stores, a major retail chain, is one of the nation's new multimillionaires, word of which has not been lost on New York.

title: Strike Is Settled At New York Post
description: The New York Post resumed publication yesterday morning, after the settling of a two-day strike against the paper by The Newspaper Guild of New York.

title: No Headline
description: Trace Element Tablets Bring Warning by U.S.

title: CASINO BETS, TAX CUT, VOTE ON DRINK DIE
description: This has not been a good season for some of the more prominent political people and issues in Florida.

title: High Court Won't Hear A Lawsuit Over 'Roots'
description: The Supreme Court today refused to revive a lawsuit filed by a woman who said that Alex Haley had borrowed from her copyrighted autobiographical book in writing his own book ''Roots.''

title: TENDER LOVING HEALTH CARE SERVICES reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss

title: VRDOLYAK IS RE-ELECTED BY CHICAGO DEMOCRATS
description: Edward R. Vrdolyak was easily re-elected chairman of the Cook County Democratic Central Committee today, despite Mayor Harold Washington's vows to force him out.

title: GENERALS OPTIMISTIC ON WALKER
description: Almost all was well with the Generals today.

title: SCHOLAR HARSHLY CRITICIZES EDUCATION RESEARCH
description: EDUCATION research has failed to improve education in the classrooms. Research may advance the researchers' careers but it does little to help teachers.

title: THRIFTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
The U.N. Today April 3, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: PITCHER FOR TWINS HAS INTRIGUING PAST
MASTERS ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
SHELLING IN BEKAA RAISES FARMERS' FEARS
description: For part of the day on Sunday, Miriam Jaroush was frightened that Syria and Israel might be going to war.

title: Market Place; Analysts Split On Car Makers
description: FORTUNES of the Big Three auto makers rebounded dramatically in 1983 as General

title: THE VALUE OF FILM LIBRARIES
description: How much is Snow White worth?

title: Topics ; Precision / Revision ; Pointless Decimal
description: Walter Mondale may or may not win the New York primary today, and he may or may not defeat Gary Hart by the 7.6-point margin reported Friday by the Marist College Institute of Public Opinion. But one thing is sure.

title: What's Fair on the Air?
description: As the campaign hurtles on, past the New York Democratic primary, a constructive proposal to open up political television is only plodding along in Congress. It's Senator Bob Packwood's Freedom of Expression bill and it deserves to go faster.

title: BILL REKINDLES DEBATE ON VALUE OF JOB TRAINING
description: A BILL now making its way through Congress, the reauthorization of the Vocational Education Act of 1963, is drawing attention to an area of education largely ignored by the many recent reports that have emphasized academic preparation for college.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I hope to carry out a dignified, thoroughly professional investigation.'' - Jacob A. Stein, the independent counsel who will investigate accusations against Edwin Meese 3d. (A21:2.)

title: Dissidents Win Vote for Board
description: Management Assistance Inc. said yesterday that a group of dissident shareholders, led by Asher B. Edelman, had won a proxy contest for 4 of the 10 seats on the company's board. The outcome was disclosed at the company's annual meeting by Raymond P. Kurshan, Management Assistance's president and chairman.

title: NO NICE WORDS IN MOSCOW
description: Despite almost daily dispatches from Los Angeles, the Soviet press has yet to find anything nice to say about preparations for the Summer Olympics.

title: WITH PUNJAB THE PRIZE, SIKH MILITANTS SPREAD TERROR
description: There have never been more than about 500 of them, the authorities say. Most are in their late teens or early 20's. Most are religious militants. Some are ordinary criminals who have simply seized an opportunity. A few are old-line Maoist revolutionaries whose main movement in India was crushed more than a decade ago.

title: EXPORTING PRODUCTS RECALLED IN THE U.S.
description: A Federal agency has begun to consider the question whether products made to be sold in the United States but withdrawn after being found too hazardous can be exported for sale abroad.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: Islander Dilemma
description: The Islanders have a concern as they open the playoffs tomorrow night against the Rangers, and, strangely enough, it concerns the exceptionally talented Mike Bossy.

title: 5TH OFFICER QUITS IN HONDURAS SHIFT
description: A fifth Honduran general has resigned in a shake-up that included the ouster of the armed forces commander, the Honduran Government announced today.

title: BIG TESTS AMONG BLACKS ARE AHEAD FOR JACKSON IN THREE CITIES
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson has won as much as 79 percent of the black vote in the Democratic Presidential primaries so far, but three of his biggest tests lie ahead.

title: Seoul Says North Korea Abducted 2 Celebrities
description: Government officials contended today that two South Korean celebrities, a movie actress and her former husband, a director, had been kidnapped by North Korean agents and held hostage for six years.

title: Yanks Are Rained Out
description: The weather cooperated with the Royals' George Brett Plan today, raining out their scheduled season opener with the Yankees. ''Our goal,'' said Dan Quisenberry, the Royals' resident wit, ''is to get as many games rained out as we can the first six to eight weeks that George is out.''

title: British Predict Rise in Output
description: Economic growth in Britain is expected to continue into 1985, but unemployment will remain little changed, at about three million people, for the next two years, the Confederation of British Industry said today. The confederation reported in its survey of manufacturing trends that output at British manufacturing companies in the next four months was expected to be the highest since 1976.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. Royals, at Kansas City, Mo. With the teams' season opener rained out yesterday, the starting pitchers will remain the same: Ron Guidry for the Yankees and Bud Black for the Royals.

title: HEIN-WERNER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: QUESTION FOR THE F.C.C. ON 'DERELICT' STATIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: Yoko Ono Is Told To Pay Producer
description: A Manhattan jury yesterday ordered Yoko Ono to pay more than $2.5 million to a record producer who helped her late husband, the musician John Lennon, produce the 1980 album ''Double Fantasy.''

title: AMERICAN MEDICAL BUILDINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $16,186,000 for the latest year and $1,947,000 for the previous year.

title: LACK OF WATER GIVES BAD ODDS TO TEXAS RICE FARM
description: Soaring production costs, high interest rates and water scarcity have recently plagued farmers in most parts of the country, but for Southeast Texas rice growers like Albert Thompson Jr., things have been especially tough.

title: SUBURBAN DISTRICTS DROPPED IN KANSAS CITY SCHOOL CASE Kansas City,Mo.,April 2 (UPI) - A Federal district judge dramatically modified Kansas City's metropolitan school desegregation suit today by dropping 11 predominantly white suburban school districts as defendants.
description: The decision left only the predominantly black Kansas City School District, the state of Missouri and the Federal Government as defendants in the trial, which began four months ago.

title: WARD ORDERS MORE ARRESTS IN DOMESTIC VIOLENCE
description: New police procedures intended to provide increased protection to victims of domestic violence were announced yesterday by Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward.

title: COLECO SAYS BANKS CUT ITS CREDIT
description: Coleco Industries, the troubled home computer and video game manufacturer, said in a filing Friday with the Securities and Exchange Commission that its bankers had reduced the company's lines of credit by $33 million since the beginning of the year.

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. President Says Hart Insults Unions
description: Lane Kirkland, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, said today that Senator Gary Hart is one of ''that old breed of politicians who professes to love workers and insults their organizations.''

title: MEXICANS RESCHEDULED AT PRICE OF AUSTERITY
description: Mexico, with foreign debts of about $80 billion, has succeeded in the last nine months in restructuring nearly all the payments that were to come due by the end of this year.

title: No Consolation In Second Place
description: Some race horses have a penchant for finishing second as often as champions win, and that penchant can baffle and infuriate their trainers. It usually happens at the lower levels of racing, where cheap horses have bad habits, such as pulling themselves up or hanging when they reach the lead, something that top horses are not supposed to do.

title: BRIEFS
description: Allied Corp, a chemicals company in Morris Township, N.J., said its Bendix Guidance System division had concluded an agreement to acquire Timex Corp.'s Gyro and Accelerometer product lines.

title: STAGE: 'THIN ICE,' DOMESTIC COMEDY
description: -year run, the marriage is coming apart. Contributing to the collapse are the machinations of the couple's best friends, a free-loving woman with a penchant for choosing the wrong man, and a homosexual sculptor. In Jeffrey Haddow's domestic comedy-drama ''Thin Ice'' (at the WPA Theater), the ''skating'' is as perilous as it is predictable.

title: JAPAN, U.S. TO DISCUSS BEEF, CITRUS
description: Japan's Minister of Agriculture is coming to Washington this week with the ''authority and flexibility'' to settle a rancorous dispute with the United States over beef and citrus trade, according to Chikara Higashi, a special emissary of Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone.

title: EDWARD C. COLE, 79, A TEACHER OF DRAMA FOR 41 YEARS AT YALE
description: Edward C. Cole, a member of the Yale University Drama School faculty for 41 years until his retirement in 1971, died March 24, two days before his 80th birthday, while visiting his son, James, in Pittsburgh. He lived in Branford, Conn.

title: SOVIET GROUP MEETS WITH LEBANESE MINISTER
description: A Soviet delegation met today with Lebanon's Foreign Minister and a Soviet spokesman later hailed the scrapping of Lebanon's troop withdrawal accord with Israel as a major step toward peace.

title: No Headline
description: THE RETREAT. By Aharon Appelfeld. Translated by Dalya Bilu. 164 pages. E. P. Dutton Inc. $12.95.

title: BRANCH INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $3.8 million.

title: MISSION HAILED IN INDIA AS STEP INTO SPACE
description: A joint mission with the Soviet Union that is to put India's first man in space on Tuesday is being hailed here both as a modest step forward in this country's plans to explore space and as an example of the cooperative relationship that has developed between India and the Soviet Union.

title: TUESDAY, APRIL 3, 1984 International
description: Three Arab terrorists armed with guns and grenades attacked crowds of shoppers in the heart of Jerusalem, wounding 48 people, one of them critically. Israeli shopkeepers and pedestrians fatally wounded one terrorist, and the police said the two others were captured. Some officials said the attack was the most brazen terrorist action in the city in memory. (Page A1, Columns 1-2.) Iran can produce chemical arms and may retaliate if Iraq continues its use of such weapons, Iran's delegate to the United Nations said. The delegate, Rajai Khorassani, said 40 Iranians have died as a result of Iraq's use of chemical weapons. (A12:3-4.)

title: UNCONVENTIONAL LAWYER WITH A NEW TASK
description: He is an accomplished three-pin juggler and an urbane intellectual who reads broadly and deeply, with a passion for 18th- and 19th-century literary criticism. He dresses ''like the Great Gatsby,'' with bow ties and double-breasted suits, and he has never registered to vote. And, several Washington lawyers who know him agree, Jacob A. Stein is ''very well regarded as a first-rate trial lawyer and a person of integrity,'' in the words of John H. Pickering, who preceded Mr. Stein as president of the District of Columbia Bar.

title: Mobil Offering
description: The Mobil Corporation said yesterday that it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the sale of $2.5 billion of debentures due in 2004.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Alcan Aluminium Ltd., Montreal, has elected to its board John F. Burlingame, a vice chairman of the General Electric Co. in Fairfield, Conn.

title: JUDGE, TAKING STAND, DENIES ACCEPTING BRIBES FROM BROTHEL OWNER
description: Federal District Judge Harry E. Claiborne took the stand today to deny testimony that he had taken $85,000 in bribes to influence court decisions and then had scurried around to cover up his actions.

title: HARTMARX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
NEW 2-HOUR WEEKLY T.V. VARIETY SHOW SATURDAY
description: ''A touch of Barbara Walters, a touch of '60 Minutes' and a big touch of Ed Sullivan'' is the way that the co-executive producer Gary Smith describes his new variety series, ''On Stage America,'' which makes its debut next Saturday evening on Channel 5 in New York and in other major cities.

title: ON WESTWAY FUNDING BEFORE THE FINAL O.K.
description: To the Editor:

title: SPARROW GETS 24 IN KNICKS' VICTORY
description: As the Knicks' playmaker, Rory Sparrow has the job of setting up his teammates. But last night Sparrow was asked to do more; he was asked to score, and to cool down Chicago's Quintin Dailey in the second half.

title: SIKH GUNMEN KILL HINDU IN PUNJAB
description: Sikh gunmen shot and killed a Hindu opposition leader today in Amritsar, the holy Sikh city in the northern state of Punjab, and crowds of Hindus attacked buses and stores in retaliation.

title: Addendum
description: * Self magazine increasing its circulation rate base to one million, from 950,000, with the September issue.

title: VOLUME UP
description: Stock prices dropped sharply yesterday in accelerated trading because of growing apprehension over rising interest rates and an unconfirmed report that a major investment house had begun a large stock- selling program. Attempts to discover the firm's identity were unsuccessful.

title: Fire Reported to Ravage Huge Tract in Indonesia
description: A forest fire in Indonesia last year destroyed an area three times the size of Lebanon and represents one of the worst environmental disasters of the century, the International Union for Conservation of Nature said today.

title: . . . The Punch Line . . .
description: A vivid speaker, the Rev. Jesse

title: ON WESTWAY FUNDING BEFORE THE FINAL O.K.
description: To the Editor:

title: Retrial Is Ordered In 3 Jersey Killings
description: A state appeals court ordered a new trial for a Newark man convicted of three murders, ruling today that statements he made to the police after his arrest should not have been admitted as evidence at his trial.

title: Occidental Notes Carry 12 1/4% Rate
description: The Occidental Petroleum Company is selling $350 million of subordinated variable-rate notes at a price of 100 through Drexel Burnham Lambert as sole underwriter.

title: KASPAROV AND SMYSLOV IN A DRAW
description: Spirited counterplay got Gary Kasparov of the Soviet Union a draw against his countryman Vasily Smyslov in the 10th game of their final candidates chess match Sunday. The 20-year-old Kasparov retained his 3-point lead, with the score now standing at Kasparov 6 1/2, Smyslov 3 1/2.

title: BRIEFING
description: Campaigns of Yore

title: CSX Profit Soars
description: The CSX Corporation, benefiting from a major acquisition last year, reported yesterday that it nearly tripled its earnings in the first quarter.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Kleinwort to Acquire ACLI Securities Firm
description: Kleinwort, Benson Ltd. a major British merchant banking firm, has agreed to acquire ACLI Government Securities, a Chicago-based primary dealer in Treasury securities, from the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation.

title: Man Survives 24-Story Fall
description: Gilmer MacDougald, a 38-year-old window washer, considers himself ''fortunate to be alive'' after plummeting 24 floors down the side of a downtown hotel. Hospital officials this afternoon said he was in ''critical but stable'' condition'' with two legs, two ankles and an elbow broken and rope burns on his hands. When his safety harness gave way Sunday he grabbed a safety rope to slow his descent and slammed into the wall two or three times on the way down.

title: KOCH SAYS CITY GETS TOO LITTLE IN STATE BUDGET
description: Saying New York City had been ''shortchanged'' by $60 million, Mayor Koch warned yesterday that the new state budget would mean ''fewer police officers, teachers, parks workers, street repairers, street cleaners and others to provide essential services.''

title: VIEWS OF WEISSKOPF ON SCIENCE AND MORALS
description: VICTOR WEISSKOPF is an elder statesman of science, a giant of modern physics, an adviser to the Pope. In ''The World According to Weisskopf,'' his career is seen as a kind of moral voyage through the disasters of our time. The program, part of the ''Nova'' public television series, will be seen on Channel 13 at 8 o'clock tonight.

title: Schub on Stage Fright
description: Turbulence. Tremors. Palpitations.

title: YANKS RAINED OUT
description: Like the director of a new show that bombs on the road, Dave Johnson watched his ''new'' Mets open the season with an 8-1 loss to the Cincinnati Reds today, and said: ''Inauspicious, right? A very inauspicious beginning.''

title: 7 INDICTED BY U.S. IN AN EXPORT CASE BOSTON, April 2 (AP) - Seven men and five corporations in Switzerland, Canada and the United States have been named in a 23-count indictment in connection with an international ring that allegedly shipped banned computer systems to the Soviet Union and East Germany, the United States Attorney's office here said today.
description: The 12 defendants were named in sealed indictments that were returned in Boston March 6, said William Weld, United States Attorney. The indictments were unsealed today.

title: JUSTICES TO DECIDE ON SILENT PRAYER IN PUBLIC SCHOOLS
description: The Supreme Court, reaffirming its rulings that organized prayer in public schools violates the Constitution, agreed today to decide whether ''moment of silence'' laws are unconstitutional as well.

title: Witness in Murder Trial To Withdraw Affidavit
description: A key witness in Claus von B"ulow's effort to get a new trial on charges he tried to murder his wealthy wife with insulin injections says he has changed his mind and will not testify.

title: NETTLES BOOK HARSH ON YANKEE OWNER
description: It was, according to Graig Nettles, an 11-year stint on a soap opera that could be called, ''As the Clubhouse Turns.''

title: Debt Issues
description: * Convergent Technologies Inc. , a microcomputer company in Santa Clara, Calif., said it was considering filing later this month for a public offering of subordinated debentures. The company gave no further details.

title: Brenda Biram, Editor, 53,With Johnson Publishing
description: Brenda Biram, the former editor of the book division of the Johnson Publishing Company, died of a kidney ailment in New York Hospital last Thursday. She was 53 years old and lived in Greenwich Village.

title: ARTRA GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $6,293,000 for the quarter and $8,449,000 for the year, extraordinary credits of $5,000 for the quarter and $158,000 for the year and a provision of $2,360,000 for the quarter and year for the writedown of oil and gas properties. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $5,988,000 for the quarter and $4,535,000 for the year, a provision of $2,050,000 for the quarter and year for the writedown of oil and gas properties and a provision of $2,102,000 for the quarter and year for estimated costs to complete the divestiture of operating assets of Harvel Industries.

title: Bridge: Glubok and Rosmarin Lead Survivors in Grand National
description: Two determined teams snatched last-ditch victories in the Grand National Team semifinals at the Beverly East Club in New York City Sunday night.

title: MILLER, H, & SONS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Devil's Bag Runs Well
description: Devil's Bag, making his first public appearance in New York since winning the Champagne Stakes last October, worked a strong mile in 1:38 yesterday at Aqueduct. The 3-year-old colt, who won his first 6 career starts before finishing fourth in the Flamingo Stakes at Hialeah March 3, is preparing for the Gotham Stakes at Aqueduct on Saturday.

title: DELTA DRILLING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LAMSON & SESSIONS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $13,133,000 for the quarter and $20,971,000 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $3,016,000 for the quarter and $231,000 for the year.

title: CARTER HAWLEY BID BY LIMITED
description: The Limited Inc., a Columbus, Ohio, retailer, last night announced a two-step takeover bid for the Carter Hawley Hale Stores - whose retail interests include Neiman-Marcus, Bergdorf Goodman and Waldenbooks - for a price of about $1.1 billion.

title: MASSEY-FERGUSON LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Results are in U. S. dollars. Massey-Ferguson recently changed its year-end from Oct. 31 to Jan. 31. Year-ago results are for the three months ended Jan. 31, 1983 and the 12 months ended Oct. 31, 1982.

title: NEVADA RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: '78 ETHICS ACT SETS PROCEDURE IN SUCH CASES
description: The Ethics in Government Act of 1978 is a broad measure that was a fruit of the Watergate scandal of the early 1970's.

title: Tracy-Locke Wins
description: Tracy-Locke/BBDO in Dallas has won the shootout for the La Quinta Motors Inns business, which is expected to bill $2.5 million. The 15- year-old client operated 150 properties from Florida to California, all in the midpriced range. The previous agency was Cunningham & Walsh.

title: AUTOMATIX INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
QUENN EMBROILED IN MIDEAST DISPUTE
description: Queen Elizabeth II, who returned from a visit to Jordan last week, has caused public criticism and some alarm among British Jews with her expressions of sympathy for the Palestinian cause and her seeming disapproval of Israeli occupation of the West Bank.

title: Mission Insurance
description: The American Financial Corporation said it is buying more common stock in Mission Insurance Group Inc., increasing its ownership to 49.9 percent, from 20.7 percent.

title: INFLATION ISN'T BEATEN
description: During the 1980 Presidential campaign, both Democrats and Republicans proclaimed inflation the nation's No. 1 problem. ''Double-digit inflation'' become a household term. During the current campaign, the inflation issue is notable by its absence - except for Republican boasting about conquering inflation. And, indeed, the reduction in inflation has been remarkable. In the summer of 1980, consumer prices were rising at more than 12 percent per year; in early 1984, at 5.5 percent.

title: CONCERT: THE PREMIERE OF LEIGHTON'S 'FANTASY'
description: IF it were not for Louis Spohr and

title: Topics; Precision/Revision; Excuse
description: We once knew a fourth-grade girl who insisted to the teacher that ''The dog ate my homework.'' R. Leonard Vance may have known her, too. Mr. Vance, who heads health standards at the Occupational Safety and Health Administration, is the subject of internal documents sent to a House subcommittee. They indicate that he blocked efforts to restrict use of a cancer-causing chemical.

title: ALLIGATORS IN LOVE
description: The courting behavior of the American alligator has long been shrouded in the underwater world. As a result, scientists had learned little about the amorous activities of huge reptiles whose jaws can crush a deer.

title: Nykoluk, Neilson Out
description: Mike Nykoluk, the former Ranger assistant coach, was described by Harold Ballard at one point this season as ''too nice a guy'' to fire. But at some other point, Ballard, the owner of the Toronto Maple Leafs, must have changed his mind.

title: DAIRY MART CONVENIENCE STORES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
CORRECTIONS
description: The obituary last Saturday of a former radio and television journalist who covered the Soviet Union in the 1950's misidentified her. She was Helen Hall.

title: PETROTECH INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $8.7 million for the latest year and $1.3 million for the earlier year.

title: Article 096580 -- No Title
description: A police detective who won $6 million in the state Lotto game says he will give half of his prize to a waitress who helped him pick the winning numbers.

title: Kelly Honorary Official For Ballet-Contest Gala
description: Gene Kelly will serve as honorary chairman for the July 2 gala benefit of the New York International Ballet Competition.

title: A SCIENTIFIC LOOK AT THE SEAL HUNT
description: -AUX-MEULES, Quebec

title: ICAHN MAKES OFFER FOR ACF INDUSTRIES
description: Carl C. Icahn said yesterday that an investor group he heads had offered $53 a share for ACF Industries. Shareholders of ACF are already scheduled to vote April 25 on a $50- a-share offer from another company.

title: GROWING UP IN SUBURBAN DENMARK
description: AT first glance, the protagonists of Bille August's ''Zappa'' look as though they must lead charmed lives. Tall, slender, uncommonly handsome young Danes, they are reaching adolescence during an era of quiet prosperity (the year is 1961). Their families are solidly upper middle class; their suburb is pretty and serene. What can go wrong for boys like Bjorn (Adam Tonsberg) and Sten (Peter Reichardt)? Mr. August's film, which is named for Sten's sinister, carnivorous pet fish, does a powerful job of tracing the boys' growing delinquency.

title: Man Kills Wife in a Hallway Of the Labor Dept. Building
description: A man, shooting rapidly with a revolver, shot and killed his estranged wife in a hallway at the Labor Department today, then shot himself, the police and witnesses said.

title: LEGISLATURE ACTED TO MUFFLE CONSUMER VOICE, CUOMO SAYS
description: Governor Cuomo said today that the Legislature had included language in the state budget that would ''dampen the consumer voice'' and ''help Lilco'' in its proceedings before the Public Service Commission.

title: REAGAN DISMISSES SATELLITE ARMS TALKS
description: President Reagan cautioned Congress today against seeking talks on control of weapons designed to destroy orbiting satellites.

title: Loss Left Him Stronger For '86, Cranston Says
description: Senator Alan Cranston says that losing his quest for the Democratic Presidential nomination will make him a stronger candidate for re-election to the United States Senate in 1986.

title: JACKSON
description: Most of New York State's 285 delegates to the Democratic National Convention will be chosen in today's Presidential primary. The polls will be open from 6 A.M. to 9 P.M. in New York City and in Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester, Rockland, Orange, Ulster and Erie Counties. They will be open from noon until 9 P.M. elsewhere in the state.

title: CSX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
RANGERS AND ISLANDERS EXCHANGE COMPLIMENTS
description: The Rangers say they know how good the Islanders are. Reminders aren't necessary.

title: Steel Import Fraud Fought
description: The Customs Service stepped up efforts to halt steel import fraud today in the newest phase of a crackdown called Operation Tripwire, officials said.

title: No Headline
description: PAMELA REED, who won acclaim Off Broadway five years ago as the raging girl in Marsha Norman's ''Getting Out,'' and who plays the rebellious, frightened wife of the astronaut Gordon Cooper in the film ''The Right Stuff,'' is busy with four other roles right now.

title: BROAD S.E.C. INQUIRY ON JOURNAL WRITER REPORTED
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission appears to be conducting a wide-ranging investigation into illicit profits from securities trading based on information improperly provided by a reporter at The Wall Street Journal.

title: 2 Top Economic Aides Are Dismissed in Chile
description: President Augusto Pinochet dismissed his two top economic ministers today in a Cabinet shake-up that was seen as a response to nationwide protests against his military regime.

title: Advertising Pages Up
description: The Publishers Information Bureau has reported that in February member magazines increased their advertising pages 5.4 percent, to 11,174, over the same month last year. Advertising revenues increased 12.1 percent, to $325 million. February marked the 14th consecutive month of revenue increases, the bureau said.

title: Nation of Islam Leader Warns Black Reporter
description: Minister Louis Farrakhan, leader of the Nation of Islam, is vowing to ''make an example'' of a black reporter for The Washington Post to force other blacks covering the Rev. Jesse Jackson to be less critical of the candidate.

title: President Schedules A News Conference
description: President Reagan will hold a news conference Wednesday at 8 P.M. at the White House, his spokesman, Larry Speakes, announced today.

title: CORNING GLASS WORKS reports earnings for Qtr to March 25
description: b-Including a gain of $5.9 million from equity in earnings of associated companies. c-Including a nonrecurring gain of $22.2 million, or $1.05 a share, from an exchange of Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corp. common shares for shares of Corning Glass and a gain of $1.8 million from equity in earnings of associated companies.

title: 'SKYLINE,' FROM SPAIN
description: GUSTAVO (Antonio Resines), a freelance photographer from Spain, arrives in New York on a summer holiday in hopes of making contacts that will further his career in this country. A stocky, well-bred young man full of self-assurance, he talks confidently of Life and Newsweek as his two most likely opportunities.

title: Fourth Body Found In Seattle Hills Area
description: The remains of another body, the fourth in three days, were found today on a wooded hillside above the Green River Valley, and the authorities said the bones were probably those of the 20th victim of a sexual psychopath who has been killing young prostitutes.

title: STRAWBERRY'S REVENGE
SHOREHAM PLAN FOR TESTSGOES TO A NEW PANEL
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has named a substitute panel to consider a new proposal by the Long Island Lighting Company for beginning low-power nuclear testing at its Shoreham plant.

title: Stallions Defeat Breakers, 31-17
description: Chuck Clanton intercepted 3 passes and Joe Cribbs rushed for 162 yards tonight as Birmingham beat New Orleans, 31-17.

title: CAMPBELL'S SOUP-TO-NUTS PLAN
description: ''If you think of the food business as being your desk top, picture a wide segment in the middle that takes up about half of the desk,'' says John Morris, vice president of corporate development at the Campbell Soup Company. ''that's where Campbell is today. What we want to do is get on either side.''

title: NVF CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After earnings of $7.9 million from discontinued operations and a tax credit of $623,000 for the quarter and year.

title: Shultz and Canadian Sign Skagit River Pact
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Canada's Foreign Secretary, Allan J. MacEachen, signed a long-sought treaty today to prevent flooding of a scenic river valley and insure a needed energy source for Seattle, Wash.

title: Dawkins Uncertain
description: Strained ligaments in his right wrist kept Darryl Dawkins, the Nets' regular center, from participating in a team workout yesterday. Afterward he accompanied the Nets to Milwaukee, where they will face the Bucks tonight, but his status for the game will not be determined until today. Also questionable is Kelvin Ransey, the point guard, who has a stomach virus that also kept him on the sidelines during practice.

title: OVER 30 CASINOS IN LAS VEGAS PICKETED BY STRIKERS
description: About 17,200 employees of three dozen gambling resorts went on strike today, setting up picket lines along the Las Vegas Strip and forcing cancellation of shows by prominent entertainers.

title: CITIZENS UTILITIES CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Year-ago share earnings have been adjusted for intervening stock dividends.

title: Chinese Back Nuclear Arms
description: A senior Chinese official told a European Parliament delegation today that China supports a nuclear deterrent in Western Europe against the Soviet Union. ''If a lion is going to attack you, you've got to be in a position to frighten it away,'' Peng Zhen, chairman of the National People's Congress, was quoted as telling the delegation from the legislative branch of the Common Market. It was the first time a Chinese leader has been quoted as endorsing nuclear weapons in Western Europe.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: TUESDAY, APRIL 3, 1984

title: No Headline
description: Time Well Bought for Argentina The intricate deal to ward off an immediate Argentine debt crisis was a notable stopgap. Four heavily indebted Latin American governments pooled funds temporarily to rescue a sister republic, with an assist from major banks and a backup commitment from the United States Treasury. The package is sensible, good politics and good public relations. But it doesn't solve the debt problem.

title: HOUSTON'S PLAYERS BLAME EACH OTHER
description: Tonight, the Houston Cougars passed the blame better than they had passed the basketball.

title: Ratings Improve
description: The United States Football League had been eagerly awaiting the game Sunday between the Generals and the Express, hoping that the presence of the visiting New Jerseyans and Steve Young's professional debut would finally enable the Express to make some impact in the Los Angeles market.

title: Reagan Sees Schmidt
description: President Reagan and former Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany conferred for 20 minutes in the Oval Office today, a White House spokesman said. They discussed the world economy, European unemployment and East-West relations, he said. Also present were Vice President Bush, Secretary of State George P. Shultz, Robert C. McFarlane, the national security adviser, and three senior White House officials.

title: YALE PROFESSORS PULL IN THE CROWDS
description: These days, some of New Haven's largest ''traffic jams'' take place inside the Yale Law School.

title: DRIVER-HARRIS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses of $358,000 for the quarter and $1,667,000 for the year from the company's British subsidiary. c-Net loss including gains on the sale of real estate of $2,054,000.

title: STEELE COMMAGER, PROFESSOR OF CLASSICS AT COLUMBIA, DIES
description: Steele Commager, a professor of classics at Columbia University, died of cancer yesterday at the St. Luke's- Roosevelt Hospital Center. He was 51 years old and lived on the Upper West Side.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: At Karl Lagerfeld's party amid the Museum

title: Hollis Frampton Dead at 48;Film Maker, Photographer
description: Hollis Frampton, an influential avant-garde film maker and photographer, died Friday after a brief illness.

title: MCGREGOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $130,000 for the quarter and $1,340,000 for the year. The company went public in October 1983.

title: SAYING GOODBYE SPEAKS VOLUMES
description: PEOPLE always seem to be leaving, moving from one home to another, changing schools, lovers or jobs. Some leave-takings are momentous, some relatively trivial, like changing offices. But, in the view of a number of theorists, nearly all such departures resonate with the core of one's being, an outlook on life shaped so early and running so deep that it can be said to characterize one's entire personality.

title: HART
description: Most of New York State's 285 delegates to the Democratic National Convention will be chosen in today's Presidential primary. The polls will be open from 6 A.M. to 9 P.M. in New York City and in Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester, Rockland, Orange, Ulster and Erie Counties. They will be open from noon until 9 P.M. elsewhere in the state. In his last full day of campaigning before the New York Presidential primary, Senator Gary Hart stressed the positive at rallies in Buffalo, Albany and New York City.

title: Richard Weiner Inc. To Get Silver Anvil
description: Richard Weiner Inc., the public relations firm, will be getting a Silver Anvil Award, the most important recognition in its industry, for its contribution to the chaos that marked the pre-Christmas introduction of Coleco Industries' Cabbage Patch Kids dolls. It will be one of 29 awards given out by the Public Relations Society of America at its annual banquet on June 7 at the Grand Hyatt Hotel.

title: ASTRADYNE COMPUTER INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $60,100 for the quarter and $286,400 for the year. c-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $438,173 for the quarter and $670,943 for the year. Corrected from Saturday's editions.

title: 'TO DIE WITH OUR WITS AND DIGNITY INTACT'
description: To the Editor:

title: Steel Output Up in Week
description: Steel production rose to 2.118 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, an increase of 3.3 percent from the previous week's 2.050 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute said yesterday.

title: GEORGETOWN 84, HOUSTON 75
description: When the confrontation of the 7-foot centers never materialized, the national championship was left to be taken by two freshmen.

title: PRESS CLUB IS RETURNING TO ITS ROOTS
description: Like a dowdy dowager who has recently come into the chips, the National Press Club is attracting the kinds of people who crowded around in its earlier and better days.

title: ADVANCED COMPUTER TECHNIQUES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
CORRECTION
description: Because of a transmission error, an article Sunday about a conference on Dwight D. Eisenhower's Presidency omitted a word from a quotation by a participant, Dr. Loretta Sharon Wyatt. Concerning Latin America, she said, ''Eisenhower and his advisers were not inevitably antagonistic to revolutions in that area.''

title: Hanson Interested In U. S. Industries
description: U. S. Industries said it had received a letter from Hanson Industries in which Hanson asked to discuss acquiring U. S. Industries for more than $20 a share. U. S. Industries, a maker of industrial products based in Stamford, Conn., said Hanson had given no specific price. It said Hanson, a subisidiary of Hanson Trust, a Britsh concern, is a conglomerate.

title: SILVA: ARCHITECT OF DEBT PLAN
description: Argentina could be allowed as much as three months to reimburse the four Latin American countries that helped it through its interest-payment crisis last weekend, Jesus Silva Herzog, the Finance Minister of Mexico, said here today.

title: . . . And the Image
description: Warren Beatty, the actor and a

title: Radioactive Gases Detected At Nevada Nuclear Test Site
description: A small amount of radioactive gas seeped from the desert floor Sunday after a nuclear weapon test 85 miles northwest of Las Vegas, the Federal Department of Energy said today.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Cliff Ellis , the former coach at South Alabama, has been named head basketball coach at Clemson. Ellis, who compiled a 171-84 record in nine seasons there, replaces Bill Foster, who left for the University of Miami. . . . Anthony Carter, the fleet wide receiver for the Michigan Panthers who broke his left arm in a game Sunday, will be out six to eight weeks, the team said. . . . The Houston Astros placed Joe Sambito, the left- hander who is trying to recover from elbow surgery two years ago, on the 21-day disabled list. . . . Dusty Baker, the veteran outfielder dropped by the Los Angeles Dodgers, has been signed by the San Francisco Giants, who had pursued him for six weeks. . . Terry Bradshaw, the Pittsburgh Steeler quarterback whose injured right elbow limited his playing time last season to only half a game, is now throwing without pain, according to a physical therapist who works for Bradshaw's surgeon. . . . Mike Norris, the former Oakland ace, has been placed on the 60-day disabled list by the A's and may not pitch this season.

title: AMERICAN FAMILY PIZZA reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Western Default
description: The Western Preferred Corporation said that it is in default on an $82.5 million bank loan and that its 1983 financial statement has been qualified by its accountants, Peat Marwick.

title: Ousted Soviet Director To Stage Opera in Italy
description: The Soviet director Yuri Lyubimov will stage ''Rigoletto'' to open the 1984 Maggio Musicale, festival organizers announced today.

title: Mattel Plastic in Toys Shows In X-Rays if It Is Swallowed
description: The Mattel Corporation, one of the country's largest toy makers, has developed a new type of plastic that shows up on X-rays with the hope it will help doctors reduce deaths and injuries among children who swallow or inhale small toy parts.

title: I.R.A. Fugitive Fights Extradition
description: A member of the Irish Republican Army described at an extradition hearing yesterday how he broke out of a Belfast prison by dressing as a guard and duped soldiers into holding their fire by shouting that he was a policeman.

title: Abbado to Replace Maazel at Vienna Opera
description: Claudio Abbado, the conductor of the London Symphony, has accepted a five-year contract as musical director of Vienna's State Opera. The Vienna's general director, Helmut Drese, said the contract was to start Sept. 1, 1986.

title: West German Output
description: Preliminary figures showed industrial production in West Germany was unchanged in February from January after seasonal adjustment, but rose 8.4 percent from a year earlier, the Economics Ministry said today.

title: Colombia Announces Cease-Fire With Rebels
description: President Belisario Betancur has announced a cease-fire for next month between Colombian security forces and the country's largest guerrilla group.

title: 3 ARABS WITH GUNS AND GRENADES WOUND 48 IN JERUSALEM CROWDS
description: Three Arabs armed with guns and grenades attacked crowds of shoppers in the heart of Jerusalem today, wounding 48 people, one of them critically.

title: SHARON STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MONDALE
description: Most of New York State's 285 delegates to the Democratic National Convention will be chosen in today's Presidential primary. The polls will be open from 6 A.M. to 9 P.M. in New York City and in Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester, Rockland, Orange, Ulster and Erie Counties. They will be open from noon until 9 P.M. elsewhere in the state. From a windshield-wiper factory in the chill morning in Buffalo to a $1,000-a-plate dinner in balmy New York City at night, Walter F. Mondale made his final appeal for New York votes yesterday.

title: CONVICTED KILLER ON TRIAL IN TEXAS
description: Henry Lee Lucas, who has said he killed more than 100 women in 17 states, went on trial today on a charge that he strangled a woman and left her body in a highway culvert in 1979.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article March 15 about the new president of Fordham University incorrectly described its founding. Fordham opened in 1841 under the auspices of the Diocese of New York and was transferred to the control of the Society of Jesus in 1846.

title: BARUCH-FOSTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
REAGAN'S HOMELESS (CONT'D)
description: The numbers keep climbing inexorably. In 1981, city shelters were housing an average of 2,700 individual homeless men and women every night. In 1982, the figure rose to 3,333. In 1983, it became 4,359. This year, it's up to around 6,500 and still growing.

title: Jersey Party Chairman Endorses Senator Hart
description: James F. Maloney, the New Jersey Democratic chairman, today announced his endorsement of Senator Gary Hart of Colorado for the party's Presidential nomination.

title: VAGABOND HOTELS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a pretax charge of $2,071,000 in connection with operating results from and net writedowns of properties sold and to be sold and also includes pretax income from investment activities of $1,424,000. c-Includes a pretax gain of $1,484,000 from properties sold or to be sold.

description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues
