TELECRAFTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Net income

title: HEART ATTACKS AND THE EMOTIONS
description: IN the year before they had heart

title: College Basketball
description: SCORES OF N.C.A.A

title: Reaction By Vatican
description: The office of Archbishop Paul C. Marcinkus today dismissed as ''preposterous'' reports that a loan made by the Vatican bank he heads might be improper.

title: AMERICAN PACESETTER reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: MACNEAL-SCHWENDLER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
L.I. Man Guilty InAnesthesiaCase
description: A Federal jury today convicted a Long Island man of aggravated assault for causing a surgery patient irreversible brain damage while posing as a licensed anesthesiologist at the Walson Army Hospital in Fort Dix.

title: Town Is Pressed On Desegregation
description: The State Education Commissioner has ordered the Hillside Board of Education to submit immediately an ''acceptable'' desegregation plan and has rejected the board's request for a further delay in the 11-year-old dispute, officials said today.

title: COOK INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $125,000 for the quarter and $279,000 for the year. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $242,000 for the quarter and $111,000 for the year. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect the discontinuance of the the company's insurance agency brokerage subsidiary.

title: Holder Is Seeking Majority of Condec
description: The Condec Corporation said it had received notice from a lawyer for William F. Farley indicating that Mr. Farley intends to acquire 1.6 million shares of Condec, which would increase his stake to 51 percent. Mr. Farley and companies associated with him had owned 14.6 percent, Condec said.

title: Tosco Refinery
description: The Tosco Corporation said it had agreed to sell its Bakersfield, Calif., refinery to the Seaside Oil Company. Tosco, based in Santa Monica, did not disclose terms. It said it expected to close the deal by June 15.

title: NICARAGUA CHOOSES COUNCIL TO SUPERVISE SCHEDULED ELECTIONS
description: The Supreme Court named a three-member election council today to supervise the Nov. 4 voting for a president, vice president and 90-member parliament.

title: Scientists Unveil Prototype Orbiter
description: Lockheed and the National Aeronautics and Space Agency have unveiled a pie-shaped satellite, a prototype of satellites they hope will some day link the world so closely that anyone with a hand-held radio could communicate with anyone else with comparable equipment.

title: Business and the Law; Accountants Vs. Lawyers
description: EVEN though accountants and lawyers often do the same kind of work, especially in the tax area, their work papers may not be treated the same way by the courts.

title: ; WERE NEW YORK TO 'SECEDE' FROM THE POSTAL SERVICE
description: To the Editor:

title: SCOTTS SEABOARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $4,000 and an extraordinary loss of $66,000. c-After income from discontinued operations of $83,000. d-After income from discontinued operations of $388,000 and an extraordinary credit of $410,000. e-Net loss after income of $146,000 from discontinued operations.

title: EVANS PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a writedown of $26 million of investments in loans made by the company's home finance subsidiary. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $22,439,000 for the quarter and $45,703,000 for the year and writeoffs of $22.4 million for the quarter associated with the company's custom home building operations.

title: Board to Reveal Alvarado Charges
description: The New York City Board of Education said yesterday that it would make public today its administrative charges against suspended Schools Chancellor Anthony J. Alvarado for taking personal loans from subordinates.

title: CULTURAL REVOLT BUDDING IN POLAND DESPITE ARRESTS
description: A vast underground counterculture, much of it operating under the protection of the Roman Catholic Church, has quietly taken root all across Poland in recent months.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article Saturday about how the major Hollywood studios are attempting to deal with drug problems in the entertainment industry incorrectly named one of those allowed to enter drug diversion programs. The individual named should have been Mackenzie Phillips, not Michelle Phillips.

title: CONCERT: THE ST. LOUIS
description: THE Saint Louis Symphony filled the first half of its Carnegie Hall concert Friday night with Elgar's ''Enigma'' Variations and Brahms's ''N"anie'' - both Romantic works, one 85 years old, the other a little over 100. The other piece of the evening - John Adams's ''Harmonium'' - was written in 1981, but it too aspired to a breadth of sound and expressivity that was also Romantic in its way.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Chief Fund-Raisers Winding Up Efforts
description: As the race for today's New York State Democratic primary election reached a climax yesterday, the volunteer fund-raisers in the state for the three candidates were winding up their campaign efforts as well.

title: Housing Cost Index Steady
description: A seven-month trend toward more affordable housing - a combination of favorable financial terms and rising family income - ended in February, the National Association of Realtors said today.

title: Democrats May Not Seat Iowans at Convention
description: Iowa's insistence on keeping its Presidential caucus the first in the nation could cost delegates their seats and their beds at the Democratic National Convention.

title: LANDMARK LAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago results include operating results for three months of Dixie Savings & Loan Assn., acquired in September 1982.

title: Close Vote on Prayer Issue
description: A proposal for a daily school prayer acknowledging the ''laws of nature and of nature's God'' was slightly ahead tonight in the count of partial returns in a nonbinding referendum. With 13 of 19 precincts reporting, the vote was 2,437 to 2,232 in favor.

title: Volcker Asks Banking Law
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said yesterday that Congress should press ahead with comprehensive banking legislation or risk seeing state legislatures develop national banking policy on a piecemeal basis.

title: Somerset Deal
description: The Distillers Company said it had agreed to buy the Somerset Importers Company from Esmark Inc. for about $250 million.

title: Midlands Energy Stake Is Bought
description: An investment group led by Ivan Boesky said it had acquired 5.2 percent of the Midlands Energy Company. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the group said it includes the Seemala Corporation, the Ivan F. Boesky Corporation and the IFB Management Corporation, all of New York.

title: FIRST BLACK MISS AMERICA FINDS UNFORESEEN ISSUES
description: On her night off, Vanessa Williams arrived at the annual Jackie Robinson Awards Dinner in New York City and was immediately surrounded by a crowd of black teen-agers.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: AN ARREST IN SLAYING AT SCHOOL
description: Administrators and students will meet today to search for ways to prevent violence at Samuel J. Tilden High School after the slaying of one student and the arrest of another as her killer.

title: 4 Sentenced in Vienna In Neo-Nazi Case
description: Four men received prison terms and five others were put on probation at the conclusion of a trial of purported neo-Nazis that began last October.

title: NORTH AMERICAN BIOLOGICALS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a nonrecurring loss of approximately $210,000 relating to sales and use tax assessed by the Florida Department of Revenue and expenses of approximately $200,000 incurred from inventory writeoffs, a special accrual to reflect outstanding vacation entitlements as of year-end and the company's unsuccessful efforts to raise public money for its Diagnostic division. c-Net income.

title: SOVIET-U.S. TALKS GAIN ON CONSULATE AND CULTURE PACT
description: The United States and the Soviet Union have held talks that are reported to have covered plans for negotiations on consular exchanges.

title: RATE OF BIRTHS SHOWING DECLINE
description: As the baby-boom generation ages, the number of births in the United States is declining and there may be little prospect of reversing that trend, a new Government study indicates.

title: Mississippi Thrift Unit Shut
description: A Mississippi savings and loan association was declared insolvent today and shut down by Federal regulators who said it had engaged in ''questionable lending practices.''

title: Comings and Goings
description: Pete Vuckovich , the ailing Milwaukee Brewer right-hander, had surgery on his right shoulder, and afterward doctors pronounced the operation a success and said the 1982 Cy Young Award winner should be ready for action in three to four months. . . . When Wayne Gretzky was on the ice, the Edmonton Oilers scored 76 more goals than their opponents this season, and his plus-76 was good enough to lead the National Hockey League in plus-minus ratings. Second was Bryan Trottier , with plus-70, followed by his Islander teammate Mike Bossy , with plus-69.

title: PHARMACY CORP OF AMERICA INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Enstar Holders Get 'Watchdog'
description: Thomas Thompson, an investor, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that he had been asked by the chairman of the Enstar Corporation to serve as an ''independent watchdog'' for the company's shareholders. Mr. Thompson and a group of companies hold 1,225,590, or 7.13 percent, of Enstar's common shares outstanding.

title: HOUSE FOR CREDIT-CARD FEE BAN
description: The House of Representatives, by a 355-to-34 vote, approved legislation today to prohibit merchants from demanding extra fees from credit-card customers through mid-1985.

title: TELECOM CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $1,530,000. c-Net loss after a loss of $25,968,000 from discontinued operations and a gain of $9,571,000 from the early extinguishment of debt.

title: Call for Boxing Reform
description: A New Jersey Assemblyman said he planned to introduce legislation that would revamp the State Athletic Commission, require a yearlong test of thumbless gloves and generally institute boxing reforms proposed by the State Commission of Investigation in a report last month. ''To not act now is to act irresponsibly,'' said the legislator, Buddy Fortunato , an Essex County Democrat who heads the Assembly's Committee on Independent Authorities and Commissiond.

title: AMERICAN MEDICAL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-After net nonrecurring merger costs of $18.1 million for the quarter and 6 months.

title: Nicaragua Aide Seeks Arms in North Korea
description: Defense Minister Humberto Ortega of Nicaragua arrived in North Korea on an arms purchasing mission Monday, the official North Korean press agency reported today.

title: Jackson Deplores Threats Against Washington Writer
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson disavowed ''violence'' and ''intimidation'' after a supporter threatened to ''make an example'' of a reporter for The Washington Post who disclosed Mr. Jackson's comments about Jews.

title: OBJECTION TO SPONSOR STALLS AID FOR VETERANS OF VIETNAM
description: The war that divided the nation a decade ago divided the State Legislature today as Senate leaders blocked a bill to aid Vietnam veterans because the leading Assembly sponsor of the bill had been a conscientious objector to that war.

title: FAMILY PLANNING PROGRAMS
description: Family planning programs should be the responsibility of the states, rather than of the Federal Government, the Secretary of Health and Human Services said today.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: THE KLEZMER

title: NOVO CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $563,000 for the latest year and $229,000 for the earlier period.

title: New Creative Director For Smith, Burke
description: Smith, Burke & Azzam of Baltimore is simply crowing over the fact that it has captured Thomas S. Little, who was co-founder of the highly successful McDonald & Little, Atlanta, to be its creative director.

title: DANCE: SPINA TAP TROUPE IN 'SWING'
description: THE members of the Peggy Spina Tap Company tapped their way through ''Syncopate and Swing,'' the tap revue they presented Sunday night at the Marymount Manhattan Theater, and as long as Miss Spina was on stage everything was fine.

title: Xerox Typewriter Offered for $4,900
description: The Xerox Corporation introduced an electronic typewriter capable of word word processing, the $4,900 Memorywriter 640. The machine has a display that shows 20 lines of type and a control panel that moves a cursor and performs other word processing.

title: RECITAL: HEINZ HOLLINGER, ANDRAS SCHIFF
description: HEINZ HOLLIGER, who may well be our finest living oboist, joined forces with another extraordinary musician, the pianist Andras Schiff, for a memorable concert in the Metropolitan Museum of Art Auditorium Sunday evening.

title: GOING FOR THE BRASS
description: My recent complaint about the life- consuming problem of constantly having to assemble 90 cents in coins for the convenience of New York buses, which demand ''exact change,'' was scarcely dry on the printed page before half the population of the city put pen to paper.

title: NORD RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Stake in Dorsey
description: An investment group led by Shamrock Associates said it had increased its holdings in the Dorsey Corporation to 660,500 common shares, or 20.4 percent of the total outstanding. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the group said its members bought 40,000 shares last Wednesday and an additional 63,500 shares on Friday. Shamrock is an investment partnership in Far Hills, N.J. Dorsey, a maker of plastic containers and highway trailers, closed today on the New York Stock Exchange at $35.75, up 50 cents.

title: LANE WOOD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. Fights Fees In Baby Jane Case
description: The Justice Department objected today to a request for payment of $25,368 in legal fees run up by a New York couple in their battle with the Government over the medical records of their handicapped child.

title: 'WHO MAKES U.S. FOREIGN POLICY IN THE MIDDLE EAST?'
description: To the Editor: I applaud President Reagan's deci

title: WOMEN LEARN FROM WORK
description: LOLA WEIXEL once welded glider fuselages and bomb cases in New York City as a member of the Hidden Army, the workforce of millions of women who labored during World War II in factory jobs traditionally reserved for men. Now she is 62 years old, has retired after 25 years as a proofreader and stays at home on the Lower East Side.

title: Stocks Decline; Dow Off 4.40 Points
description: Stock prices fell moderately yesterday in more active trading, although several reported or rumored takeover candidates posted impressive gains.

title: Woolworth Unit Head
description: Robert L. Jennings, the 55-year-old executive vice president for merchandising of the United States division of the F. W. Woolworth Company, has been named president and chief executive of that division, the company said yesterday. He succeeds John E. Parker, who has resigned to pursue other interests. Mr. Jennings has been with Woolworth since 1951.

title: Chairman Adds Duties At Towner Petroleum
description: The Towner Petroleum Company said yesterday that Selim K. Zilkha, who recently invested in the company and was named its chairman, has been elected to the additional post of chief executive.

title: Las Vegas Strike Clash Brings the Arrest of 16
description: Striking hotel-casino workers clashed with security guards today and the police arrested 16 people, including four union leaders.

title: New Jersey Generalities
description: A member of the New Jersey Assembly said that Donald Trump, the New Jersey Generals' owner, had asked ABC Sports not to use ''New Jersey'' in the team's name, and called the request ''a slap in the face'' to the state.

title: 2 GUNMEN WOUND U.S. SOLDIER ON ROAD IN ATHENS
description: A United States soldier was shot and wounded today along a highway in Athens by two unidentified gunmen who fled on a motorbike, a United States Embassy spokesman said.

title: ISLANDERS READY; RANGERS WARY
description: For three years, the Islanders have used the Rangers as stepping stones to their second, third and fourth Stanley Cups. And unless the Rangers quickly improve their game, the Islanders will march by them again.

title: SOVIET IS HOLDING BIG NAVAL GAMES
description: The largest Soviet battle fleet ever seen has been assembled in the Norwegian Sea and the North Atlantic for an exercise, the British Defense Ministry said today.today.

title: U.S. URGED TO RESTRICT TEST KITS FOR A BIRTH DEFECT
description: A consumer group is asking Margaret M. Heckler, Secretary for Health and Human Services, for more restrictions on kits to test for a birth defect that were recently approved by the Food and Drug Administration.

title: ASSESSING WHAT IS GOOD FOR YOU AND WHAT IS NOT
description: THERE is much good to be said for those who eat such wholesome foods as whole-grain breads and cereals, fresh fruits and vegetables, entrees low in fat and salt, desserts low in sugar and beverages free of caffeine. People who approach dining, both at home and in restaurants, with reason and moderation as their guides can expect an improvement in well-being and a decreased risk of developing such diet-related disorders as heart disease, cancer, high blood pressure and obesity. Unfortunately, in far too many cases, reason is supplanted by a fervor that sings the praises of a host of foods of questionable, and sometimes negative, nutritional value.

title: 'WHO MAKES U.S. FOREIGN POLICY IN THE MIDDLE EAST?'

SECURITIES INDUSTRY BACKS BILL DEFINING INSIDER
description: Securities industry officials told Congress today that a proposed new definition of insider trading would no longer require that the Securities and Exchange Commission delve into the motives of the person improperly passing on insider information on securities.

title: THE POLITICS OF CHANGE
description: At least one thing is fairly clear these days: Everything seems to be changing faster than the politicians. The scientists, the educators and the businessmen are trying to adjust to a different future, but the politicians are still stuck in the mud.

title: 'DOUBLE TROUBLE,' NEW NBC TWINS
description: TELEVISION'S Year of the Twins keeps proliferating merrily along. Female sets, each featuring one good and one vicious sibling, were featured prominently in the brief series ''Master of the Game'' and the remake of the movie ''Dark Mirror.'' Now, on NBC-TV tonight at 9:30, a situation comedy has decided to get into the identical-but-separate act. The new series is called, with leaden predictability, ''Double Trouble.''

title: KNICKS ELIMINATE BULLS FROM PLAYOFFS
description: Marvin Webster's defense was the key to the Knicks' 113-96 victory tonight over the Bulls, who lost their eighth and were mathematically closed out of the playoffs.

title: ROYAL DUTCH SHELL SWEETENS ITS OFFER TO BUY SHELL OIL
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group, taking the Shell Oil Company by surprise, said yesterday that it was sweetening its bid for the 30 percent of Shell that it does not own to $58 a share from $55.

title: TACO VIVA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
SEXUAL ABUSE OF CHILDREN DRAWS EXPERTS' INCREASING CONCERN NATIONWIDE
description: Law-enforcement and medical authorities are increasingly alarmed about sexual abuse of children, often for commercial purposes.

title: LETTER: ON OSHA No Way to Run a Railroad Inapplicable civil service laws confuse the management and weaken the structure of New York's Metropolitan Transportation Authority, says its new chairman, Robert Kiley. Those laws are by no means the only reason for the authority's dismal performance. But they're an excellent place to begin improving it.
description: Especially because it lacks modern, efficient repair facilities, the M.T.A. needs a skilled maintenance force directed by expert managers. Yet New York's civil service laws permit promotion only by competitive written examination, not by appraisals of job performance.

title: IT'S A CIRCUS BACKSTAGE AS THE CIRCUS GETS READY
description: The 23 elephants were rousing from their snuffling, pre-performance snoozes backstage at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

title: 'OZ' HELPS CBS RATINGS LEAD
description: CBS followed the yellow brick road and landed near the top of the A.C. Nielsen Company's prime-time ratings last week, with its annual ''Wizard of Oz'' again finishing in the top 10.

title: BIOSEARCH MEDICAL PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After start-up expenses of $405,000 for research and development and manufacturing and $202,000 for registration costs.

title: Acid Rain Protesters Are Active in Europe
description: Three ecologists spent a second night perched on a gasoline refinery chimney here to protest acid rain, but demonstrations in several other Western European countries were ruined by the weather.

title: Water-Pipe Solder With Lead Banned
description: Hempstead has banned installing lead solder in pipes carrying drinking water, Presiding Supervisor Thomas M. Gulotta announced today.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Scouting column in Sports Pages yesterday incorrectly described the number of viewers watching CBS and NBC programs in Los Angeles during ABC's telecast of a football game Sunday. According to A. C. Nielsen's overnight figures, the CBS and NBC averages in Los Angeles for that time slot were a 4.65 rating and a 14 share.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;

title: UPSTATE EAGLES STUDIED FOR CLUES TO MIGRATION
description: Once again, the state's scientists are trying to outsmart the migratory eagles that winter in Sullivan County.

description: WITH Argentina on the verge of default, Mexico's Finance Minister, Jesus Silva Herzog, pulled a rabbit out of a hat while Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan and a flock of other finance ministers and bankers held his cape, his cane and his top hat.

title: BOWATER EXECUTIVE TO HEAD U.S. SPINOFF
description: In the United States, they call it a spinoff; in Britain a demerger. Bowater plans to do it, and the result will be a major new public company in the United States with Anthony P. Gammie at its helm.

title: A Dollar Earned, A Dollar Saved
description: When Lou Gehrig was playing for the Yankees half a century ago, his teammates kidded him about his tendency to be tight with money. Gehrig probably had a reason: He came from a poor family in the Yorkville section of Manhattan.

title: PALESTINIANS IN SOUTH OF LEBANON SAID TO WOUND 10 ISRAELI SOLDIERS
description: Palestinian guerrillas attacked Israeli forces in southern Lebanon today, reportedly wounding at least 10 soldiers. The attack came a day after 48 people were wounded in an attack by three Arabs in the heart of Jerusalem.

title: CONGRESS BACKS BILL TO PAY THE FARMERS WHO LIMIT PLANTING
description: The House of Representatives passed and sent to President Reagan today a farm bill that would pay wheat farmers who agreed to limit their production this year and next. It would pay the producers of other commodities for limiting their production next year.

title: PREFERENCE VOTE IS WON BY HART IN A CLOSE ELECTION IN WISCONSIN
description: Gary Hart defeated Walter F. Mondale in Wisconsin's Democratic preference primary today, an election that had little bearing on the makeup of the state's delegation to the party's state's delegation to the party's national convention.

ZIMBABWEAN SAYS 6 ARE ALIVE
description: A rebel leader says six tourists, including two Americans, who were abducted in July 1982 are still alive and will be released if the Government meets political demands.

title: Get Rid of Leaded Gas
description: There are few more noxious and less necessary products than leaded gasoline. The lead spewing out of tailpipes is a major cause of lead poisoning that afflicts half a million young children. Mounting evidence suggests that lead in the body, even in amounts below the official safety level, can affect children's brain function.

title: SCOUTING;
description: No Pot of Gold

title: Mississippi G.O.P. Loses Plea on Districting
description: The Supreme Court has refused to order Mississippi to reinstate a 1982 voter redistricting plan for the Congressional primaries in June and the November general election.

title: The U.N. Today April 4, 1984
description: SECURITY COUNCIL

title: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 4, 1984 International
description: Guinea's armed forces seized power in a coup a week after the death of President Ahmed Sekou Toure to end what they called a ''bloody and ruthless dictatorship.'' All mass organizations were dissolved and the West African nation's airport and borders were closed. (Page A1, Column 1.) Assassins in Punjab killed a member of Parliament, a university professor who was fatally shot at his home by killers who had said they were students waiting to see him. The killers fled in a car. Meanwhile, at least 10 people were killed and scores injured when the police fired on a crowd in Amritsar, the holy Sikh city in the northern India state. (A1:2.)

title: ; FEDERAL EXCEPTION TO SWIFTCHECK CLEARING
description: To the Editor:

title: RUBEN BLADES'S SALSA
description: WHENEVER a pop musician who appeals to a limited audience gets to the top in his field, the chimera of ''crossover'' begins to beckon. The field may be salsa or reggae, blues or gospel music or rap. Each music has its core of artists and supporters who have had similar upbringings and share an identity that is separate and distinct from the cultural mainstream.

title: Reagan News Parley To Be Aired Tonight
description: President Reagan's news conference tonight will be broadcast live at 8 P.M. on Channels 2, 4 and 7, and on CNN, the Cable News Network. In addition, some local affiliates of PBS will carry the conference, either live or as a tape-delayed broadcast. Channel 13 in Newark, for example, will broadcast the conference at 11 P.M.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective.

title: CLARK APPROVES A PLAN TO EXPAND WATER PROJECT IN CENTRAL ARIZONA
description: Secretary of the Interior William P. Clark chose a modified billion-dollar plan today as a basis for proceeding with expansion of a huge water project in Arizona.

title: STILL THE PARENTS' JOB
description: To the Editor:

title: Scali, McCabe Gets Sharp Electronics
description: Scali, McCabe, Sloves, a subsidiary of Ogilvy and Mather Inc., has been named agency for Sharp Electronics, whose new marketing head, Robert G. Norwick, decided to consolidate the business, which had been divided into industrial and consumer divisions. Billings will be around $20 million.

title: No Headline
description: U.S. Opens 9 Inquiries Into Rights of Inmates

title: EXPERTS' ADVICE FOR PARENTS ON CHOICE OF A DAY CARE CENTER
description: Can parents be sure they have chosen a day care center where their child will be free from the threat of sexual abuse?

title: BRIEFS
description: * Alexander Energy Corp., an oil and gas exploration company in Oklahoma City, said it had agreed in principle to buy all the producing oil and gas properties of the Brooks Hall Companies for about $25 million.

title: FANS GO WILD FOR WINNING HOYAS
description: The hometown fans of the national collegiate champion Georgetown basketball team Monday night continued an increasingly familiar tradition in the nation's capital - taking to the streets of Georgetown to celebrate the crowning of another champion from Washington.

title: 7 Men and 5 Concerns Named in Export Case
description: Seven men and five corporations in Switzerland, Canada and the United States have been named in a 23-count indictment in connection with an international ring that allegedly shipped banned computer systems to the Soviet Union and East Germany, the United States Attorney's office here said Monday.

title: KRATOS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After provisions of $9,804,000 for the quarter and $15,186,000 for the year for nonrecurring charges related to Keuffel & Esser operations and tax charges of $1,966,000 for the quarter and $4,854,000 for the year for tax loss carrybacks and elimination of net deferred tax credits. c-After tax charges of $1,901,000 for the quarter and $3,799,000 for the year.

title: IMPERIAL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: RESTAURANTS: 3 OF BOSTON'SBEST
description: BOSTONCHANGES in the restaurant scene here, like so many things in this city of Brahmins, have been slow. In 1976 Madeleine Kamman, the highly regarded cooking teacher, who operated a restaurant in conjunction with her school in nearby Newton Centre, found it difficult to persuade Bostonians that her prix fixe nouvelle cuisine dinners at about $25 were worth the money.

title: BANKS MAY DOWNGRADE ARGENTINE DEBT STATUS
description: Several American banks are considering voluntarily lowering their reported net income for the first quarter to reflect a continued lag in receiving interest payments from Argentina, although the last-minute agreement over the weekend was intended to avoid having to do this.

title: Market Place; A.T.& T. and Its Dividend
description: THE American Telephone and Telegraph

title: FUNDSNET INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Reds, at Cincinnati. Ron Darling, widely considered an early candidate for rookie of the year, makes his first start of the season.

title: around the world; Report Says Torture Is Widely Used
description: At least a third of the world's nations torture or otherwise abuse prisoners, Amnesty International said today.

title: A FORMER MAYOR OF HASTINGS
description: Dr. Charles Frederick Reid, professor emeritus of education at City College and a former Mayor of Hastings- on-Hudson, N.Y., died of a heart attack Sunday while visiting his son in Columbia, Md. Dr. Reid was 85 years old and had lived in Tamarac, Fla., since his retirement 16 years ago.

title: STAGE: '76 'PACIFIC OVERTURES'
description: THE York Theater's revival of Stephen Sondheim's 1976 musical ''Pacific Overtures'' is an inspiring example of a small theater company using modest resources to mount a production that soars with more grace and elegance than anyone might have had reason to expect. It also affords theatergoers who missed ''Pacific Overtures'' when it originally ran on Broadway for 206 performances the chance to discover a work that represents musical theater at its most intellectually challenging.

title: SUMMIT OILFIELD CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
CLERICAL EMPLOYEES AT YALE VOTE HEAVILY AGAINST A WALKOUT
description: Clerical and technical workers at Yale University voted overwhelmingly tonight not to strike after a week of negotiations in which a walkout deadline was postponed three times.

title: Asbestos Findings Close High School
description: A high school here has been closed for the rest of the academic year after a Federal agency discovered potentially hazardous levels of asbestos in the school's ceiling tiles, officials said.

title: BEVERLY HILLS SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN (CALIF) (O) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income. Results for the previous year include pretax gains of $13.3 million from the sale of branch offices and $8.8 million from the sale of the company's loan servicing portfolio.

title: S.E.C.'S COMPUTER REVOLUTION
description: The Federal Express and Purolator Courier trucks lined up two deep in front of the Securities and Exchange Commission on Friday, and every few minutes another rounded the corner on Fifth Street at the base of Capitol Hill. By noon a makeshift receiving center in the lower lobby was a blizzard of paper.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST

title: Coast Officials to Examine Data on Wick Phone Taping
description: The District Attorney will review evidence from Senate investigators to see whether Charles Z. Wick, the director of the United States . Information Agency, broke the law by taping a phone conversation on a 1981 visit here, officials said today.

title: FILM: 'STONE BOY,' GRIEF AFTER DEATH
description: THE STONE BOY'' is about a grief so special and so private that the film has the effect of seeming to force us to invade its privacy, making us feel more uncomfortable than moved.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: EAC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a pretax charge of $526,000 for plant relocation and other expenses.

title: DEBATE ON BUDGET STARTING IN HOUSE
description: The House of Representatives begins debate Wednesday on a Congressional budget resolution for next year, with the Democratic leadership still expecting its deficit-reduction plan to survive challenges from seven alternatives.

title: OUSTER UNJUST, HONDURAN ASSERTS
description: The ousted commander of the Honduran armed forces said today that he had been forced to resign by ''disloyal and ambitious soldiers.''

title: 'PROPAGANDA' LABEL UPHELD ON 3 FILMS
description: A Federal judge today dismissed a lawsuit that sought to block the Justice Department from classifying three Canadian films on acid rain and nuclear war as ''political propaganda.''

title: STAGE: CIRCUS OPENS AT THE GARDEN
description: IF you've had that curious itch of

title: Street Theater
description: Passers-by stopped to search eagerly through the trash outside of 25 West 45th Street yesterday.

title: Harvester-Icom
description: The International Harvester Company said it had sold its telecommunications system to Icom Inc. of Parsippany, N.J. Terms were not disclosed. The system, based in Oak Brook, Ill., provides communications services to Harvester's sales and manufacturing operations worldwide. Harvester agreed to use the network as a customer for an extended period.

title: Cable Systems To Change Hands
description: Sammons Communications Inc. and a unit of United Artists Communications Inc. separately announced plans to acquire cable television systems.

title: AMERICAN QUASAR PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a provision of $25 million for uncollectable advances paid to limited partnerships.

title: MUSIC: AUDUBON QUARTET AT TULLY HALL
description: THE AUDUBON QUARTET has commissioned a new piece from Peter Schickele, which it played for the first Those who listen closely to Mr. Schickele's P.D.Q. Bach concerts know that some sophisticated and inventive music lies behind the buffoonery, and this Quartet No. 1, too, mixes simplicity and sincerity with a confident use of the quartet medium. Mr. Schickele's quartet is accessibility itself - with an all-American, apple- pie succession of pentatonic figures, modal melodies, country fiddling and jazz. Its calm unpretentiousness was disarming.

title: Nettles to Be Platooned
description: Graig Nettles, who expressed anger at the Yankees' plans to platoon him with Toby Harrah this season, will be platooned at third base here with Luis Salazar, according to Manager Dick Williams of the San Diego Padres. But the 39-year-old Nettles, whom New York traded to San Diego on Saturday, is taking it all in stride.

title: THE DANCE : ISRAEL TROUPE PERFORMS
description: THE KARMON DANCE COMPANY OF ISRAEL, which opened Monday night at the State Theater for a run through Sunday, could be called a folk-pop troupe. But even this makeshift label does not hint at its young dancers' most definable traits - a tremendous energy and polish that sweeps through the medley format of what has to be the fastest-paced show on the boards.

title: FIXING THE NATIONAL DEBT BIT BY BIT
description: According to the Treasury's latest accounts, the national debt, which has been called ''America's black hole,'' stands at $1,465,425,178,686.02, which works out to about $6,300 for every American.

title: GEORGETOWN WAS PREPARED
description: Dean Smith was probably trying to tell us all something when he predicted that the team that was ''psychologically prepared'' would win the national collegiate basketball championship Monday night.

title: GIANT FOOD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 25
Armstrong-Sears
description: The Armstrong Rubber Company will take over Sears, Roebuck & Company's truck tire centers, the companies said.

title: SALANT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 3
description: b-Net income

title: Young Teams
description: As long as the Yankees continue to carry on their roster such baseball fossils as Phil Niekro (45 years old) and Lou Piniella (40) and the Mets continue to find profitable uses for Rusty Staub (40), Mike Torrez (37) and Dick Tidrow (36), New York may not be known as a baseball town in the clutches of a genuine youth movement.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;
description: Top Phone Officers Shift in Connecticut

title: EASTGROUP PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Including gains on the sale of investments of $1.8 million for the latest first quarter and $1.7 million for the year-ago first quarter.

title: HYDE ATHLETIC INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CARTER HAWLEY SILENT ON OFFER
description: After receiving a $1.1 billion acquisition offer, Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. jumped on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday to a nine- year high of $29.25, within 75 cents of the price offered by The Limited Inc., a retailer based in Columbus, Ohio. The rise for the day was $3.62 1/2.

title: JUDGE COMPLETES TESTIMONY, REPLYING ANGRILY TO CHARGES
description: Federal District Judge Harry E. Claiborne finished his testimony in his own defense today after several stormy exchanges with the Federal prosecutor who cross-examined him.

title: SOUTH AFRICA BLAMES EXILE REBEL GROUP FOR BOMB
description: The South African authorities blamed the African National Congress for a car- bomb explosion this morning in the port city of Durban that killed 3 people and wounded 16 others. Earlier reports said 5 people were killed.

title: THOMPSON MEDICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
BILTMORE, NOW OFFICE BUILDING, TO GET ITS CLOCK BACK
description: The famous old clock that used to grace the lobby of the Biltmore Hotel is being reconditioned. Indeed, it should be ready for installation over the concierge desk of the renovated hotel building - now an office tower called Bank of America Plaza - in time for the official reopening of the building next month.

title: ALUMINUM PRICES FIRM IN A GROWING MARKET
description: Prices of aluminum futures firmed yesterday on the Commodity Exchange in New York, although trading has been light since the March contract expired last week. At yesterday's close, the spot April aluminum contract was quoted at a nominal 67.60 cents a pound, up 0.15 cent for the day.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: OVER the years I have received numerous requests for 60-minute recipes for two people. Most of the recipes offered, designed to serve four, can readily be cut in half. But for those who want a recipe specifically formulated to serve two, I offer dishes with mussels as a principal ingredient since they are a mainstay of ''dishes in a pot'' that are sufficient for a complete meal. Neither a vegetable nor a salad is really necessary, and potatoes or rice would be excessive. The one accompaniment I would recommend is a crusty loaf.

title: HILLENBRAND INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 3
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split in February 1984.

title: JACKSON RUNS A CLOSE THIRD
description: Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale scored a sweeping victory in the Democratic Presidential primary in New York yesterday, giving his candidacy a major push toward the nomination.

title: NEW I.B.M. PRODUCTS TIE PC'S TO OLD DEVICES
description: The International Business Machines Corporation yesterday introduced equipment and software designed to allow its Personal Computer to quickly transfer data with older I.B.M. devices, thus easing the PC's entry into the office market.

title: U.S. Judge Held in Error On Penalty in Spy Case
description: A panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit today held that a district judge erred when he ruled that an accused spy, James Durward Harper Jr., would be subject to a penalty of death if convicted at his trial, scheduled to start April 24.

title: TWO REINSTATED BY ARBITRATOR
description: Richard Bloch, baseball's impartial arbitrator, yesterday ordered Jerry Martin of the Mets and Willie Wilson of the Kansas City Royals reinstated by May 15, the date on which Commissioner Bowie Kuhn had said he would review his one-year suspension of both players for cocaine-related convictions.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: WEAPONS AND HOPE. By Freeman Dyson. 340 pages. Harper & Row. A Cornelia and Michael Bessie Book. $17.95.

title: No Headline
description: Reagan Rating in Poll Remains Solid at 55%

title: NEW FOOD-STAMP EFFORT
description: The Agriculture Department announced another round of belt-tightening this week to reduce cheating and errors in the Government's $12 billion food-stamp program and $3.3 billion school-lunch program.

title: WINE TALK
description: IF the mail and the telephone are

title: KAUFMAN & BROAD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $550,000.

title: Hart Is Pulling Ahead In Oklahoma Delegates
description: Senator Gary Hart of Colorado moved further ahead of former Walter F. Mondale in the fight for national delegates from Oklahoma, according to tabulations of county conventions.

title: ENERGETICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a writedown of $24 million for the quarter and year on the estimated value of the company's oil and gas reserves. c-There are no comparable year- ago results because the company had no operations prior to consumation of its exchange offer which closed at the end of March 1983.

title: PIER 1 IMPORTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $3,242,000 for the quarter and $5,960,000 for the 6 months. c-After extraordinary credits of $1,611,000 for the quarter and $1,848,000 for the 6 months.

title: Pakistan Flogs 2 Men
description: Two men were strapped to triangular frames in separate towns today and publicly flogged, one for drinking and the other for fornication, witnesses said.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''When they write the history of this of this one, the longest chapter will be on Jackson.

title: GENERATIONAL SQUEEZE HURT HART IN VOTING, POLL SHOWS
description: A heavy vote among older whites for Walter F. Mondale and a surge of young black voters for the Rev. Jesse Jackson put a generational squeeze on Senator Gary Hart in the New York primary yesterday, according to a New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: Court Orders Lesbian Reinstated to R.O.T.C.
description: Diane Matthews, 25 years old, of South Portland, who was discharged from the Army's Reserve Officer Training Corps after she acknowledged that she was a lesbian, was ordered reinstated today by a United States Magistrate.

title: Newark Faulted On Public Housing
description: An audit released today by the Federal Housing and Urban Development Department faults Newark's public housing authority for not providing sufficient dwellings for the poor.

title: GRANITEVILLE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss. Year-ago results reflect charges of $4 million for the quarter and $7.3 million for the year for the estimated cost of plans to redeploy assets.

title: Johnson, 0-1, Shakes Up Mets' Lineup
description: After one convincing and even embarrassing 8-1 defeat in the opening game, Manager Dave Johnson revamped the Mets' lineup today. But he stuck to his plan to start three young and inexperienced pitchers in the next three games as the heart of his front-line staff.

title: Msgr. Albert C. M. Steffens, Ex-Pastor in Sullivan County
description: Msgr. Albert C. M. Steffens, former pastor of St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church in Livingston Manor, N.Y., died Friday in St. Mary's Hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla.

title: GEORGIA ACCEPTS DR. KING HOLIDAY
description: A bill creating a holiday to honor Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in his home state of Georgia was signed by Gov. Joe Frank Harris today, a day before the 16th anniversary of the murder of the civil rights leader.

title: Senior Vice President Named by Leber Katz
description: Robert Gordon, 43 years old, with 20 years of experience in direct marketing, has joined Leber Katz Partners, as senior vice president and president of its up-and-coming direct marketing division.

title: Derby Favors Off-Track Betting
description: Churchill Downs announced today that it had reached agreement with representatives of a horsemen's group on a plan to allow off-track betting and simulcasts of the 110th Kentucky Derby.

title: MGM-UA ENTERTAINMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Includes a gain of $9,901,000, or 20 cents a share, on the sale of the music publishing business.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Saturday about by major Hollywood studios to deal with drug problems incorrectly named one of those allowed to enter drug diversion programs. The actress named should have been Mackenzie Phillips, not Michelle Phillips.

title: THEATER: REVIVAL OF 'TAKE ME ALONG'
description: WHEN Eugene O'Neill's ''Ah, Wilderness!'' was turned into a musical in 1959 as ''Take Me Along,'' the American musical theater was still carrying on a romance with turn- of-the-century America. For O'Neill's play about cozy and proper middle- class life in a small Connecticut town in 1906, Bob Merrill wrote a score that caught the spirit of the time and the situation and underscored the problems around which the play was built - an adolescent boy coping with the perceived adult world, his genial but ne'er-do-well uncle coping with a drinking problem, and the boy's father coping with the problem of aging.

title: U.N. Panel's Europe Study
description: The United Nations Economic Commission began an 11-day meeting today. Governments of 34 countries of Eastern and Western Europe plus Canada and the United States will review European economic developments.

title: BOND YIELDS HIGHEST SINCE 1982
description: Amid weak investor demand and widespread concern that the Federal Reserve is tightening monetary policy, note and bond prices slid lower yesterday, raising bond yields to the highest levels since mid-August 1982.

title: ONE LANDLORD'S TRIAL AND ERROR IN MINORITY HOUSING
description: To the Editor:

title: ANOTHER CIGARETTE FOR YOGI BERRA
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.

title: CARDILLO TRAVEL SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: OLAJUWON CALLS TEAM SELFISH
description: In the aftermath, there were tears, accusations, contradictions and rare criticism from the Houston coach, Guy Lewis. Now, in the days and weeks ahead, Akeem Olajuwon must decide whether the harsh words he had Monday night for his teammates will carry over into next season, thus influencing his decision whether to remain at Houston or turn professional.

title: SHULTZ ASKS MOVE AGAINST TERRORISM
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the Western countries had to consider pre-emptive action against ''known terrorist groups'' and face up ''to the need for active defense against terrorism.''

title: PHILS TOP BRAVES FOR CARLTON'S 301ST
description: With Steve Carlton allowing two hits over seven innings for his 301st career victory and Mike Schmidt belting a home run, the Philadelphia Phillies stopped the Atlanta Braves, 5-0, in a season-opening game tonight.

title: Van Breda Kolff Back
description: Butch van Breda Kolff, the onetime Princeton and Hofstra coach who went on to a successful career in the National Basketball Association before dropping down to the high school level, has come full circle. He has been hired as coach at Lafayette College in Easton, Pa., the school where he began his coaching career 33 years ago.

title: PRAVDA IS CRITICAL OF OIL INDUSTRY FOR FAILING TO MEET SIBERIAN GOAL
description: The newspaper Pravda acknowledged today that serious problems had slowed development of the West Siberian oilfields, a factor that may account for a recent drop in Soviet oil production.

title: SATELCO INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: MILWAUKEE OVERWHELMS NETS
description: It would be easy to place blame for tonight's woeful performance by the Nets on the absence of Darryl Dawkins, their starting center, who was sidelined with strained ligaments in his right wrist. But the 109-92 loss to the Milwaukee Bucks was the result of many inept contributions.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: State Reports Quality Of Water Is Improved
description: New York's water quality has improved significantly since 1972, with some rivers, streams and lakes 21 percent cleaner than they were 10 years ago, according to a report released today.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a mechanical error, some copies of the Late Edition yesyesterday omitted page D5, which included the continuation of the front- page article about a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation involving a former Wall Street Journal reporter. Readers wishing copies of the missing page may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: People
description: * G. Steven Dapper has been appointed president and chief executive of Wunderman, Ricotta & Kline, New York.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: A vagrant approached Joseph L. Stern in midtown. Could he spare a cigarette? ''Sorry,'' Mr. Stern said, ''I don't smoke.'' The man smiled, tipped his cap ceremoniously, and said, ''Thank you for not smoking.''

title: 10 YEARS OF PICKING UP AFTER TORNADO
description: The city official clicked his way through a batch of color slides showing the devastation that whirled from the skies through this town 10 years ago this afternoon.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Washington State Offers $158 Million of Bonds
description: The State of Washington is offering $158 million of general obligation bonds through underwriters led by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company. The yields range from 6 percent for bonds due in 1985, to 9.2 percent in 1994, 10.20 percent in 2004 and 10.3 percent in 2009.

title: 21 NURSING HOMES IN CITY LOCK OUT THEIR EMPLOYEES
description: Twenty-one nursing homes in New York City locked out their employees in a labor dispute yesterday. Other homes agreed to a 48-hour contract extension and maintained normal operations.

title: U.S. Missiles in Sicily Are Now Operational
description: Defense Minister Giovanni Spadolini announced today that the first American cruise missiles in Italy had become operational.

title: SMITH WILL REMAIN UNTIL A SUCCESSOR IS CONFIRMED
description: President Reagan asked Attorney General William French Smith today to remain in office ''until a new Attorney General is confirmed by the Senate,'' and Mr. Smith agreed, according to the White House spokesman Larry Speakes.

title: OPERA: A LIGHT DOUBLE BILL
description: THE Manhattan School of Music's double bill at the Brownlee Theater last week offered opera with a light touch. Both Menotti's ''Amelia Goes to the Ball'' and Puccini's ''Gianni Schicchi'' look at the absurdities of human nature, but it was a shame that these productions - well played and sung as they were - treated these absurdities so offhandedly.

title: U.S. ELECTION YEAR AND LATIN TURMOIL
description: The Reagan Administration fears an increase in leftist guerrilla activity in Central America between now and the November Presidential election and as a result is stepping up its own efforts in the area, according to United States and other foreign officials in the region.

title: MARTHA PRATT HAISLIP
description: Martha Pratt Haislip, a writer on gardening, died Sunday at her home in Sharon, Conn.

title: Texaco Buys Socal Outlets in Europe
description: Texaco Inc. said it had completed its purchase of most of the European petroleum refining and marketing troleum refining and marketing operations of the Standard Oil Company of California, including service stations.

title: RAIL LINE FINDS A MISTAKE LED TO TUNNELL FIRE
description: A switchman's error caused a derailment that started a fire in a tunnel near Grand Central Terminal last Jan. 30, according to a report released yesterday by the Metro-North Commuter Railroad.

title: Careers; High-Tech Openings Limited
description: WHERE will the jobs be in the next 10 years or so? Not necessarily in the high-technology companies.

title: Italian Aide Said to Ask Trial Of 7 in Shooting of the Pope
description: Italian newspapers reported today that a senior judicial official had recommended that three Bulgarians and four Turks be tried on charges of conspiracy in the 1981 attempt to kill Pope John Paul II.

title: LaRouche Loses Bid To Join League's Debate
description: Lyndon LaRouche Jr. today lost his bid to keep the League of Women Voters from holding a Democratic Presidential candidates' debate here without him.

title: MUSIC: VIOLINIST IN DEBUT
description: Bin Yim's debut at Carnegie Recital Hall on Saturday night inspired musings on the nature of endings - on the ways in which statements, made at a given time, have served their purpose and come to a close.

title: FLETCHER, AMERICA'S FIRST SCHOOL FOR DIPLOMATS, TURNING 50 AMID CHANGES
description: Fifty years ago, when the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy at Tufts University sent its first class of 21 into the world, the straightforward hope was that most of them would become professional diplomats.

title: 2 PLAYS LOSE BID FOR TONY ELIGIBILITY
description: ''And a Nightingale Sang . . . '' and ''Painting Churches'' will not be eligible for the 1984 Antoinette Perry Awards, which will be presented in a nationally televised ceremony on June 3.

title: NUI Files Suit
description: The NUI Corporation said it had asked the United States District Court in Newark to order a new election of directors of the New Jersey Resources Corporation. At the New Jersey Resources annual meeting in February, NUI was defeated in its attempt to elect directors favoring a merger of the companies.

title: SCOUTING;
description: Challenge Begins

title: Advertising; Campaign For First Boston
description: NO doubt about it: Jerry Della Femina, a Brooklyn boy and one-time New York Times messenger who graduated to being the bad boy of Madison Avenue, is now establishment.

title: FINANCIAL TRUSTCO CAPITAL reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $1,537,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary gain of $80,000. c-After a loss of $2,838,000 from discontinued operations and a gain of $2,201,000 on the sale of automotive division.

title: GRAPHIC MEDIA INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $30,250 and a nonrecurring pretax gain of $457,346 from the sale of property.

title: INDIAN JOINS SOVIET PAIR IN 8-DAY SPACE MISSION
description: The Soviet Union today launched an Indian astronaut into space for the first time, along with two Soviet astronauts.

title: 10 SLAIN IN RIOT
description: The campaign of terrorist killings in the northern state of Punjab claimed a Member of the national Parliament today, a university professor who was gunned down in his drawing room by killers who had said they were students waiting to see him. The killing in the Punjabi capital of Chandigarh today was the latest act of violence in an 18-month-long Sikh campaign for greater autonomy within India, and marked a further increase in the level of tension, fear and violence in both Punjab and the neighboring state of Haryana.

title: Accounts
description: * Globe Communications to Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Lawson for The Globe and National Examiner, both tabloids.

title: Brig's Shift to Jail Halted by Judge
description: A judge ruled yesterday that the city must halt work it began in February to convert a former Navy brig in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn into a city jail for 800 inmates.

title: STARRETT HOUSING CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $2,687,000, or 41 cents a share, for the latest year and $870,000, or 17 cents a share, for the earlier year.

title: LLOYD M. FELMLY
description: Lloyd M. Felmly, who had been the editor of the now-defunct Newark Evening News, died Monday at Point Pleasant (N.J.) Hospital. He was 90 years old and lived in Brielle, N.J.

title: BAR PANEL URGES END OF LAW THAT LIMITS ENTRY INTO U.S.
description: A law that authorizes Federal officials to bar foreigners from entering the United States because of their political beliefs hampers the free flow of ideas and should be repealed, a City Bar Association panel has recommended.

title: Abdul-Jabbar Moves Closer
description: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar scored 27 points for Los Angeles tonight, but Mike Mitchell scored 28 and George Gervin had 23 to lead San Antonio to a 137-109 victory over the Lakers.

title: TRANSCONTINENTAL ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $365,000. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $6,556,000 and a loss from the cumulative effect of an accounting change of $285,000. The year-earlier's revenue was restated.

title: Article 098630 -- No Title
description: A jury that heard a wrongful-death suit in State Superior Court awarded the family of the race-car driver Mark Donohue $9.6 million today.

title: 74 to Try Out for Games
description: A group of 74 basketball players, ranging from the all-America center Patrick Ewing of national champion Georgetown to two high school

title: 'GOD BLESS NEW YORK,' A JOYFUL MONDALE SAYS
description: Puffing a big cigar, his stocking feet propped up on a coffee table, Walter F. Mondale learned yesterday that he was winning big in the New York primary.

title: No Conwood Sale
description: The Conwood Corporation said it had terminated talks regarding its acquisition by the Gulf Broacast Company.

title: BUDGET STUDY FINDS CUTS COST THE POOR AS THE RICH GAINED
description: The Congressional Budget Office, analyzing the cumulative effect of budget and tax changes adopted since January 1981, said today that low-income families had lost the most money and high-income families had gained the most.

title: T.V. DIVERSITY GROWS IN ISRAEL
description: Israel may be the Jewish state, but in Haifa, Jewish families sit down to watch the evening news broadcast by Christian evangelicals in southern Lebanon. In Jerusalem, Israelis tune in to news in Hebrew, broadcast daily by Jordan Television from Amman. Nationwide, there is an increasing westernization of television because of the number of American serials being broadcast.

title: TIME TO ACKNOWLEDGE COMPARABLE WORTH
description: To the Editor:

title: BIOLOGISTS MONITOR MIGRATION
description: IT is not necessary to admire, or

title: Letter: On OSHA Doing the Worker Safety Job To the Editor:
description: Your March 9 editorial ''A Worker Safety Job Undone'' shows both a misunderstanding of the mandate of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration and a serious distortion of the accomplishments of the agency during my tenure.

title: THE PRESSURE IS ON HART
description: Walter F. Mondale's decisive victory in the New York primary puts pressure on Gary Hart to rebound quickly if the contest for the Democratic Presidential nomination is to continue to be regarded as a two-man race. Because of the former Vice President's success in New York, this year's front-loaded primary calendar and the arithmetic of the delegate selection process have begun to work strongly in his favor.

title: IRE FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
KELLY, DOUGLAS & CO LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary losses of $350,000 for latest year $1,333,000 for the previous year.

title: JOHNSON GALLERY DEDICATED AT MUSEUM OF MODERN ART
description: The Philip Johnson Gallery - named after the renowned architect who was founding director of the Museum of Modern Art's Department of Architecture and Design - was dedicated at the museum last evening in a private ceremony attended by 200 guests.

title: Harlem Polling Place Is Visited by Jackson
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson made an unorthodox Primary Day appearance at a Harlem polling place early yesterday, shaking hands, inspecting voting booths and leading a group of students in chanting, ''I am somebody.''

title: MONDALE IS USING NEW POLL METHOD
description: Walter F. Mondale's strategists here are trying a sophisticated method of identifying likely supporters, hoping that the new system will be more efficient than the telephone banks that politicians have used for generations.

title: MISSOURI CHURCH REVELATION SAYS WOMEN CAN BE PRIESTS
description: The president-prophet of the 230,000-member Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints announced a revelatory document today authorizing the ordination of women to the priesthood.

title: GOLDFIELD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income including a tax credit of $215,375. c-Including a tax credit of $839,935.

title: A NEW CONCERT LIFE FOR SOVIET DEFECTOR
description: VIKTORIA MULLOVA is enjoying her first American spring now that the first non- Russian winter of her young life is past. The 24-year-old violinist defected to the West last Independence Day weekend, fleeing with Vato Jordania, a conductor, from Finland into Sweden.

title: JOHNSON PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Net income.

title: SEABROOK COST MAY BURDEN NEW ENGLANDERS
description: The customers of 53 retail electric companies from Westport, Conn., to Westport, Me., will face higher rates because the Seabrook nuclear project in New Hampshire may cost nine times more than planned. And at least one utility, Seabrook's main builder, may be forced into bankruptcy.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Bank of Montreal said it was issuing $250 million of 12-year floating- rate notes through Morgan Stanley International. The notes mature in April 1996 and can be called at par after five years.

title: REGO GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company is listed on the Pacific and Spokane stock exchanges.

title: Boston College Is Tightening Rules
description: A special Boston College committee was putting the finishing touches yesterday on a proposed rule that would revoke the athletic eligibility of students who flunk out of one of the college's academic units but are later admitted to another.

title: Coney I. Bus Run To End Saturday
description: The Transit Authority said yesterday that it would discontinue the Coney Island Shoppers Special bus route, effective Saturday, because of a lack of riders and the availability of alternative service. The authority said it would save $104,000 a year.

title: DON'T PRAISE PRETORIA
description: For some three weeks now, Americans in the Government and in the press have been celebrating the apparent diplomatic progress that South Africa and its black-ruled neighbors are making toward a regional agreement. In fact, their optimism is sadly misplaced and misses an important part of the story.

title: Bronx Man Guilty In Slaying at Hotel
description: A 22-year-old Bronx man has been convicted of murdering the former wife of an heir to the Gilbey's gin fortune.

title: SCANDINAVIA TO AMERICA, VIA BROOKLYN
description: FOR most Scandinavians, according to Douglas Westergaard, it wouldn't be Thursday without arter med flask, the thick yellow Swedish pea soup made with roasted or smoked pork shoulder. Nor would it be Christmas without the simmered cod called lutfisk or Easter without sauces and preserves of lingonberries and cloudberries.

title: TELECOM PLUS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: PUBLICKER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes the writeoff of the company's investment in the South Point Ethanol joint venture totaling $1,278,000, and a charge to operations of about $300,000 due to an 18 percent reduction in personnel in the company's United Kingdom beverage division. c-Net income includes a gain of $207,000 on the sale of certain idle assets. d-Includes costs associated with idle facilities totaling $2,679,000; a loss from nonrecurring items of $525,000; a gain of $538,000 on sales of the company's idle facilities in Wigtownshire, Scotland, and Willow Springs, Ill., and a gain of $215,000 on the settlement of an insurance claim. e-Includes costs associated with idle facilities totaling $2,962,000, a gain from nonrecurring items of $4,019,000; a gain on the sale of idle property, principally the company's Linfield, Pa., facility, of $1,754,000; a gain of $1,225,000 on the settlement of an insurance claim, and a recovery of $1,285,000 from the European Economic Community for purchasing malt at prices in excess of the World Market rate from the period 1973 through 1981.

title: NEW ATTEMPTS TO CURB SALVADOR AID FAIL
description: The Republican-controlled Senate today easily defeated several proposals that would have tied military aid to El Salvador to progress in criminal justice cases and to the Government's willingness to negotiate with all parties to the conflict.

title: A STOREWIDE CELEBRATION OF NEW ORLEANS
description: BLANCHE DuBOIS would likely have been delighted. Beginning tonight, with a by- invitation-only party, and continuing through April 20, the city of New Orleans is getting a storewide salute from Lord & Taylor. This is the store's fifth annual ''Focus America'' promotion during which fashions and home furnishings reflecting the character of the honored city are sold, its crafts exhibited and appropriate music played. In this case there are also magnolia trees draped with Spanish moss, jazz bands, lots of lacy grillwork and splashing fountains. And this year, owing to the fame of Cajun and Creole cooking, there is a stronger-than-usual emphasis on food.

title: Aetna Outlook
description: The Aetna Life and Casualty Company said it expects to report disappointing but profitable results for the first quarter. It expects an operating loss in its property and casualty operations. The company said net claim costs connected with the storm and tornadoes on the Eastern Seaboard and Carolinas last week were an estimated $12 million.

title: CONSCO ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Transco Settles Supplier's Dispute
description: The Transco Energy Company said yesterday that it had agreed with a major natural gas supplier to settle about $140 million of potential ''take- or-pay'' obligations of two Transco units, the Transcontinental Gas Pipeline Corporation and the Transco Gas Supply Company.

title: STAINLESS STEEL POTS
description: steel cookware have been recommended in this column recently because many companies are manufacturing well-designed and durable pots and pans.

title: CONWOOD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
description: b-Net loss.

title: Matsushita Sale
description: The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, based in Osaka, Japan, yesterday announced plans for the largest securities sale ever for a Japanese company. The company plans to sell 100 billion yen, which is the equivalent of about $445 million, of unsecured convertible debentures due in 1994 through underwriters led by the Yamaichi Securities Company. Interest and terms of the conversion have not yet been determined.

title: Japan-U.S. Phone Deal
description: The Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Public Corporation is negotiating a purchase of 60,000 Touch-Tone telephones from Northern Telecom Inc. of Nashville, an official of Japan's semigovernmental telecommunications monopoly said today. Nippon Telegraph said it would be its first purchase of telephones from an American company.

title: CANDIDATES' RELATIVES TESTIFY FOR EQUITABLE PAY PROPOSAL
description: While their husbands sought to attract last- minute votes in New York, Joan Mondale and Jacqueline Jackson did some campaigning on their own today, telling a House panel that both Walter F. Mondale and the Rev. Jesse Jackson endorsed giving women equal pay for comparable work.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: American Bakeries Co. has named Phillip S. Lyddon vice president, general counsel and secretary.

title: GENERAL LEASEHOLDS reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
ON T.V. IN BAGHDAD, SICKENING IMAGES OF WAR
description: At odd times during the day and every night when regular programs have ended, Iraqi television reruns the same film. For about an hour the hand-held camera wanders around the field of the recent battle in the marshes along the southern end of the border with Iran.

title: VALMAC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: PUBLIC SERVICE'S TROUBLE-SHOOTER
description: In 1977, a year after the Public Service Company of New Hampshire started work on Seabrook, the Florida Power and Light Company began a similar reactor, St. Lucie 2. But while St. Lucie was finished last year, Seabrook 1 is still an estimated 27 months from completion and some 800 percent over budget.

title: Central America Out of Control
description: Other countries are not blobs on a map; their people and traditions are not graphs and statistics. These truisms get lost whenever Americans invoke the grandiose themes of vital interest and hemisphere security. But Central America has sent up some startling reminders that the region's war games involve real people whom we cannot always fathom or control.

title: Toyota Ends Philippine Tie
description: The Toyota Motor Company said today that it ended technological assistance and agency contracts with its Philippine sales agent, the Delta Motor Corporation, last month.

title: GUIDRY HIT HARD AS YANKEES LOSE
description: The Yankees went a long time - 20 years - between losses in games that counted with Yogi Berra as their manager. They lost the seventh and last game of the 1964 World Series against the St. Louis Cardinals, and today they lost the first game of the 1984 season to the Kansas City Royals, 4-2.

title: SUPER VALU STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 25
CORRECTIONS
description: An article Monday about the New York Philharmonic misidentified a substitute conductor for concerts scheduled April 12-17. He is Andrew Davis.

title: Afghans Said to Kill Or Seize 40 Russians
description: Afghan rebels killed or captured at least 40 Soviet soldiers at a military post in southwestern Afghanistan, then invited villagers to view their victims, alive and dead, Western diplomats said today.

title: BOARD CHARGES ALVARADO IS 'UNFIT' AS IT FILES 13 MISCONDUCT COUNTS
description: The Board of Education filed formal charges yesterday against Anthony J. Alvarado, the suspended Schools Chancellor, contending that he had personally benefited from his position and was ''unfit to properly perform his obligations.''

title: SEMTECH CORP reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
Canada Defies Kuhn
description: Canada reaffirmed yesterday its plan to introduce next month Government-run betting pools on sports events, including baseball, despite the objections of Commissioner Bowie Kuhn. Kuhn reaffirmed his office's intention to file suit soon in the Canadian courts in an effort to block the pools, which are designed to raise more than $200 million for the 1988 Winter Olympics in Calgary, Alberta.

title: Digital Adds to Computer Line
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation yesterday introduced a new computer that will be the most powerful in its VAX line of superminicomputers.

title: BRAZIL'S RED KNIGHT OF HOPE: UNHORSED BUT UNDAUNTED
description: For decades in Brazil and elsewhere in Latin America, the name of Luis Carlos Prestes has been synonymous with Communism. In reprisal for the fear awakened by his unswerving loyalty to Moscow and his combative commitment to Marxism, Mr. Prestes has suffered years of imprisonment, persecution and exile.

title: WATERMAN MARINE CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
TEMPLETON ENERGY INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
HEALTH FOOD AND THE CHANGE IN EATING HABITS
description: AMERICAN eating habits are changing, slowly but inexorably. The process began at least 15 years ago with the ecology movement's conviction that what we eat affects not only who we are but also the earth and its resources. Nurtured by such convictions, the whole-food movement gathered strength for a while, but in the late 70's it seemed to have gone underground, along with the rest of what we used to call the counterculture.

title: 20 Measles Cases In East Harlem
description: The city's Health Department yesterday reported a small but unusual outbreak of measles involving about 20 young children in East Harlem.

title: FOR BILLY SMITH, IT'S TIME TO GET READY FOR WORK
description: Don't talk to Billy Smith today. Put the food in front of him as soon as he sits down and get out of the way. Don't let the phone ring in his room. Don't laugh where he can hear you.

title: Kosher Champagnes
description: Among the kosher table wines being imported for the Passover holiday, as well as throughout the year, are French Champagnes. It is worth noting not only for Passover but also for weddings, bar mitzvahs and other celebrations when a kosher meal is served.

title: Tracy Austin Hurt
description: Tracy Austin , the tennis star who has been trying to overcome a series of injuries, suffered another one Monday night when she pulled a hip muscle during the opening round of the Carta Blanca Invitational in Inglewood, Calif. Hobbled, Miss Austin lost the match, 4-6, 6-1, 6-2, to Bettina Bunge , then left the court in tears. This was the second consecutive early-round elimination for Miss Austin since she began a comeback after sitting out most of 1983 with a back injury.

description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $292,967 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: Wells Fargo Renews Reward
description: The Wells Fargo Armored Service has renewed its $500,000 reward for the arrest of Victor Manuel Gerena Jr. of Hartford and the return of the $7 million he is suspected of stealing from the company's depot here last Sept. 12. The Federal Bureau of Investigation has said the reward is the largest offered in a single crime.

title: No Headline
description: It is the end of a long day, and you are fighting hard in the semifinals of the District Grand National Team Championship trailing into the final set of boards.

title: COMP-U-CARD INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Year to Jan 31

title: TO DIE OR NOT TO DIE
description: The Governor of Colorado, Richard D. Lamm, had his heart in the right place when he warned that ''we really should be very careful in terms of our technological miracles that we don't impose life on people who, in fact, are suffering beyond the ability for us to help.''

title: Egypt Rejoins Group Of Islamic Countries
description: Egypt, a founder of the Islamic Conference Organization, has formally rejoined the 45-nation body after a four-year suspension, it was announced here today.

title: 200 Students Return To Polish School
description: About 200 students returned to classrooms bare of crucifixes today, and there were signs that Poland's monthlong ''war of the crosses'' was easing.

title: AIR UNITS START VAST EXERCISE
description: The Strategic Air Command has begun a worldwide exercise code-named Global Shield 84 to provide bomber and missile crews with realistic training for nuclear war should deterrence fail, Defense Department officials said today.

title: Ratings for Mobil Lowered by S.& P.
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation yesterday lowered ratings on $2.9 billion of debt securities of the Mobil Corporation and its subsidiaries because of Mobil's acquisition of the Superior Oil Company. Superior's bond ratings were unchanged, at AA.

title: ELDERLY CHOOSE RETIREMENT COMMUNITY LIVING
description: NO longer are retirement communities looked upon by the elderly as ''old-age homes.'' More and more Americans of advanced age are moving into them, social researchers say, not to withdraw from active life in their later years, but for the positive support of others like themselves.

title: MEN AGAINST ABORTION
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN WILL URGE A WORLDWIDE BAN ON CHEMICAL ARMS
description: President Reagan, saying a rise in the use of chemical weapons had ''serious implications for our own security,'' announced tonight that the Administration would propose a treaty this month to ban the production, possession and use of such weapons worldwide.

title: Gulf and Western Finance Unit Files
description: The Associates Corporation of North America, a consumer and business finance subsidiary of Gulf and Western Industries, has filed a shelf registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for offerings of up to $600 million of unsecured debt securities.

title: Scholastic Priority
description: Terence Stansbury , the Temple guard who is the leading scorer in the school's history, was one of the 74 players invited Tuesday night to try out for the Olympic basketball team in Bloomington, Ind., later this month.

title: DONORS SAVE PLAY PROGRAM
description: Thanks to $63,000 in contributions from corporations, foundations, individuals and the city, the Ensemble Studio Theater will proceed with its 1984 marathon of new one-act plays.
