title: STORMS HIT CAROLINAS AGAIN, CAUSING DAMAGE IN 2 TOWNS
description: Severe thunderstorms moved across the Carolinas last night, a week to the day after a series of tornadoes claimed more than 60 lives, with the latest storms damaging a shopping center in Durham, N.C., and a church in Darlington, S.C.

title: Hart Gains a Delegate From Montana Caucuses
description: The final count from Montana's Democratic caucuses showed that Senator Gary Hart of Colorado picked up another delegate, a state Democratic Party official said Tuesday.

title: EVERDING TO VISIT MET TO DISCUSS BLISS'S POST
description: August Everding, who is believed to be a leading candidate to succeed Anthony A. Bliss as general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, plans to come to New York Monday to discuss the conditions of his availability with the opera company's board.

title: Green Party in Bonn Demotes Petra Kelly
description: Members of Parliament from the environmentalist Green Party have ousted Petra Kelly from the party's parliamentary leadership.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: YEARS ago people tackled do-it-yourself projects largely as a hobby, but home repairs and improvements have recently become more a way of life for many people as inflation has forced them to do their own work. From the growing stream of books aimed at the do-it-yourself market here are some that should be of interest:

description: American Executive Management Inc., a Salem, Mass., executive search company, has named J. Edward Buckley Jr. vice president.

SPRING CLEANING TIME: A CHECKLIST FOR THE HOME
description: SPRING is traditionally a time for sprucing up around the house. Outside and inside chores that have been put off during the winter months - some because of weather, others because of inclination - are best done now, in the warmer weather.

title: Priest Loses Lawsuit For Damages in Arrest
description: A Federal court jury here cleared four state troopers Tuesday of charges that they defamed a Roman Catholic priest whom they mistakenly arrested as the ''Gentleman Bandit'' in 1979 robberies.

title: LEAK/LYRIC; Immortal We first met Leopold Senghor in French class, and were at once seduced by his lyrical images of Africa that also articulated self-awareness and pride for people deprived of their identity by colonialism. The sensibility was called ''negritude,'' and Mr. Senghor, the first President of independent Senegal as well as a poet, was one of its most eloquent expositors.
description: Last week he was inducted into the Academie Fran,caise, the first black African to become one of its

title: CABLE T.V. PRESSING FREE-SPEECH ISSUE
description: A case now before the United States Court of Appeals in Boston is raising a major issue for the cable-television industry and its regulators: Does the First Amendment protect cable-television systems from government regulation in the same way that it protects newspapers?

title: BILL WOULD BE WEAPON AGAINST 'BOTTLE CLUBS'
description: Mayor Koch and several City Council members announced yesterday that they would introduce a law to make it easier for the city to close ''bottle clubs,'' numbers parlors and shops where illegal drugs are sold or stolen cars dismantled.

title: SENATORS UPHOLD AID TO INSURGENTS
description: The Republican-controlled Senate today rejected Democratic efforts to bar funds for the insurgents in Nicaragua and to prohibit the use of American combat troops in El Salvador.

title: 'HUMAN COMEDY' MOVES TO BROADWAY
description: Tonight ''The Human Comedy'' completes a journey that has covered two miles and consumed $800,000. It has traveled from Off Broadway to On Broadway, where it begins this evening at the Royale Theater.

title: Braves 4, Phils 0
description: Claudell Washington and Chris Chambliss smashed home runs, and Craig McMurtry and Steve Bedrosian combined on a six-hitter.

title: TWO-INCOME FAMILIES ON THE RISE, U.S. SAYS WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) - More than three-fifths of all married couples in the United States now have two incomes, significantly more than in earlier decades, the Census Bureau has reported.
description: In 1981 - the most recent year for which statistics are available - both husband and wife were employed in 26.3 million couples, or 62 percent of the total. That was up from 50.1 percent of married couples a decade ago, and from 40 percent in 1960.

title: 4 UTILITIES WEIGH NINE MILE PT. PLAN
description: The four utilities involved in the Nine Mile Point 2 nuclear power plant may form a new corporation and invite outside investment in the project, a utility official said today.

title: DAWKINS RETURNS AND HITS WINNER
description: Darryl Dawkins returned tonight, 24 hours after missing his first game of the season, and he proved again how invaluable he is to the Nets.

description: More Students in Poland Returning to Classes

title: LIMITS ON MAYOR'S POWER TO APPOINT ARE DEBATED
description: JAMES LeMOYNE

title: OPEC Panel Shifts Meeting
description: An OPEC committee that keeps track of petroleum prices and production has shifted the site of its April 17 meeting in the United Arab Emirates to Dubai from Abu Dhabi, the secretariat of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries said today.

title:
Market Place;
The Japanese Stock Surge
description: WHILE the Dow Jones industrial average has dropped more than 8.5 percent so far this year, its namesake in Japan keeps forging ahead. In step with rising prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, the Nikkei Dow Jones average rose above 11,000 this week for the first time.

title: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 25
FRENCH STEELWORKERS PROTESTING JOB CUTS PARALYZE A PROVINCE
description: Huge demonstrations today paralyzed the eastern part of France, where the Government plans to eliminate 25,000 jobs from the ailing steel industry. Protesting marchers brought traffic to a standstill in the streets, and angry workers blocked highways and railroads with heavy coils of sheet steel and piles of burning truck tires.

title: Guard's Wife Is Slain in Home
description: The wife of a Corrections Department captain was shot and killed in her Queens home last night, the police said.

title: REAGAN PODIUM'S NEW SPOT HAMPERS ACCESS BY SHOUTERS
description: The White House moved the podium for President Reagan's news conference this evening in an apparent attempt to prevent the shouted questioning that had come at the end of previous meetings with reporters.

title: VIDEO STATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AMERICAN FAMILY PIZZA reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Selling Phone Information
description: DIRECTORY assistance has usually been viewed by telephone companies as a necessary evil - something that must be provided to stimulate calling. But the Bell System breakup has changed that. As the Bell operating companies seek to enter new businesses, they are beginning to view directory assistance as a potential source of profits.

title: Edward Johnson 2d, Was 86; Began Investment Company
description: Edward C. Johnson 2d, founder and former chairman of the board of the Fidelity Management and Research Company, died Monday at Cataumet, Mass., of Alzheimer's disease. Mr. Johnson was 86 years old.

title: Debt Issues;
description: Citicorp Overseas Finance Corp. is offering a $100 million, 11 3/4 percent, 15- year Eurobond issue through Morgan Grenfell.

title: TWO FROM POST STAFF ARRESTED BY GUARDS AT BELLEVUE HOSPITAL
description: A photographer and a reporter for The New York Post were arrested at Bellevue Hospital Center yesterday and held for seven hours after an argument with the hospital's security staff, officials of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation said.

title: ELDERLY IN PENNSYLVANIA APPEAR TO BACK MONDALE
description: In the Jewish neighborhoods they sometimes call him ''Mandel,'' and in the Italian wards his name can sound like ''Mondalli.'' However they pronounce his name, elderly Democrats seem to favor Walter F. Mondale in the Pennsylvania primary next Tuesday.

title: 2 Tied for Lead In L.I. Bowling
description: Ernie Schlegel of Vancouver, Wash., rolled a pair of 258's tonight to move into a tie for first place with Jim Stefanich with a total of 2,683 after 12 games in the Professional Bowlers Association Long Island Open at Garden City Bowl.

title: Democracy Enlarged; Also Polluted ; Husband and Boyfriend on the '84 Soaps
description: At times in the last few weeks, the Democratic campaign has sounded like purest soap opera. In New Hampshire, wrote Murray Kempton, voters reacted to Walter Mondale as the husband and Gary Hart, the big winner there, as the boyfriend. A few days ago, Mary McGrory wrote that the two had come to ''sound increasingly like an old, warring married couple who have developed perfect pitch about each other's weaknesses and sore points.'' Now, after the New York primary, the roles have changed again. The husband's back. Walter Mondale's the big winner.

title: Reagan Gives Views On the Vietnam War
description: President Reagan said tonight that Gen. Douglas MacArthur was not allowed to ''lead us to a victory'' in the Korean War because of undue fears that the war there would widen and indicated that similar constraints hampered the American cause in Vietnam.

title: Drexel Fined by Amex
description: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. has been censured and fined $7,500 by the American Stock Exchange. The exchange said Drexel had engaged in ''front-running,'' by placing an order for options for its own account when it knew it had a customer order pending to buy 100,000 shares of the underlying stock. Drexel Burnham settled the charges without admitting or denying the exchange's charges.

description: b-Net income.

title: INTERNATIONAL PROTEINS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The loss for the latest fourth quarter was principally a result of writedowns on investments in El Salvador, liquidation payments to terminated employees in Panama, translation losses and increased costs of production---offset by deferred tax credits.

title: FLATLEY AND LAFONTAINE PRAISED IN DEBUT
description: The Islanders are a seasoned playoff team, with six of their players having played in more than 100 postseason games. But tonight two of their playoff neophytes, Pat Flatley and Pat LaFontaine, directed them on their first step toward a fifth consecutive Stanley Cup.

title: Kuhn Acts in Canada
description: Commissioner Bowie Kuhn , who had threatened to sue in an effort to keep the Government-run sports betting pool in Canada from including baseball games, followed through yesterday by seeking an injunction in Quebec Superior Court in Montreal.

title: Aetna Life Unit
description: The Aetna Life and Casualty Company said it is in the early stages of discussions on selling its Urban Investment and Development Company subisidary. Aetna said it had had ''numerous inquiries from potential purchasers as to our interest in selling Urban, virtually from the date of our acquisition in 1969.'' Aetna also said that it had followed a regular practice of selling major real estate assets of Urban as a means of realizing the value that company creates by developing property into highly marketable commercial real estate.

title: CUOMO AGAIN VETOES A DEATH PENALTY BILL
description: For the second consecutive year, Governor Cuomo has vetoed legislation to restore the death penalty for certain crimes, including the killing of an on-duty police officer, contract murders and killing during the commission of a felony.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The street disappeared. Then the smoke settled down, and there was nothing there.

title: WROTE 4-VOLUME TEXTBOOK
description: John F. Mehegan, a jazz pianist, teacher and author whose four-volume work, ''Jazz Improvisation,'' is one of the most widely used publications for teaching jazz piano, died of a brain tumor Tuesday at Waveny Care Center in New Canaan, Conn. Mr. Mehegan, who was 67 years old, maintained a studio in Westport for 20 years but had moved to Rowayton shortly before his death.

title: Hearing on New Trial For Militant Ordered
description: A Federal appeals panel, citing a Federal Bureau of Investigation Teletype, today ordered a hearing to determine if a convicted American Indian militant, Leonard Peltier, should receive a new trial in the 1975 shooting deaths of two bureau agents on a South Dakota reservation.

title: FORD'S CHALLENGE TO EUROPE
description: The Ford Motor Company's newest automobile, scheduled to be introduced in September, will not be a Ford, a Mercury or a Lincoln. It will be a Merkur (pronounced mare-COOR), a separate car line the company is establishing in an effort to appeal to buyers who otherwise prefer, and can afford, the European sedans sold by BMW, Saab, Volvo and Mercedes-Benz.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
SAVING COUNTER SPACE
description: THERE never seems to be enough kitchen counter space. One way to expand it is to mount appliances on a wall or under a cabinet.

title: FRISCH'S RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 4
Vehicle Sales Rise in Japan
description: Sales of cars, trucks and buses in Japan rebounded in March, rising 77 percent from February and 8.3 percent from the period a year earlier, to a record 574,254 units, the Japan Automobile Dealers' Association said today.

title: GUINEA'S MILITARY VOWS TO PROMOTE FREE ENTERPRISE
description: The military junta that seized power in this West African nation on Tuesday vowed in a communique issued today to encourage free enterprise and uphold human rights.

description: To the Editor: Edward Hasbrouck called the Solo

title: Jackson Obtains Court Order Impounding Voting Machines
description: All voting machines in New York City were impounded by court order yesterday after the Rev. Jesse Jackson charged that they might have been tampered with during the Democratic Presidential primary Tuesday.

title: GOVERNORS TO STUDY SEABROOK UNITS
description: The governors of the six New England states met privately today to discuss how to cancel the No. 2 unit at the Seabrook, N.H., nuclear plant, but resolved instead to study whether both units should be canceled.

title: New Space-Buying Aid Starts at Doyle Dayne
description: Yesterday marked the introduction of Doyle Dane Bernbach's new computer-based newspaper buying and planning process.

title: FABRIC EXHIBITION AT FASHION INSTITUTE
description: In the days when Marie Antoinette used to wake up at Versailles, her gaze most likely fell upon a pink and yellow wall hanging in her bedroom, a delicately woven fabric filled with peacock feathers, flower petals, bow knots and curls.

title: BLACK STRENGTH IN CITYVOTING
description: News Analysis

title: AIDS RESEARCHERS REPORT DEFECT MAY BE TREATED WITH INTERFERON
description: Researchers say they have discovered a key, potentially treatable, defect in the immune systems of AIDS victims, strengthening their hope that a type of interferon could be the first effective medicine for the lethal disorder.

title: 3 DEMOCRATIC CANDIDATES TAILOR STRATEGIES TO FIT PENNSYLVANIANS
description: Jesse Jackson's strong showing marks a turning point in New York politics. News analysis, page B1. Voter survey shows strong support for Governor Cuomo, page B10.

title: INTEREST RATES RISE SLIGHTLY
description: Interest rates rose slightly yesterday, reflecting weak investor demand. Securities dealers said trading losses had caused some speculators to withdraw from the market, putting more downward pressure on prices.

title: PRIMARY POLL: VOTERS ARE HAPPY WITH CUOMO AND, TO A LESSER EXTENT, KOCH
description: New York State residents who voted in the Democratic Presidential primary on Tuesday strongly approved the job performance of Governor Cuomo, according to a New York Times/CBS News Poll of primary voters. A smaller majority of city Democrats were favorable to Mayor Koch, the poll indicated.

title: PLEA OF NOT GUILTY IS MADE BY FATHER IN SINGER'S SLAYING
description: The father of the singer Marvin Gaye today pleaded not guilty to murdering his son and was ordered to undergo a psychiatric examination after his attorney said there was ''good reason to question his mental competence.''

title: U. of Chicago in German Link
description: The University of Chicago said today that it would assume ownership and control of the Institut f"ur Demoskopie, a West German public opinion research organization. The university said it would begin an exchange program with the 90 staff members of the institute, which was founded in 1947.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Bell Industries , a Los Angeles- based aircraft parts company, said it had terminated by mutual agreement its merger discussions with Astrex Inc., a distributor of electronics.

description: Richard Schickel. Illustrated. 672

title: HECLA AND SUNSHINE IN COMPETITION FOR RANCHERS EXPLORATION
description: In 1896, a prospector named Heber Holt found and claimed the Escalante silver mine in southwest Utah. But his dreams of quick wealth were frustrated when the cost of getting the silver out proved to be too high.

title: ART HISTORIAN AND COLLECTOR
description: Douglas Cooper, internationally known as a collector, critic and historian of modern art and as an organizer of major exhibitions in Britain and in this country, died Sunday in a London hospital. He was 72 years old.

description: The idea, which everyone liked, went like this:

CASH GIFTS TO HELP COUNTY HOLD TRIAL
description: Some Californians seeking the swift execution of a convicted murderer believe Nevada would be willing to do it, so they are contributing money to help finance the trial there.

title: FOR MEESE, UNDER FIRE, THE END OF INFIGHTING
description: Amid all the egocentric rivalries and power struggles at the White House, there is a herd instinct, too, when one of the principals is wounded.

title: SUBPOENA FOR DATA AT JOURNAL
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has served a subpoena for documents belonging to The Wall Street Journal, the newspaper disclosed yesterday. The commission is seeking personnel records of several members of The Journal's staff as well as other documents.

title: 3 Massachusetts Men Cleared in Rape Trial
description: Two Lynn police officers were found not guilty today of charges that they took turns raping a woman in a bar last year after buying her half a dozen drinks.

title: Worthy Service
description: Last night in the football offices of Columbia University's athletic department, a class of 10 students completed a 12-hour training session conducted by the Literacy Volunteers of America. The course qualified the volunteers to teach reading skills to illiterate residents of the Morningside Heights community; two of these teachers, Eric Dill and Mark Raketich, are members of the Columbia football team.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York Stock Exchange issued yesterday its latest report of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchange.

title: SHUTTLE TEAM PREPARED TO REPAIR U.S. SATELLITE
description: The countdown began today for the launching Friday of the space shuttle Challenger on a planned six-day mission to track down and attempt to repair an ailing scientific satellite.

title: STANDARD BRED PACERS & TROLLERS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Hood Nears Record
description: Bruce Hood officiated his 104th playoff game. The record for referees is 105, by Bill Chadwick, from 1941 to 1955. . . . Although the Islanders committed fewer penalties than 19 other teams in the league, they were at a player-disadvantage 80 more times than the opposition. Against the Rangers, they had only three power- play chances.

title: AMERICAN FINANCIAL ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: American Financial is the successor company to the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad Company which merged from bankruptcy in August 1980. The common stock is listed on the Pacific and Midwest Stock Exchanges. Approximately 70 percent of the stock is owned by American Financial Corporation.

title: ELEMENTAL BOWLS: LANDSCAPES IN CLAY
description: WITH names like ''Zigzag Canyon,'' ''Sun Spot Cove'' and ''Mammoth Rock Beach,'' Wayne Higby's graceful bowls transport the viewer from Greenwich Village to the shores of Maine and the cliffs of Colorado.

SPORTS PEOPLE ; Comings and Goings
description: Steve Zungul of the Golden Bay Earthquakes was named the most valuable player in the North American Soccer League's indoor season, in balloting by the league's players. . . . The attorney for Joe Namath entered a guilty plea to a charge of drunken driving against the former quarterback, stemming from an incident in Beverly Hills, Calif., last August. Namath was fined $663 and placed on three years' probation.

title: LIBYA ACCUSED AT U.N., BUT U.S. IS THE TARGET
description: A week ago, after the Sudan accused Libya of carrying out a bombing raid on its second biggest city, the Sudanese Foreign Minister came here to bring a formal complaint to the Security Council.

title: Loan for Korean Bank
description: A group of foreign banks is scheduled to sign an agreement on April 12 in New York to lend the state-run Korea Exchange Bank $600 million, the bank said today. A Korean spokesman said the loan would be co- managed by 25 leading banks, including Chase Manhattan, Citibank, Bank of America, the Royal Bank of Canada and leading British, West German, French and Japanese banks. It is to be repaid over eight years.

title: Ex-Congressman's Petition Assails U.S. Abscam Record
description: Former Representative John Jenrette, Democrat of South Carolina, asked the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Tuesday to overturn his 1980 Abscam conviction for bribery and conspiracy.

title: SENSORMATIC ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
ENDOWMENT SUSPENDS GRANTS FOR ART CRITICS
description: A controversial program of fellowship grants to art critics has been suspended by the National Endowment for the Arts, pending review by an ''internal task force'' to be appointed by Frank Hodsoll, the endowment's chairman.

title: OPERATION SUCCESS
description: Despite Vietnam and Cambodia and all the talk about the end of American innocence, most Americans continue to think of our country as devoted to respect for law and humanity in international life. They would be surprised, I think, to realize that the United States today is involved in a war of terror and subversion against an internationally recognized Government.

title: British Woolworth Plan
description: The F. W. Woolworth Company, Britain's fifth-largest retailer, is negotiating to sell 34 stores, many in prime shopping areas of major cities. Paternoster Stores, the British consortium that bought the chain in 1982, said on Tuesday that no agreements had been reached yet. Since buying the chain, Paternoster has sold more than 70 Woolworth stores.

description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, speaking today to the World Affairs Council here, amplified some of his foreign policy positions and described how his approach would affect domestic programs and the economy.

title: DATA GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 10
Couple Held In Fraud Case
description: A husband and wife who leased a seat on the New York Futures Exchange and operated a commodity trading pool were charged yesterday with engaging in fraudulent securities operations.

title: Ford Satellites
description: The Ford Motor Company said it had received a contract valued at more than $177 million to build and launch for the Direct Broadcast Satellite Corporation two satellites to broadcast television direct to homes via roof-mounted antennas. The company said the contract also includes additional performance payments for the 10-year in-orbit life of the satellites and an option for a third satellite. It said Direct Broadcast will take delivery in 1987, with a planned launching by the French Ariane rocket from French Guiana in 1987.

title: Bonn Seeks Tightening Of Emission Controls
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Cabinet, alarmed by widespread damage to West German forests, called today for stricter emmission controls for factories and cars in a fight against air pollution.

description: The Limited Inc. began its cash tender offer of $30 a share for 20.3 million shares of Carter Hawley Hale Stores, but directors of Carter Hawley, at a board meeting, did not formally comment on the offer. The directors, however, declared the regular quarterly dividend of 30 1/2 cents a share on the common stock.

title: ISLANDERS OVERCOME RANGERS WITH 2 SCORING SPURTS
description: Strangely, the Islanders looked disorganized in the first period tonight against a Ranger team that outplayed them and took a 1-0 lead. Then the Islanders seemed to recall that they were opening their quest for a fifth consecutive Stanley Cup and struck for two quick goals in each of the last two periods for a 4-1 victory.

title: Pay Rises in Australia
description: Australia's 6.5 million workers will get a 4.1 percent pay increase next week following a decision today by the National Wage Board. The Government praised the decision, but employers said the increase, matching the rise in consumer prices during the last half of 1983, would hinder economic recovery.

title: STAGE:'GARDEN OF EARTHLY DELIGHTS'
description: MARTHA CLARKE'S dramatization of Hieronymus Bosch's painting ''Garden of Earthly Delights'' is an inspired synthesis of the visual and the performing arts. A production of the Music Theater Group/ Lenox Arts Center, the ensemble performance piece opened last night at St. Clement's.

title: COCOA FALLS DAILY LIMIT IN HEAVY PROFIT TAKING
description: Cocoa futures posted a second consecutive day of heavy losses today. Cocoa plunged the daily allowed limit of $88 a metric ton as chart-minded speculators decided it was time to take profits after weeks of rising prices.

title: Stacy Keach Arrested On London Drug Count
description: The authorities arrested the American actor Stacy Keach on a charge of importing cocaine, held him overnight and then released him today after he paid a cash bail of $100,100.

title: 3 WESTERN POWERS PROTEST ON BERLIN
description: The United States, Britain and France have protested to the Soviet Union over Soviet military exercises in the air corridors to West Berlin that have forced Western commercial and military planes to alter their normal flight patterns to the city, the State Department said today.

title: GIRLS NOW GAINING FAST ON BOYS IN TEAM ATHLETICS IN HIGH SCHOOL
description: Of the 524 students on athletic teams at the Hopewell Valley Central High School here, 245 are girls and 279 are boys. The $21,000 budget for sports equipment is divided equally between the sexes.

title: LEAK/LYRIC; Vengefully Secret
description: For leaking a document that at worst embarrasses her Government, Sarah Tisdall, a 23-year-old clerk, is now serving six months in jail. What's remarkable is that she was tried not in Chile or East Germany but in Britain, under a law as menacing as any to press freedom.

title: Yields Rise On C.D.'s
description: Annual effective yields on six- month certificates of deposit and money market accounts climbed across the country yesterday, The Bank Rate Monitor reported.

Riley's plan had been to play the Laker captain fewer minutes and to take him out of games whose outcome had been decided.

FATE OF MIDLAND PLANT STUDIED
description: The Consumers Power Company said today that, for the first time, it was discussing the possibility of abandoning its uncompleted Midland nuclear power plant. The talks are being held with a coalition of state officials, consumers and industrial customers who have urged cancellation of the long-delayed plant.

title: Socal, Mesa Extend Bids
description: The Standard Oil Company of California said it had received more than 121 million common shares of the Gulf Corporation, or about 74 percent of those outstanding, in response to its tender offer for all shares at $80 each.

title: MIXED PERFORMANCE BY U.S. SWIMMERS
description: A surprising thing happened last week at the United States indoor swimming championships in Indianapolis. In 17 events for men and 17 for women, not a world record or even an American record was broken.

title: FARRAH FAWCETT STARS IN 'THE RED LIGHT STING'
description: FARRAH FAWCETT'S bumpy career takes one of its more embarrassing spills tonight in ''The Red-Light Sting,'' a made-for-television movie on CBS at 9 o'clock. Miss Fawcett, she of the hair made for shampoo commercials, first came to prominence and considerable fortune as one of the ''Charlie's Angels'' originals. Heading for what she anticipated would be worthier material, the actress made four eminently forgettable theatrical- release movies but managed to salvage her reputation once again in television, in a mini-series entitled ''Murder in Texas.'' Then she received very respectable notices for replacing the lead in the Off Broadway stage production of ''Extremities.'' The time was ripe for a triumphant return to television. Somebody obviously goofed.

title: DYED EASTER EGGS, UKRANIAN STYLE
description: ACCORDING to Ukrainian folklore, the fate of the world depends on pysanky, intricately decorated dyed Easter eggs. As long as people make pysanky, it is said, a monster personifying evil will remain chained to its cliff and the world will be safe.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: ORIGINAL GREEK This is the sixth year that the Barnard-Columbia Greek Drama Group has mounted a production of classical Greek theater in its original form and language. This year's work is Euripides's ''Electra,'' the story of a woman who helps her brother, Orestes, avenge the murder of their father, Agamemnon, by their mother, Clytemnestra. ''Electra'' was first staged as the Peloponnesian War ended, around 413 B.C., when the power of Athens had waned and its values were in question.

description: b-Net income after a tax credit of $799,000. The results for both years include the operations of businesses acquired on a pooling-of-interests basis.

title: AQUINO INQUIRY: SORTING OUT THE FACTS
description: After five months of inquiry, the commission investigating the assassination of Benigno S. Aquino Jr. has tracked down to the minute the events surrounding the killing of the Filipino opposition leader.

title: Group Says It Shot Soldier
description: An anti- American terrorist group took responsibility today for the wounding of a United States soldier in the Greek capital on Tuesday. The group, called November 17, said in a message to an Athens newspaper that Master Sgt. Robert H. Judd Jr. was shot to protest the Greek Government's failure to remove four United States bases in Greece. November 17, an extreme leftist group, has taken responsibility for the killings of a United States Navy officer nearly five months ago and of a C.I.A. station chief in 1975.

title: SECRET CATHOLICISM BURSTS INTO BLOOM, CZECHS SAY
description: The gathering was illegal and could have meant two years in prison for each of the 40 young people who sat on the floor listening intently to the older man, a banished Roman Catholic theologian, lecturing on God and man. In the hallway, coats and shoes were piled in neat clumps; several young men had traveled all the way from Slovakia for the lecture.

title: FINE ART ACQUISITIONS LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a $28,800 extraordinary gain. c-After a $31,000 extraorindary gain.

title: CONCERT: SEGOVIA PERFORMS
description: THERE comes a time in a great musician's life, if he survives long enough, when the public is happy merely to be in his presence. If he still plays well, that is all right, too, but it no longer is necessary. Who he is and has been are more important than what he does. Andres Segovia, at age 91, has reached that point in a glorious career, and Wednesday night Avery Fisher Hall was crammed with people eager to receive whatever gifts of music the grandee of the Spanish guitar might bestow on them. As usual, dozens of ticket holders in the sold-out house had to be seated onstage.

title: NANKIN EXPRESS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: The company said that the year-ago figures represent its operations starting in June 1982.

title: Fortune Federal Gives Executive New Title
description: Rausey W. Mason has been named president and managing officer of the Fortune Federal Savings and Loan Association.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Unit Officer Named At Dayton-Hudson
description: Robert J. Ulrich has been named president of the newly formed Dayton-Hudson Department Store Company. In March, the parent Dayton- Hudson Corporation of Minneapolis announced that it was combining its Dayton's and Hudson's department store chains and named P. Gerald Mills chairman and chief executive of the new company.

title: FOES OF SIKHS CLASH WITH POLICE IN DELHI
description: Protesters throwing rocks clashed with the police here today during a strike called by an opposition party to protest the wave of killings by Sikhs in Punjab state. The police said they had deployed 21,000 men in the city.

title: SOUTH ATLANTIC FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes an estimated charge of $750,000 for legal and administrative costs associated with its bankruptcy proceedings. c-Net income.

title: MUSIC: TUDOR SINGERS OF MONTREAL AT ALICE TULLY
description: THE Tudor Singers of Montreal arrived for their New York debut Monday night at Alice Tully Hall with considerable fanfare. The group traces its history to 1965, when Wayne Riddell organized it as a small amateur chorus. Over the next decade the ensemble kept expanding, and finally in 1976 Mr. Riddell was encouraged by the Canada Council to reorganize it as a 20-member professional chorus. Since then, it has toured Canada and Europe to great acclaim.

title: American Jewish Congress Chooses a New President
description: Theodore R. Mann, a lawyer in Philadelphia, has been elected to head the American Jewish Congress.

title: A Gift of 'Ice'
description: Henry J. Stern, the Commissioner of Parks and Recreation, says that a proposed gift to the city of 5,000 square feet of artificial ice for skating ''is generous'' and that ''we'd like to accept it, if it's practical.''

title: VITALITY UNLIMITED reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: 2 ACCORDS WITH CHINA SAID TO BE IN JEOPARDY
description: Two agreements that President Reagan was expected to sign with fanfare when he goes to Peking later this month are in jeopardy, Administration officials said today.

title: Meredith Start-Up
description: The Meredith Corporation, a publisher that feels particularly comfortable covering homey topics, is next going to bring out Wood, a six-times- a-year magazine about woodworking.

title: KASPAROV AND SMYSLOV DRAW 11TH CHESS GAME
description: Bold defense by Vasily Smyslov of the Soviet Union earned him a draw with his countryman Gary Kasparov in the 11th game of their final candidates chess match Tuesday. However, draws are now all to the benefit of the 20-year-old Kasparov, who kept a 3-point lead in the series, with the score Kasparov 7, Smyslov 4.

title: No Headline
description: Senator Gary Hart, in language indicating that he would maintain his emphasis on ''new ideas,'' said again today that the Democratic Party must turn to new leadership if it hopes to defeat President Reagan in the election in the fall.

title: INTELLIGENT COMMUNICAIONS NETWORKS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Ingram to Pursue Bid for Corroon
description: Ingram Industries said it had the financing necessary to complete its proposed $253 million acquisition of the Corroon & Black Corporation and ''will continue to pursue its offer'' despite Corroon's criticism of the bid.

title: Army Seeking a Fort as Site For a New Infantry Division
description: The Army is considering forts in six states as a possible home base for a new 10,000-man light infantry division to be formed next year, it was announced today.

title: A CONSENSUS IN SUPPORT OF DRAFT REGISTRATION
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST THURSDAY, APRIL 5, 1984
description: International

title: CHRISTOPHER TIETZE, PHYSICIAN AND AUTHORITY ON PREGNANCY
description: Dr. Christopher Tietze, an authority on the hazards of contraception and pregnancy, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 75 years old.

title: ORROX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss. c-After a one-time curtailment expense for Satcom of $2.3 million.

title: LECLAIR ENJOYING EXTENDED CAREER
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: A New Cab Service Makes Its Debut

title: INNOVATIVE TILE DESIGNS
description: CASA TILE '84 presents the work of 14 designers and their tile vignettes.

title: PEKING SAYS ITS GUNNERS SHELLED VIETNAMESE POSTS IN RETALIATION
description: China said today that its gunners on the southern frontier had destroyed Vietnamese observation posts, gun emplacements and ammunition depots, killing or wounding dozens of Vietnamese soldiers.

title: DNA PLANT TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Y.& R. Chairman Backs Election-Process Study
description: Convinced that the American electoral process is badly in need of repair - and that television is responsible for much of the problem - Edward N. Ney, chairman of Young & Rubicam, has pledged $25,000 to help set up an independent group to study ways of fixing it.

title: HERS
description: A FRIEND asked me to explain why she had seen ''Coming Home'' eight times. ''Coming Home'' is the film in which Jane Fonda plays the wife of a macho Marine officer. While he is serving in Vietnam she falls in love with a disaffected Vietnam veteran, paralyzed from the waist down. I asked my obsessed friend if she had liked ''Jane Eyre'' and if she was aware of the appeal of a wounded man. She saw the connection.

title: IF BANKRUPTCY JUDGES HAD LIFE TENURE
description: To the Editor:

title: VECTOR AUTOMATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The year-ago share earnings adjusted for a 130-for-1 stock split paid Dec. 7, 1983.

title: CUTLER-FEDERAL INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Charter Sees Loss In First Quarter
description: Shares of the Charter Company dropped sharply today following the company's disclosure that it expected a first-quarter loss from continuing operations ''significantly greater'' than the $4.5 million loss in the quarter a year earlier.

title: Belgian Jobless Rate
description: Belgium's unemployment rate fell to 12.3 percent in March from its record high of 12.5 percent in February, but was slightly higher than the 12.2 percent rate a year earlier.

title: INFORMER IN CBS KILLINGS TESTIFIES
description: SELWYN RAAB

title: Gillette Will Buy Cooper's Oral-B
description: The Gillette Company said yesterday that it had agreed in principle to acquire Oral-B Laboratories, the dental care business of Cooper Laboratories, for $188.5 million in cash.

title: SALVADORAN PEOPLE'S WILL FREELY EXPRESSED
description: To the Editor:

title: Cable Network Plans Broadcast of Debate
description: The Democratic Presidential debate in Pittsburgh tonight, sponsored by the League of Women Voters, will be televised live by CNN, the Cable News Network, from 8 to 9 P.M.

title: FAR-FLUNG FOSSILS GATHERED FOR EXHIBIT
description: Never has there been such an assembly. There was the skull of a Taung child who lived in South Africa 2.25 million years ago. Next to it were specimens of Tautavel Man, who inhabited the south of France 450,000 years ago. Across the room, and estimated to be 600,000 years old, was the original Neanderthal skull, found in 1856 in the valley of Germany's Neander River.

title: INQUIRIES '84: THE CAST IS FAMILIAR
description: Ten years ago today, Jacob A. Stein made his final argument to the jury in defense of Dwight L. Chapin, President Nixon's former appointments secretary, who was accused of lying to a Watergate grand jury about his knowledge of campaign ''dirty tricks.''

title: MONDALE, COMING OUT FIGHTING, BIDS FOR SUPPORT IN PENNSYLVANIA
description: Carrying red Everlast boxing gloves, Walter F. Mondale carried his scrappy campaign to Philadelphia today.

title: Oldest Briton Dies
description: Alfie Grant, who at age 107 was said to be the oldest person in Britain, died today after refusing treatment for a chest infection. Mr. Grant was a lifelong bachelor who smoked 20 cigarettes a day. He was born April 19, 1876, in London's East End and was a construction worker as a young man.

title: LAWMAKER AND MRS. SCHALFLY CLASH OVER EQUAL PAY ISSUE
description: Phyllis Schlafly and a Democratic Congresswoman faced off today on the issue of whether women should be paid as much as men for work requiring comparable skill.

title: WHEN AN INDUSTRY IS TOO BUSY
description: As an executive in an industry that is operating near 100 percent of capacity, George E. Rogers, manager of the Crown Zellerbach Corporation's paper mill in St. Francisville, La., has discovered that such a boom in paper demand is not an unalloyed blessing.

title: Grumman Loses Suit Over Buses
description: A $500 million damage suit, filed by the Grumman Corporation against the California company from which it had purchased its Flxible Bus Division, was dismissed today by a Federal judge.

title: BRESLER & REINER INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
JACKSON, DEMOCRATIC REVOLUTIONARY
description: It is always dangerous to draw quick lessons of history from an election only a few days past. But the temptation is too great to resist as one reads the returns of head-counting in New York.

title: A SEAGOING SUPERMARKET IS LURING GERMANS
description: It is not the Leonardo da Vinci or the QE2. But for Paula Neumann, a retired nurse who sits making furry little poodles out of wool and buttons at a window below deck, the ride to Denmark on the First Lady, at 75 cents a round trip, will do just fine.

title: Queen to Visit U.S.
description: Queen Elizabeth II will make her first private visit to the United States from Oct. 8-15, when she will tour racehorse stud farms in Kentucky and a ranch in Wyoming, Buckingham Palace said today. She is not expected to meet President Reagan since her visit will take place at the height of the Presidential election campaign.

title: Required Reading ; A Wing and a Prayer
description: Remarks of Representative Sherwood Boehlert, Republican of New York, to the House of Representatives, March 20:

title: LEISURE DYNAMICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a $6.8 million gain on reorganization under Chapter 11, and a gain of $2.4 million from utilization of prior years' net operating loss carryover. c-Net loss. The company emerged from Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code on Dec. 5, 1983, after an 11-month period of reorganization.

title: GORDON JEWELRY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Includes a $5.6 million gain from sale of certain real estate.

title: Data General's Income Soars The Data General Corporation, citing continued gains in
description: orders and shipment levels,

title: YANKEES 4, ROYALS 3
description: Phil Niekro and Dave Righetti shared a milestone tonight and brought a collective feeling of relief to the Yankees' brain trust.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: Fingers Returns
description: He spent more than a year on the disabled list because of arm problems, but when Rollie Fingers returned to action Tuesday night it was clear that the Milwaukee Brewers' star reliever had lost none of the control that had helped him establish a major league record of 301 career saves. ''Everything I threw went exactly where I wanted to throw it,'' said Fingers, who had little else to boast about after a brief appearance against the Oakland A's.

title: No Headline
description: The spring retail business, mainly for home furnishings and clothing, is expected to improve this month, providing a strong finish to an excellent first fiscal quarter, according to merchants, analysts and economists.

title: LOSSES LEAD RCA TO CANCEL VIDEODISK PLAYER PRODUCTION
description: The RCA Corporation said yesterday that it would stop manufacturing and marketing its videodisk player. The withdrawal came three years after RCA, introducing the product, said it would revolutionize home entertainment.

title: NATCO INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: No Headline
description: House Unit Passes Bill On Religion in Schools WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) - Legislation approved today by a House subcommittee would require public high schools to give student religious groups the same privileges to meet on school premises as other voluntary student groups.

title: GEMAYEL TO VISIT SYRIAN FOR HELP
description: President Amin Gemayel will go to Damascus in the next few days for talks with President Hafez al-Assad on how to end the factional fighting here and on the formation of a government of national unity, a Lebanese official said today.

title: IRAQI IRRESPONSIBILITY
description: The one arms control agreement that has worked effectively for almost six decades is being dealt an irreparable blow in the Iran-Iraq war. In blatant violation of obligations it assumed in 1931 when it ratified the Geneva Protocol of 1925, Iraq is using mustard and nerve gases against Iranian ''human wave'' invaders.

title: UTILITY WANTS TO FINISH MARBLE HILL
description: The Wabash Valley Power Association said today that it wanted to complete the Marble Hill power plant, either as a nuclear-fueled plant from the original designs or as a coal-fired plant, but would need a hefty rate increase to do so.

title: Trevino Tees Up
description: Lee Trevino offered an amazing performance in last week's Tournament Players Championship, finishing second to Fred Couples by a single shot. This runner-up spot was worth $86,400, the biggest purse Trevino had ever won on the PGA Tour, even though he has captured 26 tournaments, including two United States Opens, two British Opens and a P.G.A. Championship.

title: Macy's Spending
description: R. H. Macy & Company said it plans to spend about $1 billion through 1990 on new stores and the remodeling and expansion of existing stores.

title: 300 Warned of Lava Danger
description: About 300 people who live on the slopes of the erupting Mauna Loa volcano were told today to prepare themselves to evacuate their homes on 24 hours' notice. The homes are threatened by an unpredictable, 30-foot-high river of molten lava pushing toward the coastal city of Hilo.

title: Bull Unit Gets Interest
description: The French state-controlled computer company, Bull, said today that its Bull Sems subsidiary had acquired an interest of about 10 percent in Ridge Computers of Sunnyvale, Calif.

title: A's 4, Brewers 3
description: Dave Lopes doubled to dirve in a run in the sixth, and Carney Lansford followed with a run-scoring single as Oakland battled from behind for the second straight game. Lansford had three hits, including the game-winner, and Ray Burris pitched six innings of strong relief before giving way to Bill Caudill in the ninth. The loser was Mike Caldwell, the Brewer left-hander, who was staked to an early 3-0 lead.

title: SONOMA VINEYARDS reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
Northwest, Sedco
description: Northwest Industries told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it and Sedco Inc. had terminated a June 1983 agreement concerning their purchases of shares of the Pogo Producing Company.

title: N.C.A.A. Puts Off Ruling on Clock
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association's Rules Committee decided today to put off for at least another season the use of a 45-second shot clock in Division I men's basketball.

title: FAFCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
OPTELECOM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a $31,699 tax credit. c-Net income includes a $72,811 tax credit.

title: News Quiz Trips Seven In Massachusetts Race
description: On the first night of a television news quiz, two senatorial candidates could not name Israel's Prime Minister, and on the second night all seven candidates flunked questions on defense policy.

title: BALANCHINE'S 'SERENADE' STILL BAFFLES BALLETGOERS
description: FOR 50 years, George Balanchine's ''Serenade'' has been a lovely enigma. Yet rationalists might contend that there is nothing strange about it. They could easily argue that this ballet of 1934 is just an abstraction to Tchaikovsky glorifying Classical technique. To rationalists, ''Serenade'' must be as clear as sunlight.

title: Democracy Enlarged; Also Polluted ; Cheating the Voters on the Evening News
description: Sometimes, to those of us in the print branch of the news business, television can be an exasperating cousin. We share many interests and problems with TV news and just two days ago advocated freeing its political coverage from Government regulation. But that very night, election night in New York - and hours before the polls closed - the networks were pronouncing magisterially that it was a big night for Walter Mondale. Don't they see this as an abuse of the vote? Don't they hear the properly angry reaction bubbling up around the country?

title: People
description: Joseph Carlucci and Christine Hansen have been appointed to the newly created positions of executive vice president at Geers Gross.

title: No Headline
description: Dr.MarylandB.Byrne, Physician and Lawyer

title: CORRECTION
description: A restaurant review in some editions of Weekend last Friday incompletely described the ownership of La Caravelle. Roger Fessaguet and Robert Meyzen are co-owners.

title: TWO MANHATTAN APARTMENTS TURN ARCHITECTURE OUTSIDE IN
description: THERE are architects who design the interiors of apartments as though they were creating the exterior of a building. Young architects particularly - especially those who have not built many freestanding buildings - tend to look for the larger structure in the smaller one, designing what might be called interior architecture. The results are frequently unexpected and sometimes ingenious.

title: The Churchill Bunker Reopened in London
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher today officially reopened the underground wartime bunker of one of her most illustrious predecessors, Winston Churchill.

title: 2 MACHINES CHALLENGE I.B.M.
description: Commodore International Ltd., the highly successful home computer maker that two months ago went through a turbulent change of management, said yesterday that it would market its two sophisticated office computers to compete directly with those made by the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: Italian Premier Wins New Vote on Missiles
description: The Government of Prime Minister Bettino Craxi won a second vote today endorsing its deployment of 16 United States cruise missiles at the Comiso base on the island of Sicily.

title: INTERNATIONAL MOBILE MAHINES CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
LAIDLAW INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Man Wins Retrial On Drug Charges By The Associated Press
description: A new trial has been ordered for a man who was convicted on drug charges after his wife testified for the prosecution but refused to testify for the defense.

title: ADVANCED GENETIC SCIENCES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income including an extraordinary credit of $123,000.

title: Filing of Preferred By Houston Bank
description: First City Bancorporation of Houston has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the sale of one million shares of $50 adjustable- rate preferred stock, through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: TRANSAMERICA REALTY INVESORS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After a gain of $1.5 million on sale of property. c-Net loss.

title: MACHINE TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $173,000 related to receipt of life insurance proceeds. c-Net loss

title: JEFFERSON, YEATS AND TOSTOY OFFER HINTS TO HART'S THINKING
description: Three books sit on Gary Hart's desk in the Russell Senate Office Building. Two are the writings of Thomas Jefferson. The third is a collection of poetry by William Butler Yeats.

title: INTEREST ON CHASE NOTES MAY BE PAID IN STOCK
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation increased the size of its sale of floating-rate subordinated notes to $400 million from $300 million. It is offering the notes through a group of underwriters led by Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb.

title: 'FRONTLINE' VIEWS ALABAMA PRIMARY
description: THE Democratic primary in Alabama last month marked, if not a turning point, then at least a departure from the norm. For one thing, blacks voted in proportionately larger numbers than did whites. And for another, the Rev. Jesse Jackson was defeated - not so much by another Presidential candidate as by another black politician. The primary is the subject of ''The Struggle for Birmingham,'' a ''Frontline'' documentary, on Channel 13 at 10 o'clock tonight.

title: GROUNDED SHIP IS A BOON TO CAPE COD TOWN
description: Cape Cod has a new and unexpected off-season tourist attraction: the 478-foot Maltese freighter Eldia, which ran aground on Nauset Beach about 5 miles east of here in the big storm last Thursday.

title: JULIA CHILD SUES A HOTEL ON THE USE OF HER NAME
description: Julia Child, television's ''French Chef,'' is upset about a restaurant promotion using her name.

title: Baseball
description: Yankees vs. Royals, at Kansas City, Mo. Kansas City's starter is Larry Gura, who had established a reputation as a Yankee-killer before dropping two of three decisions to New York last season. (Television - Channel 11, 8:30 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8:30 P.M.) Basketball

title: O.A.S. TO STUDY DISCLOSURES ABOUT EX-CHIEF'S EXTRA PAY
description: The Organization of American States agreed today to investigate whether its former Secretary General acted improperly in going to work for a public relations company three months before he stepped down from the O.A.S.

title: U.S. VETOES U.N. BID TO CONDEMN MINING OF NICARAGUAN PORT
description: The United States today vetoed a proposed Security Council resolution that would have condemned the mining of Nicaraguan ports.

title: TAKEOVER RUMORS SPUR MILTON BRADLEY STOCK
description: The price of the stock of the Milton Bradley Company, a major manufacturer of games based in Springfield, Mass., climbed sharply yesterday on rumors the company might be the target of an acquisition bid.

title: BUSINESS EXCHANGE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: Times Company in Pact To Purchase Magazine
description: The New York Times Company announced yesterday that it is planning to acquire its fourth participant-sport magazine, Cruising World, from Cruising World Publications in Newport, R.I.

title: O'Neill and Baker Agree: Mondale's Back in Front
description: House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. and the Senate majority leader, Howard H. Baker Jr., said today that Walter F. Mondale's victory Tuesday in the New York primary put him back in front in the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Compensation Bill for Jailing
description: William Bernard Jackson, who spent four years and eight months in prison for rapes and burglaries committed by a look-alike with the same last name, was given permission Tuesday to seek state compensation. Gov. Richard F. Celeste signed a bill that allows Mr. Jackson to go to the Ohio Court of Claims for a settlement. A Columbus physician, Edward Jackson, confessed to the crimes and was convicted.

title: Man Loses Control of Truck, Sideswiping 12 or More Cars
description: The driver of a tractor-trailer truck lost control of his rig today, sideswiping at least a dozen cars, forcing some off the road and ramming into the rear of one, injuring four people.

title: CITY
description: AS a higher sun lingers longer in the city's canyons, brightening hidden yards and rooftop terraces, it inspires the urban gardener to begin dealing with the effects of winter.

title: Bengals Trade No. 1 Pick
description: The Cincinnati Bengals, who failed

title: DATA PACKAGING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 3
description: b-After a gain of $328,000 from discontinued operations.

title: JB'S RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 11
Advertising; Needham's Issues Unit Is Spun Off
description: ON May 1, Needham, Harper & Steers will turn loose the New York office of NH&S/Issues & Images, with its $20 million-plus in billings, because the unit has not been able to protect the parent company from client conflicts.

title: Seat for Union Now in Doubt DETROIT, April 4 - Despite
description: the insistence of the United Automobile Workers union that it

title: HONDURAS NAMES NEW MILITARY COMMANDER
description: The Honduran Congress elected the head of the air force to replace the ousted commander of the country's armed forces today.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: A JUDGE ON TRIAL
description: Trying a Federal judge on criminal charges must be one of the most difficult tasks a Federal court can take on, as the trial of District Judge Harry E. Claiborne has demonstrated.

title: Shell Canada
description: Shell Canada Ltd. said it would reduce its work force and relocate to Calgary, Alberta, from Toronto. At a news conference, the company's president, C. William Daniel, said it would reduce its Ontario operations by about 1,000 employees. Some 400 or 500 of the workers will be transferred to Calgary and the rest laid off or asked to take early retirement.

title: Greyhound Unit's $175 Million Sale
description: The Greyhound Leasing and Financial Corporation is offering $75 million of senior notes due in 1994 and $100 million face amount of zero-coupon senior subordinated notes due in 1994, both through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Extend the Ban on Censorship
description: Now that Congress's ban on the Administration's heavy-handed secrecy program is about to expire, the White House is making conciliatory noises to head off any extension. Congress ought not to take the bait.

title: Capitals Down Flyers; Bruins Lose
description: Gaetan Duchesne tipped in a tie- breaking goal at 7:37 of the third period as the Washington Capitals rallied twice and defeated the Philadelphia Flyers, 4-2, in the opening game of their Patrick Division semifinal playoff series.

title: REAGAN DEFENDS HIS RECORD ON WOMEN
description: President Reagan conceded yesterday that he is perceived as not concerned enough about women's issues. At the same time, he denounced sex discrimination as an ''evil'' equal to racial and religious bias.

title: Mancini-Bramble Set
description: Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini , the World Boxing Association's lightweight champion, has concluded an agreement to defend his title against Livingstone Bramble at the Memorial Auditorium in Buffalo on June 1. The 15-round fight, which will be formally announced in Buffalo next Wednesday, will be part of a double championship card that also features a 15-rounder between Johnny Bumphus , the W.B.A.'s undefeated junior- welterweight champion, and Gene Hatcher .

title: STAGE: 'THROUGH THE LEAVES'
description: THE radio is almost always on in ''Through the Leaves,'' the latest Franz Xaver Kroetz play to appear in New York. The dial is tuned to an easy-listening station that broadcasts lulling songs like ''Moon River'' and ''Chances Are.'' Yet there are few other soothing sounds in this acidic account of a woman butcher and her abusive lover. When the heroine's yelping dog isn't drowning out the radio, we're likely to be assaulted by the cacophonous grunts of coarse sex - or the grinding of a butcher's saw cutting through a thick bone.

title: A FORMER CITY COUNSEL
description: Elizabeth Rogers Horan, a former member of the legal staff of the State Department and a former assistant corporation counsel for New York City, died of cancer Wednesday at her home in Newtown, Pa. She was 77 years old.

title: To U.S. Gains
description: Britain's Virgin Atlantic airline won approval today for a low-cost fare between London and Newark, and a spokesman said it hoped to start daily service in June. The flights would put Virgin Atlantic in direct competition with American-owned People Express airline, which now offers one-way flights between Gatwick Airport and Newark for $149 coach and $439 first class.

title: HOTEL INVESTORS TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $244,000 on the sale of a hotel.

title: Las Vegas Picket Hit By Car
description: Hotel workers marched outside 32 resorts today and a picket was hit by a car as attorneys went to court to limit picketing in the fourth day of a bitter walkout along Las Vegas' gambling strip.

title: ACF Prefers Bid By Warburg Firm
description: ACF Industries said it did not consider a takeover bid by an investor group headed by Carl C. Icahn as good as a competing bid from a private investment firm. Under a ''standstill agreement'' ACF has with Mr. Icahn, it agreed to allow him to present a counteroffer to any bid.

title: Sugar Talks Set for June
description: Formal negotiations on a new International Sugar Agreement will open in June in Geneva, it was confirmed today.

title: Prizes Big for Angling Derby
description: Angling for Lake Ontario's various

title: INTERNATIONAL THOMSON ORANIZATION reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $5.4 million. The results are in U.S. dollar amounts, which are given for illustrative purposes only, and are translated at the year-end rate of exchange, 1 pound Sterling equals U.S. $1.4515).

title: TEMPLETON GLOBAL I reports earnings for As of March 31
CITY ERROR ON FUNDS FOR THE MENTALLY ILL
description: To the Editor:

title: Appraising White Elephant II
description: The scenario sounds ominously familiar. As recently as a month ago the official cost estimate for Nine Mile II, the nuclear power plant being built in New York's Oswego County, stood at $4.2 billion. Now Niagara Mohawk, the leader of the consortium of private utilities that owns the 1,100-megawatt plant, estimates a cost of $5.1 billion.

title: PROFITS FOR LAWYER REPORTED
description: A Manhattan lawyer bought stocks and options in at least six companies shortly before The Wall Street Journal published articles on them, an independent source confirmed yesterday. The lawyer, David W. C. Clark, is said to be under investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission for improperly using advance information about Journal articles.

title: Iowa and N. Hampshire Get Convention Rooms By United Press International
description: Hotel accommodations have been announced for the Iowa and New Hampshire delegations to the Democratic National Convention, ending what one leader called a ''childish, immature'' attempt to punish the states for violating party rules.

title: EXOCET MISSILE HIT GREEK TANKER
description: A team of United States Navy explosives experts last week defused an Exocet missile that was lodged in the hull of a Greek oil tanker, the Defense Department said today.

title: Hawaii Issue
description: A $75 million issue of Hawaii general obligation bonds was offered yesterday at yields ranging from 7 percent for bonds due in 1987 to 8.9 percent in 1994 and 10 percent in 2004, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers. The bonds, rated Aa, are backed by the state's full faith and credit.

title: OFFER TO SHELL EMPLOYEES SWEETENED
description: In a move to encourage employees of the Shell Oil Company to sell a crucial block of stock they hold, the Royal Dutch/Shell Group is offering to buy their holdings at an estimated $66 a share - $8 more than is being offered to other Shell stockholders, papers filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission showed yesterday.

title: AMERICAN FUEL TECHNOLOIES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Castle & Cooke Buys Its Shares
description: Castle & Cooke Inc. said it had purchased all 3.3 million of its shares held by a group headed by Charles E. Hurwitz, for $70.8 million. Castle & Cooke, a Honolulu-based food concern, had been fighting what it termed a hostile takeover attempt by Mr. Hurwitz.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: David Copperfield VI To Show His 'Magic'

title: Debt Issues
description: * Associates Corp. of North America, a subsidiary of Gulf and Western Industries, said it had filed for a shelf offering of up to $600 million in unsecured debt securities.

title: Poland Said to Delay A Solidarity Trial
description: The trial of three Solidarity activists accused of fomenting public disorder was postponed indefinitely today because they are ill, defense lawyers said.

title: SHAMIR, AFTER MEETING AN ARAB-AMERICAN, DEPLORES EMBASSY SITE
description: After several weeks of reluctance to speak forcefully on the question of moving the United States Embassy to Jerusalem, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir complained today about the American refusal to recognize the city as Israel's capital.

title: CITY SELLS FORMER POLICE HEADQUARTERS FOR APARTMENTS
description: Stripped to its Baroque bones by copper-hungry vandals and left behind by rescue plans that always fell apart, the old Police Headquarters - still looming over the low roofs of Little Italy - is now to be an apartment house.

title: Addendum
description: * Robert S. Lee Associates, a new consulting firm at 277 West 10th Street.

title: BROADWAY SONGS OF 30'S IN 'LYRICS AND LYRICISTS'
description: NOW in its 14th season, ''Lyrics and Lyricists,'' the concert series at the 92d Street Y that was started to examine the contributions of lyricists to popular songs, has undergone a change of focus. But it has remained so popular that this season a third performance, on Sunday afternoons, has been added to the Sunday and Monday evenings that have been given in the past.

title: Morton Thiokol
description: Morton Thiokol Inc., in response to an inquiry from the New York Stock Exchange, said it is not planning, discussing or considering any major corporate transaction.

title: ARGENTINES, LONG ALOOF, SEEKING LATIN TIES
description: Argentina's new civilian President, Raul Alfonsin, says his country intends to end years of political and cultural isolation and again involve itself with the concerns of the rest of Latin America.

title: On the Record Reagan on Women's Issues
description: From the prepared text of a speech yesterday to the Women Business Owners of New York, as transmitted by The Associated Press:

title: Eurodollar Bonds Little Changed
description: Fixed-interest dollar bonds showed little change from this morning's easier levels.

title: ART: A PIONEER'S EXPERIMENTS WITH ABSTRACTION
description: AN artist who was included in the Whitney Museum's Synchromist show of 1978, Konrad Cramer now has a gallery at the museum to himself, on the ground floor. Here are displayed about 30 small paintings, gouaches and prints, the majority of which are experiments with the notion of total abstraction that first took art by storm in the years before World War I. The show, installed by Gail Levin, a curator at the Whitney, is an excerpt from a Cramer retrospective that was organized by Tom Wolf and Franklin Riehlman at Bard College in 1981, augmented by additional works,

title: REPORTERS' BLINDNESS ON HART
description: Gary Hart clearly has had some trouble standing up to the scrutiny he's received from the press since his victory in New Hamphire more than a month ago. Reporters have found a lot wrong with Mr. Hart, a process in which it must be conceded he has often seemed an eager accomplice. Unfortunately for Mr. Hart and for the rest of us, the press and television have not shown similar interest in what is good about him - his attention, long before the campaign began, to issues that the other candidates have been much slower to perceive.

title: ABDUL-JABBAR SETS N.B.A. RECORD OF 31,421 POINTS
description: After almost 15 splendid seasons, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar tonight achieved the most important feat of his career in a fitting manner. With a 12-foot sky hook fired over a helpless defender from the right baseline, the Laker center became professional basketball's leading career scorer.

title: Bridge: Strong-Club Method Wins Lots of Converts in Iceland
description: Three decades ago strong-club systems were virtually unknown in American tournaments and rare elsewhere. Today they are common and have been favored in world team championships.

title: SWEDES ACCUSED ON A SOVIET DEAL
description: The Justice Department today charged a Swedish electronics company with illegally exporting American parts and equipment to the Soviet Union that gave the Russians advanced military radar capability.

title: BRITISH M.P.'S ASSAIL MRS. THATCHER OVER GRENADA
description: A bipartisan committee of the House of Commons issued a report today that criticized the performance of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Government during the Grenada crisis. It also said that the United States deliberately kept Britain in the dark about Washington's invasion plans.

title: Walker Unlikely to Start EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., April 5 - A deep bruise in his left
description: shoulder kept Herschel Walker from practicing with the Generals for

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Abbott Laboratories , North Chicago, Ill., said it had invested an undisclosed amount in Fuller Research Corp., and had signed a research and development agreement with the company for disposable and flexible laser fibers for laser surgery.

title: Manville's Legal Fees
description: United States Bankruptcy Judge Burton Lifland has approved more than $3 million in Manville Corporation lawyers' fees and expenses associated with the Denver-based company's Chapter 11 proceedings. The building materials company has now spent nearly $11 million in such fees since it sought court protection from creditors in 1982. In New York on Wednesday, Judge Lifland approved $3,272,404 in lawyers' fees and expenses covering the four months from October through January, according to a Manville spokesman, Mary Tomenko.

title: RECITAL: NELSON FREIRE, PIANO
description: THE recital of Nelson Freire, the Brazilian pianist, Wednesday night at the 92d Street Y was marked by a burly, almost clumsy approach to the music at hand. Mr. Freire has had a longstanding international career, if not a really major one, and one must assume, therefore, that his music- making is a matter of interpretive choice rather than technical limitation. Still, while there was a kind of insistent honesty to his playing, it was also rather disconcerting.

title: DEFECTIVE DENUNCIATION OF THE DEATH PENALTY
description: To the Editor:

title: Varese to Be Honored
description: A concert in honor of the late composer Edgard Var ese will be presented by the Hartt Contemporary Players of the University of Hartford tonight at 8 at Columbia University's McMillin Theater, Broadway and 116th Street. Admission is free. Information: 280-3825.

title: Tax-Exempt Trust Ads Go to Isidore & Paulson
description: Moseley, Hallgarten, Estabrook & Weeden, a securities firm, has turned to Isidore & Paulson to advertise its multistate tax-exempt unit trust.

title: Judge Dismisses Hauptmann Suit
description: A Federal judge today dismissed the last of the claims in a suit brought by the 85- year-old widow of Bruno Richard Hauptmann, convicted and executed for the 1932 kidnapping and murder of the infant son of Charles A. Lindbergh.

title: No Hype. Issues, Please.
description: For the first time, more women than men are registering to vote. They clearly have the power to elect a President committed to their priorities of life. But will the media and the men who run the campaigns allow the questions basic to the gender gap to be asked? Another four Reagan years will destroy all that we have fought for and won in women's rights and civil rights in our lifetime and the possibility of a good life for our children.

title: FROM QUIET TEXANS, A BONUS FOR CITY ARTS
description: There are a number of Texans who appear in New York from time to time who confound the popular image of residents of the Lone Star State. They are rich - very rich - and anything but flamboyant. They are quiet and understated, they shun most of the glittering parties organized by members of the international set and they are not fond of publicity. However, in the comparatively recent past they have become important additions to the city, not as ultimate fashion consumers but as benefactors of cultural institutions.

title: G.M. TELLS A STORY IN AD SERIES
description: THE General Motors public relations department a year ago engineered the corporation's first sponsorship of a television program. And it was to be a big one: a dramatization of the life of George Washington, a three-night miniseries on the CBS-TV network.

title: WALL ST. COLUMNS GET WIDE SCRUTINY
description: Members of the financial community say they always take a somewhat skeptical view of investment columns, but their wide following among the public makes such columns an important market force.

title: 'Jailbreak'
description: Inmates from seven city jails competed on Rikers Island yesterday in a break-dancing contest called ''Jailbreak '84.''

title: DEBATES NOW SHAPING CAMPAIGN FOR PRESIDENT
description: Theodore H. White remembers the first broadcast debate of modern Presidential politics. It was between John F. Kennedy and Hubert H. Humphrey in the Wisconsin primary campaign in the spring of 1960, he recalls, and it went out to a limited radio audience.

title: Closing the Bias Gap
description: President Reagan complains that he's ''frustrated by the perception that has been created about my supposed lack of interest in the welfare of women.'' One way to alter that perception and address the ''gender gap'' would be to lead the current efforts in Congress to close some loopholes in civil rights law left by a recent Supreme Court decision.

title: BEACON PHOTO SERVICE INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Beacon Photo Service was formerly Beacon Photo Retail Outlet Inc.

title: EXCERPTS FROM TRANSCRIPT OF DEMOCRATIC CANDIDATES' DEBATE
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of a Democratic Presidential debate last night in the David Lawrence Convention Center in Pittsburgh, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of Cable News Network.

title: FAMILY DOLLAR STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: The share earnings and shares outstanding for both year-ago periods were adjusted to reflect the 2-for-1 stock split effective July 5, 1983.

title: DANCE: JOFFREY II GALA
description: THE Joffrey II Dancers, the junior company affiliated with the Joffrey Ballet, gave itself a 15th anniversary gala Wednesday night at the Joyce Theater.

title: DATA SHOW MEESE DID NOT LIST TRIPS WHERE GROUPS PAID EXPENSES
description: Edwin Meese 3d's financial disclosure statements for 1981 and 1982 fail to list more than a dozen trips in which organizations paid thousands of dollars of his expenses, according to a comparison of his disclosure statements and a compilation by Mr. Meese's office of his travels while counselor to President Reagan.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Athlone Industries, Parsippany, N.J., has named Jerald A. Mayhew executive vice president and John F. Hakes vice president of Dudley Sports Co., its softball-manufacturing subsidiary.

title: BRIEFING
description: General Stays on Top

title: Gun in Athens Shooting Killed 2 Americans
description: The Greek police said today that the gun that wounded a United States Army master sergeant this week was the same weapon used to assassinate two American officials serving in Greece.

title: PHILLIPS-VAN HEUSEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: The results reflect the LIFO method of accounting. The share earnings for the prior year have been adjusted to give effect to the 2-for-1 stock split, effected by a 100 percent stock dividend, declared on Dec. 9, 1983 and paid on Jan. 3, 1984.

title: WILSHIRE OIL CO OF TEXAS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest year and both year-ago periods net do not include earnings from the company's former banking unit through Feb. 18, 1983, when the stock of The Trust Company was distributed to the Wilshire stockholders.

title: French Again in Steel Protest
description: Masked steelworkers hurled rocks, bottles of acid and steel bolts at the police, burned a building and smashed a bank's windows during protests today over the French Government's plan to slash 25,000 steel industry jobs.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: FRIDAY, APRIL 6, 1984

title: THE EFFORTS TO REVITALIZE NEGLECTED UNION SQUARE
description: It is easy to understand why Manhattan's long-neglected Union Square has become the focus of public and private efforts at revitalization.

title: Miller Hurt in Crash
description: Johnny Miller , the former United States Open champion, suffered a series of painful injuries in a vehicular accident in Provo, Utah, on Wednesday, but he was recuperating at his home in suburban Mapleton yesterday and was expected to play in the Masters tournament in Augusta, Ga., next week.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Terdell Middleton , the former Memphis State rushing star who played five years with the Green Bay Packers, was waived by the Memphis Showboats to make room for new acquisitions. The Showboats, a U.S.F.L. expansion club, hope to sign a top N.F.L. running back. . . . Walter Payton , the Chicago Bear running back, was released from a hospital after arthroscopic surgery to relieve irritation on both knees.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Astros, at Houston. After an exceptional performance Wednesday night from one young pitcher, Ron Darling, New York goes with another: Walt Terrell, who faces the former Met Mike Scott. (Television - Channel 9, 8:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 8:30 P.M.)

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation yesterday announced plans to sell $750 million of collateralized mortgage obligations, a kind of security backed by home mortgages. Interest rates and prices for the mortgage obligations will be announced next week when they are offered to investors through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: MILITARY INDUSTRY'S THREAT TO NATIONAL SECURITY
description: Defense analysts have long understood the need to keep careful watch over the defense industry and the role it plays in shaping our military policy. Yet few people seem to have noticed the disturbing way that many defense contractors are encouraging the Government to neglect preparations for conventional war and thus rely increasingly on nuclear weapons.

title: ACTING LEADER OF CITY SCHOOLS OUTLINES GOALS
description: New York City's acting schools chancellor said yesterday that he was not ''a caretaker'' and was already acting to ''move this system forward.''

title: Panel to Study Building Collapse
description: A board of inquiry was convened yesterday by the city's Department of Buildings to investigate Wednesday's collapse of two tenement buildings that were being renovated on the Lower East Side.

title: CHAPMAN ENERGY INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
