No Big Deal,' Says HanlonAfter Stunning Performance
description: Glen Hanlon, trying to be realistic about his incredible performance, seemed less impressed than anyone over his shutout tonight against the Islanders.

title: U.S. PLANS TO LEASE MISSILES TO SAUDIS
description: The Reagan Administration, which last month canceled plans to sell Saudi Arabia 1,400 Stinger antiaircraft missiles, has agreed to lease the Saudis four of the weapons to protect King Fahd's new yacht, Administration officials said today.

title: SAYS HE RAISED MONEY FOR REBELS
description: The State Department said today that it had revoked the entry visa of Guillermo Ungo, a Salvadoran Social Democratic exile allied with the insurgents, on the ground that he collected money for the guerrillas on previous visits.

title: SPACE SHUTTLE POISED FOR FIRST SERVICE CALL ON SATELLITE IN ORBIT
description: The space shuttle Challenger is set to embark on an ambitious mission to restore an ailing satellite to health and thus demonstrate for the first time the ability of astronauts to make orbital service calls to extend the useful lifetime of space facilities.

title: G.O.P. STARTING CAMPAIGN TO SHOW 'REAGAN IS TERRIFIC ON WOMEN'S ISSUES'
description: In the next month or so, the Republicans plan a number of projects aimed at women, from an ambitious advertising campaign to formation of Women for Reagan-Bush organizations in every state in the Union.

title: HOUSE VOTES PLAN TO CUT 182 BILLION IN 3 YEARS DEFICIT
description: The House today approved its Democratic leaders' plan to cut the projected budget deficits by $181.7 billion over three years.

title: PUBLISHING: BOLD IDEAS OF THE MEREDITH AGENCY
description: SCOTT MEREDITH, the literary agent for Norman Mailer, Arthur C. Clarke and many other authors, has ruffled feathers in the publishing industry for more than 30 years. He shocked publishers when he started the literary auction in 1952, selling book manuscripts to the highest bidder, and he shocked fellow agents almost 40 years ago, when he began charging fees for evaluating manuscripts and soliciting clients through mass mailings.

title: PARKER DRILLING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Net income.

title: CUOMO OFFERS PROGRAM ON TEEN-AGE PREGNANCY
description: Governor Cuomo today proposed a program to combat such causes of pregnancy among unwed teen-agers as broken homes, unemployment and the search for dignity, rather than focusing on abortion and birth control.

title: Funds Down $76 Million
description: The assets of the nation's money market mutual funds reversed their upward climb and fell $76 million, to $171.62 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: ALTMAN CO.'S SALES INDICATED
description: The Altman Foundation, which owns 98 percent of the New York- based B. Altman & Company retail chain, said yesterday that it might sell the retailer's seven stores. The company is one of the few independent department store chains remaining in the country.

title: Texas Federal Acquisition Talks
description: The Texas Federal Financial Corporation said it is involved in talks with several companies regarding its possible acquisition.

title: Ousted Honduran Aide Arrives Quietly in U.S.
description: Gen. Gustavo Alvarez Martinez, the ousted commander of the Honduran armed forces, flew here today from Costa Rica.

title: COST OF MANY LOANS MAY GO UP
description: The nation's leading banks raised their prime lending rate one-half percentage point yesterday, to 12 percent.

title: LONG SLOGAN HAS SPIRIT
description: There will be radio spots and television ads. There will be fresh-faced songs that recall the tunes of hamburger chains and Dr Pepper. There will be fun. There will be a logo like Amtrak's. There will be beaches, mountains and history.

title: SPORTS FAMILY
description: The mother is playing this week in

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: IT was, after all, a party, and its

title: ART: WELDED SCULPTURES BY HELENE BRANDT
description: -metal sculptures seems like a cross between a nursery school at recess and a medieval torture chamber. Brandt builds skeletal, armored constructions in which children and grown-ups can hole up and be wheeled about. At the same time, these constructions seem like giant beetles or birds in the process of sniffing or pecking the ground, indifferent to anyone who has wandered into their presence.

title: UNISEX INSURANCE: A 'FAIRNESS' COSTLY TO WOMEN T o the Editor:
description: Your March 27 editorial ''On Insuring Fairness for Women'' contains some statements that are incorrect and others that, I believe, miss what should be the essential element of fairness in regard to the pricing of insurance products.

title: ISRAELI LABOR LEADER CAMPAIGNS ON VOW OF LEBANON PULLOUT
description: Shimon Peres, the Labor Party's nominee for Prime Minister in the July 23 elections, said today that if he won he would quickly relieve the Israeli Army of ''the burden of deployment in Lebanon.''

title: HI-SHEAR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: The latest third quarter losses include equity in the net losses of an affiliate amounting to $2.8 million versus $8.4 million a year ago. The latest nine months losses include similar equity in losses of the affiliate totaling $2.3 million compared with $10.8 million a year earlier.

title: VAN DYKE PARKS, POP ECCENTRIC, AT BOTTOM LINE
description: VAN DYKE PARKS calls himself ''a wounded cult hero of the 1960's music racket.'' The Los Angeles pop-music eccentric, who collaborated with the Beach Boys on some of their headiest psychedelic music, is performing tonight at the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street, in his first New York engagement.

title: SHARON V. TIME INC.: BATTLEGROUND IS THE COURTROOM
description: As a soldier and a politician, Ariel Sharon, the former Israeli Minister of Defense, has spent much of his adult life in battle. The site of his latest skirmish, however, is not Sinai or Parliament, but the United States Court House at Foley Square.

title: GROUP MARKS 15TH YEAR
description: The Joffrey II Dancers, America's first ''second company,'' is 15 years old this year, and is celebrating its anniversary with a season at the Joyce Theater, Eighth Avenue and 19th Street. Today, many dance groups have second companies that serve as training grounds for young dancers. But the Joffrey Ballet pioneered the concept by establishing the Joffrey II Dancers in 1969.

title: FRANCE SAID TO OFFER TO HELP NICARAGUA CLEAR PORTS OF MINES
description: France has offered to help Nicaragua clear its ports of mines if one or more other countries join the effort, the Sandinista Press reported this week.

title: UNISEX INSURANCE: A 'FAIRNESS' COSTLY TO WOMEN
description: To the Editor:

title: A TOWN'S FACT OF LIFE: THE DEATH ROW PRISON
description: In a sense nearly everyone in this rural North Florida town, where executions of the state's death-row inmates are carried out, goes to prison.

title: Baked Goods Tampering Reported in More Items
description: Reports of copycat tampering of bakery goods spread to new products today, one day after the Girl Scout Council of Chicago halted this year's cookie drive because of cookies sabotaged with pins, staples and glass.

title: Cosmos Lose Playoff Opener
description: Jean Willrich and Kaz Deyna each scored two goals to lead the San Diego Sockers to a 5-2 victory over the Cosmos tonight in the opening game of the North American Soccer League indoor championship series.

title: Mourning Made More Personal
description: Instead of the traditional black armband that players for baseball clubs traditionally wear to denote the loss of someone close to the organization, the San Diego Padres and the Chicago White Sox are being more specific this season.

title: TRANSDUCER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: PETRO-LEWIS TO SELL UNITS TO CUT DEBT
description: The Petro-Lewis Corporation said today that it had tentatively reached 11 separate agreements to sell several of its oil and gas properties for about $680 million.

title: 6 Synthetic Fuels Projects Get Aid
description: In its first large-scale financial commitment to the infant synthetic fuels industry, the United States Synthetic Fuels Corporation today announced $4.38 billion in aid to six major projects.

title: HELP WANTED: EAR CLEANER AND GANGES MUD SELLER
description: Zubair Alam, at age 16, is already an old hand at his job. He advertises it at the top of his lungs as he pedals his bicycle laden with old newspapers and burlap bags full of empty bottles through the byways of New Delhi, earning his dollar or two a day.

title: POPULAR BANCSHARES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Dining Out Guide: Mexican Restaurants
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.

title: CATSKILL VILLAGE FACING AN INDUSTRIAL 'DISASTER'
description: Edward Jacobs, the Mayor of this Catskill village, uses the word ''disaster'' to describe what effect the closing of one of the village's major employers will have on the community.

title: No Headline
description: Four on Missing Boat Presumed to Be Dead

title: AMERICAN GREETINGS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
ROBERT SANTANGELO, EX-JUDGE ON THE STATE SUPREME COURT
description: Robert V. Santangelo, a former State Supreme Court justice and the prosecutor in the Seabury corruption investigations in New York City in the 1930's, died Wednesday at United Hosptal in Port Chester, N.Y. He was 87 years old and lived in Rye, N.Y., and Highland Beach, Fla.

title: 'MUSIC' OF A GIANT STEEL PLANT FADES IN PENNSYLVANIA TOWN
description: The shop that fabricated the Empire State Building, the gates for the Panama Canal and some of the world's biggest bridges is closing with little fanfare.

title: YANKEES TROUNCED BY ROYALS
description: The Yankees played the kind of game tonight that would make their owner George Steinbrenner wish he had another winter or spring to make changes in the team.

title: Court Reduces Perez Charge
description: Pascual Perez, the Atlanta Braves pitcher, appeared today to be nearing the end of his imprisonment, after almost three months in custody, as a three-judge appeals court upheld his March 23 conviction on the reduced charge of cocaine possession, the equivalent of a misdemeanor, instead of trafficking, the conviction that the Government sought.

title: McEnroe Wins
description: John McEnroe of the United States defeated Yannick Noah of France, 7-6, 0-6, 6-3, in a Suntory Cup exhibition tennis match today.

title: PLAYWRIGHT'S PROGRESS
description: Like many aspiring playwrights, Michael Brady came to his craft with the most serious of intents. His first three plays concerned the painful relationship between a father and son; a teacher of emotionally disturbed children, who is recovering after having been raped, and the life of a Holocaust victim.

title: CBS NEWS TO ALLOW JUDGE TO SEE TAPES IT HADN'T TELEVISED
description: After a long court fight, CBS News said yesterday that it would permit a State Supreme Court justice to view portions of a videotaped interview with two fugitive gunrunners that have not been televised.

title: Swastikas Mar Co-op City Doors
description: Vandals drew swastikas on the doors of 51 apartments at Co-op City and wrote anti-Semitic slogans on the walls of the Bronx apartment complex, Co-op City's general manager, Stephen F. Lambert, said yesterday.

title: NIXON, IN T.V. TALK, SHUNS WATERGATE APOLOGY
description: In an unusual television interview to be broadcast by CBS News next week, Richard M. Nixon was asked if he wanted to tell the American people for the first time that he was sorry about his behavior in the Watergate scandals.

title: International Festival
description: International foods, music and arts will be offered tomorrow from 3 to 10 P.M. at the annual Night of Nations festival at International House, a residence for American and foreign graduate students at 500 Riverside Drive, at 122d Street.

title: BROADWAY
description: 2 plays set for 30th year of park festival.

title: Ron Darling Puts Lesson Into Practice
description: When he was a student at Yale, Ron Darling majored in Southeast Asian and French history. But one of the more important lessons he learned as a baseball player was: Get the first man out each inning.

title: 'THE WELL,' IN YIDDISH
description: PUBLIC TELEVISION has long been beholden to independent productions - ranging from Fred Wiseman's documentaries to Robert Geller's ''American Short Story'' series - for some of its more impressive programming. It is therefore fitting that the system provide a showcase devoted exclusively to the works of American independent film and video makers. That is being furnished by Channel 13's ''Independent Focus,'' a compilation of documentaries, dramas, essays and animations, which is returning for a seventh season Sunday at 11 P.M. with an unusual half-hour film titled ''The Well.''

title: HOUSE UNIT BACKS HEROIN USE FOR CANCER PAIN
description: The House Energy and Commerce Committee approved legislation today that would permit heroin to be given to cancer patients suffering intractable pain.

title: PETRIE STORES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After tax credit of $2.7 million.

title: DENIABLE WARFARE
description: The national security adviser invited the Media Movers and Shakers (Thumbsucking Division) to a non-lunch in the Roosevelt Room of the White House the other day to tout a rare event: at week's end, President Reagan will deliver a serious and thematic foreign policy address.

title: WHERE THE BURDEN FOR THE HOLOCAUST BEGINS
description: To the Editor:

title: THE BAD NEWS HOUR: 4 P.M. FRIDAY
description: For those who keep a weather eye cocked toward the capital for political storms, Friday afternoon is a time to be especially wary.

title: Daewoo Case Pleas Entered
description: Seven people and two South Korean companies accused of violating Federal laws on importing steel entered not guilty pleas here today in United States District Court.

title: 'HARD TO HOLD,' WITH RICK SPRINGFIELD
description: DRIPPING sweat, with the backstage lights glinting off his jeweled belt and his single earring, James Roberts escapes to his dressing room, collapsing beside the Space Invaders machine. He's drained. He's exhausted. He's a very famous rock star, and he has just whipped another adoring audience into a lather.

title: DEPUTY AT U.S.I.A. IS CONTRIDICTED
description: A former United States Information Agency official, testifying under oath before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, today directly contradicted the sworn testimony given by the agency's deputy director of his role in the creation of an agency ''blacklist.''

title: F.B.I. Starts Search For Kidnapping Suspect
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation started a nationwide search today for Christopher Bernard Wilder, a 39-year- old racing-car driver charged with kidnapping one woman and suspected in the death or disappearance of six others from Florida to Nevada.

title: CONCERT: ELLY AMELING, SOPRANO, AT CARNEGIE HALL
description: OURS is not a time rich in lieder singers, but we do have Elly Ameling. The Dutch soprano's recital last night at Carnegie Hall, Schubert from start to finish, was a perfect thing of its cultivated type, a demonstration of vocal elegance unostentatiously put to the service of music in the classic Liederabend manner that is rarely encountered nowadays. Miss Ameling's voice is so rich and flexible that its beauty could easily distract the listener from the song if her interpretive powers did not measure up. As it is, there is such a fine blend of art and craft that there is no knowing where one begins and the other leaves off.

title: India Gets Oilfield Loan
description: The World Bank said today that it would lend India $242.5 million to increase oilfield output. The projects have a total cost of $954 million and will increase the number of drilled wells, improve maintenance and test new technology for increasing recoverable oil reserves.

title: N.A.S.L. PRESSES ITS DEMANDS
description: The North American Soccer League, whose financial problems have caused it to shrink from 24 to 9 teams in the last 4 years, has told its players and their union that it will fold unless a new collective-bargaining agreement satisfactory to the league is signed by April 19.

title: The U.N. Today April 6, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Carter Hawley
description: Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. has sued The Limited Inc. of Columbus, Ohio, in an effort to quash a takeover attempt.

title: STUDY SAYS CAFFEINE INCREASES POTENCY OF PAIN RELIEVERS
description: Caffeine can substantially increase the potency of aspirin and other pain relievers that are sold over the counter, a team of researchers has reported.

title: Ally & Gargano to Get Resorts Casino Account
description: Mark van Hartesvelt, who in January became senior vice president- casino marketing for Resorts International, Atlantic City, has announced that Ally & Gargano will be his new agency.

title: O'NEILL ASSERTS DEATHS IN BIERUT 'LIE ON' REAGAN
description: The Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., said today that President Reagan was personally responsible for the deaths of the 260 American military personnel killed in Lebanon.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Friday PRE-OSCAR SCREENINGS

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: ''POLICE ACADEMY'' has made nearly $20 million in 10 days, and done it playing by the rules - rules that the unsuspecting filmgoer might not even know existed. Rule 1: The kids must get even with or destroy an authority figure. Rule 2: There must be one outstandingly dirty comic sequence on a par with the peephole scene from ''Porky's.'' Rule 3: No window shades in the women's shower room, please. Rule 4: The director must do his homework, boning up on ''Animal House,'' ''Stripes,'' ''Fast Times at Ridgemont High'' and ''Porky's,'' the genre's acknowledged greats.

title: Japan Sets Network Policy
description: The Japanese Government has rejected a proposal that would have limited to 50 percent or less foreign ownership of so-called value-added networks.

title: LINEAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Reputed Mob Boss Pleads Not Guilty
description: A reputed crime boss, Paul Castellano, pleaded not guilty yesterday to racketeering charges in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Republican Chairman Assails Democratic Ad
description: The Republican national chairman has attacked a Democratic television commercial as ''character assassination,'' adding, ''The American people are tired of these campaigns that seem to go on forever.''

title: VATICAN-CZECH TIES ARE SET BACK
description: A senior Vatican diplomat said today that hopes for the establishment of friendly relations with Czechoslovakia were set back during a meeting there last month.

title: PERFORMERS PAY TRIBUTE TO GAYE AT FUNERAL
description: Some of Marvin Gaye's fellow performers, including Stevie Wonder, Dick Gregory, Smokey Robinson and Mr. Gaye's own band, paid tribute to the slain performer today at funeral services that focused on music.

title: BOODS OF THE TIMES
description: DEMOCRACY. By Joan Didion. 234 pages. Simon & Schuster. $13.95.

title: PERSIAN GULF WAR: IRANIAN DEFENSIVE DELAYED
description: United States and NATO intelligence officials say that Iranian plans for a major spring offensive against Iraq may have been delayed in part by a recent sharp increase in Iraqi air attacks. The officials say that the air attacks have been on Iranian positions on Majnoon Island and on military assembly areas behind the Iranian frontier.

title: JENIFER D. HEYWARD
description: Jenifer Dubose Heyward, a sculptor as well as a former actress and member of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo, died of cancer on March 27 at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 54 years old and lived at 34 Gramercy Park and Southold, L.I.

title: XCOR INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a $66,000 gain from discontinued operations and a $216,000 loss on the disposal of discontinued operations. c-Net loss after a $763,000 loss from discontinued operations and a $1.2 million gain on the disposal of discontinued operations. d-After a loss of $576,000 from discontinued operations and a loss of $687,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations. e-After a $1.9 million loss from discontinued operations and a $1.2 million gain on the disposal of discontinued operations. The 1982 figures are restated from amounts previously reported to present King Musical Instruments Inc. operations as discontinued operations.

title: TOP DESIGNER OF SOVIET AIRPLANES
description: Oleg K. Antonov, one of the Soviet Union's leading aircraft designers, died Wednesday, according to dispatches from Moscow. He was 78 years old.

title: MONEY SUPPLY UP $2.2 BILLION
description: Interest rates fell slightly yesterday, with most of the decline coming after the Federal Reserve's 4:30 P.M. announcement of a $2.2 billion increase in the nation's money supply for the week ended March 26, to $538.3 billion.

title: PRICE CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 18
DISPUTE OVER FIGHTER EXPORTS
description: The Defense Department says it is ''pressing hard'' to encourage developing countries to purchase fighter planes that are made specifically for export and are relatively cheap to buy and easy to maintain.

title: Rev. David W. Barry Of Fellowship Center
description: The Rev. David W. Barry, the president of the Fellowship Center since 1978 and former executive director of the New York City Mission Society, died yesterday at his home in Armonk, N.Y. He was 66 years old.

title: MOSCOW DISMISSES CHEMICAL ARMS PLAN
description: The Soviet Government's press agency, Tass, today dismissed President Reagan's plan to call for a ban on chemical weapons.

title: Reagan Election Drive Given New U.S. Funds
description: President Reagan has been certified for $3.8 million in additional Federal campaign funds, bringing his total so far this year to more than $7.4 million, the Federal Election Commission said.

title: Good Hunch
description: The first race at Aqueduct on Wednesday was a gift for hockey fans.

title: A WEEK OF LUCILLE BALL'S BEST HOURS
description: Ronald Reagan is on five television sets at a candlelit, black-tie dinner for 150 at the St. Regis Hotel. Speaking from the White House, he is reminding his viewers that more Americans were tuned in to the birth of Lucille Ball's television baby in 1953 than watched the inauguration of Dwight D. Eisenhower as President the same year.

title: RANGERS DEFEAT ISLANDERS, 3-0, AND TIE SERIES AT 1-1
description: Tonight, memories of championships past didn't help the Islanders.

title: JONES INTERCABLE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $167,400 from the sale of an investment.

title: FRIDAY, APRIL 6, 1984 International
description: Extra military aid for El Salvador totaling $61.75 million and $21 million in funds for Nicaraguan rebels were approved by the Senate. The vote was 76 to 19, with 53 Republicans and 26 Democrats supporting the compromise bill. (Page A1, Column 1.) Britain was accused of passivity during the Grenada crisis by a bipartisan committee of the House of Commons. The panel concluded that British officials were too slow to respond to danger signals in the region and too insensitive to the attitudes of Commonwealth countries there, such as the desire of Barbados that Britain take part in any intervention. (A11:1-3.)

title: Itzik Manger Revue
description: ''A Manger Rendezvous,'' a musical revue based on the life of the Yiddish poet and balladeer Itzik Manger, will be presented Sunday at 2 P.M. at the YIVO Institute for Jewish Research, 1048 Fifth Avenue, at 86th Street.

title: BLACK JOURNALISTS CRITICAL OF MUSLIM
description: Black journalists around the country yesterday criticized Louis Farrakhan, the Black Muslim leader, for threatening a Washington Post reporter and for implying that black journalists who criticized black leaders were traitors to their race and dupes of nonblack news organizations.

title: KOCH AND KILEY: HONEYMOON IS OVER
description: The portrait of a crumbling transit system with a bleak immediate future - one that the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, Robert R. Kiley, has been painting for the last four months - came back to haunt Mr. Kiley this week in the form of a scathing letter from Mayor Koch. Since taking office in December, Mr. Kiley has made a point of dashing hopes for any speedy improvement in New York City's bus and subway service. He has gone so far as to say that significant changes might not be seen for 10 years.

title: MAYOR OF SAN FRANCISCO SAYS HER CITY'S FISCAL PLAN COULD GUIDE NEW YORK
description: Mayor Dianne Feinstein of San Francisco yesterday outlined an economic and fiscal plan designed for her city by businesses there and recommended that it be used to guide New York City's development.

title: LOCKHEED NAMES HEAD OF TEST UNIT
description: John V. Lundeen has been named president and chief operating officer of American Medical Buildings Inc., which is negotiating to be acquired by the Turner Construction Company.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: A touch of Paris on the West Side.

title: FILM: PAUL MAZURSKY'S MOSCOW ON THE HUDSON'
description: BOTH Vladimir Ivanoff, a young Soviet circus musician, who defects to the United States at the end of an American tour, and Robin Williams, the actor who plays Vladimir with fine comic intensity, are most engaging characters - spirited, skeptical, but still capable of wonderment. Yet Paul Mazursky's ''Moscow on the Hudson'' doesn't seem to know what to do with them. They are men without a movie.

title: MAX & ERMA'S RESTAURANTS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Net income.

title: 'Baby Jane Doe' Is Taken Home
description: The parents of ''Baby Jane Doe'' yesterday took their severely handicapped child home from University Hospital at Stony Brook, L.I., nearly six months after her birth.

title: CHANCE AND SECURITY
description: With tornado-like force, a spring storm swirled through nearby Durham late Wednesday, tearing the roofs from houses, blowing out windows, felling trees, flipping cars and seriously damaging stores at the Northgate Mall.

title: Yonkers at the Brink Again
description: Unless Yonkers finds $10 million in a month, it will be forced to close its schools. Such a predicament for New York's fourth-largest city should arouse some sympathy, but Yonkers stands at the brink for the third time in 10 years. The rest of the state's patience is understandably wearing thin.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Diner's Journal

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''When certain people for political reasons claim that I don't understand the modern woman, I'm tempted to say, 'Then how come I have two very independent daughters?' '' - President Reagan. (A24:3.)

title: TEMPLETON GROWTH FUND LTD reports earnings for As of March 31
Barge Leaks Gas Into the Hudson
description: A barge carrying nearly 2.5 million gallons of unleaded gasoline struck a reef and leaked 2,000 gallons of its cargo into the Hudson River today, officials said.

title: MONDALE'S DUAL IMAGE PUZZLES STAFF
description: Minutes before Walter F. Mondale's plane landed at Pittsburgh International Airport today, the candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination followed the ritual that has marked his arrival at every stop since the start of the campaign.

title: ACKLANDS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Net loss after a $1.4 million gain on sale of subsidiaries. The company said that during the first quarter it consolidated warehouse operations in Calgary to one facility from two and also consolidated several operations in Edmonton.

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart yesterday on the New York primary vote, reflecting the New York Times/CBS News Poll, misstated percentages of the electorate represented by various voter categories. The correct figures (in each case one or two points higher than those printed) are: Women working outside home, 21; Catholic total, 39; Catholic men, 17; Catholic, 60 and older, 14; Jewish total, 24; Jewish men, 11; Jewish, 45-59 years old, 7; Italian descent, 7; Union households, total, 41; Union households, men, 19; Union households, women, 22; Family income $12,500-$24,999, 28; Family income $25,000-$34,999, 19; Family income $35,000-$50,000, 16; Family finances better in last year, 22; Family finances same, 51; Family finances worse, 26; Some college, 25; College graduate, 36.

title: SANDINISTAS' FOES AND EL SALVADOR WIN A SENATE VOTE
description: The Senate approved $61.75 million today in new emergency military aid for El Salvador and $21 million in funds for Nicaraguan rebels.

title: TV Series to Be Based On Outside Magazine
description: Tomorrow, on about 280 public television stations throughout the country, a new program will make its debut and mark a new phase in the life of Lawrence J. Burke, one-time boy publisher, now 40 years old.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY FUND REPORTED FINANCIALLY SOUND
description: The Reagan Administration reported today that the Social Security trust fund was in excellent financial condition, but warned that Medicare's hospital insurance trust fund would be exhausted by 1991 if there was no change in existing law.

title: ART: ITALY 100 YEARS AGO, SHOWS AT 2 GALLERIES
description: century art is being rewritten, there is a particular timeliness in the double- headed exhibition of Italian 19th-century painting that can be seen at the Stair Sainty Matthiesen Gallery, 141 East 69th Street. One show, devoted to Giovanni Boldini, Giuseppe de Nittis and Federico Zandomeneghi, is called ''Three Italian Friends of the Impressionists.'' The other musters in all 15 Italian 19th-century painters under the title ''The Macchiaioli: Tuscan Painters of the Sunlight.''

title: Final Arguments Made In Trial of Federal Judge
description: Defense and prosecution lawyers made their final arguments today in the trial of Federal District Judge Harry Claiborne on bribery and income tax evasion charges.

title: Market Place; Cosmetics Issues Out Of Favor
description: MUCH of the glamour has rubbed off cosmetics stocks in recent years, and a current example of this phenomenon can be seen in Chesebrough-Pond's Inc. The stock closed yesterday at 32 5/8, down 1/2, on the New York Stock Exchange, after trading as low as 32 1/4. That marked the stock's lowest price since Aug. 11, 1982, two days before the start of the great bull market, when it traded at 30 7/8.

title: DESPITE APRIL SHOWERS, CITY'S THINKING SPRING
description: which appeared certain at the beginning of this week, seemed like a doubtful premise with the winds and rains of the middle of the week, but should again be real this weekend, if forecasts are correct - inevitably brings New Yorkers outdoors with the spirit of caged animals. A winter of confinement makes even the least nature-oriented urbanite eager to burst the confines.

title: Mortgage Rate Average Up
description: Home loan rates rose slightly in March, to an average of 13.74 percent for fixed-rate mortgages, according to a Government report.

title: MUSIC: DENNIS KARMAZYN, CELLIST, PERFORMS
description: DENNIS KARMAZYN, who gave a cello recital Tuesday night in Alice Tully Hall, has one of the more effortless techniques now before the public. At his best, in fleet, dapper music like the Popper ''Hungarian Rhapsody'' (Op. 68) that closed his program, or in a fast movement from the Francoeur Sonata in E that preceded the Popper, Mr. Karmazyn darted deftly through music in which other cellists might labor painfully.

title: Economic Scene; A Key Political Barometer
description: THE economy is surging ahead faster than

title: The Family Doctor
description: Governor Cuomo speaks of New

title: CONCERT: AFRICAN-AMERICAN
description: ''We've never been to Africa, but our root is deep,'' Edwina Lee Tyler declared, as she and the four women in A Piece of the World drummed out African rhythms Tuesday at the Kitchen. That statement summed up a concert by two all-female bands who performed African-American music for voices and percussion.

title: IN WASHINGTON, HOCKEY IS NOT FRONT-RUNNER
description: On Wednesday night, just as President Reagan was explaining in a nationally televised news conference his new initiative to ban chemical warfare, more than 18,000 residents of perhaps the most politically sophisticated city in the world burst into riotous applause. Craig Laughlin had scored.

title: 'SUGAR CANE ALLEY,' IN MARTINIQUE
description: EUZHAN PALCY brings so much warmth to her film ''Sugar Cane Alley'' that even a funeral scene midway through has an unexpected sweetness. Set in Martinique in 1931, ''Sugar Cane Alley'' explores the lives of black plantation workers through the eyes of a quiet, perceptive 11-year-old orphan. More than the story of how Jose, who is played beautifully by Garry Cadenat, makes his way out of the shantytown of the title to become a brilliant student and, perhaps later, a writer, ''Sugar Cane Alley'' is the story of an entire way of life. In describing it, Miss Palcy chooses her details sparingly and well.

title: San Francisco's Choice
description: When the University of San Francisco decided to resume intercollegiate basketball in 1985-86 after a three- season hiatus and began looking for a coach, more than 125 prospects applied. Yesterday, after sifting through the pile, San Francisco athletic officials announced that they had found their man: Jim Brovelli , a former basketball star at the school who had been coaching at the University of San Diego the last 11 seasons. ''I'm returning to my alma mater and the school that I love,'' said the 41- year-old Brovelli, who signed a five- year contract.

title: STATE WINS POINT ABOUT BORROWING
description: The underwriters of New York State's notes today dropped a requirement that legislative leaders formally certify that the state budget is in balance and that they intend to keep it that way.

title: RCA DEFENDS TIMING OF VIDEODISK CANCELING
description: The prospect of another year with an $100 million loss finally convinced the RCA Corporation to jettison its videodisk player business, Thornton F. Bradshaw, the company's chief executive, said yesterday.

title: NIKE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
A GRANT RETROSPECTIVE
description: Cary Grant never won a best-actor Oscar. Ruefully acknowledging the oversight, the motion picture academy presented him in 1970 with a general award for ''sheer brilliance.''

title: CANADIENS WIN, LEAD BRUINS, 2-0
description: Mario Tremblay and Mats Naslund scored first-period goals, and the rookie Steve Penney was brilliant in goal as the Montreal Canadiens defeated the Boston Bruins, 3-1, tonight to take a 2-0 lead in their playoff series.

title: 'FOUL FOOTSTEP' ERASED
description: To the Editor:

title: INDIA MOVES TO OPPOSE TOUGH LAWS IN PUNJAB
description: The Indian Government today empowered the authorities in Punjab to detain people suspected of sabotage and terrorism for two years without a court trial.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An erroneous set of crossword answers appeared in some editions yesterday. Correct answers for Wednesday's puzzle appear on page C32 today, along with answers for yesterday's.

title: UNITED STATIONERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: The year-ago share earnings figures reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in March 1983.

title: Cigna Sees Loss
description: The Cigna Corporation said it expected to report a first-quarter operating loss, compared with a profit of $77 million in the quarter a year earlier.

title: ROYAL BUSINESS GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 26
description: b-Net income.

title: THEATER: CHEKHOV'S ' THREE SISTERS,' IN HARTFORD
description: HARTFORD LANFORD WILSON is one the most Chekhovian of American playwrights, telling stories of quiet suspiration about provincial people with lingering ideals. He has said that ''The Three Sisters'' is his favorite play, a fact that is evident throughout his artful translation of the original Chekhov. To prepare himself for the undertaking - as commissioned by Mark Lamos, artistic director of the Hartford Stage Company - Mr. Wilson studied Russian. The intention was not to re-evaluate or to transplant Chekhov but to blend him with a 20th- century Wilsonian sensibility. The result is both conversational and lyrical.

title: 3 DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL RIVALS MEET IN MILDEST DEBATE OF DRIVE
description: In the mildest of the year's major campaign debates, the three Democratic Presidential candidates tonight engaged in a polite discussion centering on rebuilding this state's troubled industries.

title: Satisfied Traders
description: It may take a few years to establish who got the better of it Wednesday in the deal that gave the New England Patriots the first pick in the National Football League draft on May 1. But both the Patriots and the Cincinnati Bengals, who traded away the first pick for three selections this year - two on the first round - and one choice next year, seem happy.

title: NEW YORK AREA DELUGED BY RECORD RAINFALL
description: Record rains lashed the New York metropolitan area yesterday, flooding roads, tangling traffic, causing rivers to overflow and forcing the evacuation of hundreds of families in northern New Jersey.

title: ART: 'BEAUTIES & BEASTS' AT THE PRATT GALLERY
description: STEVE KEISTER'S boxy, hanging form of planar angles with a lighted interior is a ''beauty''; Clayton Patterson's light-up caseful of street detritus is a ''beast.'' Robert Zakanitch's brushy gold canvas field bedecked with a floral pattern is a ''beauty.'' Michael Tracy's gilded icons, encrusted with hair and other matter, is a ''beast.''

title: AMERICAN FRUCTOSE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

description: A plan to build a combination gun

title: Beirut Hit by Heavy Shelling; Gemayel Sends Aides to Syria
description: Heavy shelling rocked Beirut today, and army soldiers clashed with Druse militiamen east of the capital.

title: OPENING OF DISPUTED DELI HITS LAST-MINUTE SNAG
description: Something is wrong in the universe,'' said Samuel Loeb, a passer- by who leaned into the Park 75 delicatessen yesterday to comment to workmen on the coming of a delicatessen to Manhattan's affluent Park Avenue. ''Someone has offended the Gods.''

title: COLONEL IS NAMED GUINEAN PRESIDENT
description: An army colonel, pledging to reverse the ''harm'' done by President Ahmed Sekou Toure, was named today as the new Guinean leader.

title: AMERICAN HOIST & DERRICK CO reports earnings for 15wks to March 17
description: b-After a tax credit of $6,264,000.

title: VW Layoffs in Brazil
description: Volkswagen do Brasil, facing industrial action by workers demanding more pay, plans to dismiss 700 employees, a company spokesman said today. He denied that the dismissals had been motivated by a planned slowdown, saying the work force of 31,000 was more than was needed for a production rate of 1,300 cars a day.

title: Staub's Shindig
description: To baseball players, it's a familiar part of life on the road: The traveling secretary makes housekeeping announcements on the airplane's microphone between cities. So the Mets were not surprised Wednesday night to hear Arthur Richman, somewhere between Cincinnati and Houston, make this announcement: ''Workout in the Astrodome in the morning at 11:30.''

title: Chrysler and Bieber to Discuss Seat
description: Chrysler Corporation directors declined today to nominate Owen Bieber, president of the United Automobile Workers, for a board seat in time to list his name on the agenda for the shareholders meeting June 7.

title: ACTIVISTS' OFFENSE AGAINST THE BILL OF RIGHTS
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 CONVICTED KILLERS DIE IN A SINGLE DAY IN SOUTHERN PRISONS
description: Arthur Frederick Goode 3d, 30 years old, a convicted child killer and self-described pedophile, was electrocuted here today by Florida prison officials.

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: South African Denies Comments on Guerrillas

title: NATIONAL ROYALTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1982 year loss includes a $1,419,000 writedown of oil and gas leases and a writedown of $53,686 from over-riding royalty interests.

title: DEVILS BAG OUT OF GOTHAM
description: Woody Stephens said yesterday that Devil's Bag would not run in the Gotham Stakes tomorrow or in the Wood Memorial April 21 because of sloppy track conditions at Aqueduct and Belmont Park that have interrupted the colt's training.

title: MELLON BID TO BANK NATIONWIDE
description: The Mellon National Corporation, the large Pittsburgh-based bank holding company, said yesterday that it would seek Government approval to set up 15 consumer banking offices across the country, amid mounting concern about the expansion of banking across state lines.

title: TEMPLETON WORLD FUND reports earnings for As of March 31
description: This fund, on March 31, 1983, issued a 2-for-1 stock split.

title: OPEN-ADMISSION PUPILS GET A'S FOR PERSISTENCE
description: Many of the students who entered the City University of New York under the open-admission policy adopted 14 years ago did not graduate on schedule but persisted and got their degrees eventually, according to new statistics.

title: Books of The Times
description: know the conventions and how to observe them,'' the character named Joan Didion writes in one of her many asides to the reader about the kind of fiction that her new novel, ''Democracy,'' is turning out not to be. ''I know,'' she writes, ''how to fill the canvas I have already stretched; know how to tell you what he said and she said and know, above all, since the heart of narrative is a certain calculated ellipsis, a tacit contract between writer and reader to surprise and be surprised, how not to tell you what you do not yet want to know.'' <TD WIDTH=2

title: THE CITY ;  10 Hurt in S.I. Fire
description: A two-alarm fire raced through a Staten Island apartment building yesterday, injuring eight firefighters and two civilians.

description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a transcription error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the Seabrook nuclear power project misquoted one word of a comment by Gov. J. Joseph Garrahy of Rhode Island. He said the aim of a new study was to ''examine the whole viability of Seabrook.''

title: McKesson Seeks Champion Unit
description: The McKesson Corporation, a San Francisco-based distributor of drugs, beverages and chemicals, signed a letter of intent to acquire the Office Products division of the Champion International Corporation for about $35 million.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Keeping History Honest
description: Government documents are keys to history, and access to them offers the surest path to an honest reckoning of the past. Most Americans innocently assume that public papers are public property, open to all at the National Archives in Washington. Not quite, not yet.

title: Commager Service Tuesday
description: A memorial service for Steele Commager, a professor of classics at Columbia University who died last Monday at the age of 51, will be held Tuesday at 11 A.M. in St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia, Amsterdam Avenue and 117th Street.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A headline in some editions yesterday on an article about the search for a new general manager of the Metropolitan Opera misidentified the current holder of the position. He is Anthony A. Bliss; Sir Rudolf Bing was a predecessor.

title: Giuseppe Tucci Dead at 89; An Asia Scholar and Explorer
description: Giuseppe Tucci, an eminent Asia scholar who explored Nepal and Tibet in the 1920's and translated works from Sanskrit and Tibetan, died today. He was 89.

title: AUCTIONS
description: WHEN Florence J. Gould, a patron of the arts and daughter-in-law of the railroad magnate Jay Gould, was 80 years old, she packed most of her jewelry and went to Japan and Southeast Asia. The necklaces, rings, bracelets, earrings, brooches and clips she took with her on that 1976 trip, jewelry now valued at about $8 million, will be auctioned next Wednesday at Christie's.

title: U.S. Reports Jobless Claims Edged Upward in Mid-March
description: First-time claims for unemployment compensation edged up for two consecutive weeks in mid-March, hitting the highest level since January, the Government said today.

title: MISS PTERSON POSTS 68
description: Lauri Peterson fired a four- under-par 68 today to grab the first- round lead in the $400,000 Nabisco/ Dinah Shore Invitational.

title: 18.01 DROP PUTS DOWN AT 1,130.55
description: Stock prices plunged yesterday in heavy trading after some of the nation's major banks increased their prime lending rate for the second time in less than three weeks.

CANANDAIGUA WINE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
U.S.-JAPAN TRADE TALK IS STYMIED
description: The latest round of trade talks between the United States and Japan broke down today after officials failed to agree on a plan to raise import quotas on shipments of American beef and citrus to Japan.

title: MOVIELAB INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $677,900 for the latest year and $1,682,000 for the earlier year.

title: Staar Surgical
description: The Staar Surgical Company said the Food and Drug Administration had approved its application to start human implants of its elastic intro-ocular lenses under an investigational device exemption. The company said that, under the exemption, the implants could be sold on a limited basis for investigational use while their safety and effectiveness were being studied. In over-the-counter trading today, Staar was the second-biggest percentage gainer, rising $3, to $20.50 bid.

title: Minimal Decency for the Disabled
description: The Reagan Administration deserves most of the blame for making a brutal botch of the $18 billion Federal disability insurance program. Yet the White House continues to insist that it can be trusted to manage the repairs that even it now deems necessary. The House has passed a reform bill of its own, 410 to 1. The Senate seems inclined to do the same, and well it should.

title: USE OF DELOREAN TAPES UPHELD
description: CBS News was within its First Amendment rights to broadcast Government surveillance tapes showing the automobile maker John Z. DeLorean taking part in what was described as a cocaine transaction, a Federal appeals court ruled today.

title: Your Money; Auto Insurance Payroll Plans
description: THE sale of automobile and homeowners' insurance to employees of corporations through

title: A KISS IS NO CRIME
description: John Thompson is not against hugging, so why is he rapping kissing?

New Hitachi U.S. Plant
description: Hitachi Ltd. said today that it planned to build a second plant in the United States to increase production of semiconductor chips.

title: HOLLYWOOD, HAVING BEST SPRING YET, TALKS OF A REVOLUTION IN ITS TIMING
description: It is spring, glorious spring, for the movie business.

title: LED BRITAIN'S BOMBER COMMAND
description: Sir Arthur Travers Harris, Marshal of the Royal Air Force and the last of the leaders who planned and directed Allied operations against Germany in World War II, died Thursday night at Goring-on-Thames, west of London. He was 91. No cause of death was given by his family.

title: Beirut Factions Ignore A New Truce in Beirut
description: Artillery duels and gun battles flared across the Green Line dividing the Moslem and Christian sectors of Beirut tonight and a call for a cease-fire was ignored.
