CREDIT MARKETS ;
Rally Halted by Discount Rise
description: A rally in Government securities prices yesterday came to a halt when the Federal Reserve raised its discount rate half a point, to 9 percent. But the reaction was mild because the increase had been expected.

title: FLOWERS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for 12 wks to March 10
LIVIN' ON SOUTHERN HOSPITALITY
description: The games usually don't start until after 10 P.M., but that's O.K.; the season, which ends this weekend, didn't get under way until March 1.

title: Reagan Tells of Gaffe With Mrs. Mitterrand
description: President Reagan departed from the text of his foreign policy address today to speak of one of the ''intricacies of diplomacy'' that he said had almost caused an international incident.

title: Park Ave. Deli Opens
description: City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin pronounced it ''an example of government helping hard-working people''; Jae Taik Kim, a professor at John Jay College, called it ''a watershed for Asian immigrants''; Hattie Reynolds, purchasing a tomato, called it a deli.

title: ADVANCED MICRO DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 25
description: b-Including tax credits of $2.5 million for the quarter and $5 million for the year. Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in the form of a dividend paid Aug. 22, 1983.

title: Letter: On Acid Rain Canadian Call For Pollution Control To the Editor:
description: Your March 2 editorial ''A Seaboard of Stunted Trees'' clearly underlines why action should be taken now to solve the acid rain problem.

title: PRESIDENT VS. CONGRESS
description: President Reagan's speech today began as what the White House described as an attempt to define a constructive bipartisan relationsip with Congress on foreign policy. But it has set off one of the sharpest confrontations between the Reagan White House and Congress. Administration officials said the wrangling may therefore make it harder than ever for Mr. Reagan and Congress to achieve cooperation in this election year on such issues as the Middle East, Central America and relations with the Soviet Union.

title: Teacher Charged WithFakingPh.D.
description: A teacher at a vocational school in the Bronx was arrested yesterday on charges of illegally collecting more than $31,000 in extra pay by falsely claiming a doctoral degree from Fordham University, the city's Investigation Department said.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: O'CONNOR'S BARNSTORMING
description: When all the hoopla of the Presidential campaign blew out of New York this week, one man continued parading, shaking hands and kissing babies, although he wasn't running for anything.

title: CENTRAL BANCSHARES OF THE SOUTH INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Sun Repurchase
description: The Sun Company plans to spend about $100 million to repurchase its common shares on the open market or in privately negotiated transactions, it said in its annual report. Over the last three years, Sun said, it has repurchased 9.5 million shares under separate repurchase programs for $358 million.

title: ISRAELI JETS RAID LEBANESE HOTEL
description: The Israeli military command announced this morning that Israeli war planes had attacked a wing of a hotel in Lebanon used by a Palestinian faction led by Naif Hawatmeh, which had taken responsibility for the terrorist attack in downtown Jerusalem last Monday.

title: Equity Group Proposal to DMG
description: DMG Inc. said Equity Group Holdings had proposed that DMG acquire the Mohawk Rubber Company and Master Shield Inc., two privately held companies affiliated with Equity Group, for about 2.6 million DMG common shares, subordinated debt valued at $8 million and $9.5 million cash. DMG, which is involved in real estate, dropped 87.5 cents, to $6.75, today on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: U.S. UNEMPLOYMENT IS STEADY AT 7.7%
description: The national unemployment rate remained unchanged in March at 7.7 percent of the labor force, but the number of people with jobs increased by 250,000, the Labor Department reported today.

title:
PATENTS;
Sun-Fueled Still
description: A method of producing alcohol with the aid of sunlight has been invented for Entropy Dynamics,of Bozeman, Mont., by Walton W. McCarthy.

title: MELROSE AVENUE: SHOPS ON A LOS ANGELES STRIP
description: Melrose Avenue is a long strip that lies east of Beverly Hills and West Hollywood, parallel to Santa Monica and Beverly Boulevards in Los Angeles. In the last few years it has become what can only be called an anomaly in that car-oriented city - a walking, shopping, peering-into-windows street.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 32.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 15.

title: USR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $173,000. c-Net income after a loss of $2,000 from discontinued operations and a $36,000 extraordinary gain. d-After an extraordinary credit of $194,000. e-After a loss of $18,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary credit of $54,000.

title: BURNHAM SERVICE CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including income from the sale of assets of $135,000.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: SATURDAY, APRIL 7, 1984

title: MRS. CARNER LEADS BY A SHOT ON 68-140
description: JoAnne Carner shot a four- under-par 68 today and took the lead by one stroke over Pat Bradley and Patty Sheehan after two rounds of the $400,000 Nabisco-Dinah Shore golf tournament.

title: NEWPORT ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: IMMUNOGENETICS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $519,000. c-Net loss.

title: NUCLEAR COMMITTEE TO BACK TEST OF DIABLO REACTOR
description: An advisory panel of leading nuclear scientists is recommending that California's Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant be allowed to begin test operations, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today.

title: Soul Duo Tonight
description: Sam and Dave, a soul-music vocal duo, will perform tonight at the Bottom Line (228-6300), 15 West Fourth Street, at Mercer Street, with the blues band the Nighthawks as the opening act. Shows begin at 9 P.M. and midnight, and tickets are $8.50.

title: BRITAIN TELLS UNESCO IT MIGHT FOLLOW U.S. AND DECIDE TO QUIT
description: Britain has presented the Unesco Director General, Amadhou-Mahtar M'Bow of Senegal, with proposals for changing the body, warning that it may follow the example of the United States, which is threatening to leave the organization.

title: HIGH HURDLE TO BOOSTING NEW YORK WINE
description: To the Editor:

title: Giles Unhappy
description: Another former New York regular is also unhappy. Brian Giles, once rated the top young infielder in the Mets' farm system, is back in the minor leagues for the third time, and he doesn't like it.

title: MOVE TO 9% DISAPPOINTS REAGAN
description: The Federal Reserve Board, in its first overt move to tighten credit during the current economic recovery, today raised by half a percentage point, to 9 percent, the interest rate that it charges on loans to financial institutions.

title: SYKES DATATRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Ghana Sentences 9 to Death
description: A special Ghanaian military tribunal has sentenced eight former army officers and a noncommissioned officer to death by firing squad for subversion, the official Ghana press agency said today.

title: BLISS, A T, & CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge from the extinguishment of debt of $1,365,206.

title: Admiral Is Approved As Aviation Official
description: The Senate has confirmed Vice Adm. Donald Engen, U.S.N., retired, a member of the National Transportation Safety Board, as head of the Federal Aviation Administration.

title: Central Park Rescue
description: One product of Thursday's rainstorms was the Great Central Park Rescue.

title: PHILHARMONIC: CONDUCTOR AND PIANIST MAKE DEBUTS
description: Thursday's New York Philharmonic subscription concert at Avery Fisher Hall offered two artists relatively unfamiliar to audiences here playing two pieces known to nearly everyone One of the principals was Vaclav Neumann, conductor of the Czech Philharmonic and the most recent substitute for Zubin Mehta as Mr. Metha recovers from arm surgery. Mr. Neumann's guest pianist was Brigitte Engerer, who played a Carneige Hall recital here last season. Both were making their Philarmonic debuts; their program was the Tchaikovsky B flat minor Concerto and Franck's Symphony in D minor.

title: WALL ST. JOURNAL'S DUAL ROLE IN INQUIRY RAISES QUESTIONS
description: Ten days ago, The Wall Street Journal jarred its readers by reporting that one of its reporters was understood to have conceded to the Securities and Exchange Commission that he provided sensitive information to outsiders. The Journal's news article said that the S.E.C. had begun an investigation to find out who may have profited by the reporter's actions. The newspaper has since published detailed articles about the investigation - an inquiry that includes Federal scrutiny of The Journal itself.

title: GIT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
SMALLER STATE CAPITALS ARE BEGINNING TO GROW
description: For many years this little state capital was known as a backwater town where the best meal a lobbyist could buy a legislator was a New England boiled dinner at a cafe on Main Street.

title: Stern Message for Violent Families
description: New York's Police Commissioner, Benjamin Ward, has little use for the police folklore that sees no value in arresting participants in violent family disputes. He insists that officers treat violence in the home as they would violence on the street.

title: SCREEN: 'UP THE CREEK, ' COLLEGE HUMOR
description: Heralds of the season come in many forms: robins, crocuses and movies like ''Up the Creek,'' yesterday's arrival at Loews State and numerous other theaters in and around the city.

title: PAUL WOOLLEY
description: The Rev. Paul Woolley, professor emeritus of church history at Westminster Theological Seminary, Philadelphia, died March 17 at O'Bleness Memorial Hospital in Athens, Ohio. He was 82 years old.

title: Hart Gains in Carolina Poll
description: Senator Gary Hart of Colorado has moved into a virtual tie with Walter F. Mondale in North Carolina's May 8 Democratic Presidential primary race, according to a poll released today. The poll listed Mr. Mondale as the choice of 33.2 percent of those surveyed to Mr. Hart's 33.1 percent. The Rev. Jesse Jackson had 7.7 percent, while 16.7 percent were undecided.

title: Hearing on Alvarado Set to Begin May 14
description: A tentative date of May 14 was set yesterday for the beginning of a disciplinary hearing on charges of misconduct against Anthony J. Alvarado, the suspended Schools Chancellor.

title: NURSING HOMES AGREE ON A PACT TO AVERT STRIKE
description: Owners of nursing homes in New York City and their unionized employees reached tentative agreement yesterday on a new two-year contract, ending a three-day lockout and averting a strike.

title: BRITAIN CRITICIZES MINING OF HARBORS AROUND NICARAGUA
description: Britain told the Reagan Administration earlier this week that it disapproved of the mining of Nicaragua's harbors as interference with international shipping and asked American help in halting the mining, a British Embassy spokesman said today.

title: Occidental's China Coal Deal
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation has said it reached a preliminary agreement with the Chinese Government to develop a vast coal field in the country's northern Shanxi province. The field is projected to produce 15 million tons of coal annually.

title: O'Rourke Pledges Commuter Seats
description: Westchester County will run buses to supplement Metro-North's Hudson and Harlem Lines if the number of commuters forced to stand in the trains is not reduced by Sept. 30, County Executive Andrew O'Rourke said today.

title: The Playbill's the Thing
description: Playbill, the theater magazine,

title: TRADE SANCTIONS VS. CONTRACT SANCTITY
description: To the Editor:

title: Vienna Opera Reports Maazel Has Resigned
description: Lorin Maazel, the director of the Vienna State Opera, has resigned two years before his contract was due to expire, the Culture Ministry said today.

title: SCHULMAN, A, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Fuji-Chinese Training Plan
description: The

title: Hanoi Says It Is Ready To Ease China Turmoil
description: Vietnam's Foreign Minister says his nation is ready to discuss ways to ease tensions with China, which today called Vietnam ''the main threat to Southeast Asia.''

title: 76ers 112, Pacers 106
description: Julius Erving scored 39 points and Moses Malone 23 as Philadelphia rallied in the second half. Philadelphia overcame hot shooting by the Pacers to take an 87-84 lead at the end of the third quarter.

title: TOTAL SYSTEM SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Convicted Congressman To Seek an Eighth Term
description: Representative George Hansen today announced he would seek re-election despite his four felony convictions for violating the Ethics in Government Act.

title: Tenneco Outlay
description: Tenneco Inc. said its capital spending this year is estimated at about $1.8 billion, up from $1.6 billion last year. The 1983 total was down from $2.1 billion in the previous year, the annual report said, noting that cash flow declined last year for the first time in the company's 40-year history.

title: State's Denial of Listing For LaRouche Is Upheld
description: A Federal appeals court has overturned a lower court decision and has ruled that North Carolina has a right to deny Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. of New York City a place on its ballot for the Democratic Presidential primary May 8.

title: QUESTIONS REMAIN ABOUT ACTIVITIES OF AIDES TO THE 1980 REAGAN CAMPAIGN
description: Nine months after the disclosure that some of President Carter's briefing papers ended up in the hands of the Reagan campaign in 1980, it has become clear that Reagan aides took great pains to get information about the opposite camp. But, despite several investigations, questions remain.

title: ARGENTINA AGREES TO AUSTERITY
description: Argentina is moving to impose what the Government reluctantly describes as austerity measures as part of a plan being worked out with the International Monetary Fund.

title: COCO ISLANDERS, 300 IN ALL, PICK UNION WITH AUSTRAILIA
description: The rule of John Clunies-Ross, an Englishman whose family fashioned a self- styled kingdom on these Indian Ocean islands about 150 years ago, ended today when the residents voted to become part of Australia.

title: Dart & Kraft
description: Dart & Kraft Inc. said it had agreed to sell its plastic specialties businesses to an investor group headed by Fred Broling, president of the division.

title: IN FRANCE, A PAINFUL OVERHAUL FOR STEEL
description: For more than a decade, successive French governments of the right and the left have been trying to create a slimmed- down, more efficient steel industry.

title: RANGERS BUOYED BY HANLON SHUTOUT
description: There is a poster in the Rangers' dressing room at their Rye, N.Y., practice facility, tacked up on a wall in a corner. The Stanley Cup is the center attraction, with a line of block letters underneath that reads, ''For this, a price must be paid.''

title: Latter-Day Saints Group Allows Women as Priests
description: Delegates to the world conference of the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints have voted to accept women into the priesthood under the terms of an ''inspired document.''

title: Iran and Iraq Report Heavy Fighting in War
description: Iraq said its warplanes bombed Iranian troops today east of the Iraqi city of Basra, inflicting heavy losses. Iran said its navy shelled Iraqi shore positions to the south.

title: TERRAMAR CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
CONVENTION SITE NODES: OBJECTS OF AFFECTION
description: There was a time not long ago when a humble metallic sphere called a node caused untold problems in constructing a building architects and government officials describe as a ''crystal palace'' on the West Side.

title: Primary Thoughts
description: Democrats, led by Governor

title: MONEY FUND PAYOUTS: TAX POLICIES CONFLICT
description: Across the country, investors in money market mutual funds face conflicting patterns of state taxation on interest paid by the funds, and a decision this week by New York State has further complicated the question.

title: LETHAL, IF NONPOISONOUS
description: To the Editor:

title: NEIGHBORS 'SHOCKED' BY SPY CHARGES
description: Richard Craig Smith, the former military counterintelligence agent arrested on charges of selling secrets to the Soviet Union, seemed to be a good family man, a respected Mormon Church official and an upstanding citizen, according to stunned friends in Utah.

title: HOUSTON OIL FIELDS COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-There are no year-ago results because the company began operations on June 24, 1983.

title: PRESIDENT ASSAILS CONGRESS OVER USE OF FORCES ABROAD
description: President Reagan criticized Congress today for what he said was its reluctance to support the use of military force to advance foreign policy goals.

title: CARTWRIGHT HURT
description: The Knicks wasted a 44-point performance by Bernard King, lost ground in the race for home-court advantage in the playoffs and lost their starting center, Bill Cartwright, for at least one game in bowing to the Detroit Pistons last night.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A chart yesterday on the financial status of the Social Security and Medicare trust funds listed incorrect figures for the Medicare fund in 1970. Income was $6 billion, payments were $5.3 billion and the fund at the end of the year held $3.2 billion.

title: FLOODING FORCES MANY FROM HOMES
description: Flooding from two days of record rainfall in the metropolitan area forced thousands of people from their homes yesterday and closed large stretches of major roadways.

title: Meatpackers Indicted For Sanitary Violations
description: A Federal grand jury today indicted a father and son who operated the Cattle King Meat Packing Company, six of their associates and two Agriculture Department employees on charges that they violated sanitary laws.

title: Tigers 3, White Sox 2
description: Dave Bergman hit a two-run single to cap a three-run first inning, and Milt Wilcox and Willie Hernandez combined on a six- hitter for the Tigers. The Tigers' triumph, their third straight victory marked marked the best start for Detroit since 1966 and spoiled Chicago's home opener before a crowd of 42,692.

title: MAJESTY FADING FROM RUSSIA'S WINDOW ON WEST
description: This is a haunted city, and the ghosts come out in force in the foggy twilight of early spring.

title: Kicks
description: It was West 43d Street in Manhattan

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Company Earnings table in Business Day Wednesday carried figures incorrectly identified as the fourth-quarter results of the Conwood Corporation. Conwood has not reported earnings for the period.

title: Mavericks 131 Spurs 118; MAVERICKS 131, SPURS 118
description: Rolando Blackman scored 32 points as Dallas snapped a five-game losing streak.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: NEW YORK STATE JOBLESS RATE DIPS TO 6.9%, LOWEST IN 4 YEARS
description: Unemployment in New York State last month fell to its lowest rate in four years, the Bureau of Labor Satistics reported yesterday.

title: Fumes Sicken 200 Workers
description: About 200 workers at a Bali Company clothing plant were evacuated today after 60 employees required treatment for inhalation of fumes, officials said. A county police spokesman, Sam Ratchford, said employees at the plant, which manufactures women's undergarments, were evacuated after they began complaining of nausea.

title: Books of The Times
description: A LITTLE LEARNING. By Evelyn

title: A's 3, Red Sox 1
description: Lary Sorensen and Bill Caudill combined on a five-hitter to lead unbeaten Oakland to its third victory.

title: Mrs. Gandhi to Shorten Her Africa Trip
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, under criticism for a proposed six-day official trip to northern Africa, said today that she would shorten it because of the turmoil in the northern state of Punjab.

title: ELECTION COMMISSION DISMISSES COMPLAINT ON ADDABBO FUNDS
description: The Federal Election Commission has rejected a complaint against Representative Joseph P. Addabbo, Democrat of Queens, that he had violated campaign fund-raising laws.

title: LASERMETRICS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
AUTOCLAVE ENGINEERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Net income.

title: Candidates' Aides Agree On Minnesota Standing
description: Walter F. Mondale has won at least 39 delegates in Minnesota's Democratic Party caucuses, according to his representatives and those of Senator Gary Hart, a rival for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: BARRIC RESOURCES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
ABDUL-JABBAR MAKES RETIREMENT POINTS
description: Twenty-four hours after he had solidified his position as one of professional basketball's greatest players by eclipsing Wilt Chamberlain's career scoring record, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar said tonight he would not change his decision to retire after next season.

title: HART PRESSES FOR SUPPORT IN WISCONSIN'S CAUCUSES
description: Speaking in a state and a city noted for political independence, Gary Hart today called on Democrats to break with ''the failed leadership and failed policies'' of the party's past.

title:
PATENTS;
Gene Copying
description: An invention in biotechnology, patented this week for the University of California at Berkeley, covers methods of making a microorganism with genes derived from higher organisms, such as a human.

title: Tax Form Gifts Aiding Wildlife
description: Fish and wildlife projects will share at least $2.5 million in contributions by taxpayers, the state's Environmental Conservation Commissioner, Henry G. Williams, said today.

title: 2 Ways to Hear the Chatter From Space, and One Is Free
description: While thousands of Americans will pay 50 cents or more for a telephone call to hear the shuttle astronauts who soared into space today, thousands of others will be able to eavesdrop for free.

title: CAMEROON RADIO SAYS AN ATTEMPTED COUP HAS FAILED
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, Saturday, April 7 (Reuters) - The Government radio in the West African nation of Cameroon announced Friday that an attempted coup had failed.

title: CANEI: HOT LABEL IN WINE IMPORTS
description: While most of the wine industry is struggling to keep sales even with last year, one brand of Italian table wine has managed to increase its sales 56 percent. Star Industries' Canei has become this country's third most popular imported wine, up from ninth a year ago.

title: Trying to Ban Chemical Weapons
description: President Reagan's decision to seek a worldwide ban on chemical weapons is a welcome step, especially in light of Iraq's treacherous use of mustard gas and probably nerve gas against Iran. But without further efforts the initiative is unlikely to succeed or improve the Administration's undistinguished record on arms control.

title: WHEN THE U.S. BACKS BANKS' FOREIGN DEALS
description: To the Editor:

title:
Patents;
Unit Aids In Care of Retarded
Red Ink on the Ice
description: There's a lot of money in shopping centers, but there may be a limit - at least to the amount Edward J. DeBartolo is prepared to pour into a losing sports franchise. DeBartolo, the real estate developer who bought his son the San Francisco 49ers and himself the Pittsburgh Maulers and the Pittsburgh Penguins, seems to be losing patience with the Penguins.

title: Rogers Cable Sale
description: Rogers Cablesystems Inc. said it had agreed to sell its Irish cable television holdings to the broadcasting arm of the Irish Government. It said the transaction, for which terms were not disclosed, is expected to close within 90 days. Rogers currently has a 75 percent interest in systems serving 110,000 cable subscribers in the cities of Dublin and Waterford.

title: Kidder Broker Featured in Ad
description: Kidder, Peabody & Company has been promoting an advertisement featuring a broker who may have been involved in the controversy surrounding Wall Street Journal articles.

title: TERRELL WINS ON 4-HITTER
description: The Mets got another blue-chip performance from ''the kids'' tonight when Walt Terrell pitched them to a four-hit, 8-1 victory over the Houston Astros and needed only 98 pitches to do it.

title: OLYMPICS WAS ONE OF SEVERAL RATINGS SETBACKS FOR ABC-TV
description: When ABC-TV executives look back at the 1983-84 season, they are unlikely to find many fond memories.

title: New Bulgarian Envoy to Italy
description: Bulgaria's new Ambassador to Italy arrived in Rome today, 15 months after his predecessor was recalled during an investigation into reports of a Bulgarian connection to the shooting of Pope John Paul II. The new Bulgarian Ambassador, Raico Marinov Nicolov, was greeted on arrival at Rome's airport by Soviet and other East European diplomats. Foreign Ministry officials said Italy had also named a new Ambassador to Bulgaria, Giovanni Battistini, and he will leave for Sofia on Monday.

title: IRT Fire Injures 33
description: A smoky electrical fire on the tracks of the IRT East Side subway line in downtown Manhattan yesterday forced 200 people to be removed through emergency exits and resulted in 33 minor injuries.

title: 'A BOY'S WILL IS THE WIND'S WILL.' THAT GOES FOR GIRLS,TOO
description: I have been noticing lately that my 14-year-old son, Matthew, seems to sit around the house most of the day in bare feet. I don't know what to make of this. In cargo freighters all over the world, men sleep with their boots on, and my son spends his waking hours with his shoes off. I thought getting him a dog would perk him up and maybe even set him running along forest paths, but now the two of them just sit in front of the wood stove playing with his socks. The major effort of each day seems to be to pick up those feet so I can get by carrying the firewood.

title: LNDLRD W/DIM VU OF TNANTS SKS RM TO CRY
description: By what can be described only as a stroke of cosmic misfortune, I am a New York City landlord.

title: ON THE SEVENTH DAY
description: Headline

title: LOSS OF DEVIL'S BAG COSTLY TO GOTHAM
description: Yesterday morning, radio advertisements were still urging New Yorkers to come out and see Devil's Bag race in the Gotham Stakes at Aqueduct today. But as the horses are being called to the post for that race this afternoon, Devil's Bag will be riding a van that should be in the vicinity of the George Washington Bridge, just beginning the 18-hour ride that will deliver him to Lexington, Ky., by tomorrow morning.

title: Celtics 113, Cavaliers 94
description: Larry Bird scored 33 points, including 19 in the second period, and Boston clinched the best regular-season record in the league. With their sixth consecutive victory, and 14th in a row over Cleveland at home since 1978, the Celtics raised their record to 58-19. By amassing the regular season's top record, the Celtics insured themselves of home-court advantage throughout the playoffs

title: DALLAS MUSEUM TO RECEIVE MAJOR COLLECTION
description: The Dallas Museum of Fine Art announced yesterday that it has been promised an important collection of Impressionist and Post-Impressionist painting and European decorative arts.

title: REPORT SAYS ISRAEL DIVERTS AID FOR ARABS
description: An independent study has concluded that millions of dollars in United States Government aid intended for Palestinians under Israeli occupation are being redirected by Israel away from programs that would strengthen the Arabs' economic base on the West Bank and the Gaza Strip.

title: Ex-Sandinista Returns Home
description: A former official of the Sandinista Government returned to Nicaragua today after two years abroad and urged the Sandinistas to lift press censorship and ''establish a genuine democratic process.'' The official, Alfredo Cesar, former president of Nicaragua's National Bank, has been living in Costa Rica.

title: JAY DERMER
description: Former Mayor Jay Dermer of Miami Beach died of a heart attack Thursday.

title: 'PORNOGRAPHY RING' IS BROKEN
description: An international child pornography ring, whose records were kept on home computers and involved girls who were lured by promises of household jobs, has been uncovered after operating for up to 10 years, the police said today.

title: GEORESOURCES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $339,000.

title: Donovan Predicts Labor Will Vote for Reagan
description: Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan said today that rank-and-file union members would show stronger support for President Reagan in the Presidential election than they did in 1980.

title: EAST GERMAN 'FIANCEE,' LIFE IN NAZI JAIL
description: The East German film ''The Fiancee'' tells of the ordeal of a woman who was sentenced to 10 years in a Nazi prison during the 1930's after she had been found guilty of treason. As quietly well acted as the leading role is by Jutta Wachowiak, and as serious as the film is most of the time, it is also surprisingly shrill.

title: Casinos Busy as Court Orders Cut in Picketing
description: Teamster truck drivers refused to cross picket lines today to collect garbage at Las Vegas casinos but a big influx of weekend tourists ignored pickets and crowded into the hotel-casinos.

title: DAN COLEMAN
description: Dan Coleman, an international planner whose work ranged from communities in Marin County to Kuwait, died at Kaiser Hospital here Wednesday.

title: 2 CHEROKEE NATIONS HOLD FIRST JOINT COUNCIL
description: Thousands of Cherokees, some in traditional clothing, some in business suits, returned to their ancestors' sacred ground today for the first time since they were forced down the ''Trail of Tears'' to Oklahoma in 1838.

title: CLEARING MEN'S MINDS
description: Change is not automatically synonymous with improvement, but changes in voting patterns can often startle politicians into altering their established habits in a healthy way.

title: ADDING CITY SERVICES
description: Mayor Koch's recent decision to hire 150 workers to clean streets, repair water pipes and fill potholes is not, as some officials and civic groups had hoped, the first step in an ambitious plan for significantly improving services soon.Mr. Koch says he will spend money as it becomes available, but he generally has not set specific long-range goals for either the number of workers he would like to hire or for the level of services he would like to attain. He says there is no reason to set goals absent a realistic chance there will be enough money to achieve them quickly. And he clearly does not believe that the city, despite recent talk of budget surpluses, is out of the financial woods.

title: EXCERPTS FROM PRESIDENT REAGAN'S SPEECH ON FOREIGN POLICY AND CONGRESS
description: Following are excerpts from President Reagan's speech today at the Georgetown University Center for Strategic and International Studies, as made available by the White House:

title: DETAILS OF SEXUAL ABUSE CASE AT SCHOOL DESCRIBED
description: Ten years of torture and sexual abuse at a suburban preschool scarred ''a whole generation of children'' during hundreds of molestations, according to allegations disclosed today by prosecutors and grand jury testimony.

title: THE OTHER RACE, PHILIDELPHIANS SAY, IS TOO CLOSE A CALL
description: The other race is too close to call, people who can sense such things are saying up at the subway station in North Philadelphia and down at Palumbo's Cafe- Restaurant and Pat's Steaks in South Philadelphia.

title: Dent Still Dazed At Being Waived
description: When the Yankees arrived at Arlington Stadium to open a weekend series with Texas last night, Bucky Dent was not there to greet his former teammates.

title: 51 ARE SEIZED IN STOREFRONT RAIDS IN BROOKLYN
description: The police raided 32 storefront drug and gambling operations in Brooklyn yesterday in what they described as a new crackdown on illegal businesses along Nostrand Avenue.

title: Move to Cut Deficit Costs U.S. $72,000
description: The Senate spent $72,000 today to print in the Congressional Record the full text of a bill aimed at reducing the Federal deficit.

title: CUOMO ATTACKS REAGAN BEFORE WOMEN'S GROUP
description: A day after President Reagan defended his record before a women's group, Governor Cuomo went before the same group yesterday and attacked Mr. Reagan's economic policies. He said the policies had widened the gap between rich and poor and had thus endangered all Americans.

title: AMEX HAD 1ST INQUIRY ON JOURNAL
description: Executives at TIE / Communications Inc. were frustrated and angry last October. Despite strong earnings for the latest quarter, the company's stock had plunged more than 20 percent in a week, following a negative article in The Wall Street Journal. Following that, the executives sensed that a Journal reporter, R. Foster Winans, was preparing a downbeat ''Heard on the Street'' column.

title: JOHN CONNORS, 58, PUBLISHER WITH AMERICAN EXPRESS CO.
description: John S. Connors, president of the American Express Publishing Corporation and publisher of two of its magazines, died of a heart attack Thursday on his way back to his office at 1260 Avenue of the Americas after a luncheon appointment. He was 58 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: GEOCRUDE ENERGY INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
China Buying U.S. Wheat
description: China has bought an additional 200,000 metric tons of wheat - about 7.34 million bushels - under the terms of a four-year agreement with the United States, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Large Japanese Surplus
description: Japan's current account surplus for the 1983 fiscal year may total $24 billion, a top- ranking but unidentified Economic Planning Agency official was quoted as saying by the Kyodo News Service today. The official added that the balance for the 1983 fiscal year, which ended March 31, may have been $1 billion more than projected by the Government earlier this year.

title: Bill Would Create Yonkers Monitor
description: Legislation creating an Emergency Financial Control Board for Yonkers was sent to Albany today just as the Yonkers City Manager, Rodney Irwin, proposed an alternative to avoid forming such a panel to supervise the city's finances.

title: INSURANCE POLICIES THAT FILL HOSPITALS
description: To the Editor:

title: Jury in Bribe Trial Recesses
description: A Federal District Court jury ended its first full day of deliberations today without reaching a verdict on the fate of Federal District Judge Harry Claiborne, accused of accepting bribes from a brothel owner, tax evasion and obstruction of justice. The jury deliberated seven hours and recessed until Saturday. Visiting Judge Walter Hoffman turned the case over to the jury late Thursday night.

title: Correction
description: An article in Weekend yesterday on the Joffrey II Dancers incorrectly listed some performances at the Joyce Theater. ''Double Duets'' and ''Mixtilinear'' will be danced tomorrow night, and ''Corbel'' tomorrow afternoon, when ''Kazmidity'' will be repeated.

title: ON IMMIGRATION, A POWER BEHIND THE SCENES
description: When people search for reasons to explain why Congress did not pass a comprehensive immigration bill last year, one name is repeatedly mentioned: Garner J. Cline, staff director of the House Judiciary Committee.

title: SATURDAY, APRIL 7, 1984 International
description: Britain expressed disapproval to the Reagan Administration of the mining of Nicaragua's harbors. It said the mining was an interference with international shipping and asked American help in halting the mining, a British Embassy spokesman in Washington said. (Page 1, Column 4.) Some softening of the crucifix ban in Poland's public buildings was agreed to by the Government. Officials close to the Roman Catholic Church said the Government agreed to relax its ban after more than 450 clergymen agreed to join Bishop Jan Mazur, who had been fasting on bread and water in a show of support for students who protested the ban. Bishop Mazur ended his fast and congratulated the students for forcing the Government to compromise. (1:5.)

title: PHILIPPINE GENERAL TELLS OF PLAN TO ARREST AQUINO
description: The country's top military officer told a civilian board of inquiry today that he ordered Benigno S. Aquino Jr. arrested on his return to the Philippines last summer because the opposition leader was under a death sentence imposed by a military court. Mr. Aquino was slain as he was being escorted from an airliner by military officers.

title: CHIEF CONSOLIDATED MINING CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company is listed on the Pacific and Intermountain stock exchanges.

title: Walker May Run
description: The Generals, who had expressed doubt that Herschel Walker could start in tomorrow's game at Giants Stadium against the Memphis Showboats, instead listed him as a probable starter after the star running back participated in the entire practice yesterday. Walker, whose bruised left shoulder caused him to miss practices Wednesday and Thursday, said, ''My shoulder feels fine, and I'm ready to roll.''

title: CYMATICOLOR CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
'TUKANA, ' IN NEW GUINEA
description: ''Tukana'' is somewhat more important as anthropology than as cinema, being a straightforward fictional account of the problems facing young people in the North Solomons Province of Papua, New Guinea.

title: RECYCLING BUTTER MAKES IT ANYTHING BUT SWEETER
description: For several months I have eaten more old, reused, stale or rancid butter in restaurants than anyone should be required to sample in a lifetime. It is a sure sign of sloppy restaurant housekeeping. Even worse than that, reusing butter is prohibited by a New York City regulation. Butter that has been served and then left in a dish must be discarded, according to the New York City Health Department, but the regulation is difficult to enforce and seldom does anyone try.

title: Saints Visit Jacksonville
description: There is more to negotiating than talking, and yesterday officials of the New Orleans Saints, who have been trying to negotiate a new lease on the Superdome, took one of those actions designed to speak louder than words: They made a trip to Jacksonville, Fla., to listen to an offer from that city, which is eager to attract a National Football League team to the Gator Bowl. ''It's in our best interest,'' said Eddie Jones, the Saints' president, who made the trip with Coach Bum Phillips.

title: PLANT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $9,205,000 for the latest year and $4,261,000 for the earlier year.

title: Change of Heart
description: Terence Stansbury , the high-scoring Temple basketball guard, has had second thoughts about passing up the Olympic trials.

title: Leaseway Expects Drop in Profits
description: The Leaseway Transportation Corporation said it expects first-quarter profits to be below last year's $4.8 million, or 40 cents a share, which included an extraordinary gain of 8 cents a share from the sale of a unit.

title: Kelso Said to Raise U.S. Industries Bid
description: U.S. Industries said yesterday that it had received a sweetened offer of $24 a share in cash to take the company private.

title: BIRDSBORO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $94,000 for the quarter and income of $114,000 for the year from equity in affiliates. c-Including equity in net earnings of affiliates of $67,000 for the quarter and $641,000 for the year.

title: Carter Hawley's Advice on Offer
description: Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. has sent a letter to employees and shareholders urging them not to tender their shares to The Limited Inc. until Carter Hawley's board takes a position on The Limited's $30-a-share offer. The letter said the directors' position may be decided by April 17, after they consider the tender offer ''from various standpoints.''

title: STUDY FINDS E.P.A. NOT PROTECTING GROUND WATER
description: The Environmental Protection Agency's rules for monitoring and controlling hazardous waste are inadequate to protect underground water supplies, according to a study prepared for Congress.

title: Track Tempest
description: Larry Heidebrecht , the track and field coach at perennially-strong Texas-El Paso, has resigned amid reports that he violated intercollegiate rules by using a secret athletic department bank account to funnel more than $20,000 in appearance payments from meet promoters to the school's top stars. Pending completion of an investigation by the university, neither Heidebrecht, hired in 1982, nor other school officials were commenting on the matter.

description: Jimmy Kennedy, an Irish songwriter best known for ''Red Sails in the Sunset'' and ''April in Portugal,'' died today at the age of 81.

title: Gulf Executives' Stock Clearance
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation said that about 400 executives could turn in stock options worth nearly $86 million if a planned merger with the Standard Oil Company of California went through. Gulf's chairman, James E. Lee, stands to gain $6.7 million under a stock option plan designed to take effect in case of a takeover.

title: EAST BERLIN LETS 38 GO TO THE WEST
description: East Germany will allow 38 of its nationals who took refuge in West German diplomatic missions in Prague and East Berlin to emigrate to the West, the Bonn Government spokesman said today.

title: ABC AND TURNER MAY COMPETE TO BUY ESPN
description: The American Broadcasting Companies and the Turner Broadcasting System, which operates the 24-hour Cable News Network, may become competitors for the ownership of the Entertainment and Sports Programming Network, the nation's largest cable network.

title: 10 Employees at Temple U. Indicted in Kickback Scheme
description: A Federal grand jury has indicted 10 present or former Temple University employees on charges of participating in a 15-year conspiracy that is said to have netted more than $750,000 in kickbacks from suppliers.

description: b-Net loss c-After an extraordinary loss of $286,908.

title: CLEVELAND BREAKS STALEMATE OVER POLICE ARMS
description: The Cleveland City Council passed a $231 million budget today, ending a stalemate that paralyzed city finances this week and prevented hundreds of employees from receiving paychecks.

title: Expos 8, Braves 5
description: Tim Raines belted a three-run homer and Tim Wallach hit a two-run homer in a six- run fourth inning for Montreal. The Braves led, 2-1, going into the fourth, but Gary Carter led off with a single up the middle and Wallach followed with his first homer of the season, off Ken Dayley (0-1).

title: ROBERTS & PORTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NUCLEAR REFORMISTS VS. HARDLINERS
description: Is nuclear power finally dead in the United States? In the wake of the Long Island Lighting Company's $4 billion overrun in construction of its Shoreham plant comes more bad news for the nuclear industry. Now the Seabrook project, beset by a huge overrun, may bankrupt the plant's principal owner, the Public Service Company of New Hampshire, and damage both the financial standing of other regional utilities and the area's economy.

title: FEMALE CANTORS FIGHTING PROFESSIONAL ISOLATION
description: Soon after Deborah Katchko Zimmerman was appointed cantor of Congregation Beth El in Norwalk, Conn., four years ago, she felt an overwhelming sense of professional isolation.

Chartercorp Control Sought
description: A director of Chartercorp, a Kansas City, Mo., bank holding company, said yesterday that he planned to seek enough shares to acquire control of the company. Stanley H. Durwood, a Kansas City investor and president of AMC Entertainment Inc., made his intention known in a filing with with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

description: The company called the Joffrey II Dancers, now at the Joyce Theater for the first time, was formed originally to serve as a training ground for future members of the Joffrey Ballet.

title: Tsongas to Become Partner Of Boston Law Firm in 1985
description: Senator Paul E. Tsongas, a Massachusetts Democrat who is not seeking re-election this year, will become a partner in the Boston law firm of Foley, Hoag & Eliot, concentrating on high-technology and international law issues, a law partner said today.

title: First Step
description: Zola Budd , the 17-year-old barefoot middle-distance runner from South Africa, was granted British citizenship yesterday, but it was unclear whether the move would enable her to compete in the Olympics at Los Angeles. Olympic rules impose a three- year waiting period before an athlete who changes nationalities can compete for his new country, but the waiting period is often waived. Miss Budd could not otherwise compete in the Games because South Africa's racial policies have caused that country to be banned.

title: ATARI TO CUT 550 JOBS AT 2 PLANTS
description: Atari Inc. said yesterday that it would lay off about 550 workers in Milpitas, Calif., and Fajardo, P.R., and consolidate some of its production operations in El Paso to reduce costs.

description: Yogi Berra, looking for any positive sign in this woeful first week of the season, considered the game just completed and said, ''They came back.''

PATENTS;

description: Traders at Salomon Brothers Inc. were among those who were forced to evacuate the 50- story 1 New York Plaza building in a fire yesterday.

description: ''Dear youth, you have won through goodness. You were the ones who came to Christ and calmly stood by the cross.

title: Wills Charge Dismissed
description: A charge of cocaine possession against Maury Wills , the former major league baseball player and manager, was dismissed yesterday because of insufficient evidence, according to a spokesman for the Los Angeles County district attorney's office. Wills, 51 years old, was arrested last December when the police were checking a stolen-car report.

title: 2,500 Homes Won in Cairo
description: About 2,500 young, newly married couples won new homes today in a raffle organized by the Egyptian Government. The state-built suburban homes were offered as prizes in the raffle because it was considered the fairest way to allocate scarce living space.

description: Amid the caviar and cocktail sauce, the whole dressed turtles and the frog's legs, the candidate donned an apron labeled Fritz and expertly scaled a walleyed pike at a local fish market today.

PATENTS;

description: Various compounds of phosphorous and nitrogen, patented this week for the Research Corporation, Tucson, Ariz., can be used to form frameworks for attachment of substances such as drugs, vitamins or pesticides.

title: 6 EX-DIPLOMATS CRITICAL OF CAMPAIGN
description: Six former high- ranking American diplomats indicated in their separate ways today that the current Presidential campaign was producing little serious debate on foreign policy.

description: Einar Vihjalmsson of Iceland and the University of Texas broke the 14-year-old collegiate javelin record tonight with a throw of 303 feet 1 inch at the 57th Texas Relays.

description: Baby Jane Doe's parents said today that they had permitted doctors to perform an operation to remove water from the brain of their severely deformed infant daughter.

title: REUSABLE SPACE 'TRUCK' FOR ORBIT EXPERIMENTS
description: Almost as big as a city bus, the 11-ton satellite to be gently placed in space Saturday by the shuttle Challenger will be the first launched by the shuttle's robot arm and the first meant to be brought back to earth and used again.

description: Like handymen responding to a service call, five astronauts rode off in the space shuttle Challenger today, climbing at full throttle into high orbit, with bold plans to find, pick up and then repair a disabled scientific satellite.

title: Military Contract
description: The Defense Systems division of the Northrop Corporation recieved a $46.7 million Air Force contract, the Defense Department said. The contract is for the updating of F-15 fighter plane electronic countermeasures.

title: FILM: LAUDERDALE QUARTET, 'WHERE THE BOYS ARE'
description: No one's going to make any great claims for the original ''Where the Boys Are,'' but at least it had a certain innocence. This, after all, was the film in which boy-crazy Yvette Mimieux was willing to do anything, even have sex, in order to land a husband from the Ivy League.

title: JACKSON RECALLS SPIRIT OF POPULISTS IN A BID FOR SUPPORT IN WISCONSIN
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson told a joint session of the Wisconsin Legislature today that he was the only Democratic Presidential candidate talking about ''social change'' rather than ''social service'' and the only candidate who has committed himself to a real end to the arms race.

Pope Rejects Meeting With Rebel Cleric
description: Pope John Paul II has rejected a proposed meeting with Archbishop Marcel Lefebvre, the conservative cleric who opposes changes within the church, during the Pope's trip to Switzerland June 12-17, a Vatican source said today.

description: A loss usually disturbs Al Arbour's sense of order. Yet the Islanders' coach was smiling today, even attempting some gags. For, according to Arbour, his club's 3-0 loss to the Rangers in the playoffs Thursday night wasn't that bad.

title: THE MAN FOR THE MEESE INQUIRY
description: What they wanted, Federal appeals-court Judge Roger Robb said, was ''a competent man, a man who knows his way around the courtroom, an honest man.'' So last week Judge Robb's selection panel selected Jacob A. Stein, a veteran criminal defense lawyer, to conduct a wide-ranging investigation of Edwin Meese 3d, the Presidential Counselor President Reagan nominated to be Attorney General.

description: Hundreds more people fled their homes in northern New Jersey yesterday as rivers swollen by two days of record rains continued to overflow their banks.

title: City Ballet to Present Two World Premieres
description: The New York City Ballet will present two world premieres during its two-month spring season at the New York State Theater that opens on April 24.

title: SHOULD PASSPORT MEDICINE BE REVOKED?
description: When it comes to the medical profession, New York State is the nation's leading importer-exporter. For the last decade, doctors born and educated in foreign countries have made up between 40 and 50 percent of the new physicians admitted to practice each year by the State Board of Regents. Last year, 42 percent of the 4,312 new doctors licensed by the state were graduates of foreign medical schools.

title: DANCE: 'KOYAANISQATSI,' KATHRYN POSIN WORK
description: Kathryn Posin may be one of the most exasperating choreographers in New York. There's an obvious intelligence at work. She has an eye for good dancers, and she makes them look good on stage. But somehow her dances seldom seem to penetrate the surface.

description: THOUGH most museums specialize in either art, science, industry or nature, Frederick Bayersdorfer Jr. wants his museum to specialize ''in the interrelationship of all of these,'' and make it easy for visitors to participate in exhibits.

title: 2 MOTHERS, 21 YEARS' CHANGE
description: THE two women provide a portrait in contrasts, a glimpse of how much times have changed. One, 43 years old, is animated and eager to talk of the baby whom she put up for adoption 21 years ago and with whom she was reunited last year. The other woman is 20, soft-spoken and comfortable with her decision to put her baby up for adoption, confident that, someday, she will see her again.

title: 'SALESMAN' DEMONSTRATES ITS ENDURING STRENGTHS
description: What was that strange, sniffing sound that was echoing from roughly Row D to roughly Row M toward the end of ''Death of a Salesman'' at the Broadhurst? Post- winter catarrh, or something a bit less noxious? At the time, Dustin Hoffman's Willy Loman was embracing his balky, despairing son Biff with the kind of disbelieving tenderness you expect to see on the faces of fathers when they pick up their first-born for the first time. There they were, intertwined, nuzzling, holding each other and us in the audience for longer than - well, longer than it would take a Chinese laundry to wash, iron and wrap the tear-spattered handkerchiefs that, one gradually realized, were being surreptitiously bundled back into pockets in rows D, H, J and M. Something was clearly right with Michael Rudman's production. Something was no less right with Arthur Miller's play.

title: The Island And the Arts
description: Re: Rea Jacobs's recent letter to the editor in support of the arts on Long Island: We have, indeed, come a long way with a resulting diversity and richness of artistic endeavors that stretch from one end of this great island to the other.

description: A Baltimore City Circuit judge has issued a 35-day restraining order that prevents the National Football League from scheduling games involving the Colts outside Baltimore.

title: The Power to Make War For a time last week, Secretary of State Shultz seemed to pose an interesting question: How can America pursue a muscular diplomacy without strangling the democracy it aims to defend? Having lost a power play in Lebanon and failed to make power count in Central America, Mr. Shultz was wondering whether Americans would ever be willing to fight terror with terror and covert war with covert war. If they didn't, he warned of dire consequences. If they did, Congress had to stop tying the President's hands.
description: It's an old constitutional dilemma, but this time it's no dilemma at all. For Mr. Shultz and Candidate Reagan pushed the whole subject into the mud by blaming the failure of the Lebanon intervention, and the loss of 260 troops, on their critics in Congress. By the time they finished defining their philosophy, it had crumbled into shabby alibi.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
U.S. PORTION OF BRAND SALE TO BE HELD IN JUNE
description: Blockbuster auctions continue to be big news in numismatics. Last week detailed plans were announced for the auction sale of foreign and ancient coins from the famous Garrett Collection, and now details are available on the second and final auction of United States coins from the equally renowned Brand Collection.

title: 1686 DEED CITED IN SAG HARBOR DISPUTE
description: O FFICIALS of Sag Harbor are protesting a move by the Town of East Hampton to assume control of boat moorings in waters adjacent to the village. Town officials are justifying their action by citing the Dongan Patent, a land deed given to Thomas Dongan, Governor of New York, by King James II in 1686.

description: Willie Gault, the Chicago Bears wide receiver who is also a sprinter, has filed an antitrust suit against the International Olympic Committee seeking to allow him to compete in amateur meets, including the Olympics.

description: THE 11th Annual Connecticut Spring Antiques Show at the State Armory in Hartford next weekend will offer collectors an opportunity to study, examine and purchase a wide variety of fine American antiques from almost 100 major dealers from across the nation.

title: A Shake-up in Honduras Causes Tremors in U.S
description: Just one day before the United States and Honduras were to begin joint military exercises, a group of young officers stunned Washington and the Honduran Government by arresting the commander of the Honduran armed forces, handcuffing him, and putting him on a plane to Costa Rica. The ousted commander, General Gustavo Alvarez Martinez, a strong ally of the United States, was often accused of running Honduras along with the American Ambassador, John D. Negroponte. The general was in Washington last week being interviewed by Pentagon officials anxious to find out what happened to him and to four other top officers, who were sent to embassies abroad.

title: AMERICANS ON SHIP SAID TO SUPERVISE NICARAGUA MINING
description: Americans working for the Central Intelligence Agency on a ship off Nicaragua's Pacific coast have been supervising the mining of Nicaraguan harbors in recent months, according to Reagan Administration officials and members of Congress.

description: Gov. William A. O'Neill's proposal to finance the rebuilding of Connecticut's roads and bridges by an initial increase of 3 cents a gallon in the state gasoline tax was rebuffed this week by the Democratic majority in the State Senate.

title: Hart Complains to U.S. On Mondale's Spending
description: Senator Gary Hart of Colorado has filed a complaint with the Federal Election Commission accusing Walter F. Mondale of attempting to circumvent Federal spending limits. The former Vice President's campaign manager says the complaint is politically motivated.

title: Help for Scurry
description: Rod Scurry , the Pittsburgh Pirate relief pitcher, is going to need some relief of his own. And he is getting support from the Pirates.

title: ON THE RECORD; Old Faces of 1984
description: Playbill, the magazine-program distributed in Broadway theaters, turns 100 this week but can't find an 1884 issue to prove it. The earliest edition anyone has saved is for a six-act play, ''Anselma,'' given in 1885, but people have been faithfully saving copies of Playbill ever since.

title: FICTION OF THE MANAGERIAL CLASS
description: TRY to think of an office scene in a major modern American novel. Hemingway scarcely has one anywhere in his work. (He never used his famous brawl with Max Eastman in Maxwell Perkins's office as fictional material.) In ''The Grapes of Wrath'' and scores of other protest novels of the 1930's, the callous acts of bankers and businessmen are described, but we seldom see them committing the acts - or, in the case of ''The Grapes of Wrath,'' see them at all.

title: NUREMBERG REBUILT: CITY AT THE CROSSROADS
description: Glowing testimonials to Nuremberg abound. But so do the harshest judgments of deprecation and disdain. Martin Luther said it ''shines forth throughout Germany like a sun among the moon and stars.'' Goethe wrote of it with lavish praise. Hans Christian Andersen spoke of its ''royal dignity'' and saw it as the ''quintessence of medieval culture.'' To the romanticists of the 19th century it was a ''living, vibrant treasure chest,'' and the novelist Ernst Junger has called it ''magical, like Venice or Prague.'' Yet Mozart was deeply depressed by its formidable battlements and Gothic severity. ''An ugly city,'' he said tersely in 1790, in a letter to a friend.

title: Doctor Named to Drug Post p
description: President Reagan has named Dr. Donald Macdonald, a pediatrician, as Administrator of the Alcohol, Drug Abuse and Mental Health Administration. Dr. Macdonald, 52 years old, of Clearwater, Fla., is president of the Florida chapter of the American Academy of Pediatrics and the Florida Pediatric Society.

title: IT'S CAVEAT EMPTOR WITH I.R.A. ADS
description: ADS promoting Individual Retirement Accounts are everywhere these days, but pity

title: FOR PRIVACY, PETER ISLAND
description: DEBORAH BLUMENTHAL, who frequently writes about health and beauty for The New York Times Magazine, lives in New York. By DEBORAH BLUMENTHAL

title: THE UNITED NATIONS SECURITY COUNCIL SEEMS BENT ON IRRESOLUTION
description: When it was created 39 years ago, the United Nations Security Council was viewed as the essential element of the world body, a group of 15 powerful and influential nations that would act in concert to promote the peace. That good intention has rarely become reality. However, at few times in the past has the Security Council seemed less effective - and the American position more isolated - than in recent debates.

title: SOLDER A THREAT TO L.I. WATER
description: W ATER quality on Long Island has focused in the past on the pollution of the precious resource; now, concern is centering on a new threat.

title: HOUSE COUNTS THE WAYS TO TRIM DEFICIT
description: Passing a budget resolution that sets targets for spending and revenue is not the same as cutting popular programs and raising taxes. It is, however, Step A. And to demonstrate its appreciation of the seriousness of the issue, the House of Representatives last week considered not one but eight plans for reducing the $206.8 billion deficit the Congressional Budget Office projects for 1985. As expected, the blueprint put forward by the Democratic majority's leaders carried, 250 to 168, almost cleanly along party lines.

title: Islanders: One Plays, the Other Doesn't
description: Many of them wear Stanley Cup rings and forced smiles.

title: CHINESE FOOD FROM THE HOT POT
description: S TONY WOK in Flushing, Queens, is the only Chinese restaurant of its kind in the New York area. The six-week-old restaurant specializes in hot pot cookery that the owners say is Taiwanese.

title: SPRUCING UP OUTDOOR PATIO FURNITURE AND PROLONGING ITS LIFE
description: A LTHOUGH outdoor patio furniture is supposedly designed for continuous exposure to the weather - and supposedly requires little or no maintenance - anyone who owns furniture of this kind soon learns that some maintenance is definitely required each year in order to preserve its appearance and prolong its life.

title: STRANGER AND STRANGER IN PARADISE
description: Veronica Geng's collection of satirical pieces, ''Partners,'' will be published this summer. CASTAWAY

title: AROUND THE GARDEN;
description: JOAN LEE FAUST This Week:

title: NEW YORK BLACKS TAKE A BIG STEP TOWARD POLITICAL CLOUT
description: The posters still hanging at midweek in the Rev. Jesse Jackson's New York campaign headquarters proclaimed proudly: ''Now Is the Time.'' Last Tuesday's New York Presidential primary was the time to demonstrate that black New Yorkers had enrolled in the Democratic Party in numbers closer than before to their proportion of the population and that they could be counted on to vote. They did just that.

title: RANGERS ROUT ISLANDERS, 7-2, AND LEAD SERIES BY 2-1
description: The Rangers, who one week ago said that overcoming the Islanders would be an almost impossible mountain to climb, now stand only one victory from tossing the four-time Stanley Cup champions from the pinnacle of the National Hockey League.

title: EX-GOVERNORS ON COUNCIL
description: PRINCETON THE Council on New Jersey Affairs was established by Princeton University in 1981. William G. Bowen, Princeton's president, appointed a group of leaders from the private sector and academia to investigate major public policy issues concerning the state.

title: THE CRANBROOK VISION
description: THAT A SINGLE AMERICAN SCHOOL COULD PRODUCE enough art objects during a 25-year period to fill a major exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art is not in itself extraordinary. Several art schools might be able to fill one of the Met's galleries with significant work by their alumni, and so could numerous schools of architecture. But if the exhibition were to include firstrate works of painting, sculputre, architecture, furniture design, interior design, ceramics, textiles, metalwork and bookbinding, the possible sources diminish rapidly. They come down, in fact, to one--the Cranbrook Academy of Art in Bloomfield Hills, Mich.

title: SENATOR IS PRAISED AS AN ELOQUENT LEADER IN FOREIGN POLICY
description: Frank Church's efforts in such diverse areas as foreign policy, social justice and conservation were praised today by President Reagan and members of the Senate.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. Lillian Pliner to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jacques Pliner of Baldwin, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter Dr. Lillian F. Pliner to Stephen L. Dreyfuss, the son of Janet S. Dreyfuss of Cedarhurst, L.I., and the late Joseph D. Dreyfuss. Dr. Pliner is a fellow in oncology at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York. Her fiance is a member of the Newark law firm of Hellring Lindeman Goldstein & Siegal. A June wedding is planned.

title: Mailbox
description: Critics Evaded By Georgetown

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION ;
LOTTERY PAYOUTS COULD BE BIGGER
description: -paying state lotteries? Of getting $1 million to have and to hold from that day forward? If that is your dream, forget it. It does not work that way.

title: Warsaw Pact Plans Meeting
description: Warsaw Pact Foreign Ministers will meet in Budapest late this month, the official press agency said Friday. The officials, from the Soviet Union, Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, East Germany, Hungary, Poland and Rumania, last met in Sofia, Bulgaria, in October.

title: KOOSMAN DEFEATS REDS BY 9-1
description: Joe Lefebvre had four hits, including a two-run homer, and drove in five runs today to lead the Philadelphia Phillies to a 9-1 victory over the Cincinnati Reds. Jerry Koosman gained his first National League victory since 1978. It was the Reds' third straight loss.

title: NO AWAY GAMES FOR SOMERS TROJANS
description: ONE of several differences next season between the Somers Trojans and the other 17 in the Atlantic Football League will be that the Trojans will play all 10 of the their games at home.

title: Deborah Blumenthal Weds Michael Marin
description: Deborah R. Blumenthal, the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Emanuel Blumenthal of New York, was married yesterday to Michael L. Marin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Marin of New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbi Balfour Brickner performed the ceremony at the Harmonie Club.

title: WINE
description: SET THY WINE IN ORDER

title: Walker Is Expected to Start
description: Although Herschel Walker is expected to start today when the Generals meet the Memphis Showboats at Giants Stadium, the star running back may be hampered by the bruised left shoulder that, by his admission, has affected his performances.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Three Pianists, a Bass And a String Quartet Perform in Recitals
description: The pianist David Buechner's concert last Sunday afternoon in the 92d Street Y offered the opportunity to encounter an extraordinary young artist in the springtime of his career. Mr. Buechner, who studied at the Juilliard School, was the grand-prize winner of the 1983 American Jewish Congress and Pepsi-Cola Company Young Musicians Competition. The judges listened well; at the age of 24, Mr. Buechner is already a master pianist.

title: MORMONS NAME 2 LAYMEN TO CHURCH'S HIGHEST COUNCIL
description: The 154th Annual General Conference of the Mormon church opened today, and leaders went outside their full-time hierarchy for the first time in two decades to fill two vacancies on their highest council.

title: Elizabeth Lebow Is Bride
description: Elizabeth Susan Lebow, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley E. Lebow of North Woodmere, L.I., was married yesterday to Kenneth Alan Flatto, the son of Frederick A. Flatto and Pauline Raiff, both of New York. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel performed the ceremony at the National Arts Club in New York. Mrs. Flatto is a benefits analyst for ABC. Her husband is a certified public accountant with L. J. Streisand & Company in New York.

title: THE OSCAR CHASE: A PEEK BEHIND THE SCREEN
description: Before any Oscars are handed out tomorrow night at the 56th annual Academy Awards, someone will walk out on stage and recite the voting rules. This tradition begain in 1970 when the FCC demanded it, and the Academy has gone out of its way ever

title: CRIME
description: In Chapter 13 of ''Death at Charity's Point'' by William G. Tapply, a young man telephones the lawyer who is looking into a murder (or is it suicide?). He must see the lawyer; he has some important information to convey. They make a date for the following day. In Chapter 9 of THE SUICIDE MURDERS by Howard Engel (St. Martin's, $11.95), a psychiatrist telephones a private eye. He must see him; he has some important information to convey. They make a date for later that day.

title: WHERE TO FIND CELIBIDACHE ON DISK
description: W hen the legendary Sergiu Celibidache conducted the Symphony Orchestra of the Curtis Institute of Music in New York at the end of February, the performance drew impressive reviews, with John Rockwell of The New York Times calling the experience ''thrilling'' and ''thought- provoking.'' For those who did not attend the concert but who want to hear what the conductor sounded like, the Schwann Catalogue offered little hope - only one entry in the most recent Artist Issue. One article mentioned a brisk under-the-table business in pirated performances. Well, there is also a nice-sized batch of Celibidache distributed by a local record importer who swears these are legitimate and not pirated recordings, although they are broadcast recordings and studio products.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
THE LEGACY OF THE JEWISH FARMER
description: '' JEWISH farmers? You've got to be kidding!'' said one man on hearing about a symposium commemorating 100 years of Jewish agriculture in New Jersey.

title: DANCE: JOFFREY II TROUPE IN PREMIERE OF 'DUETS'
description: The Joffrey II Dancers is an ever- changing company, for it seeks to train young dancers by allowing them to perform both new works and ballets from the standard repertory. And when they have gained experience, they graduate into the organization's parent company, the Joffrey Ballet.

title: SCHOOL SALE STIRS WOODMERE
description: I N the 1970's when the Woodmere

title: STEEL GAMBLE
description: The odds for success were long when 7,600 workers at the Weirton Steel Company in West Virginia took over the plant on Jan. 11.

title: THE SENATOR RAMPANT
description: William V. Shannon , who served as United States Ambassador to Ireland from 1977 to 1981, is a professor of history and journalism at Boston University. LOYALTIES

title: NEWARK MUSEUM REVIVES GROWTH PLANS
description: NEWARK A DRIVE to raise money to expand and renovate the Newark Museum - a plan that has lain dormant for 16 years - got under way last week, with state officials, business representatives and supporters of the arts calling the work a complement to the state's plans for urban economic rebirth and growth.

title: Experts Link Reagan To Ancient Irish King
description: Genealogists working with rare documents say they have traced President Reagan's ancestry back to Brian Boru, the 11th- century Irish King who died in the battle to end Viking rule in Ireland.

title: AN OHIO COMMISSION PUTS THE HEAT ON STATE'S UTILITIES
description: Over the opposition of most of the state's utilities, the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio late last year ordered electric and gas companies to provide a ''lifeline'' service for its poor customers. The agency said if a family's income was no more than 50 percent above the Federal poverty level, and 15 percent of its available cash was being spent on heat and light, service could not be disconnected regardless of how far the household fell behind on its bills.

description: FICTION

description: Kansas City On Its Own

title: FANNIE MAE IS MAKING IT EASIER TO GET A CO-OP LOAN
description: THE Federal National Mortgage Association is starting a major new program intended to make cooperative apartment ownership more acceptable to money lenders and thus more readily available to consumers.

title: IN ONE TOWN, SIX PICK SIX AND WIN FORTUNES
description: It was luck that made millionaires of Robert and Anna Rucker, residents of the St. Louis suburb of Florissant. But that's not the half of it.

title: A COLLECTION THAT BREATHES THE SPIRIT OF MODERNISM
description: HARTFORD

title: POLITICAL SIGNS AND 'GARBAGE'
description: A NEWLY adopted law in the Town of Islip is intended to ''regulate'' the use of signs employed in political contests. In this case ''regulate'' is a euphemism for ''restrict.''

title: NOBEL WINNER SOLVES LIFE
description: Ann Marie Cunningham writes frequently about science and technology. Her most recent book is ''Future Fire: Weapons for the Apocalypse,'' written with Mariana Fitzpatrick. A SLOT MACHINE, A BROKEN TEST TUBE

title: CONFLICT GROWS OVER PLAN TO INSTALL YONKERS CONTROLS
description: YONKERS OPPOSITION to a proposed state board that would control the finances of Yonkers grew last week at City Hall and in Albany. At the same time, Lieut. Governor Alfred B. DelBello reaffirmed his support for the idea.

title: 6 Women to Receive Awards ForRolesinCommunications
description: Six women in communications will receive the 1984 Matrix Awards on April 16 from New York Women in Communications for advancing the role of women in the industry.

title: MONTREAL WINS, 5-0, AND SWEEPS SERIES
description: Bob Gainey scored on a breakaway and set up Mario Tremblay's second goal 11 seconds tonight to spark the Montreal Canadiens to their first playoff series victory in four years with a 5-0 victory over the Boston Bruins.

title: COMPUTER LINKS STUDENT TO COLLEGE
description: TRENTON THOMAS A. EDISON COLLEGE has moved a step closer to becoming the country's first ''electronic college'' by enrolling a student who will attend classes exclusively by computer.

title: Limits of Feminism
description: To the Editor:

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER ; FLYING WITH THE CHILDREN AND SAVING
description: Time was, not too long ago, when a traveling family got substantial reductions on the airline fares charged for their children. Some reduced fares still exist, but they are generally not as sharply reduced as in the past and the age cutoff for children is generally lower.

title: A Milestone for the Mustang
description: MARILYN KING owns a 1964 Mustang

title: A REAGAN VICTORY IN SENATE ON CENTRAL AMERICA
description: The Reagan Administration got its emergency aid package for Central America through the Senate last week after two weeks of debate and a dozen Democratic attempts to reduce, delay or place conditions on it. The provision for $61.75 million in military funds to El Salvador and $21 million to rebels fighting the Nicaraguan Government may have an even rougher time in the Democratic-controlled House.

title: HOUSTON OFFICES REFLECT SLOWING OF THE ECONOMY
description: A year and a half ago, a developer here announced plans for a dazzling skyscraper, an 82- story office tower that would be the tallest building in the world outside of New York and Chicago.

title:
STAMPS;
NEW POLICY BEGINS WITH ISSUE FOR BULK MAIL
description: In a departure from the past that will be of special interest to collectors the United States has just issued a new 7.4-cent coil stamp in the Transportation Series that bears no reference to its use for bulk rate - the use for which it is intended.

title: F. H. Bradley 3d, Amanda Urmston To Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. William L. Urmston of Beckenham, Kent, England, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amanda Jane Urmston, to Floyd Henry Bradley 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bradley Jr. of Ocean Grove, N.J. The wedding is to be in June.

title: AFTER 30 YEARS, THEIR CLUB PACKED ITS BAGS AND LEFT
description: AFTER the news conference in Indiana it was official and yet I still could not believe that my hometown Colts had indeed moved to Indianapolis. Poor Mom and Dad, after 25 years of Colt season tickets and more than 30 years of rooting for the team, what would they do this fall with no pro football at Baltimore's Memorial Stadium?

title: Robin Dixon Muhlfeld Plans to Marry May 19
description: Announcement has been made by Ruth K. Muhlfeld of Chappaqua, N.Y., and Edward D. Muhlfeld of Riverside, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Robin Dixon Muhlfeld, to Mark Gordon Greenberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene H. Greenberg of Highland Park, Ill.

title: MORRIS: BAD NEWS AND GOOD
description: TRENTON ROBERT MORRIS, the conservative Republican candidate for the United States Senate, recently got some bad news and some good news.

title: TRILOGY ON A MAN'S LIFE IN LIVERPOOL
description: ''The Terence Davies Trilogy,'' written and directed by Terence Davies, is an extremely dour, guilt- ridden little film about growing up poor, Roman Catholic and neurotic in Liverpool.
