title: David Silberman, Miss Engers Wed
description: -1-18, 2 lines Claire Joan Engers, special assistant to the executive director of the Group Health Association in Washington, was married there yesterday to David Mark Silberman, a partner in the Washington law firm of Bredhoff & Kaiser and an adjunct professor of law at George Washington University's National Law Center. Rabbi Harold White performed the ceremony at the Women's National Democratic Club.

title: THE WASHINGTON PRIORITIES OF A PHILADEPHIA PRAGMATIST
description: The Senate caucus room was filled with several hundred unemployed Pennsylvanians wearing yellow buttons that proclaimed ''Jobs or Income.'' Rodney Bradley, age 10, walked solemnly to the front of the room and asked, ''Can you give my mother a decent job?'' Senator Arlen Specter replied calmly, ''That's something we're trying to do.'' The youngster was not placated. ''All we ever hear is promises,'' he said, and the audience cheered.

title: ISRAELI JETS BOMB SITES IN LEBANON
description: Israeli jets bombarded what were said to be Palestinian guerrilla bases in the mountains east of this battered capital today. The bombings were apparently in retaliation for a grenade attack last Monday by Palestinian gunmen in Jerusalem.

title: Article 108052 -- No Title
description: Managing the Nuclear Threat

title: AN ABUNDANCE OF PRE-COLUMBIAN ART
description: M ajor pre-Columbian art exhibitions are as scarce in New York these days as parades are plentiful. None has been held here since 1970 when ''Before Cortes: Sculpture of Middle America'' was presented at the Metropolitan Museum. This omission is being corrected Wednesday when a bounty of selections in stone, ceramic and metal from two of the nation's finest private collections goes on view in three New York establishments - Perls Gallery, 1016 Madison Avenue (at 77th Street), Andre Emmerich, 41 East 57th Street and Edward H. Merrin, 724 Fifth Avenue (at 56th Street).

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: EASTER EGG ART

title: SKILLFUL STANDOFF
description: Whether standards of performance have been raised in the past two decades is a debatable point. Most experts would agree that at their levels bidding has improved, because partnerships work harder and a lot of new theory is available.

title: BURRO BONANZA
description: When the National Park Service began to shoot the wild burros in Grand Canyon as an environmental menace, the Fund for Animals intervened and airlifted the last 577 out in 1980 and 1981. The survivors were put up for adoption as pets.

title: ACCORDS IN AFRICA WORRYING MOSCOW
description: The Soviet Union has made little secret of its irritation with the agreements reached over the last month between South Africa and the black-governed nations of Angola and Mozambique, but so far Moscow has given no indication of doing anything beyond watching in frustration from the sidelines.

title: HIS 'INTERVENTION': THE SINGLES BAR
description: W HEN the social history of the late 20th century comes to be written, it is possible that the name Alan N. Stillman will figure in it.

description: Jean Cascino was curious about Walter F. Mondale. The 22-year-old Bryn Mawr senior had seen him on television and found him wanting in ''pizzazz.''

title: FILMS SHOW ARMY LIFE TO RECRUITS
description: IN the movie ''Private Benjamin,'' Goldie

title:
SPORTS;
HOLTSVILLE PITCHER RIDING HIGH
description: T HE Cleveland Indians began their 1984 baseball season this month quite pleased with the progress made by a 24- year-old starting pitcher, Neal Heaton of Holtsville. If his seven innings of scoreless pitching in his last appearance during spring training is any indication of what the Indians might expect from him this year, it may not be too long before New York Met fans will be pointing to Neal Heaton and not Tom Seaver as the ''one who got away.''

title: MONDALE WINS WISCONSIN AFTER LOSS IN STATE PRIMARY
description: Walter F. Mondale won the Wisconsin caucuses today amid confusion among voters throughout the state.

title: Sports of The Times; RANGERS BLOCK ISLANDER PATH
description: ONE thing was apparent early in this series between the Islanders and the Rangers that will decide if the Islanders can move toward their fifth straight Stanley Cup: James Patrick's vacation after the Olympics had served him well.

title: Diana Donnelley, Herbert Smith 3d To Marry in June
description: Diana Kirk Donnelley, a daughter of Thomas Elliott Donnelley 2d of Lake Forest, Ill. and Cynthia Patterson of Chicago, is engaged to Herbert McKelden Smith 3d, the son of Dr. and Mrs. H. McKelden Smith Jr. of Staunton, Va., her parents have announced.

title: LIMITED FIRE CALLED BENEFICIAL
description: B URNING down the Island's first pine barrens preserve will do it a world of good, according to the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation.

title: Betsy Klein Engaged To William J. Couture
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jonas Klein of Rye, N.Y., and Georgetown, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter Betsy Lynn Klein to William J. Couture, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Couture of Wakefield, Mass., and Wolfeboro, N.H. The wedding is planned for August.

title: Honor for Snead
description: The veteran golfer Sam Snead renewed an old love affair this weekend when he returned to the Greater Greensboro Open tournament to serve as honorary professional.

title: A Correction
description: The current exhibition at the Bergen Museum of Art and Science, East Ridgewood and Farview Avenues, Paramus, is ''Science and Technology: Their Impact on Humanity.''

title: THE STICKY BUSINESS OF FINANCIAL REPORTING
description: The Wall Street Journal says its ''Heard on the Street'' column is intended ''to inform readers of market developments affecting the price of individual stocks or groups of stocks. The emphasis is on timeliness and on stocks with high interest for investors.''

title: MARIJUANA FEUD ON U.S. LAND
description: A state of jungle warfare exists in some Federal parklands where marijuana growers use booby traps, wild animals and threats of violence to protect their illegal crops, says the chairman of a House panel.

title: PANEL ENDORSES USE OF ESTROGEN
description: Patients sometimes have a hard time getting over the cure, too. In the case of estrogen therapy, however, a 14-member advisory board of the National Institutes of Health last week cautiously concluded that the risks were worth the benefits.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION ;
HIDDEN EXPENSES IN BONDING PLAN
description: TRYING to keep track of from where and for what the state is spending money can become confusing, to say the least. This is especially true when we deal with bonding.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: TAPPING THE BIRCH

title: PARTIES STUDY JACKSON ROLE IN CONVENTION
description: Because of the Rev. Jesse Jackson's strong showing in the Democratic Presidential primaries, leaders of both parties are putting renewed effort into analyzing his potential impact on the Democratic National Convention and the general election.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: I WALK AND READ

title: AS THE WATERS GET WARMER, SHAD AND SHAD ROE ARRIVE
description: THE arrival of spring also marks the arrival of shad and shad roe to the market. As the water gets warmer, the fish come to the rivers to spawn. At this point they are at their fattest and most succulent.

title: A LOOK AT HADDONFIELD OF OLD
description: HADDONFIELD THIS Camden County borough of historic homes will be more open to view than usual on May 8. For the first time, a portion of New Jersey is being included in the annual Philadelphia Open House spring tours.

title: SOMETHING FISHY ABOUT THE SNOW ON 85TH
description: To the Editor:

title: VIRGINIA TOPS IN PER CAPITA FEDERAL SPENDING
description: Military installations and Government offices helped Virginia place first in per capita Federal spending last year, the Census Bureau reports.

title: ROYAL WINNIPEG EXPANDS ITS RANGE
description: Diane Solway writes frequently about dance. By DIANE SOLWAY T he Royal Winnipeg Ballet, Canada's oldest classical company, has devoted most of its 46-year existence to an eclectic array of dance styles and programs designed to appeal to a broad audience. Portability, variety, originality - and saleability - governed the 26-member troupe's direction as well as ensured its mass appeal and longevity.

title: A NEW OLD IDEA
description: In the minds of most Americans, thatched roofs are for fairy-tale cottages. But in Britain and throughout Europe, this age-old method of roof construction has gained renewed popularity and respect because of its natural durability and old-fashioned beauty.

title: MONDALE ATTRACTS PITTSBURGH'S POLES
description: When the Polish immigrants started moving up Herron Hill from the flatlands along the Allegheny River in the 1890's, they joked that they were getting ''closer to God.'' Soon the area became known as Polish Hill and today it is still a stable, cohesive ethnic community.

title: ADVENTURES OF THE VERY GOOD-LOOKING
description: KNOCK WOOD

title: BRIDGEPORT FESTIVAL HONORS LUKAS FOSS
description: FOURTEEN years ago, Ruth Carlson Horn founded the Contemporary Composers Festival at the University of Bridgeport, and it continues to flourish today.

title: WOMAN LEARNS STORE CLERK IS SON GIVEN UP YEARS AGO
description: Twenty-six years after Pat McDermott gave up her infant son, his adoptive mother sought her out for medical records that might help treat his critical liver ailment.

title: WHY AUTHORS ARE SINGING THE MID-LIST BLUES
description: Evan Hunter's novel ''Lizzie,'' about Lizzie Borden, will be published next month. ILLIAM KENNEDY'S novel ''Ironweed'' was recently honored with a National Book Critics Circle Award. In accepting the award, Mr. Kennedy said, ''I am now as much awash in critical magnanimity as I was bathed two years ago in insolvent obscurity. The nature of this new status is extreme pleasure, but also part of it is residual bewilderment at the causes of the previous condition. I was once deeply resentful at the rejection of 'Ironweed' - it was rejected 13 times - but of course I am slowly coming out of that.''

title: THE COLTS' MOVE: FOR INDIANAPOLIS IT'S A BOON......BUT IN BALTIMORE, IT LEAVES A VOID IN THE HEARTS OF THE FANS
description: When Willie King came to work as a doorman today, he wore something new under his snappy red and gold uniform. As he whipped open the door for his tenants, Mr. King also opened the coat to reveal his new blue T-shirt. It said he loved the Indianapolis Colts.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Some passages from current and recently published books that we find particularly appealing.

title: PENNSYLVANIA STRUGGLE IN FINAL DAYS
description: From fish markets to steel plants, the Democratic Presidential candidates emphasized economic issues today as Pennsylvania Democrats prepared to decide a key primary battle on Tuesday.

title: U.S. Crews Row in San Diego
description: The presence of the United States men's and women's Olympic training teams added extra excitement to the 10th annual San Diego Crew Classic today on Mission Bay.

title: OF READERS' COMPLAINTS AND OTHER AIDS TO CRITICISM
description: Most people who write sharp letters to music critics are rational folk who want to dissent from what they consider misguided opinions and do so with a healthy vehemence. Perhaps the most common complaint takes the ''did we really attend the same performance?'' approach, expressing astonishment that any sane observer's reaction could possibly have differed from the letter writer's own. The time-hardened critic is in no position to resent such letters, realizing how often he himself has listened in dismay while friends or colleagues rhapsodized over a performance he found depressingly mediocre or inexcusably bad. Now and then, too, he has fairly floated into a lobby at intermission, elated at what he has heard, only to have to endure acidulous comments by people who plainly could not be attending the same performance.

title: HOW MANY MUNICIPALITIES FARE WITH THE CAP ON REVENUE SHARING T
description: -85 budget proposals were brought to light, a throng of lobbyists and representatives of special-interest groups descended upon Albany to fight for their share of the budget pie. Officials of the state's local governments were among them.

title: W.B.A. Crown Won by Sandoval
description: Undefeated Richie Sandoval captured the World Boxing Association bantamweight title today with a 15th- round knockout of Jeff Chandler.

title:
GARDENING;
GETTING THE SEASON STARTED
description: W ITH the arrival of spring, two concerns present themselves: How did my plants come through the winter, and what can I do to get my garden off to a good start? These are weighty concerns that cannot be covered in this space, but several important points can be touched upon.

title: McEnroe and Lendl Gain Final in Tokyo
description: John McEnroe beat Jimmy Connors, 4-6, 6-3, 6-4, today and will face Ivan Lendl in the final of the four-man, $250,000 Suntory Cup tennis event. Lendl turned back Yannick Noah, 6-2, 4-6, 6-2.

title: HEADLINERS
description: Karla's Revenge Did a former chief of the Army's double agents turn double agent himself? That chilling possibility came to light last week when the Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested a former Army counterintelligence officer, Richard Craig Smith, at Dulles International Airport on charges that he had sold information to the Kremlin about American efforts to infiltrate the Soviet spy agency, the K.G.B. The Government said that Mr. Smith, who had money problems after leaving the Army four years ago, passed secrets to a Soviet diplomat in Tokyo in 1982 and 1983. Among other concerns, Washington fears that Mr. Smith helped Moscow to discover the identity of the ''Royal Miter,'' a double agent helping the United States while working for the K.G.B. ''He hurt us,'' a Federal law-enforcement official said. A Soviet Embassy official in Tokyo called the charges ''a dirty provocation.''

title: ACCORD REACHED ON TIMES SQ. MART
description: After months of negotiation, the state's Urban Development Corporation has designated a development team that includes Trammell Crow, a Dallas real-estate entrepreneur, to build a $450 million merchandise mart near Times Square.

title: 1 BAT, 2 ANNIVERSARIES
description: AT a 10th anniversary ceremony in Atlanta today, Henry Aaron will try to re-enact his 715th home run that broke Babe Ruth's record. Al Downing will be pitching, as he was for the Los Angeles Dodgers on the night of April 8, 1974, and Tom House, then a Brave relief pitcher, who caught the historic homer in the bullpen, will be standing near the left-field fence that is now 10 feet deeper, at 385 feet, and 4 feet higher, at 10 feet, than it was then.

title: An A-Plant Shuts Itself Down
description: The Salem 2 nuclear-power plant automatically shut down Friday as workers repaired part of the reactor's instrumentation system, officials said today.

title: LEARNING TO READ AND WRITE
U.S. AND JAPAN REACH AGREEMENT ON NEW BEEF AND CITRUS QUOTAS
description: United States and Japanese negotiators reached agreement today on new export quotas that would allow American farmers to sell significantly more beef and citrus products to Japan.

title: GATEHOUSE LEADS TO A CONTROVERSY
description: I N the early years of this century

title: APPALACHIA'S PIONEER PAST
description: Early morning mist lifts slowly from the East Tennessee countryside, revealing a weathered rail fence that unites in giant cross-stitch patterns the green meadows, leafy woods, busy barnyards and assorted buildings of the Museum of Appalachia.

title: Question:
description: My husband and I would like to rent a camper or trailer in Los Angeles and tour the Southwest for several weeks. How do we find camper rental outfits? - O. A. Z., Verona, N.J.

title: LATEST TRENDS IN THE WORLD OF CAMERAS
description: Canon, perhaps influenced by the fact that it is the ''official 35mm camera of the Olympics,'' has introduced the new Canon Fl High Speed Motor Drive camera, a highly sophisticated professional camera with an integrated motor drive that is capable of speeds of up to 14 frames per second--making it the fastest camera made, based on a regular camera design. Motor drives always have been considered a necessity for sports and action photographers (and a great convenience for others), but when first introduced ''high-speed'' motors delivered five frames per second. With this new motorized unit, a standard 36-exposure roll of 35mm film will zip through the camera in a little more than 2 1/2 seconds!

title: COATS OF MANY COLORS
description: EFORE FALLING INTO sartorial disfavor nearly two decades ago, bold, brightly colored sports coats were spring and summer standards in any well-dressed man's wardrobe. Now, it seems, they are making a comeback of sorts. If history repeats itself, members of the high- technology generation will be the first to respark the trend. It was the same sort of highly spirited men, just returned from World War II, who popularized this look the first time around - young men who relished the idea of anything that was not regulation color, military cut.

title: More Sauna Lore
description: To the Editor:

title: BARBARA KING TO WED HENRY CLAY HUTH JR.
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Austin King of Riverside, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Barbara Huntington King to Henry Clay Huth Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Huth of Elkhart, Ind. A July wedding is planned.

title: RESOLVING DISPUTES IN A CO-OP
description: -op apartment

title: MAKING AN ISSUE OUT OF CHEMICAL WEAPONS
description: President Reagan's proposal last week for an international treaty on chemical weapons is the latest attempt at an agreement that has eluded diplomats since World War I. A plea to outlaw chemical warfare can do an Administration no harm in an election year, but it represents a thorny technical problem for negotiators.

title: Correction
description: In a review of C. L. R. James's ''Beyond a Boundary'' on March 25, the international cricket series played for ''The Ashes'' was incorrectly described. The matches are played between England and Australia, and no trophy changes hands.

title: SUNDAY, APRIL 8, 1984;  International
description: The mining of Nicaragua's harbors in recent months has been supervised by Americans working for the Central Intelligence Agency based on an intelligence ship off Nicaragua's Pacific coast, according to Reagan Administration officials and members of Congress. These sources say the mining operation marks the first time since the United States began supporting Nicaraguan rebels three years ago that Americans have been directly involved in military operations against Nicaragua. (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: DR. LOPEZ, ROYAL PHYSICIAN, WRONGLY EXECUTED
description: To the Editor:

title: THE COUNTY'S WATERS BECKON ANGLERS PURSUING EARLY START
description: OUTFITTED with poles, bait, lures and polarized sunglasses, an army of fishermen began their yearly seige on the rivers and streams in Westchester and Putnam Counties. In pursuing their prey, some anglers resort to carrying thermometers to determine a stream's temperature and surgical clamps to change fishing lures.

title: Doreen M. Shelley and Richard C. Sauerhaft Wed
description: Doreen Marie Shelley and Richard Craig Sauerhaft were married yesterday evening in the library of the Union League Club in New York. Acting Justice Ethel B. Danzig of New York State Supreme Court performed the ceremony, which was written by the couple.

title: SMAL TALK AT 'COCKTAIL' PARTY
description: PORT CHESTER PERHAPS there is a renewed interest in T. S. Eliot's works, what with the controversy wrought by an English play about his life (''Viv and Tim Tom'') and his posthumous Tony Award as librettist for a Broadway musical of all things - ''Cats'' is derived from Eliot's ''Old Possum's Book of Practical Cats.'' If so, a revival of Eliot's 1950 play, ''The Cocktail Party,'' won't serve the cause. Eliot, who also wrote the static play, ''Murder in the Cathedral,'' was not a man of the theater, concerned as he was about restoring poetry to it.

title: FOOD
description: A LOVE OF LAMB

title: MAKING DECISIONS ON A NURSING HOME
description: Marjorie Jones is to be applauded for her article. So often the press is quick to publicize the unpleasant, shocking or deplorable events that occur in nursing homes.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: T HE woman in the Yaphank Post Office was very nice and very helpful, as though she coped with such inquiries every day. I doubted that. ''You keep going down this road until you get to William Floyd,'' she said. ''But you don't take that. You turn left just before the expressway and follow that road all the way up, and - well, you'll see where the camp was.''

title: DanceAfrica Festival To Open in Brooklyn
description: Eight dance companies and soloists will perform April 28 and 29 in DanceAfrica '84, a festival of African- American dance now in its seventh season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: REAGAN ATTACK ON POLICY CRITICS PUTS NEW EDGE ON CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON E VER since the New Hampshire primary turned a relatively genteel race for the Democratic Presidential nomination into a street brawl, President Reagan has been doing as little as possible to divert attention from the Democratic candidates' slashes at each other. His campaigning for re-election has centered largely on the traditional appeals to business, ethnic and women's groups that marked his visit to New York City last week.

title: SEXUAL ABUSE: A CHILD'S FALSE EVIDENCE
description: To the Editor:

title: 5 Missing in Atlantic As U.S. Copter Crashes
description: A helicopter on a surveillance flight for a Trident missile launching plummeted into the Atlantic Ocean early today and sank.

title: Slow Gains in Quality of Air Reported in Atlantic States
description: A Federal study of automobile exhaust and manufacturing pollution shows that air quality ''slowly but surely'' improved in the Mid-Atlantic region in a three-year period ending in 1982.

title: Gambling Revenue And Education
description: I hasten to try to answer the elusive and illusory question propounded by Roger Keizerstein (''Gambling as an 'Aid' to Education? Don't Bet on It,'' Opinion Page, March 4) even though I am no longer ''in office,'' and not having an answer, really, but feeling quite comfortable with asking if Mr. Keizerstein, a self-appointed educational expert, does?

title: A September Wedding For Miriam Schreiber
description: Dr. and Mrs. Meyer Schreiber of South Orange, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miriam Sarah Schreiber, to Hyman Robert Fortunoff, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lester Fortunoff of Garden City, L.I. A September wedding is planned.

title: VIEWS OF SPORT ; THE JESUITS' RESPONSIBILITY AND BOSTON COLLEGE'S TROUBLE
description: GEORGETOWN is only the latest Jesuit college to excel at basketball. Over the years, teams representing schools like Marquette, Loyola of Chicago, the University of San Francisco and Holy Cross have dominated postseason tournaments. Jesuit colleges have turned out some of the greatest athletes to play the game. Think of Bill Russell and Bob Cousy.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN TO THE JON
description: L YNNE KRAMER, the owner of a busy law practice in Commack, will sometimes interrupt her work for ''an emergency hug'' from her 8-month-old son, Joshua. To do so, she walks two flights up to a nursery she had built above her law offices.

title: THE WORLD ; Lethal PoliticsIn India
description: Punjab, one of India's most advanced and prosperous states, is also one of its most troubled. Last week the national Government, which often has its hands full maintaining harmony among 700 million ethnically and religiously divided people, was particularly busy in the northern state, home to most of the country's 14 million Sikhs.

title: Colmar by Bike
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: '' UNCLE FLOYD'' fans probably don't know that the star of the show, seen nightly on the New Jersey Network stations, ended up on television because he couldn't get a job with MacDonald's or Burger King 10 years ago.

title: MEESE LAWYERS SEE 'POLITICAL' MANIPULATION
description: Two lawyers for Edwin Meese 3d have accused Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, Democrat of Ohio, of making ''inflammatory and political use of the media'' in an effort to defeat Mr. Meese's nomination for Attorney General.

title: THE ACTIVE LIFE OF BARBARA BUSH
description: ENID NEMY

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION ;
WHY I WANT A SISTER
description: ''BOY, you must be spoiled rotten.'' ''You have your own room?''

title: THE MAKER OF THE MEDIUM
description: D. W. GRIFFITH

title: 2 of 6 Who Fled Jail Held in Pennsylvania
description: A convicted murderer and another prison inmate were recaptured today, one day after they escaped along with four other prisoners from the maximum-security wing of a county lockup, the police said.

title: E.P.A. REVISES MILEAGE TESTS
description: The Environmental Protection Agency is trimming its gasoline mileage ratings to reflect more accurately what drivers can expect on the road.

title: NEUTRON BATTLE
description: News reports referred to it loosely as the neutron bomb. Actually it was a warhead designed for artillery shells and short-range missiles.

title: COURT IS BACK IN THE MIDDLE OF PRAYER DEBATE
description: With Congress still noisily debating the role of religion in the public schools, the Supreme Court last week said it would look into ''moment of silence'' laws. The Justices announced they would review the constitutionality of an Alabama law that permits a silent minute for prayer in the state's schools.

title: EXPLOITING SUMMITRY
description: President Reagan appealed to the Democrats for unity in the conduct of foreign policy in his latest address, which was a remarkable and revealing document.

title: JEWS OF ARGENTINA DEBATING THEIR ACTIONS UNDER MILITARY
description: An Israeli parliamentary delegation was here recently to seek information about some 1,500 Jews who were among the thousands of Argentines who disappeared during the eight years of military rule.

title: AMY GRANT: ON TOP BUT UNKNOWN
description: In the afterglow of Marshall

title: GUGGENHEIM FOUNDATION AWARDS FELLOWSHIPS TO 283
description: The John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation has awarded one- year fellowships to 283 scholars, artists and scientists who were chosen from 3,542 applicants in its 60th annual competition.

title: Nixon Library Is Approved
description: The City Council has unanimously approved the plans and environmental impact report permitting construction of former President Richard M. Nixon's $25 million library. The three-story library and museum is designed along the lines of ''Casa Pacifica,'' the Western White House in the Nixon Presidency.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
THE STEPFAMILY: NEW LIGHT IS SHED ON AN OLD NOTION
description: THE stepfamily is in the middle of an identity crisis. Ill- defined, misunderstood, unrecognized as the unique family form it is, and often feeling forced with disastrous results to masquerade as a nuclear family, the poor beleaguered stepfamily gets very little help from society.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
IT'S SPRING! LET'S CLEAN!
description: EVERY April, I say ''good riddance!'' to winter weather. I tend to cavort as I make my appointed rounds and I inhale greedily the special fragrance that spells springtime.

title: Bad Cold Endangers Crucial Tool for HartWILKES
description: A candidate without a voice is like a hitter without a bat, and Gary Hart was in danger of losing his voice today.

title: FLOTSAM OF THE HEART
description: Elizabeth Spencer's most recent novel is ''The Salt Line.'' THE LIGHTS OF EARTH

title: PAUL TAYLOR CREATES TWO KINDS OF RIDDLES
description: Any premiere by Paul Taylor is an event in the dance world - one could even say, in American cultural life. Few would dispute that among the performing arts in the last 40 years, the highest level of creativity has been most consistently displayed in dance. The point is not so much that there are more great choreographers in the 20th-century than, say, great opera composers (though that happens to be true), but that those at the top of the dance heap are, in fact, great.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: An article in The Times Magazine today discusses American involvement in Lebanon. It was printed before President Reagan formally ended the United States participation in the international force in Lebanon.

title: Article 107896 -- No Title
description: Airports

title: CAMEROON REPORTS 'VICTORY' OVER REBELS
description: President Paul Biya of Cameroon said today that loyalist troops had achieved a ''complete victory'' against rebels trying to topple his Government.

title: COURT GRANTS NEW TRIAL IN ABC SUIT
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit has granted a new trial to an Akron woman who lost a $40 million suit against the ABC News reporter Geraldo Rivera and a producer for invasion of privacy.

title: Laurie Taft Weds Artist
description: Laurie Wing Taft, a daughter of Sylvia Babcock Weaver of St. John, V.I., and Henry Waters Taft of Camden, Me., was married yesterday to Peter William Zaccagnino, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William L. Zaccagnino of Stamford, Conn. The Rev. Charles Smith performed the ceremony at the Congregational Church in New Canaan, Conn.

title: Mary Ellen Tiffany Is Married to John Eric Cross
description: -2-14 Mary Ellen Tiffany, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Tiffany of Pelham Manor, N.Y., was married yesterday to John Eric Cross, a son of Clifford H. Cross of Rennselaer, N.Y., and the late Mrs. Cross. The Rev. David Kendall performed the ceremony at the Huguenot Memorial Presbyterian Church in Pelham, N.Y.

title: THE EXPANDING EMPIRE OF DONALD TRUMP
description: 'DONALD! HEY, DONALD! DONALD!' THE men were yelling, eager to call him by name. A storm front of cigar smoke was gathering above the hotel ballroom, packed elbow-to-elbow for a breakfast-hour sports forum with a crowd that included some of New York's most wealthy, powerful and famous men.

title: A STORY ABOUT INCEST
description: As the Canadian film ''Just a Game'' begins, 13-year-old Catherine (Jennifer Grenier) is being picked up from her sailing lesson by her father, Andre (Raymond Cloutier). Catherine looks a little pouty about this, but we don't know why. Neither does her friend Maude (Julie Desjardins), who comments on what a dish Catherine's dad is. She cannot know that as soon as Catherine and her father drive away, he will berate her for having boyfriends, then take off his pants and once again try to force his daughter into the sort of activity that has made this family so troubled and so close.

title: TOPICS
description: -year-old daughter, accompanied by her friend, returned home breathless one frigid morning to pick up the flute she had forgotten by the front door. Because it was five minutes before the final school bell, I pulled on my coat and packed the girls and the dog into the car for the two-minute ride to school.

title: F.C. Wright Wed To Miss Horton
description: Robyne Horton and Frank C. Wright, officers of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company in New York, were married yesterday at the Manhattan home of Mr. and Mrs. Steven Kumble. The Rev. Leslie Smith, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: ATLANTIC CITY CASINOS REPORT THEIR PROFITS IN '83 NEARLY TRIPLED
description: Atlantic City's casino industry nearly tripled its net income last year, jumping from $56.9 million in 1982 to $168.7 million in 1983.

title:
GARDENING;
GETTING THE SEASON STARTED
description: W ITH the arrival of spring, two concerns present themselves: How did my plants come through the winter, and what can I do to get my garden off to a good start? These are weighty concerns that cannot be covered in this space, but several important points can be touched upon.

title: Offending the Puritans
description: To the Editor:

title: Policeman Collecting Salary 4 Years After Being Relieved
description: A police officer accused in the death by beating of a black insurance salesman has continued to collect his $28,340 yearly salary even though he has not worked since he was relieved of duty four years ago, police records show.

title: LEARNING TO READ AND WRITE
STRUGGLING STATE THE NEXT TO VOTE
description: Ronald Wamsley was tired but happy after working a double shift at the mill. He was making steel again.

title: GAUGING A COMPANY'S HEALTH
description: IN recent years Wall Street financial analysts and investment advisory services have trumpeted the value of cash flow data in making investment decisions. It is argued that cash flow information is more objective and has greater intuitive appeal than accounting-based earnings as a yardstick of corporate performance.

title: Ex Libris Syosset To the Editor:
description: I read your article on Syosset- Woodbury (March 4) with interest and enjoyment, but I was disappointed that it made no mention of the Syosset Public Library and the services we provide.

title: Laura D. Ringer Becomes a Bride
description: Laura D. Ringer, a genetic counselor at the Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn, was married in Manhattan yesterday to George M. Tannenbaum, a copywriter for Bloomingdale's in New York. Rabbi Neal Twersky performed the ceremony at Garvin's restaurant.

title: A Mother's Presence
description: As a mother of a son the same age as Samuel G. Freedman, I was deeply moved by his memoir about his mother (''A Mother's Presence,'' About Men, Feb. 26). Let me assure Mr. Freedman that mothers understand those feelings of a boy struggling to find his own identity - and what they can't understand, they forgive anyhow.

title: A MILESTONE FOR THE MUSTANG
description: which is as ancient a Mustang as anyone can have - but the car still looks good, a classic design in dark green and chrome, set off by whitewall tires and pizzazzy wheel covers.

title: THE POET WHO HAUNTS US STILL
description: Christopher Ricks, professor of English at Cambridge University, is author of ''Keats and Embarrassment.'' T. S. ELIOT

title: SYMPOSIUM SALUTES THE JEWISH FARMER
description: PRINCETON THEY settled on the land with nothing more than the clothes they could pack into a suitcase, some pots and pans and a tent to hold off the rain.

title: KOCH SEEKS BIGGER ROLE IN NAMING SCHOOL BOARD
description: For the third time since he took office, Mayor Koch is seeking to increase the number of appointments he makes to the semi-autonomous Board of Education.

title: LETHAL POLITICS IN INDIA
description: Israeli civilians and soldiers were attacked by Palestinian guerrillas last week and one consequence was a heightening of tension between Israel and Syria.

title: Baraka and the Establishment
description: To the Editor:

title: HILLS AND VALLEYS OF PROVENCE
description: Avignon immediately summons the image of its famous bridge and the imposing Papal Palace. Aix-en- Provence suggests a great music festival and Cezanne's ecstatic views of Mont-Sainte-Victoire. But the easily accessible lands that lie just to the north and east of these two towns, in upper Provence, are as yet little known to the traveler.

title: Christine B. Lalonde to Be the Bride Of Austin Chilton Hearst on July 1
description: Christine B. Lalonde, a daughter of Peggie Robinson Mularchuk of Hicksville, L.I., and the late Peter G. Mularchuk, has become engaged to Austin Chilton Hearst, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Randolph Hearst Jr. of New York and North Salem, N.Y., and a grandson of the late William Randolph Hearst. The wedding is to take place July 1.

title: COURTING DISASTER
description: John Pfeiffer is the author of ''The Creative Explosion'' and is working on a new edition of ''The Emergence of Man.'' NORMAL ACCIDENTS

title: FOR WOMEN, THE SYSTEM'S NOT SO COSY
description: JAPAN'S legendary lifetime employment system, often buttressed at big companies with a daunting array of welfare benefits, does not apply to the 22.6 million Japanese workers who happen to be women. Here, the labor force is segregated and, in keeping with Confucian tradition and Japanese custom, the men come first and the women follow behind.

title: A TINY, FLIGHTLESS BIRD STALLS U.S. STRATEGIC AIR COMMAND
description: A bird in the bush can be more powerful, it appears, than the United States Air Force's Strategic Air Command.

title: MAILBOX
description: An Issue of Race

title: DISPARITY FOUND IN SCHOOLS' USE OF COMPUTERS
description: PRINCETON ALTHOUGH New Jersey schools have one computer for every 60 students - somewhat above the national average of one for every 100 - not all children get to use one, according to a report by the Council on New Jersey Affairs of Princeton University.

title:
DINING OUT;
ITALIAN FARE IN THE MEADOWLANDS
description: -year-old restaurant in

title: Robin Steinberg, Physician, to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Milton S. Steinberg of Long Beach, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Dr. Robin Faith Steinberg to Dr. Phillip Michael Gendelman, a son of Rose Gendelman Rosen of Amherst, Mass., and the late Irving Gendelman of Milwaukee. The wedding is to be May 20.

title: Miss Fagan Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. John P. Fagan of Northbrook, Ill., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Jean Fagan, to John Richard Redmond Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Redmond of Llewellyn Park, West Orange, N.J., and Bondville, Vt.

title: Fodder Rushed to Tibet
description: An emergency shipment of 5,000 tons of animal feed is being rushed to Tibet to keep livestock from starving, the English-language China Daily reported today. The Ministry of Commerce announced the shipment after receiving an urgent request from the Tibet regional government, which said the fodder was needed because of a drought last year and snowstorms this winter.

title: Massachusetts Hopefuls Submit to 3d Live Quiz
description: Those who have trouble naming the 15 hazardous waste sites in Massachusetts designated for cleaning up under the a special Federal program have something in common with three Republican candidates for the Senate here.

title: ON THE RECORD; Falcon Crest Few of the world's females have had to endure more public curiosity than Ling-Ling, the abandoned, seduced and possibly pregnant panda in Washington's National Zoo. Recently she and her very occasional mate, Hsing-Hsing, were photographed
description: in flagrante ; last year a film of her first confinement led the evening news.

title: MONEY MANAGING WITH A DIFFERENCE
description: THE University of Pennsylvania campus

title: SUNDAY OBSERVER
description: Ode to the I.R.S.

title: ADOPTION METHODS SUFFERING
description: WHEN Dawn Pascal, a kindergartener from the Bronx, was born five years ago, she had many strikes against her. Not only was she born prematurely to an unwed teen- ager who abandoned her, but she had a club foot and a misplaced aorta. Brain damage was suspected. A team of doctors delivered a grim prognosis: a 50 percent chance for survival.

title: STATE REVIEWING MEDICAL LICENSES
description: TRENTON BASED on information from California and Virginia that nonphysicians have used falsified credentials from some Caribbean medical schools to obtain hospital positions or licenses to practice medicine, the state's Board of Medical Examiners is closely reviewing past and current licensure applications from graduates of those institutions.

title: Cherokees Vote to Allow Tennessee to Keep Land
description: The council of the Cherokee Nation, meeting on sacred Indian ground stolen by whites in the 1830's, voted unanimously today to let the State of Tennessee keep the land as a state park.

title: Dr. Wood Plans To Become Bride
description: Dr. Lucy Eaton Wood, a pediatrician, and John Hampton Arnold, who expects to graduate from the Harvard Medical School in June, plan to be married in September.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest.

title: COMING TO TERMS WITH SUCCESS
description: WITH 'TERMS OF ENDEARMENT,' JAMES BROOKS HAS FOUND A NICHE AMONG HOLLYWOOD'S ELITE.

title: FOREST SPRAYING PUT ON HOLD
description: When the Forest Service took to the air to spray herbicides on tens of thousands of Federal acres, environmentalists took offense. Last week, with flights in six Western states already virtually grounded by court rulings, the agency suspended aerial spraying on Federal land across the country.

title: MORE PROTECTION FOR SALMON AND BASS
description: CANADA'S Federal Government has moved to protect grievously diminished stocks of Atlantic salmon and the same may take place in the United States with similarly threatened populations of migratory East Coast striped bass.

title: GARCIA PACES RELAY VICTORY
description: Alberto Garcia admitted that he had lost many races by not using his head. At the Kearny-Adidas Interscholastic Relays today, however, the senior from Mount St. Michael's in the Bronx made a smart move on the backstretch of the final leg of the distance medley and turned it into a victory.

title: Bar to Pay Accident Victim
description: A tavern has agreed to pay a permanently injured woman, Janet B. Pattison, up to $9.5 million for serving liquor to Robert Jones, the driver of a car that hit her.

title: ; Private Life vs. Public
description: To the Editor:

title: DAZED REVELATIONS
description: Gilbert Millstein's most recent novel is ''God and Harvey Grosbeck.'' IN THE LAND OF NYX

title: Marvin Gaye's Father Tells of Fatal Shooting
description: Marvin Gaye's father admits he fatally shot the singer a week ago Sunday but insists, ''I didn't mean to do it,'' according to an interview published in the Sunday issue of The Los Angeles Herald Examiner.

title: GLENN WRIGHT
description: Glenn Wright, a shortstop who played for the Pittsburgh Pirates, the Brooklyn Dodgers and the Chicago White Sox from 1924 to 1935, died Friday of throat cancer at a nursing home.

title: CHAMPION OF THE NATION'S WILDFLOWER HERITAGE;
description: Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson, wife of the late President Johnson, is watching a dream come true: a wider use of wildflowers growing in public and private landscapes. ''This does not mean taking over the formal landscapes, but incorporating what the Lord put there,'' Mrs. Johnson said during a recent private visit to New York. She recounted with an infectious enthusiasm the details of her newest endeavor, which ''has always been the stuff of my heart.''

title: ; The Original Eliza
description: To the Editor:

title: TAKEOVERS TAKE OVER ANNUAL MEETINGS
description: WARNER COMMUNICATIONS has yet to pick a date or set an agenda for its annual spring stockholders' meeting. But the session - coming in the wake of management's successful defense against a takeover bid by Rupert Murdoch - promises to be one of the more vitriolic of the hundreds of such meetings just getting under way.

title: EMERGENCY PHONE NETWORK FOR SHUT-INS EXPANDED IN JERSEY
description: Elderly, handicapped and chronically ill people across the state will soon be able to summon emergency help to their homes with a touch of a button when hospitals serving 19 of New Jersey's 21 counties are connected to a special network, according to the head of the program.

title: Mary McGlynn Is a Bride
description: Mary Katherine McGlynn, a daughter of William Bernard McGlynn and the late Mrs. McGlynn of Hazelton, Pa., was married yesterday to Robert DuBois Hulme, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Norman Hulme of Swarthmore, Pa.

title: Lauda Winner In Africa
description: Niki Lauda of Austria and his Porsche teammate, Alain Prost of France, finished first and second today in the South African Grand Prix.

title: IN GUINEA AND NIGERIA, NEW REGIMES FACE OLD PROBLEMS
description: Three months ago, a group of Nigerian generals decided it was time to pronounce Africa's only experiment in Western-style democracy a failure. Within hours there were tanks in the streets and padlocks on the doors of political party headquarters.

title: Opera Highlights
description: The Center for Contemporary Opera, a group of 14 singers and a musical trio, will present a fully staged program tonight at 8 o'clock at the Universalist Church, Central Park West, at 76th Street.

title: U.S. AGENCIES TO GET DIRECT LINK TO CREDIT RECORDS
description: Federal agencies will be able to obtain direct 24- hour-a-day computer access to Americans' credit records under contracts now being negotiated by the General Services Administration.

title: AMERICA'S FAILURE IN LEBANON
description: They sent us to Beirut

title: Bonn Reports Neo-Nazi Rise And Leftist Terrorist Decline
description: The number of known neo-Nazis in the country rose slightly last year while extreme leftist groups such as the Red Army Faction lost members, the Interior Ministry said in an annual report Friday.

title: Miss Reney Plans To Marry in June
description: The engagement of Susanne Dolan Reney to K. McNeill Taylor Jr. has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Reney Jr. of Worcester and Dennis Port, Mass., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Taylor of Smithfield, N.C.

title: RAISING THE STAKES
description: For Walter F. Mondale, the decisive winner, the results of Tuesday's New York primary came as a soaking spring rain that reinvigorated his candidacy and knocked the bloom off Gary Hart's. Beyond that, the vote may have marked an important turning point in the tone and the substance of the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination. Just as New York brought out the most intense foreign policy debate so far, at times strident and highly personal, Pennsylvania, which holds its primary this Tuesday, is shaping up as a contest of the candidates' ideas on bread-and-butter issues. As the candidates swept into this economically distressed state after the political dogfight of New York, there was a noticeable change of tone. Mr. Mondale, who took with him his 45 percent victory and the nickname of Fightin' Fritz, arrived carrying a set of boxing gloves and bobbing to the theme song from the movie ''Rocky.'' But the first major event of the Pennsylvania campaign, a debate in Pittsburgh, was a gentlemanly affair, so polite and decorous that even the candidates took turns pitching cottonball questions. Aides to Mr. Mondale insisted he had not changed his attack strategy, which they credit with revitalizing his campaign. Mr. Mondale, they said, had only deferred to the wishes of the debate's sponsor, the League of Women voters, that the candidates avoid personal attacks. As proof, Mr. Mondale the next day was back to suggesting Mr. Hart was not ''surefooted'' and steady enough to be President.

title: AIR FORCE CRITICIZED FOR LEASING BUSINESS JETS
description: Gen. Thomas M. Ryan Jr., commander in chief of the Military Airlift Command, landed a sleek new jet Friday at Scott Air Force Base in Illinois, and taxied to a stop amid a crowd of well-wishers.

title: 2 WORKS TO REJOIN PROMETHEUS AFTER 50 YEARS
description: For nearly 50 years, the great golden statue of Prometheus has stood alone at the heart of Rockefeller Center, dominating the famed skating rink and flower-decked sunken plaza with his Olympian gift of fire to mankind.

title: No Headline
description: High-Energy Particles Used to Fight Cancer

title:
ON LONG ISLAND;
SUMMER RENTS LEVEL OFF IN THE HAMPTONS
description: When brokers who handle property in exclusive areas of the Hamptons advertise a listing for $200,000, they may not be talking about the sales price, but rather about the seasonal rental from Memorial Day through Labor Day.

title: REAGAN'S CALL FOR UNITY
description: It has become fashionable to decry the process and effects of summitry. This is short- sighted, because the summit meeting of the industrialized democracies in June in London will be critical. We believe that the trilateral nations - the United States, Britain and Japan - must undertake six urgent tasks. Some call for individual action; others require coordination. They should be regarded as a single package and undertaken simultaneously, not only to maximize their economic effects but also because it is politically unrealistic to expect individual governments to tackle some of these problems unless they feel confident that the costs of their own actions are likely to be more than compensated by the benefits they receive.

title: President Meets Hoyas WASHINGTON, April 7 (UPI) - In a ceremony in the White House
description: Rose Garden, President Reagan congratulated the Georgetown basketball team today for having won the national collegiate championship.

title: AS THE WATERS GET WARMER, SHAD AND SHAD ROSE ARRIVE
description: T HE arrival of spring also marks the arrival of shad and shad roe to the market. As the water gets warmer, the fish come to the rivers to spawn. At this point they are at their fattest and most succulent.

title: LAWYER ASKS WIDER COLLEGE DESEGREGATION
description: Public school desegregation has progressed in the 30 years since a historic Supreme Court decision was handed down, but many racial issues remain unsolved in public colleges and universities, legal experts said this week.

title: Broadcast TV
description: If any one of the Gilbert and Sullivan operettas is pure gold all the way through, it is ''The Gondoliers.'' Well, maybe ''Patience'' and ''Princess Ida'' and ''Yeomen of the Guard'' can join the list.

description: CHERYL BLACKERBY is the travel editor of The Palm Beach Post.

title: HANOI ACCUSES CHINESE OF INCURSION
description: Vietnam said today that up to 2,000 Chinese troops had crossed into its territory in two locations and were locked in combat with defending Vietnamese forces.

title: Ueberroth Mission
description: Peter V. Ueberroth, the head of the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee, said he might visit Eastern Europe for discussions to assure Soviet participation in the Olympic Games.

title: JAPAN'S MISTRUST OF THE FEMININE MYSTIQUE
description: Jobs in Japan are classified and advertised as being of two types, those for men and those for women. More than 70 percent of Japanese companies hire only male graduates of four-year colleges. And Japan's widely admired practice of lifetime employment does not apply to women.

title: WEEK IN BUSINESS
description: RCA yielded to indifferent consumers and a $575 million loss and announced it would stop making its videodisk players. The players, introduced three years ago amid hoopla suggesting that videodisk libraries would soon be as extensive as record libraries, were soon overtaken by video cassette recorders, which were more versatile and offered recording as well as playback capabilities. RCA had continued to produce the players long after anemic sales figures convinced analysts and other manufacturers that the players would never catch on. But RCA's chairman, Thornton F. Bradshaw, said that he came to that unpleasant conclusion only recently. RCA will take a $94.5 million after-tax write-off in the first quarter to reflect the decision.

title: FOREIGN BORN REPORTED ON RISE
description: -born population registered what county officials are calling a significant increase during the last decade while the county as a whole was losing residents. That increase, these officials say, could have an important influence on future planning.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: April 8, 1984Fiction

title: 'GEORGE WASHINGTON' BREATHES LIFE INTO AN ICON
description: Of the many heroes celebrated in American history books, perhaps the most inaccessible for the popular imagination has been George Washington, the towering but curiously distant figure who is, after all, the father of the country. During the 19th century, Washington was embalmed by protective admirers in the unreality of fabricated myths that, among other things, had him refusing to lie about chopping down cherry trees. The nation's first President was transformed into an icon, a national symbol whose somewhat forbidding portrait would adorn the dollar bill. Lacking the charisma or ideological passions of a John Adams or a Thomas Jefferson, Washington's historical image gradually became obscured by legends. It is only in the past couple of decades that serious efforts have been made to capture the flesh-and-blood man behind the image. That process is continuing with ''George Washington,'' an eight-hour mini-series that begins on CBS this evening, from 8 to 11, will continue on Tuesday and then conclude on Wednesday night.

title: BEAR HUNT SCORES UPSET IN GOTHAM
description: After the way the Gotham Stakes was run at Aqueduct yesterday, the talk of the track was how Devil's Bag might have won by a huge margin and set a record, had he been in the race. In his absence, an undistinguished colt named Bear Hunt led every step of the way to win the $182,400 race by 4 3/4 lengths.

title: FREE PROGRAM FOR FAMILIES OF MENTALLY ILL
description: FOR the estimated 800 to 1,000 Westchester families who have a chronic mentally ill member living with them, home life ''can be like living with the living dead,'' as one mother said.

title: KNICKS ARE 3 SHORT OF 48-VICTORY GOAL
description: When Hubie Brown talks about basketball with the Knicks, his approach is the same as when he speaks before corporate executives or sales people: He tries to motivate by setting goals.

title: AMERICAN LEAGUE ; ORIOLES ROUTED BY TWINS, 13-4
description: Tim Laudner and Tim Teufel hit two- run home runs, and Lenny Faedo hit a bases-empty homer and drove in three runs to lead the Minnesota Twins to a 13-4 rout of the Baltimore Orioles today.

title: MOTHER MURDERED A STRANGER
description: Roy Hoffman's novel, ''Almost Family,'' won the 1983 Lillian Smith Award for fiction. ASTONISHMENT OF HEART

title: PUCCINI'S MUSICAL MASTERY GLOWS IN A FORGOTTEN MASS
description: Giacomo Puccini came from a long line of church musicians who also composed operas on the side. He, too, started out as a church musician, but in his early 20's he turned exclusively to writing for the stage. Before that he had turned out a few sacred compositions, which after one or two performances in his home town of Lucca were forgotten. One of them was a mass, given its premiere in 1880, when Puccini was 22. It was resurrected in 1951 by an American priest, Father Dante del Fiorentino, who was doing research for a book on the composer, ''Immortal Bohemian.'' He had it edited under the title Messa di Gloria, and it had its first rehearing in 1952 in Chicago under the direction of Alfredo Antonini. The work turns up now and then in choral programs. One recording was issued here by RCA about 10 years ago but was subsequently withdrawn. Now there is a new one. It is performed by the Ambrosian Singers and Philharmonia Orchestra under the direction of Claudio Scimone, with Jose Carreras, tenor, and Hermann Prey, baritone, as soloists (Erato NUM 75090).

title: CENTER HELPS TREAT PEOPLE IN ADOPTIONS
description: -year-old Rachel Stout would cry for days, even have temper tantrums, at just a brief glimpse of a stranger. She would find comfort in eating, and, if she found nothing to eat, would pretend to stuff food in her mouth. She had been, her adoptive parents believed, an abused child.

title: The Long Road To Success at City University
description: When the City University of New York opened wide its doors to high school graduates in 1970, how many just got a foot in and how many made it all the way through? Until the release of a new study last week, the conventional wisdom was that only a small proportion of open-admissions students had managed to earn degrees at the four-year colleges. The report produced by three City University staff members demonstrated, however, that almost half those accepted to the four-year colleges under open admissions had indeed graduated, although it took them longer than other students.

title: FROM VIENNA, WITH THAT SPECIAL OPERETTA FEELING
description: Richard Traubner is the author of ''Operetta: A Theatrical History,'' published by Doubleday.

title: ;  Making Decisions On a Nursing Home
description: It is with a mixture of sympathy and anguish that I read Marjorie Jones's article, ''When It's Time for a Nursing Home'' (Opinion Page, March 11). Sympathy because I can empathize with the deep sense of agony and guilt that children go through when faced with the decision of placing an elderly parent in a nursing home. And anguish because, like too many other people in similar circumstances, Marjorie Jones may have overlooked a viable alternative for her mother. This alternative is home health care.

title: BRAZIL WATCHES ITS CONGRESS COME SLOWLY TO LIFE
description: The story is still told here of the newcomer who visited Three Powers Square in the empty heart of this sprawling capital, and assumed it was a tribute to the army, the navy and the air force.

title:
GARDENING;
GETTING THE SEASON STARTED
description: WITH the arrival of spring, two concerns present themselves: How did my plants come through the winter, and what can I do to get my garden off to a good start? These are weighty concerns that cannot be covered in this space, but several important points can be touched upon.

title:
ART;
ARTISTS AT WORK WITH PLAYWRIGHTS
description: A N artist turning to theatrical design has a chance to create a special atmosphere that will reinforce the playwright's psychological intentions. Such a challenge is bound to fire the imagination, and the visual results certainly have rich potential for examination as an independent exhibition topic.

title: Schlegel Beats Durin For L.I. Bowling Title
description: Ernie Schlegel of Vancouver, Wash., a nonwinner on the Professional Bowlers Association tour since 1980 when he captured his only two tournaments, defeated Mike Durbin, 237- 214, to win the Long Island Open today at Garden City Bowl.

description: Senator Alan Cranston of California says the Democrats who remained in the Presidential race after he and others dropped out are paying more attention to the peace issue that he made a keystone of his campaign.

description: -WHITE cat curled around Pegeen Fitzgerald's neck, and a dozen more mewed for attention at her feet as she sat on a rug at her recently constructed cat shelter in Falls Village.

ANYPLACE, U.S.A.? IT'S LISTED SOMEWHERE IN THE 996 PAGES
description: For people who love lists, the Government has produced the book to end all books, 996 pages full of information on just about any place in the United States.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: BY HISTORICAL and meteorological standards, the storm that buffeted New Jersey's coast on March 29 was a mild one. State environmental officials expected worse.

title: SUFFOLK TOWN EYE TWO NEW COUNTIES
description: T HE terms ''secession'' and ''home rule'' are being spoken openly in several parts of Suffolk County, as communities consider bucking long odds and a statewide trend by trying to form their own villages and counties. At the heart of these movements are economic concerns and the belief that existing governments cannot deal with issues - especially land- use issues - that are vital to residents in some areas.

title: Correction
description: An article in The Week in Review of March 4 incorrectly identified the court that upheld in 1976 a law authorizing a moment of silence in Massachusetts schools. The ruling was made by a three-judge panel in United States District Court.

title: THE ISLAND ARTS
description: The Concert Theater agrees with Rea Jacobs, director of cultural arts for the United Jewish Y's of Long Island (Letters to the Editor), that a performing arts focal point is needed. We feel, however, that it already exists. Now in its third season, the award-winning Concert Theater, on Long Island University's C. W. Post campus, has become a vital cultural asset to the Long Island community.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
THE AGONY OF A DISPLACED HOMEMAKER
description: KATHERINE carefully laid out the navy gabardine suit on the bed. It was a trifle worn, but a good choice for a job interview, she thought. Very businesslike.

title: 22 SENATORS ASK SHULTZ'S HELP ON EAST TIMOR
description: A group of 22 Democratic and Republican Senators has asked Secretary of State George P. Shultz to seek access for international relief agencies to the strife- ridden regions of East Timor in Indonesia.

title: FOR SANTORINI VISITORS, RESTORED HOUSES
description: You poke your head in the door of the church hall. The sights and sounds intoxicate. A 50-foot-long table is crowded with families in their Sunday best, digging into plates piled high with lamb and potatoes. Men and women glide through the intricacies of a traditional dance, spurred by pulsating violin and bouzouki. You're about to retreat when a dish is thrust into your hands and a place made for you at the table. A grizzled old- timer raises his glass, you down a potent local wine and then you're on your own - to stay or leave, to watch or dance.

title: MUSICALS MOVE AHEAD WHILE LOOKING BACK
description: First there was ''Saturday Night Fever.'' Then came ''Flashdance'' and ''Staying Alive,'' the awful sequel to ''Saturday Night Fever.'' Now, with ''Footloose,'' a film with one foot in the historic past and one in the 80's, it does seem at last as if American musical films are getting a new look.

title: 'STEM OF A BRIAR' IS THORNY, INDEED
description: WHAT is a lawyer? Probing the legal profession is just one of the concerns of Beddow Hatch in her first full-length play at Stamford's Hartman Theater, ''Stem of a Briar.'' The title refers to the third definition of a lawyer - ''a bramble, or the thorny stem of a briar'' - in some dictionaries.

title: ANTI-POLLUTION EFFORTS LAG IN SMOGGY PRAGUE
description: When the sun breaks through, Prague is a crystalline gem of a city. But during the long winter, a noxious blanket of smog clings to its ancient buildings and churches. Children are sent to the mountains for ''schools in nature'' where they can breathe clean air.

title: John A. Luke Jr., Executive, to Wed Kathleen Sue Allen, Lawyer, in June
description: Mrs. Douglas Russell McRae and Dr. John Willison Allen, both of Sacramento, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathleen Sue Allen, to John Anderson Luke Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Luke of Bedford, N.Y., and West Chop, Mass.

title: ACCESS IS ISSUE AT COASTAL RESERVE
description: THE question of whether the Bluff Point coastal reserve in Groton should remain in its unspoiled natural state or be developed enough to accommodate a public beach has been debated off and on for a decade.

description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Paul O. Lanier of Richmond of the engagement of their daughter, Melinda Ann Lanier, to Steven A. Daub, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert W. Daub of Watchung, N.J.

description: MINEOLA, L.I. WHEN William J. Catacosinos was first asked to become chairman of the troubled Long Island Lighting Company, he ducked the proposal and took a month-long trip to the Far East - alone.

title: Russel A. Herz Married To Dr. Carol B. Schreck
description: Dr. Carol B. Schreck, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Schreck of Pittsfield, Mass., was married there yesterday to Russel A. Herz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Herz of New York.

title: MIDTOWN TOWER
description: A 57-story residential tower is being planned for a midblock site between 40th and 41st Streets and Second and Third Avenues, where a New York Daily News truck garage now stands.

title: 'ROGUE OF PARIS,' TALE OF POET IN 1400'S
description: A FEW months ago, Theater Three in Port Jefferson presented a sterling production of A. R. Gurney Jr.'s ''The Dining Room.'' This comedy-drama is a series of vignettes of the meals and deals that have taken place over generations in a formal dining room. It was the first of Mr. Gurney's plays to win him wide recognition as a writer and chronicler of life among a specific upper economic class of Americans.

title: CONGRESSMAN IS CONVICTED
description: Representative George Hansen didn't take the stand during his two- week trial on charges of filing false financial disclosure statements, but he had a lot to say following his conviction last week. ''I'm a bit bloody but unbowed,'' the Idaho Republican asserted.

title: THE ELUSIVE BOOM IN PRODUCTIVITY
description: ''THE long-awaited boom in productivity growth is here,'' proclaimed a recent report by Michael J. Drury, senior economist at A. Gary Shilling & Company, an economic consulting group based on Wall Street.

title: American Quits Vienna Opera
description: The American director of the Vienna State Opera said Friday that he had resigned because of attacks ''on my artistic integrity as well as on my person.''

title: THE REGION ; Pricey Future forPolice Building
description: The landlord of last resort last week found a buyer for a property that might be considered first-rate. Mayor Koch announced that New York City had agreed to sell the old police headquarters at 240 Centre Street to a developer who would turn the 75-year-old baroque building into an apartment house.

title: MANAGING THE NUCLEAR THREAT
TRAVEL ADVISORY ; A CRUISE TO ODESSA AND KIEV, A FESTIVAL IN TEXAS
description: On the Danube Bound for Heart Of the Ukraine

title: THE CONCIERGE, THEN AND NOW
description: Retracing the movements of his long- lost daughter, Prince Rodolphe, the hero of Eug ene Sue's 19th-century novel, ''Les Myst eres de Paris,'' makes his way to a certain doorkeeper's lodgings in the Marais district. In the guise of a commoner and with a detective's guile, the prince ingratiates himself with the doorkeeper couple by calling them concierges, a step up in gentility from doorkeepers. So vividly did Sue embroider the portrait of Anastasie and Alfred Pipelet in his popular serialized novel that their name entered the French language as a slang expression for concierge.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
A NAIVE SOLUTION RIFE WITH PROBLEMS
description: THE proposed dollarization of Israel's economy has given rise to great interest - and even greater confusion - on the part of the Israeli public. In view of an annual inflation rate currently exceeding 300 percent, and a huge balance-of-payments deficit, dollarization was initially presented as a universal cure for the country's economic ills - a way to avoid the hardships that normally accompany recovery.

title: Miss Nordwall Becomes Bride
description: The marriage of Deborah Gail Nordwall, an associate in the public finance department at Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb, to David Jenkin Steward Flaschen, a marketing manager for the International Business Machines Corporation in Princeton, N.J., took place yesterday. The Rev. Richard Leonard, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at the Belle Epoque in Manhattan.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN DUBLIN
description: There's a lazy old song that suggests Dublin can be heaven, with coffee at 11, and a walk in Stephen's Green. The coffee almost certainly has to be in Bewley's on Grafton Street or Westmoreland Street, where you're likely to share it with all other forms of human life in the Irish capital. But while the Green is a strolling place beloved of Dubliners it is by no means the only oasis. The arch at the front of Trinity College is a doorway into another age. A cobblestone courtyard, a library that contains the enchanting Book of Kells (the illuminated manuscript, believed to have been written in the eighth century, of the Latin Gospels), the thud of tennis and cricket balls all combine to inspire a feeling that the real world is surely not just over the walls. And there's Merrion Square, a small park that is a celebration at this time of year of tulips and cherry blossoms. Stand in the center of it, with the tall red brick houses dominating the skyline beyond, and you are in the most pristine setting that remains of Georgian Dublin.

title:
DINING OUT;

description: IT seems as though Nino's has always occupied the old white farmhouse in Bedford Village, and it may as well have; its kitchen has

description: The New York City Department of Health cited 18 food establishments last week for violating the health code.

description: A WEDDING, a week in Puerto Rico and a cataract operation are being auctioned at the Hudson River Museum. So are a four- hour consultation with an interior decorator and a catered party aboard a 38-foot sailboat in Mamaroneck.

title: LET THERE BE MUSIC -BUT DON'T FORGET THE FEE
description: T he concert music business is a marriage between talent and audiences who want to enjoy that talent. Such are the complications of this musical courtship and matrimony, however, that only a matchmaker - the musical manager - can bring both sides together. Performers, in other words, need to perform. Managers find them places to do it.

title: WHAT'S BLUE AND BROWN AND PLAID AND GONE?
description: A T last I have the problem licked. The idea is so simple and logical, it is a wonder I haven't thought of it sooner: Wash all the socks together, put all of them in the dryer together, and all of them should come out together. No more missing, mismatched socks. Could life be so simple?

title: Roberta E. Zlokower Marries Les A. Levinowitz
description: Roberta Elaine Zlokower, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Weinrebe of Framingham, Mass., and Braintree Hills, Vt., was married yesterday to Les Alan Levinowitz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Phillip Levinowitz of Delray Beach, Fla. Rabbi Roy Rosenberg performed the ceremony at the chapel of the Church Center for the United Nations.

title: U.S. SAID TO DRAW LATIN TROOPS PLAN

title: STATE WEIGHS ITS ROLE IN METRO-NORTH
description: BARELY a year after turning the operation of the New Haven commuter rail line over to New York's Metropolitan Transportation Authority, Connecticut officials say they are reconsidering the arrangement.

description: Lauren Allison Williams, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David O. Williams of Riverside, Conn., was married yesterday to Paul Bijan Ghaffari, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Parviz Ghaffari of Los Angeles. The Rev. George Pera and the Rev. Richard Stearns officiated at the ceremony in the First Presbyterian Church in Greenwich, Conn.
