title: HEADLINERS
description: New Evidence Leonard Peltier has said all along that he was framed by the Government for the murder of two F.B.I. agents near Wounded Knee, S.D., in 1975. The Indian militant leader, who is serving two consecutive life terms, may get another chance to try to prove it.

title: REPORT ON DRUG FIGHT ISSUED
description: The Reagan Administration's organized crime drug enforcement group opened 535 cases against drug organizations and indicted 1,841 people in its first 14 months, a report says.

title: SHORT END OF THE INCOME SCALE
description: The tax and budget cuts that Congress enacted in the early days of the Reagan Administration were intended to make more money available for all Americans, their sponsors said. It hasn't quite worked out that way for poor households, the Congressional Budget Office reported last week.

title: SATELLITE PLACED IN ORBIT AS CREW FACES MAJOR TEST
description: The crewmen of the space shuttle Challenger today put into orbit the largest satellite ever deployed by the winged spacecraft. They then began closing in on an ailing solar observatory in preparation for a historic repair mission of unusual skill and daring.

title: ELIZABETH JOSLIN WILL BE A BRIDE
description: Elizabeth Dandridge Joslin, a daughter of the late Capt. Royal K. Joslin, U.S.N., retired, and the late Mrs. Joslin, of Newport, R.I., and Douglas Orr Logan, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Logan Jr. of Guilford, Conn., plan to be married next August. The engagement has been announced by R. DuBose Joslin of Philadelphia, brother of the future bride.

title: METS WIN 3-2 - GOODEN TRIUMPHS
description: Dwight Gooden made a somewhat brief but winning debut in the big leagues at the age of 19 tonight while the Mets were defeating the Houston Astros, 3-2, for their third straight victory.

title:
CAMERA;
MAKING GOOD PRINTS FROM POOR NEGATIVES
description: Jeff Wignall is co-author of ''Darkroom Expression,'' to be published soon by Eastman Kodak Books.

title: TORONTO INFANT DEATH STIRS CONCERN
description: Some officials, civil-rights advocates and medical authorities here say they are increasingly concerned that a royal commission investigating the deaths of 36 infants at a local hospital may be doing more harm than good.

title: 16 Are Injured as Car Crashes Into Memphis Concertgoers
description: A 75-year-old woman lost control of her car and 16 people were injured, two seriously, when the car careened into a crowd outside a hotel, the police said.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
A BITTER BUT NECESSARY CURE FOR INFLATION
description: YORAM ARIDOR was forced to

title: PROBLEM FOR ISRAELIS: PULL BACK IN LEBANON?
description: Western intelligence officials say the withdrawal of Israeli troops from Lebanon, or even a withdrawal part of the way back from the present positions on the Awali River, could pose major military and economic problems for Israel. Discussion of such a move intensified Thursday, when the opposition leader, Shimon Peres, said a Labor government would pull Israeli forces out of Lebanon.

title: NETS WIN, 121-98, AFTER A 24-8 SPURT
description: For a change, Coach Stan Albeck of the New Jersey Nets could sit back and watch during the fourth quarter of one of his team's games.

title: Olympic Furor
description: The executive board of the United States Olympic Committee has censured Julian K. Roosevelt, one of the two United States representatives to the International Olympic Committee, for refusal to support recent U.S.O.C. positions. Col. Don F. Miller , the U.S.O.C.'s executive director, said the resolution to censure Roosevelt was approved at a meeting of the board in Colorado Springs Friday night. Miller said a letter would be sent notifying the international committee of the U.S.O.C.'s ''disassociation'' with Roosevelt and asking the I.O.C. to find a suitable replacement.

title: SOVIET FIGHTER PILOTS SAY THEY WILL SHOOT DOWN AIR INTRUDERS
description: The newspaper Trud quoted Soviet fighter pilots today as saying that Western planes conducting reconnaissance flights in the Arctic would be shot down if they intruded into Soviet airspace.

title: A GREEK VILLA OF ONE'S OWN
description: During a three-year assignment in Greece in the mid-70's, our family spent several vacations renting houses on Aegean Islands. In the years since I have often joked that if a genie popped out of a bottle and asked me how I wanted to spend a week, anywhere in the world, I would wish for a villa on the island of Skiathos, a little green gem less than an hour's flight north of Athens.

title: THE DANCE: 'SILK ROAD,' BY MISS YUNG
description: Eleanor S. Yung has an unusual gift for the smooth synthesis of different dance forms. American modern and Chinese dance blend in many of her works into theater that has the urgency of the first and the gestural delicacy of the second, as they did in a program by Miss Yung's Asian American Dance Theater on Wednesday at Theater of the Riverside Church.

title: 'MOISTURE SEEKERS' AID THOSE WITH RARE AFFLICTION
description: B ECAUSE her body does not produce enough saliva or tears, Elaine Harris must carry her own.

title: O BAEK RYONG
description: O Baek Ryong, a member of the Central Committee of the North Korean Communist Party, died Friday after a long illness, North Korea's official press agency reported.

title: RENT TAX ON A CO-OP OFFICE
description: I own a co-op apartment that is used for a medical office. Could you tell me if I have to pay the commercial rent tax and how it is computed on a co- op office compared to a rental? . . . J. E. C. N., Manhattan

title: GETAWAY BAGS
description: Now that April is here, the travel season is not far away. For those whose idea of travel is long weekends at the beach, a lightweight but capacious leather tote to sling over the shoulder is both fashionable and practical.

title: Bolivia Announces Wide Austerity Plan
description: President Hernan Siles Zuazo of Bolivia has announced a package of emergency economic measures including devaluations, increases in prices and public utility rates and a reduction in the fiscal deficit.

title:
GARDENING;
GETTING THE SEASON STARTED
description: WITH the arrival of spring, two concerns present themselves: How did my plants come through the winter, and what can I do to get my garden off to a good start? These are weighty concerns that cannot be covered in this space, but several important points can be touched upon.

title: AIRPORT WRESTLING WITH FLIGHT VOLUME
description: A WHITE and green Air Florida jet bound for Washington, Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Miami was barreling out of the Westchester County Airport the other evening on one of the last flights of the day, and in the tiny airport passenger terminal, now nearly empty, an employee was musing on how cramped the terminal was becoming.

title: EASY APPROVAL FORECAST FOR BUDGET
description: HARTFORD LAST year the General Assembly failed to agree on a state budget and the tax increases to support it by the legislature's adjournment deadline. Lawmakers had to return for a contentious special session to put Connecticut's fiscal house in order.

title: ONE WASHINGTON'S CHOICE
description: To the Editor:

title: 4 Die in Baltimore Fire; 2d Fatal Blaze in 2 Days
description: Four children died in an early-morning house fire today, less than 24 hours after another blaze in Baltimore killed five people, officials said.

title: ON THE RECORD; Pop Quiz
description: Public ignorance about rudimentary political facts is the stuff of a thousand editorial sermons. But a candidate for the United States Senate, you might think, would know who is Prime Minister of Israel, the size of the Pentagon budget, where U.S. cruise missiles are deployed in Europe and which side Washington backs in El Salvador and Nicaragua.

title: Bombing in South Africa
description: A bomb exploded Friday in an unoccupied information office of Transkei, one of the so-called tribal homelands set up by South Africa, starting a fire that destroyed the one- story building.

title: JOHNS HOPKINS USES 2 BARRED STARS
description: The two lacrosse players who were ruled ineligible to play for Johns Hopkins earlier this season played yesterday for the Blue Jays against North Carolina. But the two players from the University of Maryland who were also ruled ineligible remained on the sidelines in the Terrapins' game against Virginia.

title: FRANK CHURCH OF IDAHO, WHO SERVED IN THE SENATE FOR 24 YEARS, DIES AT 59
description: Frank Church of Idaho, a member of the Senate for 24 years and for a time the chairman of its Foreign Relations Committee, died today at his home in suburban Bethesda, Md. He was 59 years old and had been suffering from pancreatic cancer.

title: ASPIRING CABBIES TAKE COURSE BEFORE TAKING WHEEL
description: The passenger could not make up his mind. ''Take me to First and 74th,'' he told the taxi driver. A few minutes later, he said, ''No, make that Second and 24th.'' When he changed his mind again, the driver shook his head and said, ''I'm sorry, but you'll have to get out and take another car.''

title: Film
description: Perhaps the subject doesn't seem conducive to parody, or perhaps it's already amusing enough on its own. Whatever the reason, the rock-and-roll satire ''This Is Spinal Tap'' remains the best-kept movie secret in town, and the funniest film around.

title: THEATER: 'ISLE,' BY JOYCE CAROL OATES
description: It is surprising that a novelist of Joyce Carol Oates's stature could have written such a cliche-ridden drama as ''Presque Isle.'' Her brief new play at the Theater of the Open Eye deals with a callous mother and her negligent 15-year-old daughter.

title: ONE CONCERT IS FOR CHILDREN, AND ONE PUTS THEM CENTER STAGE
description: MUSIC for or with the young people of Westchester is much in evidence this week, starting today at 3 P.M. when the 60-member, all-professional Local 398 Symphony gives another of its free children's concerts at the Peekskill High School. The program, narrated and conducted by Earl Groner, certainly covers the orchestral waterfront, from a Verdi overture to the John Williams score for ''E.T.,'' from Sibelius's ''Finlandia'' to Broadway's ''Annie.'' Also featured will be two arias (plus a song from ''Cats'') with Priscilla deLara as soprano soloist, and the local premiere of ''Destino'' by the Peekskill composer Belisario Errante.

title: 4 TO RECEIVE THE ASIA SOCIETY'S ANNUAL AWARDS
description: Three Americans and a Japanese will be honored Wednesday by the Asia Society for their contributions to a greater understanding between this country and Asian nations.

title: TOPICS
description: The university I attend helps me financially each semester with a study grant. Each year I must reapply for it to prove that my financial status hasn't significantly improved.

title: Leslie Swid Engaged to Marry Joel I. Susel in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Swid of Morristown, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Leslie Sue Swid to Joel Ira Susel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Susel of Denver. The wedding is planned for June.

title: OFF-SEASON IN EAST-WEST POLITICS MAY LAST UNTIL NOVEMBER
description: Expectation of a summit meeting this year between President Reagan and Konstantin U. Chernenko seems to be fading because of the continuing distrust and friction between the two countries and the poor prospect for any early breakthrough. There is a feeling that both the United States and Soviet Union are waiting for something dramatic to happen - a new leadership shuffle in the Kremlin or a Democrat winning the Presidency in November, neither being a very sure thing.

title: ANNA RUSSELL EXITS LAUGHING
description: She is the musicologist who discovered the forgotten Verdi opera, ''Hamletto.'' She is the impresario who headed the Ellis Island Summer Festival. She is the immortal composer of ''I'd be a red hot mama, if I didn't have varicose veins.'' She is the folklorist who has sung ''I wish I were a dicky bird.'' She is the aphorist who defined lieder singers: ''They are judged like cheese; the older and rottener they are, the better.'' She is also the vocalist who has simultaneously sung not one, not two, not three, but all four parts in a four-part madrigal. She is the French horn player who learned how to play the instrument from the article in the Encyclopaedia Brittanica. She is the artist who has set the all-time standard as the Witch in ''Hansel and Gretel'' with the New York City Opera.

title: MAKING THE WORLD SAFE FOR CONVENTIONAL WAR
description: WEAPONS AND HOPE

title: MAKING THE CASE FOR BRITAIN'S CLAIM TO THE ELGIN MARBLES
description: In recent years, the group of classical Greek sculptures known as ''the Elgin marbles'' has been the subject of an increasingly intense international debate. About 180 years ago, the sculptures were removed from the Athenian Acropolis by Britain's Lord Elgin, and since 1817, they have been housed in the British Museum in London. However, the Greek Government has repeatedly asked that the marbles be returned to Greece. In a recent interview with The New York Times, Melina Mercouri, the Greek Minister of Culture under the Government of Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou, and a passionate spokesman for the marbles' repatriation, argued that the sculptures were removed from the Parthenon without sufficient legal authority or payment - and that they belong in Greece because they form an essential part and symbol of Greek history and its national heritage.

title: STEINBRENNER'S TEAM: A WEEK IN THE LIVES
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.

title: D.A.R.'S PRESIDENT IS FIGHTING DISSENT
description: Sarah M. King, the president of the Daughters of the American Revolution, finds herself embattled a year after assuming office.

title: 3 TIE AT 210 FOR L.P.G.A. LEAD
description: JoAnne Carner and Pat Bradley, two of the top players for the last decade, and Dale Eggeling, who has won only once since turning pro in 1976, were tied for the lead today after three rounds of the $400,000 Nabisco Dinah Shore golf tournament.

title: THE REGION ; Test of Ideas in Jersey Elections
description: For followers of the conservative Presidential candidate Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. running last week in New Jersey school board elections, what mattered was not whether they won but that they had played the game. About 80 members of Mr. LaRouche's National Democratic Policy Committee were on school board ballots in New Jersey; they ran for the first time in the normally nonpartisan races to promote curriculum changes, such as a re-emphasis on classical languages and literature and the ending of ''back to basics'' instruction.

title: Kenya Jails Founder Of Human Rights Group
description: The founder of a Nairobi-based Movement for Human Rights in Africa has been jailed for two and a half years for managing an unlawful society, court officials said.

title: RICHER, POORER, TRUER
description: There he goes again. Whenever President Reagan is asked about poor people, he can't seem to resist understating or overstating the truth. He did it again at his news conference last week in talking about the effect his cuts in taxes and social programs have had on the poor.

title: FAST TALK GETS AN ELECTRONIC BOOST
description: T he urge to hurry things along is thought to be mainly a mark of the modern era. This is probably not so. Impatience had already spurred the Cavalier poets when Robert Herrick wrote ''To the Virgins, To Make Much of Time,'' and Andrew Marvell addressed similar sentiments ''To His Coy Mistress.'' Both gentlemen, had they lived later, could have accelerated their entreaties with a new electronic hurry-up device to get things said - and maybe done - more quickly.

title: CAMPUS POLICE TO BE ISSUED MACE
description: A DECISION to issue the chemical deterrent Mace to public safety officers at the State University of New York at Stony Brook as a means of self-defense has drawn criticism from students who view the move as unwarranted and potentially dangerous.

title: Jazz in Focus
description: Improvisation is one of the hallmarks of jazz, and in A MOMENT'S NOTICE: Portraits of American Jazz Musicians (Schirmer, $21.95), Carol Friedman tries to bring this quality to her photographs. Miss Friedman has photographed 74 musicians at leisure before or after performances.

title: A MOTHER'S PRESENCE
Dame Margaret's Children
description: To the Editor:

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: L EGISLATION enabling the Massapequa Water District to refund tax payments erroneously made to it since 1954 by Oyster Bay residents is expected to pass in the State Assembly and be signed into law.

title: 1,000 Protest Wildlife Traps
description: About 1,000 people rallied at the Lincoln Memorial today to support a nationwide ban on leghold wildlife traps. The rally was sponsored by Mobilization for Animals, a group based in Columbus, Ohio.

title: YALE AVOIDS STRIKE, AN ISSUE STILL OPEN
description: NEW HAVEN EMPLOYEES carried their potted plants home from work. University administrators made contingency plans to close dining halls and curtail clerical functions. Professors arranged to hold classes off campus rather than cross picket lines.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE;
description: OLYMPIC CHAMPIONS

title: Betsey McLaren to Marry
description: The engagement of Betsey Sherman McLaren to Einar Gustav Andersen Jr., a student at the New York Law School, has been announced by her parents, Mrs. Parker W. Silzer Jr. of Bedford, N.Y., and Richard K. McLaren of New York. Her fiance is a son of Grace Andersen of Lincoln, Mass., and Mr. Andersen of Hilton Head, S.C. An August wedding is planned.

title: JACKSON STUMPS IN PENNSYLVANIA
description: ''Man, this is unheard of,'' said Thomas Bolling, smiling and shaking his head.

title:
ANTIQUES;
THE ART OF DECORATING TINWARE
description: SHREWSBURY TRADITIONAL painted tinware designs have been translated into a new medium - a series of documentary wall coverings and companion cotton fabrics comprising the ''Historic American Collection'' now being introduced by Richard E. Thibaut Inc. of New York City.

title: THE IRONY AND IMPACT OF AUTO QUOTAS
description: THIS week marks an anniversary of sorts it is the start of the fourth year of the voluntary agreement between the United States and Japan to limit Japanese auto imports. Demanded by labor, supported by the auto companies, but scorned by free- traders, these limits were initially designed as a temporary crutch for a Detroit down on profits and seemingly incapable of competing with the Japanese. But, now that Detroit is walking tall again - this year promises to be the most profitable in auto history - it is still unclear whether the limits are a sage public policy:

title: Elga Z. Caune Is Married
description: Elga Z. Caune, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mintauts Caune of East Brunswick, N.J., was married there yesterday to H. Timothy Howell, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James Lee Howell of Lonoke, Ark. The Rev. Imants Kuga performed the ceremony at the Latvian Lutheran Church. The bride, a manager of Latin America planning at Avon Products Inc. in Manhattan, graduated from Rutgers University, as did Mr. Howell, who is an independent sales representative.

title: WHY NUCLEAR POWER IS GOOD FOR TREES
description: To the Editor:

title: ELLEN BACHNER IS MARRIED
description: The marriage of Ellen Bachner, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Bachner of Hartsdale, N.Y., to Dr. Carl Greenberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Cassrell Greenberg of New York, took place yesterday at Beth-El Synagogue in New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbis Lyle Fishman and Martin Zion officiated.

title: RADICAL MEDICAL REFORM
description: The most striking characteristic of the American health care system is its contrasts and inequities.

title: LOS ANGELES REPLACES CHICAGO AS SECOND CITY
description: New York is still No. 1, but Los Angeles, the western anchor of the fast-growing Sun Belt, has replaced Chicago as the nation's second largest city, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: Doug Skinner Show Will Open on April 24
description: ''Pay Attention - the Unpredictable Deadpan Humor of Composer- Ventriloquist Doug Skinner,'' a 50- minute laugh-at-lunch presentation, will open at the American Place Theater, 111 West 46th Street, on April 24 at 1 P.M.

title: REVIVAL PUSHED
description: A plan to transform the Barbizon Hotel from a failing residence for women into an elegant, open-occupancy hotel was stopped last year when the owners ran out of money.

title: COMING OF WAR, COMING OF AGE
description: Jan Kott, the author of ''Shakespeare Our Contemporary,'' is completing the first volume of his autobiography. A collection of essays on drama and literature, ''The Theatre of Essence,'' will be published this year. THE FIRST POLKA

title: AUTHENTIC MEXICAN TOUCHES
description: AS you walk up the entrance ramp to El Acapulco in South Norwalk, there is the suggestion of a fast-food eatery in the large, brightly lighted room with sturdy, inexpensive wooden chairs, laminated tabletops and plastic placemats. But this, fortunately, is not the case. El Acapulco may be one of the few Mexican restaurants in the area that is a bona fide family- run establishment.

title: Sister Cities Not Political
description: In regard to your article on Leon, Nicaragua, (Connecticut Journal, March 4), New Haven Sister Cities would like to disassociate the Board of Aldermen's decision to designate Leon, Nicaragua, as a Sister City to New Haven from the activities of New Haven Sister Cities.

title:
ART;
MONTCLAIR MUSEUM: 2 WHO CAPTURE THE TEMPO OF THE TIMES
description: MONTCLAIR BETWEEN them, the painters Robert Bermelin and Mel Leipzig capture the tempo of the times. As their current exhibition at the Montclair Art Museum proves, it is an alternating rhythm.

title: STATE PROPOSES TIME-SHARE RULES
description: THE New York State Attorney General has

title:
SHOPPER'S WORLD;
FURNISHINGS FIT FOR A SHOGUN
description: AMANDA MAYER STINCHECUM is the author of ''Kosode: 16th- Through 19th-Century Textiles From the Nomura Collection'' (Japan Society/Kodansha International). Kyoto is known as the preserver of Japan's traditional culture, and of the arts and crafts that are part of it. But Tokyo - called Edo until 1867 - has its own traditional culture too, one that developed with that of the shoguns who presided at Edo Castle in the 17th, 18th and 19th centuries. A part of that culture is preserved in Tokyo at Kyoya, a shop specializing in Edo cabinetry.

title: Letters ; Co-op Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: COZY COTTAGE FOR $1
description: One dollar is the improbable asking price for a two-bedroom, turn-of-the-century cottage that sits on a tree-lined street in East Hampton, Conn.

title: SCIENCE ACADEMY DECIDES TO HALT OPERATIONS
description: THE Connecticut Academy for Science and Engineering was supposed to play a major role in the expansion of hightechnology in Connecticut's economy, but that goal died last week when the academy decided to cease operations.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: A Goodly Sampling Of the Baker's Art

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: 3 BY SHOSTAKOVICH

title: Katharine Johnson Will Marry May 26
description: Katharine Ann Johnson, a daughter of Anne Cox Chambers, chairman of Atlanta Newspapers and former Ambassador to Belgium, and of Louis G. Johnson of Miami, plans to be married May 26 to Jesse Kornbluth, a writer and a son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Kornbluth of Nashville.

title: NEEDS OF HOMELESS BRING FORTH CARING VOLUNTEERS
description: For Sybil Rosen, it all began with the character of a homeless woman in a play she was writing. In an effort to explore the part, she volunteered to make a documentary film about services for the homeless at the Bowery Residents' Committee.

title: EYES ON ECONOMY
description: The legislators' concern is economic as well as political. Wall Street has been worrying for months that in the long term Federal borrowing to finance the deficit will push interest rates up and so choke off the recovery.

title: Data Bank; April 8, 1984
PANTHERS LOSE, 20-17
description: Efren Herrera's 32-yard field goal with four seconds left today gave the Oklahoma Outlaws a 20-17 triumph over the previously undefeated Michigan Panthers.

title: No Headline
description: Grandparents Upheld Over Visitation Rights

title: JUDGE PROTECTS WAITER'S NOTES IN FIRE INQUIRY
description: A waiter who is writing a doctoral dissertation on the sociology of restaurants does not have to give his research journal to a grand jury looking into a suspicious fire at a restaurant where he worked, a Federal judge in Brooklyn has ruled.

title: WHAT PRICE ELUSIVE BASS?
description: S OMEWHERE in the ocean between New Jersey and North Carolina, the mysterious forces of spring have begun to exert dimly felt pressures on scattered schools of striped bass.

title: MEACHAM DEMOTED
description: Bobby Meacham, whose eighth-inning error enabled Texas to score the winning run Friday night, was optioned to the minor leagues today in a move that upset Yogi Berra and raised a question about his future as the Yankees' manager.

title: Future Events
description: Evenings for Causes.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a typographical error, an article last Sunday by Russell G. D'Crench Jr., chairman of the state's Board of Governors for Higher Education misstated the percentage of minority enrollment in the freshman class this fall at Southern Conecticut State University. The figure is 11 percent.

title: Electrifying Rail Line And the Environment
description: The recent attempt that Suffolk County Legislator Phil Nolan undertakes to label himself a pure ''environmentalist'' (''Rail Station vs. Pure Water?,'' Opinion Page, March 11) leaves this reader not only amused but somewhat flabbergasted as well.

title: Norway Dismisses Spy Suspect Before Trial
description: The Norwegian Government has dismissed Arne Treholt as head of the Foreign Ministry's press and information office without waiting for his espionage trial.

title: No-Hitter and Drugs
description: Dock Ellis , who was treated four years ago for drug dependency, says he was under the influence of LSD when he pitched a no-hitter in 1970 against the San Diego Padres. Ellis, who is 39 years old and works now as the coordinator of an anti-drug program in Los Angeles, made the statement to The Pittsburgh Press in an interview that was published today.

title: NEW MAP OUTLINES BEST BIKING ROUTES
description: THE state government rarely attracts a rush of customers to its publications, but a map of Connecticut's best bicycling routes has proved an exception.

title: Sally Roffman Is Wed In Virginia Ceremony
description: Sally Anne Roffman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Emil Roffman of Richmond, was married at Temple Beth Ahabah there yesterday to Brock Holmes, the son of Mr. and George Burgwin Holmes of Washington. Rabbi Jack Spiro performed the ceremony, in which the Rev. Dr. Paul van Buren, an Episcopal priest, participated.

title: FEEDING THE HUNGER FOR STORIES
description: R. W. Flint is a freelance contributor to Parnassus, American Poetry Review and other publications. HISTORY OF MY HEART

title: HANGING UP A NEW SHINGLE
description: SHINGLE-STYLE HOUSES ARE TOTALLY embedded in our visual memories. So much so that most people forget that, when the designs first evolved along the shores of the Northeast a little more than a century ago, they were considered quite avant-garde. The buildings seemed bold when compared to the Colonial or Queen Anne styles that preceeded them. Known for their commodious rooms, multishaped dormers and rambling proches, they suggested a gutsiness and spirit all their own.

title: EXPERTS PREFER A BOARD
description: If you are one of those players who

title: New & Noteworthy
description: SAMARITAN, by Philippe van Rjndt. (Pinnacle, $3.95.) This extraordinary novel posits crises of global import and makes ''outrageous and horrifying events unfolding below the surface of these crises . . . much more credible than the fictional doings in the usual thriller,'' Stanley Ellin's review said. A complex narrative, convincing descriptions of Warsaw, Moscow, New York, Rome and Amsterdam, the author's commitment to political morality and his faith in human decency combine to create ''a stunning and often moving experience.'' MAILER: A Biography, by Hilary Mills. (McGraw-Hill, $8.95.) Drawing on rumor, report and data - including ''an awful lot of straight talk'' about money - Hilary Mills has produced what our critic, Mark Harris, called ''a sound, solid, responsible, perfectly balanced, documented biography . . . which collects the man all in one focused piece as he has not been collected before.'' Her book clarifies Mailer the man and writer ''without celebrating him'' as it covers his life ''year by year, wife by wife, book by book, obsession by obsession.''

title: EDITH B. SHEERIN PLANS TO MARRY R.R. PATTERSON
description: Announcement has been made by the Rev. and Mrs. Charles W. Sheerin Jr. of Pawling, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter Edith Barton Sheerin to Robert Rush Patterson, the son of Mrs. Robert Patterson of Delray Beach, Fla., and the late Mr. Patterson. An August wedding is planned.

title: CONTEMPORARY MUSIC A HIT-BUT WHY?
description: MONTCLAIR LUKAS FOSS marveled at the size of the audience, and Milton Babbitt said it was a major breakthrough.

title: THE RETURN OF GENE PITNEY
description: AFTER concentrating on foreign appearances for 13 years, Gene Pitney, the Rockville-born singer, is preparing for a return to the American music scene.

title: DOVER'S HISPANIC ROOTS GO DEEP
description: DOVER IN 1952, when Dover was still a commercial

title: STRIKERS AT LAS VEGAS HOTELS TO CALL FOR BOYCOTT BY UNION MEMBERS
description: Thwarted in their efforts to shut down operations at 29 hotels and casinos in Las Vegas, striking labor leaders have said that on Monday they will call for an international boycott by organized labor against three major Las Vegas employers, Hilton Hotels, Holiday Inns and Ramada Inns.

title: WHY HOUSE BUILDERS' COST ARE RISING
description: IN 1977, Marc A. Gerber built a two-story frame house on Button Hook Road in Chappaqua, N.Y. and sold it for

title: NICARAGUA IS FIRM ON ENVOY CHOICE
description: Nicaragua is not prepared to withdraw the nomination of Nora Astorga to be Ambassador to Washington, but officials have recently begun to reflect ''on the convenience of sending her to the United States,'' Interior Minister Tomas Borge said this week.

title: NEW AMENITIES FOR WORLD'S TALLEST BUILDING
description: The world's tallest building, the Sears Tower, is getting a new look 10 years after it was built.

title: KOCH PLANS ACTION IF ESTIMATE BOARD SUIT IS LOST
description: Mayor Koch says he will move to strip the Board of Estimate of its budget powers if the city loses a lawsuit challenging the makeup of the board.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS;
description: A rags-to-riches story it was. A 16- year-old orphan, wandering near the railroad tracks at Hollywood, Fla., came across a bank sack filled with jewels in March 1983.

title: INFORMERS HELPED INDICT MOB FIGURES IN 25 SLAYINGS
description: Several informers provided information leading to a major racketeering indictment that accused an organized- crime group of 25 murders, according to court documents.

title: JAZZ: BOB HAGGART, BASSIST, AND BAND
description: Bob Haggart, the bassist, arranger, composer of ''What's New?'' and ''South Rampart Street Parade'' and onetime spark plug of Bob Crosby's orchestra, has been appearing at the Rainbow Room with a nine-piece band made up of an exceptional collection of masters of Swing Era jazz styles. They play the arrangements that Mr. Haggart wrote over more than 10 years for the World's Greatest Jazz Band, in which he played bass.

title:
THE WORLD ;
French Socialists HaveLabor Woes
description: Unrest in the eastern Lorraine region last week showed how deeply France's Socialist-led Government is in trouble with many of the people who put it into power in 1981. With demonstrations that turned violent at times and roadblocks that virtually cut off the region, thousands of steelworkers protested against a plan to reduce steel production by 20 percent over the next three years. The cut would conform to an agreement among Common Market countries to eliminate Government subsidies to the industry by getting rid of excess production.

title: CUOMO'S INITIATIVES MAY DIE OF NEGLECT
description: One of the ironies of Governor Cuomo's first 16 months in office is that he has, so far, been brilliant at things people said he might struggle with, but has had trouble in areas that had been thought to be his strengths. Before he took office last year, Mr. Cuomo was said to be a thinker, a negotiator, a man of substance. Politics, insiders said, was not his forte. He was not tough enough for it, it was said, not decisive or ruthless enough.

title: FAMILIES OF SUICIDE VICTIMS FIND HELP
description: A DESPONDENT young mother of two deliberately plummets off the Tappan Zee Bridge. A disillusioned young man unable to readapt to his former style of life, hurls himself into the path of an oncoming train. Another man, married less than one year, is found dead in an Atlantic City casino-hotel, with his wrists slashed and his body suffused with drugs - leaving no doubt of his intent.

title: ABOUT MEN
description: THE MAN I DIDN'T KNOW BY OWEN EDWARDS Owen Edwards

title: THE LIFE AND DEATH OF A FAMOUS TREE
description: HARTFORD FOR the better part of two centuries, the Charter Oak was an important symbol of Connecticut's grit and independence. But today, few people know its story.

title: THE QUEENS DOME
description: Last month, The New York Times ran an excerpt of testimony given by State Senator Tom Bartosiewicz of Brooklyn given before the the New York Senate Task Force on Professional Sports and the Economy on why Brooklyn should have a domed stadium. The following article is excerpted from testimony given by Queens Borough President Donald R. Manes before the same committee.

title: BEACH HOMES IMPERILED ANEW
description: S CORES of federally insured summer homes are facing a greater threat than ever of toppling into the Atlantic Ocean in Westhampton following the devastating storm of March 29, according to local officials.

title: Upstate Plane Crash Kills 1
description: A single-engine plane crashed this afternoon near the intersection of Route 59 and the Thomas E. Dewey Thruway after taking off from Ramapo Valley Airport, killing one man and injuring another, officials said. The dead man, identifed as Garrett Miller of West Nyack, died in Suffern at Good Samaritan Hospital, a hospital spokesman said. The injured man, John Palermo, was in critical condition.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: -EIGHT Japanese companies and 12 Korean concerns have subsidiaries in New Jersey, according to Robert A. Hayzer, who opened a business in Lyndhurst last June to help Far Eastern companies with offices here and New Jersey concerns with interests in the Far East.

title: Redlich Dancers to Perform
description: The Don Redlich Dance Company will perform from Thursday through next Sunday at the N.Y.U. Tisch School of the Arts, Fifth Floor Theater, at 111 Second Avenue.

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: Chile Bows to Vatican In Guerrillas' Case

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
AUTO INSURANCE: WHY ANTICIPATE AN ACCIDENT?
description: call them John and Mary - who live in a suburban town in New Jersey. When you finish it, most of you will shed crocodile tears for John and Mary.

description: Cardinal Is My Middle Name

title: NEW PENALTIES FOR CHOP SHOPS PASS IN ALBANY
description: The operators of chop shops - places that dismantle stolen vehicles for easy resale - would face stiff penalties under the terms of legislation given final legislative approval by the Senate this week.

NURTURING WILDLIFE BACK TO HEALTH
description: CONNECTICUT wildlife is in constant collision with civilization. Baby raccoons tumble down chimneys into smoldering fireplaces and suffer severe burns before being rescued. Female deer are killed by poachers and automobiles, leaving offspring to wander helplessly. Hawks, owls and ospreys strike power lines and automobile grills, or they become paralyzed from eating rodents and fish laced with pesticides.

title: Cable TV
description: A good under-exposed suspense melodrama has returned to cable this week, rather surprisingly slotted for prime time. In ''Black Sunday'' (1977), with Robert Shaw, Bruce Dern and Marthe Keller, terrorists prowl a Super Bowl game attended by the President.

title: Pop Music
description: George Clinton, who is at the Ritz on Wednesday and Thursday with his P-Funk Allstars, announced several years ago his intention to ''save dance music from the blahs.'' He has been hard at work doing just that for the last dozen years or so, as a record producer, songwriter, arranger, vocalist, bandleader, talent scout, and master of obfuscation.

title: Island Gulls Face Poisoning
description: Managers at the Moosehorn National Wildlife Refuge are proposing to poison gulls on Petit Manan Island in an effort to recapture breeding grounds for terns. Federal refuge officials also plan to cut back vegetation on the island to make it more attractive to sand-nesting terns.

title: GEORGIA'S BITTER PEACH
description: TY COBB

title: THE OSCAR CHASE: A PEEK BEHIND THE SCREEN
description: LOS ANGELES

title: SALES TAX RISE IS HERE TO STAY, NASSAU HOPES
description: I T'S only a penny on a dollar, but

title: BRITISH VIEWERS TELL OFF THE TELLY
description: Leslie Mandel-Viney is a freelance writer living in London.

title: Headliners; What Are Friends For?
description: Not many waitresses would be overjoyed if a customer offered them an i.o.u. for a tip. Unless, of course, that i.o.u. turned out to be half of a $6 million Lotto jackpot.

title: Abdul-Jabbar's Mark Seems Safe Now
description: With one more season to play before his retirement, Kareem Adbul-Jabbar attained perhaps the greatest achievement of his stellar 15-year career this week. By getting 22 points against the Utah Jazz Thursday in Las Vegas, Nev., he became pro basketball's most prolific scorer.

title: HARD TIMES IN TYNESIDE
description: Mona Simpson is a freelance writer and critic. THE BLACK VELVET GOWN

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK:BRINKS ATTENTION SHIFTS TO BROWN FROM BOUDIN
description: THE focus in the Brinks robbery and murder trial, now entering its ninth week of jury selection, shifted briefly last week from Kathy Boudin, whose name seems to be known to many potential jurors, to her less- prominent co-defendant, Samuel Brown.

title: FOLK ART: IT IS ALL AROUND US
description: TRENTON '' TELL PEOPLE to look for folk art in their bedrooms, in their pantries, on their dining room tables.''

title: BOOMING UNDERGROUND INDUSTRY: THE BUSINESS OF PUSHING COUNTERFEIT GOODS
description: STRAPPED tightly into a parachute and pulled into the air behind a speedboat, William Callahan raised a pair of binoculars to his eyes as he floated over the beaches of Acapulco. One hundred feet above the crashing surf, his view of the balcony of an 11th-floor suite at the Holiday Inn convinced him that he had finally found the headquarters of a multimillion-dollar counterfeit operation.

title: HOW INDIANS USED PLANTS
description: WHEN Barrie Kavasch has guests for dinner, she serves American food - not steak or ribs, but perhaps crayfish on wild rice, batter-fried dandelion blossoms, milkweed pods vinaigrette, Indian pudding and black birch tea.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: MOST of the 3,000 students in 14 Northern New Jersey high schools believe it is likely that there will be a nuclear war in the next 20 years and that they will die in it, but seven of every 10 say that such a war can be prevented, according to a recent study by the Northern New Jersey chapter of Physicians for Social Responsibility.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch March 25 from Cambridge, Mass., on a dispute over the Arthur D. Little Company's testing of lethal gases misstated Francis H. Duehay's connection with the city. He is a member of the City Council.

title: FEMALE STRESS EXPLORED
description: MOST women do not identify, understand or do much about the stress they experience, says Dr. Georgia Witkin-Lanoil of Scarsdale. The author of ''The Female Stress Syndrome/How To Recognize and Live With It,'' published last week by Newmarket Press, says she hopes her book will help change those points. Its purpose, she says, is ''to legitimize and identify the many stresses of women and to help women feel that they have permission to do something about them before the quality of their lives is compromised.''

title: TROUBLE IN ASMALL PART OF THE WORLD
description: LAST week my daughter celebrated her first birthday. Friends and family surrounded her with love and good wishes. That night a very tired Emily took her pajamas to her father and pointed to her crib. She fell asleep easily, clutching her bear, covered by her rainbow quilt. We were exhausted and went to bed right after she did.

title: PINELANDS IS SUFFERING GROWING PAINS
description: WHEN the 1970's began, fewer than 7,000 people were scattered through the 109 square miles of Hamilton Township, concentrated, more or less, in the half-dozen communities of the state's largest municipality.

title: Nuptials in Jersey For Miss Lehman
description: Catherine Ellen Lehman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Charles Lehman of West Orange, N.J., was married at Temple B'nai Jeshurun in Short Hills, N.J., yesterday to Robert Gursha, a son of the late Col. Alvin Gursha, U.S.A., and the late Mrs. Gursha of Elkton, Md., and Pittsburgh. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Ely Pilchik, who officiated at the wedding of the bride's parents, and Rabbi Barry H. Greene.

title: LIFE WITH EVERYONE
description: Enid Nemy is a reporter for The New York Times. CHOICE PEOPLE

title: AT HOME IN A GREEK VILLAGE
description: Greece is a small country by anyone's measure, but it contains enough distinct countries within it to satisfy most travelers in search of new territory, and whatever predisposition you may bring to a journey there, discovering one or another of these countries is an adventure that Henry Miller aptly tells us is ''like falling in love with one's own divine image.''

title: FUN AND GAMES IN PRINCETON
description: PRINCETON WHILE Saskia, an ingenue, is rehearsing, quite dreadfully, the role of Dido in one dressing room, a black-gloved hand throws a crumbled piece of paper in through the door of another.

title: Kabuki at Japan House
description: Bando Tamasaburo V, the celebrated Kabuki actor, will perform a series of Kabuki solo dances from May 4 through May 11 at the Lila Acheson Wallace Auditorium of Japan House, 333 East 47th Street.

title: THE CALENDAR
description: President Reagan will sign a proclamation for Law Day U.S.A. in a Rose Garden ceremony.

title: CIVIC STUDY URGES KOCH TO IMPROVE SERVICES
description: New York City's streets could be cleaner, its fire code better enforced and more arrests made for serious crimes if the Koch administration improved its management practices, according to a private study of municipal services released yesterday.

title: WHEN U.N. RESTS, QUIET PERSUASION GOES ON
description: Even after the Security Council adjourns, the speeches end and visiting heads of state depart from yet another General Assembly session, the United Nations remains a port of call for petitioners who seize on the lull in the proceedings to try to call attention to their grievances.

title: Rotisserie League
description: If you're a baseball fan who's forever being disappointed by the front office maneuvers of your favorite major league team, there's a new answer to your problem - a major league team of your own.

title: OF LITTLE GLITCHES AND BIG HEADACHES
description: It is always the little things that go wrong.

title: ARRESTED YANKEE FANS PERSIST IN SUIT
description: Oct. 2, 1982, was Fan Appreciation Day at Yankee Stadium, and everyone got a free mug. But for Dennis Dembek and Joseph Turnbull, the prize was a court date.

title: JACKSON AND MONDALE FIGHT FOR BLACK VOTERS' SUPPORT
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson said today that if Walter F. Mondale won the Democratic Presidential nomination, the former Vice President would have to change his position and oppose runoff primaries to obtain Mr. Jackson's support in the general election.

title: CO-OP PROJECT AIDS POOR WHEN A LANDLORD QUITS
description: The predicament that the tenants of 507 West 140th Street faced in June 1982 was depressingly common: The building's owner, after years of barely maintaining services, bluntly said he was abandoning their home.

title: MILITARY SCHOOLS BENEFIT FROM RISE IN POPULARITY
description: There is excited talk about the Military Ball later this month, when cadets and their dates will parade through an arch of sabers. A new drama club has been formed on campus. The track and tennis teams are undefeated after two meets.

title: Taxi Crime
description: A visitor from Italy has reported

title: L.I. CASE IS FIRST TEST OF STATE'S NEW HAZING LAW
description: Last November, John Isaacson set off to join a fraternity and affirm his friendship with a group of students and former students from West Hempstead High School.

title: MEACHAM MOVE IS EXPLAINED
description: If the Yankees thought Andre Robertson was ready to play shortstop for them, George Steinbrenner would not be shuttling young shortstops between New York and Nashville. But, Steinbrenner said today, Robertson could be ''two weeks, a month or more'' away from joining the Yankees, so special steps must be taken.

title: BEN BONUS, 63, A YIDDISH ACTOR AND PRODUCER
description: C. GERALD FRASER

title: Off-Duty Officer Kills Man in S.I. Bar Dispute
description: An off-duty police officer shot and killed a man and was seriously wounded in an exchange of gunfire yesterday in a Staten Island bar. The police described it as an altercation provoked by the man who was slain.

title: Japan Reacts To Beef Pact
description: Japan's Agriculture Ministry may increase subsidies to beef producers to ease the effects of a new agreement to nearly double beef imports from the United States, the newspaper Asahi Shimbun reported today.

title: Ex-Value Line Officer Joins Integrated Asset
description: Dorothy A. Berry, former president and chief operating officer of Value Line Inc., has been named chief operating officer of the Integrated Asset Management Corporation, a unit of Integrated Resources Inc.

title: MONDALE WOULD BAR USE OF 3-MILE ISLAND FACILITY
description: Paula Kinney skipped a Tupperware party to come to the Three Mile Island nuclear plant today and hear Walter F. Mondale.

title: Bangladesh Frees 224 From Political Detention
description: Bangladesh's military Government today freed 224 of more than 300 political detainees who opposition parties said should be released to end a deadlock between the two sides on the country's political future.

title: MORE EXECUTIVES GET FINANCIAL PLANNING AID
description: YLA EASON Company cars, special parking privileges and even annual physical examinations are very much in fashion when corporations hand out ''perks'' to their top executives. But the fastest-growing of these perquisites is personal financial counseling, according to the Hay/Huggins Company, a benefits consulting company based in Philadelphia. At a time when many companies are cutting back on perks, this one has grown 37 percent in the past four years.

title: No Headline
description: Population of Prisons Slowed Growth in '83

title: APPLE PLANS PORTABLE COMPUTER
description: DAVID E. SANGER

title: NEW MATZOH MARKETS SOUGHT
description: Each autumn, Brooklyn's Satmar Hasidim begin making matzohs for the coming spring. A clamorous assembly line of 30 women, printed scarves hiding their hair and lace aprons cinching their waists, wrestle with plump wads of dough until the loaves are thin enough.

title: Donovan in New York To See Jewish Leaders By The Associated Press
description: Secretary of Labor Raymond J. Donovan met with Jewish leaders of the New York metropolitan area yesterday ''to garner as much support for the President as I can.''

title: BILL AUCTIONS SLIGHTLY SMALLER
description: Treasury financings this week are confined to the bill market, with the regular three- and six-month issues scheduled for sale today, followed by a one-year auction on Thursday.

description: International

title: Blues and Flames Advance
description: Jorgen Pettersson scored his third goal 2 minutes 42 seconds into overtime last night to enable the St. Louis Blues to advance to the second round of the Stanley Cup playoffs with a 3-2 victory over the Detroit Red Wings.

title: President for Ad Group
description: DeWitt F. Helm Jr., 50 years old, joined the Association of National Advertisers last November with the expectation of succeeding Peter W. Allport, 63, who has been president for 20 years. That will happen on May 31. Mr. Allport, who first joined the association in 1945 after briefly working for the Erwin Wasey ad agency, will be president emeritus.

title: 'BALLAD OF NARAYAMA' BY SHOHEI IMAMURA
description: NATURE is so rich and the life force so rampant in Shohei Imamura's ''The Ballad of Narayama'' that, after a preview screening, I was almost relieved to walk out into the man-made pollution of Times Square. Nature, thus prettified by Mr. Imamura, is almost as artifical as a world in which a virgin forest has been removed to make way for a cement-paved parking lot.

title: MONDAY, APRIL 9, 1984 International
description: Despite ''peace-loving rhetoric'' from Washington, Konstantin U. Chernenko said he had not seen concrete signs of readiness to improve relations with Moscow. ''Alas, the situation in the world is not improving. It remains very dangerous,'' the Soviet leader said, prefacing a gloomy survey of Soviet-American relations to published in the Monday issue of the newspaper Pravda. (Page A1, Col. 1.) World Court jurisdiction in disputes involving Central America will not be accepted by the Reagan Administration for the next two years, the Administration announced. A senior State Department official said the move, which was unexpected, had been taken because of information that Nicaragua was about to bring charges against the United States in the International Court of Justice in The Hague, the official name of the Worl Court. (A1:2.)

title: THE SCORE: DETROIT 3, OCTOPUS 3
description: It is octopus season once again in the Motor City.

title: 'LET'S TALK BLACK TALK'
description: Jesse Jackson, ostensibly a candidate for President of the United States, was having breakfast at the private plane terminal in Washington's National Airport seven weeks ago and invited a couple of reporters - one from The Washington Post, the other from The New York Times - to join him.

title: Twins 7, Orioles 3
description: Mickey Hatcher had four hits in five times at bat, giving him six in his last seven times at bat, as the Twins rallied to sweep the three-game series.

title: SEAVER LOSES TO TIGERS IN DEBUT
description: Barbaro Garbey, the 27-year-old Cuban rookie, drove in three runs with two doubles, his first major-league hits, to help the Detroit Tigers to a 7-3 victory over the Chicago White Sox today that spoiled Tom Seaver's debut in the American League.

title: British Pondering Miss Budd's Plea
description: Zola Budd, the distance runner, might not be considered for Britain's Olympic team, according to the British Amateur Athletics Board secretary, Nigel Cooper.

description: A Senate staff study called on the United States today to declare itself ready to recognize an Afghan government in exile.

description: The road from ninth grade to senior year would be much more pleasant if it did not pass through life's first Bermuda Triangle, adolescence.

title: SIC THE FEDS ON CREDIT-CARD CROOKS
description: The next time you pay for a meal or a suit with a credit card, think about ripping out the carbons from the credit form and tearing them up. Messy? You bet. But the consequences if you don't could be even messier.

description: On Monday, two events will take place here that are part of a lengthy but nonetheless hectic and intense struggle to secure the City's future as an international financial center matching the influence of New York.

title: TRIMMING THE BUDGET: THE 7 PLACES TO LOOK
description: After several weeks of sparring, the Reagan Administration and Senate Republicans, on one side, and Democrats in both houses of Congress, on the other, are ready to step into the ring for six months of bare-knuckle battling over the military budget.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; FRANKLIN LOSES ITS PRESIDENT
description: After only 13 months on the job, Avram C. Miller resigned Friday as president and chief operating officer of the Franklin Computer Corporation, in what the company termed ''a major corporate reorganization.''

title: Gillian Nicholas Is a Bride on L.I.
description: Gillian Nicholas, a daughter of Dr. and William Nicholas of New Hyde Park, L.I., was married yesterday to Thomas Gilbert Gabriel, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert R. Gabriel Jr. of White Plains. Cantor David Benedict performed the cermeony at the Welwyn Preserve in Glen Cove, L.I.

title: A 1980'S MISSIONARY PURSUES THE SOULS OF AFRICA
description: When Dr. David Livingstone died in what is now Zambia in 1873, there were but a handful of retainers to attend him at his final resting place - a modest hut. In his last days, he had become so weak with fever that he had to be carried. His quest to evangelize Africa was over.

title: Stars Triumph By 22-21
description: Chuck Fusina passed 11 yards for a touchdown to Willie Collier with 1 minute 40 seconds to play and David Trout kicked the winning extra-point as the Philadelphia Stars rallied for 16 points and beat the Arizona Wranglers, 22-21, today.

title: Acquisition by Grey
description: Grey Advertising has acquired Frances Friedman Associates, a six- month-old public relations firm that has been merged into Grey & Davis, the agency's public relations division. The unit, which has just under $1 million in fee income, has been renamed Greycom. Mark Rutman, former G.& D. president, is chairman and chief executive, while Mrs. Friedman is president.

title: Washington Watch; Emergency Oil Planning
description: WASHINGTON T HE Reagan Administration has become more

title: LEBANON SAYS ACCORD IS REACHED, BUT FIGHTING IN CAPITAL GOES ON
description: Government officials reported today that an agreement had been reached among the warring factions on disengaging their forces in Beirut. But fighting continued today, with the sound of explosions and machine-gun fire reverberating in the capital.

title: Charles W. David Dies at 99;Ex-Head of Libraries at Penn
description: Charles Wendell David, director of libraries at the University of Pennsylvania and a professor of history from 1940 until 1955, died Monday at Hahnemann Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 99 years old and lived in St. Davids, Pa., a suburb of Philadelphia.

title: ECONOMIC CALENDAR
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday

title: Cameroon Says Rebels Are Being 'Mopped Up'
description: The Government of President Paul Biya of Cameroon said today that remnants of a palace guard revolt were being ''mopped up'' and urged citizens to remain vigilant against mutineers.

title: Man Fires at Guards; Shot Dead at Airport
description: A man with a revolver shot and wounded two unarmed airport security guards today after shoving his way through a metal detector at a passenger boarding area, then was shot and killed by the police.

title: Putting the Homeless to Work There were plenty of skeptics last fall when the New York City Human Resources Administration began requiring residents of some city shelters to accept work assignments. How many homeless people are able to make themselves genuinely useful? How would they respond to compulsory work?
description: The response so far has been encouraging enough that the city wants to expand the idea to almost all of its 18 shelters. The project deserves the support of the community, and especially private industry.

title: Marcia G. Kramer Is Bride
description: Marcia Gail Kramer, Albany bureau chief of The Daily News, and Richard Norton Runes, a lawyer in New York and counsel to the State Senate Housing Committee, were married yesterday by Rabbi Harold Konovitch at the Parker Meridien Hotel in New York.

title: A New Sneaker
description: In the hottest competition in the National Basketball Association - the battle among sneaker manufacturers for the footwear fealty of N.B.A. stars - the Spot-bilt model has had a hard time getting a toehold.

title: JULI INKSTER WINS IN A PLAYOFF
description: Juli Inkster, in her first full year on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour, overhauled a faltering Pat Bradley with a birdie on the 18th hole, then beat her with a par on the first sudden-death hole today to capture the $400,000 Dinah Shore tournament, the circuit's richest event.

title: DESPITE THE ODDS, CZECH REBEL PRESSES CASE
description: Vaclav Benda pressed two fingers against his forehead and horn-rimmed glasses and told a bitter joke about political isolation in Czechoslovakia. A Czech, it goes, has only three friends: his car, his weekend cottage and himself.

title: MCENROE TOPPLED BY LENDL
description: Ivan Lendl, scoring with service returns and well-placed lobs, defeated John McEnroe today, 6-4, 3-6, 6-2, in the final of the four-player Suntory Cup tennis tournament. The Czechoslovak received $110,000 and McEnroe $70,000.

title: A DEMAND FOR GOODS FROM ASIA
description: Uwajimaya, a block-long food, gift and furniture business with a pagoda-style roof, is a mainstay of this city's international district, where streets are lined with Japanese and Chinese restaurants, small shops and curio stores.

title: METS WIN FOURTH CONSECUTIVE GAME, 3-1, FOR SWEEP OF ASTROS
description: It was only one week in a 26-week season, but the Mets put the finishing touches on their best opening week in six years tonight when they defeated the Houston Astros, 3-1, and scurried past several small milestones.

title: LATIN DEBATE REFOCUSED
description: The mining of Nicaraguan harbors, reportedly under the direct supervision of the Central Intelligence Agency, has rekindled doubts in Congress and among some officials in the Reagan Administration about the extensive use of covert activities to advance United States interests in Central America.

title: F.C.C. Backs Cable Rule
description: The Federal Communications Commission, after more than three years of controversy, rejected Friday, by a 5-0 vote, a petition filed by Ted Turner, the Atlanta entrepreneur, challenging the so-called ''must-carry rule.''

title: THIRSTY ARIZONA DEBATES WATER PLAN
description: Out West, it is said, water runs uphill, toward money. Whoever said that first could have had the Central Arizona Project in mind.

title: Moody Wins on Chip
description: Orville Moody sank a 70-foot chip shot today to beat Arnold Palmer and Dan Sikes on the second hole of a playoff and win the Daytona Beach Seniors Classic.

description: At the Manhattan Beach Jewish Center in Brooklyn yesterday, Susan Leslie Spodek, a daughter of Justice and Mrs. Jules L. Spodek of the Midwood section of Brooklyn, was married to Ronald P. Glickman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Glickman of North Miami Beach, Fla., and East Rockaway, L.I. Rabbi Alvin Kass performed the ceremony.

title: Dorchester Acquired
description: The Damson Oil Corporation said yesterday that it had acquired the Dorchester Gas Corporation by accepting roughly 16 million shares tendered by Dorchester shareholders at $22.50 each. The shares represent 94 percent of Dorchester's outstanding common stock, Damson added.

title: GENERALS WIN, 35-10, WITHOUT WALKER
description: The Generals did more than survive without Herschel Walker today. They trounced the Memphis Showboats, 35-10, as Walker, with a sore left shoulder, watched the game from a field box. The Generals had a lot of other heroes.

title: Sikh Bomb Wounds 3 In a Hindu Temple
description: A bomb planted by Sikh terrorists exploded in a Hindu temple early today in Punjab state, wounding at least three people, the police said.

description: As flooded rivers began to recede in northern New Jersey today, streets that had been submerged in water reappeared, cars that had been lost in swirling brown currents emerged and thousands of homeowners returned to neighborhoods that had been chest- deep in water for two days.

description: Knicks vs. Cleveland Cavaliers , at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. The Knicks have won three of four games in the season series.

Rabbi Robert Rothman performed the ceremony at Le Ch^ateau restaurant in South Salem, N.Y.

Potter of Waban, Mass., was married yesterday to Morton David Cahn 2d, a son of Julius Cahn of Champaign, Ill., and Mary Monteux of Gloucester, Mass. Rabbi Jonathan Ginsburg performed the ceremony at the Kane Street Synagogue in Brooklyn.
