title: McGovern, Out of Race, Scores Gain in Iowa
description: Walter F. Mondale held his lead and Gary Hart gained ground Saturday in Iowa's Democratic county conventions, but George McGovern picked up delegates.

title: ARGENTINA UNSURE HOW MUCH DEBT IS
description: After four months in office and an international flurry over a near default in its interest payments abroad, Argentina's new Government is still unable to decide the exact size and breakdown of its foreign debt or how much it is willing to recognize.

title: Happy Season Is Returning
description: MY spy-who-watches-television reported that the newscasters were even giddier than usual the other day, when the baseball season opened. They were wearing baseball caps and baseball shirts and making baseball jokes, ''giggling like little kids,'' my spy put it.

title: Market Place; Some Analysts See Stock Rise
description: T HE stock market has been a hostage of interest rate fears for the last several weeks, and

title: 2 Banks Fail In Tennessee
description: Two more Tennessee banks - Watauga Valley Bank of Elizabethton and First Security Bank of Erwin - have been declared insolvent and sold at auction.

title: Ex-Thompson Officer Is Bozell Vice Chairman
description: Wayne J. Fickinger, former president and chief operating officer of the J. Walter Thompson Company, returned to the fray last week as vice chairman of Bozell & Jacobs, one of the country's top 20 ad agencies.

title: LILCO SEEKS $72 MILLION RATE RISE
description: The Long Island Lighting Company has filed a petition with the state for a rate increase to recover its $72.1 million investment in nuclear and coal- fired power plants it had hoped to build in Jamesport, L.I., the State Consumer Protection Board said yesterday.

title: NETS ROUT CAVALIERS, 124-97
description: The Nets registered their most one-sided victory of the season tonight, 124-97, over the Cleveland Cavaliers at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. The 27-point margin eclipsed the previous high of 23, posted only 24 hours earlier against the Washington Bullets.

title: Bean Ends Slump
description: Andy Bean turned back the challenge of George Archer with a solid, two-under-par 70 and broke a two- year slump today with a two-stroke victory in the Greater Greensboro Open.

title: Three Big Oil Spills Plague California Coast
description: Three separate spills along the coast from Los Angeles Harbor to Huntington Beach dumped more than 5,000 gallons of oil into the water and onto beaches. No major ecological damage was expected from the spills, a Coast Guard spokesman said, adding that the number of spills was unusual and the amount of oil dumped was significant.

title: MUSIC: TIPPETT PREMIERE
description: Nearly 200 years ago, Joseph Haydn celebrated the creative power of his old age by writing a large work for chorus, vocal soloists and orchestra. It was ''The Creation''; and with this remarkable tone painting of genesis, and its depiction of life's variety on earth, Haydn gathered close to him and then expressed in one long coherent statement the sum of his experience as a composer.

title: THE OPERA: 'MIGNON,' BY AMBROISE THOMAS
description: DONAL HENAHAN

title: INVITATIONS TO COPY
description: To the Editor:

title: HART STAYING CALM AMID THE TURBULENCE AS PENNSYLVANIA TEST APPROACHES
description: As his chartered Boeing 707 bobbed and weaved sporadically in choppy winds one night over the weekend, Senator Gary Hart stood unperturbed at the front of the plane, huddling with three key advisers.

title: Arrest Near White House
description: A man carrying a large knife was arrested outside a White House gate this morning after he made a verbal threat against President Reagan, a Secret Service spokesman said. The spokesman, Mary Ann Gordon, said James Storm, 25 years old, of Sacramento, Calif., ''walked up to the northwest gate, made a verbal threat and was taken into the custody - he threatened the President.'' She said Mr. Storm was charged with threatening the President and carrying a concealed knife with a blade more than three inches long.

title: Catholic Magistrate Attacked by I.R.A.
description: Gunmen ambushed a Roman Catholic magistrate and his family as they walked home from church today, killing his daughter and leaving him critically wounded, the police said.

title: ECONOMISTS WORRIED BY INFLATION
description: WINSTON WILLIAMS

title: Food for the Holiday
description: Ten years ago, Jeno Hershkowitz

title: PADRES' STREAK ENDED
description: Garry Templeton booted Henry Cotto's routine grounder to shortstop with two out in the 10th inning today, allowing Steve Lake to score with the first of three runs that gave the Chicago Cubs an 8-5 victory over the San Diego Padres.

title: NEW REPORT ON FEDERAL ARTS SUBSIDIES DISPUTED
description: WALTER GOODMAN

title: LIEU. GEN. WILLIAM R. PEERS, 69, LED INQUIRY INTO MY LAIMASSACRE
description: WOLFGANG SAXON

title: SERIES TIED AT 2-2
description: The Islanders' ''Drive for Five,'' their chase for a fifth straight Stanley Cup, came within 20 minutes of a dead end last night.

title: WEINBERGER DENIES REPORT OF U.S. LATIN COMBAT PLAN
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger said today that the United States had no plans of any kind for the use of United States combat troops in Central America should the current strategy to defeat the leftists fail.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of April 9, 1984: MONDAY None reported

title: AROUND THE NATION
description: Starvation Case Figure Leaves Hospital

title: CHINA CLAIMS 23 VIETNAMESE CASUALTIES
description: China reported today that its frontier guards killed or wounded 23 Vietnamese soldiers who fired into Chinese territory and crossed the border to plant mines.

title: AMERICAN LOBBIES GAINING IN JAPAN
description: STEVE LOHR

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: HENRY JAMES LETTERS. Volume IV. 1895-1916. Edited by Leon Edel. 835 pages. The Belknap Press of Harvard University Press. $30.

title: Las Vegas Union Leader Confronts Hotel Official
description: An officer of the 13-million-member A.F.L.-C.I.O. and a Hilton official confronted each other outside the Las Vegas Hilton today as hundreds of pickets on strike against 29 Las Vegas hotel-casinos stood by jeering.

title: NEWEST GALLERY: THE A.M.A.
description: It was the American Medical Association, not one of the museums on the Mall, that recently threw open its doors to honor seven Washington artists whose works are represented in its corporate arts collection and to show off its most recently commissioned painting, a 6-by-10-foot aerial view of Washington by a New York artist, Yvonne Jacquette.

title: THEODORE DUNHAM, ASTRONOMER
description: Dr. Theodore Dunham Jr., an astronomer who discovered that the atmosphere of Venus contained a large amount of carbon dioxide, died Tuesday at his home in Chocorua, N.H. He was 86 years old.

title: LAKERS CLINCH TITLE
description: James Worthy scored a career-high 37 points as the Los Angeles Lakers, playing without Kareem Abdul-Jabbar and Jamaal Wilkes, beat the Portland Trail Blazers, 119-113, today and clinched their third straight Pacific Division title.

title: Ship-Freeing Move Weighed
description: The owners of the Caribbean cruise ship Rhapsody, which ran aground off Grand Cayman Island nearly two weeks ago, say they are considering dredging to free the 24,000-ton vessel from a coral reef. The operation calls for scooping out a slipway beside the ship to allow her to float free, Robert C. Smith, a spokesman for Paquet French Cruises, owner of the Miami-based Rhapsody, said this weekend.

title: DEVIL'S BAG TAKING A DIFFERENT ROUTE TO THE DERBY
description: When Devil's Bag arrived from Miami two weeks ago, New York was ready to give him a hero's welcome. He was a slightly fallen hero, his aura of greatness dimmed by having lost a race for the first time in his life three weeks earlier, but that made him all the more appealing and his fans more eager to cheer him.

title: MARY TYLER MOORE: A LATE-NIGHT CULT
description: At the time there were neatly lettered T-shirts that asked, ''Oh God, what are we going to do without Mary Tyler Moore?'' Now, seven years after the 168th and final episode of ''The Mary Tyler Moore Show,'' the answer is clear: Stay up till 3 o'clock in the morning watching the syndicated reruns.

title: Levels of Art
description: While Paloma Picasso was having

title: ARGENTINE FORGES WARMER U.S. TIES
description: In the fashionable drawing rooms of Argentina's conservative upper class and in the gritty halls of the country's powerful right-wing unions, the word for Foreign Minister Dante Caputo is ''Bolshy.'' That's short for Bolshevik.

title: Futures/Options; Trading Urged In C.R.B. Index
description: O F all the index markets that have been drawing futures traders in large numbers, none is as important as the one they can not trade. It is the Commodity Research Bureau index of futures prices. This index of 27 basic commodities has long been termed the ''futures Dow Jones'' by the industry and by people who consider it a key economic indicator.

title: ; THE UNFAIRNESS OF ANY TAX ON HOME TAPING
description: To the Eitor:

title: COURT DEPENDS ON SUASION
description: The International Court of Justice, often referred to as the World Court, is the main judicial organ of the United Nations. It has no machinery to enforce its decisions, depending instead on moral suasion and world opinion.

title: 4 Killed and 4 Hurt in Crash On Northern State Parkway
description: Four people were killed and four were injured in a crash that involved seven vehicles on the Northern State Parkway yesterday near Williston Park, L.I., the state police said.

title: Poll Says Many Voters Buy Hart's 'New Ideas'
description: In a comparison between Walter F. Mondale and Gary Hart, Democratic voters say they feel Senator Hart generates ''excitement,'' speaks for the younger generation of Americans and presents new ideas more than does former Vice President Mondale, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: PRESS IN COSTA RICA SAYS 4 U.S. CITIZENS DIED IN PLANE CRASH SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, April 8 (AP) - A Costa Rican newspaper reported Saturday that a DC-3 cargo plane had crashed in a mountainous area of the country two weeks ago, killing the four Americans and three Nicaraguans aboard. It said two of its reporters had found the wreckage of the plane.
description: The newspaper, La Prensa Libre, said the reporters found the charred debris on Friday about 75 miles northeast of San Jose on the San Carlos plateau, which is near Costa Rica's border with Nicaragua.

title: IN THE FAMILY
description: To the Editor: In your news story, the executive vice president of the Seven-Up Brook

title: TCHAIKOVSKY'S 'QUEEN OF SPADES'
description: JOHN J. O'CONNOR

title: MOSCOW'S GRIP ON AFGHANS
description: The general impression in the West is that the Russians are bogged down in Afghanistan. Even official Washington seems to believe that the Russians have made little progress since they intervened in 1979. In fact, the last four years have brought significant improvement in the Soviet position, and Moscow is now looking forward to the day when the Afghan rebels will be no more than a minor nuisance.

title: RANGERS AND FANS WARY BUT HOPEFUL
description: In the locker room and in the upper reaches of Madison Square Garden, where gloom descended as defeat became certain, the Rangers and their fans were forced to put aside their bravado and their hopes once again.

title: OSHA REGULATORY CHANGES: DEPARTING CHIEF PROUD, BUT CRITICISM PERSISTS
description: Thorne G. Auchter, a young Florida construction millionaire, took over the Occupational Safety and Health Administration in 1981 with a mandate from President Reagan to end what Mr. Auchter called nit-picking intrusions by the Federal Government in the workplace.

title: INDEPENDENT SUTTON LIKES CHANCES IN MASTERS
description: WHILE other boys his age were growing up with big dreams of playing on the winning team in the World Series, Super Bowl or college basketball's Final Four, Hal Sutton, the son of a wealthy Shreveport, La., oilman, was dreaming of victory in the Masters.

title: GIVING THE WIDOWED AN ARM TO LEAN ON
description: One of the saddest things about being widowed is the word ''widowed.''

title: KNICKS BEATEN ON ERVING SHOT
description: Julius Erving took only 3 shots in the second half, but the last one, a 16-foot jumper with 4 seconds remaining, gave the Philadelphia 76ers a 109-108 victory over the Knicks at the Spectrum today.

title: Plan Assailed By A.T.&T.
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company told Federal regulators late Friday that a plan developed by local phone companies to speed the introduction of telephone access charges would not solve the financial problems it is now facing.

title: NEW YORK FIRST HEARD WORK IN 1871 AT ACADEMY OF MUSIC
description: ''Mignon,'' Ambroise Thomas's most famous work, has been a staple of the French repertory for more than a century, but it has been in and out of favor elsewhere.

title: DISPUTE IS INTENSIFYING IN BUFFALO OVER WOMEN AS CITY FIREFIGHTERS
description: A longstanding dispute has escalated with a public statement by the city's Civil Service chief that ''fighting fires is not a task for women'' and angry responses from a range of city officials.

title: Lynn Tishman Weds London Bond Trader
description: Lynn Tishman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Tishman of New York, was married yesterday to Matthew Bloom, a son of Victor Bloom of London and the late Matilda Bloom. Rabbi Gunter Hirschberg performed the ceremony at Congregation Rodeph Sholom in New York.

title: NONPUBLIC DATA A FACTOR IN DISPUTE ON SHELL PRICE
description: ROBERT J. COLE

title: F.A.A. CHIEF: A SAFETY BIAS: DONALD D. ENGEN
description: Vice Adm. Donald D. Engen, U.S.N., retired, who takes over as head of the Federal Aviation Administration this week, is a former dive bomber pilot possessed of what he calls a ''safety bias.'' Admiral Engen, who replaces J. Lynn Helms as Administrator of the agency, was confirmed by the Senate without debate last week. The new Administrator is a member of the National Transportation Safety Board.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: The American Academy of Poets was founded 50 years ago in New York, and it is celebrating its half- century anniversary of improving the breed - of poets, that is - with a season of events involving its particular Muse. Two of these projects come to pass this week, appropriately enough, in two libraries.

title: A Runner No More
description: He rides a green three-speed bike on weekends around Hyde Park in London. He plays in an occasional nine holes of golf. And he has started sailing again.

title: Bridge ; TEAM OF STARS IS ELIMINATED IN A GRAND NATIONAL CONTEST
description: ALAN TRUSCOTT

title: 'Seneca Falls,' Dalton-Style
description: The learning experience was on

title: 5 EX-CITY POLICEMEN INVESTIGATED IN REPORTED SALE OF DATA TO MOB
description: Allegations that five former New York City policemen sold confidential police information to the nation's largest, most powerful crime organization are being investigated by Federal and city authorities, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: People
description: * Hy Yablonka joined Kenyon & Eckhardt, Los Angeles, as senior vice president, creative director.

title: Michele Beth Lippa Is Wed to Kenneth L. Gartner
description: Michele Beth Lippa, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Simon Lippa of East Meadow, L.I., was married yesterday to Kenneth Lawrence Gartner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Gartner of Elmont, L.I. Rabbi Samuel Kehati performed the ceremony at Congregation Beth Sholom in Lawrence, L.I., assisted by Cantor Marcus Ehrlich.

title: SPOTLIGHT ON 'VICTIMS'
description: To the Editor:

title: GUINEAN CHIEF SAYS NO FORMER OFFICIALS HAVE BEEN HARMED
description: The Guinean Army colonel who took power here in a coup last week said today that none of the officials of the ousted Government had been harmed and that none would be executed. He indicated that some of them would face trial.

title: CHALLENGER FAILS TO SEIZE SATELLITE FOR REPAIR EFFORT
description: The Challenger astronauts, try as they might with balky tools, a mechanical arm and even their gloved hands, failed in their ambitious attempt this morning to capture and repair the disabled Solar Max satellite more than 300 miles above the earth.

title: Hard to Keep Up
description: There are two constants about New York Knick basketball: one is that Bernard King will score a bundle of points and the other is that King's parents, Thomas and Thelma King, will be at courtside in Madison Square Garden cheering him on.

title: MISS BUDD NOT CERTAIN FOR GAMES
description: Zola Budd, the distance runner, might not be considered for Britain's Olympic team, according to the British Amateur Athletics Board secretary, Nigel Cooper.

title: 5-YEAR-OLD SOUTHERN NOVEL ENJOYS A SALES BOOM
description: YOU won't find ''The Dog of the South'' on any best-seller list. What's more, you are unlikely to find Charles Portis's five-year-old novel in any bookstore, North or South - with the exception of the Madison Avenue Bookshop on Manhattan's Upper East Side.

title: NUCLEAR PANEL STAFF CITES UTILITIES AS MISMANAGING SOME REACTORS
description: Bad management by utility companies is the root cause of major construction and design problems at some atomic reactor projects, Nuclear Regulatory Commission experts conclude.

title: CHERNENKO GIVES A GLOOMY SURVEY OF U.S.-SOVIET TIES
description: Konstantin U. Chernenko said today that despite occasional ''peaceloving rhetoric'' from Washington, he had discerned no concrete signs of readiness there to improve relations with Moscow.

title: NO HYPE. ISSUES, PLEASE.
description: For the first time, more women than men are registering to vote. They clearly have the power to elect a President committed to their priorities of life. But will the media and the men who run the campaigns allow the questions basic to the gender gap to be asked?

title: The Machine Tool War
description: Like many other American products, machine tools - the specialized, often automated equipment used to make everything from shell casings to surgical scissors - have recently encountered fierce competition from abroad. And like other industries, this one has pleaded for Government protection against foreign rivals.

title: '84 RACE FAR OFF TO 31 OHIO WORKERS
description: When they gathered in the lunchroom at noon, the workers in the small Colso food plant talked about horoscopes, the raw, rainy weather and planting rose bushes in the spring.

title: New Director Is Named For the Folger Library
description: Prof. Werner L. Gundersheimer, a Renaissance scholar at the University of Pennsylvania, has been named director of the Folger Shakespeare Library.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Salt Away More Oil
description: The American warships cruising around the Persian Gulf are meant to protect the oil lifeline to the West. A surer defense lies underground 8,000 miles away, in caverns carved from salt beneath the soil of Texas and Louisiana.

title: FIGURE IN INTERNATIONAL ESPIONAGE CASE SAYS SUSPECT IS USING HIM
description: A figure in an international espionage case has said he has never been a spy, asserting that a suspect in the case was seeking to frame him in hopes of obtaining a reduced prison sentence.

title: TRANSPORTATION DEPARTMENT RULE ON AIR BAGS MAY COME THURSDAY
description: After more than 14 years of road tests of air bags, arguments in courts and Congress, and lobbying, the Transportation Department is nearing a decision on whether the safety devices ought to be required on new cars.

title: PRESIDENT'S PLAN TO REDUCE BUDGET DEFICITS FACES SENATE OBSTACLES
description: The Republican leadership in the Senate, which intends to take up the President's $149 billion deficit-reduction package this week, faces a host of obstacles from Democrats and even some Republicans.

title: 4 Escapees Sought After 2 Are Recaptured
description: Four men who escaped from a Pennsylvania prison eluded a police manhunt for a second day today.

title: A Founder Steps Down As Chairman of ARA
description: William S. Fishman, a co-founder of ARA Services Inc., is stepping down as chairman of the Philadelphia-based company.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: With a man on first base and no one out, the batter hits a ground ball to the shortstop, who tosses it to second for one out. The second baseman throws to first for what appears to be an easy double play, but the runner from first deflects the ball with his hand. What is the ruling?

title: NEW YORK YOUNGSTERS TO STRUT STUFF AT OSCARS
description: Sometime during dinner at a McDonald's in his Washington Heights neighborhood, the wondrousness of it all caught up with 11-year-old Bruce Campbell. ''I was so excited I wanted to tell everyone in the restaurant, 'Hey, I'm going to the Academy Awards!' '' he said later.

title: HELPED VICTIMS OF HOLOCAUST
description: Brig. Gen. Julius Klein, retired, who worked with the West German Government to settle claims by victims of the Holocaust, died Friday in Great Lakes Naval Hospital in Great Lakes, Ill. He was 82 years old and lived in Chicago.

title: CREDITORS CONTEND DELOREAN DIVERTED MILLIONS TO HIS GAIN
description: Bankruptcy proceedings here involving John Z. DeLorean shed new light on the free- wheeling way he operated the DeLorean Motor Company. They have led to allegations that he sought to enrich himself at the company's expense.

title: Three in Texas Charged With Using Slave Labor
description: The investigation of a ranch family charged with kidnapping hitchhikers and enslaving them will intensify if bones discovered on the property are found to be human, officials said.

title: Addendum
description: * Y&R Direct, Los Angeles, changed its name to Wunderman West.

title: Iran and Iraq Report Successes in Gulf War
description: Iraqi warplanes struck at Iranian positions today and fighting on the ground in the southern sector of the war front left 34 Iranian soldiers dead, a communique by the Iraqi military command said.

title: The U.N. Today April 9, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: HOMELESS ASLIGN FOR 'DIGNITY' AT A PHILADELPHIA CONVENTION
description: David Jamison describes himself as ''just an ordinary man trying to make it in society.'' Though he has a high school diploma and clerical experience, he is homeless and without a job at the age of 26.

title: On the Record ; Mondale Poll Taker on Polls
description: From remarks by Peter D. Hart, poll taker for Walter F. Mondale, to the Center for National Policy, Monday in Washington:

title: THE CONVERSATIONS IN SPACE AS RESCUE FAILED
description: Following are excerpts from the conversations today between Dr. George D. (Pinky) Nelson and Capt. Robert L. Crippen of the space shuttle Challenger and later between Jerry Ross in Houston and Dr. Nelson.

title: CARTER HAWLEY GIRDS FOR FIGHT
description: The battle lines in retailing's biggest takeover move to date tightened during the weekend, fueled by indications that Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. - the target - was actively seeking a friendlier suitor and was considering making a bid to acquire The Limited Inc. - the intended acquirer.

title: MILTON KIMMELMAN, HOTELIER
description: DAVID BIRD

title: OBEY CAPTAIN DISASTER
description: The Reagan Presidency has never been more clearly defined than it was in the first week of April 1984. Events threw sharp light on its political and moral premises.

title: DANCE: ATLANTA BALLET IN BROOKLYN
description: JENNIFER DUNNING

title: 32-1 Shot Takes Santa Anita Derby
description: Mighty Adversary, a 32-to-1 shot ridden by Eddie Delahoussaye, scored an upset in the $302,200 Santa Anita Derby by rallying in the stretch to beat Precisionist, the 11-to-10 favorite, by 1 1/4 lengths.

title: Reagan Aide Calls U.S. Ready to Resume Talks
description: A Reagan Administration official said today that the United States was ready to resume arms reduction talks with the Soviet Union, but is not prepared to pay any price to get Moscow to return to the bargaining table.

title: Aaron Connects Once More
description: It took 16 pitches and a souped-up ball, but Hammerin' Hank Aaron delivered a home run today in the re-enactment of his 715th homer 10 years ago that broke Babe Ruth's record.

title: PYGMALION IN THE GYM: EXPECTATIONS FULFILLED
description: WILL the expectations of coaches affect physical performance such as speed of foot and length of jump - regardless of the actual skills of the athletes?

title: INTEREST RATES MOVE LOWER
description: Interest rates fell yesterday, with the biggest decline coming in the Treasury bill market, where rates for outstanding issues fell by a tenth of a percentage point or more as prices for the securities rose.

title: Trinity Makes Bid For Texas Federal
description: The Texas Federal Financial Corporation said that its board had unanimously accepted an offer to be acquired by Trinity Banc Savings Association for $44 a share.

title: LANDMARKS' AIRSPACE IN NEED OF PROTECTION
description: To the Editor:

title: The Perils of a Prop
description: The veiled, lavender hat that Kitty

title: Campbell Happier
description: The running back Earl Campbell , who demanded to be traded last season, said he has resolved his problems with the Houston Oilers and hoped to spend the next four years in their backfield. Campbell joined the other Oilers in a three-day mini-camp after a meeting with Ladd Herzeg , the general manager.

title: SLANTING OF AMERICA NEWS IS CHARGED
description: A Cuban-American spokesman, reflecting fears of a Congressional cutoff of aid to Central America, told Central American government and business leaders here today that they should try to correct what he called the media-distorted picture of the situation in the region.

title: HELENE CURTIS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split in the fourth quarter of fiscal 1984.

title: SCOWCROFT PESSIMISTIC ON SOVIET TIES
description: The chairman of President Reagan's Commission on Strategic Forces said today that Administration oratory ''has certainly given the Soviet Union a negative view'' of the chances for achieving progress in arms negotiations with Mr. Reagan.

title: Prison Terms for 2 In F.A.L.N. Case
description: Two Puerto Ricans who advocate independence for their island were sentenced in Brooklyn yesterday to two years in prison for refusing to testify before a Federal grand jury looking into bombings for which the F.A.L.N. has taken responsibility.

title: BUSH FAULTS DEMOCRATS AS FAILING TO DEAL WITH ANTI-SEMITISM ISSUE
description: Democrats working on a 1984 platform found that papering over differences may not be easy. Page B9.

title: Occidental's Plan
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said it estimated that 1984 capital spending would total $1 billion, down from $1.2 billion in 1983.

title: BLACK SCHOOL GETS $1 MILLION IN GIFTS
description: Since late November, Fisk University has received more than $1 million from a spontaneous burst of support aimed at helping the private, 117-year-old, historically black college keep its doors open.

title: LOSS OF BECK IS COSTLY
description: The Rangers looked around their dressing room after practice yesterday afternoon and grasped the reality.

title: BROKER IN INQUIRY RESIGNS
description: Citing the ''time-consuming distraction'' of an investigation being conducted by the Securities and Exchange Commission, Peter N. Brant submitted his resignation yesterday to Kidder, Peabody & Company.

title: Article 113220 -- No Title
description: At least $2.7 million in $50 and $100 demoninations was stolen over the weekend in a burglary at a Nevada National Bank branch, the authorities said today. ''A trusted employee'' and her boyfriend were being sought for questioning, the authorities said. All the money in a cash vault was taken.

title: MARRIOTT CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 23
An O'Neal's to Be Sold
description: When O'Neal's/43d restaurant

title: Market Place; 2 Managers' Investing Style
description: SECURITIES prices go up and down, but one constant in the life of a money manager is tending client portfolios. What follows is a description of the current market approach of two professional managers who like stocks with low price-earnings ratios and a superior return on capital, but otherwise differ in investment styles, partly because of the needs of their respective clienteles.

title: State Inquiry On Charter Annuities
description: The New York Insurance Superintendent's office said it is investigating whether brokers illegally sold annuities that were issued by a subsidiary of the Charter Company.

title: HIPOTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 3
description: b-Net loss.

title: 'KILLING FLOOR,' AMERICAN WORKERS
description: PUBLIC TELEVISION'S ''American Playhouse'' series is stretching its acquisition boundaries a bit further these days in an effort to flesh out a full season. Tonight's presentation on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock is ''The Killing Floor,'' a two-hour film that is really a pilot for a proposed separate series about American workers.

title: Injured Bystander To Get $1.5 Million
description: A 34-year-old bystander shot by a moonlighting police officer during an Upper West Side bank robbery will be paid $1.5 million in an out-of-court settlement announced yesterday.

title: Elaine Powers Backs New Fitness Magazine
description: Feelin' Good is the name of a new magazine being published here with the support of the Elaine Powers organization.

title: No Headline
description: Measure Seeks to Curb Violent Pornography

title: CONSUMERS FINANCIAL CORPORATION reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest year include a gain on investments equivalent to 4 cents a share.

title: Iran Says It Repulsed Effort By Iraq to Retake Marsh Area
description: Iraqi forces in boats and helicopters attacked the Majnoon Islands on Sunday but were driven back, Iran's official press agency reported today.

title: LION RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $6,742. c-Net loss.

title: U. S. Industries Buyout Is Backed
description: U. S. Industries said a special committee of its board had decided to recommend acceptance of a leveraged buyout organized by Kelso & Company for $24 a share, or a total of more than $530 million. The acquiring company would be owned by a group to be organized that would consist of company employees, Kelso and other investors. U. S. Industries makes industrial equipment, clothing, furniture and lighting products.

title: WILLIAMS HELPS KNICKS DOWN CAVALIERS
description: The shooting touch that deserted Ray Williams 10 games ago returned last night to bolster the Knicks, who have not been able to sustain themselves recently on Bernard King's offense alone.

title: TEXTBOOKS CRITICIZED AS SIMPLISTIC AND DULL
description: SHORTLY after James B. Conant stepped down as president of Harvard University, he traveled around the country in 1959 to enlist support for his school reform proposals. As he crisscrossed the country Mr. Conant, who had a Ph.D. in chemistry, often dropped in on chemistry classes. Only half in jest, he told an associate that he could do his daily sampling in any school on the way without ever skipping a lesson.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: WEST TO EAST

title: CITY TO RENOVATE SHEA STADIUM, ADDING SEATS AND ARTIFICIAL TURF
description: Renovation plans for Shea Stadium, including the installation of artificial turf, additional stands in center field and luxury boxes, will be announced today by Mayor Koch.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Herman Kull , an assistant coach of the Nets, was listed in guarded condition at Beth Israel Medical Center in Newark after undergoing double bypass heart surgery. Kull suffered a heart attack Feb. 23, and had been in and out of the hospital since. . . . Kelvin Bryant , the Philadelphia Stars' running back who was the United States Football League's most valuable player last year, underwent arthroscopic surgery on his right knee yesterday and will be lost to the team for at least two and possibly four weeks. . . . Cocaine possession charges against the boxer Aaron Pryor were dropped at a prelminary hearing yesterday in Municipal Court in Inglewood, Calif., said Pryor's publicist, Booker Griffin .

title: PEREZ OF THE BRAVES RELEASED FROM JAIL
description: Pascual Perez of the Atlanta Braves was released today from Fort San Luis prison in Santiago, where he had been held for three months.

title: SYRIAN POLICY: WINNERS IN LEBANON LOOK PUZZLED
description: Less than a month after the withdrawal of the last elements of the multinational force from Lebanon, many Lebanese officials and Western diplomats here say the Syrian Government of President Hafez al-Assad seems confused and uncertain about how to deal with the crisis it has inherited.

title: OPERA: 'MIGNON,' WITH FREDERICA VON STADE
description: AMBROISE THOMAS'S ''MIGNON,'' once beloved of audiences and singers alike, slipped into obscurity in this country about 30 years ago, probably because of its outrageously sentimental and improbable plot, which would embarrass a soap-opera scenarist. Certainly its music alone is not bad enough to account for its disappearance. In fact, the score is quite fetching, disarmingly direct in its appeal to the ear and the operagoer's tender heart. Many composers of more prestigious works would kill to have written half a dozen of the best numbers in ''Mignon.'' The score is full of sweet airs and dazzling display pieces that stick firmly in the memory, which is what good melodies are supposed to do, after all.

title: On the Record ; Mayor Koch on Foreign Policy
description: From remarks by Mayor Koch yesterday at a hearing of the platform committee of the Democratic National Committee at the Sheraton Center Hotel:

title: Prime Minister Resigns In Peru Over Policies
description: The Prime Minister of Peru has resigned in the midst of the country's deepening economic crisis.

title: FABRIC WHOLESALERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago share earnings have been restated for a 2-for-1 stock split as of June 1983.

title: 31 CHARGED BY U.S. WITH RUNNING A 1.65 BILLION HEROIN OPERATION
description: Federal authorities charged 31 men yesterday with operating an organized- crime ring that has brought $1.65 billion worth of heroin into the United States since 1979.

title: SENATE, IN CONFUSION, BEGINS DEBATE ON REAGAN DEFICIT CUT
description: The Senate began debating President's Reagan's deficit reduction plan today, while the Senate Budget Committee commenced writing a budget proposal that could conflict with the White House proposal.

title: INTERCO INCORPORATED reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
MOSCOW CHARGES ANTI-SOVIET BIAS AT OLYMPIC GAMES
description: The Soviet Olympic Committee charged today that an anti-Soviet campaign was taking shape for the Games in Los Angeles this summer and asked for an emergency session of the International Olympic Committee to look into security and to demand American adherence to the Olympic charter.

title: CONTINENTAL INFORMATION SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
TAX-EXEMPT GROUP MADE NO GIFTS TO CHARITY
description: The Preservation of American Free Enterprise Inc., a tax-exempt organization with which two men involved in a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation have been connected, used all its money to hold social events and made no charitable contributions of any sort, according to New York State records.

title: No Carter Hawley Countermoves Yet
description: The board of Carter Hawley Hale Stores met in Los Angeles but ended it meeting without announcing plans to counter a $1.1 billion takeover bid by The Limited Inc., a retailer based in Columbus, Ohio.

title: ANTHES INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a loss of $20,999,000 from discontinued operations.

title: TINY PARASITE BLAMED IN DEVASTATING DISEASE
description: A TINY parasite that seemed to be only a curiosity a few years ago is now coming to be recognized as an important factor in human disease. The parasite, a protozoa called cryptosporidium, which causes an illness called cryptosporidiosis, was discovered in a mouse at Harvard in 1907. But the parasite was not linked to human disease until 1976 - and ever since then it has been a source of increasing concern.

title: Increase Reported In Afghan War Wounded
description: The number of Afghan war wounded crossing into Pakistan has risen steadily since the end of last year, and 2,800 underwent treatment in the first two months of 1984, the International Committee of the Red Cross said today.

title: Orange Harvest Off
description: The orange harvest as of April 1 was estimated at 176.4 million boxes, down slightly from the 177.1 million forecast a month ago and 22 percent less than last season, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: TUESDAY, APRIL 10, 1984 International
description: Nicaragua asked the World Court to declare illegal United States support for guerrilla raids on its territory and what it said was Washington's role in the mining of its harbors. The State Department said it had pre-empted the complaint filed in The Hague by filing papers Friday to deprive the tribunal of jurisdiction to consider the matter for at least two years. (Page A1, Column 6.) The House will not approve the Reagan Administration's request for $21 million in new aid for Nicaraguan rebels, the Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., said. He and Representative Jim Wright, the majority leader, said reports of the involvement of the Central Intelligence Agency in the mining of Nicaraguan harbors had killed any chance that the measure would be approved. The Republican-controlled Senate passed the bill last week. (A1:5.)

title: COMPANIES CHARGED IN ILLEGAL DUMPING OF TOXIC CHEMICALS
description: Seven Brooklyn companies that clean and recycle steel drums have been charged with illegally dumping and mishandling toxic wastes, Mayor Koch announced yesterday.

title: STATE WINS HIGHER RATING FOR ITS SHORT-TERM NOTES
description: New York State won an improvement today in a key rating of its short-term notes amid a warning that the state has yet to address some long-term financial problems.

title: A First Step Back
description: Jim Eisenreich , the center fielder for the Minnesota Twins, is working with a hypnotist and taking the first step toward overcoming a nervous disorder that threatened to end his baseball career. The problem, which included such symptoms as twitching and hyperventilating, limited him to 34 games as a rookie in 1982.

title: UNESCO CHIEF SAYS U.S. SENDS MIXED SIGNALS ON PULING OUT
description: The Director General of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization said here today that he had been receiving mixed signals about whether the United States intended to withdraw from the group.

title: DIAMOND-BATHURST INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A Primary Puzzle
description: Mayor Koch is, well, puzzled. He endorsed Walter F. Mondale in New York's Democratic Presidential primary, three weeks before the primary but months after another prominent New Yorker, Governor Cuomo.

title: WORK FIRST PRESENTED IN 1866
description: ''Mignon,'' Ambroise Thomas's most famous work, has been a staple of the French repertory for more than a century, but it has been in and out of favor elsewhere.

title: HOW NEXT FALL'S TV LOOKS
description: Television programs that blend comedy with adventure and shows that feature female crime fighters and New Yorkers predominate these days in the ideas for series being considered by the three television networks as they plan their season schedules for next fall.

title: FOR SENIOR APPOINTEES, THE BACKGROUND CHECK
description: To Representative Tony Coelho, it seems perfectly obvious.

title: NICARAGUA TAKES CASE AGAINST U.S. TO WORLD COURT
description: Nicaragua asked the World Court today to declare illegal United States support for guerrilla raids on its territory and what it said was Washington's role in the mining of Nicaraguan harbors.

title: NORTHWESTERN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
U.S. Inspecting Subway Tracks
description: Nine Federal track inspectors began a two-week inspection yesterday of more than 100 miles of New York City subway track.

title: Mitsubishi Korean Deal
description: The Mitsubishi Motors Corporation said today that it planned a joint venture with the Hyundai Motor Company of South Korea to develop a compact car for the Korean domestic market. Mitsubishi said the two companies had applied jointly to the Seoul Government for participation in a national car project.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE POWER TO LEAD. The Crisis of the

title: Accounts
description: * Scali, McCabe, Sloves named volunteer agency for the American Diabetes Association.

title: U.S. VATICAN ENVOY RECEIVED BY POPE
description: The first United States Ambassador to the Vatican in more than 100 years presented his credentials to Pope John Paul II today.

title: MUSHROOMS ENSNARE PREY
description: THERE are more than 100 mushroom species that capture and digest small animals such as nematodes, microscopic ground-dwelling worms. But how the mushroom captures and digests its prey was not fully understood.

title: No Headline
description: Police Dept. Will Ask Officers About Loans

title: People
description: * Doris Gould has been promoted to senior vice president, broadcast director at Laurence, Charles & Free.

title: N.A.A.C.P.'s Counsel To Leave Office in July
description: Thomas Atkins has resigned as general counsel of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People to return to private law practice.

title: Lois, Pitts Gets Part Of USA Today Account
description: Young & Rubicam has lost part of the USA Today account to Lois, Pitts, Gershon, which has always had special strengths in media promotion.

title: TROTTIER HIT BY PENALTIES
description: In what has become a great, and physical, playoff hockey series, the most penalized player has turned out to be Bryan Trottier, of all people.

title: MARSH & MCLENNAN LOSS ON BONDS
description: The Marsh & McLennan Companies, a diversified insurance brokerage holding company, said yesterday in a terse statement that it would take an extraordinary after-tax charge of approximately $60 million for the first quarter of 1984 to reflect expected losses in Government bond positions accumulated by a staff trader.

title: A Dual Financing By Toledo Edison
description: Today the Toledo Edison Company is offering $70 million of 15 percent bonds due in 1991 at a price of 100 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A chart in Metropolitan Report yesterday on goals proposed by a citizens' commission for upgrading city services erroneously labeled the middle column. The data in that column were for the fiscal year ended June 30, 1983.

title: METS' TOUGH LEADOFF HITTER
description: ATLANTA When Dave Johnson was playing second base for the Baltimore Orioles, he spent a lot of time feeding statistics into a computer at Johns Hopkins University to develop something he called ''optimization of the Orioles' lineup.'' He presented it to Earl Weaver, the manager, who tossed it into the wastebasket.

title: Parker Out of Coma
description: Jack Parker Jr., the 28-year-old harness driver who suffered a fractured skull and other serious injuries in a five-horse spill at the Meadowlands Race Track last March 20, has emerged from a coma and has been listed in good condition, an official at Hackensack (N.J.) Medical Center said yesterday. ''He's been taken off the respirator,'' said Lisa Hoffman , the hospital official.

title: Banks Meeting On Polish Debt
description: Representatives of Poland's major commercial bank creditors will meet here Tuesday for another round of talks on rescheduling the country's debt, banking sources said today.

title: MOZAMBICAN UNITS BATTLE GUERRILLAS
description: Mozambican Government forces were said today to have begun a major operation in the south of the country after an incursion by up to 1,000 guerrillas from South Africa.

title: Stocks Are Mixed as Trading Slows
description: Stock prices finished mixed yesterday in much slower trading. Equities responding to specific news registered the biggest price moves.

title: 4 More Convicts Escape From Tennessee Prison
description: Gov. Lamar Alexander called out the National Guard to search for three convicts serving life terms who escaped from Fort Pillow Prison today, less than two months after another major jailbreak. Two of the men are convicted killers.

title: NEW TACTIC GIVEN CREDIT FOR ARRESTS
description: Federal authorities say a new tactic in fighting organized crime has resulted in the arrests in the last 10 days of two of New York City's top organized-crime leaders.

title: A DIRECTOR OF FILMS AND TV 3 DECADES
description: The director Jack Donohue, whose work ranged from M-G-M musicals with Shirley Temple to pioneering efforts in live television and location filming, has died of a heart attack at the age of 75.

title: MUSIC: BRITISH QUARTET
description: THE Fitzwilliam String Quartet of Britain returned to the Metropolitan Museum on Friday night with a fancifully conceived program of music. First came Charles Ives's Second Quartet and the Shostakovich Eighth, and at the end, some very different music - Franck's String Quartet in D.

title: Harmon Is Lost for 6 Weeks
description: The right ankle that Clarence Harmon injured Sunday in the Generals' victory over the Showboats here is fractured, and Coach Walt Michaels said today that he would miss at least six weeks.

title: DEMOCRAT, PEACEMAKER: GERALDINE ANNE FERRARO
description: At a Democratic Party meeting in Washington several years ago, there was an argument over how many elected officials should be allowed to go to the national convention as uncommitted delegates. The fight, which boiled down to a dispute over the numbers of white male politicians who would have a place on the convention floor, involved two women, United States Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro of Queens and State Representative Cleta Deatherage Mitchell of Oklahoma. Mrs. Ferraro won. In hindsight Mrs. Mitchell recalled that her opponent ''was very calm and respectful of other people's views.''

title: FOR APRIL SHOWERS AND SUNSHINE
description: The sun sparkles and the winter coats are quickly doffed, in homage to spring, which seems so late this year. The showers come again and the raincoats return, a few in gaily colored plastic, more in conventional tan shades. ''The most useful coat in my wardrobe,'' according to innumerable women stopped as they were shopping, sauntering to meet a friend for lunch or hurrying to their office during the quick-change weather of the first week of April. ''I've worn it so much the past few weeks, I'm afraid I will wear it out,'' said a woman clutching her Burberry in a brisk wind. ''I never thought that would happen,'' she said.

title: CITY'S FEES ON SOFTBALL UNDER FIRE
description: It was a perfect day for softball yesterday, and a few players limbered up under cloudless skies on Heckscher Field at 62d Street in Central Park. But softball was not only being played in the park, it was also under serious discussion there.

title: Advertising; McCaffrey Appoints a President
description: HENRY P. BERNHARD, having resigned as vice chairman from the domestic operation of Ogilvy & Mather, has joined McCaffrey & McCall as president and chief operating officer, a post vacant since 1977.

title: Cameroon Says a Leader Of Uprising Was Caught
description: Authorities in Cameroon arrested a colonel who was one of the leaders of the unsuccessful coup last week in which scores of people were killed, the Government-run Cameroon radio said today.

title: A Record Entrepreneur Plans Cheap Air Fares
description: Richard Branson, a 33-year-old British record industry entrepreneur who has been licensed by the British Civil Aviation Authority to start trans-Atlantic airline service, says his goal is to fill the gap left by the bankruptcy of Sir Freddie Laker's Skytrain operation in 1982.

title: I.B.M. Talks With Italians
description: An Italian electronics and telecommunications holding company is involved in ''advanced'' negotiations with the International Business Machines Corporation over a possible cooperation agreement, an official of the Italian company said today.

title: SMITH URGES TEXAS LAWYER FOR JUSTICE DEPT. POST
description: Attorney General William French Smith has advised President Reagan to nominate the former head of the Justice Department's lands and natural resources division, Carol E. Dinkins, as Deputy Attorney General, Administration officials said today.

title: FIRST UNION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CHURCH'S FRIED CHICKEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 18
2 WOMEN GO TO JAIL TO PROTECT ANOTHER'S CASH
description: Two grandmothers described by friends as sweet, God-fearing and stubborn, spent more than four days in jail for refusing to tell a county judge where another woman had hidden her money.

title: MAJOR STUDY ASSESSES THE CHILDREN OF DIVORCE By SANDRA BLAKESLEE
description: CHILDREN who are very young when their parents divorce fare better psychologically than their older brothers and sisters, according to the longest study of divorced families ever made.

title: COURTING A NEW ARMS RACE
description: President Reagan began the year with professions of good faith on arms control. But on a key test of this new conciliatory tone - the control of space weapons - he continues to stonewall.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: TUESDAY, APRIL 10,1984

title: BRIEFS
description: * AMAX Inc., a minerals and energy company in Greenwich, Conn., said it had completed an agreement with Britoil P.L.C. of Britain to form a joint venture to explore and develop U.S. oil and gas properties

title: Sumitomo in Paris Pact
description: The French Government said today that it had agreed to let Sumitomo Rubber Industries Ltd. of Japan take over the bankrupt French unit of the Dunlop tire group of Britain despite a last- minute counterbid from a French- Italian consortium. Sumitomo, which did not seek French financial assistance, agreed to guarantee the jobs of 3,800 of Dunlop France's 5,580 employees. Financial details were not immediately made public.

title: SCOUTING;
description: Parcells Not Sure

title: JUDY'S INC reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Allied's Spending
description: The Allied Corporation said it expects to spend a record $831 million on capital projects in 1984, up 37 percent from last year. It said the most significant increases are in its oil and gas and chemical sectors, though capital spending in its aerospace, automotive and industrial and technology sectors will also top 1983's levels. Allied said its capital spending is separate from planned 1984 research and development spending of $430 million, which will be up about 10 percent from 1983.

title: ACCORD ON A COMPUTER-CRIME BILL
description: State Attorney General Robert Abrams and key lawmakers announced an agreement today on legislation to make it a crime to break into computers.

title: FIRST CITY FINANCIAL (NEW MEXIO) (O) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income. Results reflect provisions for loan losses of approximately $3 million for the latest first quarter and $454,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: INTERNATIONAL LEASE FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
UNION'S SUCCESS AT YALE: NEW FOCUS ON WHITE-COLLAR WOMEN
description: The union drive by Yale University clerical and technical workers that resulted in a contract with the university last week was unusual among American unions.

title: Copter Is Reported Downed
description: The Nicaraguan Embassy asserted today that a helicopter carrying three Americans had been shot down earlier in the day in Jalapa, Nicaragua. Angella Saballos, the embassy spokesman, said she had no further details on the reported incident. Spokesmen for the Pentagon and the Central Intelligence Agency said they had no knowledge of a helicopter being shot down over Nicaragua.

title: HETRA COMPUTER & COMMUNICATIONS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
MONDALE STRESSES ECONOMIC ISSUES IN A TOUR OF 5 PENNSYLVANIA TOWNS
description: After flying to five cities in as many hours, logging 621 miles over Pennsylvania, the candidate was getting a little testy. At an airport news conference here this afternoon, Walter F. Mondale was asked how he thought he would fare in Tuesday's primary.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Cadbury-Schweppes, the British candy and beverage company, plans to raise at least $75 million in a United States offering of American depository receipts.

description: b-Net income

title: DUVALL AND MISS MACLAINE HONORED
description: As most of the movie industry had expected, ''Terms of Endearment'' - a tragicomedy about the relationship of a mother and daughter over a period of 30 years - took the lion's share of the major Academy Awards tonight. Paramount's ''Terms of Endearment'' collected five awards - best picture, director, screenplay, Shirley MacLaine as best actress and Jack Nicholson as best supporting actor - in the 56th annual ceremonies at the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion of the Los Angeles Music Center.

title: PLANT IS AWARDED $1.5 MILLION FOR TOXIC DAMAGE
description: The Onan Corporation has been awarded $1.5 million for damage suffered by hazardous chemical wastes that are contaminating part of its property in a suburb of Minneapolis.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption in Metropolitan Report yesterday with an article about Great Neck South High School misidentified two students working with computers. They were Jordan Orange and Jessica Spero.

title: RUBBERMAID INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
OPERATION SALVAGE IS BEGUN IN JERSEY
description: The corner of Long Acre Road and Cole Road emerged from the floods today, a tiny island in a neighborhood of water and split-level homes.

title: CHASE PLANS FOR INTERSTATE DEPOSIT-TAKING
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation plans to ask Federal regulators soon to allow it to accept deposits in bank offices in eight states, according to company and Government officials.

description: It was not a glamorous goal and it

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: COMMON MARKET FAILS TO RESOLVE CRISIS
description: Another attempt to resolve the European Common Market's financial crisis failed tonight, according to European officials at negotiations here.

title: REDS DEFEAT EXPOS, 9-6
description: Nick Esasky of the Reds drove in three runs and Duane Walker hit a two-run homer as Cincinnati beat the Montreal Expos, 9-6, tonight.

title: CHINA, RECEPTIVE TO FASHION, CHOOSES FIRST MODELS
description: When Xu Ping was approached at her job in a button factory and invited to become a fashion model, she was surprised and not very happy. Miss Xu, knowing only about artificial mannequins in department-store windows, did not think that she could stand still that long.

title: Dow Chemical Buys 3 Stocks WASHINGTON, April 9 -
description: The Dow Chemical Company

title: Marriott Net Up 19.8%
description: The Marriott Corporation reported today that it had net income of $23 million for the first quarter, a 19.8 percent increase from $19.2 million in the comparable 1983 period.

title: Blanton to Go to Jail May 3
description: Former Gov. Ray Blanton of Tennessee was ordered today to begin serving a three-year prison term on May 3 for peddling liquor licenses. The order was issued by Judge Bailey Brown of the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Mr. Blanton was found guilty of extortion, conspiracy and mail fraud on June 9, 1981, and was given a three-year sentence and an $11,000 fine.

title: UNITED STATES TRUCK LINES INC OF DELAWARE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FORMER COUNTERSPY FOR THE ARMY IS INDICTED ON SUBVERSION CHARGES
description: A Federal grand jury today indicted a former Army counterintelligence officer on charges of selling the Soviet Union information about six American double- agent operations aimed at penetrating the K.G.B., the Soviet state security agency.

title: DEVELCON ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Net income
