description: IN an unusual experiment involving birds, plants and mammals, ornithologists from the

title: INTERFIRST SLUMPS BY 74.3%
description: The Interfirst Corporation, citing problem loans in the energy industry, disclosed yesterday that net income fell 74.3 percent in the first quarter of 1984, to $9.6 million, or 14 cents a share, from $37.4 million, or 68 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: Hanoi Denounces U.S.-China 'Strategy'
description: Vietnam charged today that recent battles along the China-Vietnam and Cambodia-Thailand borders were linked to a ''global strategy'' by Peking and Washington to stem the spread of Communism.

title: GARY HART OFFERS LABOR ASSURANCES
description: With Tuesday's Pennsylvania primary a critical point in his candidacy, Senator Gary Hart spent much of today trying to assure labor that he had not voted against its interests.

title: Guilty in Frigitemp Suit
description: George G. Davis, a one-time vice president of the now-defunct Frigitemp Corporation and president of its environmental and energy division, was found guilty of Federal conspiracy charges, William M. Tendey, Acting United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, said yesterday.

title: EXILED HONDURAN CHIEF ASKS TO RETURN HOME
description: The ousted chief of the Honduran armed forces asked permission today to return home, asserting that he was removed unconstitutionally from the country in handcuffs, according to a congressional official.

title: A 'LEGALLY AND LOGICALLY SOUND' RENT STABILIZATION CODE
description: To the Editor:

title: Sales Slow for Tandem Computers
description: Tandem Computers Inc. reported today an unexpected slowdown in sales, prompting an investor selloff of Tandem stock that erased more than $200 million from the company's market value of $970 million.

title: Kingman Happy With the A's
description: Dave Kingman, who has elated teams with towering home runs and depressed them with 1,457 strikeouts in 13 major league seasons, seems to have found an understanding manager in Steve Boros of the Oakland A's.

title: SHUTTLE SET FOR NEW EFFORT TO CAPTURE AILING SATELLITE
description: The Challenger astronauts, given a ''fighting chance'' to turn failure into triumph, plan to try again Tuesday to grab the crippled Solar Max satellite and haul it aboard the space shuttle for the first repair job in high orbit.

title: DOW JONES & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FERRIS MEGARITY
description: Ferris Megarity, publicity director and director of import merchandising at B. Altman & Company, the department store, died of a heart attack last Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 59 years old.

title: LANE TELECOMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Curbs on Smoking Debated in Suffolk
description: A resolution that would require Suffolk County restaurants and work places to designate no-smoking areas drew opposing testimony from the Tobacco Institute and a group of high school students today.

title: BUSINESS PHONE FEE IS FOUGHT
description: House members opposed to a monthly telephone access charge scheduled to take effect for business customers on June 13 asked the Federal Communications Commission today for a one- year delay.

title: Death-Penalty Dispute
description: A continuing argument among Supreme Court justices was revived yesterday at New York University's law school by Justice Thurgood Marshall.

title: ROCK: MIDNIGHT OIL VISITS
description: MANY rock groups style themselves as rebels, but the Australian band Midnight Oil, which played last Friday at the Ritz, has a genuine defiant streak.

title: Federal Complaint On Asbestos Filed
description: The Federal Environmental Protection Agency has filed a civil complaint against Waterbury public schools for failing to meet asbestos safety standards.

title: POPE NAMES A PHILIDELPHIA PRIEST AND AFRICAN CARDINAL TO TOP JOBS
description: The Vatican announced today that Pope John Paul II had reorganized parts of the Curia, the Roman Catholic Church's central administration, naming an American monsignor and an African cardinal to key posts.

title: ALTEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
Digital Expands Its Line
description: The Digital Equipment Company yesterday introduced a more powerful version of its Rainbow 100 personal computer, as well as several new products that allow Rainbow machines to be integrated with other computer systems.

title: Topics On the Move
description: Moody Smiles

title: Firefighters Make Contract Requests
description: The firefighters' union submitted proposals for a contract yesterday, calling for ''substantial'' pay increases and an increase of 10 percent of their base pay for exposure to materials that are toxic when they burn.

title: AMERICAN SECURITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
VALUES REGAIN THEIR POPULARITY
description: PAUL MECK, a guidance counselor in the elementary schools of Mechanicsburg, Pa., near Harrisburg, spends about half his time going from class to class leading discussions on such topics as honesty and friendship.

title: Beverly Hills Savings Deal Off
description: Triangle Industries said today that it had broken off a previously announced agreement to acquire the Beverly Hills Savings and Loan Association. The agreement had been designed to fend off a takeover of Beverly Hills Savings by a dissident shareholder, Paul Amir.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Carlton Amdahl Quitting Trilogy
description: Carlton Amdahl, a major participant along with his better-known father, Gene Amdahl, in the quest to design an advanced supercomputer at Trilogy Ltd., announced yesterday that he was resigning his positions at the company.

title: SPACE MICROWAVE LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Net loss

title: 3 WIND UP BATTLE FOR PENNSYLVANIA
description: The Democratic Presidential candidates made their final campaign marches through Pennsylvania today in preparation for a primary Tuesday that marks an end to the first phase of the battle for the nomination.

title: METS REACTIVATE GIBBONS, CATCHER
description: The Mets arrived in Atlanta today with a four- game winning streak and promptly restored John Gibbons to the roster from the disabled list to strengthen their catching and hitting.

title: President Maps Visit To Missouri and Texas
description: President Reagan will travel to Kansas City, Mo., and Dallas Wednesday and Thursday to spotlight the accomplishments of his economic recovery program, the White House announced today.

title: Freed Man Is Offered Free Chicken for Life
description: Lenell Geter, the black engineer who served 19 months of a lifetime sentence in prison for robbery before being cleared, has received an offer of a lifetime of free fried chicken from a restaurant he was once suspected of robbing.

title: ELECTRO-CATHETER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
STATE TO CURB MEDICAL STUDENTS FROM ABROAD
description: American students enrolled in ''unapproved'' foreign medical schools will be prevented from completing their medical education in New York teaching hospitals, the New York State Health Department said yesterday.

title: Bechtel in China Accord
description: The Bechtel Group Inc., an engineering company based in San Francisco, signed a $3 million joint venture agreement today with the state- owned China National Coal Development Corporation. The New China News Agency said the new company, China American International Engineering Inc., would work on coal mines, pipelines, engineering, energy and communications projects.

title: FOREIGN SERVICE WIVES' GOAL: PAY
description: For years, the Foreign Service couple was considered a ''twofer'' - two for the price of one.

title: 50th Anniversary Of a Record Wind
description: Wendell Stephenson awakened at 4 A.M. on April 12, 1934, with a sense that the howling wind outside the Mount Washington Observatory was blowing harder than he had ever heard it. Mr. Stephenson, then a 25-year-old weather observer, checked some instruments, but when he got wind speeds at only 100 miles an hour he figured ice was blocking the anemometer, or wind meter. He knew he would have to climb up on the roof and hack off the ice with a club.

title: KING PROMOTED IN YANK SHIFT
description: For the last few months, player agents and executives of other clubs have been confused about the Yankees' front office, often asking whom they should call about free agents or trades. George Steinbrenner finally provided the answer yesterday, clearing away the confusion by naming Clyde King the general manager.

title: FLOCK INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $510,000 for the latest year and $113,000 for the previous year.

title: AND ONE WIFE'S STORY
description: Penelope B. Laingen was a research analyst in the Federal Bureau of Invstigation and worked in the Operations Research Office at Johns Hopkins University before her marriage to L. Bruce Laingen in 1957.

title: 'WHAT'S THE SCORE?' IS ALL OVER TOWN
description: There was a party in town Sunday night. A noted sculptor was the guest of honor, sitting in the center of the living room, sharing her views of art and life with an enraptured circle of guests.

title: RETHINKING MERGERS
description: Will the proposed mergers of big oil and steel companies (and others to come) reduce competition? Yes. And that is precisely why they are needed. But we should drastically alter the rules by which mergers are concluded so that, instead of lining the pockets of the affluent, they serve a productive economic purpose.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It is the most significant case involving heroin trafficking by traditional organized crime that has ever been developed by the Government.

title: U.S.F.L. Star Jumps
description: National Football League teams have lost many players to the United States Football League, but now the Kansas City Chiefs have signed away Ken Lacy , from the Michigan Panthers of the U.S.F.L. Lacy, who rushed for 1,180 yards in his rookie season, is in the final year of a two- year contract, will be available to join the Chiefs about mid-July at the conclusion of the Panthers' season. His defection marks the first time an established U.S.F.L. star has chosen to jump to the N.F.L.

title: JACKSON AS POLARIZER
description: I believe it is possible to be supportive of the social themes sounded by Jesse Jackson and be critical of the man himself - to feel warmly toward his mission of politically energizing America's blacks and other left-out groups and to be at the same time appalled at some of his methods.

title: BRIEFING
description: The Name Game

title: ASTRONAUT TELLS OF GAINS IN CURING SPACE SICKNESS
description: Scientists are on the verge of conquering space sickness after experiments showed how that illness differed from Earth-bound motion sickness, says an astronaut who studied the malady on a recent shuttle mission.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
description: Chairman, 79, Retires At Elizabeth, N.J., Bank

title: TUESDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. Minnesota Twins , at Yankee Stadium, 2:05 P.M. After a stormy week on the road, Yogi Berra brings his players in for the home opener.

title: SEEQ TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: b-After a gain of $876,000 from the reversal of a previous year provision for the loss on disposal of capital equipment. c-After a loss of $1 million from the reversal of a previous year provision for the loss on disposal of capital equipment.

title: THREE RECEIVE PRISON TERMS FOR FALSIFYING CHEMICAL TESTS CHICAGO, April 9 (AP) - Three employees of a defunct chemical-testing laboratory were sentenced to prison terms today for falsifying results of tests submitted to the Government on four chemicals.
description: Dr. Moreno L. Keplinger, 54 years old, the former toxicology manager of Industrial Bio-Test Laboratories Inc., was sentenced to a year and a day in prison and four years' probation.

title: Transactions
description: Traded Terry Leach to Atlanta for Ron Meridith, pitcher, and assigned Meridith to Iowa of American Association. HOUSTON (NL) - Placed Dickie Thon, shortstop, on the 15-day disabled list.

title: Beer Company Signs Pact With Rights Group
description: Faced with an expanding boycott of its beer, the Adolph Coors Company has signed an agreement with the National Association for the Advancement of colored People to spend more money on black-owned businesses.

title: GRAFTON GROUP LTD reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $301,000.

title: 3 MAJOR RESEARCH CENTERS REJECT CENSORSHIP
description: Three leading research universities have told the Reagan Administration they will refuse to conduct certain kinds of sensitive but unclassified scientific research for the Defense Department if military reviewers are given the power to restrict publication of the findings.

title: JACKSON TO VISIT NICARAGUAN IN THE WAKE OF 'ACTS OF WAR'
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson said here today that he would soon travel to Nicaragua in an attempt to ease tensions growing out of the ''provocative act of war,'' the mining of Nicaraguan harbors, reportedly aided by the United States.

title: PIERRE PAUL PHILIPPE
description: Pierre Paul Cardinal Philippe of France died Sunday night of a heart attack, the Vatican announced today. He was 79 years old.

title: German Retail Sales Up
description: West German retail sales rose 6 percent in February from a year earlier, seasonally adjusted, the Federal Statistics Office said today. In the first two months of 1984, retail sales were up 5 percent from the period in 1983.

title: SAXON OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $24,771,331 from settlement with trade creditors. c-Net loss included $82.3 million of writedowns of which $34.3 million occurred in the fourth quarter. The latest quarter had $2.4 million in writedowns of oil and gas properties and certain other assets. The latest year had $5.6 million in similar writedowns.

title: Mary McCarthy Wins Medal for Literature
description: Mary McCarthy, the novelist and critic, is the winner of the 1984 National Medal for Literature, given to an American writer for a distinguished past and continuing contribution to American letters. The award, for which Miss McCarthy is the 16th recipient, consists of $15,000 and a bronze medal designed by Leonard Baskin.

title: Taft Sells Parks
description: The Taft Broadcasting Company said it had completed the $167.5 million sale of three amusement parks to the Kings Entertainment Company, although Taft retains a one-third interest in the parks. Taft said it expects the sale to make little difference in its earnings. Earlier this year Taft said that it was selling the theme parks so it could concentrate on broadcasting and entertainment programming. The sale involves the Kings Island park near Cincinnati, Kings Dominion near Richmond and Carowinds near Charlotte, N.C.

title: ISRAEL ACCUSES 4 JEWS OF A DOZEN GRENADE ATTACKS
description: The police announced today that they had arrested four young Jews on charges of planting at least a dozen booby-trapped hand grenades outside churches, mosques and Arab houses in recent months.

title: WASHINGTON AIDES AFFIRM POLICY SHIFT ON U.S. TROOP ROLE
description: Senior Reagan Administration officials affirmed today that the Defense Department, in a significant shift in thinking, was now prepared to use American combat troops in Central America if leftist forces in the region cannot be defeated by other means.

title: Trucker Sentenced In Crash Fatal To 7
description: A truck driver from North Carolina was sentenced to six months in prison and fined $1,000 today as the result of a fiery crash at a Connecticut Turnpike toll booth in Stratford that killed seven people.

title: INTERNATIONAL RESEARCH & DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CPI INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 4
Bridge: Bergen and Bloom Teams Survive in Grand National
description: Teams headed by Marty Bergen of White Plains and Betty Bloom of Duanesburg, N.Y., survived Grand National knockout play in White Plains Sunday and will meet next month for the right to advance to zonal playoffs and perhaps national honors.

title: PLANNERS APPROVE ZONING CHANGE TO PRESERVE UPPER WEST SIDE
description: uf821

title: UNION NATIONAL CORP (MET LEBANON, PA) (O) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
IN A TEXAS COURT, TEEN-AGERS FACE JURIES OF PEERS
description: It was a fairly common crime, petty shoplifting, among teen- agers, but 17-year-old Marcus, the defendant, had an explanation of why he stole a $7 tape cassette from a store here a few weeks ago.

title: NEW APPROACH SPEEDS COMMUNICATION OF DATA
description: YET another new set of initials is creeping into the personal computer lexicon: L.A.N., for local area network. While still only a limited part of the rapidly growing field of computer communications, these networks are something you will be hearing more about in coming years.

title: LET 'DEFICIT BONDS' REPLACE A TAX CUT
description: To the Editor:

title: DR. JOHN MERRILL, TRANSPLANT PIONEER, DIES IN BOATING MISHAP
description: Dr. John P. Merrill, the Boston physician who in 1954 led the medical team that did the first successful transplantation of a vital organ from one human to another, died in a boating accident in the Bahamas on April 4, it was announced yesterday. He was 67 years old and lived in Weston, Mass., and Squirrel Island, Me.

title: 4 Cosmos Players Hurt
description: Four Cosmos players are injured and questionable for tomorrow night's game against the San Diego Sockers in North American Soccer League's indoor championship series. David Brcic , goalkeeper, has a bruised left thigh, Dan Canter , defender, a bruised right foot, Alan Green , forward, right hamstring problem, and Angelo DiBernardo , defender, a bruised right thigh. The Cosmos have lost the first two in the three-of-five series.

title: Berlin Wall Is Scene Of Drama and Gunfire
description: East German border guards fired at two men scrambling over the Berlin wall during the night, apparently hitting one of them and preventing his escape, West German officials said today.

title: TSC INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 25
SUBURBAN BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MR. REAGAN'S WEEK
description: Here's a small sampling of what we learned from the press last week about the domestic and foreign policies of the President of the United States:

title: UNITED STATES TRUST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Faction Leaders Agree To Disengage in Beirut
description: Lebanese factional leaders tonight endorsed a plan for the disengagement of forces along the confrontation lines in Beirut.

title: JONES/HOSPLEX SYSTEMS reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
CITY'S LEBANESE SEEK THE UNITY THEIR LAND LACKS
description: As the warring goes on in Lebanon, many Lebanese in New York City are trying to bridge the divisions that are tearing apart their homeland.

title: INTERFIRST CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
U.S. PROPOSES CUT IN ASBESTOS LIMIT
description: The Reagan Administration today proposed a reduction in the amount of asbestos permitted in workplaces to one-quarter of the current limit.

title: Advice for Cowles
description: Cowles Broadcasting Inc. said it had named Goldman, Sachs & Company to advise it on the possible sale of the company or its television properties. Cowles said Goldman, Sachs had been authorized to explore the possiblity and terms of such a sale with several companies. Cowles owns two VHF television stations, one in Daytona Beach-Orlando and another in Des Moines.

title: COOPERATION IS CITED
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it was surprised by the sharp Soviet complaint about the American handling of procedures for the Olympics, because ''we have been very forthcoming with the Soviets.''

title: ORGANIZERS ARE DEFENDED
description: Peter Ueberroth, the president of the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee, opposed today a Soviet request for an extraordinary meeting of the International Olympic Committee and said organizers here had done nothing to warrant the strong attack issued this morning in Moscow.

title: LEHMAN, SHEARSON PACT SEEN
description: Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc., one of the oldest investment banking firms in the country, is negotiating the sale of the company to Shearson/ American Express Inc. for between $300 million and $400 million, Wall Street executives said yesterday.

title: Hart Begins Campaign For Missouri Delegates
description: Gary Hart's fight to win Missouri's Democratic caucuses April 18 began Sunday with statewide newspaper advertising and an announcement that the Colorado Senator would campaign in the state this week.

title: No Headline
description: Fissionable India Indira Gandhi has a distinctive way of disabling her political opponents. First, dismissal and denunciation. If that should fail and a crisis arises, she intervenes as the peacemaking savior of a united and secular India, ready to yield what she earlier refused. It worked a few years ago after communal riots shook the poor, remote state of Assam. Now the Prime Minister is in far graver trouble in the Punjab, the prosperous granary of India. If her touch falters, so do hopes for India's unity and development, and that matters.

title: LOTS OF EXTRAS
description: When Margaret Punzo found what she thought was her dream house, she did not know about the game of golf.

title: AT LEAST ONE VIEWER MISSED NO-HITTER
description: The viewer had never seen a no-hitter and had

title: CITY WILL HUNT TAX EVADERS IN RETURNS FILED WITH STATE
description: City and state officials, saying that ''cheaters'' were evading millions of dollars of income taxes each year, announced a program yesterday to allow city auditors to examine the tax returns of residents and commuters.

title: 3 Agencies Winners In Account-Switching
description: In the account-switching arena last week, the winners included Geer, DuBois; Della Femina, Travisano & Partners, and Martin Greenfield Associates.

title: Gimmickry at a Gala
description: BOYS' TOWNS of Italy is an old and respected charity, and it tosses an annual gala capped by an awards presentation as a way of raising money. That party, honoring Mrs. Donald Trump and the Baron Enrico di Portanova was recently held at the Waldorf.

title: 'Elms' Opening Put Off
description: ''Desire Under the Elms'' will not open as scheduled today at the Roundabout Theater. It will continue in previews until the company resolves some technical problems.

title: JUNE 6TH '84: NORMANDY AWAITS ARMY OF AGELESS G.I.'S
description: A New York City homicide detective who worked on the Son of Sam case will be there. So will an Episcopal minister from Alabama.

title: Derby-Betting Bill Gains in Albany
description: The State Senate today approved legislation enabling bettors in New York to place wagers on this year's Kentucky Derby, Preakness and Breeder's Cup Series at the state's off-track betting parlors and thoroughbred race tracks.

title: MIRIAM ROTHSCHILD TALKS OF FLEAS
description: BECAUSE of her extensive knowledge of fleas, Miriam Rothschild is somewhat of a hero in Australia. She is celebrated, too, for her work with mites and monarch butterflies.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: Azzedine Ala"ia

title: Bill Called Costly to Insurers
description: A proposed law that would ban sex discrimination in insurance would mean higher benefits for policyholders but billions of dollars in liabilities for insurance companies, the General Accounting Office said today.

title: No Headline
description: Soccer Players Offer Idea The North American Soccer League Players Association is proposing that all N.A.S.L. players unwilling to take salary cuts as a way of

title: KASPAROV WINS FINAL AND WILL FACE KARPOV
description: Gary Kasparov of the Soviet Union triumphed yesterday in his final candidates chess match by drawing the 13th game with his countryman Vasily Smyslov. The final score was Kasparov 8 1/2, Smyslov 4 1/2.

title: MILWAUKEE ROAD BIDS WEIGHED
description: The trustee of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul & Pacific Railroad, which is in bankruptcy proceedings, said today that the Soo Line Railroad Company's $168.5 million cash proposal to purchase the Milwaukee Road's assets appeared to be ''marginally better'' than a competing offer by the Chicago, North Western Transportation Company valued by that company at in excess of $170 million.

title: HOUSE TO BLOCK AID FOR REBELS, O'NEILL ASSERTS
description: The Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., said today that the Reagan Administration's request for $21 million in new aid to Nicaraguan rebels would not be approved by the House.

title: TREATMENT IS NEARING FOR GENETIC DEFECTS
description: SOMEDAY, perhaps as soon as the next decade, scientists will construct largely artificial viruslike particles and use them as vehicles to transplant foreign genes into specific cells within the human body.

title: No Headline
description: Laggards in the Hot Trash Game On Jan. 1, 1986, New York and 10 other Northeastern states may start slowly drowning in their own radioactive garbage.

title: Schoolyard Attack Leads to Arrest
description: A 28-year-old Manhattan man was accused yesterday of striking 15 children with a 2-foot-long stick in the yard of Public School 133 in Harlem.

title: 4 Marines Disappear On Flight Over Oahu
description: Four marines from the island of Oahu who went on a sightseeing flight in a single-engine airplane were missing today and it was feared the plane was down somewhere near the Mauna Loa volcano.

title: 'FAMILY,' TRADITIONS
description: ''FAMILY: REFUGE OR PRISON?'' is moderately misnamed. There isn't much about it to suggest that a family, nuclear or otherwise, imprisons its members, only that it may inconvenience them, and even then not to any great degree. The program, part of Channel 13's new ''Intercom'' series, will be seen at 11 o'clock tonight.

title: 'GEORGE' IS POSTPONED
description: The new musical ''Sunday in the Park With George'' has postponed its opening at the Booth Theater from April 23 to May 2.

title: FOR THE STARS, AN EASY DFAY BEFORE A LONG NIGHT
description: The curving, palm-lined driveway to the Beverly Hills Hotel is not a driveway at all. It's Hollywood's yellow brick road.

title: San Francisco Curb on Baths
description: In an attempt to control the spread of acquired immune deficiency syndrome, a fatal disease mainly affecting homosexual men, the city's director of health today banned sexual activity in San Francisco's 14 bathhouses.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY BENEFITS FACE TAXATION BY STATES
description: One year after Congress enacted legislation to tax middle- and upper- income retirees on up to half of their Social Security benefits, pensioners in two dozen states face the prospect of paying state taxes on their benefits as well.

title: Getting It Right
description: Almost everyone believes that the National Basketball Association's arduous 82-game season is too long. Everyone, that is, except the Nets.

title: VORTEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SATELLITES OUTPACE CUSTOMERS It is not easy owning a communications satellite these days.
description: Cable television, long-distance telephone service, video teleconferencing and other forms of sophisticated electronic communications have not produced the bonanza of customers that was predicted by the satellite industry.

title: The U.N. Today April 10, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: ; THE VICTIMS OF GOVERNMENT-SPONSORED GAMBLING
description: To the Editor:

title: Group Jackson Founded Is Told to Return Funds
description: The Department of Education announced today that it wants a social service group founded by the Rev. Jesse Jackson to return more than $700,000 in Federal grants because the money was improperly spent.

title: Arson Hits Preschool Investigated for
description: The school where hundreds of the very young, it has been charged, were sexually molested and physically abused by teachers in the past decade was vandalized and set afire, the police reported today.

title: OPERA: BENJAMIN BRITTEN'S 'BILLY BUDD,' AT THE MET
description: BENJAMIN BRITTEN'S ''Billy Budd'' is not so much an opera as a discursive meditation on fate, moral choice and the corruption of power. This gloomy seascape, in John Dexter's justly celebrated 1978 production, returned to the Metropolitan Opera Saturday night, with strong performances by Dale Duesing as Billy Budd, James Morris as John Claggert, and, most important, Richard Cassilly as the haunted Edward Fairfax Vere, Captain of the H.M.S. Indomitable.

title: Acceptances' Role Is Reduced by Fed
description: The Federal Reserve announced yesterday that, starting July 2, it would no longer arrange repurchase agreements using bankers' acceptances as part of its open market operations.

title: TALKS ENDED IN KOREA
description: Sports officials from North and South Korea broke off talks today on the formation of a joint team for the Olympic Games in Los Angeles.

title: ALLEGHANY MAY BE NEAR CONRAIL BID
description: The Alleghany Corporation, a company that has long invested in railroads, is working on a proposal under which it would make a $1 billion offer to buy Conrail from the Federal Government, according to some of those involved in talks on the offer.

title: GREENMAN BROTHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
FARRAKHAN WARNS PRESS ON JACKSON
description: Louis Farrakhan, leader of the Nation of Islam, warned the press in an angry, 90-minute speech Sunday against trying to destroy the Rev. Jesse Jackson's candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: DEMOCRATS START SHAPING PLATFORM
description: Democrats, beginning work on what they hope will be a unifying platform for 1984, yesterday found that they may have trouble papering over policy divisions among their candidates for the Presidential nomination.

title: No Headline
description: Lame in Spirit Jesse Jackson, a candidate for President and for the black leadership role of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr., equivocated for nearly two weeks before admitting and apologizing for slurs against Jewish Americans. Now he's been late again, and lame, in dealing with threats against the journalist who disclosed those slurs, and hardly faithful to his mentor's teachings of nonviolence.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;
description: New York State's spring financing, traditionally the year's largest sale of tax-exempt securities, has begun through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

description: b-Net income

title: Europe Trade Rise Pledged
description: Members of the European Economic Community and the European Free Trade Association ended their first joint meeting today, pledging to extend free trade throughout Western Europe and to ''oppose protectionist pressures.''

title: NEW WAYS AT 2 G.M. PLANTS
description: Tall and silent, except for a faint beeping tone to warn the unwary, 22 unmanned forklift trucks roll heavily along the aisles of the General Motors Corporation's automobile plant here, bringing parts to workers along the assembly line.

title: 42ND STREET THREAT TO THE GARMENT CENTER
description: To the Editor:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: DNA Plant Technology Corp., Cinnaminson, N.J., an agricultural biotechnology concern, has elected to its board Edward L. Hennessy Jr., chairman and chief executive of the Allied Corp.

description: b-Net income.

MILITARY PAST OF CHERNENKO EMBROIDERED
description: Apparently trying to enhance Konstantin U. Chernenko's public image, the Defense Ministry newspaper today printed a photograph of him as a 20-year-old border guard and spoke glowingly of his courage and marksmanship.

title: Advertising; Random's Software Account
description: ONE of the first things that Random House did after it decided to join the multitude of book publishers tumbling into the home computer software business was to hire a man with a high-tech marketing background away from Sony.

title: THE SANER APPROACH TO A STATE'S RADIOACTIVE-WASTE DISPOSAL
description: To the Editor:

title: AMBIGUITY IN U.S. GOALS
description: Practically from the outset of the Reagan Administration's ''covert war'' against the Sandinista Government in Nicaragua, there has been confusion and controversy over American objectives. Periodically, President Reagan, reflecting divisions in his Administration, has fueled the argument with imprecision about his goals. The debate also flares with each increase of military pressure by American- backed Nicaraguan rebels.

title: LIMITED STEPS UP PRESSURE
description: The Limited Inc., stepping up the pressure in its week-old tender offer for Carter Hawley Hale Stores, filed a statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday saying that it would solicit written consent from Carter Hawley's shareholders to remove the company's board of directors. The Limited also sought authorization for a special shareholders meeting of Carter Hawley at which to replace the directors.

title: Charter Seeks Study of Stock
description: The Charter Company yesterday asked the New York Stock Exchange to investigate short selling of the company's stock before publication of several stories about the company in The Wall Street Journal. An investor who sells stock short borrows shares and sells them on the chance they will drop in price and can be repurchased and returned later for a lower price.

title: MICHIGAN UTILITY CUTS DIVIDEND
description: The board of the Consumers Power Company today cut the company's dividend on common stock to 35 cents a share, from 63 cents. The reduced dividend is payable on May 21.

title: MERRILL'S NEW BANK CHALLENGE
description: Merrill Lynch & Company will begin another attack on the traditional turf of banks late this spring when it test-markets a personal asset management account intended for the small investor.

title: Debt Issues
description: * First Union Corporation, a bank holding company based in Charlotte, N.C., said its public offering of $50 million of floating rate subordinated notes due 1996 had been priced at 99.75 percent through Goldman, Sachs & Co.

title: WHAT YOUNG PHYSICIANS OWE THEIR COUNTRY
description: To the Editor:

title: VECTOR AUTOMATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss. Share earnings have been adjusted for a 130-for-1 stock split effective Dec. 7, 1983.

title: Tigers 5, Rangers 1
description: Darrell Evans hit a three-run homer to back the four-hit pitching of Dan Petry as unbeaten Detroit won its sixth game. The Tigers' start matches a club record set in 1911 and leaves Detroit as the only unbeaten club in the majors.

title: CHIEF SUSPECTS NEVER MET
description: It was a conspiracy in which the two key figures were continents apart and never met or exchanged words as they purportedly masterminded the smuggling of $1.65 billion worth of heroin into the United States.

title: MATRIX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: Year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding have been restated for the 3-for-2 stock split effective Sept. 15, 1983.

title: SHUTTLE'S ROBOTIC ARM SNARES ERRANT SATELLITE
description: The Challenger astronauts reached out with their long robotic arm today to catch a failing satellite, Solar Max, and take it aboard the 305-mile-high space shuttle for the first major repair job in orbit.

title: HIGH COURT GETS CONNECTICUT SABBATH-WORK CASE
description: For a brief time, Donald E. Thornton managed the men's and boys' clothing and shoe departments in the Caldor department store here. It was a good job, paying $6.46 an hour, but for Mr. Thornton, a devout Presbyterian, it had one serious drawback. With the repeal of Connecticut's blue laws, he had to work every fourth Sunday.

title: Citicorp Rates Off
description: A general decline in short-term interest rates in the last week helped to reduce interest rates paid by Citicorp at its regular weekly auctions yesterday of commercial paper due in 91 and 182 days. Citicorp, the most active bank holding company in issuing commercial paper, sold $100 million of 91-day paper at an average rate of 10.275 percent, down from 10.313 percent a week ago, and $50 million of 182-day paper at an average of 10.291 percent, down from 10.353 percent.

description: Protesters at the Republican National Convention this summer will be allowed to camp in two city parks 14 and 18 miles from the convention site downtown, city officials say.

description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect the acquisition of Grandy's Restaurants which was accounted for as a pooling of interest.

Alleghany estimated that the offer was worth $2 billion to the Government. The plan also includes a $700 million payment to Conrail employees.

title: EUROPEANS AGREE TO CHEMICAL CURB
description: Five West European nations have agreed to restrict the export of chemicals that can be used to make chemical weapons, European officials said today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Standard Co., a diversified manufacturing and building products company, has elected John J. Griffin vice president and group executive of the International and Export Group, and H. Thompson Smith vice president and group executive of the Building Specialties Group.

description: FOR a growing number of investors, the seasonal trauma of income tax filing has been

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about the London Stock Exchange incorrectly described the minimum transaction affected by a reduction in commissions. It affects sales of British Government securities amounting to more than $:250,000 - about $357,000.

title: LABOR VOTE A KEY; BIG DELEGATE LEAD
description: Walter F. Mondale won a big victory today in Pennsylvania's Democratic Presidential primary, re-establishing a firm claim to the leadership in the race for the nomination.

title: SOME CAPSULE REVIEWS
description: NOW that Michael Jackson has once again made the world safe for record-company profits, labels large and small are deluging the marketplace with new albums, singles, EP's and everything else. And now that MTV has made ''new wave'' music a commercial concept, major labels are once again signing new bands.

title: FIRST BABY BORN OF FROZEN EMBRYO
description: A 5 1/2-pound infant girl named Zoe is the world's first baby produced from a frozen embryo, scientists announced today.

title: 4 Tied to F.A.L.N. Going to Prison
description: Four people suspected of being F.A.L.N. leaders surrendered yesterday to begin three-year prison terms for refusing to answer questions posed by a Federal grand jury investigating the Puerto Rican terrorist group.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: NOON DRAMA

title: New Congressman Sworn In
description: Gerald Kleczka, a Democratic State Senator from Wisconsin, was sworn in today as a member of the House of Representatives, succeeding Representative Clement J. Zablocki, a Wisconsin Democrat, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, who died last December. Mr. Kleczka won a special election last Tuesday. The addition of Mr. Kleczka brought the House membership to 434, with 268 Democrats and 166 Republicans. There is one vacancy because of the death last month of Representative Edwin B. Forsythe, Republican of New Jersey.

title: LABOR BOARD RULING FURTHER FREES COMPANIES IN MOVING OPERATIONS
description: The National Labor Relations Board announced a decision today that frees employers in some circumstances from an obligation to bargain with labor unions about corporate plans to transfer plants and workers to new and possibly nonunion locations.

title: U.S. Sues Bessemer, Ala., To Change City Election
description: The Justice Department today sued to overturn the method of electing City Commissioners in Bessemer, Ala., and to challenge the city's annexation policy as discriminating against black voters.

title: ELECTROSOUND GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $2,000. c-Net loss after an extraordinary charge of $129,000.

title: COUNTERSPY EXPERT DESCRIBED AS THREAT TO UP TO 30 AGENTS
description: A former Army counterintelligence officer has information that could endanger as many as two dozen American double agents who still pose as Soviet spies, a Federal prosecutor said in court today.

title: AGENCY CHIEF CITES DELAYS IN HANDLING CHILD ABUSE CASES
description: The director of the city's Office of Special Services for Children yesterday criticized its response to reported cases of child abuse in Brooklyn.

title: Quake in Washington State
description: A moderate earthquake shook a large area of central Washington state tonight, but there were no immediate reports of damage or injury. The temblor, measuring about four on the Richter scale of ground motion, was centered near Entiat and was felt in Wenatchee, Grand Coulee and Yakima.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: STAR TRACKING
description: It took the pollsters all week to predict that Walter F. Mondale would win the Democratic Presidential primary in Pennsylvania. Jeanette Oswald made the same forecast last Wednesday at a news conference in Philadelphia.

title: Bridge: A
description: The cast of ''Animal Crackers'' once included Helen Sobel Smith, as well as the Marx Brothers, and the playwright George Kaufman was a well-known figure in New York bridge clubs. But in recent years there have been no obvious links between the Broadway stage and the midtown card clubs.

title: FUTURES/OPTIONS ; Profitable Spread Cited In Value Line-S.&P. 500
description: Bargain hunting among the blue- chip stocks by institutional investors yesterday further enriched holders of 1984's most profitable stock index futures spread: the selling short of Value Line index futures and the buying of Standard & Poor's 500 contracts.

title: SALVADOR ELECTION COUNCIL FIXES MAY 6 FOR RUNOFF
description: The Salvadoran Elections Council said today that the runoff election to choose a new president will be held May 6.

Hotel Talk

title: BRITISH ANTI-SPY AIDE GOESON TRIAL FOR SPYING
description: A middle-ranking British intelligence officer went on trial today for passing secret information to Soviet officials here.

title: BOYCOTT BY SOVIET APPEARS UNLIKELY
description: The Soviet press maintained today its sharp criticism of preparations for the Olympics in Los Angeles this summer, but there were signals in Moscow that the Russians would stop well short of boycotting the Games.

title: WINE TALK
description: HERE are some of the things that happened in the American wine market in 1983: Sparkling wines continued their astonished growth in popularity. Imported wines again increased their portion of the market. States other than California continued to lose their share of the market. Lambrusco, the phenomenon of the wine world a few years ago, may have run its course. Over all, it was a good year for the consumer and very tough for the trade.

title: Helping High-Risk Teen-Agers
description: In New York State in 1982, 66,000 teen-agers experienced pregnancy. About half had abortions. More often than not the others dropped out of high school.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE ART OF THE CITY. Views and Versions of New York. By Peter Conrad.Illustrated. 329 pages. Oxford University Press. $18.95.

title: Bookkeeper Guilty In Fatal Clubbing
description: A 25-year-old man was convicted today of the murder and attempted rape of a 21-year-old woman who was clubbed to death in her parents' home in Great Neck last August.

title: Legal Aid Society Honors Rifkind
description: The Legal Aid Society presented its annual Servant of Justice award to Simon H. Rifkind at a dinner last night at the Pierre Hotel.

title: No Headline
description: Official Says Chinese Will Join Shuttle Crew

title: Real Estate; Clothier Overcomes High Rent
description: ''IT was a bitter pill to swallow,''

title: Plan for Shea Detailed
description: Mayor Koch and the Mets announced yesterday that the city would spend more than $25 million to renovate Shea Stadium and to install an artificial playing surface and 50 luxury boxes.

title: WILSON BROTHERS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $116,000 for the quarter and $1,101,000 for the year. c-Net losses.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Anti-Tech Aliens
description: What do E.T., a mermaid named Madison and John Clayton have in common? They're all main characters in successful recent movies aimed at young people - movies that tell roughly the same story.

title: DON'T BARGAIN WITH NERVE GAS
description: President Reagan claimed last week that new binary chemical weapons were necessary both to deter chemical use by the Soviet Union and as bargaining chips to induce the Russians to negotiate a complete ban on the production, testing and deployment of such weapons. Neither justification is valid. Our existing stockpile of chemical agents is already a huge deterrent, and nothing in our previous negotiating experience with the Russians sug gests that developing new weapons will expedite an arms-control agreement.

title: Surgery for Thon Due
description: The Houston Astros' shortstop, Dickie Thon , who was hit in the head by a pitch from Mike Torrez of the Mets Sunday night, was scheduled to undergo surgery today to repair a triple fracture of the cheekbone, the club said. The Astros said that Thon would be out of the hospital by this weekend.

title: Illegal, Deceptive and Dumb
description: What in Hugo Grotius's name is the Reagan Administration doing to America's reputation as a law-abiding society? Grotius was the Dutch jurist who in 1628 first codified the laws of war and peace. As befits a nation founded and governed by lawyers, the United States has repeatedly applied those laws to international behavior; indeed, it declared war on Germany in 1917 when Kaiser Wilhelm's U-boats torpedoed neutral shipping in violation of sea law.

title: Pearson Is Optimistic
description: Despite suffering serious injuries to his liver in an automobile accident on March 22 that caused the death of his brother, Drew Pearson said he hoped to play for the Cowboys in the 1984 National Football League season. ''My doctor said I'm capable of playing football and I have told Coach Tom Landry that I would like to play another year,'' the 33-year-old wide receiver said in Dallas yesterday.

title: ANTI-SATELLITE WEAPONS: LESS SERVES US BETTER
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT SHEARSON WILL GAIN
description: The planned acquisition of Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc. by Shearson/American Express is the latest sign of a trend on Wall Street to consolidate into ever-larger and more diverse financial empires.

title: WHY LEHMAN WAS SOLD
description: Lewis L. Glucksman, already acknowledged as one of Wall Street's star traders, was in his glory last July. He had seized control of Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc., and said he was eager to demonstrate his skill at managing one of the nation's oldest and most prominent investment banks.

description: WITH Easter less than two weeks away, it seems appropriate to think about gifts for children - as well as for the child in many adults. Here are some suggestions. 1.*A Wriggling Rabbit

description: President Fernando Belaunde Terry named Senator Sandro Mariategui as his new Prime Minister tonight, replacing Fernando Schwalb who resigned over differences on economic policy.

description: The war here over a bill to aid Vietnam War veterans is over. The bill was passed today by the State Senate even though the name of a conscientious objector remained on it as the chief Assembly sponsor.

title: DIRECT VOTE BACKED IN BIG BRAZIL RALLY
description: Over half a million Brazilians gathered in downtown Rio de Janeiro this afternoon to demonstrate in favor of direct Presidential elections to restore the country to full democracy after 20 years of military rule.

title: Nebraska Compromises On Church Schools
description: Gov. Bob Kerrey today signed a bill designed to end the long fight between the state and some church schools that object to state certification of their teachers.

title: RETRIEVAL OF SATELLITE: RISKS AND LUCK
description: After a free-flying astronaut failed to capture the ailing Solar Max satellite and the space shuttle's robot arm dramatically succeeded, space officials have been pointedly asked why they picked man over machine in the first place. Was it mere grandstanding?

description: Moscow's bombastic complaints about arrangements for the Los Angeles Olympics are, unfortunately, just part of the modern-day sport: milk it for all the nationalism you can.

description: The Mellon National Corporation, citing lower loan margins, reported yesterday that net income in the first quarter dropped 14.5 percent.

title: Red Nations, VW in Talks
description: Volkswagenwerk A.G. said today that it had been approached by the Soviet Union about possible licenses to produce Volkswagen diesel engines, but that no negotiations had taken place and there was no sign of any agreement.

Turkish Cypriots Set Vote on Constitution
description: Turkish Cypriots in the self-declared independent state of Northern Cyprus will hold a referendum on a new constitution in August, followed in November by general elections for a parliament.

title: Polygram Link Gains in Court
description: The proposed merger of the United States record operations of Warner Communications Inc. and Polygram Records, which is opposed by the Federal Trade Commission, received some help yesterday from the United States District Court in Los Angeles.

title: 'IMPROPER CONDUCT,' EXILES INDICT CASTRO REGIME
description: ''IMPROPER CONDUCT'' (''Mauvaise Conduite'') is something very rare in films - an intelligent attack on Fidel Castro's Cuban revolution, mostly as recorded in interviews with 28 Cuban exiles, including former members and supporters of the Castro regime.

title: Smith Increases Stake in Gearhart
description: Smith International Inc. said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that it might seek a more active role in the management of Gearhart Industries.

description: Fire in Derailed Train Forces Residents to Flee

title: Houston Winner At Cash Register
description: Houston may have lost to Georgetown in the final of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament in Seattle, but the wounds from that defeat will be soothed somewhat by the financial profits that Phi Slama Jama brought to the athletic department.

title: CBS Profit More Than Doubles
description: CBS Inc. reported yesterday that its profits in the first quarter more than doubled from a year earlier, reflecting increased revenues from the broadcasting and recording divisions.

title: Kemper Charge
description: The Kemper Corporation said it expects to report an after-tax charge of 30 cents a share for the first quarter.

title: GOVERNOR NOW FAVORS REDUCING TAXES IN 1985
description: Governor Cuomo, who resisted a Republican effort to cut personal income and other taxes this year, said today that he would like to cut taxes next year.

title: A Trial Horse
description: Dave Cowens, the former star center for the Boston Celtics who signed on March 29 to coach the Bay State Bombardiers of the Continental Basketball Association during the 1984-85 season, says he regards the assignment ''as a training program, where I can find out if I really want to coach.''

title: CB&T BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 100 percent stock dividend paid in January 1984.

title: MAN DUBBED HERO BY POLICE NOW HELD ON MURDER CHARGE
description: Last September, when a family in south-central Los Angeles said their intervention in an attempted robbery by a local gang member had led to a siege on their home, politicians and the police called them heroes and rallied to protect them from further retaliation.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A listing in SportsMonday on April 2 of results in the Riverhead Kennel Club show misidentified the third- place dog in the herding group. He is Ch. Jac-A-Lor's-Apache-v-Mossland.

title: A CORNED BEEF SANDWICH AS A FINE ART
description: FOR Leo Steiner it is not enough that his corned beef be lean. It must also be his. For Mr. Steiner, co-owner of the Carnegie Delicatessen, at 55th Street and Seventh Avenue, there is no buying chunks of ready-corned brisket or bottom round from provisioners. Instead he and his brother Sam, whom he describes as ''an M.D., a meat dealer,'' corn their own beef four nights a week.

title: PUTTING CORPORATE DINING ON AN ELAVATED PLANE
description: -Savarin, casting a sharp eye upon the effects of the table on business affairs, wrote in 1825 that ''men with great interests at stake have observed that a well-fed man is not at all the same as a hungry one; that the table constitutes a kind of tie between the bargainer and the bargained-with, making the diners more willing to receive certain impressions, to submit to certain influences.''

title: Negotiations Are Held In Las Vegas Strike
description: Hotel officials modified their wage proposals today in an open meeting with representatives of four striking unions, but failed to resolve the issues that have kept 17,000 workers off the job at 32 gambling resorts for nine days.

title: BAN ASKED ON THE SALE OF RAW MILK
description: PUBLIC CITIZEN, a consumer group founded by Ralph Nader, has asked the Federal Government to forbid the sale of raw milk, which it contends has been linked with more than 600 illnesses and perhaps 16 deaths since 1980. The sale of raw milk has been an issue of debate among regulators, elements of the dairy industry and consumers for more than a year.

title: Derby-Bet Plan Backed by State
description: Governor Cuomo and the leaders of the Legislature have agreed on a plan to allow New York thoroughbred tracks to take bets on this year's Kentucky Derby, Preakness Stakes and Breeders Cup.

title: THE 2 BERLINS, 2 WORLDS OF JEWS, 2 SETS OF GHOSTS
description: Inside the red-brick synagogue, the 28 Jews sang their Friday prayers. An elderly black- robed man with a quavering voice did his best to emulate a cantor. The last rabbi died six years ago.

title: TEXT OF GOLDWATER'S LETTER TO THE HEAD OF C.I.A.
description: Following is the text of a letter sent Monday to William J. Casey, Director of Central Intelligence, by Senator Barry Goldwater, Republican of Arizona, in his capacity as chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence: Dear Bill:

title: Idaho Official Says Court Confused Primary
description: Idaho's Attorney General said today that he would ask the United States Supreme Court to stop the state's May 22 primary election because of ''utter confusion'' caused by legislative redistricting.

title: Western Officer Named World Airways Chief
description: World Airways announced yesterday that it had named Donald L. Beck, a Western Airlines executive, as president and chief executive.

title: A PUZZLER CELEBRATES HER 133D BOOK
description: About fi fty i f t y crossword puzzle constructors, editors and pencil and pen pals of Margaret Petherbridge Farrar turned up, down and across at the Lotos Club in Manhattan to celebrate her latest crossword puzzle book.

title: Regan Voices Worry on Fed
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan today broke a long truce with the Federal Reserve chairman, Paul A. Volcker, by expressing worry that the central bank chief might be pursuing a policy leading to higher interest rates. At a Congressional hearing, Mr. Regan, a frequent critic of Mr. Volcker in the past, voiced concern about the Fed's move on Friday to increase the interest it charges member banks for loans.

description: BASEBALL

title: METS WIN 5TH IN ROW
description: The Mets rolled to their fifth straight victory, the best start in their 23 seasons, when they defeated the Atlanta Braves tonight, 4-2.

title: Patriots Sign Fryar To 4-Year Contract
description: The New England Patriots signed Irving Fryar, the speedy wide receiver from the University of Nebraska, to a four-year contract last night, according to a person familiar with the negotiations. The move came less than a week after the Patriots had obtained the first pick in the National Football League in a trade with the Cincinnati Bengals.

title: MUSIC: 'LYRICISTS' PROGRAM
description: BROADWAY musicals from 1935 to 1939 proved to be an unusually fruitful source for the ''Lyrics and Lyricists'' program at the 92d Street Y last weekend. This segment of the current series, ''The Golden Decade of Song: The Tuneful Thirties,'' included an imposing array of memorable songs by Cole Porter, Rodgers and Hart, George Gershwin, Kurt Weill and others, and the cast projected the varied qualities of the songs with spirit and sensitivity.

title: FINE DINING AT AN ENGLISH COUNTRY HOTEL
description: GREAT MILTON, England

description: PROPOSAL writers at about 500 graduate schools of business will be scrambling in the next few months to formulate plans for submission to the International Business Machines Corporation.

description: ''The President has asked us to back his foreign policy. Bill, how can we back his foreign policy when we don't know what the hell he is doing? Lebanon, yes, we all knew that he sent troops over there.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;
description: A $300 million financing by the Kentucky Turnpike Authority was tentatively priced with a maximum yield of 10 1/4 percent for bonds due in 2004, through underwriters led by the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation.

title: 2 REPAIRMEN FROM SPACE SHUTTLE SET FOR 'SURGERY IN BOXING GLOVES'
description: The two spacesuit-clad astronauts assigned to repair the Solar Max satellite Wednesday morning compare the job to performing ''surgery in boxing gloves'' and say the pinching of their fingertips is ''bloody painful.''

title: U.S. CONCEDES LOSS ON DELOREAN TAPE
description: A prosecutor in John Z. DeLorean's trial for cocaine trafficking disclosed in jury questioning today that a Government informer inadvertently erased some taped telephone conversations relevant to the case.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: MEAL planning almost invariably begins with the main dish. But there are times when the appearance of a vegetable at the height of its season makes me think first of the side dish.

; KEY TO CENTRAL AMERICAN PEACE
description: To the Editor:

title: NETS SET BACK 76ERS FOR FOURTH IN ROW
description: After defeating their last two opponents by a total of 50 points, the Nets got exactly the type of matchup they needed less than a week before the playoffs.

title: A LITLE RESPECT, PLEASE
description: Look at the Soviet Union and the United States. Superpowers, right? And who cares? Do they get any respect? They lurch around the mountains of Afghanistan and Central American jungles like a couple of gigantic, ham-handed Rodney Dangerfields muttering, ''I don't get no respect.''

GOOD WILL IN FIRST 100 DAYS HELP'S PHILIDELPHIA'S MAYOR
description: Mayors come and go but some things here never change, as S. M. Kamens discovered the other day.

title: Soviet Delegate at U.N. Assails Mining of Ports
description: The Soviet delegate to the United Nations said today that Nicaragua's harbors were being mined by ''terrorists, supported, equipped and financed by the United States'' in what he called a ''new chapter of international terrorism.''

title: BRIEFS
description: * Facet Enterprises Inc., a filters and auto parts company in Tulsa, Okla., said it had acquired an idle production facility from Vermont American Corp. Terms were not disclosed.

title: SHEARSON TO PAY $360 MILLION TO ACQUIRE LEHMAN BROTHERS
description: Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc., one of Wall Street's oldest and most powerful investment banking firms, will be acquired by Shearson/American Express for $360 million, both companies announced yesterday.

title: Post Vacant at Mapco After Chairman Retires
description: Robert E. Thomas, founder of Mapco Inc., a Tulsa, Okla., energy company, said yesterday that he had retired as chairman and director. Earlier this year, he had said he planned to stay on until year's end.

title: THE NEW BEDFORD RAPE CASE: CONFUSION OVER ACCOUNTS OF CHEERING AT BAR
description: Alan Levin, a reporter for The Standard-Times of New Bedford, Mass., tried to find out who did the cheering. So did Fred Bayles, a reporter for The Associated Press. So did a score of other reporters, from the television networks and the news magazines and the big national newspapers, sent to New Bedford, to write about the reported gang rape in Big Dan's Tavern.

title: J. Walter Thompson To Open Dubai Office
description: The J. Walter Thompson Company, the company in the JWT Group previously represented in the United Arab Emirates by an affiliated agency, is opening up its own office there in Dubai. And that brings to 118 the number of offices the agency has in 43 countries.

title: FRENCH OFFICIAL IS TARGET OF CAR'S DRIVER
description: The brother of one of nine French soldiers killed Saturday in Chad tried to run down Defense Minister Charles Hernu with his car today at the funeral of the men. Bodyguards opened fire and wounded the driver before the car could reach Mr. Hernu.

title: Campbell Soup Leads A New Product List
description: Campbell Soup was the biggest introducer of new products last year in the combined food and health and beauty aids categories, according to the Dancer Fitzgerald Sample New Product News, and it is not the first year that it has won the title.

title: A REGION UNITING AGAINST CREDITORS
description: To the Editor:

title: BURMESE ARMY IS SAID TO FIGHT INDIA REBELS
description: At least 50 people have died in recent clashes in northern Burma involving guerrillas fighting for independence from India, the Burmese Army and villagers in the region, according to reports received today from the area.

title: SON OF FARMER WHO FAILED GOES ON TRIAL IN KILLING OF 2 BANKERS
description: The trial of an 18-year-old farm boy, accused of the ambush slaying of two local bankers who foreclosed on his father's farm, began today.

title: CARME INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: ALVARADO SAYS HIS CASE HAD AN INEVITABILITY
description: There are times when Anthony J. Alvarado, the suspended Schools Chancellor, almost accepts what has happened to him in the last six weeks, when he looks over the public unraveling of his career and thinks maybe it became, at a certain point, inevitable.

title: Dutch Unemployment
description: The unemployment rate in the Netherlands rose slightly to 17 percent in March, the Government said today.

title: Law School Buys Bank Building
description: The Brooklyn Law School announced yesterday that it had bought the Republic National Bank building at Boerum Place and Fulton Street to expand its campus by about 50 percent.

title: AGENTS TAPED QUEENS CALL
description: Following are excerpts from one of many taped conversations transcribed by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in a 341-page affidavit.

title: Salvador Military Is Accused Of Bombing Displaced People
description: El Salvador's armed forces have staged bombing attacks against large numbers of the 500,000 people displaced by the civil war, according to a report published today by a group of lawyers.

title: FIRST JERSEY NATIONAL BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Lacrosse Is Back
description: For the first time since the end of World War II, lacrosse is back in the Public Schools Athletic League at Jamaica High School in Queens.

title: RANDOLPH FINDS HIS POWER ZONE
description: Don Baylor was on the way to the shower yesterday afternoon, passing Willie Randolph's locker as the second baseman exuberantly relived his soaring two-run homer in the Yankees' 4-1 victory.

title: American Air's Denver Focus
description: Plans for American Airlines to build a $100 million, 25-gate concourse at Stapleton International Airport were outlined today by Robert L. Crandall, the airline's president. Mr. Crandall met with Denver's Mayor, Federico Pena, to discuss the project, which American said would be a third ''hub'' for its operations.

title: Visa for Perez
description: Pascual Perez , the Atlanta Brave pitcher who was released Monday after three months' imprisonment in a case involving cocaine possession, received from the American Consulate here today a visa to enter the United States. He is to fly to Miami on Wednesday, and from there immediately to Atlanta.

title: The U.N. Today April 11, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: No Headline
description: N.A.A.C.P. Boycotts McDonald's on Coast

title: Filling a Gap
description: ''We've provided a weekend meal for 6,000 homebound elderly,'' said Gael Greene, the food writer and chief organizer of an auction on Sunday for Citymeals-on-Wheels. ''Now, let's give them dessert.''

title: Norwegian Prices Rise
description: Consumer prices in Norway rose 1.1 percent in March from the February level and were 6.6 percent higher than in March 1983, the Government said today.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information SystemsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: BEIRUT'S RESIDENTIAL DISTRICTS ARE HEAVILY SHELLED
description: Christian and Moslem militiamen today randomly lobbed artillery, mortar and antiaircraft fire into each other's residential neighborhoods, terrorizing Beirut's civilian population.

title: Crime Figure Is Convicted
description: Frank Balistrieri, described by the Federal Bureau of Investigation as the head of organized crime in Milwaukee, has been convicted of extortion for trying to take control of an vending machine business run by an undercover F.B.I. agent. Also convicted Monday were his two sons, Joseph, 43 years old, and John, 35. A fourth defendant, Mike Sabella, 73, a reported member of organized crime in New York, was found not guilty.

title: Doubt by Auditor On Mattel Funds
description: Price Waterhouse said ''it is not presently determinable'' whether Mattel Inc. would be able to work out a refinancing plan that would permit the toy maker to pay its bank debt and come up with seasonal financing to keep the company running.

title: Primary Data Disrupted By Students, Station Says
description: A television station has said college students it hired to put vote totals into computers in last week's primary election used the terminals to do their homework, disrupting election coverage.

title: No Headline
description: No Misconduct Found In Recall Vote Ruling

title: Dudey Moore Is Dead at 74;Coached 1955 N.I.T. Winner
description: Donald W. (Dudey) Moore, who won 270 games as the basketball coach at Duquesne University in Pittsburgh and LaSalle College here, died of a heart attack Sunday at a hospital in Bristol, Pa. He was 74 years old.

title: THE AMERICAN ACCUSER
description: On Oct. 22, 1962, a team of State Department lawyers worked through the night until 5 A.M., laying out the legal foundations for the naval quarantine of Cuba that President Kennedy had just announced to force a withdrawal of Soviet missiles from the island. Now Abram Chayes, who headed that team, is representing Nicaragua in a lawsuit against the United States in the World Court, accusing his country of illegally mining Nicaraguan ports and sending guerrillas to wreak destruction in Nicaraguan territory.

title: CREDIT MARKETS ; Short-Term Rates Are Mixed
description: Short-term interest rates were mixed yesterday, while Treasury note and bond yields rose slightly when weak investor demand led securities dealers to reduce prices modestly.

title: Whirlpool Up 30.6%
description: The Whirlpool Corporation said today that it earned $52.9 million, or $1.45 a share, in the first quarter, up 30.6 percent from $40.5 million, or $1.11 a share, in the 1983 quarter. Sales rose 26.8 percent, to $764.5 million, from $603 million.

title: GM AGENCY EXPANDS ITS INQUIRY ON BRAKING SYSTEMS TO FORD
description: The Government, already pressing a suit to have 1.1 million General Motors automobiles recalled because of brakes that lock prematurely, today announced an investigation into reports of similar problems in 431,000 Ford cars.

title: BOOK PUBLISHER LED WORLDWIDE BUSINESS
description: Sir Basil Blackwell, a leading British publisher, who on his 90th birthday ascribed his secret of longevity to ''being in a constant state of mild irritation,'' died on Monday at his home near Oxford, England. He was 94 years old. His son, Julian, said that his father worked until last Thursday.

title: DEBATE STIRRING ANEW OVER BEAUMONT THEATER
description: ''LA TRAGEDIE DE CARMEN'' is now being advertised as ''in its last weeks'' at the Vivian Beaumont Theater. The prospect of its closing, which has prompted the opera's producer to disclose some financial results of the production, is likely to renew disagreements between the boards of Lincoln Center and the Vivian Beaumont Theater.

description: b-After a loss of $700,000 from discontinued operations.

title: NOBEL-WINNING SOVIET PHYSICIST

description: -ignored vegetable in this country, and for no discernible reason unless, as several New York City produce dealers suggested recently, Americans don't want to bother with the somewhat laborious task of prizing the bean from its fleshy pod.

title: Ex-State Official Guilty of Larceny
description: A former State Agriculture Commissioner, H. Earl Waterman, was convicted by a jury today of first- degree larceny for pocketing $38,500 made on bogus sand deals while he was First Selectman in Suffield.
