title: HOW LONG SHOULD A CHILD BE NURSED?
description: AS the practice of breast-feeding has grown in popularity and more American mothers extend the period of nursing - sometimes until the child is 2 or 3 years old - a debate has taken shape over the value of nursing beyond infancy.

title: SENATE KILLS PLAN TO DELAY INFLATION-RELATED SHIFTS IN TAX BRACKETS
description: The Senate tonight defeated an amendment to delay for three years the shifting of income tax brackets to compensate for inflation that is scheduled to begin in January.

title: AMERICAN FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN (COLO) (O) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago share earnings have been restated for a 4-for-3 stock split in March 1984 and a 3-for-2 stock split in March 1983.

title: DANCE: ELIOT FELD BALLET
description: -loved works has been ''Intermezzo,'' a ballet he choreographed very early in his career in 1969. And last night, it came happily back into the repertory of the Feld Ballet, which opened a new season at the Joyce Theater. The program included a recent favorite, ''Straw Hearts,'' and the local premiere of ''The Jig Is Up,'' set to an unusual combination of Irish music and rock.

title: INTERNATIONAL PAPER OFF
description: The General Electric Company, helped by continuing gains in orders from its commercial and industrial markets, reported yesterday that earnings in the first quarter of 1984 rose 14.1 percent on a 7.9 increase in revenues.

title: Keeping Secrets
description: In 1976, Congress limited service on

title: Puerto Rico Bond Issue Is Offered
description: A $100 million financing for the Puerto Rico Aqueduct and Sewer Authority was offered with a maximum yield of 10 1/4 percent for bonds due in 2009 through a group of securities dealers led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. For shorter maturities, yields ranged from 6 1/4 percent for bonds due in 1985 to 9.40 percent in 1994.

title: Dan Wagoner Dancers At Judson Memorial
description: Dan Wagoner and Dancers will appear in an anniversary program at the Judson Memorial Church April 26, 27 and 28 at 8 P.M.

title: ISLANDERS ELIMINATE RANGERS IN OVERTIME, 3-2
description: The Islanders and the Rangers extended themselves to the limit tonight - in overtime of their decisive fifth playoff game - before the defending champion Islanders finally produced a 3-2 victory on a goal byKen Morrow.

title: N.A.S.L. Players Reject Pay Cut
description: The North American Soccer League Players Association yesterday refused the demand of the owners that players take a 15 percent cut in salary when the two sides met in Washington, according to David Brcic, the player representative of the Cosmos.

title: Enstar Invitation To Board Rejected
description: Thomas C. Thompson, who holds a 7 percent interest in the Enstar Corporation, said he is not willing to accept Enstar's invitation to join the board as an ''independent watchdog.'' He said he believed the company should be sold ''as fast as is consistent with obtaining the highest possible price.''

title: 'Ma Rainey's Black Bottom'
description: NEW HAVEN (April 11, 1984)

title: DONALD GORDON, 52, PROFESSOR
description: Donald Edward Gordon, a professor of fine arts at the University of Pittsburgh who specialized in German expressionist painting, died of cancer yesterday at Montefiore Hospital in Pittsburgh. He was 52 years old and lived in Pittsburgh.

title: AFG INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $2.9 million from the transfer of $9.4 million in long-term debt to a trust.

title: BID TO CUT COSTS IS FALLING SHORT BY $28 MILLION
description: Cost-cutting measures to help keep the municipal budget balanced have fallen short by nearly $28 million, the New York City budget office reported yesterday, and those planned savings are not likely to be achieved this year.

title: WPIX-FM Resignation
description: John C. Goodwill, the man behind the puckering cherubs of WPIX-FM, has resigned from the station to join R & R Broadcasting, a subsidiary of Robbins & Ries, a holding company that also owns an ad agency of the same name. It has no radio stations at the moment but expects to, and soon. Mr. Goodwill, 45 years old, who was vice president and general manager of WPIX, will be president and chief executive officer of the subsidiary of Robbins & Ries. Now let's see if his X wants him back.

title: ESPRIT SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: Year-ago results are from Jan. 28, 1983, the date of the company's inception, to Feb 28, 1983.

title: INVESTIGATORS NEAR END OF INQUIRY INTO DEATHS OF INFANTS AT HOSPITAL
description: Special investigators are winding down a yearlong inquiry into the deaths of infants at a San Antonio hospital, the chief investigator says, but it will be some time before a decision is made on whether to seek further indictments against Genene Ann Jones.

title: DURALITH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: Results for the latest periods include sales of $489,602 for the quarter and $1,492,058 for the year, a net income $992 for the quarter and a net loss of $48,156 for the year from the operations of Duralith Ltd. which was acquired in June 1983.

title: Stocks Gain; Dow Up 4.40, to 1,138.30
description: Stock prices rose moderately in more-active trading yesterday, as declining interest rates and bargain- hunting helped buoy the list.

title: Leading Police Official Resigns in Philadelphia
description: The city's second-highest-ranking police official resigned today, a day after agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation searched his office and car in connection with a Federal investigatton of police corruption.

title: OSCAR PROGRAM: DIFFERENT BUT LONG
description: DESPITE reports that this year's festivities would be streamlined, possibly enough to keep the entire event within a framework of three hours, ''The 56th Annual Academy Awards'' presentation from the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion of the Los Angeles Music Center began at 9 P.M. and ran 45 minutes beyond midnight, Eastern time, on ABC Monday night.

title: NO SOVIET DEMANDS RECEIVED BY I.O.C.
description: Twenty-four hours after the Soviet Olympic Committee had asked for an emergency meeting of the International Olympic Committee to investigate what it called an anti-Soviet campaign for this summer's Olympic Games in Los Angeles, an I.O.C spokesman said yesterday that the committee had received no formal request for such a meeting.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Mets vs. Braves, at Atlanta. John Gibbons of the Mets, now off the disabled list and at 21 the youngest catcher in the National League, is expected to make his debut.

title: Dow Increases Thiokol Holding
description: The Dow Chemical Company has increased its stake in Morton Thiokol Inc. of Chicago, a maker of specialty chemicals and rocket motors, to 1,146,100 common shares, or 6.82 percent of the shares outstanding.

title: KAISER ALUMINUM & CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss including a tax credit of $31.9 million.

title: NIEKRO IS WINNER IN STADIUM OPENER
description: The home opener, Yogi Berra said after the Yankees' home opener yesterday, ''is always exciting, no matter whether it's at home or on the road.''

title: 5 Killed in Sri Lanka In Guerrilla Incidents
description: Five people were killed in the northern town of Jaffna when Government forces fired on separatist guerrillas in two incidents today and Monday, a Government spokesman said today.

title: New York State Note Yields Cut
description: Yields were reduced slightly for most of New York State's $4.2 billion note offering because of strong investor demand, underwriters led by Salomon Brothers announced yesterday.

title: Sewage Treatment Found Improving
description: The treatment of sewage entering Long Island Sound has substantially improved in the last six years, with some exceptions, according to a 15- month study to be released Saturday.

title: LOSS LEAVES HELPLESS FEELING
description: Don Maloney thought his goal was a sign. If the Rangers were finally going to eliminate the Islanders from the playoffs, he thought his goal with 39 seconds to play in regulation time, was the tipoff.

title: 2 of Fugitives in Tennessee Captured With Aid of Hounds
description: Two of the three fugitives who fled a prison work detail Monday were tracked down in the brush today by bloodhounds and National Guardsmen.

title: REBUKE TO REAGAN
description: The Senate, in an angry rebuke to President Reagan, voted overwhelmingly tonight for a resolution that opposed the use of Federal funds to mine Nicaraguan waters.

title: ANTI-SEMITISM ISSUE WORRIES PARTY
description: Some Democratic officials are concerned that the controversy in the Democratic Presidential race involving the Rev. Jesse Jackson and American Jews could damage their party's chances of winning the White House in the November election. But there is no consensus on what to do about it, other than to charge the Reagan White House with exploiting the issue.

title: SALVADOR REBELS STILL SAID TO GET NICARAGUAN AID
description: Western European and Latin American diplomats here say the Nicaraguan Government is continuing to send military equipment to the Salvadoran insurgents and to operate training camps for them inside Nicaragua.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; President Resigns At Bloomingdale's
description: James S. Schoff Jr., president of Bloomingdale's, said yesterday that he would resign effective May 31 to pursue personal business interests.

title: HOMESTAKE MINING TO BUY FELMONT OIL
description: The Homestake Mining Company, the nation's largest gold producer, agreed to acquire the Felmont Oil Corporation, an oil and gas exploration company, in a stock swap valued at $400 million, the companies announced today.

title: 8 Killed in Falklands In Hospital Blaze
description: Fire wrecked the Falkland Islands' only hospital today, killing seven patients and a nurse who stayed in the burning building rather than leave her charges.

title: NEWS SUMMARY ;  WEDNESDAY, APRIL 11, 1984 International
description: The Senate voted 84 to 12 in favor of a sense of the Senate resolution that condemns the use of Federal funds to mine Nicaraguan waters. The overwhelming vote was a rebuke to President Reagan. The Senate majority leader, Howard H. Baker Jr., and 41 other Republicans voted against the Administration. Senator Russell B. Long, Democrat of Louisana, was joined by 11 Republicans in opposing the resolution, which was sponsored by Senator Edward M. Kennnedy, Democrat of Massachusetts. (Page A1, Column 6.) Nicaragua's Sandinista leaders are continuing to send military equipment to guerrillas in El Salvador and to operate training camps for them in Nicaragua, according to Western European and Latin American diplomats in Managua. The United States has been making such charges since 1980. Nicaraguan leaders, who do not explicitly deny all of the charges, say, their support is ''moral and political.'' (A1:5.)

title: LET THEM FIGHT
description: Foreign policy clearly is emerging as the main issue of the Presidential election campaign. Both parties seem to want it that way, and a serious debate on where we are and where we're going is inevitable and desirable.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A map on Monday, with an article about a drive by Mozambique against rebel forces, incorrectly used the former name of Zimbabwe's capital. The city, known as Salisbury when the country was called Rhodesia and for a time afterward, is now Harare.

title: SOCIETY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TV 'V' NOW A BOOK
description: Novelizations of feature films have become commonplace, but novelizations of television movies are a rarity. So the appearance this month of a novel called ''V,'' written by Anne Crispin and based on the series first shown on NBC-TV last year and that will return with a six-hour sequel next month, represents an unusual multimedia event.

title: Turnpike Agency Fights
description: The New Jersey Turnpike Authority is trying to block two advertising billboards along the highway, charging that they would pose a danger to motorists and clutter the landscape.

title: INTERNATIONAL PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Fed Chairman's Term
description: The House Banking Committee today voted to change the term of the Federal Reserve Board chairman so it corresponds more closely to that of the President. The bill would make the four-year term of a Fed chairman expire one year after the start of a President's term.

title: Japan Trade Surplus Rises
description: Japan had a foreign trade surplus of $3.2 billion in March, up from $2.04 billion a year earlier, the Finance Ministry said today.

title: UNWELCOME WATERS
description: For nearly 50 years, the Army Corps of Engineers has been examining flooding in the 900-square-mile Passaic River Basin of northern New Jersey.

title: REVIVED UNION STRENGTH AIDS MONDALE, POLL SHOWS
description: After suffering the embarrassment of early primary defeats, the nation's trade union movement has bounced back politically to provide a steadily increasing share of Walter F. Mondale's victory margins in recent primaries, helping to revitalize his drive for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: P.& G. REALIGNS KEY POSTS
description: The Procter & Gamble Company announced today a sweeping realignment of its top management team, shifting its two executive vice presidents to staff positions and indicating that one of its Brussels executives was the heir-apparent to the job of chief executive. A total of seven top-level changes were announced.

title: Reliance Buys More of Disney
description: The Reliance Financial Sevices Corporation, a unit of Reliance Group Inc., told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had raised its stake in Walt Disney Productions of Burbank, Calif., to 2,852,933 common shares, or 8.3 percent of the shares outstanding.

title: TOLL REPORTED HIGH IN CAMEROON
description: Scores of people were killed or injured and much property was damaged in two days of intense fighting after the attempted coup here Friday, residents of this capital city said today.

title: Spanish Patent Laws
description: Spain will bring its patent laws into line with those of the European Economic Community, which Spain will join in 1986, the community said today.

title: STEAMER AND SUSHI KIT
description: BEFORE long fresh local asparagus will be in the market. Cooking it properly can be tricky because the tapered tips cook faster than the thick stems. To assure even cooking, asparagus should be placed upright in a covered pot and steamed. The intense heat at the bottom will soften the stems without overcooking the tips.

title: WHIRLPOOL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
OF DOUBT AND ABORTION
description: To the Editor:

title: POINTING FINGERS: LAWMAKERS REPLY TO REAGAN
description: Representative Robert H. Michel, the Republican leader in the House, was pondering the effect of President Reagan's attacks last week on Congressional intervention in foreign affairs.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: THE nation now faces a cancer epidemic, but not the kind of epidemic most people think. It is an epidemic not of disease but of fear. A recent national survey conducted by the National Cancer Institute's Office of Cancer Communications found that half of Americans think that ''everything causes cancer'' and that ''there's not much a person can do to prevent cancer.''

title: NEW YORKERS
description: AS far as Burton Batt is concerned, a lot of animals behave better than a lot of people. As a result of this point of view, he doesn't bat an eyelash when his summer weekend guests have names like Caviar, Sunshine, Napoleon and Star. In fact, Mr. Batt said, he doesn't ask his two-legged friends to bring their pets with them; it's just taken for granted.

title: Four More Artists Join Chamber Music Society
description: Four musicians- Alvin Brehm, Richard Goode, Ani Kavafian and Fred Sherry - will join the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center for the 1984-85 season, which begins Oct. 21.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Variations on a Theme

title: FIRST BANNER, FIRST BALL
description: In the sunny chill of Yankee Stadium

title: ABOUT BOSTON
description: Receiving a notice for one's annual automobile excise tax in Massachusetts isn't normally a time for joy, since it can run to $700 or more.

title: CHERNENKO ATTACKS INACTIVITY OF LOCAL GOVERNMENT BODIES
description: Gathered for its regular spring meeting, the Communist Party's Central Committee today heard Konstantin U. Chernenko complain of inactive local government bodies and swollen bureaucracies, but he made no new senior party appointments.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: TO the denizens of the Bowery whose invention has long enlivened this space goes the Silver Squeegee Award for Creative Panhandling. Past columns have celebrated a number of printed appeals to motorists on the Bowery, our favorite being: ''I am raising $1,000,000 for research on alcoholism. Please help.'' This week's entry comes from Stanley and Ellen Poler. While stopped for a red light on a recent rainy night, they saw a sodden figure holding a five-foot sign:

title: Nortek May Try To Buy Amerace
description: Nortek Inc. said that it had acquired 227,939 shares of the Amerace Corporation, or about 8.8 percent, and that it might seek to acquire Amerace. Nortek, which makes building products and granite products, said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had bought the shares for investment ''with a view toward acquiring a significant equity interest in Amerace.''

title: Nestle Has Option
description: Nestle Holdings Inc. said it had acquired an option to buy all the stock of Hills Brothers Coffee.

title: No Headline
description: A Philadelphia Congressman narrowly won renomination today while another from Wilkes-Barre was headed for defeat in the Democratic primary.

title: WORLD COURT EVASION
description: Like the American officer who ordered a Vietnamese village destroyed in order to save it, the Reagan Administration is boycotting the World Court to prevent it from being ''misused'' by Nicaragua. That was the Administration's justification for its abrupt declaration last weekend that its 1946 pledge to accept the court's jurisdiction ''temporarily'' no longer applies to disputes involving the United States and any of the countries of Central America.

title: INTERCONTINENTAL LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
AN ACTIVIST TAKES ON GENETIC ENGINEERING
description: Jeremy Rifkin, among the nation's most vociferous opponents of advances in genetic engineering, says he will be back in court this week, seeking to halt an experiment that he considers potentially dangerous.

title: Running Dispute
description: The controversy is continuing in Britain over the Olympic eligibility of Zola Budd , the 17-year-old running star from South Africa who last Friday was granted British citizenship. Miss Budd plans to run in the trials in June that select Britain's team for the Olympic Games.

title: SENATE PANEL VOTES BROADCAST FUNDS
description: The Senate Commerce Committee today authorized funds for the Corporation for Public Broadcasting for the fiscal years 1987 to 1989 at levels more than twice those recommended by the Reagan Administration.

title: Japanese Seek Steel Job
description: Kenematsu-Goshu Ltd. said today that it and 10 other Japanese companies had bid jointly for a contract to supply 300,000 tons of steel tubes, worth about $400 million, for an American pipeline project. The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company plans to build a $900 million, 1,240-mile pipeline to move crude oil from California offshore fields to refineries in Texas.

title: PERILS OF LEVERAGING BONDS
description: For the Marsh & McLennan Companies, yesterday was another day of ''no comment'' on the bond-trading activities that will mean an after-tax charge against the company of about $60 million for the first quarter. The company has not said the activities were illegal, just unauthorized.

title: Chartercorp In Settlement
description: Chartercorp said that Stanley Durwood and three companies he controls had agreed not to acquire or offer to acquire any shares of Chartercorp for 10 years. They also agreed not to solicit proxies or otherwise act to seek control or to influence the company's management, board or policies.

title: YONKERS MOVES TO ENACT INCOME TAX SURCHARGE
description: The City Council voted unanimously tonight to ask for state authorization for a 15 percent city surcharge on state income taxes paid by Yonkers residents and a 5 percent levy for nonresidents.

title: STUD ON SATELLITE MAY HAVE FOILED ASTRONAUT CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., April 11 (UPI) - The astronaut James van Hoften told ground controllers today that a small stud sticking out from the Solar Max satellite might have prevented a spacewalker from docking with it.
description: In a free flight in space from the space shuttle Sunday, another astronaut, George Nelson, tried to grab the satellite with a bulky assembly, the trunnion pin attachment device. But the device did not lock onto a docking pin on the side of the satellite. Terry Hart, another astronaut, snagged the satellite Tuesday using the shuttle's robot arm.

title: MARSH HAD A $2 BILLION BOND POSITION
description: The Marsh & McLennan Companies accumulated some $2 billion in government bond positions, in large part as a result of unauthorized trading by one of its dealers, the company said yesterday. The positions were significantly larger than the company realized it held.

title: PAPERS SIGN VENDING-BOX ACCORD
description: Five newspapers have signed an agreement with New York City regulating the placement of newspaper vending machines on city streets, Mayor Koch announced yesterday.

title: ELECTRO RENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Neutrality Inquiry Is Urged
description: Democrats in the House Judiciary Committee are seeking an inquiry into whether the United States violated neutrality laws by supporting military attacks on Nicaragua. One of the Democrats, Representative Don Edwards of California, said they want a special prosecutor to look into the matter.

title: SPRAYING ON COAST SPURS OPPOSITION
description: Over residents' opposition, the California Department of Food and Agriculture is spraying suburban lawns in an effort to wipe out the Japanese beetle.

title: DESIGNHOUSE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
CHARTERHOUSE IN PACT FOR STAKE IN HAMBRO
description: Charterhouse J. Rothschild P.L.C., one of London's newest and most broadly based financial services companies, today announced a preliminary agreement to acquire Hambros P.L.C.'s 24.8 percent stake in Hambro Life Assurance P.L.C. as the first step toward a merger with the insurance company.

title: MOORE FINANCIAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
JUDGE ORDERS DECLARATION IN DELOREAN TRIAL
description: The judge in the John Z. DeLorean case, disturbed by a tardy disclosure that some Government tapes were erased, today demanded a sworn declaration from an informant and warned prosecutors that he might consider ''additional steps.''

title: National Medical
description: National Medical Care Inc. said it is not currently engaged in merger discussions with any company. However, Constantine Hampers, chairman of the operator of outpatient artificial-kidney centers, said the company ''did have some serious discussions with another company during the past week, but those discussions have been terminated and we are not now carrying on or considering any merger discussions.''

title: O' SULLIVAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
C.D. Rates Go Higher
description: Annual effective yields on six- month certificates of deposit continued an upward trend, averaging 9.97 percent, up from 9.91 the previous week, according to The Bank Rate Monitor's national index. The six- month products have reached their highest levels since the October 1983 deregulation.

title: CHIEF EXECUTIVE ADDS A TITLE AT INTERNORTH
description: Sam F. Segnar has added another hat at Internorth Inc.: He is now chairman as well as president and chief executive of the diversified energy company based in Omaha.

title: Here's Baseball, By the Book(s)
description: Three months of poring over ''The Baseball Encylopedia,'' published by Macmillan Publishing Company, enabled Frank Coffey to gather the material for ''The All Time Baseball Teams Book,'' which was published on Monday by St. Martin's Press. It is a collection of 50 ''fantasy'' teams that Coffey, a former editor with Prentice-Hall and Fawcett Books, put together by categories.

title: 5 Sri Lanka Rebels Are Reported Slain
description: Security forces clashed with separatist guerrillas in the northern city of Jaffna today, killing 5 and raising the toll to 22 since Tuesday.

title: KREMLIN AIDE ON THE MOVE
description: When Mikhail Sergeyevich Gorbachev rose in the Supreme Soviet today to nominate Konstantin U. Chernenko as President, the action seemed to confirm Mr. Gorbachev's emergence as the second-ranking Soviet party leader. His prominence at the age of 53 is due in large part to Yuri V. Andropov, who delegated ever larger responsibilities to the ''young boy'' of the ruling Politburo.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''The Council President is behind the times. The Department of Transportation is in the final stages of preparing a major citywide street repair initiative that will be announced Monday.

title: LEROY LEATHERMAN, NOVELIST
description: LeRoy Leatherman, a novelist and arts administrator who was associated for many years with the Martha Graham Dance Company in New York, died Monday after a brief illness in Daniel Freeman Hospital in Inglewood, Calif. He was 62 years old and lived in Santa Monica.

title: STAGE: 'VAMPIRES' AT THE ASTOR PLACE
description: ONE of the oddballs in Harry Kondoleon's ''The Vampires'' is a fledgling playwright who's written a patriotic, ''American naturalist'' drama about colonial times. Given that Mr. Kondoleon's own play is a terribly with-it absurdist farce, this fictional playwright is the butt of many jokes. What Mr. Kondoleon doesn't seem to realize, however, is that ''The Vampires'' is just as tired and formulaic as the old-fashioned claptrap he mocks. As the playwright on stage seems to be rewriting Paul Green, so Mr. Kondoleon seems to be rewriting Joe Orton (with periodic digressions into Christopher Durang).

title: MEAD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss after a loss from discontinued operations of $1.6 million. The year-ago results were restated for discontinued operations.

title: 25 Are Injured At Fire in Passaic
description: More than 25 people, including residents, police officers and firefighters, were injured today in an apartment fire that forced the evacuation of a high-rise complex, authorities said.

title: Jury Picked in Slaying of Two
description: Jury selection was completed here today in the first-degree murder trial of a teen-ager accused of killing two local bankers last fall.

title: Site for Sports Complex
description: The New York State Sportsplex Corporation has decided to study 15 sites in and near New York City as possible locations for a new professional sports complex.

title: ADVICE ON GROWING AND USING HERBS
description: HERBS are delightful plants to have in the garden. Their uses are numerous, but their cultural requirements are extremely varied. Some herbs are annuals and must be planted each spring. Others are perennial and come back year after year.

title: No Headline
description: Gerald C. Thomas, 89, Marine Corps General

title: OPERA: 2 SOPRANOS IN 'DON CARLO'
description: TWO sopranos made their first appearances this year in the Metropolitan Opera's ''Don Carlo'' on Monday night. In the cast changes, Stefka Evstatieva, the Bulgarian singer, made her Met debut as Verdi's Elizabeth, and Shirley Verrett sang the Princess of Eboli.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: CANADA TRUSTCO MORTGAGE CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in February. The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: Citibank Wins Bid On Texas Bonds
description: A $165 million Texas general obligation veterans' bond issue was won in competitive bidding by Citibank yesterday.

title: No Headline
description: Agency Delays Ruling On Air Bags in Autos

title: SENATE VOTE: A JOLT FOR REAGAN'S POLICIES
description: The Senate's condemnation of the mining of Nicaraguan harbors not only has dealt President Reagan his most severe political jolt on foreign policy but may have caused lasting damage to his ability to muster bipartisan support for his policies in Central America. Although the Senate resolution was not binding, Republican as well as Democratic Congressional leaders said they thought the overwhelming vote Tuesday signaled the end of Congressional financing of the Nicaraguan rebels through the Central Intelligence Agency. They said it had even put in jeopardy aid for El Salvador.

title: NEEDLEWORK RUGS, ANTIQUE AND MODERN
description: ''I love handwork,'' said the fashion designer Cathy Hardwick, sitting in her living room, where the beige wall- to-wall carpet is almost covered by two early 19th-century needlepoint rugs vivid with bright cabbage roses on a black background. ''These rugs are not grand and pretentious,'' Miss Hardwick said, ''and they add a charming country look to a room.''

title: Celanese Earnings Soar
description: The Celanese Corporation, one of the world's largest producers of man- made fibers, said net income in the first quarter increased more than sevenfold, to $44 million, or $2.74 a share, from $6 million, or 32 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales rose 9.3 percent, to $837 million, from $766 million.

title: HOT TEMPERS? CHINESE SAY, 'DON'T SUE, MEDITATE'
description: The fight started as a routine quarrel between a tenant and the landlord who wanted to evict her from her home in the teeming Jinhua neighborhood of western Canton.

title: IN POST-COUP GUINEA, A JAIL IS THROWN OPEN
description: Cell 72 was typical: a concrete room about five feet wide and eight feet long, illuminated only by the narrow shafts of light that filtered through small holes near the ceiling.

title: Irsay Tells of 'Sacrifice'
description: It may not wring tears from his abandoned Baltimore fans, but Robert Irsay says that it required personal sacrifice to move the Colts to Indianapolis. The Colts' owner estimated that the move cost ''between $1 and $2 million of my own personal money,'' including legal fees, reorganization, hiring and training new staff and an obligation to the National Football League's marketing arm to buy the entire inventory of products bearing the Baltimore logo.

title: Mondale Off the Bet Board
description: A leading British bookmaker suspended all bets on Walter F. Mondale as the Democrats Presidential candidate today after his victory in the Pennsylvania primary. An official at Ladbrokes, the bookmaker, said Mr. Mondale would be too big of an odds-on favorite for a bettor to win after the 10 percent deduction for income tax.

title: RECITAL: HARP AND GUITAR PROGRAM
description: two plucked string instruments with resonating wooden bodies - might seem a natural. And the teaming of the guitarist Narciso Yepes and the harpist Nicanor Zabaleta might seem more natural still - two admired, experienced Spanish performers with similar interests in repertory and even the same record company, Deutsche Grammophon.

title: DESOTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Get Serious About Population
description: Family planning isn't murder. But that's not obvious to American right-to-lifers who contend that efforts to defuse the population bomb in poor countries support forced abortions in China.

title: NATIONAL SHOES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-After tax credits of $258,000 for the quarter and $1,616,000 for the year. c-After tax credits of $50,000 for the quarter and $880,000 for the year.

title: Dow Raises Stake
description: The Dow Chemical Company has raised its stake again in Morton Thiokol Inc., a Chicago-based maker of specialty chemicals and rocket motors, to 1,349,500 shares, or 8.03 percent of the shares outstanding. Dow said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it bought 203,400 shares in open-market transactions Tuesday at prices ranging from $74.25 to $75.50 a share. This was the third filing to the S.E.C. in as many days by Dow, a chemical and plastics maker based in Midland, Mich. On the New York Stock Exchange today, Morton Thiokol fell $1.125, to $74.50

title: Pol Pot Forces Say They Wrecked a Town
description: Cambodian rebels said today that one of their units had destroyed Kompong Speu, a provincial capital about 25 miles south of Phnom Penh, Cambodia's capital.

title: GAF CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including extraordinary credits of $6,132,000 for the latest first quarter and $1,026,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: LED SCREEN PRODUCERS GUILD
description: Samuel G. Engel, a three-time president of the Screen Producers Guild who started the televising of the Academy Awards ceremonies, died Saturday at his home here. He was 79 years old.

title: Letter: On Sex Bias ; Pension Equality, Lawfully Achieved
description: To the Editor:

title: Experiment With Life, Not Death
description: As Florida and Louisiana prepared to execute two more condemned murderers this week, Governor Cuomo again vetoed a bill to expand New York's death penalty. Mr. Cuomo favors a less popular yet more humane and realistic form of extreme punishment for the most egregious killings - life imprisonment without possibility of parole. The idea deserves a test now that the death penalty is again being tested, and New York would make a good laboratory.

title: RAYTHEON CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Union City Ruled In Contempt
description: A Federal judge today declared Union City in contempt of court and threatened fines of $1,000 a day if it failed to surrender documents to a grand jury investigating corruption charges.

title: BALLET: ROYAL WINNIPEG IN BROOKLYN
description: ON its much too infrequent visits here, the Royal Winnipeg Ballet has been notable for its attractive dancers and its admirable policy of building an eclectic repertory.

title: EX-BOOKKEEPER INDICTED IN THEFTS FROM PRIVATE SCHOOL ON EAST SIDE
description: A former bookkeeper at a private school on the Upper East Side was arrested yesterday and charged with stealing more than $165,000 from the school.

title: U.S. ACTIONS AND STATEMENTS IN THE DISPUTE OVER NICARAGUA
description: Since taking office more than three years ago, the Reagan Administration has publicly acknowledged using military pressure, diplomacy and economic boycott against the Nicaraguan Government, which the Administration views as a threat to democracy in this hemisphere. Following are some of the actions by Congress and the Reagan Administration and statements by President Reagan on Central America. title: AEL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 24
description: b-Including tax credits of $340,000 for the quarter and $2.5 million for the year. c-Including a tax benefit allowed for Ultracom Inc. of $297,000. d-Net loss after a loss of $2,754,000 from discontinued operations.

title: A Big Difference
description: Bob Tembeckjian will today join

title: ...NATIONAL SYSTEM WITH A DIFFERENCE
description: To the Editor:

title: 1984, A BAD YEAR IF YOU FEAR FRIDAY THE 13TH
description: Stephen King is the author of 13 books, including ''The Shining'' and most recently, ''Pet Sematary.''

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Minnesota Twins, at Yankee Stadium, 8:05 P.M. New York, aiming for three straight, goes with Ray Fontenot.

title: Last of 4 Fugitives Is Sought In Tennessee Prison Escape
description: The military police, state troopers and prison guards conducted a door-to- door search today for the last of four dangerous inmates who crept away from a Fort Pillow Prison work detail Monday. The object of the hunt was Gary Bernard Sanders, a convicted killer.

title: Fed Ruling Spurs First Interstate Plan
description: The First Interstate Bancorp, the nation's seventh-largest bank holding company, said today that it had asked Federal regulators to approve its plan to open 12 ''consumer'' banks in seven states.

title: CELANESE CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: BAD CONDITIONS UNCOVERED AT COAST HOSPITAL
description: Acting on an anonymous complaint, a team of 10 investigators from the State Department of Health Services inspected conditions and nursing practices at San Francisco General Hospital. They discovered many unacceptable conditions, including kitchen facilities that were covered with a heavy accumulation of grease, a medical records system that was virtually nonexistent and practices contrary to nursing policy that contributed to the deaths of two patients.

title: D'AMATO LASHES OUT AT MOYHIHAN IN RARE SENATE OUTBURST
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato denounced his colleague from New York as ''contemptible'' today in an unusual outburst on the Senate floor.

title: U.S.I.A. NOMINEE DENIES LINKS TO A LIST OF BANNED SPEAKERS
description: Leslie Lenkowsky, nominated to be deputy director of the United States Information Agency, said today that he had no recollection of discussing at a staff meeting the destruction of some documents relating to the agency's blacklist of public speakers.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: USING a chemical paint and varnish remover is probably the quickest and easiest way to strip furniture, woodwork and exterior trim. Scraping or sanding is less expensive, but it is harder work and more time-consuming. It is also more likely to damage the surface or destroy the patina of old pieces.

title: CERTAIN-TEED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PRESIDENT, STRESSING ECONOMIC GAINS, WARNS OF 'SNAKE OIL CURES'
description: President Reagan visited a busy automobile factory today to stress the domestic economy as a campaign issue and warn against the ''snake oil cures'' of his opponents.

title: RULE IS REJECTED ON SALUTING FLAG
description: Members of a town meeting voted Tuesday night to open their sessions by singing the national anthem but not to recite the pledge of allegiance to the flag, an issue that has been debated in this Boston suburb for months.

title: Technology; Land Surveys By Electronics
description: DETROIT THE application of modern electronics has

title: SCHOOL HONORS 5 DESIGNERS AND ARTISTS
description: ''When I first came to America in 1938,'' recalls the designer Herbert Bayer, ''there were many billboards along the road, and they all had a lot of text.'' The artist, now 84 years old, was surprised that signs made for motorists were primarily verbal rather than visual.

title: Selection of Delegates In Wisconsin Assailed
description: Attorney General Bronson La Follette said Tuesday that he might seek to become a Gary Hart delegate to the Democratic National Convention in July because of caucus results that he said had made a ''mockery'' of the delegate selection process.

title: Seattle Wins Again
description: Al Davis, a rookie, belted a three-run homer, and Al Cowens drove in two runs with a home run and a double to lead Seattle to a 5-1 victory over the Boston Red Sox tonight. It was the fifth straight victory for the Mariners.

title: GOAL BY MALONEY A STICKY QUESTION
description: Had the Rangers gone on to win, Don Maloney's strange, controversial goal on Tuesday night against the Islanders might have become part of sports lore.

title: Trust Issue Priced
description: A $100 million 30-year first mortgage and collateral trust bond issue for the Texas Utilities Electric Company was priced yesterday by an underwriting team lead by Morgan Stanley & Company to yield 13.70 percent. The bonds, due in 2014, were given a 13 5/8 percent coupon and priced at 99.44. The issue is rated Aa-2 by Moody's and AAx by S. & P. The proceeds from the sale will be used to meet expenditures for the company's construction program, and other corporate purposes.

title: SAFETY-KLEEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BARCLAY'S WILL BUILD A HEADQUARTERS ON WALL ST.
description: Barclays Bank International said yesterday that it would build a $200 million North American headquarters on Wall Street. The 36-story structure is expected to open in the latter half of 1986.

title: ISLANDERS GIRD FOR ROUND 2 AGAINST THE CAPITALS TONIGHT
description: With barely enough time to go home, shave and shower after their emotional overtime victory against the Rangers Tuesday night, the Islanders begin round two of the Stanley Cup playoffs at Nassau Coliseum tonight against another young, ambitious team, the Washington Capitals.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Houston's Bonds Lose Moody's Highest Rating
description: Houston, one of the few cities in the nation with a triple A bond rating, lost some of its luster yesterday when Moody's Investors Service Inc. downgraded its bonds to Aa-1 from Aaa. However, the Standard & Poor's Corporation continues to rate the city's bonds AAA.

title: RETIREMENT LIFE VARIES IN THREE COMMUNITIES
description: AGNES MYERS is 87 years old, likes martinis, says she was ''born in Michigan so I wouldn't have to be born in Ohio'' and that she is quite happy in her retirement in Kendal-Crosslands, a continuing-care community near Philadelphia. In a hospital setting with full medical care she is able to live in comfortable quarters with some of her own furniture.

title: MEDIA HORIZONS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: In 1983, the company realized a pretax operating profit of $86,631 and a nonrecurring gain of $92,448 from the sale of a lease and leasehold improvements. The company also realized in 1982 a nonrecurring gain of $635,252 from the sale of two publications.

title: MURPHY INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-After a tax credit of $82,618 and a gain on settlement of debt of $1,082,627. c-Net loss

title: PUTTING THE DISABLED TO WORK
description: ''Here's how I read,'' Stewart Wiggins said. He picked up a small lens that was wired to a device that resembled a tape recorder. It was called an Optacon. He deftly ran the lens over a computer printout while he stuck his left index finger into the tape recorder-like device. As the lens swept over sentences, the device vibrated. Mr. Wiggins has been trained to translate the vibrations into words.

title: CALENDAR: ORCHIDS, ART
description: Greater New York Orchid Show, New

title: ALAMO UNDER SIEGE: DEFENDERS STANDING FIRM AGAINST ILLINOIS HISTORY BUFF
description: The Alamo, the Texas shrine where 187 Americans held off 5,000 Mexican troops for 13 days before being slaughtered to a man, is now undergoing a siege of a different and more modern kind.

title: Philharmonic Conductor
description: James Chambers, the former solo horn player of the New York Philharmonic who is now the orchestra's personnel manager, will conduct Dvorak's Wind Serenade at the New York Philharmonic Ensembles concert at the Asia Society Sunday at 5 P.M. Mr.Chambers will replace the ailing Zubin Mehta, the originally scheduled conductor.

title: F.C.C. TO EXAMINE FAIRNESS DOCTRINE
description: The Federal Communications Commission voted today to initiate a broad study of the fairness doctrine, the 35- year-old rule that requires broadcasters to cover controversial issues of public importance and present contrasting views.

title: Cruise Ship Bill Advances
description: The House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee approved by voice vote today a bill to allow foreign-flag cruise ships to offer one-way passenger service between Puerto Rico and the United States.

title: WARNER ELECTRIC BRAKE & CLUTCH CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Debt Issues
description: * Ajinomoto Co. , a Japanese foodstuffs company, said it had increased the amount of its 15-year convertible Eurodollar bond offering a second time to $120 million. The lead manager is Nomura Securities Co.

title: NURSE SENTENCED TO DIE IN SLAYINGS
description: A nurse convicted of killing 12 elderly patients with overdoses of a heart-regulating drug was sentenced today to die in the gas chamber.

title: THEATER: 'LOVE LETTERS'
description: WHEN Victor Marsden opens his morning mail, he finds, along with the usual bills and solicitations, love letters from his wife. A ruggedly individual trade unionist, he is dying of leukemia. His wife finds that she can be candid in private print though she is unable to reveal her emotions in person. Such is the simple story line of Arnold Wesker's ''Love Letters on Blue Paper,'' a quiet, evocative play about a man and a woman learning to adjust to an oncoming death in the family.

title: Market Place; Earning Profits From Weather
description: WALL STREET security analysts ponder two time horizons in assessing company prospects - the short term, a period of months, and the long term, perhaps several years. Whenever the market outlook is misty, for example, analysts usually allow that they are ''cautious for the short term, but bullish for the long term.''

title: ICN PHARMACEUTICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Including and extraordinary credit of $45,000.

title: PENN WEST PETROLEUM reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The latest period includes a writedown of $1,542,000 on U.S. oil and gas properties and an affiliated company's loss of $1,275,973.

title: TOWN MARKS THE REOPENING OF SCENIC CALIFORNIA ROUTE
description: In a ceremony hundreds of feet above the surging Pacific surf, more than 1,000 people today celebrated the reopening of a highway that was closed by a huge landslide 13 months ago, isolating this community and taking away its economic vitality.

title: WESTINGHOUSE ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Genesco President Also Its Chairman
description: Richard W. Hanselman, Genesco Inc.'s president and chief executive, was elected yesterday to the additional post of chairman of the big Nashville footwear and apparel company.

title: UNICORP CANADA CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Including a gain of $9 million on the sale of an investment.

title: ARGENTINE DEAL HELPED
description: J. P. Morgan & Company reported yesterday that its net income rose 23.9 percent, to $146 million, in the first quarter, up from $117.8 million a year ago. On a per-share basis, net income climbed 20.3 percent, to $3.32 from $2.76.

title: PIONEER HI-BRED INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
No Headline

description: For more than 125 years an organization of women has been

title: Entering Pleas In Parking Cases
description: Parking tickets in New York City will soon carry what will be new information for many drivers: They can plead not guilty through the mail and never make a court appearance.

title: TRASHING THE U.N.
description: The United States has been spraying the United Nations with pot-shots lately. Aimed at a clear, specific target, the effort can be useful. But as a reflex or a habit, the risk is not only of missing wildly but of being just the bully on the block.

title: Pryor Maps Comeback
description: Aaron Pryor , the unbeaten former World Boxing Association junior welterweight champion, said he had tentatively scheduled a comeback bout against Tony Baltazar next month or early June.

title: DEMOTING THE BOARD OF ESTIMATE WON'T CURE IT
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: The U.N. Today April 12, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: LATIN DEBT AT A SMALLER BANK
description: The impact of Latin America's foreign debt crisis reaches far beyond the board rooms and balance sheets of America's biggest banks. It is also felt in a sunny, spacious office on the third floor of the First Wisconsin National Bank.

title: Westinghouse Gains; Raytheon Also Higher
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation reported yesterday that earnings in the first quarter rose 16.3 percent, despite lower revenues.

title: WOMEN CAUTIONED ON HEALTH MATTERS
description: AMERICAN women must take greater responsibility for maintaining their health because the diseases of later life are greatly affected by such factors as diet and exercise, a conference on women's health was told this week.

title: Fitting Buildings to People
description: ''I can't draw a straight line,'' Richard Wener said yesterday as he opened a new architecture exhibition, ''even with a ruler.''

title: CHINA SAID TO OUST HIGH OFFICIAL
description: The propaganda chief of the Chinese Communist Party has been forced to resign, apparently after losing a power struggle over the recent ''spiritual pollution'' campaign, a diplomatic source said today.

title: Mead Corp.  Posts Profit
description: The Mead Corporation, helped by strong performances in its paper operations, reported net income of $21.6 million, or 71 cents a share, in the first quarter of 1984, contrasted to a deficit of $12 million a year earlier. Sales rose 20.4 percent, to $657.3 million, from $545.9 million. Burnell R. Roberts, chairman of the Dayton, Ohio, forest products company, said paper markets remained strong and prices had improved for many of Mead's paper grades.

title: NURSING-HOME WORKERS GET LESSON IN WHYS OF PASSOVER
description: The Hebrew Home for the Aged in Riverdale is being turned upside down these days in preparation for the Passover holiday that starts Monday night. A special set of dishes is being brought up from the basement, the ovens are being dismantled for scouring and no sofa is being left unturned in the search for bread crumbs.

title: Transactions
description: Named Laura Golden head women's basketball coach. NORTH DAKOTA - Named Bruce Bukowski assistant football coach. SAMFORD - Named Mike Hanks head basketball coach.

title:
CREDIT MARKETS ;
Prices of U.S. Securities Rise
description: Government securities prices were modestly higher in quiet trading yesterday. Analysts said activity was slow in advance of the economic and statistical data to be reported today and tomorrow.

title: 2 VIRGINIA CHILDREN DIE IN BLAZE AS HELP IS DELAYED AFTER CALL
description: A 9-year-old girl, alone with her younger brother in their burning home, telephoned information on their whereabouts 50 minutes before firefighters arrived to find them dead, according to transcripts released Tuesday by City Manager Manuel Deese.

title: HALTING INSIDER TRADING
description: Over the last three decades, the Securities and Exchange Commission has successfully discouraged most professional stock traders from capitalizing on inside information. Through a combination of rule-making, monitoring, lecturing and enforcing, the agency has bent the norms of business behavior toward the ''disclose or refrain from trading'' rule.

title: 'TURUMBA'
description: ''TURUMBA,'' the second feature by the Philippine film maker Kidlat Tahimik, unfolds in a gradual and deceptively deadpan style. It takes place in a small village, where the festival of the title is an occasion for every family to make papier- mache figurines.

title: 10 EASTERN STATES SET LOW EDB LEVEL
description: Health officials from 10 Eastern states agreed at a closed meeting here today to set a level for the pesticide ethylene dibromide, or EDB, in some food products that is far more stringent than that set by the Federal Government.

title: Bonanza for Fryar
description: Irving Fryar , the Nebraska wide receiver who signed a four-year guaranteed contract with the New England Patriots, will be well paid.

title: Thompson's Charges
description: John Thompson , the Georgetown basketball coach, says that reporters bet on college basketball games and that there should be an investigation to determine ''if what sportswriters write isn't influenced by their betting.'' Thompson did not name any reporters, but Zachary Smith , Georgetown's sports information director, said that ''based on jokes and things I've heard on press row, I'd say it's not uncommon.''

title: REPUBLICBANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FEWER YOUTHS READ BOOKS, STUDY FINDS
description: BOOK reading among Americans under the age of 21 has dropped sharply since 1978, from 75 percent of that age group to 63 percent, according to a major national survey of reading habits commissioned by the book industry. There has also been a marked drop in book reading among people who are age 65 and over.

title: The Lawyer's Task
description: Lawyers are no strangers to oratory,

title: FLAWS IN TRADING PRACTICES CITED
description: Trading practices in the government securities market, where volume exceeds $50 billion a day, appear to have permitted a trader at the Marsh & McLennan Companies to violate company policies and accumulate a $2 billion position in long- term bonds.

title: NBC ADDS MTM'S 'DUCK FACTORY'
description: -founded by Grant Tinker, and since Mr. Tinker is the current head of NBC-TV, it might seem a bit touchy for the network to stock up heavily on MTM products. On the other hand, MTM has an exceptionally good record for quality series, and NBC would be daft not to do business with the studio. In any event, another MTM series, ''The Duck Factory,'' is being added to the NBC schedule tonight at 9:30, cozily snuggled between ''Cheers'' and ''Hill Street Blues,'' two of the network's other MTM offerings.

title: WRENCH WITH GOLDEN TOUCH
description: The historic fix-it job in space today would have been impossible without a device that Dr. James D. van Hoften calls his ''million-dollar wrench.''

title: OWENS-ILLINOIS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WOODWARD STORES LTD reports earnings for Year to Jan 28
description: b-After a special gain of $514,254.

title: FOR MOYNIHAN, A SEARCH FOR THE MIDDLE GROUND
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, vice chairman of the Intelligence Committee, said today that he had tried to position himself in the political center on the question of aid to Nicaraguan rebels.

title: FED CALLED ARGENTINE BANKER
description: To clinch the last-minute financial rescue package for Argentina at the end of March, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York assured the 11 American and foreign commercial banks that they would be repaid the $100 million that they were asked to lend the ailing Latin American nation, banking sources said yesterday.

title: No Headline
description: Bridge:Alan Sontag's Team Wins The Von Zedtwitz Crown

title: SPECIAL CARE NEEDED IN ROSEWOOD REPAIRS
description: The Victorians loved rosewood every bit as much as mahogany. It was a particular favorite of the 19th century furniture maker John Belter, who laminated and molded it into his elaborate rococo revival designs. The world supplies are now so limited, however, that what remains is usually used in the form of veneer.

title: TWO ON SHUTTLE REPAIR DEFECTS OF AILING CRAFT
description: Two high- flying handymen of the space shuttle Challenger succeeded today in replacing defective electronics units on the crippled Solar Max satellite for the first extensive repair job in orbit.

title: Merger Policy Is Defended
description: Countering criticism from inside the Reagan Administration, the Federal antitrust chief, J. Paul McGrath, said today that considering world markets while evaluating mergers would produce as many Government challenges to such deals as approvals.

title: POTHOLES IGNITE NEW ROUND IN BELLAMY-KOCH FEUD
description: City Council President Carol Bellamy accused Mayor Koch yesterday of failing to deal with the city's pothole problem, touching off an exchange of increasingly bitter personal insults.

title: G.M.-Toyota Deal Approved WASHINGTON, April 11
description: The General Motors

title: HEALTH COST CURBS: GIVE JERSEY D.R.G.'S TIME...
description: To the Editor:

title: ARMED SERVICES COMMITTEE IN WHITE HOUSE REDUCES WEAPON BUDGET BY NEARLY $9BILLION
description: The House Armed Services Committee voted today to cut the weapon budget for the next fiscal year by nearly $9 billion, providing the first indication of how the Reagan Administration's military buildup will fare in Congress this year.

title: ROBERTSHAW CONTROLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes foreign currency exchange losses of $629,000 for the latest quarter and $945,000 for the year- earlier period. The year-earlier share earnings were restated reflect a 3-for-2 partial stock split to shareholders of record Dec. 13, 1983.

title: ATLANTIC RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Card Dealer
description: When your college football team is the national champion, the misfortunes of life don't seem as painful as usual. So Coach Howard Schnellenberger, whose Miami Hurricanes earned last season's No. 1 ranking from the news-agency polls, was laughing yesterday while talking about the loss of a credit card.

title: THE UPHILL BATTLE FOR EQUITABLE TAXATION
description: Of all the deliberations of government, none are more enduring than taxes. In this legislative season, study commissions in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut are deep in a thicket of abatements, assessments and exemptions.

title: On the Record ; Robert Strauss on U.S. Mood
description: From remarks by Robert S. Strauss, former chairman of the Democratic National Committee, an adviser to Walter F. Mondale, at a conference April 6 at Knokke-Heist, Belgium, on the European community and the United States:

title: Starving Panda Saved By a Chinese Peasant
description: A starving giant panda ''staggered'' into a peasant's house and was rescued from the bamboo famine affecting its mountain habitat, the New China News Agency reported today.

title: SUSPECT IN TEXAS NOW SAYS HE KILLED 360 PEOPLE NATIONWIDE
description: The prosecutors in the murder trial of Henry Lee Lucas played a videotape Tuesday in which he said he had killed 360 people nationwide, using ''most every way but poison'' to commit the crimes.

title: Parole Panel Rejects Move To Let Margiotta Out Early
description: The Federal Parole Commission yesterday reaffirmed its decision to revoke the early parole it originally planned for Joseph M. Margiotta, the former Nassau County Republican leader.

title: INDIANA NATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Warships in Baltic Collide
description: The British frigate Plymouth, taking part in a NATO exercise in the Baltic Sea, was damaged today in a collision with the West German frigate Braunschweig in fog off the Danish island of Bornholm, the West German Naval Command said.

title: I.M.F. Calls Debt Outlook Still Grim
description: Economic prospects for the world's debtor countries, especially those in Latin America, remain grim in the face of a spreading but lopsided world recovery, the International Monetary Fund reported today.

title: COLT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Solidarity Fugitives Call For Rallies Next Month
description: The Solidarity underground called today for anti-Government marches next month, its first such action since the failure of nationwide demonstrations last December.

title: AFGHANS ORDER A U.S. ENVOY OUT MOSCOW, April 11 (Reuters) - A diplomat at the United States Embassy in Kabul, Afghanistan, has been accused of spying and ordered to leave the country within 48 hours, the Soviet news agency Tass reported today.
description: In a short dispatch from Kabul, it said the embassy's third secretary, Richard S. Vandiver, had been declared ''persona non grata for espionage, collecting of information and actions against the Democratic Republic of Afghanistan.''

title: Piper Aircraft to Pay $10 Million in Settlement
description: The Piper Aircraft Corporation has agreed to pay $10 million to the heirs of three people killed when their plane crashed in Ireland, ending a 6-year-old liability lawsuit.

title: AMERICANA HOTELS & REALTY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Minority and Majority
description: Voting Rights The Rev. Jesse Jackson has made creative use of the Voting Rights Act to demonstrate the influence that blacks can achieve with the franchise it guarantees. Now he aims to use that influence to win support for the proposition that the act forbids runoff primary elections between the two leaders in a multi-candidate race. He implies that he will not support or bring out the black vote for a Democratic Presidential candidate who disagrees with his reading of the law.

title: NAGA INSURGENTS SAID TO KILL 300 WHO REFUSED TO GIVE AID
description: Guerrillas fighting for independence from India, in an incident in Burma last month, killed 300 villagers who had refused to give them aid, the Press Trust of India reported today.

title: U.S. AIDE DEFENDS MINING WITHOUT ACKNOWLEDGING IT
description: Kenneth W. Dam, Deputy Secretary of State, suggested today that the United States would be justified in assisting the mining of Nicaraguan harbors as an act of collective self-defense.

title: NEW JERSEY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $713,000.

title: PNC FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Burlington Rail Doubles Profit
description: Burlington Northern, the nation's largest railroad, said yesterday that it earned $160.6 million, or $1.90 a share, in the first quarter, more than double the $70.5 million, or 92 cents a share, it reported a year ago.

title: CELTICS 102, KNICKS 96
description: Kevin McHale did not play until the start of the second period tonight and Larry Bird rested the entire third quarter. But when the Boston Celtics' overpowering forwards played, they were too much for the Knicks to handle, individually and collectively.

title: L.I. JURY BEGINS ITS DELIBERATIONS IN SLAYING OF NEWSPAPER BOY, 14
description: A Nassau County jury began deliberations this afternoon in the trial of 18-year-old Robert Golliver, accused of murdering a 14-year-old Long Island newspaper boy a year ago.

title: A Bad Year if You Fear Friday the 13th
description: Atriskaidekaphobe is one who fears the number 13, and this is not a good year for the triskies, of which I am one. Living through a year with such a reputation as George Orwell has given this one is bad enough, but consider this added fillip - for only the 27th time since the year 1800, we are living in a year with three Friday the 13ths, the maximum possible. One fell in January, one falls in April (note, that's tomorrow) and the third occurs in July.

title: CIPHER DATA PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Caterpillar Narrows Its Loss
description: The Caterpillar Tractor Company reported today that it had narrowed its first-quarter loss to $109 million, from $172 million a year earlier, when the company was struck by the United Automobile Workers. Revenues also improved after the strike, increasing 74.6 percent, to $1.39 billion, from $796 million a year earlier.

title: WALGREEN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
It's a Steal
description: The Cleveland Indians have been a running baseball club in the opening stages of this season. Before playing the White Sox in Chicago in their sixth game of the season last night, the Indians had stolen successfuly 17 times in 21 attempts.

title: P.S.C. TO HELP CONSUMERS FIGHT UTILITY RATE RISES
description: The State Public Service Commission agreed today to help establish independent consumer groups dedicated to opposing increases in utility rates.

title: Pistons 126, 76ers 113
description: Kelly Tripucka scored 37 points, including 29 in the second half, and Isiah Thomas scored 33 to lead Detroit. The victory was the 10th in the last 13 games for Detroit (48-32), which remained tied for the Central Division lead with Milwaukee.

title: METS' STREAK HITS 6
description: The Mets continued their rousing rush into the season tonight when they defeated the Atlanta Braves, 6-1, and extended their winning streak to six games.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THURSDAY, APRIL 12, 1984

title: AGAINST THE LAW
description: More than any other people on earth, Americans believe in the idea of government under law. They really expect the state and its officials to respect the law. It was something our European friends never understood about Watergate: that in the end Americans would not tolerate criminal behavior in the White House.

title: F.C.C. Repeals Regional Rule
description: The Federal Communications Commission repealed a rule today that was intended to prevent broadcasters from building a monopoly in a specific region of the country. The agency, by a 4-to-1 vote, agreed with its staff that the so-called regional concentration rule was arbitrary and unnecessary given other existing ownership restrictions.

description: There was only one thing wrong with Tuesday night's
