title: Swaziland Searches For South Africa Rebels
description: Shooting broke out today in Mbabane, the Swazi capital, as policemen and paramilitary forces searched for members of the African National Congress who escaped from custody Sunday.

title: NEW RULE LETS DOCTOR AVOID TREATING THE VERY ILL ELDERLY
description: New guidelines established by a team of prominent doctors say it is ethical to withhold drugs and sometimes even food and water from mentally deranged elderly patients who are hopelessly ill so long as they are kept comfortable while they die.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: BROTHER ORCHIDS

title: GANNETT CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split on Jan. 5.

title: INDIA CALLED KEY STAGING AREA FOR HEROIN SENT TO U.S.
description: Delhi and Bombay are rapidly becoming the main staging, shipping and trafficking centers for heroin smuggled to the United States and Western Europe from the Khyber Pass area of Pakistan and Afghanistan, authorities here and in Pakistan say.

title: B.B.D.O.'s Resilient President
description: BACK in the late 1930's, when Tom Clark was born, Little Audrey jokes were quite the rage among the unsophisticated.

title: Peabody Ends Its Chesapeake Talks
description: The Peabody International Corporation said it had ended merger talks with the Chesapeake Financial Corporation, a company controlled by Victor Posner, because of an inability to agree on certain terms.

title: Arsenic-Tainted Easter Toys Are Found in New Mexico
description: Some Easter baskets imported to New Mexico from Taiwan could be lethal to children because the stuffed chicks and ducklings in them are preserved with arsenic, Attorney General Paul Bardacke said today.

title: BUTLER MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
G R I CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 25
description: b-Net income.

title: GOVERNORS TRADE JESTS ON REGIONAL QUARRELS
description: The fight over waterfront development between New York City and Jersey City represents healthy competition, not a border war, the Governors of New York and New Jersey said last night.

title: FLEET FINANCIAL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TRANSFER OF 707'S TO IRAN IS DISPUTED
description: The Commerce Department and the Pentagon are in a dispute over licenses to transfer two Boeing 707's to Iran that were impounded in Texas during the 1979 hostage crisis, Administration officials disclosed today.

title: Phils' 4 in 9th Topple Astros
description: Glenn Wilson's single capped a four- run, ninth-inning rally that gave the Philadelphia Phillies a 7-6 victory over the Houston Astros tonight.

title: AIDES LOOK AT HART THE MESSENGER
description: Reflecting on successive defeats in three major industrial states and pondering what to do next, top aides to Senator Gary Hart say they believe the major problem in his bid for the Democratic Presidential nomination is not the Hart message but Hart the messenger.

title: HOUSE PASSES BILL TO RAISE REVENUES AND TRIM DEFICITS
description: Summary of House bill is on page D4.

title: MAJOR ELEMENTS OF HOUSE TAX MEASURE
description: Following is a summary of major elements of the $49.2 billion tax bill passed today by the House, with cumulative revenue estimates for the fiscal years 1984 through 1987:

title: BINKS MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
DRG INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
VIEWER CONTROLS SCREEN
description: ''INNOVATION,'' Channel 13's series on health, technology and science, explores tonight the world of two-way, or interactive, television. For better or worse, the technology allows a television screen to respond to the viewer, rather than the other way around. The half-hour program will be seen at 8 P.M.

title: NUCLEAR PANEL STAFF CALLS LICENSE DENIAL 'ERROR OF JUDGEMENT'
description: The licensing board of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission made a ''clear error of judgment'' in denying an operating permit for the $3.7-billion Byron nuclear power plant, according to a new report by the commission's inspection staff.

title: VMX INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax credits of $493,000 for the quarter and $891,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss

title: FIRST VIRGINIA BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Net income for the latest first quarter included a net interest credit of $535,000 in connection with prior year income tax adjustments.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Dickie Thon, the Houston Astro shortstop who broke a bone above his left eye when he was hit by a pitch by Mike Torrez of the Mets on Sunday, underwent minor surgery to repair the bone damage, but was still suffering from blurred vision. Dr. William Bryan , the team physician, said the operation was unrelated to the vision problem, which remained a matter of concern. . . . Woody Hayes , the 71- year-old former football coach at Ohio State, was in good condition yesterday in University Hospitals in Columbus after being admitted for leg pains.

title: NETS 129, BULLS 112
description: Although the Nets were here tonight playing the hapless Bulls, their thoughts strayed to Boston, where the Knicks were playing the Celtics. Finally, in the middle of the last period of their uneventful 129-112 victory over the Bulls in Chicago Stadium, the Nets heard what they were waiting for - the Knicks had lost to the Celtics, which enabled the Nets to pull within a game of third-place New York in the Atlantic Division.

title: Rose Walks Aisle, Bases
description: For Pete Rose, there were five walks today - four to first base and one down the aisle. The Montreal left fielder got married in his hometown early today, then drew four walks and grounded back to the pitcher in five times up this afternoon as the Expos won, 9-3, from the Cincinnati Reds.

title: HERS
description: LAST year a new Waldbaum's Food Mart opened in the shopping mall on Route 66. It belongs to the new generation of superdupermarkets open 24 hours that have computerized checkout. I went to see the place as soon as it opened and I was impressed. There was trail mix in Lucite bins. There was freshly made pasta. There were coffee beans, 4 kinds of tahini, 10 kinds of herb teas, raw shrimp in shells and cooked shelled shrimp, fresh-squeezed orange juice. Every sophistication known to the big city, even goat's cheese covered with ash, was now available in Middletown, Conn. People raced from the warehouse aisle to the bagel bin to the coffee beans to the fresh fish market, exclaiming at all the new things. Many of us felt elevated, graced, complimented by the presence of this food palace in our town.

title: 2 SHIPPING CONCERNS STOP CALLS IN NICARAGUA
description: Two shipping companies have stopped sailing to Nicaraguan ports as a result of the mining of the three main ports of that Central American nation, according to representatives of the companies.

title: AVANTEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 24
Perez Arrives
description: Pascual Perez, the Braves' right-hander, arrived tonight during the game with the Mets, after his release from prison in the Dominican Republic.

title: Article 116987 -- No Title
description: A $3 million personal injury settlement between the City of South Tucson and Roy Garcia, a former city policeman who was accidentally shot, was approved Monday by a Federal judge, Richard Bilby.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Exploration Co., Houston, an independent oil and gas company, has appointed Charles B. Hauf vice president-exploration.

title: BRIEFS
description: Citicorp's application to acquire all the voting shares outstanding of Citibank-Maine of South Portland, Me., was approved by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

title: U.S. Considers Challenge To Primary Vote Rule
description: The Reagan Administration is considering challenging a requirement in 10 Southern states that primary elections be won by majority vote, the same requirement contested last month by the Rev. Jesse Jackson, the Democratic Presidential candidate.

title: President's Daughter Tells Plans to Marry
description: Patti Davis, the daughter of President and Mrs. Reagan, is planning to marry Paul Grilley, a yoga instructor from Beverly Hills, Calif., the First Lady announced today.

title: Progress Seen On Polish Debt
description: Debt rescheduling talks between Poland and representatives of some 500 Western creditor banks have made ''further progress'' but did not achieve a breakthrough, according to a participant today.

title: Coach's Office Is Rifled EL PASO, April 11 (AP) - The university police at Texas-El Paso
description: are investigating a complaint from an assistant track coach that someone broke into his desk and files as well as those of the secretary in the

title: Businesses in China
description: China has 1.4 million registered businesses, employing more than 103 million people, the Government said today. In addition, the country has 1,140 joint ventures and foreign enterprises, the New China News Agency reported.

title: TORCHMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The first quarter earnings included capital gains of $4 million, or 21 cents a share, for this year against $2.4 million, or 13 cents a share, for year- earlier period.

title: Fedders Quits Journal Case
description: John M. Fedders, enforcement chief at the Securities and Exchange Commission, has removed himself from its investigation into whether a reporter for The Wall Street Journal improperly gave outsiders sensitive information on articles he wrote and whether the outsiders traded securities illegally on the basis of such information.

title: American Slain in Mexico
description: An American employee of the Agriculture Department has been found shot to death in northern Mexico beside his United States Government vehicle, Mexican officials and the United States Embassy said today. William H. Cross, who worked for the Agriculture Department in Starkville, Miss., was found Monday about 60 miles west of Durango on the route to the Pacific resort of Mazatlan. All objects of value except a wedding ring were missing.

title: A VISITOR'S 'FROM SOMALIA WITH LOVE'
description: FREDERIC MITTERAND'S ''From Somalia With Love'' exists as a visitor's meditation on that country, with reflections on the culture, history, climate and population of Somalia delivered by a narrator's lulling monotone. These observations are interspersed with the same man's memories of a love affair, which are linked with his thoughts about Somalia in an insistent but oblique fashion.

title: Son Files for Father's Seat
description: Keary Sawyer, hoping to follow in his father's footsteps, Tuesday announced his candidacy for the Fifth Congressional District seat being vacated by four-term Representative Halold S. Sawyer. At a news conference, the younger Mr. Sawyer, a Republican like his father, said, ''My candidacy is highlighted by a four-letter word - jobs.'' His father, who is 64 years old, announced March 23 that he was stepping down to return to his law practice.

title: Say It Isn't So
description: Pantyhose was just the beginning. Joe Namath , the former Jet who has appeared on television as an unlikely salesman for sheer nylons, went all the way Tuesday night when he appeared on stage at an Atlantic City casino wearing white earrings, a ruffled blue dress, stockings and size-12 pumps.

title: COMPUTER MICROFILM CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
TWO ARGENTINE JUDGES WITHDRAW FROM JUNTA CASE
description: Two federal judges have disqualifed themselves from trying former junta members for the 1976 coup in a case that is raising questions about national complicity with the military.

title: YONKERS FIREFIGHTER UNDERGOES A HEART TRANSPLANT
description: A 42-year-old Yonkers firefighter who had been given only a few months to live underwent heart transplant surgery yesterday, and surgeons said he was ''hanging in there beautifully.''

title: Dutch Firebomb Kills 3
description: A man with a grudge threw a firebomb into a cafe today, starting a blaze that killed three people and seriously injured another, the police said. They arrested a 33-year-old man who said he had acted out of revenge because he said he had been roughed up by patrons the night before.

title: DR. EGON NEUSTADT, A MAJOR COLLECTOR OF TIFFANY LAMPS
description: Dr. Egon Neustadt, an orthodontist who owned one of the largest private collections of Tiffany lamps in the world, was found dead yesterday in his Manhattan apartment. He was 86 years old. While the cause of death was not immediately known, the police said Dr. Neustadt had died of natural causes.

title: CELANESE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
LITTLE, ARTHUR D, INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DEMOCRATIC CONTENDERS TURNING TO SECOND HALF
description: After a Pennsylvania primary that propelled Walter F. Mondale into a strong lead in convention delegates, the Democratic Presidential candidates turned today to analyzing the tasks facing them in the second half of the nomination campaign.

title: Adviser Says Private Polling Has Reagan in Lead for Fall
description: President Reagan's top political adviser said Tuesday that his latest private polls put Mr. Reagan well ahead in the Presidential race against either Walter F. Mondale or Senator Gary Hart, the two leading Democratic contenders.

title: PRIMARY PROCESS: PROS AND CONS ON OLD AND NEW
description: Political scientists and political buffs can agree that 1984 is producing a most interesting chapter in the workings of political primaries. But they have more trouble agreeing on how well the system works.

title: AMERITRUST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including securities transactions.

title: HOUSE GROUP JOINS IN OPPOSING MINING NICARAGUAN PORTS
description: The House Foreign Affairs Committee today approved a resolution opposing the use of Government funds for the mining of Nicaraguan harbor.

title: RECITAL: ABRAMS
description: DANIEL ABRAMS'S piano recital at Alice Tully Hall Sunday night seemed as concerned with the spaces between the music as the music itself. His uninterrupted program of Beethoven, Brahms and two Bachs (J. S. and J. C.) operated on the principle that applause too often hinders communication between player and listener but that silence can form a bond between them.

title: OWENS-CORNING FIBERGLAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $2.3 million from an exchange of stock for long-term debt.

title: THOUSAND TRAILS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DAEWOOD CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Couples Gets Into the Money
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.

title: Sockers Sweep Cosmos for Title
description: The San Diego Sockers demonstrated their superiority in indoor soccer again tonight, capturing their third consecutive indoor championship by sweeping their three-of-five-game series against the Cosmos.

title: JURY IN TRIAL OF FEDERAL JUDGE IS TOLD TO TRY AGAIN
description: The jury in the trial of Federal District Judge Harry E. Claiborne was rebuffed and ordered back to work today when it attempted to return a blank jury form signifying it had failed to agree on a verdict.

title: A MINI-MUSEUM AT THE WORLD BANK
description: When Eugene H. Rothberg arrives for work at the World Bank each morning he steps into a handsome mini-museum of his own making.

title: Florida Gets Stiff Rules To Protect Fresh Water
description: Florida adopted what officials called the strictest rules in the country to protect its fresh water, ordering that every community water supply be screened for 127 additional toxins.

title: DEFUSE WORLD DEBT
description: The international debt crisis remains a major obstacle to world economic recovery. Recent emergency actions to tide over Brazil and Argentina were a step in the right direction but will need to be repeated again and again unless bolder action is taken to provide more equitable burden-sharing for lenders and borrowers alike.

title: Disney Holdings
description: Roy Disney said Shamrock Holdings Inc., a company he controls, had bought an additional 500,000 common shares of Walt Disney Productions. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, he said the purchases, made in mid-March on the open market, give him a total of 1,428,061 Disney shares, or about 4.1 percent of the total outstanding.

title: TRADING IS SLOW
description: Stock prices fell moderately yesterday in continued slow trading.

title: MINING TO CONTINUE, REBEL CHIEF SAYS
description: The largest anti-Sandinista insurgent group met in Honduras on Tuesday and decided to continue mining Nicaraguan ports, according to one of the group's top officials. He denied that Americans were involved in the mining.

title: ROADWAY SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 24
description: The latest quarter figures include revenue of $3,938,000 and net income of $174,000 in Spartan Express Inc., which the company acquired on Feb. 10.

title: CITIZENS GROWTH PROPERTIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $217,000 for the quarter and $416,000 for the year and gains from the sale of real estate of $179,000 for the quarter and $264,000 for the year. c-Including tax credits of $61,000 for the quarter and $256,000 for the year and gains from the sale of real estate of $35,000 for the quarter and $108,000 for the year.

title: THE DEMOCRATS: A DELEGATE UPDATE
description: 124 of 172 delegates chosen in the

title: WEST CHEMICAL PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $167,000 and a tax credit of $225,000. c-Net loss including income of $163,000 from discontinued operations and a loss of $37,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: U.S.F.L. Players Approve a Union
description: The players of the United States Football League have voted by a decisive margin to have their own union.

title: Manila Debt Is Extended
description: Creditor banks of the Philippines have approved a second extension of a 90-day moratorium on repayment of foreign debts, the central bank said today.

title: BURLINGTON NORTHERN INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HOLLYWOOD OPENS DRIVE ON ALCOHOL AND DRUGS
description: Two recovered alcoholics - Betty Ford, the wife of former President Gerald R. Ford, and the actor Ralph Waite - were principal speakers at a conference on alcoholism and drug abuse held this morning at the Burbank Studios.

title: Teen-Age Suicides Stir Texas Prevention Drive
description: Parents and counselors, concerned that three teen-age suicides this week in the Dallas-Fort Worth area may provoke other deaths, today began a suicide prevention program at schools.

title: MONCHIK-WEBER CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Net income.

title: Karl Spooner, 52; Pitcher for Dodgers Had a Brief Career
description: Karl Spooner, whose sore left arm cut short what had promised to be a brilliant pitching career with the Brooklyn Dodgers, died Tuesday after a long illness. He was 52 years old.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
PROTECTING A HOME
description: SOME home security systems that have been introduced recently are designed to be installed by a homeowner. The Anova Master System combines telephone, light and appliance control and alarms in three units that operate on house current and can be used independently or together.

title: MUSLIM ACCUSES PRESS OF TWISTING HIS COMMENTS
description: Louis Farrakhan, leader of the Nation of Islam, the Black Muslim sect, today repeated his charge that Milton Coleman, a black reporter, was a traitor for reporting comments made by the Rev. Jesse Jackson about Jews. But he said accusations that he had threatened the reporter's life were false.

title: Article 117999 -- No Title
description: A limousine driver who charged a Japanese businessman $300 for a trip between Kennedy International Airport and a Manhattan hotel was sentenced yesterday to two to six years in prison.

title: QUINONES SEEKS TO START TEST OF 4-DAY INSTRUCTIONAL WEEK
description: Nathan Quinones, the Acting Schools Chancellor, said yesterday that he would like a four-day instructional week to begin soon in at least two high schools. The fifth school day would be reserved for non-classroom activities.

title: Trial Set on Hughes Estate
description: Lawyers for California and Texas tentatively agreed Tuesday to make Colorado the site of a legal battle to determine which state will gain the right to tax the estate of Howard R. Hughes, who controlled a financial empire when he died in 1976. The tentative agreement setting the trial in the Denver area or in Boulder on July 18 was announced by the Supreme Court special master in the case, Wade McCree, a retired Federal judge and Michigan law professor who will preside. A Colorado site was preferred because of its central location to witnesses expected to testify.

title: CANADIAN MANOIR INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a provision of $490,000 for losses from Electronic Interconnect Systems Inc. which is about to be sold. c-Net loss including a special gain of $188,150.

title: NEW HOUSEWARES: WHITE, BRIGHT, BOLD
description: ''STACKS and stacks is what I like - and not dinnerware in sets, because I feel it's important to be able to buy things individually,'' said Ristomatti Ratia, left, the chief designer and chairman of Marimekko, the Finnish company whose name is synonymous with bright modern objects.

title: MUSIC: CATHERINE MALFITANO
description: The Chamber Music society of Lincoln Center's concerts tend to be amiable grab bags of dissimilar material, and Sunday afternoon's program in Alice Tully Hall, featuring works by Bach, Mozart, Schubert, Wagner and Varese, was no exception.

title: CAMILLE CLAUDEL'S ROLE
description: AN exhibition that we simply have to see in New York is the retrospective of sculptures and drawings by Camille Claudel (1864-1943) that is on view through June 11 at the Musee Rodin in Paris.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: NOP'S TRIALS. By Donald McCaig. 328 pages. Crown. $14.95. ONLY. By Winston Groom. 190 pages. Putnam. $12.95.

title: SON OF CUOMO WILL JOIN STAFF OF PROSECUTOR
description: Andrew Cuomo, a major figure in his father's administration, announced today that he was leaving state government to become an assistant district attorney in Manhattan.

title: BARNETT BANKS OF FLORIDA INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Republicans Abroad Given Vote Deadline
description: Lois Burke Shepard, chairman of Republicans Abroad International, has announced that ballots for the primary among Republicans living overseas must be returned to the party's country chairmen by May 12 or the regional chairmen by May 13. The ballots will be counted on May 26.

title: FURNITURE (AND MORE) FROM PORTUGAL
description: WHAT had started out as a most formal evening became much more informal and festive when Marvin S. Traub, the chairman of Bloomingdale's and his wife, Lee, broke away from the receiving line and made their way down the department store's wide center aisle on the main floor. They were accompanied by Raquel de Bettencourt Ferreira, the Portuguese Secretary of State for Commerce, the guest of honor last night at a party for the store's promotion, ''The Discoveries of Portugal.''

title: Alfa Romeo Price Rise
description: Alfa Romeo, the No. 2 Italian auto maker, said today that it planned to raise prices of its models by an average of 2.5 percent beginning April 24. The increases apply to the domestic market.

title: FEDERAL PAPER BOARD CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BALKY BLACK BOX KEY TO OPERATION
description: The balky, 550-pound black box that the Challenger astronauts replaced on the satellite Solar Max today does a crucial job. It adjusts the position of the $235 million observatory so it can point its telescopes and scientific instruments with incredible precision as it speeds through space at more than 17,000 miles an hour.

title: COAST BANK ELECTS CHIEF
description: Beverly Hills Savings and Loan Association announced a number of changes today in its board of directors, including the election, as expected, of Paul Amir, a major shareholder, as vice chairman and chief executive.

title: Strictly Nonpolitical
description: It was a message to promote fair

title: RIGGS NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
COMBAT ROLE LAID TO U.S. ADVISERS
description: A United States military official said today that American advisers based in El Salvador had accompanied Salvadoran pilots on training missions in which they had occasionally engaged in combat and targeted or bombed guerrilla positions.

title: CHERNENKO ADDS PRESIDENT'S POST TO HIS LEADERSHIP OF SOVIET PARTY
description: Konstantin U. Chernenko completed his consolidation of top offices today when he became President of the Soviet Union.

title: Charles H. Morgan, 81, Dies; Amherst Fine Arts Professor
description: Charles H. Morgan, emeritus professor of fine arts at Amherst, who established the Mead Art Museum at the college, died April 4 of a heart attack.

title: CENTERRE BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Tabloid Is Planned For Conventioneers
description: Frequently at annual meetings of various industries a trade publication that covers the industry will put out a daily paper for the conventioneers. Not surprising then that The National Journal, which certainly can be considered a trade publication for people in government and politics as well as the press that covers them, is planning a similar caper for both the Democratic and Republican National Conventions.

title: THURSDAY, APRIL 12, 1984 International
description: The Foreign Affairs Committee of the House approved a resolution opposing the use of Government funds for the mining of Nicaraguan harbors. The resolution, approved by a vote of 32 to 3 with 2 abstentions, was identical to one passed by the Senate on Tuesday. At the same time, Administration officials, suddenly faced with a revolt even by Republicans toward their Central American policy, said that the latest phase of the mining of Nicaraguan harbors had ceased last weekend. (Page A1, Column 6.) U.S. advisers flew with Salvadoran pilots on training missions in which they occasionally engaged in combat and targeted or bombed guerrilla positions, a United States military official said. The statement, if correct, reflects a dramatic increase in the American military's role in El Salvador's four-year-old civil war. A spokesman for the United States Embassy said the embassy knew of no pilots engaged in such activity calling it ''contrary to orders.'' (A1:5.)

title: SERVICE ACADEMIES SEE RISE IN QUALITY OF APPLICANTS
description: Officials of the three military academies say they are seeing a dramatic improvement in the quality of their applicants, thanks in part to a resurgence of patriotism. The result, according to admissions officers, will be entering classes that the officials believe will have the most qualified students ever.

title: 'NEW' PALESTINIANS NEEDED TO MAKE PEACEIN THE MIDDLE EAST
description: To the Editor:

title: GALLERY TO FEATURE 4 PUEBLO POTTERS
description: ONCE, early in her career, Nancy Youngblood Cutler worked for hours on a piece of pottery - first kneading the clay, then shaping it into a pot, scraping it, carving it, burnishing it - only to watch it crack to pieces when she put it in the fire to harden.

title: SQUARE D CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
IRAN-IRAQ DEBATE: A CLASH OF STYLE AND SUBSTANCE
description: In an unusual confrontation between diplomats of nations at war, the Iraqi and Iranian delegates to the United Nations defended their Governments this week against charges of misconduct in the Persian Gulf war.

title: Mass Is Said for 2 Fishermen Lost Off Long Island in Storm
description: A memorial mass was offered today for two fishermen believed killed at sea in the storm that pounded the East Coast on March 29.

title: MORGAN, J P, & CO INCORPORATED reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DOWNTOWN LOS ANGELES: THE NEW SETTLERS
description: THERE are few balconied apartment buildings overlooking swimming pools, no pink bungalows on streets lined with palms, no shopping malls. But downtown Los Angeles, bounded generally by the Santa Monica, Harbor and Santa Ana Freeways, is becoming a vital and diverse residential neighborhood, much as New York's SoHo has in the last 15 years.

title: Gannett Profits Up 8%
description: The Gannett Company said today that its first-quarter profits rose 8 percent, to $34.8 million, or 44 cents a share, from $32.2 million, or 40 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: Mobile-Phone Lotteries Set
description: The Federal Communications Commission, changing its rules, voted today to begin using lotteries to award licenses for advanced mobile phone systems across the country.

title: Colt's Net Soars 99.4%
description: Colt Industries, a diversified industrial products concern, reported yesterday that strong earnings by its automotive operations helped net income in the first quarter soar 99.4 percent, to $32.5 million, or $1.35 a share, from $16.3 million, or 66 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales rose 26.9 percent, to $463.4 million, from $365.1 million.

title: ; HEALTH COST CURBS: GIVE JERSEY D.R.G.'S TIME...
description: To the Editor:

title: KINARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GOULD JEWELRY SETS AUCTION RECORD
description: The jewelry of Florence J. Gould, a patron of the arts and daughter-in- law of the railroad magnate Jay Gould, sold yesterday for $8 million, the highest price ever reached at auction for a single collection of jewelry. The sale was the second session of an all-day sale at Christie's that totaled $17 million, a record for a jewelry auction in the United States.

title: School Chief Says She Paid Workers
description: Dr. Joan M. Raymond, the Superintendent of Schools here, said today that she had used carpenters and other Board of Education employees to perform occasional work at her residences but had always paid them with her own funds.

title: Matzoh From the Beginning
description: Of all the special Passover foods required for the seder, when families gather to celebrate the exodus of the Jews from their Egyptian bondage, none is more important than matzoh. The thin, crisp crackerlike sheets symbolize the unleavened bread eaten on the journey, the bread of affliction.

title: 8 Jersey Counties To Get Flood Aid
description: Federal officials announced today that eight New Jersey counties had been declared eligible for $9.8 million in Federal disaster aid to help repair damage caused by last week's floods and a severe coastal storm two weeks ago.

title: QUAREX INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
KRUEGER, W A, CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DEBATE RISES ON WOODSHED BULLDOZED UNDER FOR ART'S SAKE
description: Some people were skeptical in 1970 when the artist Robert Smithson came to Kent State University, used a bulldozer to pile mud over an old woodshed and called it a $10,000 work of art.

title: REAGAN IS PRODDED FOR DEFICIT ACTION
description: President Reagan was warned by home builders and bankers today that ''time is running out'' for dealing with the high Federal deficit and preventing a downturn of the business recovery.

title: SHOOLS FIND LITTLE PROGRESS ON DROPOUTS
description: City school officials have made no significant progress in preventing students from dropping out of school, according to a Board of Education draft report for the last school year.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
description: MUSIC IN EVERY ROOM: Around the

title: GOLDEN WEST FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
IN THE FEUD WITH CONGRESS, NO QUARTER IS GIVEN
description: The relationship between Congress and the Central Intelligence Agency, never one of the warmer partnerships in Washington, has suddenly deteriorated into a bitter feud over the issue of whether lawmakers were adequately informed about the mining of Nicaraguan harbors.

title: INTERNATIONAL MINERALS & CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $8,900,000, or 33 cents a share, from the sale of phosphate reserves.

title: GRAND-SCALE MALCOLM MORLEY
description: THERE can be little doubt now about Malcolm Morley's importance. As much as any painter of his generation, he has been following the path of the most resistance. During the last few years, his canvases have been rings in which he, Abstract Expressionism, Pop Art, Conceptual Art and assorted modernist heavyweights have been hammering away at one another. Morley has helped preserve the urgency of one of

title: MUSIC: IVO POGORELICH, PIANIST, AT CARNEGIE HALL
description: DONAL HENAHAN

title: VERBATIM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
THE EVENING HOURS
description: ''THE kids certainly are out in full force tonight!'' a delighted Jennifer Edelman exclaimed. Among the ''kids'' were Brooke Astor, Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney, Lily Auchincloss, Mary Lasker and Blanchette Rockefeller, more cream- of-society than milk-and-cookies, you might say, but young in heart all the same. The event that brought them, along with 600 other guests, plus assorted strolling violinists, flamenco guitarists and an explosion of flowers, to Tavern on the Green Tuesday night was the Parks Council's black-tie benefit dinner honoring Arthur Ross. The council, founded in 1926, is a citywide organization concerned with parks, recreation and environmental education. Mr. Ross's most recent gifts to the city are 1,000 Himalayan pines and 1,000 elms.

title: LaRouche Qualifies For Matching Funds
description: The Federal Election Commission ruled today that Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. had qualified for Federal matching funds after paying almost $70,000 in fines and repayment of Federal funds from his 1980 campaign.

title: BANK OF NEW ENGLAND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SHARON IS BEATEN BY SHAMIR IN VOTE
description: Yitzhak Shamir was nominated by the Likud bloc today to run for a second term as Prime Minister in elections July 23. He defeated former Defense Minister Ariel Sharon, 407 to 306.

title: UNITED VIRGINIA BANKSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HOUSE VOTE OPPOSES MINING OF NICARAGUAN PORTS
description: The House tonight followed the lead of the Senate and voted 281 to 111 to approve a nonbinding resolution opposing the use of Federal funds for the mining of Nicaraguan harbors. In the Senate, the resolution was approved 84-12 with the support of Republican as well as Democratic leaders. But House Republican leaders denounced the measure as a politically inspired attack on President Reagan. Supporters called the mining an illegal act of war and charged that the President had abused his authority. They warned that such measures would prove counterproductive.

title: SENATE LIQUOR TAX RISE KEPT
description: The Senate today overwhelmingly rejected an effort to kill a proposed $2- a-gallon increase in the liquor tax, a central provision of its pending tax bill. Then it defeated a second plan, pushed by the liquor industry, that would cut the increase to $1 and raise the tax on wine 20 cents a gallon.

title: Russians Routed
description: Czechoslovakia routed the Soviet Union today, 7-2, dealing the Russians' A team its first loss in international hockey play in two and a half years.

title: CATERPILLAR TRACTOR CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bomb Kills 2 In New Belfast Terror
description: A bomb killed a 52-year-old woman and a policeman at the woman's home today in the second terrorist attack in Belfast in five days.

title: German Printers Strike
description: West Germany's main union of printers staged 24-hour strikes at 30 major newspaper and magazine plants today to press demands for a 35-hour working week with no pay cuts. A spokesman for the union, I.G. Druck und Papier, said printers had stopped production of at least nine major daily newspapers, including the European edition of The Financial Times of London and Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung.

title: 2D DEMOCRAT SEEKS GREEN'S SEAT
description: Robert Tembeckjian, a 33-year-old lawyer and political novice, announced yesterday that he would seek the Democratic nomination for the House of Representatives from the 15th Congressional District on Manhattan's East Side.

title: Ford Dividend Up
description: The Ford Motor Company raised its dividend on common stock by 10 cents, to 40 cents a share, for the second quarter.

title: Boxing Precaution
description: A California legislative committee has endorsed a bill that would require boxers to undergo neurological examinations at least once a year and force the state's promoters to bear the costs of the program. Under the measure, introduced by Assemblyman Art Agnos , a Democrat from San Francisco, a boxer who suffers a knockout or is stopped twice in a row or who fights 12 times within a year would have to undergo a further examination before fighting again.

title: VITAMIN SUPPLEMENT LINKED TO 12 DEATHS OF PREMATURE BABIES
description: At least 12 premature babies have died after being given a new intravenous Vitamin E supplement, and the product is being recalled, Federal health officials said today.

title: CHATTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
RULE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
THE REGION ;  QE2 Fined $2,500 On Food Violation
description: The British owners of the Queen Elizabeth 2 have agreed to pay a $2,500 fine after inspectors found nonkosher food in the liner's kosher kitchen, according to state officials.

title: ISLANDERS, LEADING BY 2-0, FALL TO CAPITALS IN OPENER
description: Craig Laughlin, laughing, called it a ''chip shot with a 9-iron.'' By any name, it won a hockey game tonight for the Washington Capitals against the four-time Stanley Cup champion Islanders.

title: SAVINGS BANK OF PUGET SOUND reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
JOHN CLEESE IN FARCE, 'PRIVATES ON PARADE'
description: BEHIND the opening credits of ''Privates on Parade,'' a cartoon sun sinks slowly behind a cartoon palm tree, setting, in effect, on the entire British Empire. The simple, comic image is a fitting way to begin this fine, witty, extremely self-assured English film, which opens today at the Cinema 2.

title: TRANZONIC COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $8,360,569 for the quarter and $8,126,091 for the year.

'A Shtetl Passover,' A Lost Home Remembered
description: The festival of Passover, which begins with the seder Monday night, has always been a time for Jews to come home. But there is a Jewish home that no longer exists - the shtetl, the Jewish village of Eastern Europe.

description: ELEANOR BLAU

title: CURRENCY MARKETS ; Dollar in Broad Rise; Gold Declines by $2.75
description: The dollar rose yesterday against most other foreign currencies despite sharp declines in the nation's money supply and in retail sales figures, news that usually pushes the dollar lower. Gold prices declined.

title: No Headline
description: V.D. Tests for Parents Seen as Saving Infants

TRW GAINS
description: The Lockheed Corporation reported yesterday that its first-quarter earnings rose 31.2 percent from the year before. Analysts attributed the aerospace company's higher profits to better operating margins and higher revenues.

title: SHOE-TOWN CHANGING TOP-LEVEL EXECUTIVES
description: Shoe-Town Inc., which operates 191 off-price shoe stores in 11 states, has named George M. Kaye, currently president and chief operating officer, to be chairman and chief executive officer.

title: BANKER'S NOTE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
Turk in Papal Case Gives Up in Italy
description: A Turk implicated in the attack on Pope John Paul II in 1981 surrendered to the Italian authorities today after being extradited from West Germany.

title: Bridge:;  A Lot of Points May HideProblems in 3 NO-TRUMP
description: If you find yourself in three no- trump with 28 high-card points in the combined hands and every suit well protected, there is a temptation to think that nine tricks will be easy to find. But trouble may be lurking around the corner.

title: Market Place; Profit Outlook For Marsh
description: RECOMMENDING stocks and predicting corporate earnings can bump head on into surprise news developments. This was underscored Monday when the Marsh & McLennan Companies announced an extraordinary after-tax charge of about $60 million for the first quarter of 1984.

title: CONFESSED KILLER CONVICTED IN TEXAS SLAYING
description: Henry Lee Lucas, who has figured in a widespread investigation of hundreds of slayings throughout the country, was convicted today of capital murder in the slaying of a woman whose body was found in a highway culvert in Williamson County, Tex., in 1979.

title: Father of Justice O'Connor
description: Harry Alfred Day, the father of Justice Sanda Day O'Connor of the Supreme Court, died Monday at the family ranch east of here, the family announced today. Mr. Day, 85 years old, was a life- long rancher. In addition to Justice O'Conner, survivors include his wife, Ada Mae; another daughter, Ann Alexander; a son, Alan Day; a brother and eight grandchildren.

title: BALLET: WINNEPEG 'GISELLE'
description: ANNA KISSELGOFF

title: PROSECUTOR TELLS HOW BANKERS DIED
description: A teen- age farm boy accused of shooting to death two prominent local bankers was portrayed today as an expert marksman and fascinated by things military, one who had long planned the ambush on Sept. 29 of the bankers who had foreclosed on his father's farm.

title: A HELPFUL USHER SINGS A LULLABY OF OLD BROADWAY
description: It has been Thelma Moore's good fortune to find ''nice people'' at all of the way stations of her life.

title: CITYTRUST BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Dr. Robert Stewart Jason, Ex-Dean of Medical School
description: Dr. Robert Stewart Jason, dean emeritus of the Howard University College of Medicine in Washington, died last Friday at his home in Manhattan after a long illness. He was 82 years old.

title: G.I. Is Jailed for Trip to East
description: A United States Army sergeant convicted of trying to desert to East Germany has been dishonorably discharged and sentenced to four years in prison, a V Corps spokesman said today. A military court found that the sergeant - Randy J. Tuegel, 26 years old, of Dubuque, Iowa - crossed into East Germany Nov. 21, according to the spokesman. East Germany returned him Dec. 28, the spokesman said.

title: Doctors Striking in Greece
description: More than 5,000 Government-employed doctors throughout the country began a two- day strike today to protest what they said were unsatisfactory wages and benefits.

title: STRYKER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
F.H.L.M.C. Offers Mortgage Bonds
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation is offering $724 million of collateralized mortgage obligations through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: BAYBANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CUSTOMER SLAIN BY TWO OFFICERS AT ROBBERY SITEE
description: Two police officers responding to a report of a robbery at a Bronx grocery store late Wednesday night shot and killed a customer who came out of the store with a gun in his hand, the police said.

title: BRIEFS
description: * A. H. Belo Corp., a Dallas newspaper and broadcasting company, said it had agreed to sell its cable television systems, Queen City Telecommunications Inc., in Clarksville, Tenn., to an individual investor for $13.3 million.

description: LESLIE BENNETTS

title: CAMPAIGN NOTES

title: MUSIC FILLS THE CITY
description: AS the most dramatic period of the Christian church year, the eight days from Palm Sunday through Easter, commemorate an astonishing sequence of events. The quick succession of moods - the hopefulness of Palm Sunday, the tragedy and despair of the Crucifixion on Good Friday and the triumph and wonder of the Resurrection on Easter - these have been reflected in some of the most inspired music in history. It is music that can be found this weekend and all next week in New York churches and concert halls.

title: MONDALE ATTACKS REAGAN'S POLICIES
description: Walter F. Mondale today accused President Reagan of pursuing ''misguided'' and ''blundering'' policies in Central America that could lead the United States into war.

title: GOLDIE HAWN IN COMEDY, 'SWING SHIFT'
description: ''SWING SHIFT,'' directed by Jonathan Demme and written by Rob Morton, a pseudonym is a sweet romantic comedy about America's World War II ''soldiers without guns,'' the women who gave up their household duties to fill the sudden demand for workers in industries once staffed exclusively by men. At the war's end, most of the women went back to their pots and pans, but the first shots had been fired in the mid 20th century war for women's liberation.

title: Diner's Journal
description: GRILLING meats and other foods over a hot stone slab is a technique that goes back thousands of years, and some modern chefs maintain that it has advantages over cooking with metal pans or barbecue grills. Carlo de Gaudenzi, chef and co-owner of La Camelia restaurant, at 225 East 58th Street, between Second and Third Avenues, recently revived stone cooking, which is performed with flair at tableside.

title: Housebreaker to Be Caned
description: A man whose hand was cut off while breaking into a house was sentenced today to two years in prison and one stroke of a cane. The man - Andrew Nduini Kamere, 35 years old - had pleaded guilty to a charge of housebreaking. Claude Robertson-Dunn, a British resident of Nairobi, had struck out with a sword when Mr. Kamere broke into his home.

title: Mondale Will Not Enter North Dakota Primary
description: The North Dakota Democratic Presidential primary ballot will not include the name of Walter F. Mondale.

title: DISKS SELL LIKE HOT CAKES
description: The Jewish Compu-Chef floppy

description: As the one-man rule of 83-year-old President Habib Bourguiba nears its inevitable end, Tunisia's critical problem is not so much the growing gap between rich and poor as the growing gap between the generations.

description: Jesse Jackson disputed a Black Muslim leader's description of Hitler as ''a great German'' but refused to sever political ties. Page 10.

title: MURDER CHARGED IN DRIFTER DEATH
description: A grand jury returned six murder indictments today in connection with the death of a drifter who witnesses said was tortured while he was held captive on a ranch, a prosecutor said.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: ADT, a manufacturer of electronic life and property protection systems, has appointed Glen Dallas vice president-operations.

title: Debate Rises on Woodshed Bulldozed Under for Art's Sake
description: Some people were skeptical in 1970 when the artist Robert Smithson came to Kent State University, used a bulldozer to pile mud over an old woodshed and called it a $10,000 work of art.

description: The New York State Insurance Department has begun questioning the Marsh & McLennan Companies to evaluate the unauthorized bond trading the company said had taken place.

title: Kidnapped Horse Found Unharmed
description: Hadol du Vivier, an 11-year-old sire who was considered Europe's top trotter during his racing career, was recovered unharmed tonight after his kidnappers had demanded a $250 million ransom.

title: MAN HELD ON WAR CRIME CHARGES
description: A 61-year-old Ukrainian sought by Federal agents after being charged with war crimes in the Nazi-occupied Soviet Union has been arrested at his sister's home here, Justice Department officials said.

description: The Consumers Power Company may file for reorganization if it cannot obtain financing to continue construction of its Midland nuclear power plant, the utility's top officer says.

THE SENATE WAKES UP
description: Two cheers for the Senate and that 84-12 vote by which it denounced President Reagan's policy of mining the harbors of Nicaragua. He's been demanding bipartisanship and, as Senator Robert Byrd noted, he certainly got it, with 42 Republicans joining all but one Democrat in a well-deserved rebuke.

New Defense Plea In Lennon Slaying
description: Lawyers for Mark David Chapman, the confessed killer of John Lennon, told an appellate court yesterday that their client was mentally incompetent when he pleaded guilty and that his sentence should be vacated.

description: The Docutel/Olivetti Corporation last night announced a major management shake-up, including the resignation of its president, and a large fourth-quarter loss.

title: HART, IN TRUMAN COUNTRY, MOUNTS TWO-FISTED ATTACK
description: Senator Gary Hart traveled to Harry S. Truman's hometown of quiet streets and Victorian homes today to cast himself as a battling man of the Plains and to reinvigorate his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: LOCKHEED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Canadian Official Wins Steelworker Election
description: Lynn R. Williams has defeated Frank McKee and becomes the first Canadian to be elected president of the million- member United Steelworkers of America, the union announced today.

title: REINSURER IN SEATTLE PICKS NEXT CHIEF
description: James J. Meenaghan, former president and chief operating officer of the Fireman's Fund Insurance Companies, will join the John F. Sullivan Company, a large reinsurance broker, as president May 15.

title: SOVIET APPROVES SWEEPING OVERHAUL OF THE SCHOOLS
description: The Soviet Union's nominal legislature ended a two-day session today by endorsing a sweeping reorganization of the nation's entire school system to give it a stronger focus on labor and ideology.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in the Business People column on Wednesday about the president of Bloomingdale's, James M. Guinan, incorrectly reported the line of management authority. Both Mr. Guinan and Marvin S. Traub, chairman and chief executive of Bloomingdale's, will report to Howard Goldfeder, chairman and chief executive of the parent company, Federated Department Stores Inc.

title: Manatt Asserts PartyWon't Pick Dark HorseWASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) - Charles T. Manatt, the Democratic Party chairman, said today that he saw no chance the party's Presidential candidate would be anyone other than the three candidates now actively campaigning.
description: ''Zero,'' Mr. Manatt said in an interview when asked the question. ''No chance.''

title: New Pact for Denny
description: Last year's National League Cy Young Award winner, John Denny , has signed a new three-year contract with the Philadelphia Phillies, meaning he will not opt for free agency at the end of this season. The 31-year-old right-hander, a 19-game winner last year, received a contract that contains guaranteed years for 1985 and 1986 and an option year in 1987. Other terms were not disclosed.

title: WHY WOULD THE RUSSIANS INVADE WESTERN EUROPE?
description: To the Editor:

title: FIRST RESULT OF 2 BELL SPINOFFS
description: The Southwestern Bell Corporation and the American Information Technologies Corporation, two of the seven companies spun off from the American Telephone and Telegraph Corporation on Jan. 1, yesterday reported their first earnings results.

description: FRIDAY, APRIL 13, 1984

title: WARNER UNIT-POLYGRAM MERGER HELD UP
description: The proposed merger of the record unit of Warner Communications Inc. and Polygram Records was dealt a setback yesterday when a Federal appellate court granted a temporary injunction against the merger, pending appeal next month.

title: CNA INCOME SHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CARTER'S $900 MILLION CREDIT
description: Carter Hawley Hale Stores said yesterday that it had raised $900 million in lines of credit with a group of banks led by the Bank of America for ''general corporate purposes.'' The announcement in Los Angeles fueled speculation that the company was preparing a countermeasure to the takeover bid from The Limited Inc.

title: Henderson in Plea
description: A former Dallas Cowboy linebacker, Thomas (Hollywood) Henderson , has pleaded no contest to charges of attempting to bribe the two teen-aged girls who are scheduled to testify against him April 25 on charges that Henderson forced them to commit sexual acts last year. Sentencing on the bribery charge was set for June 11. It carries a possible term of five years and eight months in prison.

title: ROLL CALL IN HOUSE ON MINING
description: Following are the positions of representatives from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut when the House approved a nonbinding resolution opposing the use of Federal funds for the mining of Nicaraguan harbors. A ''yes'' vote was a vote in favor of the resolution.

title: Quaker Chemicals
description: The Quaker Oats Company said it had sold its chemicals division to the Pentech Corporation for $45.3 million.

title: DIPLOMAT CHARGED IN DRUG SMUGGLING
description: A diplomat and three other people arriving at Kennedy International Airport from India have been arrested and accused of carrying 88 pounds of heroin in their suitcases, Federal authorities announced yesterday.

title: State Dept. Fights Bill Favoring Salvadorans
description: A State Department official said today that Salvadorans illegally in the United States should not be given special status to stay here because of what might happen to them if they were deported.

title: The Macintosh In Japan Debut
description: The Canon Sales Company introduced Apple Computer's Macintosh at its computer fair in Tokyo today.

title: The Four-Day High School
description: New York City's Acting Schools Chancellor, Nathan Quinones, proposes that high school students attend longer classes but for only four days a week. He would devote the fifth day to counseling, assemblies, clubs and field trips.

title: Reliance Increases Its Stake in Disney
description: The Reliance Financial Services Corporation, a unit of Reliance Group Inc., said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had increased its stake in Walt Disney Productions to 3,198,233 common shares, or 9.3 percent of the shares outstanding. This was the second filing by Reliance this week disclosing its purchase of shares of the Burbank, Calif., entertainment company.

title: Columbia Names Szoke
description: Wayne Szoke , an assistant basketball coach at Princeton when the Tigers won the Ivy League championship the last two years, was named yesterday as the head coach at Columbia, which has not won a title since 1968. Szoke (pronounced zoke) replaces Buddy Mahar , who was dismissed last month after leading Columbia to just two winning records in six seasons.

title: SPRING, SENIOR YEAR AND ROMANCE IN THE AIR
description: Tricia Juhn's last date before Eric Gordon sounded great on paper. ''He was this older guy, a junior at N.Y.U.,'' said Tricia, a high school senior. ''Culture coming out of his ears, independently wealthy. We went to D.D.L. for lunch - Dino De Laurentiis - to Shakespeare in the Park and the Met.''

title: FIRST BANCORP OF OHIO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest quarter net includes a nonrecurring gain of $674,000 from Ohio tax refund.

title: GROWING FLEET OF CRUISE SHIPS
description: ABOARD M.S. NOORDAM, off Le Havre, France, April 9 - When Nico van der Vorm, chairman of the Holland America Line, is asked why he has just built this $150 million luxury cruise ship for the United States market, he replies with a quotation from the 16th-century Dutch scholar Erasmus: ''The highest form of bliss is living with a certain degree of folly.''

title: SHELBY WILLIAMS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Advertising; Using Qube To Market Cosmetics
description: ON Monday, in four cities served by Qube cable television, Warner Cosmetics will broaden its search for customers for its Ralph Lauren cosmetics line. It will thus be using the interactive cable TV system in a way that has already proved highly successful in a single-market test.

title: SPI PHARMACEUTICALS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Maryland Move
description: With the Colts gone, it would appear to be a bit late to lock the barn door, but the Maryland Congressional delegation is hoping to do just that - retroactively. The delegation, led by the state's Senators, Paul Sarbanes and Charles Mathias, and Representative Barbara A. Mikulski of Baltimore, is sponsoring legislation that would make it more difficult for owners of sports franchises to move their teams. The bill would ban such moves unless the owner could convince a three-member arbitration panel that the team had sustained consistent financial losses and that no local buyer could be found or that its stadium was inadequate and a suitable one could not be provided.

title: REGAN'S RAISES FOR HIS STAFF SET OFF A DISPUTE IN ALBANY
description: State Comptroller Edward V. Regan has printed checks giving pay increases to 40 senior members of his staff, setting off a dispute with the Democratic Cuomo administration over who has the power to control the payroll of the Comptroller, a Republican.

title: MORTON THIOKOL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
'ICEMAN,' FROZEN NEANDERTHAL
description: ''ICEMAN'' isn't much of a movie, but what a science project! There in the Arctic wilds, scientists discover a block of ice in which a Neanderthal man has been frozen (this footage is actually quite beautiful). Then they transport the specimen back to their lab and begin slicing the ice with lasers, as the camera records every drip. When the thawing is complete, they prepare to perform an autopsy on the man, who has also been hooked up to a battery of machines. Suddenly, there are some unexpected beeps. It's brain-wave activity! Cancel the autopsy, please.

title: CHANGES ON LONDON EXCHANGE
description: The London Stock Exchange's governing council issued a discussion paper today concluding that several membership restrictions and the current trading system separating dealers from brokers should be dismantled.

description: The House Energy and Commerce Committee today approved legislation to put a cap on natural gas prices until 1987 with the aim of forcing home heating bills down next winter.

OILERS TAKE 1-0 LEAD AS GRETZKY GETS 2 Edmonton, Alberta, April 12 (UPI) - Wayne Gretzky broke a playoff slump by getting two goals and two assists tonight as he led the Edmonton Oilers to a 5-2 victory over the Calgary Flames in the opening game of their Smythe Division final series.
description: The Oilers, who have lost only once to Calgary in the last 15 games, will meet the Flames in Game 2 of the four-of-seven series Friday night at the Northlands Coliseum.

title: A Playwright Talks About the Blues
description: NEW HAVEN - When Ralph Ellison pondered the pain of his blackness in "Invisible Man," he remembered Louis Armstrong plaintively singing, "What did I do to be so black and blue?" "Perhaps I like Louis Armstrong," Mr. Ellison wrote, "because he's made poetry out of being invisible."

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; M.A.C. Plans to Issue $225 Million of Bonds
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation announced plans yesterday to sell about $225 million of bonds in the week of April 23 to refund about $277 million of outstanding bonds. The new bonds will be sold through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

description: The International Business Machines Corporation reported yesterday that its net income rose 23 percent in the first quarter, to a record $1.2 billion, or $1.97 a share, from $976 million, or $1.62 a share, in the first quarter of 1982.

title: ADVISERS' SALVADOR ROLE: U.S. RESPONDS
description: The Defense Department said today that it could not ''substantiate'' a report that United States advisers in El Salvador had accompanied Salvadoran pilots on training missions that brought them into combat.

Success Story
description: Three seasons ago, the Detroit Pistons drew 228,349 fans in 41 home games while finishing sixth in the National Basketball Association's Central Division.

title: Locust Threat in Atlantic
description: The British Defense Ministry will send specialists to the South Atlantic this weekend to spray insecticides on locust eggs in an effort to prevent locusts from disrupting Britain's air links with the Falkland Islands. About every 25 years locusts swarm around Ascension Island, which Britain uses as a stopping- off point for flights to the Falklands, according to the Defense Ministry.

title: FEDERAL JUDGE SUSPENDS RULE LINKING DRAFT STATUS TO AID
description: The Department of Education overstepped its bounds by requiring students seeking financial aid to sign forms saying they had either registered or were ineligible for the draft, a Federal district judge has ruled here.

description: The Briggs & Stratton Corporation said it will lay off about 1,000 employees, or 10 percent of its work force, next Thursday, as it returns to normal production after ''near-record production'' the last three months.

A MOST-WANTED FUGITIVE SOUGHT IN GIRL'S STABBING
description: A teen-aged girl abducted early this week in Indiana was stabbed and left for dead in upstate New York yesterday, and authorities said they believed the attacker was one of the nation's most-wanted fugitives.

description: Thirteen of the House Judiciary Committee's 20 Democrats made public a letter today calling for the appointment of a special prosecutor to look into President Reagan's support of military attacks on Nicaragua.

COLORADO CONSIDERING BID TO BAN POKER BONANZA
description: Poker, the Colorado Attorney General declared to the surprise of many a cardsharp, is a game of skill under state law.

title: Track Repercussion
description: In the wake of the scandal that has shaken the Texas-El Paso track program, the school's largest track meet has been canceled. The meet, the El Paso Invitational, which had been scheduled for April 21, was called off by the meet director, Alan Veach , who said that the action had been taken because of uncertainties surrounding a university investigation of the track program. The track coach, Larry Heidebrecht , resigned last week after it was disclosed that the university was looking into a report that he had used a secret athletic department bank account to funnel illegal payments from meet promoters to his star athletes.

title: THE CITY Builder Gets O.K. On Subway Link
description: The Board of Estimate yesterday gave final approval for a private developer to build the major portion of a pedestrian tunnel connecting the IND and IRT subway lines under Lexington Avenue between 51st and 53d Streets.

title: Sushi and sashimi on the West Side.
description: THE extra block that theatergoers will have to walk to eat at Sushi Zen is well worth the few minutes it takes. But if it weren't for the red, white and blue bunting announcing the presence of this tiny two-month-old restaurant on 46th Street, between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas, it would be easy to miss.

title: OLD AND NEW MASTERS ON VIEW
description: THE first thing to be said about ''Reading Drawings'' at the Drawing Center, 137 Greene Street in SoHo, is that no one could possibly find it boring. Culled from the collections of the Victoria and Albert Museum in London, it consists of 98 drawings of every imaginable kind. Doubtless, it helped that the Victoria and Albert is both a museum of fine art and the national museum of design, but even so there is an exceptional catholicity about this show, which can be seen through July 28.

title: THE BEAR'S BIG BLUFF
description: Without realizing it, the Soviet Union is providing Peter Ueberroth the best possible basic training for his future task as baseball commissioner.

title: BROOKLYN RENEWAL: TWO-STORY HOMES
description: The designation of the Fulton Park section of Bedford-Stuyvesant in Brooklyn as an urban renewal area goes back to 1967, and the construction of the final redevelopment parcel got under way only last year.

title: NUCLEUS LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Condec Takes Farley Unit Bid
description: The Condec Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by a corporation owned by William F. Farley for $29 a share, or more than $131 million.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about management changes at the Procter & Gamble Company incorrectly characterized the responsibility of two new vice chairmen. The executives, Thomas Laco and Edwin L. Artzt, have responsibility for certain day-to-day operations of the company.

title: A PLAYWRIGHT TALKS ABOUT THE BLUES
description: SAMUEL G. FREEDMAN

NO SPLIT ENTRIES FOR DERBYBETTORS HERE
description: New Yorkers will be able to bet legally on the Kentucky Derby on May 5 and will even have a choice of betting outlets. Under a new bill passed this week by the State Legislature, Derby betting will be offered both by offtrack betting parlors and at Aqueduct Race Track. But the kind of potential bonanza available to offtrack Derby bettors in previous years will not be available this time.

title: POLICE ON COAST VISITING SCHOOLS IN FIGHT ON SMUT
description: Carrying briefcases of pornographic photographs, detectives are asking teachers in high schools and junior high schools here to identify the teen-age girls depicted.

title: RED GROOMS ON THE ROAD
description: No one can accuse Red Grooms, one of the art world's most reliable comedy acts, of a shortage of invention. A live-wire wit with manic energy, he puts out an epic amount of material, his brilliantly zany view of American life informed with a rare good humor. Since his last New York gallery appearance in 1981, he's been busier than a one-armed paperhanger; a recent extravaganza being a walk-in environment of the city of Philadelphia - similar to his ''Ruckus Manhattan'' of 1976 - complete with the Liberty Bell and a session of the Continental Congress.

title: A CONCERT BY A VIRTUOSO ON THE PORTUGUESE GUITAR
description: JON PARELES

title: Reuters to Introduce Picture Service in '85
description: Reuters, the international news agency, announced today that it would start a worldwide news picture service early in 1985.

title: VISIT BY THE MILWAUKEE
description: TIM PAGE

title: CITY TO PAY WELFARE BENEFITS AT BANKS AND CHECK OUTLETS
description: The Board of Estimate yesterday unanimously approved a $7.8 million plan that will have welfare and food- stamp recipients collecting their benefits directly from 350 banks and check- cashing outlets.

ART: THE UPSIDE-DOWN WORLD OF GEORG BASELITZ
description: -down imagery of Georg Baselitz has become so familiar that it is all but superfluous to mention it. Yet, as Baselitz's new canvases at Mary Boone, 417 West Broadway, insist, there's no discussing the work without trying to come to terms with the inversion. Mainly this is because it doesn't achieve its purpose, which is to deflect the beholder from the subject to the way it is painted.

title: MUCKER FOR CAPITALS DIGS OUT A WINNER
description: His job is often thankless. And Craig Laughlin is thankful for that.

title: Does Nuclear Power Have a Future?
description: The nuclear industry is next door to moribund. No new power plants have been ordered since 1978, and unfinished plants that have already cost billions are being canceled. With some notable exceptions, utilities are now finding that nuclear plants cost far more to build than expected, and operate less efficiently. Public disquiet about nuclear safety continues unabated.

title: SCRIPPS-HOWARD BROADCASTNG reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Chemical Applies For Florida Bank
description: Chemical Bank said it had applied to Federal banking authorities for permission to convert its trust company in Palm Beach, Fla., into a consumer banking unit.

title: COMPUTRAC INSTRUMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ALMOST ARMS CONTROL
description: It is clearly too late to negotiate a comprehensive arms control agreement with the Russians before the elections in November. Yet several interim measures could be completed in the next few months. If Mr. Reagan is serious about arms control, he need only work out the details of several general provisions already under negotiation.

title: PAULIN, H, & CO LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Nicholas to Dance
description: Harold Nicholas of the Nicholas Brothers tap-dance team, will appear in ''A Night at the Savoy - A Salute to Swing'' at the Village Gate, Bleecker at Thompson Street, tonight at 12:30 A.M. Also appearing will be Norma Miller and her jazz dancers. Doors open at 10:30 P.M. Admission, $12.50. Information, 475-5120.

title: MUBARAK GOVERNMENT SEIZES OPPOSITION PAPER'S ISSUE FOR THE FIRST TIME
description: The Government halted the distribution of an opposition newspaper today. It was the first such action in Egypt since President Hosni Mubarak took office in October 1981.

title: SHUTTLE READY TO LAND TODAY
description: The Challenger astronauts gently placed a once-crippled satellite back in orbit today, completing their task of demonstrating that significant, cost-saving repairs can be made in space.

title: Accounts
description: * Jet Express, Chicago, a new no- frills airline, to Zechman & Associates, Chicago.

title: SOUTHWEST BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Selection of Delegates In Wisconsin Assailed
description: Attorney General Bronson LaFollette said Tuesday that he might seek to become a Gary Hart delegate to the Democratic National Convention in July because of caucus results that he said had made a ''mockery'' of the delegate selection process.

title: JACKSON SAYS HE DISAGREES ON MUSLIM'S VIEW OF HITLER
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson said yesterday that he strongly disagreed with the contention of Louis Farrakhan, leader of a branch of the Black Muslims, that Hitler was a ''great man.'' But Mr. Jackson continued to refuse to dissociate himself completely from Mr. Farrakhan.

title: MONEY SUPPLY FALLS $5 BILLION
description: The Federal Reserve yesterday announced a $5 billion decline in the nation's basic money supply for the week ending April 4. The drop was twice as large as expected.

title: NEWS SUMMARY FRIDAY, APRIL 13, 1984 International
description: No mines remain in Nicaraguan ports, according to the nation's Chief of Staff. Commander Joaquin Cuadra Lacayo also denied that the Sandinista Government was sending arms to rebels in El Salvador, as the U.S. has charged. (Page A1:Column 1.) Arab terrorists hijacked an Israeli bus near Tel Aviv and forced it to the occupied Gaza Strip, where it was being held with at least 10 passengers aboard. (A1:2.)

title: POP AND JAZZ
description: STEPHEN HOLDEN

title: THE REGION ;  Union City Yields Subpoenaed Data
description: Union City officials, facing $1,000-a-day contempt fines, turned over subpoenaed records today to investigators looking for evidence of municipal corruption.

title: FIRESTORM IN A TEACUP
description: Let's stipulate at the outset that mining the harbors of Nicaragua was not the hottest idea the C.I.A. ever had.

title: DISCOVERED EFFECT ON COSMIC RAYS
description: Scott E. Forbush, discoverer of a global effect on cosmic rays, died of pneumonia April 4 in Charlottesville, Va. He was 79 years old and lived in Charlottesville.

title: Intel Profit Quadruples
description: The Intel Corporation, the semiconductor maker whose 8088 microprocessor lies at the heart of I.B.M.'s Personal Computer and all I.B.M.-compatible machines, said yesterday that its first-quarter profit had quadrupled, to $50.3 million, or 43 cents a share, from $12.5 million, or 12 cents a share, a year before. Sales were $371.6 million, up 56 percent from $237.5 million. Demand for the 8088 and other chips has so overwhelmed Intel that customers have been put on allocation.

title: Records for Sale
description: Nearly 20,000 records will be offered for sale Sunday at the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center, Amsterdam Avenue and 65th Street, from noon to 5 P.M. to benefit the Rodgers and Hammerstein Archives of Recorded Sound. For a $2 admission fee, browsers may choose from musical theater, jazz, opera, film sound track and classical music recordings.

title: SATELLITE TO RESUME STUDY OF FLARES AND SUNSPOTS
description: Before it broke down in 1980, the Solar Max orbiting observatory gathered data that brought scientists to the brink of a host of discoveries about one of the most familiar yet mysterious of objects: our Sun.

title: GREAT NORTHERN NEKOOSA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an investment tax credit of $4,400,000. c-Includes an investment tax credit of $8,300,000.

title: Thomas Babe play to revive link with star and director.
description: RICHARD CHAMBERLAIN, who has rarely appeared on the New York stage, is planning to come to Broadway next fall. He will star in Thomas Babe's new play, ''Born Every Minute,'' which will be directed by Robert Allan Ackerman. There is a Chamberlain-Babe-Ackerman connection that goes back to 1978, when the three did Mr. Babe's ''Fathers and Sons'' for a brief run at the Public Theater and then reopened the play in Los Angeles. Mr. Chamberlain and Mr. Ackerman also worked together not long ago on an acclaimed production of Shaw's ''Arms and the Man'' at the Williamstown Theater Festival in Massachusetts.

title: PILOTS WARNED AWAY FROM LANDING STRIP
description: The Air Force and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration issued a plea today asking private pilots not to violate restricted air space when the shuttle Challenger lands here Friday morning.

title: SCREEN: DOWN-AND-OUT YOUTHS IN 'SUBURBIA'
description: BETWEEN its alarming though not especially pertinent precredit sequence, in which a baby is fatally attacked by a Doberman pinscher, and its apocalyptic finale, in which another innocent is lost, Penelope Spheeris's ''Suburbia'' is a clear- eyed, compassionate melodrama about a bunch of young dropouts who call themselves ''The Rejected'' or, for short, the TR's.

title: Murder Verdict In Newsboy Case
description: After delibertating eight hours, a Nassau County jury today found Robert W. Golliver, 18 years old, guilty of the murder of Christopher Gruhn, a 14- year-old newsboy.

title: DANNERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-Net income.

title: RETAIL SALES DOWN 2.2% IN MARCH
description: Retail sales in March posted their sharpest monthly drop in more than a decade, the Government reported today.

ROYAL DUTCH SHELL DROPS SHELL WORKER OFFER
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group said early today that it was withdrawing the part of its tender offer for the Shell Oil Company that would offer more to Shell employees than to outside shareholders.

description: b-Net loss.

title: Baseball; Detroit Goes to 7-0, Its Best Start Ever
description: Alan Trammell, Chet Lemon and Lou Whitaker hit home runs as Jack Morris and the unbeaten Tigers defeated the Texas Rangers, 9-4, today. The victory extended Detroit's streak to seven games, the best start in the club's 84-year history.

title: T-BAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
COMPANY STARTS TO PLANT STREET TREES
description: Seven slender ash trees, their buds barely beginning to bloom, were planted in pits along a sunny Harlem block yesterday. It was the first step of an unusual agreement between the city and a company that hopes to take over the planting and maintenance of trees throughout the city.

title: Druse Leader Seeking A Syrian Role in Beirut
description: The Druse leader Walid Jumblat joined other opposition leaders today in a call for Syrian troops to intervene in Beirut to end factional fighting.

title: CHINESE TECHNICIAN CLIMBS OUT OF CONSULATE
description: A Chinese businessman lowered himself out a window of the 20-story Chinese Consulate in Manhattan early yesterday in what is being investigated as an attempt to seek political asylum here, authorities said.

title: 26 Children Hurt As Train and Bus Collide c
description: A freight train and a bus carrying elementary school students collided at a crossing in this southeast Virginia community today, injuring the bus driver and all 26 children aboard, the authorities said.

title: MRS. KIRKPATRICK CHIDES LATIN CRITICS
description: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, said today that the Government could not practice ''unilateral compliance'' with rules of international law that its adversaries violated with impunity.

title: U.S. OFFICIAL, IN EGYPT, DISCUSSES NEW CAIRO PLAN TO END GULF WAR
description: With many Arab diplomats increasingly concerned about a major step-up in the Iran-Iraq war, a high-ranking State Department official met with a senior Egyptian official today for talks focusing on a new Egyptian diplomatic effort to end the 42-month conflict.

title: Mets Scouting'Quicker Kids'
description: Artificial turf won't be installed in Shea Stadium for perhaps a couple of years, under the city's plan for renovating the stadium. But the Mets aren't letting any grass grow under their feet in adapting present strategy to future conditions, even though they have traditionally opposed artificial turf.

title: MERCHANT BANK OF CALIFORNIA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The Merchant Bank of California was formerly the First National Bank of Beverly Hills.

title: BRITAIN BARS SALE OF POISONS TO GULF
description: The Government announced in Parliament today that it had banned the unlicensed export to Iran or Iraq of eight chemicals that can be used in the manufacture of nerve gas.
