description: b-Net loss.

title: FED ISSUES STATEMENT ON ARGENTINE LOANS
description: The Federal Reserve Board issued a statement yesterday that said it had provided neither funds nor credit guarantees on a $100 million loan extended to Argentina at the end of March by 11 international banks. The Fed said the statement was issued in response to inquiries prompted by an article published yesterday in The New York Times.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: toed stars of ''Gremlins,'' except for the facts that water makes them multiply and that they are due to arrive in New York in eight weeks. Even now, as marketing for the new film directed by Joe Dante (with Steven Spielberg as executive producer) gets under way, an air of secrecy prevails. As frustrating as that may be for the public at large, it's downright inconvenient for those involved in marketing the film. However, they don't seem to mind. If anything, they view it as a challenge.

title: PPG INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Reduced by $11,800,000 for costs resulting from a curtailment of operations at a chemical manufacturing plant.

title: ALVARADO FACES A NEW CHARGE OF MISCONDUCT New York City's Board of Education yesterday made public an additional charge of misconduct against Anthony J. Alvarado, the suspended Schools Chancellor.
description: The board contends that a summer employee of the board baby-sat, ran errands and performed other personal chores for the Alvarado family while it was on a two-week vacation on Long Island last summer.

title: BANDAG INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GANNETT GIVES $15 MILLION FOR JOURNALISM CENTER AT COLUMBIA
description: Columbia University announced yesterday that it would establish the country's first center for advanced studies in journalism and communications, under a $15 million, five-year grant from the Gannett Foundation.

title: MILTON W. MAYS DEAD AT 73;FORMER INSURANCE EXECUTIVE
description: Milton W. Mays, former president of the Continental Insurance Companies and former vice chairman of its parent concern, the Continental Corporation, died of a heart attack Tuesday at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived in Greenwich.

title: CITY PLAN LISTS 8 SITES FOR PLANTS TO BURN TRASH AND MAKE POWER
description: To replace the city's dwindling dump sites, the Koch Administration proposes to put garbage-burning incinerators in every borough.

description: A couple of old Yankees took a close look at the young Mets today and decided that their pitchers had made a spectacular debut this season but had not yet felt the full fury of the hitters in the National League.

description: Highlights of budget bill, page B7.

title: WALTER FLOWERS, 51, FORMER U.S. REPRESENTATIVE
description: Former Representative Walter Flowers, a member of the House Judiciary Committee during the Watergate hearings in 1974, died last night in Falls Church, Va. He turned 51 years old yesterday and lived in McLean, Va.

title: CANDICE BERGEN: HAPPY TO SETTLE DOWN
description: At the age of 37, Candice Bergen is still the quintessential blond beauty every woman wants to look like and every man wants clinging to his arm. But as she sees it, her eyes are too ''hooded'' and her fashion-model slimness is an optical illusion created by the fact that she often wears black.

title: GREAT AMERICAN FEDERAL SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss The company recorded income of $1.2 million, after taxes, during the latest first quarter from the sale of five offices in its branch consolidation program.

title: CROCKER LOSES $120 MILLION
description: The Crocker National Corporation, the nation's 14th-largest banking organization, yesterday reported a loss of $120.8 million in the first quarter of 1984 as the result of a major provision for bad loans. It followed a $57.2 million loss in the fourth quarter and a $10.4 million loss for all of 1983.

description: MacNamara, Clapp & Klein has been assigned the Cinzano U.S.A. business by Julius Wile Sons & Company, a subsidiary of Nabisco Brands.

description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $1,028,000. c-Includes an extraordinary gain of $8,664,000. Share earnings reflect share reorganization last year. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: WAS LEADER'S HEIR APPARENT
description: Prime Minister Edward Sokoine, heir apparent to President Julius K. Nyerere, was killed today in an auto accident near Morogoro in central Tanzania. He was 46 years old.

description: The results for the latest quarter include Flagship Banks Inc. from the Jan. 1 date of acquisition.

COMPUTER IS LEAVING A WIDE IMPRINT ON CONGRESS
description: The computer has become essential to the functioning of virtually every aspect of Congress and appears to be contributing to subtle but far-reaching changes in one of the oldest and most traditional of America's national institutions.

title: Midweek TV: Jets 2, Giants 1
description: Next season's National Football League schedule, released yesterday, shows that the Jets will make two weeknight appearances to be televised nationally by ABC: at home against Pittsburgh on Thursday, Sept. 6, and in Miami on Monday, Nov. 26. The Giants' only weeknight appearance will be at home against San Francisco on Monday, Oct. 8. The Giants play the Jets Dec. 2 at Giants Stadium, and, though it may seem strange at first to New York fans, it is the Jets, late of Shea Stadium and now of the Meadowlands, who will be the home team.

title: Kaiser Loss Is $410.9 Million
description: The Kaiser Steel Corporation announced yesterday a fourth- quarter loss of $410.9 million, reflecting a one-time write-off of $400.2 million related to discontinued steel-manufacturing operations.

title: Pope John Paul II Is Subject of Documentary
description: ''John Paul II: the Pope From Poland,'' a documentary written by Andrew De Ruttie and narrated by the novelist James Michener, can be seen Sunday night at 9 on Channel 5. This hourlong account is a fairly straightforward treatment of Karol Wojtyla's years before and after his rise to the Papacy.

title: TO THE MOHAWK NATION, BOUNDARIES DO NOT EXIST
description: To hear Vaughan Aldrich tell it, he and the 7,000 other Mohawk Indians who live here form a sovereign nation whose territory just happens to straddle the border between the United States and Canada.

1400's Bible from Prague.
description: A 15TH-CENTURY Hebrew manuscript Bible from Prague, richly illuminated, will be auctioned by Sotheby's on June 26. The announcement of the auction of this rare work comes on the weekend of the opening in New York of ''The Precious Legacy: Judaic Treasures From the Czechoslovak State Collections'' at the Jewish Museum, Fifth Avenue and 92d Street, an exhibition that can be seen Sunday through Aug. 26. The generously embellished vellum Bible contains 84 illuminated pages of initial- word panels and margin illustrations of scrolled flowers and, occasionally, of animals. The three-volume manuscript is in a 20th-century binding, 9 1/2 inches by 7 inches. Sotheby's expects it to bring about $500,000.

title: SIMMERING ANGER
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato's unusual outburst on the Senate floor Wednesday at his colleague, Daniel Patrick Moynihan, was more than just momentary anger, his aides said.

title: Funds Rise $647 Million
description: The assets of the nation's money market mutual funds recovered slightly, rising $647 million, to $172.27 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: LATE RALLY LIFTS DOW 26.17 POINTS
description: Stock prices surged in late trading yesterday in the market's biggest rally in more than a month as institutional investors shrugged off early hesitations and rushed to buy.

title: CRENSHAW'S 67 LEADS MASTERS
description: Ben Crenshaw found just the driver he wanted last year sticking out of a barrel of odd used golf clubs in a Houston sporting goods store. He paid $300 for the 30-year-old driver and with it today he missed only one fairway on the Augusta National Golf Club course while shooting a 5-under-par 67. That was good enough for a one-stroke lead in the opening round of the 48th Masters Tournament.

title: A PEKING OFFICIAL SAID TO LOSE POST
description: A front-page commentary in the Communist Party newspaper today offered the strongest official indication yet that the party's propaganda chief had been relieved of his duties.

description: The conviction of a woman in the fatal stabbing of her husband was voided today by an appeals court on the ground that her three confessions were not legal.

description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Scene; The Challenge For Democrats
description: WHILE the economic recovery increases the odds of President Reagan's re-election, relatively high unemployment persists in different parts of the country and could hurt him in some key states.

title: FOR FAR-OUT EXPERIENCE NEARBY, A PLANETARIUM VISIT
description: DOUGLAS C. McGILL

title: HARRIS POLL FINDS HART IN A TIE WITH REAGAN
description: Senator Gary Hart's bid for the Democratic Presidential nomination is fading because his appeal to independents is not reflected in party primaries, but he still shows more strength against President Reagan than does Walter F. Mondale, Louis Harris, the pollster, said today.

title: ALLIED BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: All amounts for the year-ago quarter were restated to include entities acquired in transactions accounted for on a poolings of interest basis.

title: TROOPS RETAKE IT
description: Four Arab terrorists hijacked an Israeli bus Thursday night, but troops stormed the vehicle early today and rescued about 35 passengers held hostage for 10 hours.

title: STANDARD MICROSYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding have been retroactively restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split effective June 22, 1983.

title: JACKSON TAKES CAMPAIGN TO ARIZONA
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson today sought support from various voter groups in an attempt to build a coalition of support before Arizona's Democratic caucuses on Saturday.

title: O.A.S. Council Rules Against Former Chief
description: The permanent council of the Organization of American States ruled today that former Secretary General Alejandro Orfila had violated the organization's rules by working for a United States company, opening the way for possible revocation of his pension.

title: Carrie Smith to Sing
description: The singer Carrie Smith will perform tonight at 6:15 at the Society for Ethical Culture (874-5210), 2 West 64th Street. Tickets are $6.

title: Cyclone Destroys Port in Madagascar
description: A cyclone destroyed most of the port of Mahajanga today, killing 15 people and seriously injuring 30 with winds of up to 150 miles an hour, the Malagasy radio said.

title: CITY AND JERSEY CITY END DISPUTE ON U.S. DEVELOPMENT PLAN
description: After feuding for more than 16 months, New York City and Jersey City yesterday settled their dispute over a $40 million Federal grant to help redevelop the Jersey City waterfront.

title: Election Panel Dismisses Democratic Complaint
description: The Federal Election Commission has tossed out a Democratic complaint charging illegal collusion between the National Conservative Political Action Committee and President Reagan's re- election committee.

title: A Ralston Closing
description: The Ralston Purina Company said that because of economic problems it would close its tuna cannery in San Diego on July 1, laying off 1,200 workers. It said the book value of the building and equipment is about $30 million, but the extent of charges against earnings remained undetermined. Ralston, which is also involved in livestock feed and cereals. said it would continue processing tuna in Puerto Rico and American Samoa.

title: SMITHSON DEFEATS FONTENOT AND YANKEES
description: One of last year's rookie surprises had a disappointing evening last night in the Yankees' 3-0 loss to the Minnesota Twins, while a Yankee newcomer made a smooth entry into the major leagues.

title: MARSHALL & ILSLEY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago results are restated to reflect the May 1983 acquisition of Central Bank & Trust which was accounted for a pooling of interests.

title: COLUMBUS MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
U.S. CHECK ON 355 AIRLINES FINDS PROBLEMS IN 50
description: The Federal Government, reporting initial results of a rigorous inspection of the nation's 355 airlines, said today that 50 lines had safety-related problems requiring further study.

title: Cosmos Are Getting No Rest
description: Twelve hours after they had been swept in the North American Soccer League's indoor championship series, the Cosmos were at work this morning preparing for an outdoor season that they hope will not be aborted by a stalemate in labor negotiations.

title: Putting Nutrasweet in Gum Balls
description: Thanks to Leaf Confectionary of Chicago, gum balls will soon be available with Nutrasweet. And buyers need not cope with the mechanical complexities of a gum- ball machine to get them - the innovative Leaf folks have packed them eight balls to a box.

title: TRW INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HALT EXPERIMENTS U.S. COURT IS ASKED
description: Environmentalists today asked a Federal district judge to halt scheduled outdoor experiments using genetically altered organisms to delay the formation of frost on plants.

title: AFFILIATED PUBLICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 25
LAWYERS FOR KLAN AND NAZIS GIVE FINAL ARGUMENTS
description: -SALEM, N.C., April 12 - A Federal jury will begin deliberating Friday morning on whether six Ku Klux Klan and three American Nazi Party members violated the civil rights of five Communist Workers Party members who were killed at an anti-Klan rally.

title: BOISE CASCADE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
OPEN CAPITAL MARKETS IN JAPAN SOUGHT BY U.S.
description: The United States, in backstage maneuvering at a conference here of world financial officials, tried again today to put pressure on Japan to open its capital markets to foreign underwriters and borrowers.

title: EX-ATLANTIC CITY MAYOR SAID TO CONFESS TIES TO MOBSTERS
description: Former Mayor Michael J. Matthews of Atlantic City was held in $300,000 bail today after the United States Attorney told a Federal judge that Mr. Matthews had confessed to taking payoffs from organized-crime figures.

title: KOCH AND ESTIMATE BOARD CLASH ON RENOVATING SHELTERS
description: The Board of Estimate yesterday blocked consideration of a plan by Mayor Koch to spend $18 million to renovate shelters for the homeless, with members saying they first wanted Mr. Koch to submit a comprehensive plan for homeless care.

title: RYAN'S FAMILY STEAK HOUSES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NCNB CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Retirement Ending Ties Of Hunts to Alcoa
description: Almost a century of service by the Hunt family to the Aluminum Company of America will end May 1 when Alfred M. Hunt retires as vice president and secretary.

title: Bankruptcy Court Rule
description: The Senate voted today to extend until May 26 the authority for Federal bankruptcy courts to operate in order to give Congress more time to rewrite United States bankruptcy laws.

title: Trained Runner Eludes Tennessee Prison Search
description: A prison escapee who is a long- distance runner eluded a multi-state search for a fourth day today as National Guardsmen aided by tracking dogs and helicopters pursued the killer at a cost of more than $20,000 a day.

title: CABLE TV INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $170,000 from an accounting change.

title: WACHOVIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Nestle Profits Up 15%
description: Nestle S.A., the Swiss-based food conglomerate, said today that its profits rose 15 percent in 1983, to $586 million, while revenues rose 1 percent, to $13 billion. The company attributed the increase to cost-reduction measures, ''tight control of working capital,'' a decrease in financial costs and increased investment in marketing, research and development.

title: Title to Louganis
description: Greg Louganis took his 26th national title in winning the 1-meter springboard competition tonight at the United States indoor diving championships. Kelly McCormick won the women's 3-meter springboard event. Louganis had a final score of 659.16 and defeated the defending champion Ron Marriott, who scored 607.20 for his 11 dives at the University of Florida's O'Connell Center pool.

title: Different Drum
description: When Eric Patterson was born in 1961, his father was heavyweight boxing champion of the world. As he grew up in Scarsdale, N.Y., and Great Neck, L.I., he often accompanied his father to gymnasiums until his father retired from boxing in 1972.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Del E. Webb Corp . 's offering of 25,000 units was priced at $955 per unit, according to the First Boston Corp. Each unit consists of one 11 1/2 percent subordinated note due 1988 in the principal amount of $1,000, and 20 four-year warrants to buy common stock.

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: Cameroon Says 70 Died In Attempt at Coup

title: BRIEFING
description: Independent Republicans

title: HOW THE S.E.C. WATCHES STOCKS
description: For almost 50 years, the Securities and Exchange Commission has kept its ''ticker room'' - the nerve center where it monitors trading activity - hidden from the public eye.

title: Luring a Linebacker
description: Ever since they lost two of their linebackers to the United States Football League last winter, the Cincinnati Bengals of the National Football League have been looking for replacements.

title: CBT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Australian Paintings
description: The Institute for Art and Urban Resources is showing ''An Australian Accent,'' an exhibition of paintings by Mike Parr, Imants Tillers and Ken Unsworth of Australia, Sunday through June 10 in the main exhibition center at Project Studios 1, 46-01 21st Street in Long Island City, Queens.

title: PENTAIR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

; AILANTHUS: A TREE FIT FOR ASPHALT JUNGLES
description: To the Editor:

A CITY REBELS AT GAMES' COST
description: The city of Long Beach, in a dispute with the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee over the cost of security for the Summer Games, has suspended preparations for the four events scheduled to be held here.

title: NATIONAL BANCORP OF ALASKA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FIRST ALABAMA BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CHEMICAL NEW YORK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The per share figures do not reflect 50 percent stock dividend payable April 13 but after adjusting for the stock dividend the primary net per share was $1.58 for the latest quarter and $1.63 for the year-earlier period. The company said that the decline in primary earnings per share resulted from the sale of additional shares of common stock and conversions of convertible debt and preferred stock.

title: VALLEY NATIONAL CORP OF PHOENIX reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest quarter net included a nonrecurring loss of $1.5 million in connection with the disposition of a subsidiary.

title: THE PROPER SPONSER OF A VETERANS' BILL
description: To the Editor:

title: Officials Revoke Parole For Convicted Murderer
description: Officials revoked parole today for a former graduate student who murdered his Stanford University mathematics professor and refused to promise he would never kill again.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ; PAINT, PAINT, PAINT YOUR BOAT
description: Splashing red paint on an upside-

title: No Names, Please
description: Rusty Wailes , a rower who won gold medals at the 1956 and 1960 Olympics, lived in the Seattle suburb of Edmonds for years, and no one ever named a park for him. Then along comes Rosalynn Sumners , an Edmonds skater who won a silver medal at the 1984 Winter Games, and all of a sudden Mayor Larry Naughten and the City Council decide they want to change the name of Dayton Street Park to Rosalynn Sumners Park.

title: KILLER IN TEXAS SENTENCED TO DIE
description: Henry Lee Lucas, who says he has killed up to 360 people, was sentenced today to death by lethal injection for the rape and murder of an unidentified woman in 1979.

title: Inquiry on Jackpot At Slot Machine
description: Officials have moved to block payment of a $150,360 slot-machine jackpot because, they said, the machine had been manipulated or tampered with.

title: Reagan Announces Sale Of 40 Tanks to Thailand
description: President Reagan announced today that the United States would sell Thailand 40 M-48 tanks because of the threat posed by Vietnamese troops in neighboring Cambodia.

title: FIRST AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
EMILY POST AND THE ART OF ENJOYING ASPARAGUS
description: I don't know what came over me the other evening as I peered down at a plate of crunchy, spring-green asparagus. I put down my fork, picked up a stalk in my fingers and ate it in several bites, telling myself all the while that my table manners were deteriorating.

title: End of the Ride For Elvin Hayes
description: The longest playing career in the 38-year history of the National Basketball Association will end tonight in Kansas City when Elvin Hayes of the Houston Rockets will appear in his 1,303d game, then remove his uniform (No. 44) for the last time.

title: REFURBISHGATE
description: From September 1982 through the end of 1983, when the New York Telephone Company was selling phones to customers (rather than solely leasing them for a monthly fee, as it had before that time), the company sold - by its own account - roughly one million phones. Nearly all of them were used. Yet very few of the buyers ever knew this - they were charged the same price as for a new phone.

title: INTEREST RATES RISE SHARPLY
description: Interest rates rose sharply in all maturities yesterday, with long-term bond prices falling by nearly 1 3/4 points and Treasury bill rates rising by more than an eighth of a percentage point.

title: HOUSING FUND AS TAX SHELTER
description: Among the many tax shelters available to individuals are Government-subsidized housing programs. These little known shelter-investments not only provide the opportunity for tax benefits, but also - in contrast to some other shelters that are much better known to the public - serve one of the country's major social needs by stimulating more apartment building.

title: 2 Options To Be Ended
description: Citing lack of trader interest, the Chicago Board Options Exchange said it would drop two of its subindex option contracts, one based on international oils and the other on computer and business equipment stocks.

title: U.S.-JAPANESE TRADE PACT: 'COLONIALISM' CONFIRMED
description: To the Editor:

title: Police and Protesters Battle in Frankfurt
description: Street battles flared in central Frankfurt tonight between the police and thousands of young people during a march to protest the opening of a new runway at Frankfurt International Airport. Environmentalists objected to destruction of forests to make room for the runway.

title:
PATENTS;
METHOD OF SORTING PAPER CURRENCY
description: A method of sorting paper currency by denomination has been patented for GTE Laboratories, Waltham, Mass.

title: ALEXANDER SETTLES SUITS AGAINST 4 AT HOWDEN
description: Alexander & Alexander Services, one of the nation's biggest insurance brokers, said yesterday that it had settled lawsuits against four executives of its troubled British subsidiary, the Alexander Howden Group, but that litigation against a fifth British executive was continuing.

title: WASHINGTON FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN (DC) (O) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

PATENTS;
Hepatitis B Vaccine Process
description: WASHINGTON

title: Roll-Call in House on Mining
description: Following are the votes of Representatives from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on a House resolution Thursday night opposing the use of Federal funds for the mining of Nicaraguan harbors. A ''yes'' vote was a vote in favor of the resolution.

title: BANCOHIO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FIRST ILLINOIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
YANKEES LOSE
description: When the hard times finally arrived for the Mets, they arrived in numbers.

title: DOW DECLINES BY 7.01 AS TURNOVER EXPANDS
description: Stock prices finished mixed yesterday in heavier trading after the market's explosive rally on Thursday. Some of the large-capitalization and technology issues were the main losers.

title: TURKISH-AMERICAN PARADE
description: With public words of brotherhood

title: Shultz Plans Asia Visit
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz plans to visit South Korea and Japan on May 1 and 2 to brief the Governments there on President Reagan's trip to China, the White House said today. Mr. Reagan is scheduled to arrive in China on April 26 for a five-day visit.

title: FIFTH THIRD BANCORP (BRACENTON, FLORIDA) (O) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Russian Art Recovered
description: The police have recovered 12 priceless tapestries that were stolen from the Soviet Ambassador's official residence in Rome last January. The tapestries, which belonged to Peter the Great, were on loan from the Hermitage in Leningrad. The police did not say how they found the tapestries.

title: Farewell to Skiing
description: After a 13-year skiing career that included 32 victories in World Cup races, a slalom title, 2 overall championships and 2 gold medals and a silver medal at the 1980 Winter Olympics, Hanni Wenzel has decided it was time to do something else.

title: Dr. Carter Ailing
description: Dr. Carter, one of the favorites for the Kentucky Derby on May 5, has been confined to his stall because of a cough that could alter his spring plans and even cause him to miss the Derby. The colt is not running a temperature, but he has already lost two days of training, with the result that he might miss his last scheduled Derby prep, the Blue Grass Stakes at Keeneland April 26.

title: MERCANTILE TEXAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: All per share results are on fully diluted basis.

title: ROSE GETS DOUBLE FOR HIS 4,000 HIT
description: On the 21st anniversary of his first hit in the major leagues, Pete Rose collected his 4,000th hit today and, in typical fashion, said he would remember it not as a milestone but as a hit that kept a Montreal Expo rally alive.

title: MIKES SUBMARINES reports earnings for 12 wks to March 18
JURY SEATED IN DeLOREAN'S TRIAL ON DRUG CHARGES
description: Jury selection for the drug trafficking trial of John Z. DeLorean was completed today after 21 days, and Federal District Judge Robert M. Takasugi said opening arguments would begin Wednesday. Six men and six women were selected for the panel. Two men and two women were chosen as alternates.

title: TELEDYNE CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Former U.S. Counterspy Enters Not Guilty Plea
description: Richard Craig Smith, a former Army counterspy, pleaded not guilty today to five counts of selling the Soviet Union information about secret United States double-agent operations aimed at penetrating the Soviet K.G.B. espionage agency.

title: DETROIT BRINGS BACK THE BONUS
description: The General Motors Corporation disclosed today that its chairman, Roger B. Smith, was paid $1,058,000 in salary and bonuses for the year, the first time a G.M. executive's reported annual compensation has gone over the $1 million mark.

title: Royal Dutch Bid for Shell
description: The Shell Oil Company said yesterday that it was ''very concerned'' that the Royal Dutch/Shell Group had withdrawn an offer to pay Shell employees more for their stock than it would other shareholders.

title: 'The Human Comedy' May Close Tomorrow
description: Unless business picks up this weekend, it is likely that the musical ''The Human Comedy'' will close after Sunday's matinee, Joseph Papp, the producer, said yesterday.

title: 3 INQUIRIES OPEN ON BOGUS DEGREES
description: Three new inquiries into the awarding of bogus diplomas to doctors were announced yesterday as the number of people under investigation in New York State alone rose to 500.

title: REAGAN SUSPENDS BENEFITS CUTOFF
description: The Reagan Administration today suspended its efforts to cut off Social Security disability benefits. It ordered that benefits be continued or restored for 40,000 of the people who are challenging their removal from the rolls.

title: WESTERN PACIFIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results for the latest first quarter include a gain of $11,760,000, or $5.07 a share, from the conversion to cash of holdings in Cone Mills upon the consummation of the company's plan to become a private company in a leveraged buyout transaction. Year-ago first quarter results reflect an expense provision of $605,000 for the cost of settlement rights under stock option agreements.

title: JAPANESE WARNING TO U.S.
description: Japan warned today that if it was blocked by the United States from becoming the No. 2 voting member of the World Bank, it would cut back its aid to the poorest countries by more than $1 billion over the next three years.

title: RYLAND GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including a nonrecurring pretax gain of $401,000 from the sale of developed lots.

description: b-Net income.

description: Year-ago share earnings figures were not available because the company did not convert to a public stock company until Feb. 24, 1983.

title: CHECK TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-The company went public in June 1983 and therefore had no year-ago sales figures.

title: FIRST CHICAGO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HARRIS BANKCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Miss Goles's Upset Run Ends
description: First, spectators in one part of the stands at the Sea Pines Racquet Club here late this morning jumped up and began to hurry off. Then another group scurried away, and then the two players on the stadium court left their game and ran for shelter, too, as rain moved in suddenly and swiftly during the first quarterfinal match of the Family Circle Magazine Cup tennis tournament.

title: BORDEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Net income for the year-ago first quarter includes a net gain of $16,982,000, or 59 cents a share, in proceeds from settlement of a disputed contract with Texaco Inc.

title: LINDBERG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: HELPING IMMIGRANTS TO SHOP WISELY
description: ''We came empty-handed,'' said the slender 28-year-old man who had traveled more than 11,000 miles to begin a new life in New York City. ''We left everything we owned in Vietnam,'' Khai Minh Nguyen told his classmates in the English language and employment services project for adult refugees at the McBurney Branch of the Y.M.C.A. in Manhattan.

title: NETS LOSE, WILL MEET 76ERS IN PLAYOFFS
description: After playing nearly 7 minutes of brilliant basketball to erase a 15- point deficit in the final period against Atlanta, the Nets lost to the Hawks, 118-112, before 15,061 fans at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: WATSON IS GOING FOR IT
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.

title: Carter Hawley Move on Bid Seen
description: Directors of Carter Hawley Hale Stores will continue their special meeting today in Los Angeles to explore their response to the $30- a-share tender offer and proposed merger made by The Limited Inc.

title: THE RISK IN TUNISIA
description: The old man totters out of the hotel, propelled by a cluster of aides. They hoist him to their shoulders like a wax figure. His body is immobile, his cheeks the color of parchment.

title: SENATE ROLL-CALL ON TAX BILL
description: Following is the roll-call vote today by which the Senate approved legislation to raise taxes by $47 billion over three years. FOR TAX BILL - 76 Democrats - 33 Baucus, Mont.

title: Meese Inquiry to Get Material From Panel
description: A House subcommittee voted Thursday to give the special prosecutor investigating Edwin Meese 3d all materials relating to any role the Attorney General- designate might have had in documents from the Carter Administration that reached Ronald Reagan's 1980 Presidential campaign.

title: WHEELING PITTSBURGH STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MONDALE FAULTS HART RECORD ON WOMEN'S ISSUES
description: Walter F. Mondale today attacked President Reagan and Senator Gary Hart for their views on women's issues, saying Mr. Reagan had an ''abominable'' record while Mr. Hart's support was only ''nominal.''

title: FOR THE BLACKS IN FRANCE, A FAREWELL TO FRATERNITY
description: The days when Josephine Baker, the black American entertainer, was the toast of Parisian cafe society seem today like memories from another country.

title: Chicago Hospital Discharges Boy, 4, Saved From Drowning
description: A 4-year-old boy who was revived after being submerged in the icy waters of Lake Michigan for nearly 30 minutes last Jan. 2 was discharged from a Chicago hospital today.

title: PULTE HOME CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Louisiana Power Revenue Request
description: The Louisiana Power and Light Company, a unit of Middle South Utilities Inc., said it had filed for an increase of $315.5 million, or 27 percent, in its revenues from retail electric sales.

title: Banks Trying to Lure Last-Minute I.R.A.'s
description: As taxpayers race to meet the Monday income tax filing deadline, a number of banks in New York City and elsewhere are opening up their branch offices this weekend in hopes of luring more people to sign up for Individual Retirement Accounts.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST SATURDAY, APRIL 14, 1984
description: The Economy

title: AMERICAN MEDCARE CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-There are no comparable year- ago results because the company went public in June 1983.

title: DRESHER INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
STATE IS SLOW IN MAKING TAX REFUNDS BECAUSE OF BUDGET PROBLEMS
description: New York State tax refunds are being made at the slowest rate in seven years, because of inadequate budget appropriations.

title: KOCH CRITICIZED ON HIS PLAN TO USE HOSPITALS AS SHELTER
description: Mayor Koch's plan to shelter homeless New Yorkers in city hospitals could jeopardize the medical care of regular patients, two Borough Presidents charged yesterday.

title: WHEN STUDENTS GET LOST IN THEIR CLASS
description: To the Editor:

title: BANK OF VIRGINIA CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
INVENTORIES SHOW BIG 1.8% JUMP
description: Businesses increased their inventories by 1.8 percent in February, the biggest jump in almost 10 years, the Commerce Department reported today. Sales, meanwhile, fell four- tenths of 1 percent, the first decline since February 1983.

title: HOME HEALTH CARE OF AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NEW VENTURES FOR H & R BLOCK
description: When the Government started offering simpler and shorter tax forms in the 1970's, it boded nothing good for the people at H & R Block, the self-described ''tax people'' who specialize in filling out returns for taxpayers lost in the complexities of the law.

title: Breland Winner
description: Mark Breland of Brooklyn defeated Luciano Bruno of Italy, 5-0, tonight to win the 147-pound boxing title in the World Championship Challenge, a program of 12 matches pitting internationally acclaimed amateur fighters. In the 112-pound division, Steve McCrory, the United States amateur champion, was defeated by Pedro Reyes of Cuba when referee Carlos Castillo stopped the fight after McCrory had taken two standing 8 counts in the second round.

title: Staying Afloat
description: Although New York isn't usually associated with kayaking and canoeing, the state is well represented this week at the Olympic kayak and canoe trials in Lorton, Va.

title: ADAMS EXPRESS CO reports earnings for As of March 31
description: Assets figures represent net assets.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 19.

title: BROCKWAY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago results include a gain of $1.4 million from the settlement of anti-trust litigation.

title: OLD VIC HAILS GIELGUD'S 80-YEAR-RUN
description: The first words Sir John Gielgud ever spoke on the stage of the Old Vic, the cradle of so much British theatrical talent, were those of the Herald in ''Henry V'': ''Here is the number of the slaughtered French.'' That was in 1921; he was 17 years old.

title: STAGE 'LAUGHING STOCK'
description: Romulus Linney is a playwright with a rich, Faulknerian sense of humor. In the best tradition, he is a local colorist, taking regional characters and showing us how their lives are inextricably bound up with land, family and ancestral roots.

title: ON THE STRIDES PSYCHIATRY HAS MADE
description: To the Editor:

title: UDAG FUNDS ARE NOT FOR USE IN THE 'WAR ACROSS THE HUDSON'
description: To the Editor:

title: Iraq Reports Air Raids Against Iranian Forces
description: An Iraqi war communique said today that Iraqi jet fighters carried out 147 raids against Iranian forces and Iraqi helicopter gunships and combat units attacked Iranian positions along the border.

title: L.I. Utility to Raise Water Rates 5.9%
description: Water bills for about 70,000 families and businesses in the town of Hempstead in Nassau County will rise by 5.9 percent on April 23 because of a ruling by the State Public Service Commission.

title: Quick Repairs
description: There comes a time for all golfers - from duffers to touring professionals - when something goes wrong with their swing. They usually seek help from a friend or a professional at a golf club or driving range.

title: UNITED STATES BANCORP OF ARIZONA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SATURDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. Chicago White Sox, at Yankee Stadium, 3:20 P.M. With an unusual starting hour designed to accommodate network television, Tom Seaver pitches in New York for the first time since being claimed from the Mets in the compensation pool during the offseason. (Television - Channel 4, 3 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 3:15 P.M.) Mets vs. Cubs, at Chicago. Tim Leary tries to restore to the right track a pitching staff that was routed by the Cubs yesterday. (Television - SportsChannel, 3:15 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 3:15 P.M.)

title: SHUTTLE LANDS IN DESERT ON COAST, DIVERTED BY BAD WEATHER ON CAPE
description: The Challenger astronauts, diverted by bad weather from landing at their preferred site on Cape Canaveral, Fla., landed safely here today after a mission that deftly opened an era of servicing and repairing satellites as they orbit the earth.

title: EX-LEHMAN HEAD TO HELP SHEARSON
description: Peter G. Peterson, who was pushed aside last summer as chairman of Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc., confirmed yesterday that he would spend a ''very brief period'' as an unpaid consultant to Shearson/American Express Inc., which announced on Tuesday that it was buying Lehman.

title: VALLEY RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
4 Marines' Bodies Removed From Site of Crash in Hawaii
description: The bodies of four marines killed in the crash of a sightseeing plane were removed Thursday morning from the slopes of a dormant volcano as nearby Mauna Loa belched lava for the 19th day.

title: NEW STEEL UNION CHIEF: LYNN RUSSELL WILLIAMS
description: Almost all union presidents face difficulties these days, but the problems facing Lynn R. Williams, new president of the United Steelworkers of America, seem especially burdensome. The membership has fallen from 1.4 million in 1979 to less than 750,000 today; the union faces a major loss of dues revenues and has made substantial staff reductions. Its organizing staff is small and, for the most part, stays in the headquarters in Pittsburgh. The union was divided by the race for president between Mr. Williams, then acting president and secretary, and Frank McKee, the union treasurer.

title: Kaiser Steel to Sell Its Fontana Works
description: The Kaiser Steel Corporation said it had signed a letter of intent to sell its Fontana steel works to the Pacific Steel Corporation for more than $100 million.

title: JACKSON NATIONAL LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GF CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: LOWENSTEIN, M, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Stillman Berry of Stanford; Leading Breeder of Flowers
description: Dr. Stillman Berry, renowned breeder of flowers, collector of seashells and chief executive officer of Winecook Ranch Company for 67 years, died Monday, Stanford University officials have announced.

title: Barbara Hutton Story Finds a New Publisher
description: ''Poor Little Rich Girl: The Life and Legend of Barbara Hutton'' by C. David Heymann, a biography of the late Woolworth heiress that was removed from the market by Random House last December because of acknowledged inaccuracies and the threat of litigation, has found a new publisher. Lyle Stuart, president of Lyle Stuart Inc., said that he would bring out the book in October after it was ''cleaned up and corrected.''

title: HONG KONG'S PLIGHT ALTERS LOOK OF FLUSHING
description: Driven by the uncertainty over the political fate of Hong Kong, an increasing number of businessmen and professionals from the British colony have sunk new roots in New York City in the last two years.

title: THOUSANDS ASSAIL PARIS'S STEEL PLAN
description: Tens of thousands of steelworkers from the eastern province of Lorraine marched through Paris today to protest President Francois Mitterrand's plans to reorganize the state-owned steel industry.

title: Key Rates
description: Kenny Index, Kenny Information SystemsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: JACKSON COMPARES NICARAGUA ISSUE TO WATERGATE
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson today said that the Reagan Administration, in mining the harbors of Nicaragua, had created a crisis for the country that made ''Watergate look benign.''

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: FUTURE PAST

title: 33 Delegates at Stake In Arizona Caucuses
description: The three candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination campaigned in Arizona this week in a rushed bid to win some of the 33 national convention delegates at stake in the state party's caucus system that starts Saturday.

title: McGovern Says Jackson Is in Error on Muslim
description: George McGovern today praised the Rev. Jesse Jackson's campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination but said Mr. Jackson made a grievous error in not repudiating Louis Farrakhan, the Black Muslim leader supporting the candidate.

title: REAGAN WILL USE EMERGENCY POWER FOR SALVADOR AID
description: President Reagan invoked emergency authority today to give El Salvador up to $32 million in new military aid after Congress recessed without approving the money, Administration officials said.

title: COMPANY NEWS ; LTV and Republic To Report Losses
description: In the joint proxy statement filed for their proposed merger, the LTV Corporation and the Republic Steel Corporation said that, based on preliminary figures, each lost more than $30 million in the first quarter, an official with one of the companies disclosed yesterday.

title: FUTURES/OPTIONS ; Orange Juice Rebounds On Brazil Price News
description: Orange juice futures rebounded from heavy losses to post gains of up to 1 cent today on news that Brazil's export agency is considering raising the price of its orange juice concentrate.

title: BANKS WIN
description: To the Editor:

title: BAKER, FENTRESS & CO reports earnings for As of March 31
description: Asset figures represent net assets.

title: AMICOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $219,000 from an operation held for sale.

title: DATATRAK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
EARLY APRIL AUTO SALES UP BY 33.2%
description: Sales of new American-made automobiles jumped 33.2 percent in the first 10 days of April, the six major manufacturers reported today. The daily selling rate of 26,299 was the highest for any early-April period since 1979.

title: PEKING DENIES KEY AIDE QUIT
description: The Chinese Government today denied reports that Deng Liqun, the head of propaganda work for the Communist Party, had resigned.

title: Olympic Decision
description: Sam Bowie and Melvin Turpin , the Kentucky basketball stars, will pass up the Olympic tryouts next week.

title: No Headline
description: Bridge: Challenge of the Game Holds

title: DISMISSED LILCO WORKERS FACING A BEWILDERING 'VOYAGE INTO THE UNKNOWN'
description: Thomas J. O'Brien Jr. was four months short of reaching his 31st anniversary at the Long Island Lighting Company when his supervisor handed him a three-paragraph letter of dismissal last month.

title: LAZARE KAPLAN INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Net income.

title: BRIEFING
description: 3 Heroes' Kin Found

title: KIDNAPPED BABY IS RECOVERED
description: A baby girl who was kidnapped from a Queens hospital Wednesday night was returned to the hospital in good condition last night, a hospital spokesman said. An 18-year-old woman who had apparently taken the baby was arrested and charged with kidnapping.

title: VALID LOGIC SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $190,000.

title: Energy Reserves' Board Under Fire
description: Tilco Inc., a Tilsa, Okla., oil and gas company, became the second major holder in Energy Reserves Group Inc. to announce it is considering a proxy fight against the company in an effort to remove its board of directors. Tilco said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that it holds 4,063,723 common shares of Energy Reserves, or 8.27 percent of the total outstanding.

title: Twisters Hit Central Illinois
description: A series of tornadoes roared through several counties in central Illinois Thursday evening, flattening dozens of trees and damaging several homes and buildings. No serious injuries were reported. The twisters touched down south of Champaign in the towns of Toledo, Montrose and Newton, and at Loda in Iroquois County north of Champaign.

title: Schlichter Meeting
description: Art Schlichter , the Colt quarterback who was suspended indefinitely last year after he had amassed hundreds of thousands of dollars in gamblng losses, met with Commissioner Pete Rozelle yesterday but got no word on whether he would be allowed to play this fall. Schlichter, who has been under treatment for compulsive gambling, was told that a decision would be made later this spring. . . . Baseball Commissioner Bowie Kuhn is not expected to take part in a meeting with Pascual Perez on the Atlanta Brave pitcher's recent conviction for cocaine possession in the Dominican Republic.

title: SUSPECT IN ABDUCTIONS IS SHOT DEAD
description: Christopher Bernard Wilder, who was suspected of kidnapping and murdering several young women, was shot to death today in a scuffle with police near the Canadian border, the authorities said.

title: IVB FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including extraordinary gains of $167,000 for the latest first quarter and $508,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: CAPE'S FICKLE WEATHER DIVERTS SHUTTLE AGAIN
description: With today's aborting of a landing at the Kennedy Space Center, bad weather has now forced the cancellation of two out of three planned shuttle landings here.

title: CAIRO COURT REVERSES ORDER AGAINST AN OPPOSITION PAPER CAIRO, April 13 (AP) - Copies of an opposition newspaper that had been confiscated by the Government appeared on newsstands today after a civil court reversed the order.
description: Thursday's issue of Al Wafd, a weekly newspaper, had been impounded because of an article that the Government said violated restrictions on reporting about a Moslem fundamentalist group accused of assassinating President Anwar el-Sadat.

title: 3 Killed in Spain; Basques Are Suspected
description: Two masked gunmen shot to death a retired army officer outside a fruit market today, and two national policemen died when the gunmen's booby-trapped car exploded, the authorities said.

title: Sundance Talks
description: The Sundance Oil Company said it is holding talks with unidentified parties on the possible acquisition of Sundance. Caswell Silver, chairman and chief executive officer of the Denver- based concern, said that the essential aspects of the proposed deal had not been resolved and that there was no assurance that further discussions would lead to a definitive agreement. The company, which has about 10.8 million shares outstanding, said it had made the announcement in response to recent trading activity in its stock. Yesterday, it jumped $1.125, to $9.75, and was the third most active issue on the American Stock Exchange, after rising $1.125 on Thursday.

title: HOUSE UNIT SAYS REPORT ON MINES ARRIVED JAN. 31
description: The House Select Committee on Intelligence was informed about United States involvement in the mining of Nicaraguan ports in late January and it later monitored the operation closely, according to the committee's chairman.

title: UPJOHN CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NEWPORT PETROLEUMS INC reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
Chairman to Buy More GAF Stock
description: Samuel Heyman, chairman and chief executive officer of the GAF Corporation, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that he intends to acquire up to 15 percent of GAF's voting stock outstanding.

title: SENATE VOTES $47 BILLION TAX RISE TO HELP TRIM THE FEDERAL DEFICIT
description: The Senate, after four long days of debate, early this morning wearily approved a $47 billion tax increase that is its first step toward a $143 billion deficit reduction package.

title: The Paper Wall
description: Not since the days of Joseph McCarthy has the State Department shown such zeal in finding reasons to bar ''controversial'' visitors from the United States. In the case of Guillermo Ungo, the exiled Salvadoran leader, the department outdid itself.

title: CHECKPOINT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 25
Scouts Win Suit
description: The Greater New York Councils of Boy Scouts has won court approval to sell a 151-acre parcel of its 1,000-acre Alpine Scout Camp in northern Bergen County to a housing developer for $3.6 million.

title: RAY MIDDLETON, LEADING MAN IN MUSICALS FOR 30 YEARS, DIES
description: Ray Middleton, a leading man of the Broadway musical theater for three decades, died of a heart attack Tuesday in Panorama City, Calif. He was 77 years old.

title: MEDIUM IS THE HISTORY
description: We all sealed ourselves in a padded room to watch American history on television this week. Afterward grandmother said she was amazed to learn that George Washington had married such a short woman.

title: MARINE MIDLAND OFF
description: The First Chicago Corporation yesterday reported a 14.5 percent increase in its net income for the first quarter, while another large banking company, Marine Midland Banks of New York, announced a 3.4 percent decline.

title: REAGANS, ON $422,834 INCOME, SEEK $50,000 REFUND
description: President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, expect to receive a $50,000 refund check for overpaying Federal taxes on an income of $422,834, their tax returns showed today.

title: CANADIAN NATIONAL RAILWAYS CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $99,383,000. c-Net loss.

description: b-Net loss.

title: CYPRESS SAVINGS ASSOCIATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PRODUCER PRICES UP BY 0.5%
description: Producer prices rose five-tenths of 1 percent in March, the second-biggest jump in 16 months, as a huge increase in prices for fresh fish pushed overall food costs upward, the Government reported today.

title: JACKPOT ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
KAYDON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Year-ago share earnings not available as the company was a wholly owned unit of Bairnco Corp. It was spun off on April 5, 1984. Year-ago results are restated to reflect reorganization.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There's been some complaint that some other body was not keeping pace with what was happening.

title: AWARD FOR BENNY GOODMAN
description: At its annual dinner inthe Waldorf-

title: Refugee Center Operator Is Arrested in Texas
description: SAN BENITO, Tex., April 13 (UPI) Federal agents arrested the head of a church-sponsored refugee shelter today on charges of transporting illegal Salvadoran aliens, ending a two-day standoff between the government and the sanctuary worker.

title: NEW YORK SUBSTITUTE FOR A RED CARPET
description: To the Editor:

title: ISLANDERS WIN IN OVERTIME, 5-4
description: The feeling that this could be the end of something big for the Islanders - their string of four Stanley Cups - shifted suddenly tonight.

title: Doft Group Seeks Higher Logan Bid
description: Doft & Company, an investment banker, said it and various customers had made a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission indicating that they own 5.2 percent, or about 400,000 shares, of the common stock of Jonathan Logan Inc., an apparel maker. Doft said it had purchased the shares for risk arbitrage purposes.

title: DAY CITES LAW ROLE OF WOMEN
description: In 1873, when the United States Supreme Court ruled that Myra Bradwell was not Constitutionally entitled to practice law, Justice Joseph B. Bradley wrote what was to become for feminists a landmark opinion.

title: FLAMES DEFEAT OILERS, 6-5,IN OVERTIME
description: Carey Wilson scored his second goal of the game 3 minutes 42 seconds into overtime tonight to lift the Calgary Flames to a 6-5 victory over the Edmonton Oilers, squaring their Stanley Cup quarterfinal series at a game each.

title: Trade in Texas
description: In a trade involving wide receivers, the Dallas Cowboys traded Butch Johnson to the Houston Oilers for Mike Renfro. In addition, the Cowboys will trade second-round picks with Houston in the college draft next month and will get an undisclosed selection in the 1985 draft.

title: Jackson on Central America
description: On the Record

title: OLAF C. CHRISTIANSENNORTHFIELD, Minn., April 13 (AP) - Olaf C. Christiansen, a music composer and teacher who directed the well-known St. Olaf Choir, died Thursday in Northfield Hospital after a long illness. He was 83 years old.
description: Mr. Christiansen, who retired in 1968, expanded the a cappella choir tradition begun by his father, F. Melius Christiansen, also a composer and director. He also founded the Oberlin Conversatory a cappella choir in 1925 and co- founded the Christiansen Choral School, which was attended by more than 7,000 directors of music from throughout the United States.

title: Midshipman Excused From a Tower Jump
description: A 22-year-old midshipman who threatened court action after she was dismissed from the Naval Academy for refusing to jump off a 34-foot tower into a swimming pool has been reinstated, officials of the Academy say.

title: FEDERAL-MOGUL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $2 million.

title: TIGERS GO TO 8-0
description: The unbeaten Detroit Tigers scored eight runs in the first inning today and went on to their eighth victory in a 13-9 decision over the Red Sox.

title: Searle's Stock Drops Sharply
description: Shares of G. D. Searle & Company dropped sharply yesterday in heavy trading, apparently as a result of disappointing first-quarter earnings. The

title: BURRIS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
description: b-Net loss

title: Talks Set April 24 On Soviet Charges
description: The International Olympic Committee has called a special session between Soviet sports officials and Los Angeles Olympic organizers to discuss the Russians' complaints about preparations for the Games this summer.

title: STATE BORROWING A RECORD TOTAL OF $4.3 BILLION
description: New York State's annual spring borrowing reached record levels this year and could go even higher next year, state officials said today.

title: FIBRONICS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Year to March 31
Books of The Times
description: ENDERBY'S DARK LADY. By Anthony

title: PLANTERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
INDUSTRY OUTPUT UP 0.4% IN MARCH AS GROWTH LAGGED
description: The growth of industrial production slowed last month from the robust pace of the start of the year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 14.

title: PENNSYLVANIA REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Including gains on the sale of real estate of $8,000 for the quarter and $28,000 for the 6 months. c-Including a gain of $32,000 for the quarter and 6 months on the sale of real estate.

title: FRIES ENTERTAINMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
CORRECTION CORRECTION
description: A picture caption with an art review in Weekend yesterday misidentified the painter of ''Day Fishing at Heraklion.'' He is Malcolm Morley.

title: Prices Up in Britain
description: Retail prices in Britain rose three-tenths of 1 percent in March from February and were up 5.2 percent from March 1983, the Department of Employment said today. Analysts said the latest figures raised doubts on whether the Government could attain its aim of keeping inflation to 4.5 percent by the end of 1984.

title: SATURDAY, APRIL 14, 1984 International
description: Emergency authority was invoked by President Reagan to provide El Salvador with up to $32 million in new military assistance after Congress did not approve supplementary funds before going on its Easter recess, Administration officials said. Their announcement was preceded by contradictory reports. They said the President's action was an attempt to avoid an all-out confrontation with the House Democrats. The Democrats had offered a compromise of their own that the Administration appeared to accept only in part. (Page 1, Column 6.) The mining of Nicaraguan ports was monitored closely by the House Select Committee on Intelligence after the panel was notified in January that the United States was involved, according to the committee chairman, Representative Edward P. Boland, Democrat of Massachusetts. (1:5.)

title: SUSPECT IN SPYING CASE TELLS OF CHANGE IN PLEA
description: James Durwad Harper Jr., indicted on charges of selling missile research data to a Polish spy, said through his attorney today that he had reached a plea bargain and would plead guilty to one count.

title: FIRST TULSA BANCORPORATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: LEONARD KANTOR
description: Leonard Kantor, a New York playwright who wrote a number of dramas for television, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital.

title: 2 VERSIONS OF BILL COMPARED
description: The tax bill passed early today by the Senate differs in some ways from the tax bill passed by the House on Wednesday.

title: COMMON CAUSE: ENVIRONMENTALISTS AND INDUSTRY
description: Perhaps it is only springtime and cherry blossoms working their magic, but the environmentalists and the chemical industry, fierce combatants for years, are suddenly flirting with each other.

title: INVESTING RULE CLARIFIED FOR INSURANCE BROKERS
description: In a policy clarification, the New York State Department of Insurance said yesterday that New York funds held in a fiduciary capacity by insurance brokers, such as Marsh & McLennan, may not be placed anywhere but in bank investments.

title: NUCLEAR PHARMACY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Net income.

title: Korean Night at Museum
description: The Society for Asian Music will present Korean classical music and dance tomorrow at 2:30 P.M. in the Uris Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, at the Fifth Avenue at 81st Street entrance. Sang-Won Park will play the kayagum, a silk- string zither, and Won-Kyung Cho will perform traditional and classical dances. Tickets are $6; $3 for students and the elderly.

title: AMERICAN NATURAL RESOURCES CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split distributed May 1.

title: Swedes Enter U.S. Plea In Radar Sale to Soviet
description: A Swedish electronics company pleaded no contest today to charges of illegally selling an advanced radar system with important military applications to the Soviet Union in the late 1970's.

title: LIBEL RULING FOCUS OF PARLEY 20 YEARS LATER
description: Twenty years after a United States Supreme Court decision that reshaped the law of libel to protect vigorous public debate, 150 lawyers and journalists met today to celebrate its principles and trade tips on the more mundane business of winning libel suits.

title: ACTOR COULDN'T MAKE IT, 'UNEMPLOYED' MEHTA DID
description: Zubin Mehta found himself in an unaccustomed role Thursday night at the Abraham Goodman House, filling in for Tony Randall in the role of Robert Schumann and playing opposite his wife, Nancy, who played Clara Schumann.

title: HODGSON HOUSES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $161,000. c-Net loss.

title: BREARLEY MARKING 100 YEARS OF RIGOR AND INDEPENDENCE
description: When several students from the Brearley School, an all-girls school on the Upper East Side, went to Harvard University last fall to participate in a model United Nations session, they were amazed by what they saw.

title: Fund-Raiser Sued
description: The State Attorney General today accused a fund-raising company of illegally concealing i:s cut of donations intended for Child Find, which helps locate missing children.

title: SALVADOR MOVES EMBASSY IN ISRAEL TO JERUSALEM, JOINING COSTA RICA
description: El Salvador officially moved its embassy in Israel from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem today, joining Costa Rica, the only other country with an embassy here.

title: TAX GRIEF? BLAME IT ON NEW YORK
description: If you're about to lose your mind figuring out a way to pay your Federal income tax, I suggest you put the blame for your malady on the good ole State of New York. I'm serious. Had the Empire State not approved the 16th, or income tax, Amendment in 1911, it's doubtful that the annual Federal squeeze on your purse would ever have taken place.

title: INSURANCE FOR AUTOS IS RATED
description: HOW good is the service provided by automobile insurance companies? Do they settle claims promptly? The State Insurance Department recently ranked 63 insurance companies based on complaints filed by consumers, and says that service seems to be improving.

title: SIX CHARGED WITH MURDER IN DEATH OF DRIFTER ON TEXAS RANCH
description: Three members of a reclusive hill family have been indicted for murder in the death of a drifter who, the authorities say, was tortured and beaten for days while his screams and pleas for mercy were tape-recorded.

title: Nominee for Tax Court Post
description: President Reagan said today that he would nominate Joel Gerber, deputy chief counsel to the Internal Revenue Service, to be a judge of the United States Tax Court for a 15-year term.

title: Gold Is Sold
description: Ron Blanding, the Denver Gold's owner, has told his coaches and players that he has completed a deal to sell the franchise and that the official announcement will come as soon as the United States Football League approves.

title: Smaller Wheeling Loss
description: The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation today reported that it had narrowed its loss in the first quarter to $4.9 million, from $23.9 million a year earlier. Wheeling-Pittsburgh, the nation's eighth-largest steel producer, said sales increased 49.9 percent, to $258.9 million, from $172.7 million, as shipments jumped 76.9 percent, to 594,282 tons, from 335,975 tons.

title: British Pop Star Held Briefly
description: Jimmie Ruffin, a British pop music star, was arrested at the airport and jailed overnight after a loaded revolver was reported to have been found in his carry- on bag, an airport spokesman said today. The 47-year-old musician was released Thursday from the Wayne County Jail when prosecutors declined to issue a warrant after questioning him about whether he was aware he had the gun, according to a spokesman for the prosecutor's office.

title: COLONIAL BANCORP (WATERBURY, CONN) (O) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
COLLECTIVE FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss. There are no share earnings figures because the company went public on Feb. 7, 1984.

title: Letter: On Winter Cleanup A Low-Salt Diet for City Streets To the Editor:
description: I am writing in response to your Worm and the Apple article ''Street Bombs'' (March 30). While we take the ''bomb effects'' of our winter salting operations seriously, we have always been led to believe that the public thinks we are pickling their shoes or making brine apples!

title: NEW SCHOOL GETS WEST BERLIN GRANT
description: The City of West Berlin has donated $225,000 to the New School for Social Research to support a professorship in the school's University in Exile program, the school said yesterday.

title: MEXICAN OFFICIAL CONDEMNS MINING OF NICARAGUA'S PORTS
description: Mexico's Foreign Minister today denounced the mining of Nicaragua's ports as a violation of international law and called for ''the total elimination of all armed violence, direct or indirect, against Nicaragua.''

title: Payments Reported
description: Rob Williams , the Denver Nugget guard, said that when he was at the University of Houston, a local lawyer regularly gave him and other Houston players money. Williams made the disclosure after the lawyer, Jerry R. Bonney , had filed suit seeking repayment of $15,000 in loans he said he made to Williams in 1982.

title: HART, RETURNING TO WEST, TREADS FAMILIAR GROUND
description: The background has changed from wood-frame homes, lean pine trees and factory smokestacks to Spanish architecture, groves of succulents in bare, ragged mountains. And, as Senator Gary Hart has moved his Presidential campaign west, the sound track has changed, too.

title: ROLM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
Stock Tips Aren't Candy Bars
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has been highly active in pursuing illegal ''insider trading'' in the financial markets. In two years it has brought charges against 44 persons, one-third of all the cases brought in 35 years of policing corporate traders. The quickening pace may owe something to the recent vast expansion of trading, but it's due mainly to a decision to crack down on white-collar crime. For even greater effectiveness, the commission needs stiffer penalties.

title: DOME'S LOSS FOR 1983 IS $1.1 BILLION
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd. yesterday reported a loss of $1.1 billion (Canadian) for 1983, the largest loss in Canadian corporate history. Most of the loss was caused by an $896.9 million write-down of oil, natural gas and mining reserves.

title: TRIBUTE TO BASIL PATERSON
description: The event is billed simply as ''A

title: Vote Fraud Convictions Overturned by Judge
description: A Federal judge today overturned the vote fraud convictions of Maggie Bozeman and Julia Wilder, black women whose case inspired a 1982 voting rights protest that helped win extension of the Voting Rights Act of 1965.

title: STATE STREET BOSTON FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest quarter results include a gain on the disposition of options of $3,146,000, or 37 cents a share. The results for the year-earlier period include the estimated loss on the sale of subsidiaries of $2,458,000 and the per share and shares outstanding figures have been restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split distributed on May 18, 1983.

title: AMERICAN RESTAURANTS reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
description: b-Including extraordinary gains of $320,000 for the latest year and $17,000 for the previous year.

title: KOCH, WITH A QUIP, RELEASES '83 TAX RETURNS
description: ''It's a pain to pay, a pleasure to have had it,'' Mayor Koch said yesterday as he released his 1983 income-tax returns.

title: HECKLERS INTERRUPT REAGAN SPEECH AT GATHERING OF FUNDAMENTALISTS
description: President Reagan, addressing 10,000 fundamentalist Christians, was suddenly heckled tonight by a score of people shouting, ''Bread, not bombs!''

title: Female Sacrifice What a time to be a woman!
description: Presidential candidates beg for the honor of one's hand upon the voting lever. They trumpet their delight at the prospect of a female running mate. They promise a cabinet full of Madame Secretaries. Meanwhile the incumbent says he's put more females in high office than his predecessors did, and points proudly to the first woman on the Supreme Court.

title: WIEBOLDT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-After a charge to pension expense of $250,000 and a LIFO inventory provision of $450,000. c-Including a gain of $1,198,000 on the sale of real estate.

title: FIRST FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TEXAS SCHOOL BOARD TO VOTE ON CHANGING EVOLUTION RULE
description: The State Board of Education today agreed to take an emergency vote on whether to repeal its rule that schoolbooks may mention evolution only as one theory of the origin of humanity.

title: U.S. and Hondurans Hold Airborne Exercise
description: United States and Honduran soldiers, in the latest American exercise in Honduras, staged an airborne exercise today about 60 miles from the Nicaraguan border, the Pentagon announced.

title:
PATENTS;
Data and Speech Sent Together by Telephone
description: A technique that would allow computer data to be transmitted over telephone lines simultaneously with a two-way conversation has been patented for A.T.& T.'s Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, N.J.

title: LYE LEADS MASTERS BY 3 SHOTS ON 66-135
description: Mark Lye, a 31-year-old playing in his first Masters tournament, blasted out of a bunker into the second hole for an eagle 3 and went on to shoot a six- under-par 66 and take an unexpected three-stroke lead after two rounds at the Augusta National Golf Club.

title: NEWS OF HIJACKING DENIED TO ISRAELIS
description: Most Israelis knew nothing of the hijacking of a bus south of Tel Aviv on Thursday night until they awoke this morning and turned on the radio or picked up their newspapers.

title: MOBILE HOME INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net income.

title: LOW-POWER LICENSE GRANTED DIABLO NUCLEAR PLANT
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission today voted to allow test operations at the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant on the central California coast.

title: TOMLINSON OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $298,889 for the quarter and $593,737 for the 6 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $954,294 for the quarter and $378,479 for the 6 months.

title: TRIAL OF FEDERAL JUDGE ENDS WITH THE JURY DEADLOCKED
description: The bribery trial of Federal District Judge Harry E. Claiborne ended today when the jury declared that, after eight days of deliberation, it was unable to reach a verdict on any of the seven counts against the judge.

title: Two Party Leaders Sign Campaign Ethics Code
description: The heads of the Democratic and Republican parties signed a campaign ethics code today but the chairman of the Republican Party, Frank J. Farenkopf Jr., immediately charged the Democrats with a possible violation.

title: BELLWETHER EXPLORATION reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
CREST-FOAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29

U.S. JUDGE REQUIRES DESEGREGATION PLAN FOR LITTLE ROCK AREA LITTLE ROCK, Ark., April 13 (AP) - A Federal district judge today ordered the consolidation of the predominantly black Little Rock school district with two predominantly white neighboring districts in a major desegregation plan affecting 56,000 students.
description: Judge Henry Woods set hearings for April 30 to work out details of the plan, which could take effect in September.

title: FLORIDA NATIONALL BANKS OF FLORIDA INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $2,254,000 which was from a gain associated with divestiture of certain assets and settlement of litigation.

title:
PATENTS;
Way to Split Water Into Hydrogen, Oxygen
description: A method of splitting water into hydrogen and oxygen, using the tiny plants called green algae with the sun's rays as the energy source, has been patented for the Department of Energy.

title: 3 Die in South African Mine
description: Three black miners were killed, three were missing and seven were injured in a rock fall Thursday more than a mile underground at a gold mine near Johannesburg, officials said today. A rescue team was trying to reach the site of the accident.

title: SCREEN: A 'FRIDAY THE 13TH' SEQUEL
description: A promise is a promise, or at least it ought to be. But despite its title, ''Friday the 13th - The Final Chapter'' shows no signs of being the last in its none-too-illustrious line. By the end of the film, the vicious killer, Jason, has indeed been bested by a small boy who attacks him with a machete (''splitting his skull in two, lengthwise,'' as the production notes explain for the purist's benefit). The experience has such an unfortunate effect on the boy himself that at the film's end he appears all set to resume his machete work for ''Friday the 13th V.''

title: KNICKS WIN, PLAYOFF SPOT SET

title: SOME PRIZED POSSESSIONS
description: While poking around a flea market in Sheffield, Mass., one summer morning, George E. Schoellkopf spotted what he thought was an exceptional continuous-arm Windsor chair. All the signs were right. The arm and back, fashioned from one piece of wood, were graceful and well proportioned. The turnings were bold. Moreover, the fact that the seat was made of chestnut and carved to a wafer-thin edge led Schoellkopf to believe that this was the work of Ebenezer Tracy, an 18th-century furniture maker from Lisbon, Conn., whose beautifully designed and crafted Windsor chairs have been copied for well over two centuries. ''When I turned the piece over and saw his name stamped on the underside, my suspicions were confirmed,'' explains Schoellkopf, who is a New York City antiques dealer.

title: METRO-NORTH LEADER BRIEFS WESTCHESTER ON GAINS
description: The president of the Metro-North Commuter Railroad told Westchester County legislators here this week that the railroad was making improvements in service but still had ''a long way to go.''

title: U.S.F.L. ENVISIONS FALL SCHEDULE BEGINING IN 1987
description: The United States Football League intends to begin playing a fall schedule by 1987, putting it in direct competiton against the National Football League, according to two prominent U.S.F.L. executives.

title: THE SAROYAN MAGIC REMAINS POTENT
description: A weaselly figure in a grubby raincoat sneaks into a telegraph office, exuding shifty desperation. He pulls out a gun and orders the manager to hand over the ready cash, all of it. And is the result a surreptitious finger on the alarm button, followed by a shoot-out, blood on the shiny wooden floor, harrowing scenes in the emergency ward, and other such hard-nosed familiarity? Not at all. The manager makes it clear that he is more disappointed with the thief than impressed by his firepower. In fact, he reads him a little moral lecture about violence and World War II, which happens to be unfolding somewhere offstage at the time, and tells him he's more than welcome to any money he needs: ''Give it to your ma.'' The effect is more or less instantaneous. Within moments the loot is back in its cash box, and the revolver on a chair, abandoned forever. The men shake hands, and off goes the ex-robber, a weasel magically recycled into a white mouse.

title: ITALIAN RESTAURANTS: ENDLESS LIST
description: HUNDREDS of Italian restaurants of widely varying degrees of quality abound in New Jersey. From stylish dining rooms with topnotch kitchens that would compare favorably with those in Manhattan all the way down to glorified pizza parlors with little to recommend them besides their moderate prices, there is an Italian spot for every palate and purse.

title: A 3-YEAR LEARNING TRIP TOGETHER
description: LOUISVILLE AT the Samuel V. Noe Middle School here, ''teams'' of 150 children remain together for all three years, in the same classroom space and with the same group of teachers, a setting designed to guide them more effectively through early adolescence in the inner city. The attitude of Richard Tinsley, 13 years old, one of the students, is typical: ''I feel like I got brothers and sisters around,'' he said as he sat in class. ''It's like your family's here, too. It's 'cause you know people so well. They're real nice to me and I try to help them.''

title: Jean Helene Kaufman Marries a Geophysicist
description: Jean Helene Kaufman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Kaufman of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Benjamin Alter, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lee Alter of Oceanside, L.I. Rabbi Jack Stern Jr. performed the ceremony at the Westchester Reform Temple.

title: A NEW ALUMNI SPIRIT GROWS AT PUBLIC COLLEGES
description: BY the time Michal Turiel Winter finished registering for freshman courses at the State University of New York at Binghamton in the fall of 1977, she was a full-fledged alumna. After graduation she joined Binghamton's Metro New York Club and the Alumni Association.

Talbot will meet unseeded Tom Page of New York in today's final. Page beat Ned Edwards, also of New York, 15-12, 8-15, 15-9, 15-7.
