title: BOOK FAIR BARKERS
description: Edwin McDowell is publishing correspondent for The New York Times. Holding an annual children's book fair is a social and commercial ritual as hallowed in many elementary schools in the United States as the selling of cookies by Girl Scouts. After weeks of anticipation, youngsters are paraded into the school gymnasium or auditorium and allowed to browse among attractive displays of paperback books in collapsible metal racks and stalls. The children are encouraged to buy as many books as parental budgets will allow. While at some schools parents are invited to come and make purchases too, the book fair is largely an experience of independence and free choice for children.

title: FROM A PLACE, A MOOD
description: I am hardly ever witty, but not long ago I happened to sit in a chair that seemed to change my usual conversation. It was a settee - blue- gray silk tautly drawn over a frame of bird's-eye maple; the legs were inlaid with ebony and faceted. The chair recalled the elegance of the 1930's; my conversation took on shades, turned quickly and became, for the 20 minutes I was in it, repartee. It was not a deep reading chair; the seat was firm, the back, shallow, and its geometry positioned me so that I sat at its edge, toward my company. I felt at the point of myself. People laughed, and it was the laughter, I imagine, of the French salon: bright, thin, quick.

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
A PIONEER GALLERY SUMS UP 15 YEARS
description: T he Witkin Gallery is 15 years old this month. In the history of art, 15 years is not a long time, but it is more than one-tenth of the entire history of photography, and at age 15 the Witkin Gallery is the oldest art gallery in New York City - perhaps in the world - devoted primarily to photography.

title: STAYING FIT WHILE TRAVELING
description: NO TRAVELER SHOULD TAKE A vacation from exercise. Yet fitness plans often are left out of an itinerary. As a result, a voyager's homecoming may be heralded by added girth and a loss of conditioning. Surrendering one's shape is not an inevitable consequence of an extended business or pleasure trip, however. There are a multitude of fitness options to keep travelers in top form on the road, regardless of how they travel or where they stay. These include exercises one can do to boost circulation and reduce tension while confined to a plane seat; easy hotel-room workouts; swimming, running and walking at hotel fitness facilities or at fitness centers.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: PRAISESONG FOR THE WIDOW, by Paule Marshall. (Dutton/Obelisk, $6.95.) Paule Marshall's third novel ''rings with the same music and some of the same lilting Barbadian speech'' as ''Brown Girls, Brownstones,'' and our reviewer, Anne Tyler, admired its purposeful, knowledgeable progress toward its final realization. ''Convincing and eerily dreamlike,'' the story centers on Avey Johnson, a decorous, middle-aged black woman whose journey to her true self, a self revealed in ''breathtakingly vivid glimpses of her first years with her husband,'' is universal and astonishingly moving. THE VON BULOW AFFAIR, by William Wright. (Dell, $3.95.) On trial in 1982 for the attempted murder of his wealthy wife, Sunny, Claus von B"ulow, an aristocratic Dane, ''took on new life as a celebrity,'' as Dudley Clendinen remarked in his review; ''The jury found him guilty of a ghoulish crime . . . but the public found him fascinating.'' William Wright's perceptive, informative chronicle ''dispels the aura in which the very rich are veiled'' and ''gives back to Sunny von B"ulow a measure of the dignity that was stricken from her.''

title: A RURAL SCHOOL SERVING ITS NEIGHBORS
description: THIS south Georgia farming town (pop. 15,225) is a community of comfortable old homes, one traffic light and Brooks County High School. The school, which serves the entire county and is partly student- built, was recently refurbished to meet the needs of the surrounding community and includes some unusual vocational programs. For example, it runs the state's only state-certified community day-care center, which is perhaps the only one in the nation at a public school and operated largely by students. Also, the school's feeder-pig farm is probably the only one of its kind operated by high school students as a money-making venture. Carpentry and a program for nurse's aides also emphasize hands-on training.

Kaplan, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Kaplan of Manhasset, L.I. Justice Alfred M. Ascione of the New York State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the New York Athletic Club, assisted by Judge Guy Gilbert Ribaudo of the New York City Civil Court.

title: EVICTED TENANT GETS $135,107 DAMAGE AWARD

title: DAVID GUNN'S UNDERGROUND, FROM HIS NOTES
description: It may not provide much consolation to New York City's subway riders, but the man in charge is familiar with their problems. David L. Gunn arrived from Philadelphia two months ago to take over the Transit Authority, which operates the subways and buses. Mr. Gunn is now a daily user of the service he oversees, commuting by subway from his Brooklyn apartment to headquarters on Jay Street in downtown Brooklyn. He also rides the rails for most other business and personal trips around town. The Week in Review asked Mr. Gunn to record his thoughts and observations as he traveled about, acquainting himself with a system that he described last October as being ''in very serious trouble,'' and with the job he later characterized as ''a suicide mission.'' Excerpts from Mr. Gunn's diary follow. March 14

title: AN AFFLUENT SCHOOL WITH VALUE ADDED
description: RIDGEWOOD HIGH SCHOOL prides itself on academic richness, and over the years it has developed a reputation as being a cut above other upper-middle- class, suburban high schools in the New York area. Ridgewood is a community of about 25,000 people, mostly professionals, about 20 miles from New York City, and its high school is a symbol for them of its educational system. ''The parents here look for the best,'' said Paul Zitelli, head of the 18-member math department, ''and we try to give them the best. The expectations are high.''

title: Bargain Trips
description: To the Editor:

title: INDIAN AROMAS AT THE MALL
description: COMBINE handsome Indian decor with authentic ethnic cooking, add a soup,con of Indian music, the aroma of exotic spices, and presto, you have the recipe for an irrestible new restaurant.

title: Holly Taylor To
description: Mr. and Mrs. John C. Taylor 3d of Mamaroneck, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Anne Holliday Taylor to Laurence M. Bambino, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Bambino, also of Mamaroneck. The wedding is to be in June.

title:
ART;
MAKING PAINT SEEM FULL OF ENERGY
description: STIMULATING exhibitions can sometimes be found in library gallery spaces. Marion Maas's turbulent, gripping paintings (oils, acrylics and watercolors) currently fill the large, new exhibition area at the Manhasset Public Library and offer a fairly comprehensive view of her most recent efforts to create personal interpretations of landscape, interior and still- life themes.

title: A BLEND OF PARENTS AND TEACHERS
description: NEW ORLEANS AT Jean Gordon Elementary School in New Orleans, one of the three top-scoring schools of the city's 79 public elementary schools, the key to success is parent involvement, as well as highly competent teachers. ''Without a strong parent group,'' said the principal, 34-year-old Brian Riedlinger, ''you can have a good school but you can't have a great school, no matter how hard the teachers work.''

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
STATE COLLEGES MUST BE UNIFIED
description: PARENTS of New Jersey students planning to attend college face an almost 50 percent chance that their children will choose an out-of-state school, and the cost to those parents will, on the average, be two to three times that of four years at one of New Jersey's nine state colleges.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
THE MACARTHUR AORPORT DEBATE: IT'S A BOON TO MANY, BUT...
description: THE current controversy over the expansion of Long Island MacArthur Airport in Ronkonkoma is not an isolated case by any means. Small local airports throughout the tristate area are currently experiencing sudden and rapid growth as airlines seek out these underutilized facilities.

title: HIS JOB IS WRITING ABOUT PEOPLE'S JOS
description: WHAT'S the best city for job seekers? What's the minimum rate for a principal performer in a soap opera? How much does Playboy pay its Playmate of the Month? What's the salary range for corporate patent lawyers in Boston?

title: AUDIO FALLACIES RECEIVE THEIR JUST DESERTS
description: H owever quaint it may be, the trouble with folklore is that it often lends tenacity to falsehood. Belief in things that aren't so usually goes along with traditional assumptions, and nowhere more so than in audio. In this field, fallacy sprouts in all seasons, and this is as good a time as any to clear the thicket of dubious propositions. Proposition 1: Chrome tape causes more head wear in cassette recorders than ordinary ferric tape.

title: CHICKAMAUGA: GREEN PEACE
description: JERRY KLEIN is on the staff of The Peoria Journal Star in Illinois.

title: APRIL FEATURES TOSCANINI AND CHORAL PRESENTATIONS
description: A PRIL is Arturo Toscanini month in New Rochelle, as the Council on the Arts celebrates the 30th anniversary of the maestro's last concert with the NBC Symphony. Next week's music column will tell about the extraordinary reunion luncheon last Sunday at which nearly 100 former members of Toscanini's orchestras came together from every part of the country; meanwhile, don't miss the free exhibition at the New Rochelle Public Library that runs through the 27th. You will find photographs, letters from distinguished musicians, personal effects and other fascinating memorabilia of the man Winthrop Sargeant called, simply but eloquently, the world's greatest conductor.

CAMERA;

description: Peggy Sealfon is East Coast editor of Petersen's Photographic magazine.

description: A modern sculptor,with experience creating monumental works of art in metal, and an architect combined their talents to design and build a dramatic all-metal house that encompassed an artist's studio.

title: Kimball Wins in Diving
description: Greg Louganis turned in a poor final dive to hand Bruce Kimball the 10-meter platform title in the United States Indoor Diving Championships today. In the women's 10- meter final, Wendy Wyland was the winner.

title: THR N.L.R.B. HAS A NEW LINEUP AND LINE
description: Since becoming chairman of the National Labor Relations Board 13 months ago, Donald L. Dotson has been saying that workers and employers are in the same boat and have to learn to pull together. He has put his philosophy in practice by pushing the board to intervene less in labor-management disputes.

description: The last crank phones in the United States stopped ringing in Bryant Pond, Me., last Oct. 11 as the central switchboard in Elden Hathaway's home, manned by two operators in the living room, shut down.

A Universe of Yarns At Discount Prices

Everything is discounted 15 to 30 percent from suggested list prices, and winter clearances, specials and discontinued lines mean further markdowns.

title: SALVADORAN LEGISLATURE CHANGES VOTING SYSTEM FOR RUNOFF
description: El Salvador's legislative assembly voted Friday night to abolish the electoral registry for the May 6 presidential runoff election, but the Central Election Council said today it will ask President Alvaro Magana to veto the legislation.

title: EVACUATION PLAN ATTACKED
description: PLANS for the evacuation of the 55,000 schoolchildren within a 10-mile radius of Indian Point in event of a nuclear accident there are still far from workable, according to a petition sent to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission on April 6 by the New York Public Interest Research Group and seven local community organizations. The petitioners have asked the commission to suspend the operating licenses of Indian Point Units 2 and 3 ''until and unless'' the problems with the evacuation plan can be resolved.

title: BRAZILIANS TURN TO LYNCHINGS TO FIGHT SOARING CRIME RATE
description: Osvaldo Otavio Pires was brought handcuffed into Elio's Bar in the Jardim Guanhambu slum on the outskirts of Sao Paulo at about 8 A.M. on April 2. Over 100 men, women and children had gathered there to await his arrival.

title: Verbatim: Unhappy Bank Customers
description: ''There is a growing concern about the effects of (bank) deregulation. Complaints about the proliferation of fees, reduced services, delayed funds availability and generally a reduction in the sensitivity of banks and other depository institutions to their public responsibilities are inundating us.

Mrs. Lostab has a husband, two sons and a nephew who make their living at sea, and they consider the inlet in its present state to be a threat to the fishermen's lives.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
A GRANDUER THAT WAS ROME
description: CHAPPAQUA T HE invitation read: ''You will dine nicely at my house. First there will be lettuce, useful for fiber we all need, and shoots cut from their parent leeks, then tunny salted. Eggs will not be lacking, and a nice piece of smoked cheese with black, salty olives. These are enough to whet your appetite - do you want to hear the rest of the menu: Fish, mussels, sausages and plump birds from the poultry yard and the marsh.''

title: THE SAROYAN MAIC REMAINS POTENT
description: A weaselly figure in a grubby raincoat sneaks into a telegraph office, exuding shifty desperation. He pulls out a gun and orders the manager to hand over the ready cash, all of it. And is the result a surreptitious finger on the alarm button, followed by a shoot-out, blood on the shiny wooden floor, harrowing scenes in the emergency ward, and other such hard-nosed familiarity? Not at all. The manager makes it clear that he is more disappointed with the thief than impressed by his firepower. In fact, he reads him a little moral lecture about violence and World War II, which happens to be unfolding somewhere offstage at the time, and tells him he's more than welcome to any money he needs: ''Give it to your ma.'' The effect is more or less instantaneous. Within moments the loot is back in its cash box, and the revolver on a chair, abandoned forever. The men shake hands, and off goes the ex-robber, a weasel magically recycled into a white mouse.

title: AID TO UNEMPLOYED IN APPALACHIA AREA IS CONFERENCE GOAL
description: Many of Appalachia's unemployed, stripped of an industrial heritage forged by their parents and grandparents, are in danger of becoming ''a lost generation'' if new jobs are not created, participants have told a conference on unemployment here.

title: Incantation
description: You don't need to believe in witchcraft to know that the Cleveland Indians need all the help they can get. The club hasn't won an American League pennant since 1954, and according to local legend there is a very special reason - a curse laid on the team in 1958 by a disgruntled manager, Bobby Bragan.

title: SPACE SHUTTLE CONDITION CALLED 'REMARKABLE'
description: The $1 billion winged spaceship that returned Friday from a historic mission in space was pronounced in ''remarkable'' condition today after the rigors of a seven-day voyage outside the earth's atmosphere.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Pascual Perez , the Atlanta Braves pitcher, met with Harry Gibbs, the director of security for Commissioner Bowie Kuhn , but no word on any action Kuhn might take as a result of Perez's conviction on a cocaine possession charge in the Dominican Republic is expected until sometime this week. . . . John Castino, the Minnesota Twin infielder who has been sidelined for two weeks with lower back problems, was placed in a body cast that doctors hope will clear up his ailment within 10 days. . . . Nate (Tiny) Archibald , the Milwaukee Buck guard who has been sidelined with a pulled hamstring since March 8, will not be rejoining the team for the playoffs, Coach Don Nelson announced. . . . President Reagan has been chosen to receive the Collegiate Golf Foundation's Lifetime Achievement award. . . . The Texas Rangers have signed the designated hitter Larry Parrish to a two-year contract extension, with a third-year option, worth an estimated $800,000 a year through 1987. The club then has the option to sign Parrish for the 1988 season.

title: NEW CAREER LADDERS FOR TEACHERS
description: A FEW weeks ago, every teacher and principal in the 72,000-student Charlotte-Mecklenburg school system in North Carolina, one of the nation's largest, was asked by the superintendent to submit in a sealed envelope the names of the best instructors in his or her school. By early next month, 150 of the nominees will be chosen in a lottery to begin training next fall as ''master teachers'' under an ambitious plan to change the way teachers in the school system are rewarded.

title: Miss Budd Is Winner Of First Race as Briton
description: Zola Budd, the 17-year-old South African-born runner, won her first race as a British subject today with a time of 9 minutes 2.06 seconds for 3,000 meters, a clocking well inside the Olympic qualifying standard. But fresh doubts were raised over her desire to compete in the 1984 Olympic Games.

description: HARTFORD THE differing roles that partisan politics plays in the General Assembly was displayed last week as lawmakers began the final month of the current legislative session.

title: PUTTING EASTER DINNER LEFTOVERS TO USE
description: Once Easter Sunday dinner has been served, there will inevitably be ham and hard- boiled eggs consigned to the refrigerator. The ham is likely to have been baked and glazed so it can provide the basis for a hearty breakfast or for sandwiches. The eggs can become egg salad for quick lunches.

title:
DINING OUT;
CHINESE FARE FOR ARDSLEY
description: ONE would think that the county has had enough of restaurants serving Sichuan- Hunanese cuisine. We are frankly looking forward to a new wave of regional dishes, but until Mongolia's hot pot and barbecue, Canton's squabs and casseroles, or even authentic dim sum invade the county, we will continue to settle for some nicely made if now-too-familiar Sichuan- Hunanese dishes.

title: CRIME
description: Superintendent Simon Kenworthy returns in John Buxton Hilton's CORRIDORS OF GUILT (St. Martin's, $10.95), but this is not a Scotland Yard affair. The book is rather unusual and hard to describe. It has all of the elements of an espionage novel - except that it has no espionage. It concerns a plot against the state, a dead man, a woman who has been framed, malfeasance in high office and civil disorder. Politics enters into it also.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
CURBING STOCK PURCHASES IS NO ANSWER
description: ''GREENMAIL,'' a derisive term for corporate buybacks of targeted blocks of stock for a premium, is an unfair practice and an embarrassment to our corporate system. But is the recipient of the premiums the villain? Perhaps the significant minority shareholder is just a kind of Darwinian predator necessary to stimulate corporate vitality and productive use of assets.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: AT age 60, the Princeton architect/ educator Robert L. Geddes is the youngest educator to receive the ninth annual Award of Excellence in Architectural Education, given jointly by the American Institute of Architects and the Association of Collegiate Schools of Architecture.

title: CONNECITCUT WILL USE PLANES TO GET SPEEDERS
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill, citing a 40 percent increase in traffic fatalities this year, said Friday that the state police would begin using airplanes to spot speeders this summer.

title: AGE 12 AND BURNING WITH QUESTIONS
description: Ron Loewinsohn teaches English at the University of California, Berkeley. His most recent book is ''Magnetic Field(s),'' a novel. EDISTO

title: HEADLINERS
description: A Life Full of Death Henry Lee Lucas is one of the new breed of mass murderers, law enforcement officials say, the drifter who prowls the country in search of his victims. Mr. Lucas, who says he has killed up to 360 people, was sentenced to death last week for the rape and murder of an unidentified woman whose body was found along a Texas highway in 1979. He has already been convicted of two other Texas murders and faces at least 18 more indictments in five states. Mr. Lucas wanted to die, one of his defense attorneys said, because he wanted to go to heaven to join his 15-year-old common law wife, Frieda (Becky) Powell, whom he murdered in 1982.

title: Article 123897 -- No Title

title: THIS IS NO TIME TO SCRAP THE FAIRNESS DOCTRINE
description: * To the Editor: The Times editorial supporting Senator Packwood's ''Freedom of Expression Act'' fails to focus on the bill's truly harmful impact. In calling for near total deregulation of the airwaves, this bill would abolish existing obligations of broadcasters to ''afford reasonable opportunity for the discussion of conflicting views on issues of public importance.''

title: EASING 'PAYMENT SHOCK'
description: LMA BORROWERS in the metropolitan area who took out adjustable-rate mortgages last year at artificially low introductory rates now are facing the discomforting prospect of substantial rate rises.

title: BASKETBALL PLAYER DECIDES FUTURE
description: His height - 6 feet 9 inches - and his talent with a basketball thrust him into the spotlight whether he is playing on the court or simply walking along the halls of his school. The attention comes not only from fans but also from many colleges, each of which wants him to sign up with them and subsequently help them improve their basketball teams.

title:
Long Island Opinion;
SURE ENOUGH, IT'S SPRING
description: RAISED in a city apartment, I could appreciate the beauty of a flower when I saw one, but the name and character of particular species remained mysteries to me. One exception was the rose, the long-stem variety, which was delivered often to my front door by the neighborhood florist when my husband and I were courting.

title: GENIUS OR ECCENTRIC?
description: Truth against the world,'' was the motto of Frank Lloyd Wright's Welsh family, and the architect took it as his own. Wright was an individualist, in every sense of the word. His work was different from anything that had come before and he defended it with all the power of his being. In fact, Wright assumed that it was the natural order of things for us to conform to his buildings - not the other way around.

title: Katharine B. Sacks to Marry in August
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Robert S. Sacks of New Haven of the engagement of their daughter, Katharine Bird Sacks, to Joseph Charles Huether, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Paul Huether of Clifton, N.J.

title: Cerebral Palsy Aide Named
description: James E. Introne, who was Commissioner of the Office of Mental Retardation and Developmental Disabilities under Gov. Hugh L. Carey, has been appointed executive director of the Manhattan-based United Cerebral Palsy Associations, according to George S. Dolim, president of the organization. Mr. Introne will replace Earl H. Cunerd, who is retiring after 17 years in the position. Mr. Introne, 38 years old, will be responsible for the organization's 226 state and local affiliates across the country, which provide services for children and adults with cerebral palsy and other disabilities.

title: OLD NEWSPAPERS SOUGHT
description: NEW BRUNSWICK EVER since The New Jersey Gazette published its first issue in Burlington in 1770, New Jersey has seen the birth of 4,500 different newspapers.

title:
ELECTRONICS;
USER RAPPORT
description: Increasingly , the computer is becoming part of the home environment and the choice available is now so large as to be overwhelming. One of the problems, of course, is that, unlike a radio or a refrigerator, a computer is not a single-purpose instrument. It can be a filing system, a manipulator of symbols, an educator, a communicator and a recreational tool. In fact, it seems to generate new uses for itself as its functions increase. Although most computers are extremely versatile, some are better suited than others to certain tasks. Matching the computer to the job and the environment can be a challenge.

title: Miss O'Brien Is to Marry D. S. Moore
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert O'Brien of Westport, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Devon O'Brien to Daniel Sargent Moore, a son of Bishop Paul Moore Jr., Episcopal Bishop of New York, and late Jenny McKean Moore. The wedding is to take place in June.

title: PLAYING IT SAFE AT THE PAPERMILL
description: MILLBURN

title: September Wedding for Nathalie Dana
description: Nathalie Pepperrell Dana and John Lowell Thompson plan to be married Sept. 8, her mother, Nina M. Dana, of New York and Washington, Conn., has announced.

title: PRAISING ATTICS
description: Once upon a time, most houses had an attic - an unfinished open space under the roof, boiling in the summer and freezing in the winter, where household relics passed their last solitary days. Up in the attic were piled the broken furniture no one cared to mend, old sofas whose hospitality now extended only to mice, trunks of outdated clothes and memorabilia, towers of tattered magazines turning to yellow flakes on the splintery floorboards.

title: ALLEN'S WRANGLERS UNTYPICAL
description: Since 1966, with a few interruptions, George Allen has been bringing good football teams into the New York area to take on the Giants, the Jets or the Generals. Like his record everywhere else, Allen's success against the local clubs has been outstanding - seven victories in nine games.

title: Caroline Labiner To Marry in Fall
description: The engagement of Caroline S. Labiner, who expects to receive a master's degree in architecture in June from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, to Dr. Franklin G. Moser, a senior resident in radiology at the Mount Sinai Medical Center in New York, has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Gerald Wilke Labiner of Holmby Hills and Malibu, Calif., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander S. Moser of New York and Loon Lake, N.Y.

title: MY VENICE: A CITY REPAYS A LIFETIME OF VISITS
description: What can the harried tourists with aching feet, who spend only a few hectic days in Venice, absorb of the subtle intoxications of Venetian life? By necessity, they rush along behind the guide who holds aloft a discreet colored umbrella (the old banners and placards are out). They go from one landmark to the next, each of which is so famous it has been described in hundreds of books and each of which deserves hours of quiet contemplation.

title: The Right Rules for Cable
description: With the hyperbole now common in discussions of cable TV regulation, New York's franchise director calls it ''a vicious'' bill. He refers to a proposed Federal law that tries to strike a balance between chaotic local regulation and commercial freedom for the new medium. Though the legislation could be improved, the urban alarm seems unwarranted.

title: CREATING MAZES FOR FUN AND PROFIT
description: -agers scramble to line up summer jobs this month, Bela Selendy of Cornwall can sit back and smile.

title: AWARDS GALORE FOR A YOUNG COMMPOSER
description: THERE is nothing that Ronald Caltabiano would like better than to be left alone to compose his music. He speaks of the possibility of the solitary devotion to his art with a sort of wistful longing, in light of the manifold financial pressures that confront most composers of today.

title: A FEAST FOR EASTER
description: Easter was, in the beginning, a spring festival, named after the dawn goddess Eostre, a time to celebrate the rebirth of nature. I have never been able to determine at what point, in what era, Easter and a baked ham were first associated. But the custom remains, and it is a good one. To the best of my knowledge, the custom is strictly an American one.

title: Tammy Payne Married to Robert Dennis Feeley
description: Mary Tammis Payne, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Payne of Larchmont, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Robert Dennis Feeley, a son of Mrs. Joseph J. Feeley of Bellerose, Queens, and the late Mr. Feeley. The Rev. William V. Reynolds performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Augustine.

title: CENSUS BUREAU PICKS JERSEY CITY FOR A TEST OF NEW TECHNIQUES(AP) - The Census Bureau will conduct a test census next year in this Hudson County community to try out new counting techniques that might be used in the 1990 national census.
description: William Hill, a spokesman in the bureau's New York regional office, said the agency would hire several hundred residents to assist in the test. The agency plans to open an office here in the fall.

title: A LAVISH BECKETT PORTFOLIO REVIVES A FAMILY TRADITION
description: Mel Gussow is a drama critic for The New York Times.

title: Dianaed
description: Richard Sears Humphrey Jr. of Beverly, Mass., and Mrs. J. Downey Humphrey of Chestnut Hill, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Diana Emmons Humphrey to Hugh James Halsey, a son of Charles Day Halsey Jr. and Sandra MacRae Halsey, both of New York. The wedding is to be June 23.

title: U.S. WORLD COURT MOVE DEPLORED
description: A member of a panel of international lawyers said today that, by rejecting World Court jurisdiction in the dispute over the mining of Nicaragua's harbors, the United States ''created the impression we are trying to turn the rule of law into a one-way street.''

title: HOW I LEARNED ABOUT AMERICA - AND AFRICA - IN TEXAS
description: J. M. Coetzee, the South African novelist who wrote ''Waiting for the Barbarians'' and ''Life and Times of Michael K.,'' is teaching at the State University of New York at Buffalo this semester. In September 1965 (this is an essay that can begin in no other way), I sailed into New York harbor aboard an Italian ship, once a troopship, now crammed with young folk from foreign parts come to study in America. I came, immediately, from England; at the age of 25, I was heading for Austin, where the University of Texas was to support me to the tune of $2,100 a year for teaching freshman English while I studied in the graduate program.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINNION;
BLUEBONNETS AND MEMORIES
description: WILDFLOWER picking is a springtime ritual and, where I grew up, Holy Saturday was its day of enactment. Like the Columbus Day brilliance of fall foliage in the Northeast, Easter weekend, no matter when it falls, is the height of color in South Texas. A virtual sea of bluebonnets, broken only by intermittent patches of Indian pinks, extends from one horizon to the other.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
DEFENSE COSTS: HOW MUCH IS ENOUGH?
description: AS Congress reviews the new defense budget, a perennial question arises: How much is enough? The question is all the more urgent at a time when budget deficits in the hundreds of billions are weakening our economy.

title: PERSONAL EXPRESSIONS
description: The climate of interior design is right today for the individualist. There is no one dominant style of decorating and this leaves almost all options open, whether it is indulging a yen for designs of the 50's or living in a house constructed entirely of steel and aluminum.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: THERE is an ''Upstairs, Downstairs'' at Lyndhurst, the American Gothic Revival mansion on the Hudson River, and this year, for the first time, the downstairs staff will be featured along with the family of the house.

title: A RETURN TO RELIGION
description: Fran Schumer is a writer who lives in New York. THERE IS NOT A seat left in Prof. Harvey R. Cox's classroom at Harvard College. Students are sitting on the floor, straining to hear the words of today's lecture on Jesus and the Parables.

title: MAYOR LOSES BID FOR PISTOL PERMIT
description: PASSAIC AN APPLICATION by Mayor Joseph Lipari for a permit to carry a handgun has been turned down, prompting something of a debate in this city of 55,000 people.

title: OPERA COMPANY PLANS DOUBLE BILL BY MINOTTI
description: The Washington Opera has announced that it will perform two Gian Carlo Menotti operas, ''The Telephone'' and ''The Medium,'' at the Edinburgh Festival this summer.

title: Shanghai
description: To the Editor:

title: SCHOOLS NEW FOCUS IN YONKERS TUG OF WAR
description: STATE officials, including Governor Cuomo, held firm last week to their insistence on an emergency financial control board for this financially hard-pressed city, while the city struggled to avoid one.

title: HEADLINERS
description: African Cardinal Promoted Pope John Paul II announced several unexpected changes in the hierarchy of the Roman Catholic Church last week, not the least of which was the appointment of an African cardinal to the second most powerful administrative post in the church. Bernardin Cardinal Gantin of Benin, on the West African coast, was named Prefect of the Congregation for the Bishops, which directs the appointments and activities of most of the world's archbishops and bishops.

title: PHILADELPHIANS SPLIT ON CURBING BUILDING HEIGHT
description: The issue, as many Philadelphians put it, is William Penn's hat, and around it swirls a swelling controversy.

title: Dallas Minorities in Majority
description: Minority groups became the majority in Dallas as the city's white population fell to 49 percent in 1983 from 51.9 percent in 1980, according to a report issued Thursday by city officials. The Department of Planning and Development estimated that by 1990, 58.7 of the city's people would be members of minority groups and 41.3 percent would be whites. In 1960, figures of the United States Bureau of the Census showed that the city was more than 75 percent white.

title: HER LAST THREE YEARS AT THE MOVIES
description: Gerald Mast teaches film history and theory at the University of Chicago. His latest books are ''Film/ Cinema/Movie'' and ''Howard Hawks, Storyteller.'' TAKING IT ALL IN

title: PUZZLED YANKEES RAINED OUT
description: Yogi Berra doesn't even pretend to understand. ''If I knew why we were getting behind so early, I'd tell you,'' the Yankee manager said yesterday before the game with Chicago was rained out at Yankee Stadium. ''The starters looked good in spring training. I thought our problem was the bullpen.''

title: SHARON PLAYHOUSE MAKES A RECOVERY
description: '' ONLY eternal optimists can be theater people,'' said Nelson Slater. Mr. Slater should know. He is president of the Sharon Creative Arts Foundation, a community arts group that operates the Sharon Playhouse, a 388-seat country theater just west of the village green in that handsome northwestern Connecticut town.

title: THE REGION;
description: Holes in Streets And Flare-Ups Over Methods

title: GROCERY DELIVERY SERVICE
description: Many residents of the Garth Road section of Eastchester were seriously inconvenienced by the closing in early February of the neighborhood's only supermarket, C-Town, which had been a fixture on the block for many years.

title: THE ACTION GOES ON
description: Those who have been ousted from the candidates matches to determine a challenger for the world championship, and those who did not make it into these matches need not sit idly by. Action on the tournament circuit goes on unimpeded everywhere.

title: WHERE TO HEAR EASTER'S SOUNDS
description: Churches around the county have assembled a bountiful array of Easter holiday music to be presented beginning today and continuing on Maundy Thursday, Good Friday and during Saturday evening vigil services, as well as Easter Sunday morning.

title: RARE ANTHEMS OF EASTER SEASON
description: CHURCHES around the state have assembled a bountiful array of Easter music to be performed today, Maundy Thursday, Good Friday, during vigil services Saturday evening and on Easter Sunday.

title: Bucks Take Title by 104-92
description: Junior Bridgeman scored 29 points to lead the Milwaukee Bucks to the Central Division title with a 104-92 victory over the Indiana Pacers in a National Basketball Association game tonight.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Some passages from current and recently published books that we find particularly appealing.

title: STRAIGHTENING 'STRAITS'
description: ''We will use whatever means is required,'' said President Jimmy Carter in 1980, ''to keep the Straits of Hormuz open.''

title: International
description: El Salvador's emergency arms aid was ordered by President Reagan because ''we cannot turn our backs on this crisis at our doorstep,'' the President said in his first public comments since the furor in Congress in recent days over the Administration's policies in El Salvador and Nicaragua. (Page 1, Column 6.) A crime wave in Brazil has brought about frequent street executions of muggers and thieves by residents, particularly the slum dwellers in Rio de Janeiro and Sao Paulo. Lacking adequate police protection, different sectors of society are increasingly improvising their own, somtimes violent, responses to crime. (1:5.)

title: HUNTERS BAGGED 167,449 DEER IN STATE IN 1983
description: New York State hunters killed 167,449 deer and 550 black bears during the 1983 hunting season, according to the State Department of Environmental Conservation.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: A limousine moved across Manhattan the other night, and the trees of Central Park were in dark silhouette against the bright lights of Central Park West.

title: THE EYES OF TEXAS ON STAR STUDENTS
description: ENERGETIC recruiting battles for high school talents are nothing new at Texas colleges and universities. So when Lane Stephenson, a spokesman for Texas A. & M., talks about the recruiting wars with the University of Texas, the words sound familiar.

description: To the Editor:

title: DRIVE TO SIGN UP POOR FOR VOTING MEETS RESISTANCE
description: Voter registration drives aimed at poor people who receive Government benefits have encountered opposition in many states from officials who contend that the efforts favor the Democratic Party and disrupt the work of local social service agencies.

title: GETTING THE BREAKS TO GO ON-LINE
description: MATTHEW L. WALD

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: The new work of Joel-Peter Witkin, on view at Pace/MacGill Gallery, 11 East 57th Street through Saturday, consists of grotesque versions of well-known subjects from the Scriptures and classical mythology, subjects such as the expulsion of Adam and Eve from the Garden of Eden, Venus with a Flute Player and the Crucifixion. The emotional tone is bitter, sardonic, often gruesome, and the show is not recommended for the queasy or the young.

title: LIVING WITH KEEPSAKES
description: A fashion designer makes a formula postwar apartment a very personal and original home by focusing interest on her varied, colorful and highly individual collection of art, artifacts and books acquired over a lifetime of trips to foreign places. And, despite their diverse origins, her collections live comfortably alongside each other.

title: MET OPERA: MOZART'S 'SERAIL'
description: Three artists who were not in the first Metropolitan Opera presentation of Mozart's ''Entf"uhrung aus dem Serail'' this season had joined the cast by Thursday evening's performance.

title: CITY PANEL NEAR VOTE ON SAVE-THE-THEATERS PROPOSALS
description: MARTIN GOTTLIEB

title: DE LA MADRID FACES A TOUGHER AUDIENCE
description: Still basking in a warm reception from his southern neighbors, President Miguel de la Madrid Hurtado of Mexico is now preparing for a chillier reception from President Reagan up north. Their meeting, scheduled for May 15, will test how much weight Washington gives to the pledges of support Mexico's President received during his Latin American trip.

title: U.S. ATTORNEY IN MANHATTAN SETS UP ANTICORRUPTION UNIT
description: A special unit to combat corruption has been formed by the United States Attorney's office in Manhattan.

title: Robin Bernstein, Lawyer, Weds Harry Klagsbrun
description: Robin Andrea Bernstein, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alex Bernstein of the Riverdale section of the Bronx, was married yesterday to Harry Klagsbrun, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Klagsbrun of Stockholm. Rabbi Shlomo Balter performed the ceremony at the Conservative Synagogue Adath Israel in Riverdale.

title: NEW BOY ON CAMPUS: MEN'S STUDIES
description: LOS ANGELES IN the early 1970's the women's movement dipped its toe into the academic

title: A FIRMER RESPONSE TO FAMILY STRIFE
description: It can start with a few cross words, but all too often a quarrel between members of a family escalates into violence. Called to the scene by a distraught neighbor or child, police officers can find themselves caught up in the confrontation, risking life and limb trying to defuse an angry household with calm talk.

title: If Not Mines, What?
description: Credit William Casey and his C.I.A. wizards with a grand slam in slipping those mines into Nicaragua's harbors. In a stroke, they managed to enrage and confuse Republicans and Democrats at home, allies and adversaries abroad. And they let Nicaragua's Sandinistas robe themselves in the vestments of international law. Congress's lopsided protest should teach a lesson in law and history to an Administration disdainful of both. But the vote only closes a lesser argument over means without advancing the necessary debate about the ends of Central American policy.

title: Police Tear-Gas Attack Ends Standoff in Norfolk
description: Police officers throwing tear gas opened fire on a gunman trying to escape from a house he was using for cover early today in an eight-hour standoff that also included the fatal shootings of an officer and a bystander.

title: CALL OUT RESERVES
description: IF the Battle of Waterloo was

title: REQUIRED RECYCLING WEIGHED
description: TRENTON FACED with the prospect of New Jersey running out of room for garbage, the state's Department of Environmental Protection is considering, for the first time, statewide mandatory recycling - requiring households and businesses to separate metals, glass, paper and plastics prior to collection or shipment to landfills.

title: Yanks Seek Study Of Armstrong Deal
description: Without filing a formal grievance, the Yankees have asked Commissioner Bowie Kuhn to intervene in a dispute with the Kansas City Royals and help determine whether Mike Armstrong was ''damaged goods'' at the time of his trade.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE ;
 'SKY DAY'
description: Taking art out of the studio generally is no big deal, but when the art happens to be kites and inflatables that students in the C. W. Post Center's School of the Arts have been creating all year long, the public exposure takes on a special festive air. And this is happening on the Brookville campus today, when from 10 A.M. to 8 P.M. the art students stage a ''Sky Day.'' In addition to testing their original kites, model airplanes and hot-air balloons, the high-flying students will offer a neon sky show, complete with electronic music, and then move indoors for lectures, films and displays dealing with how the creative arts relate to man's desire to soar. All the activities, throughout the campus, off Northern Boulevard, are free. ON WHEELS

title: THE HIDDEN REASON FOR TEACHER SHORTAGE
description: THE explanations offered for the apparent decline in the scholastic caliber of students planning to be teachers have been less than candid because they disregard the issue of gender.

title: RECITAL: A PROGRAM OF ART SONGS
description: Given the favorable critical comment Berenice Bramson's previous New York recitals have generated, it is scarcely surprising that her interpretations of art songs at Goodman House on Tuesday night again gave cause for rejoicing.

title: NEW PRESSURE IN INVESTMENT BANKING
description: ATTENTION on Wall Street this week

title: PARENTS' MOPS AND PAINT SAVE NEWARK SCHOOL
description: NEWARK FRANKLIN SCHOOL ''literally rose out of the ashes,'' said Charles P. Mitchell, who took over as principal of the elementary school here in 1976 after a fire set by neighborhood youths caused $300,000 in damage. ''After the fire,'' he said, ''the building was in shambles and the outside had so much graffiti it looked like a New York City subway train. There was low teacher and student morale, a lot of discipline problems, and lots of parent apathy and parent outrage.'' But with strong community support that he was able to mobilize, the school now thrives amid its grim surroundings.

title: BOOKSHELF Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest: AIRPLANE RIDE. Written and illustrated by Douglas Florian. Unpaged. T.Y. Crowell. $10.95. (Ages 3 to 6) An exuberant pilot and his sturdy biplane set off for adventure and look down at busy cities, peaceful countrysides and wide open spaces.

title: ...AND WHAT ECONOMISTS THINK OF THEM
description: -term objective should be to broaden the individual income tax base so that the present inequities and distortions will be removed, and at the same time to lower the tax rates. Something like the Bradley-Gephardt bill would be a good start. There are a considerable number of tax breaks that could be removed right away; over the long pull, there's enough there to provide revenue to balance the budget by the end of this decade, presumably with some spending cuts. Hart, Mondale and Reagan are all talking about the same thing; my guess is that they are different on the degree of progressivity. The President is probably more interested in a flatter rate schedule; a flatter rate is much less progressive.

title: SCRUTINIZING THE WETLANDS
description: AS part of its job in processing applications to build in or near tidal wetlands, the State Department of Environmental Conservation must review environmental impact statements for projects expected to have a significant effect on the environment.

title: U.S. Charity Rules Offered
description: Federal employees would be permitted to earmark donations made through the Combined Federal Campaign for the charities of their choice under a proposal by the Office of Personnel Management. The proposal made Friday would halt use of a national eligibility list for the fund, which last year raised $110 million under a program similar to the United Way.

description: About 100 seventh-grade students from public schools here have been selected to participate in an after-school program designed to help teen-agers from minority groups gain admittance to some of the top preparatory schools in the country.

title: AFTER LATINO BOOM, THE LONG PULL AHEAD
description: ''WHEN I say I'm majoring in Puerto Rican studies,'' said Debbie Acosta, a junior at Hunter College, ''graduate- school admissions officers always ask me, 'What are you going to be when you grow up? A Puerto Rican?' ''

title: JAZZ: BENNY CARTER IN QUARTET
description: Benny Carter, making what has become a slightly more than annual visit to Sweet Basil, is very obviously enjoying himself playing in a quartet that will be there through tonight. Mr. Carter is playing trumpet as well as his customary alto saxophone on this trip and, at the age of 76, his playing still retains the impeccable projection and imaginative flair that have been his hallmarks for more than 50 years.

title: SUNDAY OBSERVER ; The Disposable Idea
description: When the 30-year-old masses became inflamed by Gary Hart's ''new ideas'' campaign, I was suddenly overwhelmed with sadness. Partly, I suppose, this was brought on by discovery that the country would soon be run by the people I used to spank.

description: A PROPOSAL by Representative Thomas J. Downey that would broaden the acquisition powers of the Federal Government in private communities on Fire Island is earning mixed reviews.

title: Shekel vs. Dollar

title: INVENTIVE TRADITION
description: If you were to ask almost anyone, even a child, to make a picture of a typical American house, the chances are that he would draw a more or less square, two-story house, with a front door in the center flanked by a couple of windows on either side, and with a steeply pitched roof and a chimney at one end, or possibly with one in the middle,'' wrote Russell Lynes in his 1957 book, ''The Domesticated Americans.'' ''He would, in other words, draw something like a Cape Cod cottage . . . .''

title: ATLANTIC CITY: GETTING AFFORDABLE HOUSING
description: ATLANTIC CITY'S onstage glitter and gaming-room glamour tend to obscure the reasons behind allowing casino gambling there in the first place.

title: A GROWING INTEREST IN PUBLIC AFFAIRS
description: WHEN Yala Fischer retired from her job as executive assistant to the president of a major manufacturing concern in Manhattan, she wasn't sure what to do with the glut of free time. ''I was looking for something I thought would interest me, and help me keep up with events,'' she recalled. ''I don't have a college degree, and any courses I'd taken were strictly for my job.''

title: DR. CARTER UNLIKELY FOR DERBY
description: Dr. Carter, the gray colt who has been among the early favorites for the May 5 Kentucky Derby, has been stricken with a viral infection that has knocked him out of the Blue Grass Stakes and will almost definitely prevent him from running in the Derby.

title: EASTER MUSIC
description: EASTER MUSIC BRIDGEPORT - United Congregational Church, 877 Park Ave. Paul Knox, music director. 10:30 A.M. today: Procession of Palms with choirs, hand bells, tower bells, recorders, Orff Instruments, organ. Schubert's ''Benedictus'' and ''Osanna,'' ''Lenten Carol'' by Darst. 8 P.M. Thursday: chorales from Bach's ''St. Matthew Passion,'' Moravian anthem: ''Speak to Me of Christ's Sorrow.'' 10 A.M. Easter Sunday: ''Entrata Festiva'' by Peeters, tower bells, hand bells, harp and organ. ''Carols for Easter for Choir and Harp'' by Williams, ''Christ Our Passover'' by MacFarlane, ''Hallelujah'' from Handel's ''Messiah.'' Quartet, harp and organ. Golden Hill United Methodist Church, Golden Hill St. Dorothy Partridge, music director. 7:30 P.M. Thursday: Sonata No. 6 by Frederick the Great, Sonata in G major by Telemann, ''Melody'' by Gluck. Janet Weaver, flutist; choir and organ. Noon Friday: combined adult and youth choirs of Council of Churches in Greater Bridgeport, excerpts from Handel's ''Messiah,'' works by Tertius Noble. Edith Coles, soprano. 10:30 A.M. Easter Sunday: music by Davis, MacFarlane, Handel. DANBURY - St. James Episcopal Church, 25 West St. Susan Randall, music director. 9 A.M. today: procession from City Hall to the church with trumpets. 7:30 P.M. Thursday: music by Bach, Friedell, Walther. Noon Friday, music of Handel, Mozart, DuBois, Faure. Linda Holland, soprano. 7, 9:15 and 11 A.M. Easter Sunday: Music by Clarke, Willan, Ley, Handel and Widor with choir, soprano soloist, organ, trumpet.

title: NEW LOOK AT EFFECTIVE SHOOLS
description: THE physical plant at Public School 39 in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn leaves a great deal to be desired. Paint is peeling from the windows of the 107-year-old building, and a scaffold and wire screen have been erected outside to protect pupils from wood falling off the facade. The gymnasium is a made-over classroom with a chinning bar on the wall and a portable basketball hoop, and many of the teaching areas, arranged in rows like a railroad apartment, hold two classes. ''We don't even have the luxury of hallways to teach in,'' said Myron Yermak, the principal.

ANTIQUES;

title: THE NATION ; Fever Lines
description: Seasonal adjusting seemed in order for some of last week's batch of economic indicators. A surprisingly sharp 2.2 percent drop in February's retail sales was due, Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said, to the combination of bad weather and an unsustainably high level of sales in January, while a rise in wholesale prices of 0.5 percent in March, the second biggest jump in 16 months, was mostly the result of an extraordinary 30 percent increase in the price of fish.

description: Two doctors have told Congress they failed to pay back Federal grants for their education and shirked their vow to work in areas short of physicians because of rules they believed were unfair and rigid.

APPEALS BAN ANGERS PINELANDS TOWNS;
Last of three articles

title: Vietnamese Due in Falklands
description: Officials close to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees said today that seven Vietnamese refugees in Britain would be resettled in the Falkland Islands. In London, Adrian Monk, a spokesman for the Falkland Islands Government, said the Vietnamese were related to the wife of a Briton who is already in the Falklands.

title: Eleanor Piel, E. J. Perper Plan to Wed
description: Eleanor Jackson Piel and Edward Jehuda Perper, Harvard Medical School students, plan to be married in June.

title: GRENADA'S FIRST PREMIER TO RUN IN NEW VOTE
description: Grenada's first Prime Minister, who took office while the Caribbean island was still under British rule, says he plans to run for the office again in the next elections.

title: A CARELESS TOOTH FAIRY GUMS UP THE JOB IN THE NIGHT
description: M Y friend Malcolm had a powerful urge to convince his school-age daughter that there was indeed a tooth fairy. The urge was rooted somewhere deep in the father- daughter bond, but beyond that Malcolm was at a loss to explain his mission.

title: RAILROAD TO THE POCONOS IS A CLIFFHANGER
description: STROUDSBURG, PA.

title: CHICAGO RESIDENTS DON'T MISS SECOND CITY STATUS
description: It landed more like an egg than a bombshell, the news that Chicago, the nation's second city since 1890, had been bumped to third place by Los Angeles.

title: No Headline
description: WHEN my husband comments that I am aging well, I don't feel better. I feel like a bottle of wine. What I resent about the aging process are the indignities, mental, physical and emotional, that I must submit to. I'd like to have a frank discussion with my anatomy. Blood, how dare you become iron-poor? Hair, what gives you the right to turn gray? Tummy, say good night and go tuck yourself in.

title: MUSIC GREEETS THE EASTERSEASON
description: WITH the customary outpouring of traditional music by Handel, Haydn and Bach, some offbeat folk and rock-and-roll strains, celebrations in dance and a world premiere of an Easter mass, musicians and worshipers gather this week to mark Holy Week. Here are some of the musical highlights on tap:

title: LEGALLY SPEAKING, POLISH GOVERNMENT IS BIG ON APPEARANCES
description: JOHN KIFNER

title: THE IMPACT OF JESSE JACKSON
description: If Jesse Jackson fails to place his hand firmly upon the Presidency, many other black Americans - far better qualified than he - are waiting to go through the door that he has opened. One thinks immediately of Barbara Jordan, Charles Rangel, Shirley Chisholm, Julian Bond, Andrew Young, Coretta Scott King and who knows how many younger black Americans just beginning to move along the political road that leads to national fame. SONDRA GORDON LANGFORD Chatham, N.J.

title: AN EFFECTIVE TEACHER: THE KEY INGREDIENTS
description: WHEATON, Ill. MONICA CRAIG, a fourth

title: FOR KATE NELLIGAN, GHOSTS HAUNT THE STAGE
description: SAMUEL G. FREEDMAN T here is a moment in ''A Moon for the Misbegotten'' when James Tyrone Jr.'s gaze goes blank. He has just seen, either genuinely or metaphorically, his own ghost. And as Josie Hogan, his companion under the moon, tells Tyrone, ''It's the worst ghost of all, your own.''

title: A NEAR MANIA FOR THE WRITTEN WORD
description: HENRY JAMES LETTERS

title: MAXIMUM EMOTION WITH A MINIMUM OF DEFINITION
description: T he English painter Howard Hodgkin, now in his 52d year, has not a large international constituency of the kind that is kept in order by a cabal of dealers and curators, fed with a continuous and large-scale output and stoked with promotional material and an occasional well-timed appearance in the auction rooms.

title: CRITICS CHOICES
description: The film ''Brief Encounter,'' starring Trevor Howard and Celia Johnson, was made in 1945 and its Noel Coward story of bittersweet love in a suburban English railway station has ensconced itself in the ''Casablanca'' category of movie classics. In a repeat broadcast Monday evening at 9 on Channel 13, Mr. Howard and Miss Johnson can be seen as they were reunited some 35 years later for the Granada TV production of ''Staying On.'' The special chemistry survived splendidly.

title: JESSYE NORMAN: BORN TO SING THE 'FOUR LAST SONGS'
description: Theodore W. Libbey Jr. is classical music editor of High Fidelity magazine.

title: ASSISTANCE FOR VICTIMS OF DISASTERS PREPARED
description: THE first weeks of spring have been a time of misery all along the Jersey Shore and throughout the Passaic River basin. The fierce coastal storm that pounded beaches and sea walls and poured water into coastal communities in the last days of March was followed a week later by some of the heaviest rains and most-sweeping floods in memory along the Passaic and its major tributaries.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE;
description: SOUTH AFRICAN PLAY

title: PARAMUS OFFICES
description: Paramus, N.J., which is known primarily for its concentration of huge shopping malls, is getting another kind of commercial development on Route 4.

title: CONGRESS WILL MEDDLE
description: The Senate's vote this week to condemn the mining of Nicaragua's harbors was more than a signal about what we are doing in Central America. It was also a clear response to the President's complaints last week about Congressional meddling in foreign policy. Indeed, the President should anticipate greater activity by Congress in the field of foreign policy. Nothing is so conducive to action as the sting of being ignored on your own territory.

title: MERRILL TO READ FROM HIS POEMS
description: THE Poet's Voice, Fairfield County's popular series of free poetry readings, will present James Merrill as a fifth poet in this year's program at the New Canaan Library today at 3 P.M. The reading is free and open to the public.

title: Lori Beth Leftoff Married To Howard Marc Kaplan
description: Lori Beth Leftoff, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Leftoff of Stony Brook, L.I., and Flushing, Queens, was married yesterday to Howard Marc Kaplan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Burton Kaplan of Flushing. Rabbi William Orentlicher performed the ceremony at the Bayside Jewish Center in Queens.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: EIGHT years ago, the Rev. Russell White , pastor of Bethel Baptist Church in Orange, improvised a plan to cut drug trafficking and crime by getting young men and women off the street.

title: Mary Grape Has Nuptials
description: Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, Conn., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Mary Dudley Grape, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dudley Hamilton Grape of Fairfield, Conn., to Dr. Eric Booth Karlen, a son of Mrs. Sven B. Karlen of Bronxville, N.Y., and the late Mr. Karlen. The Rev. Stephen J. Chinlund performed the ceremony.

description: Why is this Islander team different from all other hockey teams?

description: To the Editor:

title: PRIVATE SCHOOL FOR 'AVERAGE KIDS'
description: AT Blue Ridge School, a small private high school situated hard by its Appalachian Mountains namesake near Charlottesville, Va., the corridors are filled with students of distinctly average academic abilities: not future world statesmen but boys wearing coats and ties over their cords and army pants, who call their teachers ''Sir'' and ''Buddy,'' and follow a measured-out day with all the tractability that teen-age males can muster.

title: CUOMO VETOES ITEMS THAT HE FINDS LIMITING
description: Governor Cuomo this week vetoed several measures that would have imposed restrictions or new requirements on his running of the government. The measures, approved by the Legislature, were included in the state budget.

title: NUTS AND BOLTS OF INTERSTELLAR REPAIR
description: Space agency officials hailed the repair last week of the Solar Max satellite as the advent of a new age in space technology, now that humans can toil in the void with the tools of the mechanic's trade.

description: Mended Hearts

description: HOWELL RAINES PHILADELPHIA

title: THORNTON PACE INDIANS
description: Andre Thornton drove in three runs with a homer and a double today, and Rick Sutcliffe pitched his second complete game of the season as the Indians handed the Baltimore Orioles their sixth loss in seven games, 8-2.

title: Miss Birrell Weds Ward Rafferty Jr.
description: Laura Tudor Birrell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George A. Birrell of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Ward Rafferty Jr., a son of Mrs. Rafferty of Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla., and the late Mr. Rafferty. The ceremony was performed at Christ's Episcopal Church in Rye, N.Y., by the Rev. Wendell Phillips, rector emeritus.

title: DAMAGE TO TREES REPORTED SEVERE
description: Severe deterioration of tree foliage and declining tree growth are being observed throughout the Ohio Valley.

title: RETURN OF STRANDED DOLPHIN IS SUCCESSFUL FOR FITST TIME
description: For the first time a stranded dolphin has been successfully returned to its natural habitat, a spokesman for the Mystic Marinelife Aquarium says.

title: OPERETTA: VIENNA VOLKSOPER'S 'MERRY WIDOW'
description: The Vienna Volksoper's production of Lehar's ''Merry Widow'' Wednesday night at the New York State Theater was a generally charming affair, and apparently a considerable step up from its opening-night ''Fledermaus.''

title: EDUCATION BOARD WILL SUE YONKERS
description: The Yonkers Board of Education voted unanimously yesterday to sue the City of Yonkers for $12.5 million to prevent a shutdown of public schools on April 30, when the system is expected to run out of money. The financially troubled city was expected to fight the suit.

title: RIVER, STAY AWAY
description: Now nearing completion in New Milford, N.J., are the first 16 units of a 70-unit condominium town-house project being built on a 7 1/2-acre parcel next to the Hackensack River.

title: 2 MUSEUMS HAIL FAIRFIELD PORTER
description: ALTHOUGH they share the same fertile South Fork artist's colony landscape and, geographically, are less than 20 miles apart, the Parrish Art Museum in Southampton and Guild Hall in East Hampton traditionally have gone their own distinct ways: the venerable Parrish, with its strong collection of turn-of-the-century and early 20th-century works, generally concentrating on the past, and the younger Guild Hall focusing on contemporary art.

title: DAY CAMPS PROVING BOON TO HANDICAPPED
description: JAMES GREENE, an 11

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: Do not prune maples, birches and beeches now because they bleed; wait until summer when trees are in full leaf. . . . After seeding lawns and/or vegetables, soil must be kept moist to aid germination. . . . Prune overgrown forsythia after flowers fade. . . . The soil is too cool to plant bean, squash and cucumber seeds, but full speed ahead on planting spinach, lettuce, radish, peas, onions and turnips.

title: CONCERT: OMEGA GROUP IN A Premiere
description: An impressive work by William Thomas McKinley for piano, clarinet violin and cello was given its premiere by the Omega Ensemble at Carnegie Recital Hall on Wednesday night.

title: HOW THE AGED WON STATE AID
description: ALBANY IT began, as have many requests

title: ANN JONES PLANS SEPTEMER BRIDAL
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Horace C. Jones of Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia, of the engagement of their daughter Ann Jones to Rufus M. Cole, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Cole of West Hartford, Conn. The wedding is planned for September.

title: BALLET: JOLINDA MENENDEZ AND WINNIPEG TROUPE
description: Jolinda Menendez returned to New York on Thursday as a guest artist with the Royal Winnipeg Ballet at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. And judging by the cheers at the end of her performance of the title role in ''Giselle,'' it was obvious she'd been missed.

title: 21 Food Outlets Cited by City; 21 Food Outlets Cited by City For Violations of Health Code
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 21 food establishments last week for violating the health code.

title: COMPUTERS LET STEEL PLANT BUCK TIDE OF CUTBACKS
description: HILLSIDE LIKE other ''smokestack industries,'' steel fabrication has fallen on hard times in New Jersey, but at least one company has been able to survive - and even expand - by turning to computerization.

title: A BACH 'BATTLE OF THE BANDS' IS HEADING THIS WAY
description: J ust the other day, in discussing the New York Philharmonic's singularly drab plans for celebrating Bach's 300th birthday next season, I mentioned the probability that musical organizations all over the world would be competing to find imaginative ways to mark the anniversary. The early precincts are already being heard from. The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center will present a preseason Bach Festival in September whose most engrossing feature promises to be a kind of ''battle of the bands'' between the Society's own resident artists under Charles Wadsworth, their artistic director, and Christopher Hogwood's Academy of Ancient Music. It ought to be a fascinating meeting of musical minds.

description: Sixteen national correspondents and contributors to The New York Times tell how to find the springtime highlights of their areas, from maple syrup on snow in Vermont, to splashes of wildflowers in the desert and bears emerging from hibernation in Yosemite.

title: R. D. Schutzman Marries Jill Suzanne Behan in Rye
description: Jill Suzanne Behan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Reginald J. A. Behan of Rye, N.Y., was married at the Manursing Island Club there yesterday to Robert David Schutzman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Schutzman of New York.

description: JUDY KLEMESRUD

title: JACKSON SUPPORTERS CONTEST PARTY RULES
description: NEW HAVEN THE Rev. Jesse Jackson's supporters met here last week to select a delegate to July's Democratic National Convention. But unlike the supporters of former Vice President Walter F. Mondale and Senator Gary Hart of Colorado, Mr. Jackson's group in the Third Congressional District was choosing a delegate even though Mr. Jackson did not win one in that district in the state Democratic Presidential primary on March 27.

title: YALE CREWS DOMINANT
description: Yale's depth of talent was manifested today as the Elis won 9 of the 10 eight-oared races contested on its home Housatonic River course.

description: To the Editor:

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Three of the most exalted masterpieces of the choral repertory will be performed in New York this week. Wednesday night at 7:30, Musica Sacra, under the direction of Richard Westenburg, will present Johann Sebastian Bach's ''St. Matthew Passion'' at Avery Fisher Hall. The soloists include Charles Bressler, Malcolm Smith, Gwendolyn Bradley, Janice Taylor, and Jon Humphrey.

title: SIX NORTHEAST STATES DISCUSS RADIOACTIVE WASTE DISPOSAL
description: Delegates from six Northeastern states met here Thursday and Friday to talk about where to dispose of the region's low- level radioactive waste.

title: BATTLING THE BOGYMAN
description: Bridge-players sometimes imagine bogymen, recalling Hughes Mearns who wrote: ''As I was going down the stair, I met a man who wasn't there.'' An example is the diagramed deal reported by Herb Lavine of Westfield, N.J., from a game at the Cavendish Club here.

title: THE NATION ; Giving theDeficits Their Due
description: President Reagan may have thought he was venturing into friendly territory last week, but the reception accorded him by an Arlington, Tex., parley of construction executives and bankers was hardly heartwarming. ''Deficits keep interest rates high,'' lectured one panelist.

title: Jill S. Adelman Marries Steven Lustig, Lawyer
description: Jill Susan Adelman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Burton K. Adelman of Tenafly, N.J., was married yesterday to Steven Lustig, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sanford Lustig of Dayton, Ohio. Rabbi David J. Seligson performed the ceremony at the St. Regis-Sheraton Hotel, assisted by Cantor Ephraim Biran.

title: SHINNECOCK SHOALS CHALLENGE FISHERMEN
description: WHEN hurricane winds struck the fragile Atlantic coastline in the Hampton Bays area in 1938, a channel was formed from fishing grounds in deep ocean waters to a port area in Shinnecock Bay. Now, as prevailing northeasterly winds are again changing the configuration of Atlantic shore areas, a shifting quarter-mile-long sand bar is threatening to close off the Shinnecock Inlet channel.

title: Watford Reaches Final
description: Watford posted a 1-0 victory over Plymouth Argyle today and reached the final of the English F.A. Cup soccer competition. George Reilly scored the goal after 12 minutes to send his team into the final for the first time ever. In the other semifinal, Everton defeated Southampton in overtime, 1-0.

description: Bruno V. Bitker, a former member of the United States National Commission for Unesco and a longtime supporter of the United Nations, died here Thursday after a long illness. He was 86 years old.

title: Unkown Soldier Is Selected
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger announced Friday that an unidentified serviceman from the Vietnam war has been selected to be interred at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier at Arlington National Cemetery.

title: Jackson Wins DelegatesIn South Carolina Tally
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson scored a victory in his home state today for his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination, and Walter F. Mondale won some delegates of his own here as South Carolina Democrats met in convention. Mr. Jackson, a Greenville native, won 34.4 percent of the vote and 17 of the state's national delegates as previously unpledged delegates defected. The proportion of uncommitted delegates, which had been higher than Mr. Jackson's, dropped to 27.1 percent, or 12 elected delegates. Mr. Mondale and Senator Gary Hart of Colorado, who ran closely in the unofficial percentages, will get six elected delegates each, state party officials said.

title: FILM VIEW ; FOR THE AWARDS: APPROVAL AND A YAWN
description: S hortly after the end of Monday night's extended Oscar telecast, the streets of the Upper West Side of Manhattan were suddenly filled with people. It looked a little like a post-New Year's Eve crowd, though far more dozy if not actually stunned. Some were obviously people who don't yet own their own color television sets and were returning to deprived households of black-and-white. Others were walking impatient dogs. Like people, dogs should not be expected to go nearly four hours without relief.

GARDENING ;
RASPBERRIES: BEST FROM YOUR OWN PATCH
description: HAVE you ever wondered what makes a raspberry a raspberry? If the core stays on the plant when the fruit is picked, it is a raspberry; otherwise it may be a blackberry, a loganberry or even a dewberry.

description: The Army is moving toward putting into effect a change in battlefield doctrine that emphasizes offense, deep strikes and a high level of mobility.

description: Ingmar Bergman's new version of ''King Lear,'' the demanding tragedy that has overwhelmed as many theater companies as it has audiences, has pulled the troubled Royal Dramatic Theater out of an artistic slump that had become a cultural scandal here.

title: BASQUE EXILES IN FRANCE LIVE IN FEAR
description: On the surface, everything seems normal in the resorts of St.-Jean-de-Luz, Biarritz and other villages hugging the beaches of France's southwestern coast. The tulips are well tended, the cafe waiters haughty and the windows of the boutiques artfully arrayed with fishnet sweaters, driftwood, suntan lotion and piles of sand bearing footprints.

title: LYE HODS LEAD AT RAINY MASTERS
description: Mark Lye was still the surprise leader in the 48th Masters Tournament when a heavy thunderstorm suspended play in today's third round with Lye and 17 other golfers out on the Augusta National Golf Club course.

title: 2 DESIGNERS, 2 OUTLOOKS
description: It is a paradox of long standing that two fashion designers can describe their work in almost exactly the same way but produce garments that are as dissimilar as the Right Bank is from the Left. That is reflected in the designs of the Vicomtesse Jacqueline de Ribes and Agn es B., whose name is Agn es de Fleurieu.

title: A MINORITY SUCCESS STORY
description: IF parents here named the public schools they would give anything to get their children into, Kenwood Academy, on the South Side, would be high on the list. Noted locally for the excellence of its faculty and its close ties with the University of Chicago, Kenwood has received more than 1,000 applications so far for about 150 openings next fall.

title: Nancy Jean Marvel Marries David M. Birnbaum
description: Nancy Jean Marvel, the daughter of Mrs. William W. Marvel of Arlington, Va., and the late Dr. Marvel, was married yesterday to David Mark Birnbaum, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jesse L. Birnbaum of New York. The Rev. Thomas L. Jones performed the ceremony at the Chevy Chase (Md.)

title: Young Stands Out In Express Victory
description: Steve Young capped his best game as a professional when he scored on a 1-yard quarterback sneak 2 minutes 51 seconds into overtime tonight to give the Los Angeles Express a 23-17 victory over the Memphis Showboats.

title: David R. Eagle Is Married ToDulcyGrusdBrightman
description: Dulcy Grusd Brightman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward E. Grusd of Washington, was married yesterday to David Ruben Eagle, a son of Helen Eagle of Newark and the late Harry Eagle.

title:
ANTIQUES;
WHERE THE FLEA MARKETS WILL BE
description: WITHIN doors or out of doors, antiques shows are a proven lure, attracting visitors from throughout Connecticut as well as nearby states.

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: The pianist Sarah Grunstein grew up in Australia, where she studied at the Sydney Conservatorium and received a Queen Elizabeth II Silver Jubilee Award for Young Australians. In 1979, Miss Grunstein moved to New York, where she took music degrees from the Juilliard School. On April 7, she made her formal New York debut at Carnegie Recital Hall.

title: TREK TO MACHU PICCHU
description: -NEWTON is a correspondent for NBC News in El Salvador.

title: MAVERICKS OF DESIGN
description: The lone inventor, living by his wits, has largely become a figure of legend. In his place, the research and development team has taken over the task of providing the moving force of technological progress, and in today's climate of corporate research, offbeat notions - regardless of merit - do not always find nurturing soil. A notable exception is the audio industry, where the individual inventor is staging a comeback. In fact, quite a few new companies owe their existence to the unorthodox ideas of some solitary maverick.

title: JACKSON DOUBTS HE'D SERVE IN CABINET
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, looking beyond the Democratic Party's convention in July, says he seriously doubts he would accept a Cabinet position in the event a Democrat defeated President Reagan this fall.

title: Miss Fennessy And E. P. Bousa Planning to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Eamon T. Fennessy of Upper Saddle River, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Maureen Louise Fennessy to Edward Peter Bousa, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Bousa 3d of Upper Saddle River and Popponesset Beach, Mass. A September wedding is planned.

title: PROSPECTS
description: A Mortgage Time Bomb

title: The Editorial Notebook; Scattered Signposts to Man
description: Dinosaurs took eons to rise to ascendancy, but humans appear so abruptly in the evolutionary record that their origins are still shrouded in mist and controversy. The fossil evidence of human evolution is so sparse that almost every significant remain can be gathered in a single room.

title: METS DROP SECOND IN A ROW TO CUBS, 5-2
description: The Mets suffered some more shots of reality in Wrigley Field today when they lost again to the Chicago Cubs, 5-2. And, one day after saying goodbye to their six-game winning streak, they had a two-game losing streak.

title: UNIVERSITY SEMINARS: ON AND ON AT COLUMBIA
description: WILLIAM S. VICKREY, a professor of economics at Columbia University, describes himself as a ''frustrated encyclopedist'' whose intellectual interests range far beyond the confines of his specialization in urban economics. Ever since he spent time working in Japan early in his career, he has maintained an interest in East Asian affairs. As an economist, he is concerned with questions of methodology in the social sciences, and as an urbanist, he studies the history and development of cities. As a pacifist and Quaker, he worries about world peace.

title: 'TELL ME THE PLOT,' I HISSED, BUT HER LIPS WERE SEALED
description: MAUREEN DOWD

title: ARTS COUNCIL GETS LARGEST GIFT
description: THE Arts Fund, the fund-raising and redistribution program of the Council for the Arts in Westchester, has received its largest private contribution ever - a $100,000 gift from International Business Machines.

title: DANNY MANNING: TALENT IN SEARCH OF ROOM TO GROW
description: DANNY MANNING'S senior trip will extend to a new destination this week. At the point in life when most ambitious and talented high school seniors are busy ignoring their teachers, planning their parties and preparing to load their backpacks and discover a new world, Manning is adding another stop to a journey that began late last summer.

title: Dr. Gae Rodke and Dr. Charles Swencionis Marry
description: Dr. Gae Michele Rodke and Dr. Charles Swencionis were married yesterday at the Sunwood Estate in Old Field, L.I., by the Rev. Dr. Robert Neville, a Methodist minister who is dean of humanities and sciences at the State University of New York at Stony Brook.

title: A 'SCANDALOUS' SHOW RETURNS
description: '' ADVANCING AMERICAN ART,'' at the William Benton Museum in Storrs, is a show certain to provoke discussion. But it can scarcely aspire to the uproar it caused when first presented, in 1946, as proof to the world that America was not all military might and Hollywood movies, but a country capable of culture, also.

title: LETTERS GROUP GIVES PRIZES TO 8 WRITERS
description: The American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters has announced the award of $5,000 prizes to eight writers to ''encourage them in their creative efforts.''

title: COMPUTERS FOR PICKING A COLLEGE
description: COMPUTERS in the classroom have taken a few steps down the hall and found their way into the guidance office. High school students no longer have to leaf through a 2,000-odd page college guide or handbook to find out what colleges meet their needs - they can get a list via computer.

description: To the Editor:
