title: Susan Rowe Married To Richard J. Bartow
description: Susan Pamela Rowe, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Robert Rowe of Boca Raton, Fla., formerly of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Richard Joseph Bartow, a son of Dorothea Reilley Bartow of East Brunswick, N.J., and the late John Richard Bartow. The Rev. Robert Stewart MacLennan performed the ceremony at the Hitchcock Presbyterian Church in Scarsdale.

title: Katherine Autera And L. J. Jardine Exchange Vows
description: The First Presbyterian Church of Ridgewood, N.J., was the scene yesterday of the wedding of Katherine Tilt Autera, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael E. Autera of Ridgewood and Southampton, L.I., and Leonard James Jardine, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard L. Jardine of Providence and Saunderstown, R.I. The Rev. Dr. Howard J. Hansen, assisted by the Rev. Eugene Hendricks, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: CHANGE IN THE DIVORCE LAW TERMED A THREAT TO FAIRNESS
description: often known as L.A.W. - have become increasingly concerned with a new wrinkle in the law that goes by the unwieldy name of reverse partial summary judgment. We feel that this procedure negates the intent of equitable distribution, and threatens to turn New York into a ''no-fault'' divorce state.

title: June Nuptials Set By Holly Blatman
description: Dr. Ceevah Miriam Blatman, a resident in psychiatry at the Dartmouth Hitchcock Medical Center in Hanover, N.H., and Dr. Douglas Miller Rothkopf, a senior resident in surgery at the center, plan to be married in June.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
JUDGMENT DAY FOR SENIORS
description: APRIL 15 is a kind of judgment day for high school seniors. Fantasies have flourished until now: ''Somehow, I'll make it. Never mind that I live in the Northeast, am not an athlete or at the top of my class. Maybe just being an intelligent student, eager to learn, will somehow be enough.''

title: BRITISH POP: TWINS BAND A THREESOME
description: The Thompson Twins, a fashionably eccentric, interracial threesome that has enjoyed a series of English hits, represents British pop trendiness incarnate. The group, whose instrumental lineup features xylophone, synthesizers and a heavy battery of percussion, goes in for the same sort of visual eclecticism as groups like Culture Club, which also pose as models of pan-ethnic and pan-sexual harmoniousness.

title: A PLACE FOR MISFITS TO LEARN TO FIT IN
description: PRINCETON FOR THE mentally and emotionally disabled men and women who frequent The Hub here, Saturday night is not the loneliest night of the week. They have managed to make their weekends a social, happy time.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CELEBRATING THE SEA, VACATIONS FOR VOLUNTEERS New Brunswick Bicentennial
description: Among the guests scheduled to attend the birthday celebration are Queen Elizabeth II and Pope John Paul II.

title: IF REAGAN WINS
description: President Reagan's decision to use emergency power for funds for El Salvador without the approval of Congress and in its absence during the Easter recess tells us more about the President than anything else.

title: Correction
description: A caption in the Travel section on April 1 incorrectly identified the painting on which a mural at the Charing Cross subway station in London is based. The painting was Botticelli's ''Venus and Mars.'' The subway line serving the platform shown was also misidentified; it is the Bakerloo Line.

title:
GARDENING ;
RASPBERRIES: BEST FROM YOUR OWN PATCH
description: HAVE you ever wondered what makes a raspberry a raspberry? If the core stays on the plant when the fruit is picked, it is a raspberry; otherwise it may be a blackberry, a loganberry or even a dewberry.

title: THOUGHTS ON THE LIMITS TO AMERICAN POWER
description: Frank Church, Democratic Senator from Idaho from 1956 to 1980, died on April 7. What follows are excerpts from his speeches.

REFORM INSTEAD OF ARMS
description: James LeMoyne, who has reported from Central America, is a reporter for The New York Times. FROM GUNBOATS TO DIPLOMACY

title: MORE FUNDS SOUGHT FOR THE STATE'S PORTS
description: THE Maritime Advisory Council of New Jersey - appointed last fall by Borden R. Putnam, Commissioner of the Department of Commerce and Economic Development, to monitor the state's ports and oversee waterfront development - contends that President Reagan's proposed 1985 budget falls $18 million short of what is needed to maintain New Jersey's harbors.

title: A CANDID TALK WITH SAUL BELLOW
description: D. J. R. Bruckner is an editor of The New York Times Book Review. THE NEW STOries Saul Bellow has been writing recently, collected in ''Him With His Foot in His Mouth and Other Stories,'' to be published next month, are marked by such personal feeling and most of them by such good humor and light= ness of mood that one wonders what is going on with Bellow. Ask him and you get an answer.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: TODAY is National Deadline Day, the one day that all Americans race against every year. It is April 15, the day that income tax returns are normally due, not so much a competition to be first as it is, for many, a competition to be last. Of course, as with certain other holidays, because it falls on Sunday we're celebrating it this year on Monday.

title: TRAVEL BOOKSHELF
description: The Traveler's Key to Northern India: A Guide to the Sacred Places of Northern India

title: DANCE: 'REAL ADVENTURES,'A SOLO BY MARY FULKERSON
description: Disaster, or at least dull misery, seemed imminent Wednesday at the start of a performance by Mary Fulkerson at Roulette, in TriBeCa. But it soon became one of the most compelling solos of the season.

title: HIGHER MEAT PRICES EXPECTED LATER THIS YEAR
description: Consumers will face sharply higher prices for pork this spring and summer and somewhat higher prices for beef and poultry, according to agricultural forecasters.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;  Punishment Enough
description: Authorities in Pittsburgh have dropped a drunk driving charge that had been lodged against the Steeler lineman Gabe Rivera, the team's No. 1 draft choice last year, in connection with the automobile accident in October that left him paralyzed from the chest down.

title: U.S. LIFE AGREES WITH SOVIET BOY WHO FLED
description: Four years after a disagreement with his parents escalated into an international incident, 16-year-old Walter Polovchak is a typical American teen-ager interested in fast food, girls and cars.

title: LAND OF SCORPIONS AND SAGEBRUSH
description: Alice Hoffman 's most recent novel is ''White Horses.'' BEYOND THE WALL

title: Judge Cuts Air Crash Award
description: A Federal district judge has reduced by nearly half a $5.2 million jury award to the four children of a couple killed in the nation's second-worst air disaster. Judge Charles Schwartz reduced the award to $2.4 million and ruled that the four children of Everard W. and Mary Ann Marks were not entitled to the $2 million the jury awarded for loss of inheritance. The parents were killed July 9, 1982, when Pan American Flight 759 crashed in a takeoff from New Orleans International Airport, killing all 146 people aboard and eight on the ground.

title: HBO GAMBLES ON A COSTLY MINI-SERIES
description: NAN ROBERTSON

title: 'JOSEPH' IS AMAZING AT EVENING THEATER

title: CUL-DE-SACS STIR CONTROVERSY
description: SMITHTOWN homeowners are using verbal roadblocks to defend the tranquillity of their neighborhoods against developers and officials who are opening up cul-de-sacs to through traffic. They object to traffic noise and other disruptions that they say are caused by the openings.

title: FOOTLOOSE AND ON THE GO WITHOUT A CAR IN THE WORLD
description: -LESS. Careless. Carefree. I had done it. The unthinkable. I had totaled my car on Route 9A in Briarcliff Manor, one wintry February day on a business trip for my company.

title: RETOOLING COLLEGES FOR THE 21ST CENTURY
description: THE international credibility of the United States and the vitality of its economy are increasingly dependent on the development and implementation of new technologies. However, the obsolescence of college and university laboratories and scientific equipment now threatens our country's ability to maintain its leadership in science and technology. Since colleges and universities conduct a major share of basic research in the United States and virtually all the training of engineers and scientists, the quality of higher education's teaching and research laboratories is directly related to the training of our next generation of scientists and engineers and to the continued vitality of our nation's efforts in basic research.

title: About Books
description: HOW MUCH of ''House of Slammers'' (Macmillan, New York, $14.95) is autobiographical is the inevitable question after learning that Nathan Heard, the author of this novel about the State Prison in Trenton, was an inmate there from 1961 through 1968.

title: HOW U.S. AID IS PROCESSED By States News Service
description: WASHINGTON UNDER the Disaster Relief Act of 1974, the law governing Federal disaster intervention, the Federal Emergency Management Agency must determine that the magnitude of the ''recovery activities'' is beyond the capabilities of state and local governments.

title: BRADLEY PLAYS KEY TAX ROLE By States News Service
description: WASHINGTON FOREIGN affairs, concern over tax policies, old-fashioned constituent politics and Senator Bill Bradley have combined to derail for now an effort to close a tax loophole that lets people deduct from their taxable income the cost of luxury cars used for business.

title: U.S. GROUNDS CHARTER AIRLINE FOR VIOLATION OF SAFETY RULES
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has grounded Rich International Airways, saying inspectors had uncovered ''hundreds of violations'' of Federal safety regulations at the Miami-based charter airline.

title: SIBLING COMPANIONS
description: As a mother and a daughter, it is my observation that the spacing of children has little bearing on the intensity of sibling rivalry in a family. The degree to which parents communicate that there is enough love for each child affects the quality of the interaction between children as young people and as adults.

title: TRAINING THE NEXT ARMS-CONTROL GENERATION
description: A SELECT group of American scientists has decided to ''clone'' itself in the interest of world security. The scientists - about 25 nearing or past retirement age - as a group make up this nation's leading arms-control experts who reside at universities and who are trained in the ''hard sciences.'' As physicists, chemists, geologists, engineers and biologists they have advised Presidents and generals since World War II on matters of international security and arms negotiations.

title: Woman Vice President Favored by 24% in Poll
description: Among the women considered ''well qualified to serve as Vice President of the United States,'' Americans most often name Associate Justice Sandra Day O'Connor of the Supreme Court, former Representative Barbara Jordan of Texas, and Transportation Secretary Elizabeth Hanford Dole, according to the Gallup Poll.

title: NEW CENTERS OFFER DAY CARE FOR ADULTS
description: RESTLESS elementary school children once filled the one- story brick building on Shore Drive in Branford. That ended three years ago, when the town closed the schoolhouse because of declining enrollment .

description: To the Editor:

LET'S DEAL WITH HUMAN PROBLEMS

title: KENNEDY SEEKS COORS INQUIRY
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy called today for a ''full and immediate'' Senate investigation of whether the Adolph Coors Company received favored treatment from the Federal job safety agency because of its top official's ties to President Reagan.

title: A COLLEGE CAPITALIZING ON STUDENT ABILITIES
description: MILWAUKEE WHEN Kathleen Sullivan Dietrich entered Alverno College as a psychology student here 10 years ago, her view of higher education was ''to study under professors who had great knowledge in order to become successful.''

title: GROTESQUE IMAGERY HAS COME TO DANCE
description: T he grotesque has never been totally absent from theatrical dance but it is an aspect of human behavior that dance has recently rarely mirrored. The grotesque as leavened with humor, however, is something we can expect to see increasingly in the future.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
WASHINGTON HALF DOLLAR NAMED COIN OF THE YEAR
description: The George Washington half dollar, already the best-selling commemorative coin in United States history, has now gained added distinction - it has received the first ''Coin of the Year'' award from Krause Publications. The selection, announced early this month, was made by an international panel of 43 mint officials, medalists, numismatists and other experts who chose it from among more than three dozen nominated coins issued by nations around the world.

title: E.P.A. MOVES TO CUT OFF HIGHWAY FUNDS TO CITIES LACKING POLLUTION TESTS
description: The Federal Environmental Protection Agency has taken the first steps toward cutting off more than $20 million in Federal highway funds for this city because it has discontinued its program of testing for automobile emissions.

description: ALAN S. OSER

title: Mugabe Chides Bishops For Atrocity Charges
description: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe attacked Zimbabwe's Roman Catholic bishops today for accusing security forces in troubled Matabeleland Province of atrocities against civilians.

description: Shea Stadium

title: CARLING BASSETT CAN ACCEPT HER LOSSES
description: Carling Bassett, the quick, competitive, pony-tailed 16-year-old, took an impressive 4-0 lead in the first set of her semifinal match against Claudia Kohde-Kilsch this morning at the Family Circle Magazine Cup at the Sea Pines Racquet Club.

title: Harvard to Refuse Pacts In Censorship Dispute
description: Harvard University will not accept approximately $4 million in Pentagon- supported research contracts unless the Reagan Administration drops a proposal to censor the publication of unclassified research.

title: Bolivia Workers Strike O A P
description: Workers have begun a four-day national strike against austerity measures that sharply devalued the Bolivian peso and increased the prices of food and gasoline fivefold.

Speaking Personally;
WHAT IS 'KOSHER' FOR PASSOVER?
description: MY AUNT has three food processors: One for meat, one for dairy products and one for use at Passover.

title: EGYPT RESUMES CONTACTS WITH ISRAELI OPPOSITION
description: Egypt has resumed its contacts with Israelis who are critical of their Government's policy on West Bank settlements and favor more flexibility toward Egypt and other Arab countries, officials here said today.

description: Question:

title: COMPETITIONS CAN MAKE A DIFFERENCE
description: Naomi Graffman writes frequently about the performing arts.

title: One-Time Chance
description: Tennis is just a demonstration sport at the 1984 Games in Los Angeles, but the way Jimmy Arias sees it, the chance to participate even on the periphery of the Olympics is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity that is too good to pass up. As a result, the 19- year-old star said that he would forego a defense of his national clay court title - and risk a decline in his computer ranking - in order to play on the United States team in Los Angeles. ''The Olympics are a chance to represent my country with the whole world watching - it's an opportunity I can't pass up,'' he explained.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS ; Historic Floor
description: It was a spot that was beginning to rival the Alamo as a tourist attraction: the old Texas School Book Depository Building in Dallas. Hundreds of thousands of visitors were streaming there every year.

title: PERSIAN GULF: DREAM COME TRUE FOR SPECULATORS
description: Both William Safire's March 23 column about Persian Gulf oil and Henry S. Rowen's April 2 letter in rebuttal fail to explain why U.S. and allied policies regarding the gulf are and will continue to be counterproductive.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a transmission error, last week's theater review incorrectly identified ''Tom and Viv,'' a play about the life of T. S. Eliot.

title: Amy Margaret Moss Becomes Bride Of Glenn Brown Jr., a Fellow Lawyer
description: Amy Margaret Moss, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William John Moss of Garrison, N.Y., and Glenn William Brown Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Brown of Waynesville, N.C., were married yesterday. Msgr. Herman L. Heide and the Rev. Emmanuel Sullivan performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Garrison.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS ; Fatal Attraction
description: Migrating ruby-throated hummingbirds, desperate for food last fall after a drought, were reported being electrocuted in Missouri because they mistook red insulators on electric fences for bright flowers.

title: Susan F. McDonough Weds Robert M. Vogt
description: The marriage of Susan Frances McDonough and Robert Martin Vogt took place yesterday at St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church in Short Hills, N.J. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Thomas Keefe.

title: Costly Charges
description: The former Houston guard Rob Williams's allegations that an attorney gave him and some of his teammates money could cost the school 90 percent of the money it received for participating in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Final Four playoffs two years ago. Williams, now with the Denver Nuggets, said Wednesday that the Houston attorney and university alumnus Jerry Bonney gave him and four teammates $500 to $600 after home games played during the 1980-81 season and asked in return to be considered as their agent.

title: CUOMO, LIKE KOCH, TURNS LIFE INTO LITERATURE
description: Mario M. Cuomo and Edward I. Koch, who battled each other for Mayor and then for Governor, have carried their competition into a new forum: the bookstore.

title: A FAMOUS BIRDER OBSERVES SPRING
description: -known authority on birds, celebrated the first day of spring this year by visiting osprey nesting grounds not far from his home in Old Lyme.

title: TANGLED TRADES AT MARSH & MCLENNAN
description: Marsh & McLennan stunned the trading world by announcing that it would take a $60-million after-tax charge to first-quarter earnings, largely because of what it called unauthorized trading by one trader that left the insurance brokerage firm with a $2 billion position in government bonds. Analysts said the firm's problem was a result of shortcomings in a system that relies too heavily on the judgments of individual traders. Most agreed that the incident would cause no permanent harm to Marsh, but trading procedures were likely to be tightened.

title: ACADEMICS TURN TO WALL STREET
description: A little over two months ago,

title: METRO-NORTH READIES TRAINS FOR SUMMER
description: -North Railroad is once again busy preparing its air-conditioning equipment to battle the heat. But this year, for some passengers at least, there will be a new weapon available - the openable window.

title: August Wedding For Alison Rowe
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph H. Rowe of Marblehead, Mass., and Hilton Head, S.C., of the engagement of their daughter, Alison Rebecca Rowe, to Stephen Iglehart, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Iglehart of Mystic, Conn. An August wedding is planned.

title: Kennedy Excels At Nanuet Relays
description: John F. Kennedy High School of the Bronx won four events and one of its runners, Francisco Pena, was named the outstanding individual in the Nanuet Relays today. But Kennedy was edged by Don Bosco of Ramsey, N.J., for the team title.

title: Data Bank; April 15, 1984
PRACTICAL TRAVELER: THE HIGHS, LOWS AND WHYS OF CAR RENTAL RATES
description: Virginia Richmond wanted to rent a car in West Palm Beach, Fla., for a week. In late February, while still at home in Summit, N.J., she noticed newspaper advertisements in which Budget quoted weekly Florida rates as low as $49, Greyhound as low as $39 and Alamo as low as $38.88. All the offers required reservations but were to remain effective at least through April, ''subject to availability.''

title: Pact With Flight Attendants Reached at Northwest Orient
description: Northwest Orient Airlines and its 2,900 flight attendants reached a tentative contract at 9:30 tonight, averting a strike at 12:01 A.M. Sunday.

title: Future Events
description: Mostly Dance, Theater BY ROBERT E. TOMASSON

title: BOXERS MAKE ENCOURAGING PRE-OLYMPIC SHOWING
description: Twenty minutes after his super-heavyweight victory over Italy's Francesco Damiani in the World Championships Challenge Friday night, Tyrell Biggs came into his dressing room fuming.

title: AUTHORITIES UNSURE OF MOTIVE IN SERIES OF WOMEN'S DEATHS
description: The authorities said today they may never know whether a suspected mass-killer, Christopher Wilder, died by accident or by suicide in a struggle yesterday with a New Hampshire state police detective.

title:
ART ;
35 MOORE BRONZES IN RETROSPECTIVE
description: D ISCOVERING a passion you did not know you had is one of life's more tonic experiences. Through encountering Michelangelo in Italy, George Ablah, a real estate investor from Wichita, Kan., who specializes in revitalizing white elephants, realized he had a passion for monumental sculpture. One very fine upshot of Mr. Ablah's indulgence is an exhibition of Henry Moore bronzes at Blue Hill Plaza, an office complex Mr. Ablah owns near Pearl River in Rockland County.

title: 13 Held in a Manhattan Raid
description: The police arrested 13 people in a lower Manhattan garage yesterday and found as many as 25 stolen automobiles, some converted to taxicabs. Officials said the incident started out as an arrest for a car theft and then led to the raid on the garage at 447 West 17th Street, listed as Romed Industries. Officer David Odermatt said charges against the 13 included grand theft auto, grand larceny and bribery.

title: THE REGION ; Hands Across
description: The Hudson

title: ...TO OTHERS ON L.I., IT'S MORE OF A BANE
description: THE other day, I had a most distressful experience. I had let my 4-year-old daughter out to play in the backyard about 1 P.M. She and I had just finished a leisurely lunch overlooking the beautiful, quiet woods that encircle our half-acre home.

title: 'DAMES AT SEA' SINKS QUICKLY
description: -act version in Greenwich Village to a two-act Off Broadway musical two years later, ''Dames at Sea,'' ''the new 30's musical'' as it was then called, rode high on the nostalgia bandwagon. It depicted an era when women were called ''tomatoes'' and times were ''swell'' (though only on screen, not in real life.)

title: MUSIC: P-FUNK BAND AT RITZ
description: George Clinton is the songwriter and ringmaster of the P-Funk All- Stars, whose 18 costumed musicians had a three-night stand at the Ritz last week.

title: Rep. Hansen of Idaho Files for Re-election
description: Representative George Hansen filed his re- election candidacy papers in a crowded state office Friday, then wielded a sword as a symbolic attack on Federal officials who prosecuted him for financial disclosure violations.

title: EVIDENCE CONVICTING ONE MAN MAY FREE ANOTHER
description: Ernest Holbrook Jr. has spent more than two years in a state prison for the rape and murder of a child, a crime it now appears he did not commit.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Hammond Mortgage Securities Corp., a limited-purpose, California- based subsidiary of the Hammond Company, a mortgage banker, said it had filed for up to $100 million of mortgage-collateralized bonds to be issued through Kidder, Peabody & Co.

title: HEALTH GROUP INC. FINDS A SUCCESSOR FOR CHIEF
description: Health Group Inc., a closely held hospital management company based in Nashville, has named J. George Harris its chairman and chief executive officer.

title: Wrong Delegates Listed For Jackson, Paper Says
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson may have lost Democratic convention delegates to Walter F. Mondale because of certain sample ballots distributed for the Pennsylvania primary, it was reported today.

title: Susan Teltser, Writer, Is Wed to Arthur Schwarz
description: Susan Schoenfeld Teltser of Tenafly, N.J., a freelance writer and lecturer, was married yesterday to Arthur Lasker Schwarz of Scarsdale, N.Y., president of Ehrlich-Bober Advisors Inc., an investment management concern in New York. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel of Temple Emanu-El performed the ceremony at the Culinary Center in New York.

title: Filipinos Are Jolted By Suit Against Priest
description: A woman's $21 million lawsuit charging she was lured into sexual relations with seven Filipino priests has shaken the city's large Filipino community.

title: CONCERN OVER JACKSON RUNOFF STAND
description: In the corridors and the cloakrooms of the Capitol, Democratic lawmakers are increasingly critical of the Rev. Jesse Jackson and the price he is charging for supporting the party nominee in the fall campaign.

title: Robin Roberts's Pitch
description: After the 1953 baseball season, Robin Roberts and a group of other major leaguers went on one of those international barnstorming tours. As Roberts recalled it the other day, for all the fanfare the trip attracted, it was a one-barn tour - to Japan.

title: The Premises of Housing Court
description: New York's 10-year-old Housing Court, a branch of Civil Court, has been meeting in shabby and overcrowded quarters. Its judges have been overworked, its records inadequate.

title: S.E.C. NAMES HEAD OF JOURNAL INQUIRY
description: Gary Lynch, the 33-year-old associate director of the Securities and Exchange Commission's enforcement division, has been named to head its investigation into whether a reporter for The Wall Street Journal improperly gave outsiders sensitive information on articles he wrote and whether the outsiders traded securities illegally on the basis of such information.

description: Three army colonels were each sentenced today to 12 years and a day in prison for plotting a military coup in October 1982.

title: OUTDOORS: MANY SURF-CASTERS ACHIEVE REMARKABLE LENGTHS
description: ON April 28 and 29, many of the East Coast's most accomplished surf-casters will gather at Cape Henlopen State Park in Lewes, Del., for the second annual Stren distance-casting championship meet.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: GILBERT AND SULLIVAN The doyen of New York interpreters of Gilbert and Sullivan, the Blue Hill Troupe, is celebrating the 60th anniversary of its founding this year. Over six decades the troupe has achieved a dexterity within its specialty and is one of the few that regularly performs the entire Gilbert and Sullivan cycle of 13 operettas.

title: AMERICAN RESCUED BY BEIRUT MILITIA
description: An American professor who was kidnapped more than two months ago was rescued today by Shiite Moslem militiamen who stormed a West Beirut house in which he was being held.

title: STUDY SUGGESTS PLAN TO IMPROVE SECURITY IN PARK
description: Someone trying to report a crime in Central Park has a one-in-four chance of finding a working telephone call box there, according to a study being prepared for the Parks and Police Departments on security in Central Park.

title: Iranians Cast Votes For New Parliament
description: Iranians voted today in mosques, schools and mobile booths for a 270-member Parliament to replace the one elected after the 1979 Islamic revolution.

title: WHERE MICROCHIPS MAKE MONEY, HART THEME FITS
description: The women wore pearls and the men wore wire-rimmed glasses. They sat in wicker chairs amid the potted palms, toyed with the croissants, took short tastes from their tall glasses of white wine and, when it was all over, gave Senator Gary Hart a warm burst of applause.

title: MURDER SITE: COMMUNITY IN TRANSITION
description: When the police cars came last night the local people were surprised. One man was watching ''The Ten Commandments'' on TV in his living room, and came out during a commercial to see what the fuss was about. Another man was on his way to work at Rossi's Bakery, to help put bread in the bags. Ordinary things.

title: MUSIC: STUDENT GROUP
description: THE Cosmopolitan Symphony Orchestra, now in its 20th season, is made up of some of the most gifted music students in the metropolitan area. On Saturday afternoon this youthful ensemble presented an ambitious program at Town Hall under the direction of Meir Minsky.

title: One Man Is Killed, 2 Are Hurt In Attack at Paris Restaurant
description: One man was shot dead and two were slightly wounded when a man opened fire on a Tunisian restaurant in Paris with a machine pistol early this morning, the police said.

title: GENERALS ARE UPSET BY WRANGLERS, 20-3
description: The Arizona Wranglers, a desperate team after losing four games this season, were a dominant team today. Led by the fullback Kevin Long, who ran for 123 yards and two touchdowns, they beat the Generals, 20-3, at Giants Stadium.

title: JAKUB BERMAN, A POLISH EX-AIDE
description: Jakub Berman, who served behind the scenes as the Soviet Union's chief enforcer and boss in Stalinist Poland after World War II, died last Tuesday, according to an announcement published Saturday in the Polish newspaper Zycie Wars zawy. He was 83 years old.

title: CAMBODIANS FLEE VIETNAMESE ATTACK
description: Vietnamese forces invaded the headquarters of a Cambodian resistance group today, driving thousands of guerrillas into the hills and forcing tens of thousands of refugees across the border into Thailand, military and aid officials reported.

title: Jenrette Fails in Bid To Become Delegate
description: Former Representative John Jenrette's attempt to make a political comeback has hit a snag after he was unable to secure a spot in the state's delegation to the Democratic National Convention.

title: Junior Tennis Perils
description: She maintained an all-A high school record, and by rights and personal inclination should probably be at Stanford, expanding her intellecual horizons and savoring the delights of college.

title: HOW CONGRESS WAS INFORMED OF MINING OF NICARAGUA PORTS
description: The issue of whether Congress was adequately informed about the covert mining of Nicaraguan harbors has figured centrally in the debate that erupted this month. Following are some questions and answers about the dispute, the mandate and organization of the Senate and House intelligence committees and their relationship in this case and in general with the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Dana Robbins Marries Donald Olenick
description: Dana M. Robbins, an assistant corporation counsel in the appeals division of the New York City Law Department, and Donald J. Olenick, an associate with Kramer, Levin, Nessen, Kamin & Frankel, were married yesterday at the Burden Mansion in New York by Rabbi Jonathan Ginsburg.

title: SUSPECT IN 37 ROBBERIES SEIZED
description: A man suspected of robbing at least 37 women at gunpoint on the Upper East Side since January was arrested by detectives after he was seen driving in the area, apparently seeking another victim, the police said yesterday.

title: Lisa F. Winston Weds Wayne David Wilentz
description: Lisa Faye Winston, a daughter of Richard A. Winston of New York and the late Zena Lakritz Winston, was married yesterday to Wayne David Wilentz, a son of Stefani Sheresky of New York and Warren W. Wilentz of Fort Lee, N.J. Rabbi Martin Zion performed the ceremony at Temple Israel in Manhattan.

title: A 'WELL DONE' FOR THE RETURNING METS
description: A rainout today ended the Mets' most productive trip in five seasons, and they headed home for their first appearance in New York with six victories in nine games and a ''well done'' from their rookie manager.

title: INFLATION HINGES NOT ON M-1 ALONE
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC: LUKAS FOSS LEADS MILWAUKEE SYMPHONY
description: IT was an uncompromising and

title: PUBLISHERS FIND PROFITS IN TV NOSTALGIA BOOKS
description: What do a number of very old television situation comedies, including ''Leave It to Beaver,'' ''The Odd Couple,'' ''The Dick Van Dyke Show'' and ''The Honeymooners'' have in common?

title: 'A FEELING OF RELIEF'
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.

title: C.C.N.Y. ALUMNI RECALL 1949 STRIKE
description: I came to see if the old spirit was still here,'' said a man with a pepper- and-salt beard while Shelley Tenzer strapped on an accordion and gave out with a spirited rendition of an old folk song: ''Hold the fort, for we are coming/Union men be strong.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I would ask that they recognize that it was not an easy thing for Barry Goldwater to write that letter and it was not an easy thing for me to resign the vice chairmanship.

title: AlanSkuppWeds Michele S. Hiller
description: Michele S. Hiller, an institutional options trader at Salomon Brothers in New York, and Alan R. Skupp, associate counsel of the Sun Chemical Corporation in New York, were married yesterday at the Chanticler in Milburn, N.J., by Cantor Louis Davidson.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Record Hunters' Holiday

title: Torture for Family Planning
description: This was Dwight Eisenhower speaking nearly 20 years ago: ''Once as President, I thought and said that birth control was not the business of our Federal Government. The facts changed my mind. . . . Governments must act and private citizens cooperate urgently through voluntary means to secure this right for all peoples. Failure would limit the expectations of future generations to abject poverty and suffering and bring down upon us history's condemnation.''

title: ; IN HAPPY PURSUIT OF THE AMERICAN DREAM
description: To the Editor:

title: McCrory Wins
description: Milton McCrory successfully defended his World Boxing Council welterweight title today, stopping Gilles Elbilia of France at 1 minute 8 seconds of the sixth round. McCrory boosted his record to 23-0-1 with the victory.

title: Safeco Stock Split
description: The Safeco Corporation plans a 2-for-1 stock split and a 15 percent rise in its quarterly dividend, the Seattle company said over the weekend. The new shares will be distributed June 1 to shareholders of record on April 20.

title: DANCE: PREMIERE OF ELIOT FELD'S 'ADIEU'
description: JACK ANDERSON

title: JEWS DEBATE APPROPRIATENESS OF UPDATING SEDERS
description: As Passover begins tonight, Jews at seders around the world will ask the traditional question from the Haggadah, the text for the Passover service, ''Why is this night different from all other nights?''

title: Japan Bankruptcies Up
description: Corporate bankruptcies in Japan rose 15.5 percent from a year earlier, to a record 1,926 cases in March, a private credit research agency said this weekend.

title: 9 CLEARED OF CHARGES LINKED TO 5 DEATHS AT ANTI-KLAN RALLY
description: -SALEM, N.C., April 15 - An all-white jury acquitted six Ku Klux Klansmen and three American Nazi Party members today of civil rights violations in the killing of five members of the Communist Workers Party and the wounding of seven others in 1979.

title: THEATER: MUSICAL 'LOVE,' A NEW VERSION OF 'LUV'
description: MURRAY SCHISGAL'S 1964 Broadway hit, ''Luv,'' was a very funny little lampoon of modern marriage, neurotic New York-Jewish division. The new, vestpocket musical version, retitled ''Love,'' is more flat than funny - and, at first, one wonders if that's because the material has become dated. Conceivably it has, but this adaptation is not a fair test of the play's durability. Though often faithful to the letter of the original, the musical lacks the manic edge that is essential to spark Mr. Schisgal's jittery urban style.

title: A BRACING CROQUET WEEKEND IN BOCA RATON
description: Liz Whitney Tippett showed up in both her racing colors - her pants suit was fuchsia and her Rolls-Royce was purple. Zsa Zsa Gabor said she was in love again. Joan Fontaine walked into a shop to escape the rain and ended up with a new wardrobe. Peter Jennings, Peter Maas, George Plimpton and Tova Borgnine played croquet. Cleveland Green, Bob Kuechenberg and Dwight Stephenson of the Miami Dolphins strode around making everyone else feel like midgets. Igloo, an Australian dingo dog with yellow eyes, cowered under a table during the fireworks. It was some cast of characters and some weekend, even for Florida's Gold Coast.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
COMPANY PUTS INSURANCE UNIT UP FOR SALE
description: MICHAEL BLUMSTEIN

title: Burned Church Opens For Palm Sunday
description: A historic Capitol Hill church heavily damaged by lightning and fire, reopened today for Palm Sunday services.

title: Warner to Offer Preferred Stock
description: Warner Communications Inc. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a shelf offering of 7.26 million shares of series C cumulative convertible preferred stock, the company said Friday. The filing is in connection with the repurchase of Warner shares held by News International P.L.C., which is owned by Rupert Murdoch, the publisher.

title: 3 Christensen Brothers To Get Award
description: The annual Capezio Dance Award will be given this year to Willam, Harold and Lew Christensen - three brothers celebrated for their pioneering role in American ballet.

title: QUESTION OF WHO CAN BEAT REAGAN: HART'S EFFORTS TO BUILD A CAMPAIGN ISSUE
description: ''The electability issue is going to dominate the nominating process from now on and I have demonstrated that I am more electable than Walter Mondale,'' Gary Hart said Friday in South Tucson, Ariz., striking what is becoming a key theme in his campaign. Dotty Lynch, his pollster, said in an interview the same day that the campaign was focusing on one Mondale weakness, the ''persistent feeling that he can't beat Reagan,'' and the evidence in many national polls that Mr. Hart could do better in the Presidential election.

title: SOUTHERN AFRICAN PATH TO NEEDED CHANGE
description: To the Editor:

title: MRS. LLOYD ON DUTY DURING RAINOUT
description: Chris Evert Lloyd answered the ringing phones outside the pro shop at the Sea Pines Racquet Club as she waited for the rain to stop. She was scheduled to play Claudia Kohde-Kilsch today in the final of the Family Circle Magazine Cup tennis tournament.

title: CRENSHAW CAPTURES MASTERS BY 2 STROKES
description: Ben Crenshaw, one of the most popular figures in golf, finally realized a true measure of the glory that had long been predicted for him as he won the 48th Masters Tournament today by two shots over Tom Watson.

title: Sondra Easton Is Married To Michael Roger Levitan
description: Sondra Easton, a vice president of Rand Thompson Consultants Inc., a New York executive search concern, and Michael Roger Levitan, an assistant vice president of Citibank in New York, were married yesterday.

title: AT MUSEUM, A JEWISH CULTURE AND ITS PASSING
description: Caroline Beck stopped to read a poem on the wall of the Jewish Museum, written 40 years ago and called ''Sweet Sixteen'' by another young girl, who lived in a very different world.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Roll Out the Barrels

title: Hephaestian Folly in Space
description: When Hephaestus forged a cunning net to catch one of his fellow Greek gods in bed with the wrong goddess, the technology was successful - but the embarrassed victim was so enraged he threw the technologist down from heaven, leaving him with a permanent limp.

title: Cuba Holds Municipal Voting; 98 Percent Turnout Expected
description: Cubans voted today in municipal elections that provide their only direct say in the Government.

title: PORT AGENCY PLANS TO BEGIN PROJECT IN HOBOKEN DESPITE DELAYS IN ALBANY
description: The Port Authority plans to go forward with a sweeping revitalization of a stretch of Hudson River waterfront in Hoboken, N.J., even though the New York State Legislature has yet to approve a measure authorizing the project and a similar one in Queens, according to officials in the agency and in New Jersey.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The 3 Coins in the Fountain

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, APRIL 16, 1984

title: SALVADOR LEADER IS UNDECIDED IN ELECTION DISPUTE
description: El Salvador's Provisional President refused to take sides today in a dispute that erupted this weekend over voting procedures in next month's presidential runoff election.

title: BREAKING DOWN BARRIERS FOR THE ISOLATED ELDERLY
description: ''My days would be dull, very dull if I didn't come here,'' Emma Saikkonen said. ''My husband is dead and my friends are all dead, and those that are left have moved out of the city.''

title: Foreign Correspondent Is Married to Jill Eden
description: Jill Eden, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Theodore B. Eden of Brightwaters, L.I., was married yesterday to Steven Dryden, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin B. Dryden of Arlington, Va. Rabbi Richard Chapin performed the ceremony at the Tavern on the Green.

title: MONDAY, APRIL 16, 1984 International
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan announced that he was resigning as vice chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence. The New York Democrat said he was protesting the failure of the Central Intelligence Agency to inform the committee ''properly'' about the scope of United States involvement in the mining of Nicaraguan harbors. (Page A1, Column 6.) An American was rescued from kidnappers in Lebanon by Shiite Moslem militiamen who raided a West Beirut house in which he was being held after he was seized by unidentified gunmen two months ago. The Moslems also rescued a French construction engineer who had been abducted five days after the American, Frank Regier, an engineering professor. Two Americans are still missing in Beirut. They are the United States Embassy political officer, William Buckley, who was kidnapped Mar. 16, and Jeremy Levin, the bureau chief of the Cable News Network, who disappeared Mar. 7. (A1:5.)

title: No Headline
description: School Dropout Report Disputed by Quinones

title: CANADIANS TOP NORDIQUES, 2-1
description: Bobby Smith and Ryan Walter scored power-play goals tonight to give the Montreal Canadiens to a 2-1 victory over the Quebec Nordiques and to a 2-1 lead in their four-of-seven-game Adams Division playoff series.

title: NETWORKS GETTING MESSAGE ON POLLS
description: It was a fitful and dog-tired Harry Truman who turned in his sleep one memorable election night in 1948 to hear radio commentator H. V. Kaltenborn pronounce him doomed. Mr. Truman was ahead in votes counted, Mr. Kaltenborn acknowledged, but no matter. The polls showed Thomas E. Dewey incontestably ahead. Tally all the votes and it would be done with.

title: 2 Guilty Pleas on Computers
description: Two business executives face prison terms of up to 25 years after pleading guilty to importing counterfeit Apple II computer parts from Taiwan, assembling them and selling the computers in four cities.

title: MOYNIHAN TO QUIT SENATE PANEL POST IN DISPUTE ON C.I.A.
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan announced today that he was resigning as vice chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence.

title: COMPUGRAPHIC MARKETER SHIFTS TO SCITEX AMERICA
description: Bryan E. Newman, who has been senior vice president for marketing at the Compugraphic Corporation, is the new president of the Scitex America Corporation, a unit of the Israeli- based Scitex Corporation.

title: Stallions Triumph; Victory Streak at 7
description: Cliff Stoudt passed for two touchdown and ran for a third today as the Birmingham Stallions beat the Michigan Panthers, 28-17, for their seventh consecutive United States Football League victory.

title: DEMOCRATIC CANDIDATES ASSAIL REAGAN ON SALVADOR AID MOVE
description: The three Democratic Presidential candidates this weekend criticized President Reagan's decision to invoke emergency authority to send El Salvador $32 million in new military aid.

title: HOSPITAL MERGERS INCREASE AID COST, U.S. STUDIES FIND
description: Hospital mergers and acquisitions are rapidly increasing the costs of Medicare and Medicaid without providing additional health care to the elderly and poor people covered by the two programs, according to Federal officials.

title: PRESIDENT OF SWARTHMORE INSTITUTES NEW FERMENT
description: It was typical of the seriousness and moral ambition that infect almost everything at Swarthmore College that the job of finding a new president, undertaken in 1981, lasted a year and a half, involved the rejection of at least 16 promising candidates and plunged the search committee into such dejection that it considered quitting.

title: TWO VETERANS LEAD YOUNG TIGERS TO A GRAND START
description: DETROIT IT has been 12 years since an

title: The Catfish Switches
description: In 1978, the first time Jesse Helms ran for re- election to the United States Senate from North Carolina, much of his television advertising relied on endorsements from athletes native to the state. Perhaps most prominent was the endorsement of Jim (Catfish) Hunter, the right- handed pitcher for the Yankees, who that fall defeated Kansas City for the American League championship and the Los Angeles Dodgers in the World Series.

title: A SECOND WIND IN THE RUNNING ROOM
description: -*and late-1970's is alive and well. And different. The elite runners have more races and more tangible rewards, which makes them and their bank accounts happy. Most recreational runners seem to have learned to escape the pitfalls and thus get more satisfaction, which makes them happy.

title: TOLL RISES IN F.B.I. INQUIRY INTO PHILADELPHIA POLICE
description: The second-ranking official in the beleaguered Philadelphia Police Department has resigned as the Federal Bureau of Investigation continues a three-year-old investigation of corruption in the department.

title: THE GROWING APPEAL OF TRANSIT ADVERTISING
description: ''You don't have to be Jewish to love Levy's real Jewish rye'' is, by most accounts, one of the best- remembered advertising slogans in New York history. What many people may not remember is that the ads, which ran during the 1960's and 70's and highlighted people of different ethnic backgrounds, appeared almost exclusively in the city's subways.

title: DODGERS DEFEATED BY GIANTS IN 11TH
description: Joel Youngblood's pinch-hit single brought Chili Davis home with the deciding run in the 11th inning today as the San Francisco Giants snapped the Dodgers' five-game winning streak, 8-6.

title: Quake Shakes East Austria
description: An earthquake measuring 4.5 to 4.7 on the open- ended Richter scale shook sections of eastern Austria soon after noon today, causing minor damage, the state-run Austrian television said.

title: WEILL'S OPERA 'DOWN IN THE VALLEY'
description: THE Channel 13 telecast tonight at 9 o'clock of ''Down in the Valley,'' Kurt Weill's ''American folk opera,'' offers a fascinating glimpse into Weill's American period and the sort of folkish Americana that so influenced the ''serious'' musical world in this country during the 1930's and 40's.

title: CHINA TO PRESS REAGAN ON TAIWAN ARMS
description: The Chinese leadership is ready to press the issue of United States arms sales to Taiwan when President Reagan visits China next week, a leading foreign affairs magazine here has indicated.

title: Investigator in Crash Tells of Tranquilizers
description: Large doses of tranquilizers had been prescribed for a sheriff's sergeant involved in a collision that killed three Secret Service agents riding ahead of a motorcade for Queen Elizabeth II, a Federal investigator says in court documents.

title: TEXT OF MOYNIHAN STATEMENT
description: Following is the text of the statement issued here today by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan:

title: Bid for Scott & Fetzer Made
description: Top officers of the Scott & Fetzer Company have offered to purchase it for $360 million in cash, the company said yesterday. Its board is studying the plan, which was submitted Saturday. Scott & Fetzer, based in Cleveland, produces the World Book Encyclopedia and Kirby vacuum cleaners.

title: SOME HAGGADAH SUGGESTIONS
description: Following are excerpts from suggested additions to the traditional Haggadah, which is read at the Passover seder:

title: STATE CONSIDERS ISLAND IN OCEAN AS A POWER SITE
description: A nine-year-old proposal to build an artificial island in the Atlantic as the site for four coal-fired plants that would generate electricity has been given new life by New York State.

title: Debra Kanofsky Is Married
description: The marriage of Debra Faith Kanofsky, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Kanofsky of Massapequa, L.I., to Alex Greenberg, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Greenberg of Plainview, L.I., took place yesterday. Rabbi Robert A. Raab, assisted by Cantor Bernie Barr, performed the ceremony at the Galaxie in Plainview.

title: WIDE DRUG SALES IN SUBWAY TRAINS REPORTED
description: Illegal drugs, including marijuana, heroin and cocaine, are being openly sold on trains on all of the city's subway lines and in some stations, according to a state study.

title: El Salvador Withdraws From New Orleans Fair
description: El Salvador, asserting that a joint Caribbean pavilion was misrepresented and ultimately bungled, has become the first participant to back out of the 1984 World's Fair here.

title: SIKH RAIDERS BURN PUNJABI STATIONS
description: Scores of masked Sikh terrorists, armed with guns, bombs and gasoline, set fire to at least 37 small railroad stations in the countryside of Punjab state today.

title: ISLANDERS WIN TO LEAD SERIES, 2-1
description: Since the start of April, the Islanders have been consistently outshot, outhustled and outplayed, and if any logic applied, they would be headed out of the Stanley Cup playoffs after another mediocre performance tonight.

title: Bridge: An Expert Makes Good Use Of His Opponent's Troubles
description: Minor legal misdemeanors can generate unusual positions at the bridge table, and an adaptable expert may be able to take advantage of his opponent's misfortune.

title: CACOPHONY IN THE SEARCH FOR A MELODY
description: Californians are battling these days over a melody.

title: WILLIAMS STILL LACKING REINS FOR HIS CREATIVITY
description: IN airport and hotel video-game

title: HEWLETT-PACKARD PLANS LIGHTWEIGHT COMPUTER
description: DAVID E. SANGER

title: FIVE-SHOT VICTORY FOR MISS OKAMOTO
description: Ayako Okamoto of Japan turned back early pressure from Donna H. White and scored a five-stroke victory today in the J & B Scotch Pro-Am golf tournament.

title: YANKEES WIN ON FLY-BALL HIT
description: Ron Reed headed off the mound and toward the Chicago White Sox dugout sure that the ball would be caught for the third out in the 10th inning yesterday.

title: Ice Jams Shut River In Midwest to Ships By The Associated Press
description: The St. Clair River was closed to vessel traffic yesterday as five American icebreakers and one Canadian counterpart continued working to clear the ice that has clogged the river more than a week, a United States Coast Guard official said.

title: Latvia's K.G.B. Chief Becomes Party Leader
description: A Soviet Communist Party official who headed the K.G.B. internal security agency of Soviet Latvia for more than three years has been made the Latvian First Secretary, in effect the Baltic republic's leader.

title: PRISON IS CHARGED WITH LAX SECURITY
description: At Fort Pillow State Prison, the scene of two recent breakouts involving nine prisoners, employees sell guns and drugs to inmates, security is lax and officials ignored warnings of an escape in which three people subsequently died, a state report says.

title: Brother of Aquino Joins 137 in Protest Fast
description: A brother of Benigno S. Aquino Jr., the slain opposition leader, and 137 other Filipinos began a fast today to dramatize their opposition to the Government of Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of April 16, 1984: MONDAY Bally MfgInter First CorpDana CorpLilly (Eli) & CoGould IncSouthern Co TUESDAY Amer CyanamidK Mart CorpBelo (A H) CorpScott PaperChase Manhattan CpSecurity PacificDr Pepper CoSmucker (J M) CoDonaldson Lufkin Southern Ind G & EEnserch CorpStauffer ChemicalGt Western FinlTexas IndusHoneywell IncV F Corp WEDNESDAY Alberto-CulverDow Jones & CoBanc Texas GroupDun & BradstreetBard (C R)Newhall Land & FrmgBearings IncOwens-IllinoisBurlington IndusPNB Mtge & Rlty InvConrac CorpSouthern UnionContinental GroupWisc Pwr & Lt THURSDAY Acme ElecLee EnterprisesAlagasco IncLegg MasonAmer Water WksMidland-RossAmer Hotels & RltyOwens-Corning FibgerBlack & Decker MfgParker-HannifinCBI IndusPPG IndusCentl Louisiana ElecPotomac Elec PwrDiamond ShamrockPulte Home CorpFirst Wisc CorpResearch-CottrellGeneral HostReynolds (R J) IndusGeneral Signal CorpSunstrand CorpGillette CoThomas IndusIowa-Ill G & EUMC IndusJohnson & JohnsonWeyerhaeuser Co FRIDAY Communications SatWachovia CorpScientific-Atlanta

title: Clashes in Third Day At Frankfurt Runway
description: Demonstrators and riot policemen clashed for a third day today at the new runway at Frankfurt Airport. One demonstrator was arrested and several others were taken into custody and later released.

title: SWALE NOW HEAD OF FIELD FOR DERBY
description: Swale, the current favorite for the Kentucky Derby on May 5, will probably skip the Preakness Stakes even if he wins the Derby, which would mean forfeiting a chance at racing's Triple Crown, his owner said today.

title: School Sniping Victim Dies
description: Carlos Lopez, wounded by a sniper who opened fire on a crowded schoolyard, died Friday of his injuries, officials at Martin Luther King Jr. Hospital said. Mr. Lopez, 24 years old, was shot twice in the abdomen in the assault Feb. 24 that also left a 10-year-old girl dead. Twelve others were injured.

title: THE WAR PARTY
description: The uproar over President Reagan's covert war on Nicaragua might suggest that it is a unique or isolated policy. To the contrary, it reflects a general ideological premise of this Administration: that the United States can best deal with its problems in the world by using force and acting unilaterally, without regard to the views of friends and neighbors.

title: HOSPITALS WOO PATIENTS
description: N. R. KLEINFIELD

title: BRAZIL STRESSES ITS OIL SUCCESS
description: ALAN RIDING

title: TWO AMERICAN DIPLOMATS KILLED BY A BOMB IN SOUTH-WEST AFRICA
description: Two United States diplomats were killed in a bomb explosion Sunday at a filling station in the northern part of South-West Africa.

title: WHEN SECURITY PRE-EMPTS THE RULE OF LAW
description: While Nazi Germany prepared for war and spread its power across Europe, the United States and the civilized nations of Europe scrupulously observed the letter of international law. This prompted Winston Churchill to comment that ''it would not be right or rational that the aggressor powers should gain one set of advantages by tearing up all laws and another set by sheltering behind the innate respect for law of their opponents. Humanity, rather than legality, must be our guide.''

title: MILWAUKEE TRUSTEE EVALUATES 3 OFFERS
description: The trustee of the bankrupt Milwaukee Road has placed a value on three offers to buy the railroad's core assets. He expressed no preference between two of them, which are, as expected, within close range of each other, but said the third offer must be substantially upgraded to win Government or court approval.

title: YOUTHS AND U.S. AGENTS IN INCIDENT NEAR SOVIET SITE
description: A van carrying four teen-agers nearly ran down several members of a Federal-New York City antiterrorist stakeout team hiding outside a Soviet compound on Long Island early yesterday, Federal authorities said.

title: Question Box
description: -yard pass is completed to the defensive team's 40-yard line. The receiver then advances to the 10 before being downed, but not before a teammate clips an opponent on the 25. At which point is the penalty imposed, where the ball becomes dead or where the clip occurred?

title: ZIMBABWE BISHOPS DESCRIBE DETAILS OF ATROCITY CHARGES
description: Zimbabwe's Roman Catholic bishops offered details today of what they said were atrocities committed by Government troops fighting rebels in southern Matabeleland.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Stock Exchange has elected Daniel P. Tully vice chairman of its board of governors, succeeding Frederick B. Whittenmore, who was ineligible for re-election.

title: SPRINGTIME IN NEW YORK RENEWS POETS' CREATIVE URGE
description: In Greenwich Village, Grace Schulman touches up a poem about the blossoming of love.

title: TORN GLOVE, THEN TURNABOUT
description: They call it the Carl Brewer rule in honor of the man who made it necessary. The former National Hockey League player liked to cut holes in his gloves and let his mischievious hands slip out to perform dirty tricks on the opponents.

title: OPERETTA: VIENNA VOLKSOPER PRESENTS 'CZARDAS PRINCESS'
description: THE Vienna Volksoper's performance of ''Czardas Princess'' at the State Theater on Thursday night served to remind us that it is only a few hours by train from Vienna to Budapest.

title: THE SECOND COMEBACK
description: Last week, Richard Nixon and Henry Kissinger chose the most fashionable restaurant in New York for their lunch together: Le Cirque, where their fast-track

title: 10 IN BROOKLYN ARE FOUND SLAIN INSIDE A HOUSE
description: Ten people - three women, a teen- age girl and six children - were found shot to death last night in an apartment in a two-family home in Brooklyn. Only an infant girl was found alive, crawling among the victims.

title: Books: A Protector
description: THE GOLEM. As told by Elie Wiesel and

title: SLOWDOWN BLURS RATE VIEW
description: MICHAEL QUINT

title: ORIOLES GET 3 IN 9TH TO TOP INDIANS, 6-5
description: Wayne Gross's pinch-hit double drove in two runs to cap a three-run ninth inning as the Baltimore Orioles scored a 6-5 victory today over the Cleveland Indians.

title: THE BETTER WAY TO DEAL WITH TRADE BARRIERS AND SUBSIDIES
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 African Leaders Meet
description: Prime Minister Col. Diara Traore of Guinea met with President Abdou Diouf of Senegal today to consolidate ties between the new military leadership of Guinea and its West African neighbors.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Academic Independence

title: FOR 2 ENIGMATIC STARS, COMEBACKS CONTINUE
description: TO those involved, it seems difficult to imagine that less than four months have gone by. Lewis Schaffel, the Nets' chief operating officer, says he can't believe it; neither can Micheal Ray Richardson. They were the two principals in an agreement reached last Dec. 21, a day that in retrospect has become the most critical for the team this season.

title: C.I.A. CHIEF SEES MIGRATION, NOT MINING, AS PUBLIC WORRY
description: The Director of Central Intelligence, William J. Casey, says he believes the American public is more concerned about the wave of immigration that would follow new Soviet and Cuban gains in Central America than about reports that his agency has supervised the mining of Nicaraguan harbors, according to an interview in U.S. News & World Report.

title: MINNEAPOLIS FEARS LOSING THE TWINS
description: The prospect of a vanishing baseball franchise is troubling this city.

title: Uruguay Government Closes Two Opposition Publications
description: Uruguay's military Government has closed the opposition newspaper Cinco Dias and magazine Frente Amplia, the editor of Cinco Dias said Saturday.

title: MONDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. Chicago White Sox , at Yankee Stadium, 1 P.M. Phil Niekro, the Yankee starter, has been a notoriously slow starter over his long career, but at 2-0 he is the team's most successful pitcher this season.

title: Martin Is Jailed as Drunk
description: Billy Martin, the former Yankee manager, was booked early Saturday by the Newport Beach police for an investigation of public drunkenness and disorderly conduct at a home in this suburb. Neighbors had complained of hearing a loud argument.

title: Futures/Options; Questions On Marsh Loss
description: A WEEK ago today, the Treasury bond futures market was stunned when the Marsh & McLennan Companies, the nation's largest insurance broker, announced it was writing down its first-quarter earnings by $60 million because of losses in the bond market. A write-down of that size would normally indicate that the actual losses were at least twice that much.

title: COMMUTER PLANE LIFTS SAAB'S HOPES
description: BARNABY J. FEDER

title: TWO BOWATERS INSTEAD OF ONE
description: Last month, when the normally cautious Bowater Corporation announced plans to spin off its North American operations, analysts welcomed the gamble with almost universal praise, and the company's stock jumped 20 percent in one week on the London Stock Exchange.

title: Casino Workers' Union Aide Held on Jersey Drug Charges
description: An official of the largest casino workers' union was being held in the Camden County jail today on charges of possession and intention to sell narcotics after about $30,000 worth of drugs and $87,000 in cash were found in raids on his hotel room and home, state police officials said.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Get Out of Jail Free
description: The air rings with talk of lotteries. New York took in nearly $1 billion in Lotto tickets last year and Governor Cuomo wanted a new sports lottery. In a recent Op-Ed page article, Alfred Tella, an economist, urged a Federal lottery with a $35 million prize every Saturday, to reduce the deficit.

title: MUSIC: BLOCH'S 'SCHELOMO'
description: WHEN called upon to become one of the sudden substitutes for Zubin Mehta at the New York Philharmonic this spring - the music director is recuperating from elbow surgery - Andrew Davis kept the originally planned solo vehicle but replaced the rest of the program with pieces of his own choosing.

title: Ken Dryden Scores
description: MY friend Jane has never seen a hockey game, but she thinks she's on the verge of becoming a hockey fan after all the excitement over the recent Ranger-Islander series. I would recommend two things: Try to catch a playoff game on television this week and then read ''The Game'' by Ken Dryden.

title: LET'S BUILD A DEFICIT SINKING FUND
description: To the Editor:

title: EUDORA WELTY CELEBRATED ON HER 75TH BIRTHDAY
description: With champagne and sighs, with flowers and peacock feathers, old friends and new worshipers alike gathered in this quiet Southern capital Friday to celebrate the 75th birthday of Eudora Welty. Miss Welty, a gentle and gracious Mississippian, accepted it all - analyses of her work by European and American scholars, parties, receptions, interviews - with serenity.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: CLEVELAND SPARKS JACKSON CAMPAIGN
description: At the downtown Convention Center here, the predominantly black audience that had come to greet the Rev. Jesse Jackson heard the Interfaith Rainbow Coalition Choir sing ''God Put a Rainbow in the Sky,'' and those on the platform read a ''Rainbow Litany.''

title: PHOTO SHOWS COMET IS IN RIGHT POSITION FOR '85 RENDEZVOUS
description: Astronomers at the Kitt Peak National Observatory in Arizona have located a faint comet, known as Giacobini-Zinner, which is the target of the world's first space mission to a comet, the National Science Foundation reported today.

title: 'Invention,' Soviet Says Of Pentagon's Report
description: Soviet press outlets said today that a Pentagon report on Soviet military might is a ''hackneyed invention'' aimed at misleading the public.

title: Talbot Keeps Title
description: Mark Talbot of Alston, Mass., successfully defended his title in the Rolex-United States Open Squash Racquets championships by defeating Tom Page of New York in straight sets, 15-13, 15-11, 15-10, yesterday afternoon at the Yale Club. Page is ranked eighth in the world.

title: LEE HART: OUTSPOKEN PARTNER, BUT NOT AN ADVISER
description: Lee Hart is an outspoken woman who says what she thinks about almost everything, but she is not ready to be specific about what her program might be should she become the First Lady. She has no doubt, however, that the position is ''one of the greatest platforms for women in this country today.''

title: Wrong Medicine in Bottles Prompts Recall of Heart Pills
description: The Kroger Company is recalling 2,000 bottles of a prescription medicine because they may contain a drug different from what it says on the label.

title: IN MEXICO CITY TRAFFIC, HAWKERS AND FIRE-EATERS
description: A person stewing in one of Mexico City's legendary traffic jams these days faces a parade of vendors, sweeping toward him with a panoply of goods.

description: Four new account assignments were announced Friday.

title: REBOUND NO. 1,000 FOR NETS' WILLIAMS

title: NICARAGUAN REBELS REPORTED TO SEIZE A TOWN

title: SHOWTIME SERIES OFFERS 'PRINCESS AND THE PEA'
description: THE ''Faerie Tale Theater'' series on Showtime, the pay- television service, continues to be one of the more charming exercises devised for cable television. Getting its first run tonight at 8 is an adaptation of ''The Princess and the Pea,'' the fable that served as the basis for the stage musical ''Once Upon a Mattress'' that opened 25 years ago and starred Carol Burnett and Joe Bova. This new nonmusical but equally broad version features Liza Minnelli as Princess Alecia and Tom Conti as Prince Richard.

title: Advertising; Broadcast Role Set By Gould

title: CONCERT: ANNA RUSSELL IN A FAREWELL TO NEW YORK
description: COMEDY is one of the great mysteries of human existence. As Kierkegaard put it, either you laugh or you don't. Anna Russell has long been one of those musical comedians who know the secret of creating laughter in long, loud spasms. A shameless clown in the tradition of Gerald Hoffnung, Victor Borge, Peter Schickele and Jack Benny, she plays on funnybones like a virtuoso glockenspielist.

Ben Crenshaw , the Masters champion, has been sued for divorce in a Texas court by his wife, Polly , on grounds of irreconcilable differences. . . . Gunther Behnke , a 7-foot-4-inch center from West Germany, has signed a letter of intent to play college basketball for the University of Kentucky. Behnke was, a member of the West German Olympic team. . . . Keith Lee , the Memphis State forward, has turned down an invitation to try out for the 1984 Olympic team, citing a heavy class load and the illness of his mother. . . . A Federal judge yesterday denied a request for a temporary restraining order sought by the Chicago Bears wide receiver Willie Gault , who is attempting to compete in the Olympics despite his professional status.

title: No Headline
description: Rolling Up Taxes at Deficit Gap Members of Congress have recessed for a week to report home about how responsibly they're attacking that old devil, the deficit. Well, they are and they aren't. Both houses have voted to raise more revenue over the next three years. Considering the President's reluctant leadership, there's more to celebrate than to deplore in what they've done so far. But even when they finish, the most important fiscal reforms will remain undone.

title: IN THE MIDEAST, A COLD PEACE
description: The Passover season seems to exert a peculiar attraction for Israelis to ''go down to Egypt,'' to use the biblical term for the journey to the land that our ancestors left some 3,500 years ago. I recently went to Cairo in search of an answer to the vexing question, What is the state of Egyptian-Israeli relations five years after the signing of the peace treaty? And after an extensive round of talks with leading officials, I returned with the impression that peace is alive, although not exactly kicking, at the moment. Egypt's Minister of State, Butros Ghali, is not far from the truth when he describes the current mood as a ''cold peace.'' True, the Israeli flag flies not only over our embassy but also over the impressive Israeli pavilion at the annual international Cairo trade fair. The Israel Academic Center has been functioning for nearly two years, organizing meetings between Egyptian and Israeli academics. Israeli tourists enjoy the warm welcome of ordinary Egyptian citizens and mingle freely without offense with Arab visitors from hostile countries. Airline and bus companies provide connections between the two countries, and Israeli ships pass freely through the Suez Canal. But there is a darker side to the coin. Cairo restricts Egyptian tourism and trade with Israel. Cultural relations, which had made a promising start, are virtually at a standstill. The Egyptian Ambassador, recalled 18 months ago in the wake of the terrible outrage committed by Lebanese Gideon Rafael, former director general of Israel's Foreign Ministry, is author of ''Destination Peace: Three Decades of Israeli Foreign Policy.''

Most importantly and most subtly, it is here that we encounter competing visions of governance.

title: Interleague Deal Looms
description: The New England Patriots aren't saying anything, and the Washington Federals aren't saying much, but it appears that the Washington running back Craig James may be on his way to a change of teams and leagues. The Federals say he has been given permission to talk with the Patriots, and James, who has been sidelined six weeks with a knee-ligament injury and is not expected to return to action for two more weeks, was reportedly being examined by the Patriots' team physician yesterday.

title: Dome Reaches Debt Accord

title: REPUBLIC STEEL LOSS WIDENS
description: The Republic Steel Corporation, the nation's fourth-largest steelmaker, yesterday reported a net loss of $36.7 million in the first quarter. Although this was worse than the $34.8 million loss the Cleveland-based steelmaker reported a year earlier, the 1983 figure included a $16.4 million gain for an accounting change and a $48 million gain for the sale of income tax credits. Republic's sales were up strongly, rising to $878.3 million, from $679 million.

title: BANKRUPTCY COURT DENIES DELOREAN'S CLAIM TO FUNDS

title: Navy to Base Major Vessels In Port in Washington State
description: The Navy plans to base a new 15-ship aircraft carrier battle group in Everett, Wash., starting in late 1988, the Pentagon announced today. The move is in line with a broad policy adopted in late 1982 of spreading out the fleet to more ports in the United States, to reduce vulnerability to attack.

WEDNESDAY, APRIL 18, 1984 International
description: A London police officer was killed and 10 people were wounded as machine- gun fire from the Libyan Embassy raked a group of Libyans protesting the Government of Muammar el-Qaddafi. The police, who said the shots were fired by a lone gunman without warning, surrounded the building. The gunman and staff members of the embassy remained behind locked doors and shuttered windows into the night. (Page A1, Column 6.) The C.I.A. directed a sabotage raid against the key Nicaraguan port of Corinto last October, destroying 3.2 million gallons of fuel and forcing the town's evacuation, according to Congressional informants. They said that, like the mining of Nicaragua's harbors that began in January, the Corinto raid was carried out by Latin mercenaries working for the C.I.A. who reached the port by speedboat from an offshore mother ship where American intelligence agents directed the operation. (A1:2.)

title: PLAY PUBLISHER RELOCATES AFTER MIDTOWN RENT RISE
description: Sixty years ago the Samuel French Company moved uptown from West 38th Street, following the northerly movement of the legitimate theaters on which the concern had based its business of representing writers, publishing plays, collecting royalties and selling books on the theater.

title: LAWS RESTRICT BRITISH ACTION AGAINST LIBYA
description: International law dictates broad immunity for accredited diplomats and makes embassy grounds inviolable, limiting the British Government's ability to act against those responsible for the shootings from the Libyan Embassy in London today.

title: FESTIVAL OF JAZZ LISTS DATES
description: The annual Kool Jazz Festival-New York, which originated 31 years ago in Newport, R.I., as the Newport Jazz Festival, will run for 10 days this year - from June 22 through July 1. Along with such established jazz stars as Oscar Peterson, Sarah Vaughan, Stan Getz, Lionel Hampton, George Shearing, Dizzy Gillespie, J. J. Johnson, Benny Carter, Count Basie and Sonny Rollins, the 1984 festival will include a program with the avant-garde composer Philip Glass and the Philip Glass Ensemble in Carnegie Hall on June 27.

title: Florida State Update
description: A special commission investigating athletics at Florida State has recommended that student-athletes no longer be housed in separate dormitories, that no courses of study be dominated by athletes and that the use of correspondence courses for athletes be limited. The commission was appointed last year by Florida State's president, Bernard Sliger , after the athletic department had been rocked by a series of scandals, including accusations that players had been given inflated grades, allowed to cheat on correspondence courses and given spending money. Although in general calling for athletes not to be given special treatment, the commission did make one recommendation that could make college life easier for them: It suggested that those who must spend 20 or more hours a week participating in sports should be allowed to carry a lighter course load than other students.

title: AGGRESSIVE C.I.A. CHIEF
description: As debate over the United States involvement in the mining of Nicaraguan harbors has grown in recent weeks, William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, has become the central figure in the dispute. Although the mining was recommended by an interagency committee and approved by President Reagan, Administration officials have said the operation was ultimately Mr. Casey's project from inception to execution. They said it was a quintessential reflection of Mr. Casey's aggressive, action-oriented leadership and determination to confront what he believes to be Communist subversion in Central America.

BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: ADIEUX: A Farewell to Sartre. By Simone de Beauvoir. 453 Pages. Pantheon Books. $19.95. WHILE ''Adieux'' is a moving portrait of Jean-Paul Sartre in the last 10 years of his life, it is not a flattering one. Sartre was chronically ill during that time and half blind, unable to read, toward the end. The prospect of dying did not seem to concentrate his mind. Rather, he appears to be more diffuse, as if in his philosophy of engagement, or commitment, he felt the approach of death to be a disengagement or remitting.

title: HERS
description: THINGS have been going well for me recently. I've been on a roll. You'd think this would make me happy, but I'm superstitious. I believe someone up there keeps track and allows only a certain amount of good luck. At any moment I expect to be hit by a tidal wave of misfortune. Recently my son, playing at school, hurt his knee - painfully but not seriously, as it turned out. When he called to tell me I wasn't surprised; something like that was bound to happen. Teddy and I got off easily - this time.

Though some of these tapes have been around for years, many homeowners and apartment dwellers don't realize how useful they are in mending, sealing, repairing, bonding and protecting all kinds of surfaces and materials inside and out.

title: A LOOK AT GOVERNMENT REGULATION
description: DEREGULATION is a political issue, a point made in 1980 when Ronald Reagan campaigned with a promise to get ''the Government off the back of industry.'' As President, he tried to fulfill the promise, and appointed the Task Force on Regulatory Relief. Some of the consequences are examined on ''Assault on Big Brother . . . Regulating the Regulators,'' on NBC-TV at 10 P.M. tomorrow.

title: Sunshine, at Last, for the Disabled
description: Faced with adverse court decisions, a revolt of state officials, bad publicity and a virtually unanimous defeat in the House, the Reagan Administration has finally stopped trying to cut benefits for the disabled under the guise of reducing fraud. There is urgent need for a public redefinition and repair of the mismanaged Social Security disability insurance program.

title: RESPECT WORLD LAW
description: Internation al law, never a dominating force in world affairs, has taken a battering in recent years. Many Americans seem indifferent to this trend and even scornful of the rule of law. In this, they are courting disaster. They do not see that it is in the interest of the United States, which stands to lose the most in a state of world anarchy, to take the lead in upholding international law and and the institutions than can protect it.

title: THE ARTISTIC BLENDING OF PLAYWRIGHTS AND PAINTERS
description: PLAYWRIGHTS and painters have had a long and mutually rewarding relationship. Lives of artists have been dramatized on stage (and on screen), and artists such as Picasso and Kandinsky have written for the theater. Paintings have played important roles in plays, most notably Bo"cklin's ''Island of the Dead,'' which provides the haunting climax of Strindberg's ''Ghost Sonata.'' Occasionally a work, such as Tom Stoppard's ''After Magritte,'' has used an artist as thematic source. There have also been frequent attempts at living tableaux on stage, as in the Talking Band's ''Gioconda and Si-Ya-U,'' a comedy- mystery in which actors posed in the manner of such paintings as Pierre Cot's ''Storm.''

title: CORRECTION

The Columbia announcement also misidentified the prize administrator; he is Robert C. Christopher.

title: CITY CAR OWNERS: JOYS AND SORROWS
description: FOR many, to live in Manhattan is to agree to forgo full-time use of an automobile. Most prosperous Manhattanites who own cars do not use them in the city; traffic is too frantic, vandalism too rampant, parking facilities inadequate and alternate-side-of-the-street parking rules too complicated.

title: CONCERT: JUDITH BLEGEN SINGS
description: THE Sunday evening concert at Alice Tully Hall by the soprano Judith Blegen was a gentle delight. Miss Blegen has a graceful stage presence, a lustrous, airy voice and irrepressible lyrical instincts.

title: Texaco Eurobond

Last month the company issued $1 billion of a convertible Eurobond. Guaranteed by Texaco, the bonds are issued through the company's subsidiary in the Netherlands Antilles, Texaco Capital N.V. The bonds will be convertible into 20 shares of Texaco common stock for each $1,000 par value, or $50 a share.

Among the more interesting handcrafted pieces that use the Formica Corporation's ColorCore surfacing material are Wendell Castle's coffee table, above left (not for sale); Garry Knox Bennett's divided Eames chair, above far left ($1,400); his lavish partner's desk, left, with gold-plated details ($12,000), and Mitch Ryerson's Victorian hall stand of inventive primary-colored latticework ($6,000).

Both situations may lead to fatigue, chronic eyestrain and headaches.
