LTV China Order DALLAS, April 18 (Reuters) - The LTV Corporation said its Continental Emsco Energy Products subsidiary had received a $22 million order from the China for 20 self-propelled rigs and related equipment. The sale, to the China National Machinery Import and Export Corporation, includes spare parts for the rigs and drilling equipment. LTV said the equipment is expected to be delivered over the next eight months. The company previously has delivered 31 oil rigs to China.;  ; Investor Seeks Union Planters

title: STAGE: MUSICAL 'MANDRAKE' BY SOHO
description: ''MANDRAKE'' is the kind of musical that Cole Porter might have written had he survived into the age when actors could casually toss around four-letter words. Based on Machiavelli's 16th-century satirical comedy ''La Mandragola,'' it portrays a Florentine society obsessed with sex, money and ''image.'' Though the church is still powerful, in the words of Fra Timoteo, the local priest: ''Attendance has dropped from its medieval peak. Devotion is no longer chic.''

title: THURSDAY, APRIL 19, 1984 International
description: The NATO allies initiated a new approach to the Soviet bloc in an effort to break a long deadlock in the negotiations in Vienna on reducing conventional forces in central Europe, Administration officials said. Under the plan, the NATO countries would no longer insist that the two sides agree on how many troops they now have in the region. (Page A1, Column 6.) Chemical weapons would be banned under a United States proposal offered by Vice President Bush. Addressing the Geneva Conference on Disarmament, Mr. Bush said the United States was ''willing to pay the price'' of openness by allowing inspections on short notice to verify compliance. (A13:1-3.)

title: USING PLASMA TO MAKE IRON
description: GARY A. LAMPPA, commissioner of the Minnesota Department of Iron Range Resources and Rehabilitation, has a vision of bringing in a new method of metallurgy - plasma technology - to save his state's old iron ore towns. Plasma technology, once used to test space vehicles by heating them to the temperatures they face when re-entering the atmosphere, uses superhot electrically heated gases that are extremely efficient in melting metals. Mr. Lamppa believes it could help revive the ailing iron ore towns by enabling mills there to convert iron ore into iron right at the mouth of the state's ore mines. The mills, he hopes, would then turn the iron into steel and finally into semifinished slabs more cheaply than most domestic steelmakers can produce them.

title: Top Back Breaks Leg
description: Sam Harrell , the Houston Gambler back who is leading the United States Football League in rushing, suffered a broken leg in Monday night's victory over the Oakland Invaders and will be out four to six weeks, the club announced yesterday. The injury occurred late in the game after Harrell had scored 2 touchdowns, bringing his season total to 13, and as he was gaining his 154th yard of the night.

title: Miss Budd Withdraws
description: She may have acquired British citizenship in quick time, but Zola Budd is apparently going to have to do more than run like the wind to win over the hearts of the British people. The 17-year-old barefoot runner from South Africa withdrew from a 1,500- meter race in Crawley, Sussex, to be run Saturday after the Crawley Council had expressed misgivings about her appearance. The race will inaugurate Crawley's $450,000 sports arena, and Mayor Alf Pegler said members of the Council had been concerned that the local significance of the event would be overshadowed by ''political connotations and anti- apartheid demonstrators.''

title: Gulf Delay Sought

The F.T.C. is scheduled to vote Thursday on whether to take no action against the merger, require the combined company to spin off some operations or ask a Federal court to block the entire deal. But F.T.C. officials said the agency's staff was not ready to make any recommendation this week.

'ROUND MY FATHER,' STARRING OLIVIER
description: ''VOYAGE Round My Father,'' tonight's Mobil Showcase presentation on WNEW-TV at 8 o'clock, seems to have been tailored for television even though it was originally produced in 1969 as a play for BBC radio and then, in the early 1970's, for the British stage. John Mortimer's subject is his father, a dedicatedly eccentric Englishman who suddenly becomes blind and decides to ignore it. On the London stage, Clifford Mortimer was played by Alec Guiness, who was later succeeded by Michael Redgrave. This television version stars Laurence Olivier. The role clearly is a magnet for distinguished actors. In addition, Lord Olivier is joined by Alan Bates as the son through whose eyes we see the father.

ART: A VIEW OF THE BLUE FOUR AND EXPRESSIONISM
description: ONE consequence of a widespread interest in an artistic style, such as Expressionism, is that everything in the back rooms, attics and closets of art history that is at all related to that style is likely to find its way onto gallery walls. One of the most serious of the recent historical exhibitions related to Expressionism is a show devoted to the Blue Four, at the Leonard Hutton Gallery, 33 East 74th Street, through May 24. It is a pleasant exhibition that is not likely to tell us a great deal we did not already know.

title: PHILHARMONIC: REQUIEM BY BRAHMS
description: THE ''German Requiem'' of Brahms represents him in his most resigned, world-weary mood. Not that he is the liveliest of composers even when he is in good spirits. George Bernard Shaw, who spent much of his early days as a critic attacking Brahms, once complained that he was the sort of fellow who, when he felt really cheerful, would write ''The grave is my goal.'' There is truth to that Shavian joke, of course, but the deeper truth is that Brahms was one of those rare composers who understand themselves and know how to dig into their psyches and find music that expresses their own peculiar view of existence.

title: 3 VIGOROUS ARTISTS FROM DOWN UNDER
description: ''AN AUSTRALIAN ACCENT'' at P. S. 1, 46-01 21st Street in Long Island City, is an exhibition with quite exceptional expressive power. The three artists involved, Mike Parr, Imants Tillers and Ken Unsworth, are image makers (and, sometimes, image scavengers) of a driving, obsessional and visionary sort. Their pictures come freighted with dreams, often of a complex and disquieting kind, and the idioms employed allow of a rapid and comprehensive attack upon a vast range of problems - emotional, conceptual, esthetic and perceptual.

title: Watching film makersin New York.
description: NOTHING tests the New Yorker's studied nonchalance like a movie crew. And no crew has been more visible lately than the one for ''Falling in Love,'' which for several weeks has been occupying Grand Central Terminal. The film, which stars Meryl Streep and Robert De Niro and is being directed by Ulu Grosbard, has attracted its share of onlookers, of course. But many of them have been blase enough to ask, ''Is this a commercial, or what?'' and leave it at that. Only infrequently has the footage been ruined by onlookers, like one who interrupted a street scene near Saks Fifth Avenue to ask, ''Hey, Meryl, how's the baby?''

title: FRENCH ALLIANCE WEATHERS STORM AS COMMUNISTS BACK MITTERRAND
description: The left-wing alliance between the Socialist and Communist parties, threatened by a dispute over Government-initiated job cutbacks in heavy industry, was reaffirmed today under weakened conditions in a vote of confidence at the National Assembly.

title: New Jersey
description: An ''Easter Art Hunt'' at Princeton University's Art Museum tomorrow morning has the usual trappings of a holiday search - eager children, a gaily decorated basket and about three dozens eggs of various hues. But i Martha Schlossstein, a museum lecturer, has devised a game that guarantees children will be taking a close look at the museum's offerings. First, the youngsters are divided into groups. One child in each draws an egg from the basket. It contains a clue about a painting or display. Each group searches the galleries until it finds the art work that matches its clue. The child who drew the egg has to offer a comment on the art.

title: DIXIE CARTER, A TV STAR WHOSE HEART IS IN CABARET
description: TO millions of people, the name Dixie Carter is connected mainly with prime- time television, a world very distant in spirit from the intimate cabaret environment of Freddy's Supper Club, 308 East 49th Street, where she is appearing through April 28. The 43-year-old singer-actress, who is riding high with the NBC situation comedy ''Diff'rent Strokes,'' became a full-fledged television star last year playing Carlotta Beck, the snobbish wife of a plantation owner on the short-lived nighttime soap opera ''Filthy Rich.'' But cabaret, not television, is where her heart is.

title: HUDSON VALLEY
description: Each year in mid-April, pale pink blossoms burst forth on eight Japanese weeping-cherry trees at Boscobel, the stately Federal home that stands on a bluff overlooking the Hudson River at Garrison in Putnam County. Other flowers in bloom at this time of year include blue pansies, early tulips and daffodils. Boscobel is the restored home of States Morris Dyckman, dating back to 1804. The mansion is refurnished as a museum of Federal furniture, including pieces by Duncan Phyfe and English china, silver and furnishings of the period. Boscobel, with its formal gardens, is open daily from 9:30 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission is $4; $2 for those 6 to 14 years old. The scenic way there by car from New York City is across the George Washington Bridge, taking the Palisades Interstate Parkway north to the Bear Mountain Bridge, crossing the bridge and then making a sharp left turn on Route 9D, north to the entrance.

title: Court Bars Mother's Plea
description: The Colorado Supreme Court today denied the petition of a fundamentalist Christian to end the imprisonment she is suffering in silence to hide her son from her former husband. A lower court jailed Betty Lou Batey April 12 until she would tell friends in her church to bring the boy, Brian Batey, 12 years old, to court. She placed him with them to hide him from his father, Frank, a Californian who is a homosexual. Mr. Batey is Brian's legal guardian.

title: Automobile in Art
description: The Whitney Museum of American Art in Fairfield County in Stamford Conn., is exhibiting ''Autoscape: The Automobile in the American Landscape,'' a survey of the automobile in American art, tonight through June 6. More than 50 paintings, photographs and sculptures, illustrating how American artists have interpreted the presence of the automobile, are included. The museum, which is open free Tuesday through Saturday, 11 A.M. to 5 P.M., is housed in the Champion International Corporation building, One Champion Plaza, in downtown Stamford.

title: Michelin Layoffs
description: Michelin, the world's second-largest tire maker, told labor representatives here that it would lay off 4,920 of its 46,000 workers by the end of next year because of a depressed world tire market. Michelin said the planned job cuts are the latest in a series announced in recent months by French heavy industries to reduce overstaffing and modernize operations.

title: CHEMICAL ARMS MUST BE BANNED
description: Vice President Bush unveiled in Geneva this week a United States proposal for a comprehensive worldwide ban on chemical weapons. Moscow promptly labeled the proposal - described by Pravda earlier in the week as a lot of ''noise'' - a propaganda ploy containing ''patently unacceptable conditions for verification.'' No doubt about it: Chemical weapons pose some of the most confounding verification problems encountered in the vast realm of arms control. Kenneth L. Adelman is the director of the Arms Control and Disarmanent Agency. For this very reason, the United States will be seeking some new and rather bold approaches, including an ''open invitation'' for international inspection on short notice of all military and government-controlled facilities. Overcoming the problems of verification is essential. Arms control is empty without compliance, and compliance without verification, particularly in a closed society, is impossible to establish. A ban on chemical weapons honored by open societies and violated by closed societies would be no ban at all. It would be unilateral disarmament in the guise of multilateral arms control.

title: DISCRIMINATION AIDED
description: The Supreme Court's recent decision involving Grove City College has undermined Title IX of the 1972 education amendment, which prohibits sexual discrimination by educational institutions that receive Federal financial assistance. In the absence of Congressional action, the decision will very likely be used by the Justice Department to eviscerate similar Federal guarantees against discrimination toward minority people, the elderly and the disabled, thereby dismantling more than 20 years of civil rights progress.

title: Westchester
description: A profusion of spring flowers and even a crop of spring lambs will be part of the attraction this weekend at the historic sites maintained along the Hudson River by Sleepy Hollow Restorations. Daffodils and hyacinths will be featured at Sunnyside, Washington Irving's home in Tarrytown, and at Van Cortlandt Manor, the early Dutch manor house maintained in Croton-on-Hudson. The lambs can be seen at Philipsburg Manor, the restored 18th-century Dutch farmstead in North Tarrytown. The flowers and the lambs are something extra to be enjoyed along with a sense of history at the three landmarks, which are reached from Route 9. They are open 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. every day, and admission is $4; $2.50 for children and the elderly, and free for under-6's. Combination tickets are available. For information, (914) 631-8200

DINER'S JOURNAL
description: CZECHOSLOVAK restaurants are not among the trendiest nightspots in town - when was the last time you heard someone coo about a darling little place that serves the most divine bramborova polevka? Nonetheless, if you are looking for a stick-to-the-ribs square meal at reasonable prices, try the beef tenderloin with cream sauce and bread dumplings at Ruc, 312 East 72d Street, between First and Second Avenues. This typical Czechoslovak dish, which costs $14, features strips of tenderloin in a mild white sauce accompanied by a sprightly cucumber salad. While the meat is lean and tasty, the dumplings are outstanding. Unlike the circular dumplings served in Chinese and many Eastern European restaurants, these are thick, toast-shape slabs made from flour, eggs and cubes of bread. When boiled, the combination becomes firm and somewhat elastic.

title: NEW DAY IS CELEBRATED FOR UNION SQUARE PARK

description: United States diplomats here said today that they could not rule out the possibility that two American helicopters that came under fire Wednesday may have strayed over rebel-controlled territory in El Salvador.

Shultz, according to Reagan Administration officials. (A1:5.)

title: CHEERLESS DAY FOR GENERALS
description: The pay was low, the work was hard, and the job conditions were occasionally dismal. But for many determined young women on the fringes of show business in the New York area, the positions offered the ultimate lures: glamour and the prospect of fame.

title: LETTER TO NICARAGUA: 'DEAR COMANDANTE'
description: Members of Congress are always writing ''Dear Colleague'' letters to other members, promoting a bill or noting an event. Now 10 Democratic lawmakers have written a ''Dear Comandante'' letter that is kicking up a fuss on Capitol Hill.

title: California Poll Reports Mondale Trails Reagan
description: Mervin D. Field, who runs the California Poll, reported today that former Vice President Walter F. Mondale trailed President Reagan, 52 percent to 44 percent, among a representative sample of California voters. He said the President and Senator Gary Hart were each supported by 48 percent.

description: China said today that over the last week its artillery killed or wounded several hundred Vietnamese soldiers and destroyed guns and vehicles along its border with Vietnam.

title: National League; Cubs Win in 10th CHICAGO, April 20 (UPI) - Ryne Sandberg hit a triple to lead off the last of the 10th inning and scored on a one-out, bases-loaded single by Mel Hall to give the Chicago Cubs a 5-4 victory today over the Pittsburgh Pirates.
description: Sandberg's hit, which went over the head of Doug Frobel in left field, came off Kent Tekulve (0-1), and the Pirates then walked Gary Matthews and Bill Buckner intentionally to load the bases. Ron Cey hit a grounder to the shortstop and Sandberg was forced out at the plate before Hall delivered his game-winning hit to left field.

But occasionally, it has an opportunity to present a dance program of its own, and it offered one Wednesday night in the Theater of the Riverside Church.

title: SAN FRANCISCO IS JITTERY WAITING FOR CONVENTION
description: It is but one of hundreds of conventions scheduled in San Francisco this year, and the crowd of 30,000 people will be by no means the largest ever gathered here. Nonetheless, the approach of the Democratic National Convention July 16-19 has caused the civic pulse to race.

title: POLICE ATTRIBUTE CRASH FATAL TO 5 TO NOVICE DRIVER
description: The police said yesterday that an ''inexperienced'' 18-year-old driver who got his license two weeks ago caused Thursday night's crash on the Major Deegan Expressway in the Bronx, in which he and four passengers were killed.

title: U.S. Sues on Chicago Housing
description: The Justice Department sued six Chicago area real estate concerns today, accusing them of perpetuating racial segregation by steering white home buyers to white neighborhoods and black buyers to minority or integrated areas.

title: U.S. WARNS STATES IN EASTERN EUROPE ON TERRORISM TIES
description: The Reagan Administration has told six Eastern European Governments that they cannot hope for improved relations with the United States if they continue to support Palestinian and other ''international terrorists,'' State Department officials said today.

title: 3 STATES CHECK A CANCER INSTITUTE THAT DONATED 10% TO RESEARCH
description: The Virginia-based American Institute for Cancer Research is being examined by three states and two private agencies because it gave less than 11 percent of the money it raised to research, The Los Angles Times reported today.

title: MABEL MERCER, PHRASER OF SONGS, DIES
description: Mabel Mercer, whose influence on popular music over the last half century reached far beyond the audiences who heard her sing in the intimate rooms where she usually performed, died yesterday in the Berkshire Medical Center in Pittsfield, Mass. She was 84 years old.

description: If you have been riding the subways long enough, you are prepared. You wear a long, heavy coat and never put your bookbag down. You keep it over one shoulder or hold it up against yourself. You do what you can not to touch anyone.

Carlos Castro Madero announced last November that Argentina had built a secret plant for enriching uranium, hope seemed almost dead for averting a race in nuclear weapons among Argentina, Brazil and Chile. Now, under Argentina's new leadership, prospects seem suddenly bright for keeping Latin America forever free of nuclear weapons.

title: THE WIZARDRY OF OZ
description: You can hardly keep up with the Mayor's golden announcements these days - he's going to hire 1,000 new policemen, fill all the potholes, put 300 more street-sweepers to work, throw the book at ''litterpigs'' and ''reclaim the parks'' from the thugs and muggers and druggies. This city is going to be as safe and clean and smooth and green as, well, Oz. It must be campaign time.

title: 11 ACCUSED OF CONSPIRACY IN BOGUS CREDIT-CARD RING
description: Federal officials said yesterday that they had cracked the largest credit- card counterfeiting ring ever encountered in the New York metropolitan area, one that cost banks in the region an estimated $50 million last year.

description: A Federal grand jury here is investigating allegations that an agent of the Bechtel Power Corporation in Korea made payments and gifts of more than $100,000 to South Korean officials in connection with contracts awarded Bechtel for the design of nuclear plants in Korea, according to two Justice Department officials familiar with the inquiry.

title: Niagara Mohawk Seeks Rate Rise
description: The Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation said it seeks to raise electric rates by 7.8 percent and natural gas rates by 4.4 percent. Niagara Mohawk, based in Syracuse, said it expects the increase would raise revenues by $177.2 million annually.

title: FIRE UNDER THE NOSE
description: Although pathetically addicted to cigarettes, I once gave them up for five years. It was a question of character. Anybody who couldn't whip the cigarette habit, I thought, ought to be ashamed of himself; to prove I had true grit, I decided to fight.

description: As a boxer, Randall (Tex) Cobb enjoyed success until he ran into Larry Holmes in a heavyweight championship fight in November 1982. Holmes retained his title with a unanimous decision, and Cobb hasn't fought since.

description: The Roy C. Ketcham High School, closed since ''potentially hazardous'' levels of asbestos were discovered in ceiling tiles on March 30, will reopen on Tuesday, school officials said today.

description: Samuel F. Hinkle, the principal figure in the development of Hershey's Syrup, Krackel, Mr. Goodbar and the nutritionally fortified chocolate bars first issued as K, C and D rations to armed forces in World War II, died Thursday after a long illness. Mr. Hinckle, who was 83 years old, died at the Alpine Nursing and Convalescent Center in Hershey, Pa., where he lived.

title: Briton Leads by 2
description: Nick Faldo of England, the best player in Europe last season, who is seeking his first American tournament victory, shot a 4-under-par 67 and took a 2-stroke lead today in the second round of the $400,000 Sea Pines Heritage Classic. Faldo, a three-time winner of the British P.G.A. title, had a two-round total of 133, or 9 under, at the Harbour Town Golf Links. Tom Kite, a winner in Miami earlier this season and a Masters contender until he hit into the water on the 12th hole of the final round, was Faldo's closest pursuer.

title: SAD JOHNSTOWN AWAITS DEMISE OF A STEEL PLANT
description: The workers at the United States Steel Corporation plant in this stark industrial town have committed a principled or a foolish act: They have voted themselves out of their jobs.

description: Staff members of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission have agreed with the Long Island Lighting Company that faulty diesel generators at its Shoreham nuclear power plant should not block low-power testing.

title: FUND HALT FOR SEABROOK
description: The Public Service Company of New Hampshire said today that it had stopped construction payments on the suspended Seabrook nuclear plant and had halted the conversion from oil to coal at its Schiller station power plant to save cash.

description: Colorado today filed a suit to stop deployment of MX missiles, arguing that the project would affect the state's environment even though the missiles were to be placed in Wyoming and Nebraska.

title: NEWS SUMMARY ;  SATURDAY, APRIL 21, 1984 International
description: Six Eastern European Governments were told by the Reagan Administration that they could not hope for improved relations with the United States if they continued to support Palestinian and other ''international terrorists,'' carried out espionage and sought to evade American export laws. State Department officials said the warnings were given last month to the ambassadors of Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, East Germany, Hungary, Poland and Rumania. (Page 1, Column 6.) Jose Napoleon Duarte said he would seek negogiations with Nicaragua if he is elected president of El Salvador, according to two United States Senators. The Senators, J. Bennett Johnston of Louisiana and Lawton Chiles of Florida, both Democrats, had recently visited El Salvador, Nicaragua, Honduras and Panama. (1:5.)

title: A CROISSANT BOOM IN U.S. MARKETS
description: In 1981, when sales of the traditional desserts, coffee cakes and sweet breads produced by the Kitchens of Sara Lee were faltering, the company's parent, Consolidated Foods, brought in new management. The new management took decisive action: It brought in the croissant.

title: Litton Expansion
description: Litton Industries said it plans to buy 25 acres of land in Orlando, Fla., and build a $14 million headquarters for its International Laser Systems division. An announcement from Litton's Washington office said construction is scheduled to start this summer and occupancy is expected in early 1985. Litton's Laser division employs about 400 people in developing and production of laser systems for military and law enforcement markets.

title: Joseph Weisberg Dies at 73; Publisher of a Jewish Weekly
description: Joseph G. Weisberg, editor and publisher of The Jewish Advocate, died April 9 at Massachusetts General Hospital after becoming ill at his desk in Boston, where The Advocate is published. He was 73 years old.

description: -- The Government said today that it had received a secret Libyan response to its conditions for ending the four-day-old police siege of the Libyan Embassy here. It said the British Ambassador in Libya was being instructed on how to pursue negotiations.

description: Jury duty can be dull. But the neighborhoods in which the courts are found in Manhattan most certainly are not.

title: Phone Access Charge Plan
description: The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission said today that the agency would soon modify its telephone ''access charge'' plan, but that he did not think the F.C.C. would bow to Congress and postpone for another year the new fees facing business customers.

title: 'I WILL NEVER FORGET HIS FACE'
description: Bradford Brown, convicted of murder, spent 1975 to 1979 in a Federal prison. William Jackson was locked up from 1977 to 1982 after an Ohio jury found him guilty of two rapes. Lenell Geter was in a Texas prison for 14 months, following a 1982 trial for armed robbery. Each man's conviction rested on eyewitness identifications by strangers - people, sometimes including the crime victim, who did not know the assailant before witnessing the crime. In each case, the eyewitness was wrong.

title: KING CAN'T SAVOR GAME 2 SCORING SPREE
description: Bernard King is a very intense player. After a game, he needs time to wind down before he grants interviews.

title: 23 ARE WOUNDED BY LONDON BOMB
description: Twenty-three people were wounded tonight, one seriously, when a bomb exploded in an unclaimed baggage section inside Heathrow Airport. There was no immediate indication of who might be responsible for the bombing.

title: BOSTON BANK PLANS OUT-OF-STATE UNITS
description: The Bank of Boston Corporation said yesterday that it had filed applications to establish consumer banks in 16 locations in 10 states along the East Coast and in the South, including New York City.

They were what remained after the Federal Government gave away its holdings to states, homesteaders, railroads, mining companies and schools and created the National Parks and Forests.

Here, in a country where large profits were only recently regarded as unseemly, the Government's own companies demonstrate how thoroughly the idea has taken hold.

description: For all of the excitement of their previous two games, in which they played poorly and won, the Mets managed not only to play well tonight, but also to beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 3-1, in 10 innings.

title: PAIN AND MEMORIES AT THE SERVICE FOR 10 IN BROOKLYN MASS SLAYING
description: Father, forgive them, for they know not what they do,'' the Rev. Philip F. Fabiano said yesterday at a funeral for 10 people slain last week in what officials said was the worst mass murder they could recall in New York City.

title: MORE TO COLEMAN THEN JUST LANTERNS After lighting the way for generations of campers with the same basic lantern, the Coleman Company has decided to redesign its first and still premier product.
description: The move to improve the gasoline- , kerosene- or propane-powered lanterns - they now offer adjustable, stronger light - is part of an aggressive campaign of innovation and expansion. In the past 28 months, the 84- year-old company, based in Wichita, Kan., already the largest manufacturer of camping and recreation equipment in the world, has taken over 10 new companies.

title: SAVERS FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
THE DUAL NEWS ROLES OF HODDING CARTER 3D
description: Hodding Carter 3d, the anchor of ''Inside Story,'' a public-television program that scrutinizes the news media, received payments for appearing on an ABC News program at the same time that he was working on ''Inside Story'' segments about ABC News.

title: Angels Down Jays, 10-6, in 13 TORONTO, April 20 (AP) - Consecutive doubles by Rob Picciolo, Fred Lynn and Doug DeCinces triggered a four-run 13th inning today that gave the California Angels a 10-6 victory over Toronto.
description: DeCinces also hit a sacrifice fly to tie the game in the ninth and singled a run across in the 11th as the Angels offset a performance by Toronto's Lloyd Moseby, who drove in five runs and hit the first grand slam of his career .

title: DELOREAN, IN TAPE, TELLS OF LACKING DRUG MONEY
description: In a tape recording played today at his drug trafficking trial, John Z. DeLorean was heard telling an undercover agent that he no longer had the money he needed to buy into a multimillion-dollar drug deal. Defense attorneys asserted he was telling the agent to ''get lost.''

title: JUDGE ISSUES WARRANT FOR J. DAVID'S FOUNDER
description: A judge issued a warrant today for the arrest of J. David Dominelli, a currency trader, who has apparently left the country saying he would retrieve and return to his clients up to $112 million invested in his now-bankrupt company.

title: Patriots Get James
description: The financially beleaguered Washington Federals released the running back Craig James from his expensive contract yesterday, and soon afterward the New England Patriots announced that, as expected, they had signed him. James's new deal is for three years and is reported to be worth $1 million; his contract with Washington was for four years at $2 million and had two years to run.

title: TERRATECH RESOURCES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $225,000. c-Net loss.

title: Chemical Arms Offer Condemned by Soviet
description: The Soviet Union today called the United States proposal for a treaty banning chemical weapons absurd and unacceptable.

title: ON SPYING IN THE GERMANYS,WITH NO FOULS CALLED
description: If the Soviet Union and its Warsaw Pact allies decided to go to war, one of the first people to have a hint of impending hostilities might be Col. Roland Lajoie.

title: DOW CORNING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Dow Corning is a joint 50-50 venture of Dow Chemical Co. and Corning Glass Works.

title: MARCON COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a tax benefit of $45,500.

title: Cuomo Offers Bill On Hydropower
description: Governor Cuomo submitted a bill to the Legislature today that would redistribute less-costly supplies of upstate hydroelectricity to households and businesses across the state.

title: A LIVING ARTISTS SHOW AT THE MODERN MUSEUM
description: The large international exhibition of contemporary painting and sculpture that will inaugurate the renovated and expanded Museum of Modern Art on May 17 is also intended to demonstrate the museum's commitment to the work of living artists.

title: SAFEWAY STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 24
Millionaire at 9
description: John Henry, the 8-year-old gelding whose career earnings of $4.6 million make him the richest race horse ever, has been considered the Methuselah of thoroughbred racing for the last few seasons. But on Wednesday at Oaklawn Park in Hot Springs, Ark., an even older gelding finally joined the sport's Millionaire's Row.

title: United Central
description: United Central Bancshares, a multibank holding company based in Des Moines, said that all negotiations had ended on a preliminary plan regarding a possible merger. Kenneth M. Myers, chairman of United Bancshares, would not identify the other company involved or give the possible terms of the merger plan. United Central, which has about 12.6 million shares outstanding, was quoted at $4.875, down 12.5 cents, Thursday in over-the-counter trading.

title: C.I.A. MINING VS. MORE THAN ONE WORLD LAW
description: To the Editor:

title: A Nest Egg for Easter
description: After life had gone so wrong so fast

title: A STROLLING TASTER ON MADISON AVENUE
description: Out-of-towners who think New York is unfriendly, and most of them do, ought to come to my Carnegie Hill neighborhood and talk to a few of the merchants. Along with the traditional mom-and-pop corner store and boutiques similar to those that have transformed the landscape of areas like Columbus Avenue, the two blocks on Madison Avenue between 88th and 90th streets are chock-full of merchants who find the area as friendly as any small town.

title: 5 Iranians Flee to Denmark
description: Five Iranians, including two women and two children, arrived here today without papers aboard a Turkish flight from Istanbul and requested political asylum, the police said.

title: DMI FURNITURE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 25
description: b-Including extraordinary gains of $27,000 for the quarter and $287,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss after an extraordinary loss of $49,000. d-Including an extraordinary gain of $3,000.

title: WORLD AIRWAYS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
No Headline
description: Its Aegis Offer Minstar Inc. said yesterday that its MIN Acquisitions subsidiary had increased to $5.25 a share, or about $51.5 million, its offer for all common shares of the Aegis Corporation. Minstar is headed by the investor Irwin L. Jacobs.

title: No Headline
description: Time to Burn New York's Trash New York City produces 20,000 tons of solid waste every day and the Sanitation Department is running out of places to put it. It argues in a new report that the only place left is the sky.

title: TSR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Hecla-Ranchers
description: The Hecla Mining Company has increased its stake in Ranchers Exploration and Development Corporation, a mining concern based in Albuquerque, N.M., to 2.6 million shares, or about 43 percent of the shares outstanding, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. Hecla, a Wallace, Idaho, company that has a merger accord with Ranchers, said it bought 103,700 common shares in open-market transactions Wednesday.

title: Meeting Is Set With Soviet
description: The president of the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee said today that he and other members of the committee had decided to meet next Tuesday with sports officials from the Soviet Union, which has been critical of arrangements for the Games this summer. Peter Ueberroth, the committee's president, said in a prepared statement that the meeting, to be held at International Olympic Committee headquarters in Lausanne, Switzerland, would provide ''a good opportunity to sit down and clarify misunderstandings or misconceptions that exist, and to settle things one way or the other.'' The Soviet-American differences became especially acute last week, when the Soviet Olympic Committee, calling for the emergency meeting, said that the United States Government was violating the Olympic charter.

title: EQUINOX SOLAR reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Two Translators Win $1,000 Landon Awards
description: Robert Fitzgerald, who translated ''The Aeneid'' (Random House, 1983), and Stephen Mitchell, who translated ''The Selected Poetry of Rainer Maria Rilke'' (Random House, 1982), have been named winners of the 1982- 84 Harold Morton Landon Translation Award.

title: Haig Says Reagan Aides Overstress Popularity
description: Former Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that President Reagan must reassess the people closest to him.

title: PROBLEMS WITH PETS FOR EASTER
description: In many households Easter is celebrated with new pets, especially

title: 2 More Counties To Get Flood Aid
description: Cape May and Ocean counties have been added to the six New Jersey counties declared eligible for Federal grants and low-interest loans to help rebuild homes and replace property damaged during recent storms and floods, officials said today.

title: DEVELOPER TOLD TO STOP RAZING 3 TOWN HOUSES
description: The Department of Buildings yesterday ordered a halt to the demolition of three town houses on the Upper West Side, where a developer has filed plans to erect a 24-story apartment building.

title: Nissan Output Abroad
description: The Nissan Motor Company said today that its overseas production in 1983 rose to a record 269,182 units, beating the previous record of 226,165 units, set in 1981.

DAVIES GETS SARATOGA POST
description: Dennis Russell Davies will become the principal conductor and classical-music program director of the Saratoga Performing Arts Center in 1985.

title: Black Mayors Criticize Voter Registration Plan
description: Black mayors said today that the Democratic National Committee was shunting them aside in voter registration plans.

title: No Headline
description: By twos and threes, a procession of clergymen and the laity approached a flower-bedecked table in the chapel of St. Vladimir's Orthodox Theological Seminary today and knelt before a purple and gold likeness of Jesus' burial shroud.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: MIENS AND MAYANS Two exhibitions, civilizations apart, are on view these days at the International Center for Photography, 1130 Fifth Avenue, at 94th Street (860-1777). The societies, from the most contemporary to the most ancient, are recorded by two photographers dedicated to widely different scenes.

description: Fabrics Resist Static And Absorb Moisture

title: Comings and Goings
description: Ivan Lendl , seeded first in the Monte Carlo Jacomo Open, complained of leg and kidney pains yesterday and withdrew from a quarterfinal match against Henrik Sundstron . . . . Rick Reuschel , the veteran pitcher who had been on the disabled list since March 27 because of muscle spasms in his right shoulder, was reactivated by the Chicago Cubs.

N.B.A. Playoffs; Lakers Defeat Kings Again INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 20 (AP) - Kareem Abdul-Jabbar scored 26 points tonight as the Los Angeles Lakers, staving off a rally by Kansas City, downed the Kings, 109- 102, to take a 2-0 lead in their Western Conference playoff series.
description: After trailing by 71-54 midway through the third period, the Kings pulled to 2 points back - 83-81 - early in the final quarter before the Lakers began widening the margin again.

title: DOME PETROLEUM LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Nippon Phone
description: The Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Public Corporation said it had signed contracts valued at $51 million to buy Touch-Tone telephones and super- minicomputers made in the United States. Officials said the Japanese domestic telecommunications monopoly would spend $49 million for 60 super-minicomputers developed by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and $2 million for 60,000 standard Touch-Tone telephones from Northern Telecom Inc. of Nashville.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 9.

title: Fires and Death Bring Recall Of 102,000 Electric Heaters of 102,000 Electric Heaters
description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission has announced the recall of 102,000 electric space heaters suspected of being responsible for six residential fires, including one in which a baby died.

title: Driver Dies as Rig Hits Train in Indiana Fog
description: A tractor-trailer rig loaded with liquefied petroleum gas smashed into a freight train today and exploded, killing the truck driver and injuring seven others, the authorities said.

title: AMERICAN EQUITY INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including a gain of $939,506 from the sale of a motel and from collection of an installment note on property sold in 1980. c-Including a gain of $534,899 from the sale of property.

title: Jackson Seeks Backing Of Ohio's Governor
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson met with Gov. Richard F. Celeste today, seeking the Ohioan's endorsement for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: CONGRESS'S PHYSICIAN CHANGED MEDICATION SUPPLIER TO KEEP RECORDS SECRET
description: Congress switched drug suppliers in 1982 to insure that the medication records of its 535 members remained secret, according to newly released court documents.

title: VOLATILITY HURT CHARTER
description: At its peak, the Charter Company had interests in publishing, broadcasting, insurance, real estate and - above all - oil. It was one of the highest flying of the high-flying energy companies of the 1970's.

description: Hormone Process To Raise Milk Output

description: ''A lot of people are dying down there and we're lucky not to be among them.'' - Sen. Bennett Johnston, Democrat of Louisiana, upon returning from tour of Central America. (4:2.)

title: A CHIEF IS ELECTED BY CHICAGO PACIFIC
description: The Chicago Pacific Corporation, formerly the Chicago, Rock Island & Pacific Railroad, yesterday elected Harvey Kapnick as chairman, president and chief executive. Mr. Kapnick also bought $1.5 million of stock in the new company.

title: MIG'S SHOOT AT ARMY COPTER ON WEST GERMAN-CZECH BORDER
description: Two Soviet-built planes of ''unknown nationality'' fired on a United States Army helicopter today while it was on an observation mission along the West German-Czechoslovak border, the Pentagon announced.

title: 2 SENATORS SAY DUARTE PROPOSES NICARAGUA TALKS
description: Two United States Senators said today that Jose Napoleon Duarte, who is running for the presidency of El Salvador, told them he would seek negotiations with Nicaragua if he was elected.

title: Jets' New Look
description: Fans who have been surprised at the Jets' off-season shake-up may continue to be in for the unexpected. The club's 1984 depth chart shows that two would-be returning starters - Stan Waldemore at left guard, and Mike Augustyniak at fullback - have been relegated to backup positions.

title: U.S. Starts Maneuvers In the Caribbean Area
description: United States war games involving 30,000 military personnel from all service branches started today. The operations are to include the evacuation of 300 people from the American naval base at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba.

title: 10 Are Reported Killed In Ugandan Army Clash
description: Two Ugandan Army units hunting for rebels clashed with each other at Kirolo, about 40 miles north of Kampala, and more than 10 people, including civilians, were killed, the newspaper Munno reported today.

title: TRUS JOIST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PAYING TAXES BY ESTIMATE
description: With the deadline for filing 1983 Federal income tax forms having passed on Monday, many taxpayers are looking ahead - probably without much joy - to paying estimated taxes for 1984. However, there are specific rules to follow in doing so.

description: Preakness Likely For Dr. Carter

title: Future Change
description: A change of head coaches when their record was 0-3 didn't help the Oakland Invaders. Now, with the record at 0-8, they plan a new tactic: a change of coaches

title: Warsaw Pact Demands NATO Stop Deployment of Missiles
description: The Warsaw Pact has again demanded that the North Atlantic Treaty Organization halt deployment of nuclear missiles in Western Europe and said the bloc's members ''insist'' the program be stopped as a condition for resuming arms limitation talks.

title: LOMAS & NETTLETON FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
COLUMBINE EXPLORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29

title: School Founder Enters Plea Of Not Guilty to Molestation
description: Virginia McMartin, 76 years old, said today that she was ''not guilty, period'' to a charge of child molestation at the preschool center she founded in suburban Manhattan Beach.

title: MARKET-HUNTING IN 'PROGRESSIVE P.R.'
description: A press release turned up this month in reporters' mailboxes outlining the schedules and public appearances of 11 European, Latin American and Canadian figures, including a Nobel Peace Prize winner from Argentina and the film maker Costa-Gavras, who had come to this country to protest United States ''intervention in Central America'' and express solidarity with Nicaragua.

title: U.S. BASKETBALL CANDIDATES FACE CUTDOWN
description: For more than half of the basketball players who arrived here Tuesday with the hope of making the United States Olympic team, the thank you's will come at breakfast Saturday, with the goodbyes soon after.

title: Bank Merger Set
description: An agreement has been reached for the Washington Mutual Savings Bank of Seattle to acquire the Lincoln Mutual Savings Bank of Spokane, Wash., the companies said.

title: TERRORISTS BOMB WASHINGTON CLUB FOR NAVY OFFICERS
description: An explosion severely damaged the officers club at the Washington Navy Yard early this morning, and a group that said it opposed United States policy in Central America took responsibility. No one was in the building at the time.

title: BANCAL TRI-STATE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest quarter net included nonrecurring, after tax gains of $900,000 against $1.7 million, primarily from the sale of assets, in the year-earlier period.

title: No Relief in the Sky
description: When Jeff Reardon, the Montreal Expos' relief pitcher, became ill Thursday night during a flight from New York to St. Louis, his teammates were afraid he was having a heart attack.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a mechanical error, two paragraphs of the Books of The Times column in Weekend yesterday, reviewing ''A Matter of Honor'' by Don Kowet, were printed out of sequence. The two last paragraphs of the review were intended to appear above the preceding two paragraphs.

title: Japan's Economy Gains
description: With exports increasing and domestic demand improving, Japan's economy continues to recover slowly but steadily, the Director General of the Economic Planning Agency said today.

title: SHIRT-SLEEVE PUDDING, GRANNY'S LEG AND HOLLY-GOG
description: In the House of Commons, a Member of Parliament recently expressed regrets at what he described as the decline of the traditional British pudding. He deplored the infrequency with which rice pudding, summer pudding, plum pudding ''and other similar delights'' appeared on the menu in the House restaurant. If his allegation was correct, this is certainly a matter of some gravity. Puddings have for generations been an essential ingredient of British life, and the art of pudding- making has long been regarded rather more seriously than that of, say, landscape-painting.

title: BRITAIN SAYS IT WILL NOT MAINTAIN PRESENCE IN HONG KONG AFTER '97
description: The British Foreign Secretary, Sir Geoffrey Howe, said here today that Britain would not maintain any administration in Hong Kong after it relinquishes sovereignty to China when the British lease expires in 1997.

description: Because of an editing error, an article in Sports Pages yesterday about the North American Soccer League incorrectly reported the estimated annual saving from a new agreement with the N.A.S.L. Players Association. It is $1.35 million.

title: ORGANIZED LABOR IS GETTING LATE START FOR MONDALE IN INDIANA
description: Organized labor, one of the driving forces of Walter F. Mondale's campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination, has barely begun to crank up its engines here in the industrialized heart of Indiana, with the May 8 primary less than three weeks away.

title: NATIONAL COLOR LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: Revenues are restated to conform to classifications used in 1984. Share earnings are restated to give retroactive effect to the 5 percent stock dividend of Jan. 23, 1984.

title: DAMPER ON 'HAPPY HOURS'
description: The Army Chief of Staff, Gen. John A. Wickham Jr., has put a damper on ''happy hours'' at Army service clubs around the world by banning bargain prices on alcoholic drinks at such events.

title: A.M.C. Layoffs
description: The American Motors Corporation said slower than expected sales of its Renault Alliance and Encore subcompact cars in Canada had resulted in 5,000 hourly workers at its Kenosha, Wis., assembly plant being placed on temporary layoff for four days next week. The plant, which had already been scheduled to be idle for a holiday Monday, builds 960 cars a day.

title: TRANSCON INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $370,000. c-Net loss.

title: THEATER: 'ANOTHER PARADISE'
description: Donna Spector's ''Another Paradise'' is a mildly evocative family chronicle about the resilience of Appalachian women. The play, presented by the Open Space Theater Experiment at the TOMI Terrace Theater, is framed by contrasting monologues delivered by a mother and her older daughter. The mother survives the intimidations of her Bible-thumping husband by adopting a policy of accommodation. The daughter's response is to create a fictionalized picture of her past, substituting happiness for heartaches.

title: 6 Years for Fixing Cases
description: Harold Conn, a former clerk in Cook County Traffic Court involved in a Federal investigation of corruption in the Chicago courts, has been sentenced to six years in prison for taking $1,600 in bribes to fix cases. He remained free on $4,500 bond after he was sentenced Wednesday by Federal District Judge John A. Nordberg.

title: MAGANA SAYS HE EXPECTS ISRAELIS TO STEP UP THEIR AID FOR SALVADOR
description: El Salvador's Provisional President says he thinks there will be increased economic and military aid from Israel now that the Israeli Embassy here has reopened and El Salvador's Embassy has been moved to Jerusalem.

title: NICARAGUAN TROOPS RETAKE A DEFEATED TOWN
description: Nicaraguan Government troops supported by aerial bombing have retaken this remote jungle outpost from Costa Rican-based rebels. But they are in control of a town that no longer exists.

title: Suspect's Estate Valued At About $1.8 Million
description: The estate left by Christopher Wilder, a suspect in sex-slayings who was shot to death a week ago after a cross-country crime spree, has been estimated to be worth as much as $1.8 million.

title: FOR WOMEN, VISIBILITY FOR THEIR GAME
description: Ask Pat Head Summitt if she's the Bobby Knight of women's basketball, and she laughs and wonders if the comparison is a compliment.

title: INQUIRY ON CARTER PAPERS FOUGHT
description: The Justice Department urged a Federal District Court today to dismiss a lawsuit requesting the appointment of a special prosecutor to investigate how the 1980 Reagan campaign organization obtained briefing papers from the Carter White House.

title: OPERA: 'MOSES' BY SOLTI
description: Georg Solti's commitment to Arnold Schoenberg's monumental opera ''Moses und Aron,'' which the conductor performed in a concert version Thursday night with the Chicago Symphony in Orchestra Hall, is deep-rooted. He conducted it in English both at Covent Garden in 1965-66 and with the Chicago Symphony in 1971, and in French with the Paris Opera in 1973.

description: Separatist guerrillas in Sri Lanka said today that they carried out a car bombing April 9 in the northern part of the island in which 15 Government soldiers were killed, the United News of India reported.

title: Singer Leaves Hospital
description: The singing star Michael Jackson was released from a hospital ''in excellent spirits'' after undergoing surgery to repair a portion of scalp burned in filming a television commercial, his surgeon said today. Mr. Jackson, 25 years old, left Brotman Medical Center Thursday night, Dr. Steven Hoefflin said. Word of the departure was not released until today. Dr. Hoefflin said the entertainer was doing ''very well'' and was ''undergoing very minimal discomfort.''

title: BEIRUT FIGHTING SAID TO END AS BUFFER FORCE IS DEPLOYED
description: Virtually all exchanges of fire were said to have ended today in Beirut as 1,500 Lebanese gendarmes moved in between the warring militia forces.

title: SIMEON'S LAST CASE
description: Leslie Garis writes frequently on literary subjects.

title: SUN-DRIED TOMATOES
description: -DRIED TOMATOES are a luxury that can be found in most fine- food specialty shops and their uses are legion. Most of them come from northern Italy, primarily from the region of Emilia-Romagna. It is said that the northern tomatoes of that nation are sweeter than those of the south. The tomatoes are split in half by hand and the seeds are removed. The seeds, if left inside, contribute a bit of acidity and bitterness and for that reason are eliminated.

title: READYING A CONCERTO
description: On Friday night, the Boston Symphony Orchestra, under the direction of Seiji Ozawa and with Peter Serkin as soloist, will present the first New York performance of Peter Lieberson's Piano Concerto at Avery Fisher Hall. Mr. Serkin, who gave the concerto its world premiere earlier this month in Boston, reflected recently on the work's origins.

title: TIME TO ACCOMODATE DEBTOR NATIONS
description: WHEN great interests are at stake and conflicts are many, we take refuge in Pilate's crude skepticism: What is truth? Interlocutors slide from reasoning to rationalization and invariably become irritated by evidence that theirs is only half the truth. These are commonplaces of our day-to-day existence, but become far more significant when they occur internationally. Dialogue is blocked and everything conspires to create a situation that damages us all.

title: A Plethora of Backs
description: Now that the New England Patriots have signed Craig James , the former running back for Southern Methodist University and the Washington Federals of the United States Football League, Coach Ron Meyer is reconsidering his plans to switch to a one- back offense. With James and Tony Collins , the sixth-best rusher in the American Football Conference last season with 1,049 yards, Meyer may use them as he did James and Eric Dickerson when he coached at S.M.U. ''He's a heavy-duty running back, capable of doing everything a running back is called upon to do,'' Meyer said of James.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
ARBITRATION: AN OLD BUT GOOD IDEA
description: DISPUTE is a fact of life in this great nation. Whether the disagreement is between teachers and their school district, factory workers and their employer, or an all-star outfielder and his team owner, we cannot pick up a newspaper without seeing blazing headlines about a dispute of one sort or another.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
DOES ANYONE ANSWER LETTERS?
description: RECEIVING an answer from big business appears to be almost impossible. During the last two years I have had several problems with corporations that were very eager for my business. Their offers appeared regularly in the mail.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
TRYING A NEW WAY TO REVIVE CITIES
description: SEVENTEEN years ago this summer, Newark and several other New Jersey cities erupted in a firestorm of hatred, death and destruction.

title: SLIDE SHOW ON WASTE DISPOSAL AVAILABLE
description: AN expert on water quality is taking a slide show on the road to gain support for the development of a new facility for dealing with hazardous wastes.

title: SPECIAL TOURS FOR SPECIAL INTERESTS
description: Different people travel for different reasons. For some, a wide beach and rolling surf suffice. For others, 13 cities in 15 days barely fill the bill. For still others, the pursuit of a hobby or passion provides the incentive. Aware of this, more and more tour operators are arranging programs for people interested in art, architecture, archeology, history, photography and the like.

title: CONSERVATIVES, G.O.P. CHOOSING TEICHER CHALLENGER
description: Confusion continues to follow in the wake of Representative Richard L. Ottinger's decision not to seek re-election in the 20th Congressional District. A month ago Democrats meeting in convention narrowly selected Oren J. Teicher as their nominee, only to learn that he faced a vigorous primary challenge.

title: HARD TIMES FOR HOLY LAND, U.S.A.
description: SOME people thought John Baptist Greco was crazy 28 years ago, when he first began to build ''Holy Land U.S.A.'' ''Why are you doing this?'' they would ask, as Mr. Greco, the son of a shoemaker, mixed concrete, moved boulders and fashioned cast-off statuary and windows, scrap iron, lumber, plastic and wire, discarded mannequins and old automobile paint into a 17-acre reconstruction of ancient Bethlehem and Jerusalem on a steep, rocky hill overlooking the industrial city of Waterbury.

title: JUDGE REFUSES TO SHUT DUMP IN NEW YORK-JERSEY DISPUTE
description: A Federal judge has refused to close New York City's largest landfill, but the Mayor of Woodbridge Township says he will haul trash to City Hall in Manhattan if discarded medical supplies from the dump keep washing up on his community's beaches.

title: THE POET AND THE POP STAR
description: ENDERBY'S DARK LADY

title: MOZART MUST HAVE THWACKED OUT OCTAVES, TOO
description: The pianist Steven Lubin earned a Ph. D. in musicology from New York University.

title: Amy Faller and Peter Sargent Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. James Faller of Jenkintown, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter Amy Marie Faller to Peter Birch Sargent, a son of Mrs. Edward C. Sargent of Bronxville, N.Y., and the late Mr. Sargent. A July wedding is planned.

title: Yugoslavs Detain Djilas And 27 for Questioning
description: Milovan Djilas and 27 other people were detained for questioning overnight on suspicion of ''hostile activity,'' the official Yugoslav press agency reported today.

title: ANTI-SANDINISTA SEEKS MORE AID
description: A leader of the Honduran-based Nicaraguan rebels said today that he expected the United States to continue to provide aid despite the publicity over the mining of Nicaraguan harbors.

description: MEXICO CITY

title: FUGITIVE INDIAN MILITANT FINDS UPSTATE RESERVATION A PRISON
description: Dennis Banks, the fugitive Indian militant, fled to New York State in January 1983 seeking to avoid imprisonment in South Dakata. But the Indian reservation to which he fled has, in effect, become his prison.

title: Catherine Coyle To Wed R.C. Lee
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas P. Coyle of New York and Southampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Catherine Louise Coyle to Raymond Clifford Lee, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank A. Lee of Old Tappan, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title: NICARAGUAN RADIO IS REPORTED TO AID SALVADOR GUERRILLAS
description: Government officials say the Reagan Administration's assertions that Nicaragua is aiding Salvadoran rebels are based on a secret United States radio monitoring operation that has intercepted several thousand messages between the two Central American countries since 1981.

title: SWIMMER CREATES A ONE-MAN TEAM
description: TED TUCKER, a freshman at Valley Regional High School in Deep River, wanted to swim competitively this year, and he was not deterred by the fact that his school did not offer the sport. The 14-year-old has become the first swimmer in the state to invoke a little-known rule that allows for a one- man swim team.

title: QADDAFI OFFERS INQUIRY TEAM TO LONDON
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, said today that he was willing to send an inquiry team to question the occupants of the besieged Libyan Embassy here about the incident Tuesday that resulted in the death of a policewoman and the wounding of 10 protesters, the BBC reported tonight.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
WHAT THE 'SPRING BREAKS' DID TO US
description: S PRING is traditionally a season of renewal, a time for fresh beginnings, change and replenishment. Rebirth defines the rhythm of the vernal equinox as our universe swells annually with life.

title: CITY CHALLENGED ON REVOCATION OF TAX ABATEMENTS
description: Auditors take pride in thoroughness. When the auditors of the Department of Housing Preservation and Development decide to look into the claims for J-51 tax benefits on a building that has been rehabilited, they want to see a piece of paper backing up the claim for every dollar spent on the job.

title: WORKD MADE OF PAPTER, NOT ON IT
description: THE craze for paper as an art medium, which started in the 1970's, has abated but is by no means over.

title: 2 POTTERS SHOW JAPAN'S INFLUENCE

description: MARTIN GOTTLIEB

title: MODERN AFFIRMATION OF EASTER'S LESSONS
description: ON Easter, Dr. Michael Ryan said, he often pictures the holiday as he experienced it years ago in a New Hampshire church. In the midst of the service, the minister had called all the children to the front of the sanctuary and given them chocolate Easter eggs.

title: Ambach Asks Yonkers To End School Dispute
description: Saying it would be ''unthinkable'' for the Yonkers schools to close with more than one-fifth of the school year remaining, State Education Commissioner Gordon M. Ambach today urged the City Council and the Board of Education to resolve their fiscal dispute quickly.

title: STATE TO LIMIT HOSPITALS' ACQUISITION OF DIAGNOSTIC TOOL
description: TRENTON NO MORE than eight hospitals in New Jersey will be allowed to buy an expensive new diagnostic device until a panel of experts can evaluate its impact.

title: POVERTY SAID TO GROW FOR SOUTH AFRICA BLACKS
description: Studies conducted under the auspices of the Carnegie Foundation in New York over the last two years have shown a radical increase in impoverishment among South Africa's black majority despite improvements in some black living standards.

title: ELDERLY, TOO, FIND PLEASURE AT CAMPSITES
description: In 1950, Gertrude Landau, director of the William Hodson Senior Center in the Bronx, had an idea: if poor city children could go to summer camp, why not older people?

title: CITY WILL FINANCE THE RENOVATION OF 4 ABANDONED BRONX BUILDINGS
description: City officials announced a plan yesterday to rebuild the last four abandoned city-owned buildings along the Grand Concourse in the Bronx to house 223 low- and moderate-income families.

title: A FINE TIME FOR FLOWERS
description: At Christatos & Koster on Madison Avenue, John H. G. Pell, the financier and historian, was browsing among the tulips, orchids and hyacinths when a deep pink azalea bush captured his heart, so he bought it for his wife, Pyrma.

title: U.S. ENERGY AGENCY IS MAKING AN EFFORT TO SAVE SHOREHAM
description: The Federal Department of Energy is involved in intense negotiations aimed at saving the Shoreham nuclear plant on Long Island, according to documents obtained by a House subcommittee.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Week in Review on April 1 incorrectly described the source of an assessment of Navy budget needs by Adm. James D. Watkins, the Chief of Naval Operations. The admiral's assessment was in a classified memorandum to Navy planning officers.

title: A NEW CHEF WITH FINESSE

Its polished blond wood furnishings, bar and trim are set against a background of hunter green carpeting, green plaid tablecloths with dark green napkins (unfortunately made of sleazy synthetic fabric), plants and accents of shiny brass.

title: ZATOPEK SHOULD CARRY THE OLYMPIC TORCH

title: PEKING'S FAMILY POLICY
description: In 1982, President Reagan said, ''Our goals are plain. Where families are threatened, we seek to lessen those threats.'' Next week, we will see these words put to the test. When the President lands in Peking, he will be conferring with a Government in the midst of the most systematic and relentless campaign against the family that the modern world has yet seen.

title: LETTER TO LONG ISLAND EDITOR Finding Money Through Recycling How can the Presiding Supervisor of the Town of Hempstead and the Town Board justify their continued refusal to ''earn'' upward of $500,000 a year for the town taxpayers? The Town of Islip, with a population of 298,897, earned a net of $200,000 last year thanks to its mandatory glass bottle, tin can and newspaper recycling program. Hempstead, with a population of 738,517, or two and one-half times Islip's, could easily earn in excess of $500,000 and thereby reduce the tax burden.
description: Implementation of a program of source separation in the Town of Hempstead would also provide our residents with another benefit, namely, the reduction of the amount of material accumulated on Mount Trashmore in Oceanside and other communities.

title: Faldo Shoots a 68 to Lead by 4 Strokes
description: Nick Faldo of Britain shot a 3-under-par 68 and stretched his lead to four strokes today after three rounds of the Sea Pines Heritage Classic.

title: PRESIDENT IN 1960'S
description: Otto Arosemena Gomez, an Ecuadoran lawyer and legislator who served as Provisional President in Quito for two years, died Friday of a heart attack in the ocean resort of Salinas, Ecuador, Reuters reported yesterday, citing family sources in Quito. He was 58 years old.

title: Fathers and Daughters
description: As a firm believer that men and women, girls and boys, aren't so very different, I wish to respond to Edward Tivnan's article ''End of a Line'' (About Men, March 11).

title: THROUGH THE MOTIONS Specialists
description: When we were 8 years old, Mother taught us how to sweep: You use the broom to make a neat pile of dirt, hold the dustpan to the floor, choke up on the broom and shove the dirt onto the pan. Then put the broom down, open a trash bag, place the dustpan inside and shake it, hard.

title:
ART ;
AFTER AN 'INSPIRED ACCIDENT,' A BEGUILING USE OF LIGHT
description: LIGHT is the most elusive of creative media, yet its effects can impart strong and lasting sensations. The colorful, awe- inspiring spectacle of fireworks and the mesmerizing patterns of amusement park signboards are two examples of the ways in which light can be creatively manipulated, and the photographs and sculptures of Eric Staller, now on view at the Fine Arts Center Gallery of the State University of Stony Brook, combine elements of bQth.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; ; Soprano From Texas, Three Pianists, a Cellist And Cremona Quartet
description: Jo Ann Pickens stands out among the debut recitalists reviewed. The soprano from Texas seems to be doing well in Europe but is not nearly as active in her own country as she ought to be. Judging from her concert of songs in Merkin Hall on April 14, she is a first-rate talent with a considerable future.

title: HEADLINERS
description: High-Tech Intrigue For Edward Durward Harper Jr. , an engineer in California's Silicon Valley, the chips were down. Caught in a scheme to steal United States defense secrets and sell them to Polish intelligence agents for $250,000, Mr. Harper cut a deal with Government prosecutors and pleaded guilty last week to one of nine counts against him. An army spokesman said the defense material involved was ''extremely sensitive'' and could be useful to an enemy in defeating portions of America's strategic systems. Mr. Harper's wife, Ruby, who died last year, allegedly stole the data while working as an executive secretary to the president of two Silicon Valley firms. Mr. Harper, who has agreed to testify for the prosecution in any related cases, could get life in prison.

title: SUSAN JEFFRIES VON HOFFMANNN TO MARRY STEVEN MOURY TOMPSON IN SEPTEMBER

title: Prize for Sluggers

Now, thanks to the company that makes Gatorade, another home-run champion will be determined, this one through a single-elimination tournament that begins today and runs through the World Series.

title: HOW TO SUCCEED BY BEING TALENTED, AMBITIOUS AND NICE

It was a plot point in the play, ''Painting Churches,'' during the course of which Marian Seldes, playing Miss McGovern's mother, kept asking her what she'd done to her hair.

title: CORRECTION

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
WISHING FOR A HAPPIER EASTER
description: WALKING to the sound of a rainy downpour last Easter, I felt sympathy for those who would have their Easter dawn services washed out. And I was glad we weren't having the outdoor Easter egg hunt we had enjoyed for so many years as our children were growing up. Easter is late this year, so - granted clear skies - it should be perfect for services and for egg hunts, with balmy breezes, burgeoning blossoms, unfolding leaves, boots and mittens in storage.

FROM THE FRONT PORCH, THE ALFRESCO HOME FOR THREE SEASONS
description: UNTIL we moved to New York, my family and I had never enjoyed the amenities of a real front porch. Now we live in a neighborhood of houses built in a time when front porches, real front porches, were, well, simply de regueur.

title: Valerie A. Mars To Wed Teacher

title: Canada Reconsidering

As a result, the Canandian Government may be on the verge of changing its proposed national sports lottery, Sportspool, which was designed to help raise $200 million for the 1988 Winter Olympics in Calgary.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. title:
STAGE VIEW;
THREE PLAYS ILLUMINATE THE RANGE OF PINTER
description: Harold Pinter writes so seldom for the stage nowadays that he'd only have to trace a line of dialogue in the dirt with his big toe for the world's theatrical scholars to jet in with cameras, spades and preservative; and the three short plays now receiving their American premiere at the Manhattan Theater Club offer more to dig into than that. ''Victoria Station,'' about a taxi dispatcher first puzzled, then infuriated and finally converted to a sort of crazed camaraderie by an amiably uncooperative driver, may seem little more than an anecdote, a nostalgic throwback to the revue sketches its author wrote 20, 25 years ago. Yet it injects a strangeness, an unease, a distinctive Pinterishness into the kind of disembodied banalities every passenger must have heard bleated from office to taxi and back again. It leaves you wondering if you aren't hearing the two survivors of some unmentionable disaster playing out their last rituals in an empty, airless city. And the other two components of the triple-bill Pinter has called ''Other Places'' are certainly much more than anecdotal.

title: WOMEN'S STUDIES: THE DEBATE CONTINUES
description: Walter Goodman is a reporter for The New York Times. By Walter Goodman HERE IS A NEW FEMInist heroine on college campuses around the United States. She is Estelle Freedman, a 36- year-old historian, who, after prolonged and acrimonious debate, has become the first specialist in women's studies to be granted tenure since Stanford University established its feminist program. Her personal victory last fall is being hailed as a triumph for her speciality, which, after more than a decade of remarkable growth, remains a problematic addition to America's colleges.

title: HBO'S 'FAR PAVILIONS' FALLS SHORT
description: The splendor of 19th-century India! The savagery of the Second Afghan War! The romance of forbidden love! All of this, plus a relatively lavish production budget of $12 million, has been poured into the Home Box Office mini-series ''The Far Pavilions,'' the initial two-hour installment of which can be seen on the HBO pay cable channel tonight at 8 (the remaining episodes will be shown tomorrow and Tuesday evenings, also at 8). The ingredients are certainly promising for whipping up the kind of sweeping epic that often brings in healthy television ratings (cf., ''Roots,'' ''The Winds of War'' or ''The Thorn Birds''). Why, then, is ''The Far Pavilions'' so boring? The answer could be crucial to the future of cable television and the function of pay services.

A new novelist ''with not just a keen eye but a keen ear, a keen wit'' and a feel for the good novel's narrative contours, Danny Santiago chronicles the 15th year in the life of a streetwise Chicano kid with ''a manic appetite for experience'' who is ''trying to live long enough to look back someday and say he grew up in the tough Eastside neighborhood of Los Angeles.'' Our reviewer, David Quammen, said ''Famous All Over Town'' presents ''some hard cultural realities while not for a paragraph failing to entertain.'' description: Amid the negative comments regarding the design of the latest United States silver dollar it's interesting to note that Canada, too, has a new silver dollar. However, unlike its U.S. counterpart, that coin is esthetically quite pleasing. This comes as no surprise to most numismatic observers since Canada consistently comes up with attractive new coins - and that, in turn, underscores the relative artistic poverty of most U.S. coinage in recent years.

Miss Dreier, who lived in New York and on her farm in West Redding until her death in 1953, promoted and bought art works so new and experimental that they often cost less than $10. But they were signed by such artists as Wassily Kandinsky, Paul Klee and Fernand Leger.

title: Honor for Sampson

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
'BUT, MOMMY, ILL THE GRASS EVER COME BACK?'
description: AS we passed the bridges and skyscrapers of Manhattan one day, my children seemed overwhelmed by their construction and the details of their history. There was so much information to be learned about the many buildings and landmarks in one tiny little area of land. Struggling to comprehend the significance of it all, my 6-year-old caught me by surprise: ''But, Mommy, where's the grass?''

title: Caging the Chemical Monster With an election in the offing and no progress to report on arms control, the White House has flamboyantly proposed a treaty on chemical weapons that the Russians denounced before they even read it. But the treaty is an important step forward, and the prospects for controlling this abhorrent form of warfare may not be as bleak as they seem.
description: The drawn-out negotiations at Geneva have gained new impetus from Iraq's use of mustard and nerve gas in its war with Iran. President Reagan and his top aides also suspect, more dubiously, that chemical agents of some kind have been used by Vietnam. In any case, if other third-world countries resort to these easily made poisons, chemicals might quickly proliferate.

title: Notable Changes
description: To the Editor:

title: Heidi and Christopher Bovers to Wed David A. Johnson and Mary Ziminsky
description: Heidi Girarde Bovers and David Arthur Johnson plan to be married in June and Mary Frances Ziminsky and Christopher N. Bovers are planning a September wedding, the parents of the brides-to-be have announced. The Bovers are brother and sister.

title: SHELLFISH, ESPECIALLY CLEN, CHEAP NOW
description: MANY people are apprehensive about cooking clams or mussels. They are not quite sure how to handle these shellfish and are convinced that the cleaning of them alone is a long and tedious chore. But both mussels and clams on the market at this time are exceptionally free from sand, mud or barnacles. It is now possible to find mussels that have been grown on wooden frames or stakes and shipped in two-pound plastic bags from Maine; their black and silver oval shells are so smooth they appear already washed. Clams in recent weeks have been so clean that they have needed little more than careful rinsing to get rid of the sand.

title:
STAMPS;
U.S. RELEASES LAST TWO ISSUES FOR 1984 OLYMPICS
description: The two final issues to focus attention on the 1984 Olympics - one is a block of four and the other is a postal card - are being put out in the next two weeks. They conclude a long string of stamps and postal stationery that began a year ago to mark this year's Winter and Summer Olympics.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
JACKSON: TAX REFORM AND PUBLIC JOBS
description: THE economic goals of the Jackson candidacy are full employment, equal opportunity and a decent standard of living for all Americans, to be achieved within a free and just society and in friendly cooperation with other nations.

description: Pamela Harper is a professional garden photographer and writer.

title: MUSLIM SUGGESTS SECESSION OF BLACKS
description: Louis Farrakhan, the leader of a Black Muslim sect, said today that if the Rev. Jesse Jackson was not taken seriously at the Democratic National Convention the Muslim leader would ''lead an army'' to Washington to demand that blacks be allowed to secede from the United States.

title: 76ERS FEELING NETS' PRESSURE
description: It was a somber scene, one not often witnessed in the Philadelphia 76ers' home locker room after a game. But Friday was an unusual night. The 76ers, the defending champions of the National Basketball Association, had just been embarrassed for the second time in three nights by being routed, 116-102, by the Nets in their three-of-five-game playoff series.

title: A NEW ANTITRUST LAW
description: The sharp division in the Administration caused by the Justice Department's off-and-on- again decision, rejecting then approving the LTV-Republic Steel merger, underscores the need for a new antitrust law for distressed industries as part of an industrial strategy.

title: SCREENING OF DISABLED FAULTED
description: Family Court judges are allowing too many handicapped children to enter summer and preschool programs, which will cost the public $131.8 million this year, a state legislative panel said today.

title: Cosmos Win
description: More than 21,000 fans turned out for the Strikers' Minnesota debut tonight, but the Cosmos forward Stan Terlecki spoiled the occasion, scoring two goals to lead New York to a 2-1 preseason victory in overtime.

title: REVA G. GERSHEN TO MARRY WILLIAM J. LOWRY IN JUNE
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alvin E. Gershen of Princeton, N.J., and Palm Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Reva Gisele Gershen, to William Joseph Lowy, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Simon Lowy of the Bronx. The wedding is to be in June.

title: Progress on Virus
description: Veterinarians at the University of Kentucky may be close to isolating the virus subtype that has affected more than 100 of the 1,400 thoroughbreds stabled at Keeneland in Lexington.

title: CONCERT: TRIBUTE TO SHIFRIN
description: A sizable audience gathered in the Abraham Goodman House Wednesday night to pay tribute to Seymour Shifrin, the distinguished American composer and teacher who died in 1979. The roster of participating performers included the Atlantic String Quartet, Speculum Musicae, the pianists Richard Taub, Robert Levin and Charles Fisk, and the soprano Christine Whittlesley.

title: Hthe Catskill Daily Mail
description: Howard E. Silberstein, former owner and publisher of The Catskill (N.Y.) Daily Mail and Industrial Commissioner of New York State from 1937 to 1944, died April 15 at his winter home in Vero Beach, Fla., after a brief illness. He was 77 years old and also lived in Catskill.
