title: ANTIQUES VIEW ; THE FINE ICING ON FRENCH FURNISHINGS
description: Bronze mounts - those gold- hued metal cupids, gods, lions' faces, wreaths and swirls of leaves embellishing furniture and decorations from Louis XIV through Louis Majorelle - are as French as souffles. They add brilliance, sculptural beauty, elegance and historic spirit to furnishings, as can be seen in a small, choice exhibition ''Elements of Style: The Art of the Bronze Mount in 18th- and 19th-Century France,'' on view through June 15 at Rosenberg & Stiebel, 32 East 57th Street.

title: A Fishing Education Is a Part of Yale
description: ''Thisis what it is all about,'' said Ed Migdalski happily as he stood under lowering skies from which cold showers were soon to descend. He was watching nearly three dozen graduate, undergraduate and faculty members of the Yale Fishing Club flailing a trout stream and pond in the university's 2,000-acre Outdoor Education Center in East Lyme, Conn.

description: John Gross is an editor of The New York Times Book Review. A CHIME OF WORDS

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: USTINOV PLAYS BEETHOVAN-FOR LAUGHS
description: As a schoolboy, Peter Ustinov made his acting debut in a dramatized nursery rhyme. His first review, memorialized in his school records, said he was ''adequate in the part of a pig.'' Since then, he has learned to mistrust critics and to diversify his art. Just turning 63, he is celebrated on several continents as an actor, playwright, director, novelist and autobiographer. Currently he can be seen in a favorite hyphenate as actor- playwright in ''Beethoven's Tenth,'' opening tonight at the Nederlander Theater. In Mr. Ustinov's new play, Ludwig von Beethoven suddenly returns to life and joins the household of an acerbic English music critic. Naturally, Mr. Ustinov plays the composer (George Rose is the critic), just as in earlier attempts at incarnation he has personified Nero, Sophocles and Samuel Johnson. Extending his range in the world of detective fiction, he has played everything from Belgian (Hercule Poirot) to Chinese (Charlie Chan). His finest role is, of course, himself. In that guise, he can sit back and be inimitably Ustinovian. A conversation with Mr. Ustinov is a Renaissance riff of free association, embracing such seemingly discordant subjects as the decline of civilization, famous old actors doing television commercials, frozen royalties and, whenever possible, Beethoven. Soon a hotel room becomes a United Nations of characters and voices. He had just come off the road. Beardless for Beethoven, he looked well-fed but less imposing in person than on screen or stage. Settling down with the first of several cigars, he said that he had been touring from Wilmington to Detroit, and at almost every stop an admirer had come up to him and reminded him of a past performance or a specific line of dialogue.

title: Linny Keller to Marry Merrick G. Andlinger
description: Mr. and Mrs. C. Lawrence Keller of Short Hills, N.J., and Londonderry, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Beatrice Linder Keller, to Merrick Gerd Andlinger, the son of Jane Maier Andlinger of Greenwich, Conn., and Gerhard R. Andlinger of Scarborough, N.Y. The wedding is planned for June 30.

title: Flames Force a 7th Game With Oilers
description: The Calgary Flames couldn't beat the Edmonton Oilers once in eight games during the regular season, but they have beaten them three times in their Smythe Division final playoff series. Calgary sent the series back to the Oilers' home arena with a 5-4 victory in overtime Friday night in Calgary.

description: Former Representative John B. Anderson's political party does not automatically qualify for Arizona's November ballot, says Attorney General Bob Corbin.

ANTIQUES;
A SPECIAL SHOW IN WESTPORT
description: Westport Antiques Show will be held at the Fairfield County Hunt Club in Westport April 27 through April 29. Show time on Friday is from 11 A.M. until 9 P.M.; on Saturday and Sunday, from 11 A.M. until 6 P.M.

title: India and Bangladesh Exchange Fire on Border
description: Indian and Bangladeshi troops exchanged gunfire Friday night in a dispute over India's construction of a fence along the border to prevent illegal immigration. At least one person was killed, an Indian spokesman said today.

title: EARLY MUSIC: PERCEVAL
description: Early-music groups in this country generally aspire or pretend to a quest for authenticity. Tuesday night in St. Vincent de Paul Church, the Ensemble Perceval of France offered another kind of quest - this one for the Holy Grail - and seemed less concerned with authenticity than with the evocation of medieval legend through every possible means.

title: Grumman Appealing Dismissal of Bus Suit
description: The Grumman Corporation has appealed a court decision rejecting a $500 million damage suit against Rhor Industries of California over defects in the Grumman Flxible bus.

title: Curry Retains His Title
description: Donald Curry floored Elio Diaz of Venezuela three times and retained his World Boxing Association welterweight title today. The challenger, who took his first loss in 35 fights, could not answer the bell for the eighth round.

title: SALVADOR COLONEL TAKES OFFENSIVE AGAINST REBELS
description: For nine hours, 600 Salvadoran troops walked 10 miles over rugged terrain to arrive here the night of April 13.

title: SURPRISE AND WORRY IN A SPURTING G.N.P.
description: The gross national product surged at an 8.3 percent annual rate in the first quarter, far above most analysts' expectations and more than a point higher than the 7.2 percent ''flash'' figure. The rate, which far outpaced the 5 percent rate of the fourth quarter of 1983, spurred new fears that the economy was overheating. However, some analysts, noting that the G.N.P. has exceeded predictions since the recession ended, said the latest figures were skewed by an unsustainable rise in inventories. Most agreed that the growth in the measure of goods and services would flatten as the year progresses, with the latest estimates showing a growth rate of 3 to 4 percent in the second quarter, more in line with a steadily expanding economy.

description: On Salt in Foods

title: BRONX RENOVATION GETS A HAND
description: BUILT in the 1920's, when the Pelham Parkway area of the Bronx was being developed as a middle-class enclave, the Pelham Terrace apartments at 754-768 Brady Avenue reflected the area's strivings for comfort and respectability.

title: FEDERAL OFFICIAL SAYS HE BELIEVES CAUSE OF AIDS HAS BEEN FOUND
description: Dr. James O. Mason, head of the Federal Centers for Disease Control, said today that he believed a virus discovered in France was the cause of acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS.

title: THE ART OF THE 19TH CENTURY IS NOW RIDING HIGH
description: All over the Western world, long-disregarded aspects of the 19th century are back in business. People fall upon them as if they were the last undiscovered country of the mind, and they can't get enough of them.

description: A man who allegedly threatened to assassinate Walter F. Mondale was shot and wounded by a Secret Service agent early today after the man reportedly tried to attack the agent with a butcher knife, officials said.

Hampden Robb Jr. of Bridgehampton, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter Diana Wagstaff Robb to Anthony Taylor McDowell, a son of Yolande Mascia McDowell of Norwalk, Conn., and the late James Hugh McDowell. A September wedding is planned.

title: 'DON'T BOTHER ME' OFFERED AT CROSSROADS

title: KANSAS CITY
description: Neighboring Independence may be going all out for Harry S. Truman's 100th birthday, but Kansas City, which has its own claims upon him, is lighting a few candles, too. Among the events: Harry S. Truman night at the ball game (May 8, the Kansas City Royals vs. Detroit, Harry S. Truman Sports Complex: 816-921-4400 for tickets) and a Harry S. Truman Town Meeting, at which political commentators and politicians will discuss the significance of the Truman years (May 7, Folly Theater, 12th and Central: tickets are free; 816-234-4141 for information). And the man himself will be brought back to life by Kevin McCarthy in the one- man show, ''Give 'Em Hell, Harry,'' at the Folly on May 4 and 5 (tickets are $11 and $16; 816-474-4444).

title: A PREMIUM ON GOOD TEACHERS
description: SCHOOL districts in the state are using everything from higher salaries, to recognition awards, to special work arrangements in an effort to attract the best people into the teaching profession, and to keep them there.

description: FOUR may prove to be the year of the first Congressional election in New Jersey history in which ''the best woman'' won.

description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Henry H. Bard of Locust Valley, L.I., of the engagement of Mrs. Bard's daughter Elizabeth Taft Meyer to James H. Eaton 4th, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eaton 3d of Andover, Mass., and Kennebunkport, Me. The wedding is planned for September.

title: CORRECTION
description: The article ''What's Doing in Baltimore'' (Travel, April 1) incorrectly stated that Pimlico Race Track is at Fells Point in East Baltimore. It is in the northwest section of the city.

description: Victoria Schaefer Blewer has become the fiancee of Christopher Aram Bohjalian. The future bride is a daughter of Sondra G. Blewer of New York and Sugar Hill, N.H., and John M. Blewer of New York and Essex, Conn.

title: TROUBLE IN FRANCE
description: The big question in France is how long the Communists will stay in the Government. President Francois Mitterrand was so confident they weren't ready to leave that he maneuvered them last week into voting confidence in the policies they attack every day.

title: MEMORIES OF A CHERISHED HOME
description: Now that my family home in Independence, Mo., has been given to the people of the United States and will be opened to the public, visitors should not be surprised if they see a ghost there - not a scary ghost, but a happy, frolicsome one. That ghost is myself as a little girl, romping through the downstairs rooms and running up and down the steep stairs to the second floor.

THE WORLD ;
A Long Goodbye
description: To Hong Kong?

title: 26 FOOD PLACES LISTED FOR HEALTH VIOLATIONS
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 26 food establishments last week for violating the health code.

title: REAGAN TAKES A BREAK FROM THE FUROR OVER CENTRAL AMERICA
description: HEDRICK SMITH WASHINGTON P RESIDENT Reagan takes off for China today, demonstrating the power and prerogative of an incumbent to walk away from frustrating deadlocks back home and shift the nation's attention elsewhere. As he makes his first visit to any Communist country, Mr. Reagan can look forward this week to upstaging the Democratic Presidential contenders as well as the Republicans who helped deliver a stinging rebuke 12 days ago over the mining of Nicaraguan harbors.

title: HotLineSetUponFloodAid

title: MAN'S ROLE ON EARTH
SHE'S IN HARMONY WITH MUSICIANS
description: THE artist Madeleine Meehan can't read a note of music and she hasn't ''picked out 'Three Blind Mice' on the piano since third grade,'' she said. But she recently spent three days sitting among the musicians of the combined Minnesota and St. Paul Chamber Orchestras, feeling ''so much a part of the orchestras,'' she said, during rehearsals and recording sessions at Orchestra Hall in Minneapolis, that on the night of the ensuing public concert she found ''it odd to take a seat in the audience.''

title: CRITICS' CHOICES Theater
description: Marsha Norman's '' 'night, Mother'' was the best American play of the 1982-83 season. Writing with both humor and passion, Miss Norman tells the story of a grueling confrontation between a widowed mother and her divorced, adult daughter on the night that the daughter calmly announces her intention to commit suicide.

title: JET DIVERTED BY BOMB THREAT
description: A United Airlines jet carrying 437 people from San Francisco to Honolulu landed safely here tonight after being diverted by a bomb threat, the authorities said.

title: 8 GERMANS SAY COPTER STRAYED ACROSS FRONTIER
description: The West German border police said today that eight people reported seeing a United States Army helicopter enter Czechoslovak airspace on Friday, when American officials say it was fired on by two Soviet-built fighter planes.

title: SLONIMSKY TURNS 90
description: This Friday, one of the more valued members of the American musical community will be 90 years old. His name is Nicolas Slonimsky, and over his long life he has been a distinguished composer, conductor and lexicographer. He still composes and conducts occasionally, but his principal tasks these days, which he carries on with absolutely no apparent flagging of mental or physical energy, are the compiling of the latest incarnations of both ''Baker's Biographical Dictionary of Musicians,'' a standard reference work that he has edited (and written) in both its fifth (1958) and sixth (1978) editions, and ''Music Since 1900,'' a gigantic compendium that traces key events in 20th-century music on a nearly day- by-day basis. Both are marked by helpfully reliable scholarship and droll, Nabokovianly polysyllabic writing.

title: A Season Reborn
description: Whining reluctance, winter finally relaxed its grip on our corner of America and yielded to the festivals of renewal and liberation that the West's main religions mark on related calendars.

title: SELECTING SUMMER RENTALS
description: PEOPLE living in New York City usually consider accessibility one of the most important considerations when they look for a summer rental or vacation retreat. In fact, they often classify resort communities according to whether they are one, two or three hours' drive from the city.

title: SCHUSSING INTO SUMMER, KARPOV VS. KASPAROV
description: Though the warm weather may write finis to their sport in many places, skiers will find the welcome mat out in central Oregon, where Mount Bachelor expects its new Summit Chair, lifting skiers to the top of a 9,000- foot peak, to permit skiing into August.

title: HE RECORDS NATURE WITH HUMOR AND REVERENCE
description: The recent renaissance of significant photographic activity on the West Coast - especially in Southern California - has occurred without a great deal of established institutional support. Until a few years ago a mere handful of galleries and universities catered to the photographic audience; the major California museums were not noted for their commitment to photography as an art form. Only John Humphrey at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art paid ongoing heed to the medium. The standing complaint was also the terrible truth: West Coast photographers looking for national reputations had to journey to New York, to register at the photography department of the Museum of Modern Art.

title: PANEL PERMITS CASUAL TALKS BY SELECTMEN
description: TWO selectmen do not a quorum make, at least when they are talking informally, according to a recent ruling by the Freedom of Information Commission. The commission's decision that two members of a three-member board of selectmen can have a chat about administrative matters without calling a legal meeting has the approval of most selectmen, though there are some who are worried that the public's right to know has been damaged.

title: ARGENTINE GROUP CHALLENGES PERONISTS IN UNIONS
description: When Alberto Piccinini heard the knock on the door before dawn one day, fearing the death squads, he shouted, ''How do I know you are really the authorities?'' The police replied by breaking down the door.

title: CONFEREES
description: Religious buildings are increasingly becoming the focus of preservation efforts these days. Often the preservationists are pitted against congregations that feel they need to get rid of old buildings because they are expensive to maintain and not necessarily suited to serving today's needs.

title: EWING, MULLIN STAY AS KNIGHT CUTS 40

description: An article in the Communist Party newspaper today rejected a new Western approach to troop reductions in Europe that the Reagan Administration had offered as an opening toward wider improvement in East-West relations.

description: Gov. Mark White of Texas is preparing to call a special session of the Legislature this spring to consider nearly $1 billion in new taxes to save the state's public schools from what he and many others here see as quickening deterioration.

title: THE SALTY SECRET OF GERMAN POTTERY
description: While the Government in Bonn exhorts German workers to enter the computer age, potters in nearby H"ohr-Grenzhausen stubbornly cling to practices handed down from the Middle Ages. The salt-glazed gray pottery, with its curling blue flourishes and simple floral and leaf patterns, has been produced in this central German town since the 1500's. It is still molded by hand and fired in wood-burning kilns.

title: Hanoi Says Chinese Artillery Killed 3 People in Past Week
description: China fired thousands of artillery rounds into Vietnam's northern border provinces this week, killing three people and wounding two others, the Hanoi radio said today.

description: The assets of the Ford Foundation, the nation's wealthiest private philanthropy, increased by $700 million, to $3.4 billion, in the year that ended last September, the foundation's president said in his annual report.

title:
ANTIQUES ;
ART POTTERY AT NEWARK MUSEUM
description: NEWARK THE Newark Museum's collection of American art pottery, one of the foremost in the Northeast, will be showcased in a major exhibition starting Thursday and running through next February.

description: I'd like to hear a response from this year's Presidential candidates, including the President, to Lewis Thomas's thoughts about man's role on earth. RUDD A. CRAWFORD JR. Oberlin, Ohio

title:
GARDENNG;
THE IMPORTANCE OF SPACING
description: ONE important aspect of planting is largely overlooked in reference books, garden periodicals and even lectures on gardening - the appropriate spacing for plants. In an article in the April issue of Horticulture magazine, Roger Swain discusses the relationships between plants in the same planting.

title: FLOWERS THROUGH A PAINTERLY LENS
description: Dennis Stock made his reputation as a hard-edged photojournalist - photographing jazz musicians, Asian refugees, the counterculture of the 1960's. But, he says, ''to keep myself passionate about photography for so long, I have to find subjects still full of wonder.''

title: 3,500 IS GOAL OF SUMMER JOBS FOR YOUTH
description: THE Summer Jobs for Youth program made its first job placements last week, officially beginning a third year of service to the county's economically disadvantaged young population. And if the early response from private industry to this year's campaign is any indication, the program may go well beyond its new goal of placing 3,500 youths.

title: RECENT FIGHTING IN SRI LANKA DIMS HOPES FOR ETHNIC PEACE
description: Fighting between Tamils and Sinhalese in northern Sri Lanka recently has touched off fears that this island democracy is on the brink of prolonged civil strife.

title: Mark Robert Wolfson To Wed Lynn Roberts
description: Announcement has been made by Dorothy Roberts Cohen of New York of the engagement of her daughter, Lynn Terry Roberts, to Mark Robert Wolfson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. M. Robert Wolfson of Glencoe, Ill. The wedding is to be in September.

description: ''I believe we have the cause of AIDS, and it is an exciting discovery.'' - Dr. James O. Mason, head of the Federal Centers for Disease Control. (1:1.)

title: 'JUNK' BONDS-- THE MARKET'S CINDERELLA
description: -growing segments of the bond market has been lower-rated securities, the so-called ''junk,'' ''high-yield'' or ''low-grade'' bonds whose numbers have exploded in recent years. According to Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., $18 billion in debt issues has been raised by 300 lower-rated companies since 1977. At the end of 1983, the value of all low-grade bonds was $40 billion, or 10 percent of the corporate debt market.

title: BILL ON ALIENS A DIVISIVE ISSUE FOR DEMOCRATS
description: Proposals to rewrite the nation's basic immigration law have deeply divided the Democratic Party, pitting Hispanic groups against organized labor on a potent election-year issue.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Personal Finance column last Sunday misstated the 10-year forward averaging rule. Under certain circumstances, the rule can be used to calculate tax on distributions from Keogh plans.

title: Egypt Gets $41 Million Grant
description: The Agency for International Development has granted Egypt $41 million to improve electricity distribution networks in Alexandria, officials at the Electricity and Energy Ministry said today. The grant will help finance the construction of nine transmission stations and associated distribution lines, the officials said.

title: HANOI ASKS U.S. VETERANS FOR TALKS
description: The Vietnamese Government, lacking formal diplomatic ties with the United States, has asked an organization of American veterans of the Vietnam War to visit Hanoi every three months for talks on a variety of issues.

title: OLIVER DONATES NOTES TO JAZZ ARCHIVE
description: ''This is going to look like a lot of junk to you,'' the arranger and bandleader Sy Oliver said. He was pulling some pages of handwritten music from a folder - large yellow pages full of bold, quickly written melodies and chords, punctuated with a scratch-out here and there.

title: NEWARK TURNS DOWN $500,000 SCHOOL GRANT
description: NEWARK EDUCATORS in Jersey City and Lakewood are racing to meet a May 15 deadline to apply for a sizable Federal grant originally meant to help Newark improve its English program in grades 7 through 12.

title: Brazil Detains 8 Protesters
description: Eight demonstrators who began a fast demanding direct presidential elections were detained Friday under new emergency measures that will also be used to censor political reports next week from Brasilia broadcasters.

title: HEADLINERS
description: Hoffman's Complaint Attention must be paid when an actor of the stature of Dustin Hoffman demands that his performance schedule be cut to seven shows a week from Broadway's traditional eight. Mr. Hoffman, who is playing Willy Loman in a much-acclaimed revival of ''Death of a Salesman,'' said last week the role was so physically and emotionally demanding that he couldn't give audiences the performance they deserved if he wore himself out doing two shows on Saturdays. He got little sympathy from Broadway money men, who said dropping a performance would slice 12.5 percent from the show's potential income.

title: WHAT IS HOLLYWOOD SAYING ABOUT THE TEEN-AGE WORLD TODAY?
description: Half-way through the hit new movie ''Footloose,'' the heroine's puritanical father warns her to stay away from Ren, the new boy in town, played by Kevin Bacon. ''He's a troublemaker,'' he says ominously.
Baby Boomers

title: ART CENTER FINDS NEW HOME
description: THE old Huntington Theater's lights are going up again on Saturday. The vaudeville boards have been rebuilt into a sprung stage for dancers. And the Inter-Media Art Center, established originally in Huntington, is returning to the town its founders call ''the most culturally active on Long Island.''

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS ; A Town Divided
description: Charging that the Mayor was meddling in its affairs, the nonpartisan Housing Authority in Anthony, Tex., packed up a year ago and moved its office three blocks to New Mexico. When the Mayor, Adrian Baca, ordered the defectors to return by Aug. 15, the authority sat tight in the sister town of Anthony, N.M.

title: NEW CLUB CATERS TO BRIDGE ADDICTS
description: At 1 A.M., after five hours of play, a roomful of bridge players had dwindled to a single foursome. Cigarettes were ground out nervously in overflowing ashtrays. A tense silence was interrupted by occasional outbursts.

title: Informer in Massachusetts Gets a Suspended Sentence
description: Stanley J. Barczak, a former tax examiner who was an informer in a 1982 bribery investigation, has been given a suspended sentence even though his testimony about widespread corruption in the Massachusetts Revenue Department was never proved in court.

title: LASER TURNTABLES NOW COME WITH EXTRA CONVENIENCES
description: When the digital phonograph made its American debut just a year ago, only two laser turntables were available for playing the new Compact Disks. Since then, more than a dozen new models have sounded off, and as production rises, prices drop. This is good news for audio fans eager to scramble aboard this new bandwagon but kept on the sidelines by the cost. On average, compact disk players today are about $200 cheaper than last year and there is a growing choice among different brands.

title: PHILS ROUT METS
description: Through the highs and lows of the Mets' first 14 games this season, Manager Dave Johnson has played the role of a patient teacher: coddling when necessary, scolding only if pushed, but always putting the best possible face on even the worst circumstances.

title: FATHERS AND DAUGHTERS
LAW TYING DRAFT REGISTRATION TO COLLEGE AID GAINS RESULTS
description: Although the Supreme Court is still considering its legality, a law linking Federal student aid to draft registration seems to have achieved most of the objectives sought by its proponents.

title: TWO MUSICIANS COUNTERPOINT AND BALANCE EACH OTHER
description: Beethoven's five piano concertos are so thoroughly thought out in their blend of solo part and orchestra that superior performances rarely happen without some equally thoughtful matchmaking between the principals involved.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES Broadcast TV
description: ''Grace Bumbry and Shirely Verrett in Concert at Covent Garden'' brings together two distinguished sopranos for a rare joint appearance. The British actor Simon Ward will serve as host for this 90-minute program, which will be shown Wednesday at 9:30 P.M. on Channels 13 and 49.

title: F.B.I. SIFTS DEBRIS OF CAPITAL NAVE YARD BLAST
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation was sifting ''a huge amount of debris'' today to determine the type and amount of explosives used in the blast that severely damaged the officers club at the Washington Navy Yard.

title: Zanzibar Leader Wins 87.5 Percent of Vote
description: The sole candidate in Zanzibar's presidential election received 87.5 percent of ballots cast, election officials announced today.

title: TAPE CHANGES THE HOME MOVIE PICTURE
description: With video recording joining jogging and Jacuzzis as part of our popular culture, a basic technical shift is under way: Increasingly, magnetic tape is replacing film for making private moving pictures.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: SEARINGTOWN ONE recent day when the sun was shining and it seemed like a good idea to attempt another vegetable garden, I realized that it was time to stop living off the fantasy of being a Long Islander and face the reality of the situation: green beans never will grow in my back yard. Oh, stuff that I don't really need will spring up like weeds - 40 zucchinis, each 12 inches long, or 648 radishes.

description: DAVID SHRIBMAN

title: Sally Williams, an Actress, Marries John Madden
description: Sally Williams, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Williams of Chesapeake, Va., was married there yesterday to John Patrick Madden, a son of Eileen M. Madden of Yonkers and the late Eugene P. Madden. The Rev. Edward Rigg performed the ceremony at the Jolliff Methodist Church.

title: WOMEN HAVE A BLUNT COACH
description: -style straw hat are the now-familiar trademarks that set Brooks Johnson apart from a crowd at a track and field meet. But there is more than his manner of dress that distinguishes him from most college coaches. When others involved in the Olympic Games often play politics, Johnson has succeeded by being rather blunt and outspoken.

title: MRS. LESSING ADDRESSES SOME OF LIFE'S PUZZLES
description: Doris Lessing, who is in the front rank of internationally acclaimed novelists, recently gave two talks in New York on literature, women and men, and similar puzzling matters.

title: Durbin Bowling Victor
description: Mike Durbin won four consecutive matches today and became the first bowler to capture the Firestone Tournament of Champions three times.

title: DESPITE GAINS, TRANS-HUDSON BATTLE GOES ON
description: TRENTON ALTHOUGH there has been some hard-won movement - despite objections by some New York officials - on projects designed to improve New Jersey's side of the Hudson River, emotions on both sides of the river are still running high.

title:
ART;
PAINTING/PHOTOGRAPHY': CAMERA'S ROLE AS A TOLLO IS GROWING
description: At times while ''Paintin/Photography'' at the Thorpe Intermedia Gallery near Sparkill in Rockland County, one loses track of the confluence of the two media. This is a minor difficulty, however, for on the whole the show is a rather awesome display of personal maneuvers in today's growing army of artists. The 26 artists here are working to distinguish themselves through smart manipulation of diverse media.

title: International
description: The Soviet newspaper Pravda rejected new Western proposals for force reductions in Western Europe that the Reagan Administration had presented as a possible opening toward wider improvement in East- West relations. It was the second time in a week that the Kremlin had reacted negatively to a new Western arms initiative. (Page 1, Column 6.) West Germans say they saw a United States Army helicopter enter Czechoslovak airspace Friday, when American officials say it was fired on by two Soviet-built fighter planes. West German border police said that at least eight people have asserted they saw the helicopter fly into Czechoslovak air space. Statements to the border police by the helicopter crew that they were in West German airspace when fired on could not be confirmed by a United States Army spokesman in Stuttgart. (1:5.)

title: CORRECTION
description: A caption last Sunday on the contents page of Home Design, part 2 of The Times Magazine, incorrectly attributed the painting ''Cigarette,'' shown in the cover photograph. The painter is Donald Sultan.

title: GENERALS TO MEET ROZIER AND MAULERS
description: The Generals confront another expansion team, the Maulers, in Pittsburgh today. The records are opposite but deceiving: 6-2 for the Generals and 2-6 for the Maulers.

title: Jane Bachman to Marry Steven I. Wulf in October
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Bachman of Wellesley Hills, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jane Elizabeth Bachman, to Steven Ira Wulf, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin L. Wulf of Troy, N.Y., and Sanibel Island, Fla.

title: CONSUMER RATES

WESTCHESTER OPINION;
WANTED: AS MANY JANE KELLEYS AS POSSIBLE
description: MANY were saddened last month to learn of the death of Jane Seymour Kelley at the age of 85. A civic leader for more than 50 years, past president of the Scarsdale, Westchester and New York State Leagues of Women Voters, founder of several ongoing organizations and recipient of many awards, she made an indelible impression on all who came in contact with her.

title: ONCE AGAIN,IT LOOKS EASY FOR MONDALE
description: PHIL GAILEY

title: Data Bank; April 22, 1984

DANCE;
BALLET COMPANY WITH EUROPEAN FLAVOR
description: YORKTOWN HEIGHTS DRIVING through Yorktown Heights on a rainy Sunday it is hard to imagine long- legged ballet dancers running through their paces on the second floor of the Yorktown Community and Cultural Center. This grand old elementary school building on a typical commercial strip, is home to the Dance Theater in Westchester, the five-year-old regional ballet company directed by Rose-Marie Menes. The group will present its spring season next Saturday evening, along with two children's matinees Saturday and Sunday afternoons at the Yorktown High School auditorium.

title: PAYING DUES TO UNCLE SAM --BELATEDLY
description: MILLIONS of taxpayers burned the midnight oil last weekend to get their tax returns in under the deadline. But many took advantage of a provision in the tax law that gives them an additional four months until the day of reckoning.

title: STAGE: MUSICAL 'ROAD'
description: In a score of Paramount movies in the 1940's, Bing Crosby and Bob Hope trotted the globe in search of fame, fortune and Lamour. The formula was simple and also surefire. Two friends, a singer and a comedian - partners in penury, brashness and show business - fast-talked their way out of trouble. Through a series of turnabouts, they found themselves in Utopia, or, at least, in the spotlight.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: MORE than $300 has been donated thus far to the Granby Land Trust, a private, nonprofit conservation group that will administer the care of a 500- year-old white oak in the town of Granby in northern Connecticut.Gifts have come from as far away as Woodbridge and Middlebury. The Simsbury Bank and Trust Company, which has an office in Granby, has promised to match the first $500 donated.

title: No Headline

title: Miss Brenner, a Designer, Is Engaged to David Janoff
description: Mr. and Mrs. Howard Brenner of Levittown, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Deborah Brenner to David Z. Janoff, the son of Esther Janoff of Forest Hills, Queens, and the late Jack M. Janoff.

title: THIRD WORLD TRUTHS FROM 'SUGAR CANE ALLEY'
description: Euzhan Palcy's ''Sugar Cane Alley'' sneaks up on you with what at first seems to be its artlessness, as if it were a tale being told by someone too shy to look you directly in the eye. There is, however, something so dependably right about its choices of images, events and actors that you eventually realize that what initially seemed to be artlessness is a conscious style. It's neither mock-primitive nor sophisticated, but a style thoroughly at the service of its narrative, which is a deceptively gentle - almost polite - tale about growing up black, poor, proud and fiercely ambitious on the French West Indian island of Martinique in the early 1930's.

title: THE SINGLE-FAMILY 'FEEL'
description: The move of corporations to the Danbury, Conn., area has created a need for new housing there and the designers of Shepherd Hill, a 140-unit condominium going up on Old Brookfield Road in Danbury, think that need is for something compact that still feels like a home.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS ; Wild Lawns
description: Many suburban homeowners find grass-cutting painful. Nellie Shriver, head of the Fruitarian Network, says it's the other way around: It's the grass that feels the pain.

title: HELP ON WAY FOR TITLE IX

title: LISPENARD CROCKER
description: Lispenard Seabury Crocker, widow of Edward S. Crocker, a former Ambassador to Iraq, died Thursday at her home in New York. She was 82 years old and a longtime resident of Kittery Point, Me. Mrs. Crocker is survived by a daughter, Mrs. Marshall Green of Washington; two sisters. Mrs. Fergus Reid Jr. of New York and Mrs. William W. Howells of Boston; three grandsons and one great-grandson.

title: TWO BALLET COMPANIES IN SEARCH OF A FUTURE
description: Nearly all private ballet companies - as distinct from those in state opera houses - eventually die. This is a historical fact that might be kept in mind on Tuesday when America's two leading (and private) ballet companies - American Ballet Theater and New York City Ballet - open their spring seasons at Lincoln Center on the same night.

title: THE EASTER STORY
description: There was a lot of talk around here this Holy Week about politics and prayer, but not much about the suffering of the human race or what we should be praying for.

description: Theoretically, only the people of Somers should be concerned about the move into their town of two corporate giants, International Business Machines and Pepsico - and for the most part, Somers is welcoming them.

description: The Federal Environmental Protection Agency has given New York State $715,000 to conduct a new study to pinpoint the present location in the upper Hudson River of sediments contaminated by toxic PCB's.

title: Laura E. Bellamy To Become Bride
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William M. Bellamy Jr. of Chappaqua, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter Laura Elizabeth Bellamy to Steven Brewster Fitzpatrick, a son of Capt. Wayne Nichols Fitzpatrick, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Fitzpatrick of Severna Park, Md.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: NANUET
description: WHERE heavily congested Route 59 passes through Nanuet, this Rockland County community seems to be made up entirely of modern, bustling shopping centers. But just a few blocks away, it becomes an older, less crowded, almost rural community, with tree-lined streets, well-kept lawns and wooded country roads.

description: SELECTED LETTERS

title: CRITICS' CHOICES Cable TV
description: Seeing Boy George on stage in ''Culture Club in Concert,'' which will be shown by Home Box Office on Saturday at 10:30 P.M., it's easy to understand why he's the object of such universal affection - the maker of million-selling pop records, the winner of the Best New Artist Grammy Award, and the inventor of a much-imitated ''look.'' Behind his mascara and lipstick, under his rabbi's hat with the multicolored braids dangling from of it, is an utterly disarming character.

title: JAPAN'S WARY FINANCIAL REVOLUTION

title: Elizabeth Cleary Planning to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Malachy F. Cleary of New York and New Rochelle, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Frances Cleary, to Daniel R. McCarthy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David McCarthy of Portsmouth, R.I. A December wedding is planned.

title: CONCERT: 'LAST WORDS'
description: FRANZ JOSEPH HAYDN'S ''Seven Last Words of the Saviour on the Cross'' occupies an unusual position among his works. The composer, asked to provide instrumental music for a lengthy Good Friday service, delivered seven extended meditations, grave and beautiful, to serve as interludes between sermons built around the Crucifixion. Haydn later recalled the circumstances of this commission: ''Each time at the end of the sermon the orchestra would begin again. My composition had to be in keeping with this presentation. It was not the easiest task to compose seven Adagios in succession, each of them lasting close on 10 minutes, without tiring the listener.''

title: Teamster Sees Reagan Gaining Worker Support
description: Jackie Presser, president of the teamsters' union, said today that he expected President Reagan to get even more support from blue-collar workers this year than he got four years ago.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: A punt on fourth down is so poorly executed that the ball goes straight up and hits the ground behind the line of scrimmage without being touched by any member of the defense. Is it legal for an offensive player in the National Football League to pick up the ball and advance it?

title: SPARKS FLY WITH 2 CABLE COMPANIES IN ONE AREA
description: On one side of Route 329, the telephone poles are strung with television cable belonging to Service Electric Cable TV. On the other side, the poles are hung with Twin County cable.

title: ANGELS RALLY FOR 5TH IN ROW
description: Doug DeCinces and Bobby Grich hit two- run home runs in the seventh inning today to rally the California Angels to a 9-6 triumph over the Toronto Blue Jays.

title: SURPRISE AT WOMEN'S TRYOUTS
description: JEFF METCALFE

title: SOCIAL WORK PROGRAMS FOR PRIVATE OUTPATIENTS
description: Marlene Cooper is a social worker on the staff of the Presbyterian Hospital at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, and her domain - all the practical and emotional ramifications of disability, illness, family rupture, aging, death - does not differ from that of other hospital social workers. But she does represent a new effort being made in some hospitals to extend their social work programs to cover patients who are not hospitalized and who are not cared for by clinic staff members but by private physicians.

title: No Headline
description: The National Guard cordoned off this town today after two-thirds of it was destroyed by a tornado Saturday night. Spawned by waves of severe thunderstorms, tornadoes swept through 10 counties in northern Mississippi, killing 15 people and injuring more than 100.

title: The U.N. Today April 23, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: PLAYING ROLES FOR THERAPY
description: THE anorexic woman in her late

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Society is pressed to its ancient defense against the violent criminal: the fear of swift and severe punishment.

title: DEATH OF A HIJACKER: STIRRINGS IN ISRAEL
description: Israeli authorities have gradually begun to respond to the growing indications that one of the Arabs who hijacked an Israeli bus 10 days ago was captured alive and then killed. The possibility that this happened has caused concern in official circles because it has thrown into question one of Israel's longstanding and cardinal policies: that terrorists can surrender with the assurance that they will not be executed.

title: DANCE: FESTIVAL TROUPE AND 'SLEEPING BEAUTY'
description: ELEANOR D'ANTUONO, for many years one of American Ballet Theater's leading ballerinas, and John Meehan, a former principal with the company, danced in a new, and for many reasons, interesting staging of ''The Sleeping Beauty'' Saturday night at Queens College's Colden Center.

title: GUINEA'S NEW ECONOMIC PATH
description: Not long ago, Guinea's new military ruler, Col. Lansana Conte, was asked to describe this nation a quarter of a century hence. He thought about the question for what seemed a long time, then replied: ''Guinea will be very prosperous.''

title: UPSTATE WINDMILL PROJECT CHURNS UP DISPUTE
description: This village, which calls itself ''the hang-gliding capital of the East,'' is trying to take advantage of the strong air currents that sweep the nearby Shawangunk Mountains to become ''the windmill capital of the United States'' through a new electricity-generating project.

title: Dentsu of Japan Still Largest Agency
description: Dentsu, the Japanese giant, continues to be the world's largest advertising agency, according to Advertising Age, which today publishes its international report.

title: Oilers,North Stars Advance
description: Jari Kurri rekindled Edmonton's lost firepower with two goals in a four-goal second period tonight to lead the Oilers into the Stanley Cup semifinals with a 7-4 victory over the Calgary Flames.

title: Angola Dynamite Blast Reportedly Kills 30
description: A jeep loaded with dynamite exploded on Thursday in the Angolan town of Huambo, killing about 30 people and wounding more than 70 others, according to Yugoslav press accounts published today.

title: Graduates Said to Get 30% More Job Offers
description: College seniors this spring are getting 30 percent more job offers from business recruiters than their counterparts did last year as the economy continues its rebound, a national survey indicates.

title: CORPORATE PROFITS UP IN QUARTER
description: Fueled by increased production and sales, first-quarter corporate profits in most industries jumped from last year's levels. The higher-than-expected earnings spread across many sectors of the economy, reflecting a broad recovery.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: MONDAY, APRIL 23, 1984

title: Thayer Case Denials Made
description: Paul Thayer, the former Deputy Secretary of Defense, and eight codefendants have filed documents denying allegations that they used inside corporate information to reap $1.9 million in illegal stock profits.

title: NICARAGUAN BISHOPS URGE TALKS WITH REBELS
description: Nicaragua's nine Roman Catholic bishops issued a pastoral letter today criticizing the Sandinista Government and urging it to open negotiations with leaders of armed insurgent groups.

title: 'DRIFTING,' FILM MAKER IN ISRAEL
description: THE chief character in Amos Guttman's ''Drifting,'' which opens today at the 8th Street Playhouse, is a desultory would-be film maker. ''I'm busy with my film right now'' is the sort of thing he likes to say, although during the course of ''Drifting'' his only activities related to film making are to wonder how he can raise some money and muse about whether it would be worthwhile to dramatize the life of Ramon Novarro.

title: HART ON 'CHAFF' AND MONDALE'S FINANCES
description: From Senator Gary Hart's appearance yesterday on the NBC News program ''Meet the Press'':

title: Aide Says Pisani Won't Seek R
description: State Senator Joseph R. Pisani will not seek re-election because of the time and expense needed to defend himself against Federal charges of mail fraud and income-tax evasion, a spokesman said today.

title: Probation Reform Hits a Snag
description: New York's judges sentence many more felons to probation than to prison. Yet the probation system is greatly neglected, especially in New York City. Its rescue depends on the state's taking charge from localities. A sensible plan to do that is caught in a spat between Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch.

title: A DIVERSE MIRACLE
description: No matter how many times one has seen Jerusalem, it astonishes: the exotic mix of faces and cultures and clothes and buildings, the physical expressions of history. But given that diversity, and the bloody history, the most surprising thing about Jerusalem today is that it lives and functions in relative tranquility.

title: PRESIDENTIAL FOREIGN POLICY POWER, LIMITED
description: To the Editor:

title: EPISCOPAL BISHOP CALLS U.S. LATIN POLICY 'ILLEGAL AND IMMORAL'
description: Bishop Paul Moore Jr. of the Episcopal Diocese of New York denounced United States policy in Central America yesterday as ''illegal, inconsistent, ill- advised and immoral.''

title: Factory Order Estimate Rises
description: Orders to United States factories rose a healthy 1.4 percent in February, the Government reported in a revision of its earlier estimate.

title: MONDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. Kansas City Royals, at Yankee Stadium, 8:05 P.M. Phil Niekro seeks his fourth victory without a defeat. (Television - SportsChannel 8 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 8 P.M.) Mets vs.

title: China Getting ShowOf Brooklyn Museum
description: An exhibition of 51 American oil paintings from the Brooklyn Museum will begin a four-month tour of China on Saturday while President Reagan is making his first visit to the country.

title: MEAD STRESSES DATA GROWTH
description: The Mead Corporation, while not neglecting its main business of paper and forest products, is keeping a sharp eye on the home computer market through its Mead Data Central division.

title: COAL MINE LABOR TALKS FACING UNCERTAINTIES
description: When the leaders of the United Mine Workers meet the representatives of the nation's major coal producers here Tuesday to seek a new labor contract, the negotiators will face uncertainties not felt since the heyday of John L. Lewis.

title: QUARTERLY BANK RESULTS MIXED
description: There were distinct winners and losers among the nation's largest banks during the first quarter as at least one reported record profits, while others did quite poorly.

title: CRISIS COMMANDER
description: The command role of Home Secretary Leon Brittan, who has been directing the Government's handling of the Libyan Embassy crisis, was highlighted this week by the absence of two people: the Prime Minister and the Foreign Secretary. The crisis erupted just after Margaret Thatcher left on a three-day state visit to Portugal; the Foreign Minister, Sir Geoffrey Howe, was in China negotiating the future of Hong Kong.

title: A Voice for Abused Children

title: No Headline
description: Technology, Security and Zeal Tightening up export controls and combating the legions of Soviet agents who seek technology of military value are prudent measures. But in its pursuit of technology leaks, the Reagan Administration is losing sight of larger objectives and even undermining them.

title: INDONESIAN AIDE SAYS SOVIET BACKS CAMBODIA PEACE PLAN
description: Indonesia's Foreign Minister says the Soviet Union has expressed support for an Indonesian initiative for a political solution in Vietnamese-occupied Cambodia.

title: 'GENTLEMEN OF VERONA,' IN SHAKESPEARE SERIES'
description: ''THE Two Gentlemen of Verona'' is not the sort of theatrical challenge that producers and directors are eager to confront. The play is splattered with puns that are likely to prove incomprehensible to the average contemporary audience and, worse, the ending features one of the more unconvincing turnabouts in stage history. Nevertheless, the BBC's ''Shakespeare Plays'' is committed to doing the complete works. There is simply no avoiding this one, which can be seen on WNET, Channel 13, tonight at 8 o'clock.

title: LABOR DEPT. STUDY ON CARTER HAWLEY
description: The handling of the profit-sharing plan for employees of Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. is being studied by the Labor Department for possible violations of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, it has been learned. The plan owns an 18.5 percent block of shares that may determine whether The Limited Inc. succeeds in acquiring Carter Hawley.

description: For those who prefer team play to the pair games readily available in clubs, a group of commercial leagues in the metropolitan area provide a solution.

title: OPEN-SECRET WAR
description: Why don't we come right out with it? Everybody knows we want to put pressure on the Communist regime in Nicaragua, to prevent its takeover of El Salvador today and its importation of Soviet missiles tomorrow. To neat and tidy minds, the honest answer is to cut out all this ''secret war'' and ''covert action'' talk, and make a decision whether or not to declare war.

title: TREASURY'S FINANCINGS TO RETURN

On Wednesday the Treasury is scheduled to sell $8.25 billion of new two-year Treasury notes, and securities dealers are already looking ahead to a $16 billion package of notes and bonds that they expect to be announced on May 2 and auctioned in the week of May 7.

title: MONDAY, APRIL 23, 1984 International
description: Britain broke diplomatic ties with Libya and ordered the occupants of the Libyan Embassy in London to leave the country by next Sunday. Britain acted because of the refusal of the Libyan Government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi to cooperate in an inquiry into a shooting incident last Tuesday outside the Libyan Embassy. In that incident, a British constable was killed and 10 protesters were wounded. British officials say they believe the embassy's occupants include the gunman reponsible for the death of Constable Yvonne Fletcher and the wounding of the others. (Page A1, Column 6.) Libya responded to Britain's decision with ''surprise and indignation'' and accused the Thatcher Government of ''launching a campaign of hatred and racism against the Libyan Arab people.'' The Foreign Ministry in Tripoli said, however, that the Government would continue to provide security and protection for the 8,000 British citizens living in Libya. (A10:4.)

title: Futures/Options; Prospect Of Unifying Exchanges
description: Mercantile exchanges announced a week ago that they were giving each other's members access to, in effect, their weakest markets, the news provoked much cynicism. But it also raised the prospect once again of uniting New York's five futures markets.

title: THEATER: 'BEETHOVEN'S TENTH ' WITH PETER USTINOV
description: SERVING as both author and star, Peter Ustinov has brought Ludwig van Beethoven back from the grave in ''Beethoven's Tenth,'' his new play at the Nederlander. But why? This illustrious comic actor gets all dressed up as the unkempt genius, only to leave the character stranded in an inert and sentimental domestic comedy that might be mistaken for a padded, Anglicized rendition of ''Father Knows Best.'' Certainly there's enough funny material for a 20-minute sketch in ''Beethoven's Tenth'' - as well as the seeds of a classic Ustinovian performance - but the evening is as unrealized as the nonexistent symphony of its title.

title: LAKERS SWEEP KINGS

title: Hindu Priest Killed in Punjab
description: A Hindu priest was shot and killed in Punjab today as militant Sikhs and Hindus set their terms for resuming talks with the Government on the crisis in the northern Indian state, the Press Trust of India reported. The news agency said gunmen riding on a scooter fired at the priest of a Hindu temple in Jogiana, wounding him, his wife and two others. The priest later died in a hospital and the others were reported in serious condition, it said.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: SEX AND DESTINY. The Politics of Human Fertility. By Germaine Greer. 541 pages. Harper & Row. $19.95. BACK in the early 70's, Germaine Greer emerged as the Sally Bowles of the women's movement. Flamboyant, sexy and intellectual enough to casually drop references to Shakespeare and Eliot, she was constantly popping up in magazines and on television talk shows - dressed in exotic costumes and talking about how women should use sex as a ''revolutionary'' tool. Although she liked to describe herself with the rather sexist term of ''super- groupie,'' her best-selling book, ''The Female Eunuch'' - in which she argued that women had been castrated by a repressive society - was acclaimed for its passionate feminism and for its wit and erudition.

title: DECLINE OF EUROPE'S SHIPYARDS

title: ACID RAIN REPORTED OVER SOVIET UNION
description: RUSSIAN scientists have reported that monitoring stations along the western borders are detecting acid rain entering the Soviet Union from central and western Europe.

title: NATIONAL INTERGROUP HAS PROFIT
description: Spurred by a strong rebound in its aluminum division and a slow recovery in steel, National Intergroup Inc. yesterday reported a small profit in the first quarter compared with a loss in the quarter a year earlier.

GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: CHINA WARE This has been a large and colorful season for arts of the Chinese persuasion, an outpouring that honors the 200th anniversary of the start of trade between China and the United States. New York's galleries and museums have been mounting exhibitions of costume, ceramics, paintings and other items reflective of the Far Eastern culture. The touch of Chinese history, however, has not been noticeably felt in the local dramatic arts, at least not much until tonight at 8, when the Pan Asian Repertory remedies the situation.

description: Lea Plarski, the chairman of the selection committee for the United States Olympic women's basketball team, has a prediction. She says the American team ''will win the gold medal'' at the Summer Games.

All in Family For Baseball
description: The Yankees used to kid Yogi Berra for rushing to the clubhouse telephone to find out how his son Dale was doing on the Pittsburgh Pirates. But the Mets now have two doting fathers of their own: Mel Stottlemyre and Bill Robinson, who were Yankee teammates 15 years ago and who now are coaches on the Mets.

title: Solution Expected
description: Juan Antonio Samaranch , the president of the International Olympic Committee, said yesterday that he was hopeful a solution could be reached when Los Angeles and Soviet Olympic officials meet here Tuesday to discuss their differences over arrangements for the Games this summer. Tuesday's meeting was called by Samaranch in response to harsh Soviet criticism of the United States and fears of a Soviet boycott. . . . The women's 5,000-* and 10,000-meter runs will be held as demonstration events at the United States Olympic trials in June, Jacqueline Hansen, a marathon runner, announced yesterday. Miss Hansen has been active in a fight to get the events on the Olympic agenda this summer along with the American Civil Liberties Union.

title: DETREX CHEMICAL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in February 1984.

title: NEW WNET SHEDS FISCAL TROUBLES
description: Two years after it faced the worst financial crisis in its history, WNET-TV has placed its finances on a sound footing, according to the station's management and members of its board of trustees. By the end of the year, they say, the New York metropolitan area's major public television station will have erased its deficit of $6.5 million.

title: Sentence Imposed In Gilbey Murder
description: A Bronx man convicted of strangling the ex-wife of an heir to the Gilbey gin fortune was sentenced yesterday to 25 years to life in prison.

description: Golden Enterprises Inc. yesterday named its chairman and chief executive, Sloan Y. Bashinsky, to the additional post of president of the Birmingham, Ala., company.

description: The word comes from the Knick bench. ''Thirty-five, thirty-five!'' Coach Hubie Brown will shout. That is Bill Cartwright's play.

title: ; Alderman Planning Newspaper Inserts
description: The Alderman Agency of New York, specialists in creating catalogues for retailers, is going to diversify into newspaper inserts, very special newspaper inserts.

title: Doubts on Miss Budd
description: Zola Budd, the exceptionally talented middle-distance runner from South Africa, will probably not be eligible for the Olympics this summer despite her new British citizenship, a member of the International Olympic Committee said yesterday. In an interview in Stockholm with The Associated Press, Gunnar Ericsson of Sweden, who serves on the I.O.C.'s eligibility committee, said the panel would discuss the case Friday at I.O.C. headquarters in Lausanne, Switzerland.

title: Firefighter Saves 3 Young Children
description: Three young children were rescued yesterday by a firefighter who rushed into their East Harlem apartment before the fire hoses were hooked up.

title: NESTLE IN TALKS ON A PURCHASE
description: Coopervision Inc., which last week introduced a new extended-wear contact lens, said yesterday that it was having talks with Nestle S.A. and Nestle's Alcon Laboratories about the possible acquisition of Coopervision for about $500 million.

title: Singer Net Up Sixfold
description: The Singer Company reported yesterday that, aided by strong gains in its aerospace electronics operations, its earnings in the first quarter increased almost sixfold on a 4.5 percent increase in revenues. The Stamford, Conn., concern, which also cited substantial gains by its consumer products and international groups, said net income soared to $18.1 million, or 96 cents a share.

Nigeria Plans New Currency
description: Nigeria's military government announced tonight that the country's local currency, the naira, is to be replaced within two weeks in a move to root out corruption.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Chesebrough-Pond's Inc., a consumer products company in Greenwich, Conn., said its Health-Tex division had agreed in principle to acquire Imperial Reading Corp. Chesebrough will pay $4.9 million for Imperial's facilities and worldwide rights to the Brittania trademark for children's wear and accessories.

title: THEATER: 'BATHERS,' IN U.S.S.R.
description: NEW HAVEN THE chief of police, the chief prosecuting officer and other powerful politicians spend sybaritic days and nights luxuriating in a local bathhouse. In this pleasure palace, only partly converted from its original role as a children's sports complex, the officials dally with readily available women, feast like Romans and drink expensive bourbon. The scene could be America or any other Western society. It happens to be Pupkov, in the provinces of the Soviet Union.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A listing in the Executive Changes column of Business Day yesterday misidentified a Norwalk, Conn., maker of electrical and electronic connectors. It is the Burndy Corporation.

title: WINTER COATS WARM UP THE FALL OPENINGS
description: Willi Smith opened the fall fashion season, as he has been doing for a couple of years, with a presentation of his lively young clothes for Williwear at the Puck Building in SoHo yesterday morning. The good-humored show was an amalgam of the British- Japanese urchin look. Smudged faces, high-laced shoes or sneakers and visored caps on disheveled hair helped to distract attention from the good-looking casual clothes that are the basis of the collection. They are reasonably offbeat and reasonably trendy, offering an antidote to the current preppy fashion scene.

description: The Kimberly-Clark Corporation said today that growth in the sales of household towels and disposable diapers helped it post a 14.3 percent rise in its first-quarter income.

title: 'CITY NEWS,' A DRAMA ON 'AMERICAN PLAYHOUSE'
description: PUBLIC television's ''American Playhouse'' is a distinguished series, but in terms of experimental work it is not terribly adventurous. Forays into being provocative are generally made in terms of tackling, very carefully, lofty political or social issues. Tonight's presentation on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock, ''City News,'' is a low- budget whacky exercise that tries to be a bit different. It is, although the film is not nearly as clever or sophisticated as it hopes to be.

title: BALLET: FELD'S 'PAPILLON'
description: ELIOT FELD'S ''Papillon,'' performed by the Feld Ballet on Friday at the Joyce Theater, will likely prove to be one of the madder new works of the season. This look at butterflies is chocolate cake and May wine - not substantial as a steady diet, but tremendous fun.

title: Barrett C. Shelton, 81, Editor Of Decatur Daily in Alabama
description: Barrett Clinton Shelton, editor and publisher of The Decatur Daily for 60 years, died Sunday in a Birmingham hospital. He was 81 years old.

title: DEVASTATED FOREST OFFERS A RARE VIEW OF REBIRTH
description: LAST year, in perhaps the most severe environmental disaster the earth has suffered in centuries, a forest fire devastated a vast, remote section of Indonesia. Compounded by the worst drought in the area in a century, the fire destroyed plant and animal life over 13,000 square miles of woodland, an area the size of Connecticut and Massachusetts combined.

title: Bandits Win, 20-7
description: John Reaves tossed two touchdown passes tonight as the Tampa Bay Bandits downed the Michigan Panthers, 20-7, handing the defending United States Football League champions their third straight defeat. Reaves fired a 12-yard scoring pass to the tight end Marvin Harvey in the first period and hit the wide receiver Eric Truvillion on a 17-yard strike late in the second quarter to give the Bandits a 14-7 halftime edge.

title: Flickinger's Talks With Pneumo End
description: The Pneumo Corporation and the S.M. Flickinger Company said they had ended talks concerning Pneumo's possible acquisition of Flickinger.

RUBY GOLDSTEIN, EX-FIGHTER AND CONTROVERSIAL REFEREE
description: Ruby Goldstein, a prominent boxing referee who worked in 39 championship fights during a 21-year career beginning in 1943, died of cancer Sunday at his home in Miami Beach. He was 76 years old.

title: Chinese Coal Pact With Occidental
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation will sign a coal pact with China next Sunday, Dr. Armand Hammer, Occidental's chairman, said.

title: NEW PLAN TO MANAGE SEABROOK
description: The partners in the Seabrook nuclear project have moved to take over financial management of the plant after its lead utility, the Public Service Company of New Hampshire, defaulted Friday on its 35.5 percent share of expenses, executives of two of the partners said here today.

description: State Senator Joseph R. Pisani, who is scheduled to go on trial Monday in Federal District Court in Manhattan on 39 counts of embezzlement and tax fraud, announced today that he would not run for re-election this year.

title: KOCH PROPOSES AN INCREASE OF 5% IN BUDGET FOR BOARD OF EDUCATION
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he planned to increase the Board of Education's budget by about 5 percent for the next school year. The increase, however, would be considerably less than the board and civic groups contend is needed to bring about substantial improvement.

title: MCDONALD'S CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Reade Cleared In Movie Case
description: The Walter Reade Organization Inc., operator of eight Manhattan movie theaters, was cleared of any liability by a Federal jury yesterday in an antitrust suit brought by the Quad Cinema Corporation. Quad Cinema, which operates a movie theater by that name in Greenwich Village, had charged Walter Reade and 18 other defendants with illegal practices that excluded Quad Cinema from showing popular movies during their first run in Manhattan. The company had asked $2.9 million in damages from the defendants, which included the nation's major motion picture distributors and Manhattan's major motion picture exhibitors.

title: INTERSTATE BANKING RUSH IS ON
description: Even though interstate banking is supposed to be prohibited by Federal law, growing numbers of banks and savings institutions, including some of the nation's largest, are scrambling to expand across state lines.

title: ART OF PROGRAMMING FOR BALLET
description: STARTING tonight, the New York City Ballet will be dancing eight times weekly for nine weeks at the New York State Theater. Except when the three-act ''Jewels'' occupies the entire bill, each performance will consist of several works drawn from a repertory that contains some of the treasures of contemporary ballet.

title: CALFED INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TUESDAY, APRIL 24, 1984 International
description: An end of a London Embassy siege is in prospect. A spokesman for the diplomats and students in the Libyan mission said they would leave the building next Sunday, the deadline set by Britain when it broke off relations with Libya. The spokesman said: ''We have a lot of packing to do. After that, we will all be happy to leave Britain.'' (Page A1, Columns 1-2.) A U.S.-China nuclear accord is expected to be announced by President Reagan after he arrives in Peking on Thursday for his six-day visit. Administration officials indicated that negotiators had reached agreement on a treaty that would permit American companies to help China build nuclear reactors. (A1:3.)

Racing Inquiry
description: Ever since the thoroughbred horsemen's association got into a contract dispute with some race-track owners in the Detroit area, there have been charges by the horsemen that race- fixing and other improprieties have been rife at two area tracks, Detroit Race Course and Hazel Park. Last week, about 50 horse owners picketed the state capital demanding an investigation, and now it appears they're going to get it. Leonard Gilman , the United States Attorney for Detroit, has ordered the Federal Bureau of Investigation to investigate the charges.

title: STRONG EARTHQUAKE SHAKES AREA IN NORTHERN CALIFORNIA
description: A strong earthquake shook the San Francisco Bay region at 1:16 P.M. today. It was centered about 12 miles southeast of San Jose, where the greatest damage occurred, and was measured at about 6.0 on the Richter scale.

title: 500 OCCUPY BRAZIL CONGRESS
description: About 500 people occupied Congress here today in defiance of emergency decrees and shouted slogans demanding direct presidential elections. On Wednesday, Congress is to take up an opposition proposal for direct elections.

title: Senate Democrats Support Rise in Connecticut Gas Tax
description: The Democratic majority in the State Senate, seeking to break a long impasse, agreed today to support higher gasoline taxes and motor vehicle fees to pay for the rebuilding of Connecticut's roads and bridges.

description: Merck & Company said its near- term earnings prospects were being hurt by price cuts imposed in Japan.

title: FOR L.I.R.R., CELEBRATION OF SURVIVAL
description: There was a time in the region's history when grown men thought the fastest way to get from New York to Boston was to pass through Long Island.

description: Unions representing postal workers and coal miners opened contract negotiations here today, vowing to resist concessions on wages and benefits.

description: b-Includes a gain of $2,172,000 from the retirement of debentures. c-Includes a loss of $6,468,200 due to fees and expenses associated with the merger of Dillon Companies.

title: JACKSON HOLDS MONDALE MAY BE STRETCHING LAW
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson contended today that contributions to independent delegate committees for Walter F. Mondale, a rival candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination, might skirt Federal election laws.

description: They had to change the original name and they decided to abandon the original schedule, but a planned renewal of women's professional basketball came a step closer to reality yesterday. The owners of the nine- team Women's American Basket 1/8all Association (formerly and briefly the Women's National Basketball Association) held their first player draft in Columbus, Ohio.

description: b-Net losses.

Glen Cove Lifts Ban on Russians
description: The City Council voted 5 to 2 tonight to lift Glen Cove's two-year ban on the use of municipal recreational areas by Soviet diplomatic personnel and their families.

title: ADAMS: HIS LEGACY ENDURES
description: THE brilliant clarity of Ansel Adams's photographs - and especially the Western landscapes in black and white for which he is best known and most loved - is no accident. It is partly the result of a deep love of nature and a good eye, plus the natural dryness and clarity of the Western air.

title: UGI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Martin Marietta
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation, an aerospace and defense-system company based in Bethesda, Md., said its Data Systems division had received a 10-year contract from the Navy valued at $225.6 million for an automated personnel/payroll data system. The contract, which is annually renewable at a fixed price, calls for the installation of hardware, software and data communications equipment; management of equipment maintenance, and training.

title: TOP FEDERAL TRAVELER GIVES AN ENDORSEMENT

title: STUDY CHALLENGES SPACE LASER PLAN
description: A study released today by the Congressional Office of Technology Assessment concludes that the prospect for success of a space-based antimissile system is ''so remote that it should not serve as the basis of public expectation or national policy.''

title: Mid-April Auto Sales Surged 22.6%
description: Sales of new American-made automobiles rose 22.6 percent in the mid-April selling period from a year earlier, the manufacturers reported today. On a daily selling rate basis, the figures were the best for the period since mid-April 1979.

GARDENS YIELD BOUNTY OF FRIENDSHIP
description: Suzanne Block calls it her Garden of Eden, a quiet retreat from the busy rounds of a Cabinet wife, a city plot where tiny tufts of lettuce and peas and spinach are peeping through the still soggy ground.

title: REINER HAS LAST LAUGH WITH HIS ROCK SPOOF
description: HOLLYWOODSatire, according to show business wisdom, is what closes Saturday night. Audiences go for the pratfall, not the quick knife thrust to the ribs. So nobody ever expected to get rich from ''This Is Spinal Tap,'' a satire on rock music groups and on documentaries about rock music groups.

title: GENERAL DATACOMM INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
Earlier Inauguration Of President Proposed
description: Two Senators proposed today that the victors in November Presidential elections take office later in the month.

description: The Honda Motor Company said today that a 20 percent rise in overseas sales helped offset a 2 percent decline in domestic sales, increasing its profits by 72 percent for the fiscal fourth quarter, ended Feb. 29.

title: Soon-Hee Lee Presents An Evening of Songs
description: The soprano Soon-Hee Lee, who presented a concert at the Abraham Goodman House Saturday night under the auspices of the Korea Music Foundation, neatly bisected her program, devoting the first half to music by Mozart, Hugo Wolf and Franz Schubert, and the remainder to the French repertory, including works by Debussy, Joseph Jongen and Ernest Chausson.

title: Honeywell System
description: Honeywell Inc. said its Commercial division had developed the first high- technology central energy management and temperature control system for small- to medium-size buildings. The new system, called Deltanet, will cost about $30,000 more than the typical conventional pneumatic temperature control system. Honeywell did not say when production would begin.

title: Some Export Curbs Eased
description: The Government said today that it was easing controls on the export of certain sophisticated laboratory equipment.

title: CONVENTION SITE: NEW NAME?
description: At the moment, the city's exposition and convention center has a fairly straightforward name: the New York Exposition and Convention Center.

description: ALTHOUGH it has only been selling its products in the United States for seven years, the Citizen Watch Company of Japan, the world's largest maker of watches, is determined to move into a lead role in this country. That means pushing out K. Hattori & Company, Japanese maker of the Seiko, Pulsar, Lorus, Alba and Jazz brands.

title: NEW PROFITABILITY AT LEANER AMFAC
description: Once a sprawling and weakly profitable conglomerate, operating in sugar, food, land and retailing, Amfac Inc. today is slimming down. And with its overhaul firmly begun, first-quarter earnings of $6.2 million ''represent a renewal of profitability'' after a $68 million loss in 1983, Amfac's chief executive, Myron Du Bain, says.

description: President Julius K. Nyerere has appointed Foreign Minister Salim Ahmed Salim as this East African country's Prime Minister, the Tanzania radio announced today.

title: 2 Coaches Out
description: The Philadelphia Flyers and the Indiana Pacers will have new coaches next season. The Flyers, who were eliminated in three straight games by the Washington Capitals in a first-round National Hockey League playoff series, said Bob McCammon would leave as coach and general manager.

title: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 25, 1984 International
description: A major Soviet-led offensive overran a valley north of Kabul that had been an Afghan guerrilla stronghold for years, according to an official broadcast from Afghanistan. It was the sixth attempt, since Soviet forces entered Afghanistan in late 1979, to clear insurgents from the Panjshir Valley. (Page A1, Column 4.) Price rioting took the lives of at least 26 people in the Dominican Republic as mobs battled the police in a second day of protests over price increases on all imported goods and many basic foodstuffs. The Government closed all schools and shut down a radio station. (A1:5.)

title: WELLS FARGO MANAGEMENT & EQUITY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

He called demonstrators against the arms race and against new American missiles ''useful idiots of the Soviet Union.''

description: Margaret Bingham Stillwell, a writer and professor emeritus of bibliography at Brown University, died Sunday at a nursing home in East Greenwich, R.I. She was 97 years old.

description: Cable News Network's coverage of the New Bedford, Mass., rape trial was criticized and complimented yesterday before a Senate subcommittee - as the network prepared to offer live coverage of yet another potentially lurid case, the charges of child molestation at a California nursery school.

description: Runoff elections will be required for 16 of Teheran's 30 seats in the 270-member Parliament, the national press agency said today in a report received in London.

description: The Supreme Court heard arguments today on the validity of the Reagan Administration's restrictions on travel to Cuba.

DEVON COAST'S EERIE SECRET: 749 YANKS DIED HERE
description: For weeks the rumors would not go away. Was it possible, neighbor asked neighbor in the Devon countryside as winter turned into spring, that several hundred bodies of American soldiers lay buried in an unmarked grave beneath the rich green turf in a pasture of a farm owned by Nolan Tope?

title: EMBASSY EVACUATION TALKS GO ON
description: Britain deported a 34-year-old Libyan radical today who was described as the chief personal representative in this country of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader.

description: Industry officials said Monday that an ice jam on the St. Clair River was costing Great Lakes shippers up to $1.7 million a day and causing some vessels to wait more than a week to get through.

title: The Rain's Message to New Jersey
description: Due to indifference and the failure of political leadership, the two million residents of New Jersey's Passaic River Basin, 20 to 30 miles northwest of Manhattan, live with the constant threat of catastrophe. Despite repeated warnings, the basin's 120 municipalities have for years resisted serious flood control and builders have kept building on the attractively flat flood plain. As the recent rains made so painfully clear, the risk of a truly disastrous flood grows more serious each year.

description: Joan Benoit, the fastest female marathoner in history, will undergo arthroscopic surgery on her right knee today and may miss her chance to run the marathon in this summer's Olympic Games in Los Angeles.

RATING THE NEW WINE LISTS
description: RESTAURANTS seem to be opening in New York faster than clams at a Fourth of July picnic. This is fine for peripatetic diners. But what about wine fanciers; how do they fare in these new places? Is as much thought given to the wine lists as to the food? Are wine prices reasonable in the trendy new places, or outlandish, as in so many of the once-trendy old places? Are some new restaurants worth visiting for the wine alone?

description: New York City hopes to spend more than $28 billion over the next 10 years to rebuild and repair its roads, bridges, water pipes, parks, schools and other facilities, Mayor Koch announced yesterday. An additional $12 billion is scheduled to be spent on subways and buses.

title: A TASTE FOR SWEET AND SOUR
description: At a time when our foreign policy debate is heating up, it is refreshing to turn to an issue that commands bipartisan support. President Reagan arives in China this week with the broad backing of the American people to strengthen Sino-American relations. But in the future we will need a steadier perspective at home and a richer agenda with the Chinese.

title: Police on Coast Warn Of Prostitute Scam
description: Women posing as prostitutes are luring hotel guests to their rooms, where they use knockout drops to put their victims to sleep while they rob them, the police said today.

title: 'CINDERELLA' ARRIVES AFTER SOLD-OUT TOUR
description: The conductor Kenneth Schermerhorn strode across the stage nervously exercising his hands. ''Where's the pumpkin?'' a prop woman called out sharply. Mikhail Baryshnikov surveyed the scene, walking back and forth and watching the bewigged dancers quietly as they flexed their feet and limbered up at any nearby surface that could be grasped.
