title: Dogs Kill Boy, 6, in Texas
description: A 6-year-old boy who apparently climbed over a fence to retrieve a ball was mauled to death by a neighbor's dogs, the police said. The body of the boy, Jacob Hoffer, was found about 8 P.M. Monday in the fenced backyard of the neighbor's home.

title: Armenians in Athens Burn Turkish Flag
description: More than 1,000 demonstrators marking the 69th anniversary of the start of the massacre of Armenians in Turkey marched to the Turkish Embassy today and burned a Turkish flag there.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;
description: A $226.8 million bond issue for the Municipal Assistance Corporation was priced yesterday with yields ranging from 8.50 percent to 10 percent. The financing is to refund about $277 million of outstanding bonds and will be sold through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: JUSTIN M. GOLENBOCK
description: Justin M. Golenbock, senior partner and co-founder of the Manhattan law firm of Golenbock & Barell, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 64 years old.

title: DON'T ALLOW 'NEW FEDERALISM' TO DILUTE THE CLEAN WATER ACT
description: To the Editor:

description: The Libyan official who acts as Foreign Minister, Ali Abdel Salam Turayki, said today that Libya was prepared to accept Britain's decision to break diplomatic relations between the two countries and to ''implement the decision peacefully.''

NIEKRO RAISES RECORD TO 4-0
description: Phil Niekro continues to prove he is no April Fool. There is, however, a joke in Niekro's season-starting performance and it is clearly on the Atlanta Braves.

title: THE GANG OF FOUR'S FAREWELL VISIT
description: GANG OF FOUR, whose farewell tour arrives at the Ritz tonight and tomorrow night, was always special. Like most of the new British bands that emerged with the first flash of punk rock in 1976-77, Gang of Four arrived with a calculated snarl; one of its earliest songs was titled ''Love Like Anthrax.'' But while most of the original British punk bands sang of apocalypse to music that was little more than revved-up Chuck Berry, Gang of Four's message and musical style were all of a piece.

title: High Court Bars A State Tax Credit
description: The Supreme Court today invalidated a franchise tax credit that New York State had granted for the last 12 years to New York-based export companies.

60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: MANY novice cooks have the impression that great cooking depends on the multiple use of spices. This may be true to a degree in Oriental cooking, but it is rarely so in Western cuisines.

title: AN NBC DOCUMENTARY ON BEING SINGLE TODAY
description: ''SECOND Thoughts on Being Single'' is a sign of how far the culture has strayed. The NBC News documentary - quite a good one, too - finds there is a difference between men and women. In most times and places, this has been taken for granted, of course; in America today it apparently is not. The documentary will be seen on NBC-TV at 10 P.M.

title: ; Hood, Hope Promotes Three to Top Positions
description: Fourteen-year-old Hood, Hope & Associates, Tulsa's gift to the advertising world, has made some major executive changes.

title: CRAB HOUSE HERALDS BALTIMORE'S SPRING
description: BALTIMORE THERE are three sure signs of spring in this city: The return of the Orioles and baseball, the cheery burst of daffodils at Harborplace and the reopening of Olde Obrycki's Crab House. The last is a gastronomic event eagerly awaited by the legions of fans who have been deprived of the famous Obrycki's spiced crabs during the restaurant's annual winter closing.

title: PROVIDENCE'S 24 HOURS OF TURMOIL: MAYOR'S CONVICTION ENSNARLS CITY
description: When Mayor Vincent A. Cianci Jr. drove up to City Hall today, he was met by cheers from the street, a force of silent state troopers under orders to prevent him from removing any records and one city fireman who wanted his autograph.

title: EXXON NET RISES 39.6% IN QUARTER
description: The Exxon Corporation, benefiting from improved conditions in the oil industry, yesterday announced a 39.6 percent increase in earnings in the first quarter of 1984 on a rise in revenues of 5.1 percent.

title: COHEN HOLDS CASTING CALL FOR ANGELS
description: ''BE an Angel,'' reads the full- page advertisement that Alexander H. Cohen has placed in the current issue of Playbill magazine. The producer is seeking investors for Joanna Glass's ''Play Memory,'' which opens tomorrow, and for Dario Fo's ''Accidental Death of an Anarchist,'' which Mr. Cohen plans to stage on Broadway next fall.

title: THE TRIP TO PEKING: BENEFITS ALL AROUND
description: For President Reagan, the journey to Peking this week offers an opportunity to serve the nation's interests by strengthening American ties with China as well as a chance to enhance his own bid for re- election by casting himself as a negotiator for peace. As the Reagan entourage crosses the Pacific Ocean, Administration officials are conveying an air of restrained but expectant optimism. There is ebullient talk about ''a new era'' of Chinese-American relations, reminiscent not so much of the uncharted opening that President Nixon created in China 12 years ago as it is of Mr. Nixon's effort later in 1972 to draw the Soviet Union into a less menacing relationship with the lure of mutually profitable economic partnership and political parity.

Zola Budd Qualifies
description: Zola Budd , the South African-born runner, won a 1,500-meter race yesterday that was fast enough to qualify her for the British track and field Olympic trials next month. Running barefoot at the Crystal Palace stadium, the 17-year-old won an invitation race by 60 meters from England's Bridget Smyth in 4 minutes 10.82 seconds, comfortably within the 4:24 requirement. The race was Miss Budd's second since she was granted British citizenship April 6, a Government decision that angered Labor opposition politicians, who charged that she had received favored treatment compared with others applying for British nationality.

description: An article in some copies of The Living Section yesterday about the Cinderella Ball of the American Ballet Theater incompletely identified the honorary chairmen of the event. They are the Count and Countess Frederic Chandon de Briailles.

title: AT SHOW HOUSE, ROOMS WITH A PERSONAL TOUCH
description: VISITORS to this year's Kips Bay Boys' Club Show House will be surprised at the relatively small scale of the neo-Federal house in which 16 design firms were invited to display their talents. Although the brick- facade house recalls a comfortable and prosperous time, it is not a grand or imposing mansion.

title: TRANS WORLD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss after a loss of $89,495,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Vietnam's Resistance Reports Killing Russian
description: The anti-Communist underground in Vietnam has killed a Soviet officer in the Cam Ranh Bay area, a clandestine resistance radio broadcast asserted today.

title: HON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
2 Texas Sisters Held in Plot To Kill Husbands, Police Say
description: Two sisters were arrested after they gave undercover agents a $1,100 ''good- faith deposit'' on a $15,000 contract to kill their husbands, the authorities said today.

title: AERONCA INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $575,000. c-After a loss of $81,000 from discontinued operations and a tax credit of $249,000.

title: Court Clerk Seized In Car Ticket Case
description: A clerk in Criminal Court in Manhattan was indicted by a grand jury yesterday on charges of taking money from motorists for payment of tickets, issuing false receipts and keeping the money.

title: LAB DUPLICATES BLOOD ELEMENT VITAL IN CLOTTING
description: Scientists reported yesterday that they had produced the largest and most complex protein ever created artificially in the laboratory, a substance vital to the normal clotting of blood.

title: LIFELINE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Bechtel Plans Own Inquiry WASHINGTON, April 25 (UPI) - Bechtel Group Inc., facing Federal inquiries into allegations that it funneled bribes to South Korean officials, plans its own investigation.
description: Separate investigations by the Justice Department and the Internal Revenue Service have focused on allegations by Daniel Charboneau, a former Bechtel employee, about the activities of Joon Sik Cho, a Korean- American consultant hired by the giant construction company's Bechtel Power unit to help win contracts to build nuclear power plants in Korea.

title: SUNBELT EXPLORATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Net loss.

title: COURT GETS LATIN RANCH SUIT
description: The Federal Court of Appeals here heard testimony today on whether the constitutional rights of a United States citizen were violated when his ranch land in Honduras was seized to establish an American-built military base for training soldiers from El Salvador and other Central American countries.

title: WHEN NOVA SCOTIA MINES DIE, HOPES PERISH TOO
description: In this battered, dreary town of 22,000, coal has long been a source of deep pride. It has brought disappointments just as deep.

title: HUMOR: DOUG SKINNER
description: DOUG SKINNER, the bespectacled straight man and pianist for Bill Irwin's clowning in ''The Regard of Flight,'' is performing his own solo show, ''Pay Attention,'' lunch hours at the American Place Theater. Eddie Gray would argue about the word ''solo.'' Looking like a young Jack Gilford, he is Mr. Skinner's blissfully disruptive dummy and he does not let the ventriloquist get away with anything, especially boredom.

Georgia Labor Official Convicted in Fraud Case
description: The Labor Commissioner of Georgia was convicted today of conspiracy to defraud the state by having employees work on his private boats on state time. A judge in Atlanta sentenced the Commissioner, Sam Caldwell, to one year in prison, four years' probation and a $10,000 fine.

title: OUR TOWNS
description: As it turns out, some of the ''Haves'' still cling to the life of a ''Have Not.'' In fact, a few might even yearn for it.

title: 'FOUR SEASONS' SERIES RETURNS TO CBS SUNDAY
description: This week, television editors and critics all across the country were sent a large chocolate-covered kiss to remind them, in the words of the press release, that ''Alan Alda's 'The Four Seasons' will return to the air on Sunday evening, April 29, with an episode called 'The Kiss,' about the sexual fantasies among friends. Share this kiss with someone you fantasize about.''

title: Sliwa Released From Jail
description: Curtis Sliwa, leader of the Guardian Angels, was released from jail against his wishes today after a businessman paid his $105 fine for trespassing on city property. On Tuesday, the businessman, Ervin Steiner Jr., tried to pay Mr. Sliwa's fine but he refused to leave his cell.

title: DU PONT, MONSANTO PROFITS SOAR
description: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, helped by the general improvement in the economy and strong performances by several of its businesses, reported yesterday that net income in the first quarter of 1984 soared 83.7 percent on an 8.5 percent gain in revenues.

title: CHICAGO AND NEW YORK, ARCHITECTURAL RIVALS
description: CHICAGO THIS may be the second city by most standards of measure, but not in architecture. Chicago's status in the world of building has always been as much that of a leader as a follower - it is the city of Louis Sullivan, Frank Lloyd Wright and Mies van der Rohe, a place that has a record of consistent devotion to architectural quality that is unmatched by any other American city.

title: UTL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MONSANTO CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
REAGAN ARRIVES FOR VISIT TO CHINA AND TALKS WITH SENIOR LEADERS
description: President Reagan arrived here today for a six-day visit to China and quickly plunged into meetings with senior Chinese leaders.

title: SURGICAL CARE AFFILIATES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Comparable year-ago results are unavailable because the company began operations in June 1983.

title: BALLET: NEW 'CINDERELLA'
description: LED graciously by Cynthia Gregory and gallantly by Patrick Bissell, American Ballet Theater's elaborate three-act ''Cinderella'' had its New York premiere Tuesday night in the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: TRW, Trico End Merger Meetings TRW Inc. and Trico Industries said they had terminated negotiations under their letter of intent calling for the acquisition of Trico by TRW. The companies said they expected to continue exploring various options, including the possible purchase by Trico of the 1,339,530 shares of its common stock held by TRW. That represents about 16.4 percent of Trico's shares outstanding.
description: The letter of intent, announced in January, called for TRW to exchange 0.137 share of its stock for each Trico share. Trico, based in Gardena, Calif., is a supplier of oilfield equipment and services. TRW, based in Cleveland, is involved in high-technology products and services.

title: CHEMICAL FABRICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
BASE INCOME NEED UP AGAIN IN POLL
description: The minimum income that a family of four needs to make ends meet is $300 a week, according to respondents to the latest annual audit of Americans' perception of living costs made by the Gallup Poll.

title: IDEAL BASIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results for the latest first quarter include a gain of $500,000 on the sale of a cement terminal. Year-ago results include a gain of $4.4 million on the sale of a cement plant and real estate. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect the adoption of actual cost accounting method on Jan. 1, 1984.

title: THIRD WORLD TRADE VS. DEBT
description: The United States and other industrial countries are creating a basic economic conflict: They are erecting trade barriers against steel, textiles and other prime sources of income for third-world debtor countries while trying to assure that those countries keep up with their payments to the banks. To free American banks from taking substantial short- term losses on their $8.6 billion in Argentine loans, for example, the American Treasury orchestrated a $500 million emergency loan package on March 31.

title: PROFITS JUMP AT SHELL AND GULF
description: The Shell Oil Company, which is the object of a $58-a-share bid by the parent Royal Dutch/Shell Group, said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings soared 32.5 percent, to $326 million, or $1.05 a share, from $246 million, or 80 cents a share, a year earlier.

WIDE LEAD HELD BY HART IN UTAH AS DEMOCRATS BRAVE SNOW TO VOTE
description: Senator Gary Hart held a wide lead in Utah's Democratic caucuses tonight as voters braved near-blizzard conditions to attend meetings where 22 national convention delegates were at stake.

title: Rare Bald Eagle Is Hatched
description: The Cleveland Museum of Natural History was playing father today to a newly hatched bald eaglet, only the second such bird ever hatched from an artificially inseminated egg. The museum said it had been trying for nearly 10 years to produce such a hatchling. The bald eagle is on the endangered species list in much of North America.

title: No Headline
description: An Apology on Auto Prices We misused an important statistic last week when we wrote that Detroit raised prices by nearly 40 percent in the three years during which imports of Japanese automobiles have been restricted by quotas. Consumers are now paying nearly 40 percent more than they did three years ago for the cars Detroit produces, but less than half that increase is due to directly higher prices.

title: Hoffman Illness Halts 3 Shows of 'Salesman'
description: Performances of the sold-out revival of ''Death of a Salesman'' at the Broadhurst Theater were canceled Tuesday night, yesterday afternoon and last night because Dustin Hoffman, the star of the play, has been ill.

title: WILLIAM BYRD PRESS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HOME BEAT
description: WHEN the West Bend Company asked a number of market- research concerns to find out what consumers felt was wrong with their irons, the No. 1 complaint was about cords. That persuaded the West Bend, Wis., company to develop what it terms ''the first cordless iron.''

title: ON A PEDESTAL AGAIN
description: On the court, the sneakers are squeaking more. The uniforms are soaked with sweat more. The players are battered and bloodied more. This is the National Basketball Association playoffs, the rebuttal to the theory that nothing happens in an N.B.A. game until the last few minutes.

title: REV. A.B. BUCHANAN, LED MANHATTAN CHURCH
description: The Rev. Albert Brown Buchanan, former rector of Calvary Episcopal Church, died of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis Monday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 67 years old and lived in Boston.

title: Profits Up 49% At Matsushita TOKYO, April 25 (AP) - The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company said today that stronger sales and cost reductions helped it to increase profits for the first quarter by 49 percent, to the equivalent of $222.9 million, from the period a year ago. Revenues rose 25 percent, to $4.66 billion.
description: Profits per American depository share went up by 48 percent, to $1.41.

title: Muzzio Takes Penn Decathlon
description: Rob Muzzio finished first in the discus throw and placed among the top five finishers in four other events today to win the Penn Relays decathlon with 7,734 points.

description: Renewed efforts to unite the three principal insurgent groups fighting the Nicaraguan Government have reached an impasse, diplomats and insurgent leaders said today.

description: Earlier this month, the United States Ambassador to France, Evan G. Galbraith, sent a cable home complaining that his embassy had been overrun by official American visitors - secretaries, deputy secretaries and under secretaries . . .

title: Wrong-Way Drive Leads to Prison
description: A Queens man who drove the wrong way into the Brooklyn Battery Tunnel, killing another driver, was sentenced yesterday to 5 to 15 years in prison.

title: C.D. Rates Rise for 13th Week Annual effective yields on six- month certificates of deposit climbed for the 13th consecutive week, The Bank Rate Monitor reported yesterday. The national yield for 50 major institutions reached 10.08 percent in the week ended yesterday, up from 10.05 percent in the previous week, to its highest level since deregulation took effect in October 1983.
description: New York maintained its first- place position, with the average yield on six-month certificates rising to 10.44 percent, from 10.41 percent. Chicago institutions ranked second, at 10.17 percent, followed by Los Angeles, at 10.07 percent; Philadelphia, at 9.99 percent, and Detroit, at 9.74 percent.

description: The National Arts Club honored Jason Robards last night for his ''continued contribution to the American theater,'' and for what Alistair Cooke called ''his unique status as the greatest O'Neill actor of our time and certainly of any time before.''

title: 'A DECENT RESPECT...'
description: Opinion weighs in the world, even though as Stalin said of the Pope it may command no divisions. This is why Iran sent dozens of men to die in European hospitals to prove its charge that Iraq used gas warfare. That is why Iraq paraded half a dozen terrified little boy prisoners before the foreign press.

description: Rashid Karami, the Sunni Moslem leader who is expected to become Lebanon's next Prime Minister, met today with President Amin Gemayel and said afterward that he saw an opportunity to ''steer Lebanon to the shores of peace.''

description: FOR six years the murder of Marian Slamovich in San Francisco went unsolved. An unknown intruder, apparently surprised to find the 47-year-old victim at home, shot her and fled. She died a month later, and the police were baffled.

title: DEMOCRATIC CANDIDATES FACEA CRUCIAL TWO-WEEK PERIOD
description: Campaign developments this week illustrated the emerging consensus among Democratic Party officials and strategists that as a practical matter, the race for the party's Presidential nomination could well be over in two more weeks.

title: A.T.&T. Display Of PBX Expected
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company will announce a digital private branch exchange, or PBX, system for small- to medium-sized businesses, a company executive said. Industry analysts expect A.T.& T. to introduce a smaller version of its digital switching system that can handle several thousand telephone lines in a large company. The Gazelle, the company's code name for the new PBX system, is expected to extend the earlier system's capabilities to companies with fewer than 1,000 lines. A.T.& T. would not officially confirm the reports, saying only that it will introduce a ''major new business communications system'' today.

title: WASHINGTON GAS LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Rep. Paul of Texas Says Foes Used His Mail List
description: Representative Ron Paul, Republican of Texas, said today that a political action committee used his private mailing list of more than 100,000 names to send a letter opposing his Senate candidacy and backing his opponent, Representative Phil Gramm, for the Republican nomination.

title: SHELL OIL COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said results for the latest quarter were impaired some $12,000,000 by retroactive adjustments to natural gas prices resulting from regulatory orders and court rulings.

title: Houston Offers $70 Million Bonds A $70 million issue of Houston general obligation bonds was offered yesterday, with yields ranging from 6 percent for bonds due in 1985 to 8.8 in 1994 and 9.9 percent in 1990, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. About $27.2 million of the issue was unsold as of late yesterday, underwriters said.
description: The bonds were rated AAA by Standard & Poor's, but Moody's Investors Service recently reduced its rating to Aa-1. Analysts at Moody's said Houston's financial condition is still very strong, but added that the city is faced with large capital spending projects. The two-year term for elected officials makes financial planning more difficult, the rating agency added.

title: CLEANUP BEGINS IN AREA DAMAGED BY STRONG CALIFORNIA QUAKE
description: Residents and officials today began the job of cleaning up an estimated $10 million in damage left by an earthquake Tuesday that injured 25 people, cracked a bridge, damaged power stations and shook houses off their foundations.

description: Phyllis Rose is a professor of English at Wesleyan University and the author of ''Parallel Lives: Five Victorian Marriages,'' recently published by Knopf.

title: ISLANDERS GROPE FOR ANSWERS
description: The Islanders, those smart, well-drilled champions, failed on Tuesday night to perform so many technical things, such as winning face-offs and getting into the attacking zone, that today they trailed the Montreal Candiens by 1-0 in their Stanley Cup semifinal series.

title: ITT, Times-Mirror In Microwave Link SECAUCUS, N.J., April 25 (AP) - The ITT Corporation's long-distance telephone unit announced an agreement today that will more than double its transmission capability by the end of the year.
description: ITT Communications Services Inc. will link its microwave transmission network with a similar network owned and operated by the Times- Mirror Microwave Communications Company of Austin, Tex., an ITT spokesman, Michael Hughes, said.

title: Surgery for Joan Benoit
description: Joan Benoit , the world's fastest female marathoner, underwent arthroscopic surgery on her right knee yesterday in Eugene, Ore. Dr. Stan James , the orthopedist who performed the microsurgery, said he had cut out part of a tight band of tissue, perhaps three or four millimeters in diameter, in the area that was tender and sore. He said ''the possibility is not really great'' that she will be ready to run May 12 in the United States Olympic marathon trials for women in Olympia, Wash.

title: Tass Offers Hope MOSCOW, April 25 (AP) - Tass, the official Soviet press agency, reported today that ''several fundamental issues were resolved'' Tuesday at a meeting in Lausanne, Switzerland, between Soviet sports officials and Los Angeles Olympic organizers. The Tass account, the first report in the Soviet press on the results of the meeting, noted among other things the agreement on procedures for Soviet athletes to enter the United States.
description: The report did not provide any concrete assurance of participation at Los Angeles this summer by the Russians, who have been critical of numerous elements in the preparations for the Games and who have until June 2 to decide whether to accept their invitation.

description: THE Upper East Side duplex apartment that the stage and film director Gene Saks and and his wife, Keren, bought 30 minutes after seeing it in 1981 had languished on the market for about a year, justifiably unwanted. It was poorly designed and built, with a confused layout on the first floor and a warren of small rooms on the second. Doors were hollow; fixtures were low and cheap; linoleum figured prominently.

description: Year-ago share earnings adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split paid in March.

title: Indian Parliament Approves Security Law
description: The lower house of Parliament approved a security law today that allows the Government to detain suspected extremists in the north Indian state of Punjab for up to two years without trial.

title: DRAMA MARKS 50 YEARS OF UNIVERSITY IN EXILE
description: A Polish Nobel laureate in exile stood in a church on lower Fifth Avenue yesterday and read an open letter of moral outrage from a jailed dissident in Poland to his jailer. The letter, as another speaker put it, fell like ''a tornado'' on the 50th anniversary of the University in Exile.

title: LOW COUNTY OYSTERMAN EYES DEVELOPERS UNEASILY
description: One of the last stretches of pristine marshland along the East Coast is a labryinth of tidewater creeks meandering in a sweep of swamp and low grass. Here, 17 miles northeast of Savannah, Ga., four generations of Andrew Kidd's family have stalked these muddy rivers at low tide each season, hunting the sweet, fat oysters that are their livelihood.

title: AT HOME ABROAD ;  A Dual Society?
description: Israel's effective absorption of the West Bank and Gaza has gone too far to be reversed by any political arrangement now foreseeable. But the Israeli-Palestinian conflict has not ended. It has become an internal ethnic conflict in an Israel whose large Palestinian minority makes it a dual society.

description: VEGETABLE gardeners are in luck. The cool wet spring has delayed planting and there is time for the tardy to catch up.

title: BE FAIR TO MEESE
description: Although the independent counsel appointed to investigate Edwin Meese 3d, the President's counselor, has just begun his work, many are saying that Mr. Meese is not fit to be confirmed as Attorney General and ought to withdraw his name now - no matter what the independent counsel concludes.

title: CUOMO VETOES INCREASE IN MEDICAID PAYMENTS

title: THURSDAY, APRIL 26, 1984 International
description: President Reagan will be honored by a 21-gun salute as part of a lavish welcome when he arrives in Peking today for a six-day visit to China. Diplomats in Peking said the preparations made by the Chinese for receiving Mr. Reagan, among them the unusual honor of letting him deliver a televised speech in the Great Hall of the People, were the most extensive for any visiting chief of government. (Page A1, Columns 2-3.) title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;  Blazers Lose Center
description: The Portland Trail Blazers announced that their starting center, Mychal Thompson , would miss the rest of the playoffs because of a fractured right elbow. Thompson was injured when he collided with a teammate, Calvin Natt , early in Tuesday night's victory over the Suns at Phoenix. His absence is likely to prove extremely damaging to the Blazers, for whom he was the top rebounder and No. 2 scorer in the first three games of the opening-round series.

title: Delayed Penalty
description: Doug Risebrough , the center for the Calgary Flames, has been suspended for the first six games next season as a result of a penalty in an April 12 playoff game with Edmonton. The Oilers had complained that Risebrough had injured Glenn Anderson with a high stick and the National Hockey League, after an investigation, agreed. Because Calgary's season is over, the penalty was delayed until next season. . . . Wayne Gretzky , the Edmonton center who was dazed by a hard check from Lars Lindgren in a 7-1 victory over the Minnesota North Stars Tuesday night, says he will be in the lineup tonight for Game 2 of the 4-of-7-game Stanley Cup semifinal playoff series.

title: 3 decades later,a 'Fanny' revival set for Broadway.
description: THE producers and backers of ''Fanny'' must have breathed a collective sigh of relief the morning after the musical opened on Broadway on Nov. 4, 1954. ''Everything has turned out fine in 'Fanny,' which opened at the Majestic last evening,'' Brooks Atkinson wrote in The New York Times. The musical went on to play 888 performances, but then disappeared from New York. Come November, almost 30 years to the day after the curtain went up on the show, Broadway will have ''Fanny'' again. The revival will star Richard Kiley and Giorgio Tozzi, and will be staged by Albert Marre, who directed Mr. Kiley in ''Man of La Mancha.''

title: A Minor Setback The Minor League World Series, among the champions of the three Class AAA leagues, has been called off this year because the league presidents could not agree on a site. Commissioner
description: Bowie Kuhn and Eddie Johnson , the president of the National Association, the minor league umbrella group, said that the Pacific Coast and International Leagues both favored Las Vegas, Nev., but that the American Association had vetoed it. However, Bill Cutler , the president of the Pacific Coast League, said that it was actually Kuhn's office, which has repeatedly expressed concern about baseball's being associated with legalized gambling in Las Vegas, that had turned down the idea.

title: 3 More Killed in Punjab
description: Three people were killed and several wounded today in extremist violence in India's northern state of Punjab, the police said. A police spokesman said at least two people died and a number were wounded when men on the roof of a Sikh shrine in the town of Moga fired at paramilitary policemen. The Press Trust of India news agency said gunmen had shot dead a merchant in a village in the Faridkot district.

title: PRODUCTION PACE UP AT 2.6% RATE
description: Business productivity, the gauge of workplace efficiency, advanced at an annual rate of 2.6 percent in this year's first quarter, the Labor Department said today. This was slightly less than the gain achieved in the fourth quarter of 1983.

title: HOW PAPER PAINTS NAMIBIA: AFRICA'S PEYTON PLACE
description: -West Africa - When they buy his newspaper, Hannes Smith says, some people slide its tabloid pages between the folds of a larger publication so as not to be seen in possession of it. Others, he asserts, have shot themselves because of disclosures he has printed about their private lives. Still more, he reckons, live in trembling of what he might publish in the future.

description: Officials acted properly when they demoted a city social worker after he publicized the mishandling of abuse cases in which nine Brooklyn children died, Mayor Koch said yesterday. But the Mayor said the welfare worker might have been too stiffly fined.

title: HAITIANS CHALLENGE A DECISION THAT DENIES RIGHTS TO ALIENS
description: Lawyers for a group of Haitian refugees are challenging a recent Federal appeals court ruling denying constitutional rights to foreigners seeking admission, asylum or parole in this country and upholding the Government's right to detain them indefinitely.

title: THE IN-ONE-TILL-AND-OUT-THE-OTHER TAX VORTEX

description: Total assets of the nation's money market mutual funds fell in the week ended Wednesday by $357 million, to $171.3 billion, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. In the previous week, the assets declined $610.8 million, and two weeks ago they rose $647 million.

title: SPRING BLIZZARD BLANKETING ROCKIES By The Associated Press
description: An extensive spring blizzard buried parts of the Rockies under snow four feet deep yesterday, and snowplow operators said it was like driving into ''a brick wall.'' The storm later spun off tornadoes that destroyed homes and businesses in the Plains.

title: WEST SIDE HOUSING PROGRAM RESUMES
description: The long-awaited resumption of housing development in the West Side urban-renewal area has begun, with one project in construction and others probable starters later in the year.

title: Marriott to Sell Park to Bally
description: The Bally Manufacturing Corporation said it had signed a letter of intent to acquire Marriott's Great America theme park in northern Illinois for $114.5 million. The sale includes a 325- acre park in Gurnee, including buildings, rides and other improvements.

description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $5,700,000 on a debt exchange. c-Net loss after a loss of $58,000,000 from discontinued operations. d-After a loss of $62,500,000 from discontinued operations. title: Irving Application
description: The Irving Bank Corporation, joining the growing list of banks that seek to expand by taking advantage of a loophole in Federal banking laws, said it had filed applications with the Comptroller of the Currency to charter banking subsidiaries in 13 states. It said the banks plan to offer a range of banking services, with the exception of taking demand deposits. The subsidiaries would be in Chicago; Los Angeles; Dallas; Minneapolis; Atlanta; Cincinnati; Boston; Philadelphia; Charlotte, N.C.; Stamford, Conn.; Morristown, N.J.; Burlington, Vt., and Nashua, N.H.

description: Officials of the Dominican Republic have brought pounds of documents to the United States indicating that 2,000 fraudulent medical degrees were granted to North Americans in Dominican schools. It was the first substantiation of the wide Dominican involvement in a scandal in the medical profession that has alarmed the American authorities.

title: CHURCH & DWIGHT CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Color Tile Merger
description: Color Tile Inc. said it had entered into an agreement with the majority shareholders of Color Your World Inc. to acquire the company's 1,415,200 shares for an average price of $25 (Canadian) each. Color Your World operates 128 retail stores in Canada and 22 retail stores under the name ''Peerless'' in the Pittsburgh area. Color Tile is a retailer of building materials.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: NATALIA MAKAROVA'S car had been towed awaywhile she was rehearsing that afternoon, but the dancer, along with the 250 other guests celebrating the Eliot Feld Ballet's 10th anniversary Wednesday night, was having a ball anyway. The celebration took place on the balloon- and-flower-decorated stage of the Joyce Theater, where Miss Makarova and Gary Chryst had been the evening's guest dancers.

title: TARIFF CUTS IN JAPANESE TRADE PLAN
description: The Japanese Government today approved a package of trade measures intended to soothe foreign complaints of limited access to Japanese markets.

description: * American Savings and Loan Association of Florida , Miami, said it had purchased through a subsidiary a 40 percent beneficial interest in National Capital Group Inc., a new corporation formed to invest in or acquire businesses.

title: Educational Rescue Missions
description: Counting Dropouts - and Saving Them New York City's Acting Schools Chancellor, Nathan Quinones, has been worried about an accurate calculation of the dropout rate for high school students. When a recent report suggested the rate might be as high as 43 percent, he urged a closer examination of the numbers and now is satisfied that the best figure is 38 percent. Mr. Quinones is wasting his concern on a distinction without a difference.

description: Nine days ago, Terry Porter began feeling chills as he was running up and down the basketball court at Indiana University. During the next two nights, he awoke with a fever, his body ''soaking with sweat.''

title: HERPES DRUG TERMED PROMISING
description: New medication for genital herpes has been tested and, according to two Federal specialists, offers the first genuine hope for effectiveness both as treatment and protection against recurrence.

title: AT TRIPOLI'S AIRPORT, 'RULE, BRITANNIA'
description: Singing ''Rule, Britannia'' and shouting ''Hip, hip, hooray!'' British family members left here for London tonight in the first phase of a simultaneous repatriation of British and Libyan diplomats from their respective missions. Libyan officials delayed the Britons' departure for nearly five hours at the Tripoli airport.

title: ACID RAIN DANGER SEEN AS GROWING
description: If acid rain continues to fall at current levels, it will effect more lakes and streams, kill more fish and plants and may irreversibly damage the environment, according to a study released this week by the Environmental Defense Fund.

Baldwin Plan Gets Group's Backing
description: The executive committee of the American Council of Life Insurance, an industry group, endorsed a plan under which life insurance companies would contribute money ''on a voluntary basis'' to holders of annuities issued by the Baldwin-United Corporation.

title: TWO ARE KILLED ON EAST 72D ST.; GUNMAN IS SHOT
description: A man sprayed gunfire into a tailor shop at 345 East 72d Street yesterday, killing the owner and a female companion, the police said. The gunman was shot by an off-duty police officer as he ran from the scene, and a neighborhood resident was slightly wounded by a stray bullet.

title: HART EASILY DEFEATS MONDALE IN VOTING FOR UTAH DELEGATES
description: Senator Gary Hart was a substantial winner at Utah's Democratic Presidential caucuses Wednesday night, apparently winning more than half the 22 delegates to the national convention that were at stake, according to incomplete tabulations today.

title: Kirkland Backs Mondale On Delegate Finances
description: Lane Kirkland, head of the A.F.L.-C.I.O, today defended union financing of independent committees backing delegate campaigns as ''perfectly legitimate'' but said he had ordered it stopped at the request of Walter F. Mondale, whom the federation has endorsed for President.

MOBIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

Shell Discovery
description: The Shell Oil Company said it had found a oil deposit in the Beaufort Sea off Northern Alaska that could be as big as 100 million barrels of oil. John Bookout, Shell's president, said at a meeting of shareholders that although further testing was required, the discovery from the man-made Seal Island appeared large enough to be developed economically.

title: Jockey Hurt on Coast
description: Pat Valenzuela broke his collarbone in a Hollywood Park accident that will cost him a possible ride in the Kentucky Derby next Saturday.

title: A 'BARBER OF SEVILLE' SCORED FOR PUPPETS
description: For two years, the mezzo-soprano Emily Hastings was the Metropolitan Opera's understudy for Rosina, the young heroine of Rossini's ''Barber of Seville.'' Although she rehearsed for hours, she never got to perform the role. So, when the Brooklyn Opera Society asked Miss Hastings to sing Rosina, she leaped at the chance. Then she was told that although the voice would be hers, the character would be played by a puppet.

title: When the Family Tries To Cope With Drug Abuse
description: When drug abuse enters the family circle, the user and his or her family are usually incapable of coping with its trauma or solving the problem. But, in an unusually upbeat showing that uses real-life young victims and their parents, NBC News observes some of the new methods being used to prevent, treat and cure drug addiction among young people.

title: NEEDED: FEDERAL ANTI-DRUG AID
description: Because of an extraordinary commitment of police resources and a new and different strategy known as Operation Pressure Point, a bridgehead has been made against the drug traffic on New York's Lower East Side. But it is now clear that we cannot achieve final victory unless we get help. And that means help from President Reagan.

title: COUNT BASIE, 79, BAND LEADER AND MASTER OF SWING, DEAD
description: Count Basie, the jazz pianist whose spare, economic keyboard style and supple rhythmic drive made his orchestra one of the most influential groups of the Big Band era, died of cancer yesterday morning at Doctors' Hospital in Hollywood, Fla. He was 79 years old and lived in Freeport, the Bahamas.

title: The Paysons' home on view
description: JOAN WHITNEY PAYSON, the ebullient, highly visible owner of the New York Mets until her death in 1975, was the extremely private mistress of a 50-room, fieldstone mansion in Manhasset, L.I., that she and her industrialist husband, Charles Shipman Payson, filled with art, antiques, collectibles and souvenirs. What remains of these possessions, including the well- waxed Georgian furniture, a Paul Revere silver porringer, baseball memorabilia and seven porter's uniforms from the Paysons' private Pullman car, reflects their multifaceted life of privilege, philanthropy and investment. And it is what visitors will see tomorrow and Sunday, when the Georgian-style house goes on public view for the first time in preparation for next weekend's on- premises auction of its contents by William Doyle Galleries.

title: ANDREW CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
I M S INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After $1.1 million loss from discontinued operations.

title: Midland Nuclear Plants
description: The Consumers Power Company will probably abandon its uncompleted Midland nuclear plants within a few weeks, unless state utility officials in Michigan agree on a plan for completion, John B. Selby, president of the company, said today.

title: MILLIPORE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
OILERS AND STEINKUHLER AGREE
description: After a final round of negotiations with the agents of three players, the Houston Oilers decided yesterday that Dean Steinkuhler, the guard from the University of Nebraska, was the man they wanted on the first round of Tuesday's National Football League college draft.

title: BRUNSWICK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SPECIALTY BOOKSTORES: A BROWSER'S GUIDE
description: NEW YORK is a city of readers, a place where people demand more than the best sellers. That is why New York, perhaps more than any other major American city, can support small bookstores that concentrate on only one or two subjects. From mysteries to military affairs, these speciality bookshops cater to people who enjoy hunting down a good book almost as much as they enjoy reading it - customers who love to spend long weekend hours browsing for rareities, remainders and those impoossible to find titles.

title: FRIDAY, APRIL 27, 1984 International
description: American-Chinese amity will be stressed today by President Reagan in a speech that aides said was designed to set the tone of his six-day visit to China. Mr. Reagan planned to call for Peking and Washington to set aside their ''fundamental differences'' and join as friends in writing ''a new chapter for peace and progress.'' (Page A1, Column 6.) A last-minute concession by Peking has opened the way for the United States and China to initial an agreement Monday on the peaceful uses of atomic energy, according to commerce officials accompanying President Reagan in Peking. (A4:1-2.)

title: MANATT ACTS ON JACKSON BID
description: The Democratic national chairman, Charles T. Manatt, moving to meet one of the Rev. Jesse Jackson's demands, today asked state party officials to consider allocating additional convention delegates to Mr. Jackson.

title: A.T.& T. INTRODUCES COMPUTER-PHONE LINK

title: A MAN FOR ALL CRISES
description: The Sunni Moslem leader who was chosen today to head a government of national unity in Lebanon is a flexible pro-Syrian politician who has been Prime Minister nine times since 1955. Rashid Abdul Hamid Karami, a 62-year-old lawyer and political leader from the northern port city of Tripoli, is popularly known as a man for all crises. The nation's leaders have been accustomed to turning to him in times of major national strife or political upheaval. Now he is being asked to form a government that could guide Lebanon out of nine years of civil war.

title: DELOREAN SEEKING DISMISSAL OF CASE

Irene Papas as an unusual grandmother.
description: THERE is only a passing reference in Gabriel Garcia Marquez's monumental ''One Hundred Years of Solitude'' to the unfortunate young girl: ''Two years before, far away from there, she had fallen asleep without putting out the candle and had awakened surrounded by flames. The house where she lived with the grandmother who raised her was reduced to ashes. Since then her grandmother carried her from town to town, putting her to bed for 20 cents in order to make up the value of the burned house. According to the girl's calculations, she still had 10 years of 70 men per night, because she also had to pay the expenses of the trip and food for both of them as well as the pay of the Indians who carried the rocking chair.''

title: UPSCALE AMUSEMENT PARKS It used to be that local amusement parks were packed mainly with teen-agers and parents towing young children, all shrieking their way through stomach-wrenching rides, stuffing themselves with junk food and finally, perhaps, buying a garish souvenir or two as a memento.
description: Today, the most popular of those carnival-style amusement parks have evolved into theme parks, in which the public spent an estimated $2 billion last year. As their customers have grown older, the theme parks have matured, too, and like so many consumer- driven industries, have been going upscale.

title: NEW AMERICAN MUSIC FROM THE GONGS OF BALI
description: Gamelans are Indonesian percussion orchestras, with ancient links to the religion, dance and shadow-puppet plays of Java and Bali. Every gamelan has a name, and the Gamelan Son of Lion, which will be playing Sunday night at Washington Square Church, is the leading East Coast example of a gamelan devoted to works composed for it by American composers. Sunday's concert will be the gamelan's fourth annual presentation of such music in New York.

title: Diner's Journal
description: SHAD have been swimming upstream in Northeastern waters for more than a month, and for aficionados of the fish's delicate roe, it is a time for celebration. Shad roe is usually wrapped in bacon, broiled and served with boiled potatoes and lemon. Following is a random sampling of restaurants around town serving shad roe. It is advisable to call ahead to be sure it is being served on a particular night:

title: Floridian Sent to Jail Over a Divorce Form
description: A stenographer credited with bringing about Florida's new simplified divorce rules was sentenced to 30 days in jail today by Florida's Supreme Court, which said she practiced law without a license.

title: Arch to Buy Mine
description: The Pennsylvania Power and Light Company said it had signed a letter of intent to sell the Pennsylvania Mines Corporation, a subsidiary, to the Arch Mineral Corporation. Terms were not disclosed. The company said it would agree to purchase 4 million to 4.5 million short tons of coal annually from Arch, which would also lease undeveloped coal reserves in Greene County, Pa., from Pennsylvania Power.

title: Israel Denies Latin Arms Tie
description: The Foreign Ministry today denied that Israel had provided Soviet-made arms to the Nicaraguan rebels. According to reports in the United States, a rebel commander said his group had weapons that had been captured by Israel from Palestinian guerrillas in 1982.

COMINGS AND GOINGS
description: The status of Grant Fuhr , the Edmonton goalie, is doubtful for Saturday night's Game 3 of the Oilers' Stanley Cup semifinal playoff series against the Minnesota North Stars. Fuhr suffered a badly bruised left elbow in the Oilers' 4-3 victory Thursday night in Edmonton. . . . Jamaal Wilkes , a starter for the Los Angeles Lakers, will miss at least the first two games of their playoff series with Dallas because of a severe gastrointestinal infection. . . . The Dodgers placed Ken Landreaux on the 15-day disabled list after the outfielder injured a finger on his left hand. Landreaux's spot on the roster will be filled by Franklin Stubbs , who had been playing outfield for Albuquerque of the Pacific Coast League. . . . Brownell Combs 2d , a prominent horseman whose family-owned Spendthirft Farms in Lexington, Ky., became a public corporation last year, has made an offer for his company to buy Churchill Downs race track for $38 million.

title: Smith to Raise Gearhart Stake Smith International Inc. said it planned to start a cash tender offer for 3.7 million shares, or 23.1 percent, of Gearhart Industries' common stock at $31 a share. The purchase would raise Smith's stake in Gearhart to 56.3 percent. Smith, an energy-related equipment maker in Newport Beach, Calif., said the offer would not be conditioned on any minimum number of shares being tendered.
description: Marvin Gearhart, chairman of the Fort Worth oil and gas company, said he would vigorously fight any two- tiered takeover offer by Smith. He said, however, that, ''If it were a fair offer to all shareholders, we would present it to all of them and let them decide.'' Gearhart declined 50 cents, to $28.125, yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: STOCK-INDEX OPTIONS: A LONG, HARD WEEK
description: With the spread this week of charges that brokers could have manipulated a Standard & Poor's stock index, traders and exchange officials agree that the 13-month-old market in stock-index options has drifted into uncharted waters. First, hundreds of thousands of dollars were lost by traders in the volatile market of April 19. That episode was followed by allegations of manipulation that threaten to leave a permanent blemish on the youthful market.

description: I needed a bathtub and knew precisely the bathtub I wanted. I had bathed in the original model in 1966. It was situated in a second-rate hotel in Paris. It was about six feet long and maybe three feet deep - deep enough and wide enough, I noted at the time, to drown the quarreling couple on the other side of the onionskin wall whose yammerings were disturbing my reading of Marcel Proust.

title: Rain-Curtailed One-Hitter

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: HOLLYWOOD HEROINES As a screen star in the 1920's, Lillian Gish was a power at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer. She called a lot of shots, said Richard Kozarski, a film historian. Miss Gish decided that Nathaniel Hawthorne's novel ''The Scarlet Letter,'' whose theme of adultery had previously been considered unsuitable for the movies, should be made into a film. She went on a crusade and was largely responsible for its production in 1926. She brought Victor Seastrom - perhaps best known to a later generation of moviegoers as the old man in ''Wild Strawberries'' (1957) - from Sweden to direct, and the 80-minute film became a classic.

Juan Antonio Samaranch , the president of the International Olympic Committee, expressed a similar view last week.

title: STAGE: CHINA EMPRESS
description: Tzu Hsi, the title character in Ruth Wolff's ''Empress of China,'' is a villainess of epic proportions, a former concubine who intrigues her way to the crown with fiendish machinations that would have been recognized by Richard III. Though there is nothing admirable about her quest, it is also evident that the people in her orbit deserve her malice. She is surrounded by the weak-willed and the easily vanquished, including her primary victim, the young Emperor who is the late-19th-century Chinese equivalent of a wimp.

title: 10 Banks Attacked in Chile

Transactions BASEBALL HOUSTON (NL) - Placed Alan Ashby, catcher, on 21-day disabled list effective last Wednesday. Purchased contract of Mark Bailey, catcher, from Columbus of Southern League. MINNESOTA (AL) - Recalled Ed Hodge, pitcher, from Toledo of the International League. SAN FRANCISCO (NL) - Recalled Mark Grant, pitcher, from Phoenix of Pacific Coast League. TEXAS (AL) - Sent Tom Henke, relief pitcher, to Oklahoma City of the American Association. BOXING WORLD ASSOCIATION - Postponed welterweight title fight between Donald Curry of the United States, the champion, and Nino LcRocca of Italy, the challenger, to July 14. The match was originally scheduled for Monte Carlo June 23, but the date was changed to avoid conflict with a major golf tournament in Monaco. COLLEGE N.C.A.A. - Announced that John W. Ryan, president of Indiana University, will head the new Presidents' Commission of the N.C.A.A. He was also chosen to be the Big Ten Conference representative on the commission. N.C.A.A. - Committee on Infractions reprimanded and censured Southern University and withdrew two of its football scholarships for rules violations in recruiting of Anthony Hudson, a high school lineman. DUKE - Tom D'Armi, baseball coach, resigned in order to reduce his responsibilities at the university. He will continue to supervise preparation of athletic facilities for Duke games. MIAMI (Ohio) - Darrell Hedric, basketball coach for the last 14 years, resigned and will become associate athletic director, replacing H. Wayne Gibson, who resigned.

;  Fibak Back in Poland
description: Wojtek Fibak , the Polish tennis star who has kept himself aloof from his nation's official sports efforts, has returned to his homeland for the first time in three years amid reports that he will soon be named to Poland's Davis Club team. Fibak, once a supporter of the now-outlawed Solidarity labor movement, paved the way for a reconciliation last year when he held a news conference in Paris to renounce politics. ''It's a great feeling to be back,'' said Fibak from his parents' home in Poznan.

title: WHY THE N.F.L. MUST START DRAFTING UNDERCLASSMEN
description: ON Tuesday, the National Football League will conduct its annual draft of college players. For many young men, the draft represents an opportunity to earn large salaries and public approbation. Other equally capable players, however, will be denied the chance to compete for jobs, because of the N.F.L.'s draft-eligibility rule. This rule provides that the only players eligible to be drafted are those who have graduated, exhausted their college eligibility, or attended a school for five years.

title: SNICKETS WERE MADE FOR WALKERS
description: The city of York is above all a walker's paradise. Travelers emerging from the railway station are captivated by the city walls, crenellated and clean as if fresh out of Disneyland. In spring the grassy banks are a golden swirl of daffodils, but even without flowers the lure of the walls is irresistible. Friends expected for morning coffee appear several hours late, flushed and apologetic. One glimpse of the Minster, that Gothic miracle of a cathedral at the end of the wall trail, and they are undone. They think it will only take half an hour, but they get lost in the centuries.

title: Dietary Questions Resolved by Rabbis Barbara Kram, in her April 15 article ''What Is Kosher for Passover?'', presented a problem that does not exist. She correctly mentioned that many laws, customs and traditions are explained in the Shulhan Arukh (16th century); what she neglected to mention is that problems that occurred afterward were answered by various rabbis in the Responsa.
description: We indeed do need laws on the various items mentioned, and I believe Mrs. Kram can find answers by discussing these problems with her rabbi. Our religion is one where questions are welcome, and has been based on the give and take of rabbi and student for many centuries.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
TRANSPORTATION TOKENS ADDED TO OLYMPIC ISSUES
description: The three commemorative coins made by the United States Mint aren't the only official numismatic issues of the 1984 Summer Olympic Games in Los Angeles. Perhaps without knowing the hobby implications, commuters in the Los Angeles area are already using another set of numismatic commemoratives: a series of 24 transportation tokens bearing Olympic designs. The tokens, which went into use on Jan. 1, are more than just a means of calling public attention to the Games. They also are raising funds to help finance the huge cost of public transit associated with this summer's extravaganza. The tokens, made of brass, are being sold to commuters for 50 cents apiece---their value as bus fare---by the Southern California Rapid Transit District. However, they also are being marketed in uncirculated sets at a substantial premium, and proceeds from such sales are expected to provide the transit district with upwards of $1.7 million---enough to close the deficit it is likely to incur during the Games. Issuance of the tokens was the brainchild of Robert G. Hennkens, president of the Marketcom Group, a marketing organization in St. Louis. Mr. Hennkens had learned that because of the added transit service required during the Olympics, necessitating the acquisition of hundreds of extra buses and the hiring of hundreds of extra drivers, the Southern California RTD faced the prospect of a multimillion-dollar operating loss. It's anticipated that transportation of Olympic athletes, officials and visitors will require a fleet of 475 vehicles. Mr.Hennkens convinced transit officials that by issuing special tokens and selling them at a premium to collectors, they could close their budget gap in a relatively painless way and also reap promotional advantages.

title: SHOWCASE TO HELP PLAINFIELD HOSPITAL

title: SUPRAPHON'S DISKS CELEBRATE CZECH MUSIC-MAKING
description: For nearly 40 years, the Czechoslovak label Supraphon has been a celebration of that nation's music-making, and of its music. Flagship of the line has been the magnificent Czech Philharmonic, near unsurpassable in Dvorak, Smetana and Janacek, where its mastery of accents peculiar to Czechoslovak musical language is uncanny, and distinctive in the general repertory, where its particular sweetness of tone and elegant sense of precision and balance are always evident. It shares, with the other regional Czechoslovak recording orchestras, indeed with most Czechoslovak performers altogether, a rather phlegmatic approach to virtuosity (although equipped with full capabilities thereof) that makes many performances seem less interesting than they reveal themselves to be upon further hearings.

title: Mondale Wins on Guam; Hart Gains Utah Votes
description: Walter F. Mondale, a longtime supporter of increased home rule for Guam, won the overwhelming majority of Guam's delegation at the territorial convention today.

title: UNDERSTANDING AND MISUNDERSTANDING POLAND
description: John Darnton, the Eastern European correspondent for The New York Times from 1979 to 1982, won a Pulitzer Prize for his reporting from Poland. THE POLISH REVOLUTION: SOLIDARITY

title: HOLBROOK PARK SITE COMES UNDER FIRE
description: THE construction of the last park in the Town of Islip's multimillion-dollar system of regional parks is drawing criticism from some residents in Holbrook who fear it will destroy valuable pine barrens and add traffic to residential streets.

title: Dr. S. C. Updegrove To Wed Miss Hayes
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard R. Hayes of Port Washington, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Kathleen Marie Hayes to Dr. Stephen Craig Updegrove, a son of Dr. and Mrs. John H. Updegrove of Easton, Pa.

title: RECORD 23 DECLARE FOR AMERICA'S CUP
description: The commodore of the Royal Perth Yacht Club in Australia said last night that a record 23 yachting syndicates, including 9 from the United States, had declared as challengers for the 1987 America's Cup races.

title: CHICKEN WITH AT-HAND INGREDIENTS
description: CHICKEN baked or sauteed and lightly seasoned with herbs, some lemon or a splash of wine is exceedingly appealing once the weather begins to warm. No lengthy involvement in the kitchen, elaborate planning or expensive ingredients are required for dishes such as these. Every market sells chickens and every kitchen should have some herbs, lemon and wine on hand.

title: Stacy M. Stacom To Marry in June
description: Stacy Mary Stacom, a daughter of Matthew J. Stacom of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Claire P. Stacom, has become engaged to Frederic Eugene Ossorio Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic E. Ossorio of Greenwich, Conn.

title: HIGH POINT'S NEW VERVE
description: HOWROOMS AT THE SOUTHERN FURNIture Market in High Point, N.C., are looking snappier this spring than they have for quite some time: chairs in overblown shapes and brash color combinations; sleek tables and etag eres painted with glossy finishes; floppy- cushioned sofas resting on stumpy raised legs. These provocative designs could be called the Pop Art of the furniture world.

title: Fast Or Slow?
description: To the Editor:

title: WEEK IN BUSINESS
description: Food and fuel prices dropped in March, easing the Consumer Price Index rise to 0.2 percent, the smallest increase since December. The annual rate of inflation is expected to remain in the 4 1/2- to 5-percent range. The news was welcomed by economists, who had feared that the first quarter's unexpectedly high 8.3 percent rate of growth in the gross national product would signal the higher prices that accompanied too-fast recoveries of the past. A secondary index of consumer prices, to which Social Security increases and some cost-of-living increases are tied, did not move at all during March. Some analysts noted, however, that there could be problems if large labor unions react to record earnings and increase their wage demands. That could drive wages - and ultimately prices as well - back to inflationary levels.

title: CONTROVERSY EVOVLVES OVER PISANI SEAT
description: NEW ROCHELLE THE decision last week by State Senator Joseph R. Pisani not to seek re-election accelerated a chain of political events that had been set in motion months ago and added to the drama of a political year that has been filled with surprises.

title: CRAFTS ; PARSONS WORKS IN TENAFLY
description: TENAFLY THE America House Gallery here is playing host to the Clay/Fiber/Glass/Metal Department of the Parsons School of Design with a show of representative works by faculty members, graduating seniors and recent alumni.

title: Lisa Sue Goldberg and Eric Kramer Are Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Goldberg of New York, East Hampton, L.I., and Palm Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Sue Goldberg, to Eric Peter Kramer, a son of Harriet Kramer of Eastchester, N.Y., and the late William Kramer. A September wedding is planned.

title: ARTS PROMOTER'S CREDO? WELL, NO AND YES
description: WHAT transformed Nat Habib from a bored Brooklyn businessman - a manufacturer of frozen desserts - into an Off Broadway producer and a Westchester promoter of arts and education could well be summed up by a variation on the song title, ''I Can't Say No.'' Indeed, Mr. Habib's credo is simply to say ''no to everything'' - and then to change his mind.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: SINCE the North Tarrytown Police Department became the first in the state to offer a fingerprinting program for children in January 1983, the identification measure has grown in popularity and scope, with at least 25 county police departments now offering parents the opportunity to make a record of their childrens' fingerprints. Parents may do this by getting in touch with their local police departments.

title: Letters; The '80-20' Rule

title: 20 ISRAELIS ARRESTED IN A PLOT TO BOMB ARAB BUSES
description: Israeli security forces rounded up 20 Jewish suspects today after foiling a plot to blow up Arab- owned buses in the Jerusalem area, officials announced.

title: SUNDAY OBSERVER;
description: Stamp Out Sports!

title: CROCKER'S LOAN CRISIS
description: ONE of the first bank loans that Frank V. Cahouet ever made turned out to be a mistake. As a junior loan officer at Security Pacific Bank, just out of business school, he authorized a $5 million loan to an electronics company and within months the company fell behind on payments.

title: IN NAPLES, WHAT ELSE BUT PIZZA?
description: PAUL HOFMANN is a former New York Times correspondent who lives in Rome.

title: MUSIC: SERKIN IN LIEBERSON PREMIERE
description: Performance techniques long ago reached such daunting levels of difficulty and intricacy that few composers nowadays would dare to play their own works in public. The creator and the interpreter are almost always different people, a situation that can have serious drawbacks. However, when the performer happens to be close to the composer temperamentally and philosophically, as was true Friday evening at Avery Fisher Hall, the atmosphere should be nearly ideal for hearing the work as its designer meant it to be heard.

title:
GARDENING;
GARDENING IN CONTAINERS
description: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y. is best known as the home of the National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum, but the community has another attribute that is even more striking to the gardener: Each house and place of business is adorned with window boxes filled with flowers in a rainbow of colors. Even the lamp poles along the streets have baskets of red geraniums and trailing green ivies hanging from them.

title: YONKERS APPROVES CONTROL BY STATE
description: The City Council reversed itself today and agreed to state supervision of city finances so that its schools could remain open.

title: BOXING CATCHES JERSEY FLAT-FOOTED
description: When Davey Pearl, a well-known boxing referee, flew to Alaska last year to referee a fight, he spent his time on the plane drawing up the rules. In Alaska and several other states, there are no boxing regulations. New Jersey has a law covering boxing that was passed in 1931; it is honored more in the breach than in the observance, according to the State Commission of Investigation, which is examining the fight game in Atlantic City. Boxing has grown quickly as an adjunct to casino gambling, and Atlantic City is now the fight capital of the nation. There were 183 bouts in the city last year, according to state officials, but the industry was regulated by a single commissioner and the same small staff that used to oversee a handful of bouts each year.

title: Finder $12,000 Richer
description: A man who found more than $12,000 in cash buried in a muddy bank along the Missouri River last month has collected the money from the police because no one claimed it. The man, Russell J. Jones Jr., 20 years old, of Omaha, picked up the cash Thursday, said Lieut. Joe Boan, in charge of the police property room. Mr. Jones gained legal right to the money after no one else claimed it during the 30-day waiting period required by law after the discovery.

Van Thunen of Saddle River, N.J., and Singer Island, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Laura Ann Van Thunen, to Malcolm Whelen Greenough 3d, the son of Mr. Greenough Jr. of Prides Crossing, Mass., and Smith's Parish, Bermuda, and Sarah E. Greenough of Beverly, Mass.

description: A confessed killer, Ottis Elwood Toole, was convicted of first-degree felony-murder today in the 1982 death of a man in a Jacksonville boarding house fire, and a prosecutor said he would seek the death penalty.

Congdon of Oakland, Calif., was married yesterday to Paul Randelman, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur Randelman of Trenton and Atlantic City, N.J. The Rev. James Kitchens, a Presbyterian minister, and Rabbi Bernard Perelmuter officiated at the ceremony at the Mills College chapel in Oakland.

title: HOUSING EXPO
description: Mindful of the urgent need for housing affordable to its middle income families, Westchester County will sponsor its first Housing Expo next Friday and Saturday.

title: BOOM AND BUST CYCLE: A TOWN'S CURE
description: Ever since it rose from a rough mining camp to a small red-brick Victorian city high in the Rockies, Leadville has felt like a yo-yo on someone else's finger. When the silver ore that built this town collapsed in price in the 1890's, Leadville fell with it. When steel and lead and zinc were crucial to the World War II effort, the town rebounded. When the steel industry shrank early in this decade, the Climax molybdenum mine shut down, 3,000 men lost their jobs and Leadville took its latest nose dive.

title: NAVAL ACADEMY 8 TAKES ADAMS CUP
description: The United States Naval Academy confirmed its No. 1 ranking as the fastest heavyweight varsity rowing team in the East by defeating Harvard and the University of Pennsylvania to win the Adams Cup today on a calm course along the Schuylkill.

title: THE BOOM IN ELECTRONIC KEYBOARDS
description: GUITAR sales are sliding, sales of brass are flat, and organ sales have dropped to a pianissimo. But portable electronic keyboards are booming, and dramatically increased advertising by several of the big music manufacturers - featuring some of the first cable television ads for musical instruments - are promising to shake things up in the $2.2 billion musical instrument business this year.

title: Pity and Anger For Dependent Woman The April 8 Speaking Personally article about the displaced homemaker evoked both pity and anger: Pity for the woman who had learned the hard way, after apparently close to 40 years, that she had been mistreated; anger at the husband who had convinced her that the old myths on which she had built her life were true.
description: That's what the women's movement is all about. No one should fail to realize that almost all women, at one time or another, will have to run their own lives.

Colrick and the late Mr. Colrick, also of Short Hills. Msgr. Harrold A. Murray performed the ceremony at St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church in Short Hills.

title: Mr. Mondale UnPACs Even as Walter Mondale abolished the 127 supposedly independent committees formed to support his convention delegates, the candidate protested that the entire operation had been legal, proper and beyond his control. The action, though belated and taken only after pressure from rival Gary Hart, was welcome. The evasiveness was not.
description: The delegate committees have been conduits for political action committee money, chiefly from organized labor. They may indeed be wholly legal, though the Federal Election Commission has yet to say so. But was the operation proper? Certainly not when measured against Mr. Mondale's righteous rejection of campaign contributions from special- interest PAC's.

title: THE MYTH OF THE MONOLITHIC BLACK VOTE
description: Ever since light-skinned and free blacks held themselves different from those with dark skin and those still in slavery, blacks have disagreed over how to fight slavery, segregation and discrimination. The disagreements have not abated, and they may never. The candidacy of the Rev. Jesse Jackson for President demonstrates the gains that have been made. It also has put the disagreements in sharper focus. Earlier in this century, perhaps the most notable conflict was over whether the best course for black improvement was through emphasizing manual training and de-emphasizing social intercourse with whites, as Booker T. Washington urged, or through book- learning to develop the leadership cadre - the ''talented tenth'' - needed by the race, as W.E.B. DuBois advocated.

title: STAGE: 'SUZANNA ANDLER' BY MARGUERITE DURAS
description: Marguerite Duras, best known here as scenarist of Alain Resnais's film ''Hiroshima, Mon Amour,'' is now represented as a playwright by the New York premiere of ''Suzanna Andler'' at the South Street Theater. It is interesting to observe how the cool prose style of this French writer, who first established herself as a novelist and journalist, translates so ineffectively to the stage.

title: HIS EVERY CLOUD HAS A SILVER LINING
description: WHEN Barry Schilit was in the Army during World War II, pondering a choice of assignments, a psychologist kept discouraging him from his selections. ''He said, 'You'd like weather,' '' Mr. Schilit recalled. ''I said, 'Come on, you need weathermen - that's the idea.' He said, 'It's true. But that's beside the point. You will really like it.' ''

title: EUROPE'S INTELLECTUALS AND AMERICAN POWER
description: An hour's flight separates Paris and Bonn - less than 300 miles - but the change in intellectual and spiritual time zones seems so great some days it can leave a visitor disoriented, mentally jet-lagged. For an American making the trip during the last 12 months, Europe's unsettled mood was a fault line running down the middle of Europe at the French-German border, with the Americans astraddle.

title: LOST IDEALS OF YOUTH
description: To imagine that the mercenary desires of the young adults of the 1980's are motivated by the humanistic goal of creating jobs for others is difficult. It seems that Mr. Johnson's speculation about the ''spiritual dimension'' of the current youth culture's materialism is contradicted by his observation that a favorite pastime of the group is the satirization of the people of third-world countries. DIANE P. MAZEFSKY Pittsburgh

title: WHY SOME WRITERS AREN'T WELCOME HERE
description: Jeri Laber is executive director of the United States Helsinki Watch Committee, which monitors compliance with the Helsinki accords on human rights. It has just published the report, ''Inhibiting Public Debate: U.S. Violations of the Helsinki Accords.''

title: Maris Groshans Is Married to John A. Ottman Jr.
description: Maris Groshans, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Russell Glen Groshans of Potomac, Md., was married yesterday to John Arthur Ottman Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ottman of New York. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Vincent S. Gatto at Our Lady of Mercy Roman Catholic Church in Potomac.

title: Connors and McEnroe Gain Final in Dallas
description: Jimmy Connors and John McEnroe moved into the $500,000 World Championship of Tennis final today with straight-set victories.

title: A CORPORATE LOOK INTO THE NEAR FUTURE
description: We may see the future, or at least some of it, on ''The World of Tomorrow'' tonight. In general, the future, as seen on television, is either horrendous - the post-nuclear devastation of ''The Day After,'' for example - or a bright and shining place. In ''The World of Tomorrow'' it glistens, technology gladdening our lives, relieving us of burdens and giving us home entertainment as well. In part, this is because one of the corporate sponsors is A.T.&T. (the other is Del Monte) and A.T.&T., as ''The World of Tomorrow'' tells us, is very much a part of our future. The one-hour program, with William Shatner as host, will be shown on WNEW/Channel 5 this evening at 8.

title: CRIME
description: An old friend is back in THE GONDOLA SCAM by Jonathan Gash (St. Martin's, $12.95). He is the British antique dealer Lovejoy, who first appeared in 1977 in ''The Judas Pair.'' Lovejoy has not changed very much. He is always broke, always hustling, always randy, always seedy and unsavory, always resourceful. He never has been an admirable character, and he is always ready to forge an antique, to bend the law, to lie outrageously, always managing to justify himself by specious reasoning. And if ever there was a male chauvinist, it is Lovejoy. But he does have one redeeming characteristic. In his way, he is a true artist and even more - a visionary who loves beautiful antiques more than life itself and who knows as much about them as Bernard Berenson did about Renaissance art.

title: Judith Hokanson Becomes the Bride Of Edwin Stuart Grosvenor in Capital

title: PRESERVATION FOCUS OF HISTORICAL GROUP

The observation, which this year begins May 13, is proclaimed yearly by the National Trust, a private, nonprofit Washington-based organization that encourages public participation in the preservation of sites, buildings and objects significant in American history and culture. While primarily an advocacy group, the National Trust also maintains some properties, including Lyndhurst in Tarrytown.

title: ARBITRATION SHOULD BE PART OF 'LEMON LAW'

title: FOR WAGES: NO BIG TAKEOFF IN SIGHT
description: WITH profits rising strongly, prices climbing faster than a year ago and the unemployment rate falling, the stage seems set for wages to take off once again. This year's heavy bargaining calendar includes some powerhouse unions - the auto workers, miners and postal workers - and their leaders are making tough statements about hefty wage increases ahead. Washington fears that a few heavyweight wage pacts could push consumer prices skyward and endanger the recovery. ''The economic outlook,'' said Robert Ortner, chief economist for the Department of Commerce, ''is to a great extent in the hands of labor and management. But despite the springtime rumblings from labor and worried words from the Administration, the dam is not likely to burst on wages this year - or the next. Double-digit wage raises appear to be a fading memory, not a realistic fear for the immediate future. Though wages are expected to rise this year by slightly more than last year's 5 percent, organized labor is also expected to be less aggressive during the recovery under way than in any recent postwar recovery. Nevertheless, many labor analysts say 1984 may produce major innovations for some industries, such as lifetime job security and more flexible compensation packages. Labor's new moderation reflects sweeping changes in the environment in which labor operates - and in labor's attitudes resulting from those changes. The nation's unemployment rate, though down to 7.8 percent from 10.7 percent at the end of 1982, is still high by historical standards.

These pot- pourris of excerpts are produced in quantity year after year. They rarely become classics, but they have become an essential part of the way members of the operatic community announce their arrivals and visits.
