title: CONNECTICUT FIGHTS OVER TOLLS, TAXES
description: Money often exacerbates Connecticut's regional differences. It did so again last week, but this time it may have provided both the problem and the solution. Sectional rivalries might seem unlikely in so compact a state, but geography and economics sometimes pull Connecticut in different directions. Fairfield County, with its affluent suburban towns and its sleek corporate headquarters, tends to lean toward New York, where many of its commuters work. Legislators from the area say their constituents sometimes pay more attention to what happens in Albany than in Hartford. Other parts of the state, with their picturesque villages and their older industrial cities, tend to feel more a part of New England. In Greenwich they follow the Yankees; in Griswold, they follow the Red Sox. More than baseball loyalties, however, were strained by the maneuvering in the General Assembly this spring over how to finance the renovation of the state's roads and bridges. After a difficult debate last year, Fairfield County lawmakers persuaded the Legislature to remove the 35-cent tolls on the Connecticut Turnpike in Fairfield and neighboring communities along the state's southern shore, on the ground that the tollbooths caused accidents and congestion. They are scheduled to be removed on Jan. 1, 1986. To raise money for the $5.5-billion, 10-year bridge and highway repair program, Gov. William A. O'Neill proposed in February to raise gasoline taxes and motor vehicle fees. But legislators from the sections of Connecticut without toll plazas proposed keeping - and even increasing - the tolls to hold down the tax increases.

title: BEIRUT'S MOOD, NOW THAT MORE OUTS ARE IN
description: With the appointment last week of Rashid Karami as Lebanon's new Prime Minister, two rather different moods seemed to descend on Beirut at once. The first was a widespread feeling that after almost two years of nonstop civil violence, Lebanon might be headed for a period of relative calm. The second was an equally strong impression that the country's troubles were anything but finished. The agreement on the pro-Syrian Mr. Karami finally brings the Lebanese Moslem opposition back into the corridors of state power and redresses the imbalance that had existed ever since the administration of President Amin Gemayel took office in September 1982. That imbalance was the source of much agitation during the last two years. The Christians, and more particularly the Phalange Party, dominated decision-making, to the great disgruntlement of the Moslem majority.

title: IN SHORT
description: TO LIVE AND DIE IN L.A. By Gerald Petievich. (Arbor House, $14.95.) Susan Sontag once remarked that, for escape, ''I love to read the way people love to watch television.'' With ''To Live and Die In L.A.,'' reading is just like watching television; its characters and plot are straight out of an amiable, time-killing made-for-TV movie. Ace counterfeiter Rick Masters rules Southern California, but two treasury agents (among many others) are determined to put him behind bars. Richard Chance is a kamikaze cop who owes more than a little of his personality to Hicks in Robert Stone's ''Dog Soldiers.'' He's not above stealing money as well as classified evidence in order to assure that Masters gets his comeuppance. Also on the case is Jim Hart, a diligent, burned-out treasury officer who plugs away despite remorse over his wife's death. What does distinguish the story from a television melodrama is its liberal dose of sexual activity, some of it kinky. ''To Live and Die In L.A.'' is very much a male-dominated narrative. Men reflect on the mean streets they walk down; at one point a doomed crook muses, ''If there was anything he'd learned, it was that one simply could not be too cautious when dealing with the scum-of-the-earth.'' The bottom line here is that in Lotusland the good guys and the bad guys get all mixed up in the scum, and this world view makes Gerald Petievich's final resolution decidedly ambivalent.

Stands of slender birch trees, with tiger lily fringes, push up to the roadsides. But spiky, machine-perfect rice fields surround the farms, and the canvas boots of the farmers working them have an unusual articulation between the big and second toe - to accommodate the traditional Japanese wooden sandals.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE COLLECTED STORIES OF JEAN STAFFORD. (Dutton/Obelisk, $10.95.) Thirty brilliant stories written over a quarter of a century appear in this volume, and our critic, Guy Davenport, who reviewed the hard- cover edition in 1969, said their ''fullness of detail'' gives them ''the weight and texture of novels.'' ''There flows through these stories the theme that man is a double prisoner,'' Mr. Davenport observed. More than half are set in institutions and ''all of them study the inescapable confinement of the self.'' STIEGLITZ: A Memoir/Biography, by Sue Davidson Lowe. (Farrar Straus Giroux, $14.95.) Stieglitz, the pio neering American photographer and champion of obscure artists, as seen through the eyes of a grandniece. Written with verve and affection and illustrated mostly with snapshots, ''many by the master himself,'' this memoir-biography is a ''Family Chronicle, from the arrival in New York, 1849, of Alfred's father to the disposal of Alfred's ashes beside Lake George 97 years later,'' as Hugh Kenner noted in his review.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY'S ARDENT PROSELYTIZER
description: Ansel Adams, who died last Sunday at the age of 82, had an enormous and manifold impact on the art of photography in this century. In the public mind he is best known for his consummately crafted landscape photographs, which combine the innate beauty of the Western wilderness with a romantic vision of great sublimity. But his contributions to the art go beyond his images. He was an energetic proselytizer of the photographic faith, using his skills as a writer, teacher and organizer to further the medium's fortunes.

title: RAMBLING THROUGH YORKSHIRE
description: Yorkshire is an enormous place, and it used to be even bigger. Before the bureaucrats in London redrew the map a decade ago, splitting it into five pieces, the county covered 6,081 square miles, more than 12 percent of England. Sydney Smith, the 19th-century wit and divine, wrote that one Yorkshire parish was ''so far out of the way that it was actually 12 miles from a lemon.'' Even today, North Yorkshire, the largest remaining fragment, is the biggest county in the country.

title: CHILDREN LEARN TO SAY NO TO DRUGS
description: Twenty-two students in Roberta Bellow's sixth-grade class at Tashua Elementary School in Trumbull were recently wearing pins that read: ''Just Say No.''

title: Iran Says It Downed Iraqi Jet; Iraq Reports Artillery Duels
description: Iran said its air force shot down an Iraqi MIG-23 today and that 35 Iraqi soldiers were killed or wounded in artillery shelling in the past 24 hours.

title: DANCE TUNES SHOW POP'S PROGRESS
description: It is entirely appropriate that the

title: Page Knudsen Is Engaged to Marry Jay Cowles, Executive, in September
description: Mr. and Mrs. C. Calvert Knudsen of Seattle have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Page Knudsen, to John Cowles 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Cowles Jr. of Minneapolis. The wedding is to be Sept. 8.

title: A DAYLONG FESTIVAL OF FOLK MUSIC
description: PEOPLE sometimes forget, said Susan Garber, that folk music traditionally involved singing or playing instruments in a group, not listening to someone strum an acoustic guitar.

title: EUROPE TAKES SIDES, AND SWIPES, IN THE U.S. ELECTION
description: For the first few months of the year, the European press had a love affair with Senator Gary Hart of Colorado. Except for some important French newspapers, President Reagan is unpopular with commentators in Europe; in London and Bonn, Rome and Madrid, the picture often drawn of him does not vary a great deal from the cartoon that Krokodil, the Soviet satirical journal, ran not long ago, showing a Presidential cowboy exuberantly astride a nuclear bomb. Mr. Hart's early primary victories, and his strong showing in trial-heat polls against the President, were therefore taken as a sign of hope by many here.

title:
ANTIQUES;
A PRIZED COLLECTION OF GLAASS GOES ON SALE
description: FLEMINGTON THE Iorio Glass Shop here has long been known for its contribution to the history of fine American cut, engraved and blown glass.

title: Mike Schmidt's Salary
description: Mike Schmidt , the Philadelphia Phillies' third baseman, will earn nearly $2 million this season, making him one of the highest-salaried players, if not the highest, in baseball over the next few years. That was the contention of a report today in The Philadelphia Inquirer.

title: Miss Wright Is Affianced
description: The engagement of Cathy Lou Wright to Walter Seff Isaacson has been announced by her parents, Dorothy Dixon Wright of Chevy Chase, Md., and V. Orville Wright of Alexandria, Va. The future bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Isaacson Jr. of New Orleans.

title: CAN POLITICAL PASSION INSPIRE GREAT ART?
description: The most provocative topic in the art world this year is once again the relationship between politics and art. Instead of speculating on suspected artist-dealer-curator-collector-critic-media conspiracies - although there is, of course, still plenty of talk about that - citizens of the fastest and most fashion-plagued art world anywhere are now talking about social responsibility, ideology, nuclear war and changing the world.

title: FROM ENGLISH BELLS TO CHINESE ZITHERS: ALL ON NEW DISKS
description: Recent record releases from various parts of the globe, including our own, make up a mixed bag ranging from sounds of the streets and bell towers of English cities to the exotic sound of a Chinese zither taped in a recording studio right here in New York City.

title:
STAMPS;
COMMEMORATIVE MARKS LOUISIANA'S EXPOSITION
description: The United States is issuing a 20-cent horizontal commemorative on May 11 to mark the 1984 Louisiana World Exposition that will be held in New Orleans from May 12 through Nov. 11.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There is a Chinese saying, to see once is more useful than to hear a hundred times.

title: VILLANOVA REGAINS 2 RELAY TITLES
description: For Villanova, all is well at the Penn Relays. The Wildcats from the Philadelphia suburbs have become winners again, and with a national collegiate record to boot.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN RIO DE JANEIRO
description: It is a tribute to Rio de Janeiro's grandeur that, despite everything, it continues to live up to its own nickname of Marvelous City. Over the past couple of years, the everything has been harder to ignore: a severe economic crisis has brought a sharp rise in crime and a visible deterioration in public services. Even the innate optimism of the Cariocas, as Rio dwellers are known, has at times looked frayed, but, by taking precautions only marginally more rigorous than those that New Yorkers might urge on out-of-towners, the visitor can still marvel without risk.

title: THE CLIMATE IS ROMANTIC
description: Sound is the raw material of music, and as musical styles change, so do our feelings about the ''material'' of which music is made. The notion of tonal beauty is as much subject to the swings of fashion as are other standards of pulchritude. The bleating shawms and croaking krummhorns of the Renaissance might not entice ears attuned to Brahmsian sonorities.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM IBSEN TO KOVACS TO VERDI

title: LOST IDEALS OF YOUTH --
description: As a participant in the socially conscious 1960's and as someone who has recently returned to study at Columbia, I must agree with Paul Johnson that the campus ethos has drastically changed. Ascribing the shift to a seemingly inexorable generational pendulum, Mr. Johnson (a Briton) leaves out some key American variables: the Vietnam War and civil rights as motivating cause; the phenomenon of the 1970's ''me decade'' as a transition from politics to personal growth to wealth- seeking.

title: ABRAMS CHANGES THE STYLE OF REAL-ESTATE REGULATION
description: WITH small steps that were not much noted when they were taken, Robert Abrams has made some major shifts in the way New York State regulates real estate activities during his five-year tenure as Attorney General. The shop he runs is a quite different place from the one operated by his predecessor, Louis J. Lefkowitz, and to some affected by the shifts, some of the changes have been questionable.

title: RCA REISSUES RUBINSTEIN
description: There was a time, not too long ago, when record collectors would spend considerable time - and with good reason - appealing to record companies to reissue this or that recording by a favorite artist. There is still some of that, and there are still many older recordings that have fallen out of the catalogue despite their deserving permanent status. But the flood of reissues in the past couple of years has made many of these pleadings seem like carping.

BUSINESS FORUM;
MONDALE: FIRST, CUT THE DEFICIT
description: MY top domestic priority is to make our free economy the strongest, most productive on earth - and to do it fairly. The overriding goal of economic policy must be to give all Americans the opportunity to work.

title: SAVING UP FOR THE TOYS ONE CAN'T BUY

Sure, I had heard all the shocking details - people fighting over the dolls, knocking each other to the floor, selling them for hundreds of dollars each. I commiserated with friends who could not find any of the dolls after traveling all over the country.

The date was April 8, and in nostalgic conclave at the El Dorado Club in New Rochelle were well over 100 singers and instrumentalists who had worked under the baton of Arturo Toscanini, whose grandson now lives in New Rochelle, as does Mr. Merrill.

To credit a novice director (Hugh Wilson) with whatever success the movie achieves, while all but ignoring the contributions of the screenwriters (other than saying 'a lot of the gags don't work') is outrageous. . .''

title: SOFTER SOUNDS FROM BRITISH ROCK
description: Out of the ashes of the late- 70's punk explosion, English rock has been busily reinventing itself. As yesterday's angry young men become today's polished pop craftsmen - still bitter, but musically more sophisticated - the most talented of them have begun writing songs designed to stand the test of time. Joe Jackson, who gained recognition five years ago as a defiant, Elvis Costello-styled singer-songwriter, has matured into a cosmopolitan pop romantic on his newest album, ''Body and Soul.'' Paul Weller, the guitarist-songwriter-singer who led The Jam, one of the hardest rocking and most literate post-punk bands, recently teamed with the keyboardist Mick Talbot to form The Style Council, an eclectic duo whose music comes closer to cabaret than to hard rock.

title: CONNECTICUT ACTS ON A-PLANT COSTS
description: Legislation to restrict Connecticut utilities from charging their customers for the cost of the Seabrook nuclear power project in New Hampshire received final approval in the General Assembly this week.

title: ART
description: It seems not 18 but 180 years since Op Art was talked of at every table and was the subject of a comprehensive exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art called ''The Responsive Eye.'' Much of the work that was then prized for its look of urgency has long since foundered.

title: OWNERS OF DAMS MUST REGISTER
description: Owners of private dams or dikes have until July 1 to register with the State Department of Environmental Protection. The registration will permit the state to update its dam inventory and thus, keep tabs on potentially hazardous dams.

The Staten Island couple had hoped to buy a single-family house in the metropolitan area, but they recently gave up the quest after three months and settled for a small condominium apartment on the southwestern edge of Staten Island.

title: Dynamite Rig Runs Off Road

Among the charges against the driver, Clifton Young, 38 years old, of Midwest City, Okla., was hauling dynamite without a permit. He was carrying dynamite and other explosives in an 18-wheel tractor-trailer.

title: LETTERS ON TRAVEL
description: To the Editor:

title: SO FAR, EARTHQUAKE ARCHITECTURE HOLDS UP
description: WALTER SULLIVAN When completed in 1952, the four- story Saada Hotel in Agadir, Morocco, with a balcony circling each of its upper stories, looked as solid as the Rock of Gibraltar. Yet within 15 seconds during an earthquake less severe than the one in Northern California last week, the building was flattened. Fortunately, no such collapses occurred when towns along the Calaveras Fault in the San Francisco Bay region were rocked in the quake that registered 6.2 on the Richter scale at its epicenter, 12 miles east of San Jose. Some houses were shaken off their foundations, and the City Hall and Santa Clara County Building in San Jose were evacuated pending inspection for structural damage. The tremor's greatest emotional impact, however, was on people working in San Francisco skyscapers, which swayed for about half a minute. In recent years buildings dozens of stories high have been built in the heart of San Francisco as well as in Los Angeles. Both cities are near the San Andreas Fault, the source of numerous quakes, some of which have been been extremely severe. But none of that class has occurred since the high-rise building boom began. A 7 reading on the Richter scale is a ''major'' earthquake and an 8 is a ''great'' quake, capable of tremendous damage. Sooner or later, both cities are almost certain to experience a great earthquake. No one knows how severe the damage would be, but steps are being taken to minimize it.

title: WHO HAS DONE MORE FOR A STATE THAT HAS LITTLE?
description: Senator Thad Cochran stood in shirt sleeves in the drizzly night air at a catfish fry he was giving at the high school football field in this farming community. He shook hands with each of the 1,200 people there, and interrupted a bluegrass band to say why he was running for a second term. ''Through me, the people of this state have made an investment in seniority and experience,'' Mr. Cochran told the interracial group. ''I invite comparison between my record and ability to get things done for Mississippi and someone who has had his entire experience in the state. My opponent was selected by Washington power brokers who are trying to get up a candidate to unseat an incumbent.''

title: 'Duplicate Keys'
description: WORDSWORTH said it right: ''We murder to dissect.'' He was deploring what books do to life's beauteous forms. ''Duplicate Keys'' proves his case beyond a shadow. Killing off two characters before page 1 (members of a not-so-hot rock band, shot by person unknown while relaxing in their nice New York apartment), Jane Smiley arrives wielding bright dialogue like a scalpel, disarming us. It take less than a paragraph before we're on to the fact that neither she nor we are going to care very much who done it, let alone why. We are all in it for the dissection.

You don't have to use books at all.''

title: '84 LABOR CONTRACTS REPORTED PRODUCING 3% INCREASES IN PAY
description: Labor contracts negotiated in the first quarter of 1984 produced modest pay increases, the Government has reported, continuing a trend that economists said would ease pressure on companies to raise prices.

title: BROADCAST TV
description: On July 27, 1981, Reve Walsh went to a department store in Hollywood, Fla., with her six-year-old son. Warning young Adam not to wander, she left him in the toy department as she went to inquire about buying a lamp in another area, some 150 feet away.

title: THE ISSUE IS COMPETENCE
description: Whatever else the primaries have shown, they have been a depressing rerun of old issues. If that is a foretaste of the general campaign, the election won't do its job of informing and challenging the public to focus on America's needs.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM IBSEN TO KOVACS TO VERDI
description: Ibsen's 'A Doll's House' Starring Julie Harris, Christopher Plummer and Jason Robards Jr.; adapted by James Costigan; directed by George Schaefer, 1959 MGM/UA 89 minutes. $39.95

title: The Ivy View Ivy League colleges may be seen to be elite, but when it comes to athletics, they are closer to the ''real world'' than those schools that put a heavy emphasis on sport, according to
description: David McLaughlin, the Dartmouth president who spoke Friday at a gathering of 200 captains of past Dartmouth teams. He said that some colleges placed so much emphasis on sports that ''two classes of students are established.'' Reggie Williams, a 1976 Dartmouth graduate who now plays linebacker for the Cincinnati Bengals, agreed.

title: Shelby Gasek Married To Shannon Murphy
description: Shannon Barclay Murphy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas A. Murphy of Tewksbury, N.J., was married yesterday to Shelby Compton Gasek, a son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Stanley P. Gasek of Utica, N.Y. The Rev. Alfred M. Niese performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of St. John on the Mountain in Bernardsville, N.J.

title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES
description: An Islander From Montreal

title: TEACHING HISTORY THROUGH SONG
description: The children at St. Margaret McTernan School in Waterbury clapped their hands, swung their feet back and forth rhythmically, and sang off-tune but eagerly to the strumming of a guitar. This was a history lesson.

title: THE QUILTING BEE STILL HAS ITS PLACE IN THE COUNTRY
description: IRENE NAPPI of Peekskill has

title: BETSY HORTON TO MARRY RICHARD B. COONS SEPT. 22
description: Mr. and Mrs. A. Bruce Horton Jr. of Los Altos, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter Mary Elizabeth Horton to Richard Bertram Coons, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. William Coons of Columbus, Ohio.

title: HUDSON MUSEUM DRIVES FOR MEMBERS
description: THE Hudson River Museum has officially designated May as Membership Month and begun a vigorous campaign both to double its membership and to obtain greater community involvement in the institution's affairs.

title: CITY LOTS FOR SALE
description: For the past several years Carmela Flodin has waged a losing battle against the illegal dumpers who have littered the vacant, city- owned lot that abuts her property in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn.

title: THE DANCE: 'CHACONNE'
description: ANNA KISSELGOFF

title: TEXT OF REAGAN REMARKS AT PEKING CEREMONY
description: Following is the prepared text of remarks President Reagan is scheduled to make today at a signing and departure ceremony:

title: Home Rule for Capital Is Backed by Mondale
description: Walter Mondale took a jab at President Reagan's foreign travels and vowed to support home rule for citizens of the nation's capital in a brief appearance before supporters at his campaign headquarters today.

title: U.S. Will Allow Phone Merger
description: The Justice Department has announced that it would not challenge the proposed acquisition of U.S. Telephone Inc., the nation's eighth-largest long distance company, by United Telecommunications Inc., the ninth-largest telephone holding company. United Telecommunications, based in Kansas City, Mo., provides local telephone exchange services in parts of 21 states but serves fewer than 3 percent of the nation's telephone users, the department said. U.S. Telephone, based in Dallas, provides long distance service through resale of other interexchange carriers' offerings.

title: Irish Leaders Expected To Call for Unification
description: Irish political leaders examining ways to end the violence in Northern Ireland appear to be planning to call for Irish reunification this week when they report their conclusions.

title: Risa Steinberg Married to Mark Olinsky, a Lawyer
description: Risa Dee Steinberg, a daughter of Annette Steinberg of Great Neck, L.I., and the late Gilbert Steinberg, was married yesterday to Mark S. Olinsky, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Olinsky of Holmdel, N.J. Rabbi Ephraim Wolf performed the ceremony at the Great Neck Synagogue.

title: LANGEVIN'S STILL HITTING
description: UNIONDALE, L.I.

title: IN A TROUBLED STATE
description: Uri Etkin was born here 59 years ago, fought in Israel's wars from 1948 on, remains a reserve army colonel. On this beautiful Galilee kibbutz, the country's largest shipper of almonds, he helps manage an electric parts factory. He is a taciturn man, volunteering little. When he was asked how things were going at the kibbutz, he answered almost gruffly.

title: ; Beefsteak Charlie's Picks Smith/Greenland
description: Smith/Greenland has discovered a new place to wine and dine its clients - Beefsteak Charlie's.

title: Sydny Weinberg Is Married
description: The marriage of Sydny Helene Weinberg, executive editor of Pocket Books, and A. Bradford Miner, a senior editor of Bantam Books, took place yesterday in the Pierre's Cotillion Room.

title: A LONG, HARD BUS RIDE TO VISIT UPSTATE PRISON
description: The line for passengers formed early. Even though the bus was scheduled to leave Manhattan at 10 last Friday night, some of the travelers had arrived at the terminal before 8. They had good reason to be punctual, they said.

title: Creditors to Swap Alfa Debt for Stock
description: Grupo Industrial Alfa, once Mexico's most successful privately owned conglomerate, has decided to capitalize 30 percent of its holding company's debt as part of a complicated loan restructuring agreement with its 140 creditors.

title: REAGAN PAYS HOMAGE TO IMPERIAL UNIFIER AND BUILDER
description: Qin Shi Huang, whose tomb President Reagan visited today, was the ruler who first unified China and, while establishing a centralized empire, radically altered the political and social structure.

title: ALL FUNERAL COSTS MUST BE ITEMIZED
description: Twelve years after first being proposed, a Federal regulation goes into effect Monday to require funeral homes to provide an itemized list of services and materials they offer, along with the cost of each item, before a person agrees to any arrangements.

title: TENNESSEANS PUSHING JACKSON EFFORT
description: The Jackson for President headquarters is in the corner of the King shopping center, to the right of the neighborhood bar, the coin laundry and the $7.50-a-game bingo parlor. People would wander into it now and then, but it was losing to the leisure-time competition.

title: Delegate Picked by Card Is Challenge in Kansas
description: An official of Walter Mondale's campaign here for the Democratic Presidential nomination said today that he is challenging the selection of a national delegate pledged to Gary Hart who was chosen by a cut of the cards.

title: KEY CHOICE FOR GIANTS
description: T HE Jets have masked their intentions, for good reason, while the Giants will talk a little about their important third choice in the National Football League's annual draft of college players, which takes place tomorrow.

title: German Car Imports
description: Foreign makers increased their share of the West German new car market to 28.3 percent in first quarter from 25 percent a year earlier, the national motor office said Friday. First-quarter sales by foreign producers totaled 194,780, up from 163,900 in the 1983 period.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It just requires funeral homes to have a price list available and to tell the truth, yet it led to screams and howls from the industry.'' - Jessica Mitford, author of ''The American Way of Death.'' (B10:6.)

title: BRIEFING
description: Raves From Budapest

title: ARTIST DELIVERING LECTURES IN LIEU OF JAIL FOR SPEEDING
description: ''I want to thank you for driving too fast and getting up here,'' said Michael Gallatly, a young painter, as he shook hands with Frank Stella, the artist.

title: OILERS SET RECORDS IN TAKING 3-0 LEAD
description: Like an army that never runs out of ammunition, the Edmonton Oilers are going for a four-game sweep of Minnesota and a trip to their second straight Stanley Cup final.

title: Canada Output Off
description: Canada's industrial production fell 3.5 percent in February, to $33.2 billion, after rising 2.3 percent in January, Statistics Canada said Friday. The seasonally adjusted index covers manufacturing, mining and utilities, and accounts for nearly 30 percent of the index of gross national product.

title: TO PIN DOWN THOSE WHO 'STEAL' TIPS ON SECURITIES
description: To the Editor:

title: Debt Issues
description: BankAmerica Corp. is selling $150 million of two-year extendable notes with a final maturity of 1994 and an initial coupon of 12 1/8 percent at a price of 99 7/8 to yield 12.196 percent to 1986 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers. The notes may be redeemed by investors or retired by the company after two years, at which time the company may reset the interst rate and extend the maturity for two, three, or four years.

title: GETTING TO KNOW IN-LAWS
description: THE lox has been carefully selected. The fresh breads and the pies

title: DEVIL'S BAG STRUGGLING AS DERBY APPROACHES
description: WHEN Devil's Bag crossed the finish line in the Derby Trial Stakes at Churchill Downs Saturday, the colt had retained his role as a favorite for the 110th Kentucky Derby that is now five days away. But in victory, he seemed to have lost more than he had won.

title: MONDAY, APRIL 30, 1984 International
description: Formalizing of agreements with Peking on such issues as scientific and cultural exchanges, economic cooperation and development of nuclear energy was planned by President Reagan before he was to start on the final leg of his six-day trip to China. The agreements, to be formalized today, call for guarantees against double taxation for American corporations in China, a new round of exchanges of performing arts groups, museum exhibits and other cultural programs, and arrangements enabling American companies to help build Chinese nuclear reactors. (Page A1, Column 6.) Concerted pressure on Libya's leader will be sought by the United States in consultations with Britain and other allies, Reagan Administration officials said. Until Britain broke diplomatic ties with Libya last Sunday over the shooting in London of a police constable by someone inside the Libyan Embassy, only the United States, which expelled all Libyan diplomats in 1981, had taken action against the Government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. (A1:4.)

title: EASING OF BRIBERY LAW UNDER FIRE
description: The attention focused on a case involving possible improper payments by the Bechtel Corporation to South Korean officials is impeding efforts by the Administration and some members of Congress to ease the restrictions in the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, which prohibits such payments, according to Congressional aides and business lobbyists.

title: 'La Duse' Plays Saturday
description: A performance of ''The Woman, The Actress: La Duse'' will be presented by Any Place Theater at the Actors Information Project, 244 West 49th Street, between Broadway and Eighth Avenue on Saturday at 8:30 P.M. The play is based on the life of the Italian actress Eleonora Duse. Tickets are $10. Reservations: 699- 4062.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, APRIL 30, 1984

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Metropolitan Report on Friday about antismoking legislation in Suffolk County misidentified the County Executive, Peter F. Cohalan. He is a Republican.

title: Complete Reagan Text To Be Beamed to China
description: The Voice of America said today that it would broadcast the full text of President Reagan's Friday speech in Peking, portions of which were deleted by Chinese officials, to China in both English and Chinese.

title: OPERA: PETER SCHICKELE'S 'ABDUCTION OF FIGARO'
description: JOHN ROCKWELL

title: Bankruptcy Bill Signed
description: President Reagan signed a bill today extending the current bankruptcy court system.

title: DETAILS OF TREASURY PLANS DUE
description: The only Treasury financings scheduled this week are today's regular sale of bills due in three and six months, but market particpants are looking ahead to a heavy schedule of note and bond financings next week.

title: ENDLESS SEASON FOR PROSPECTS
description: F OR most college football players, the season ends with the final game. Then a new routine sets in, leaving players with more time to study or socialize or sleep, at least in the afternoon, which had previously been spent at practice.

title: ; TO PIN DOWN THOSE WHO 'STEAL' TIPS ON SECURITIES
description: To the Editor:

title: Watch Out for That Truck Tax Sixteen months ago
description: Congress finally recognized that heavy trucks should pay for a greater portion of the damage they inflict on the nation's highways. It significantly raised their weight tax. In return, in the same law, it gave them a long-sought right to run still bigger trucks on the interstate system, unhampered by state and city limitations on size or weight.

title: Stranded WatsonRescued in Snow
description: Steve Watson, the Denver Broncos' all-pro wide receiver, and two hunting companions were rescued this afternoon - hungry but unharmed - after being snowbound in a cabin 13 miles east of here for five days.

title: ANGELA LANSBURY SEEKS SERIES
description: Broadway's loss may be television's gain next fall. Over the years, Angela Lansbury has toyed with the idea of starring in a television series, but she was reluctant to give up the chance to play in Broadway musicals, which have really been her priority since she scored a smash success in ''Mame'' almost two decades ago and won the first of her four Antoinette Perry Awards.

title: U.S. PLANS TO SEEK ACTIONS BY ALLIES TO DETER QADDAFI
description: The United States plans to consult with Britain and other allies in the hope of converting the latest concern over Libyan activities into concerted international pressure on Col. Muammar el- Qaddafi, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: PEKING'S STRIDES IN TRYING TO FEED ITS PEOPLE
description: To the Editor:

title: Luncheon Toasts
description: When the Duke of Gloucester, who

title: Dodgers Shut Out Padres
description: Alejandro Pena limited the Padres to five hits, and Mike Marshall hit his seventh home run as the Los Angeles Dodgers defeated San Diego, 6-0, today.

title: IRON DEFICIENCIES IN INFANTS MAY HAVE LINK TO ECONOMY
description: An increase in the number of iron-deficient babies in the United States may be partly a result of high unemployment and Federal cuts in food supplement programs, a Pittsburgh physician says.

title: POLLUTION THREAT IS CITED IN STUDY ON INCINERATORS An environmental study has estimated that if New York City builds eight incinerators to burn its garbage, the resulting air pollution will increase the incidence of lung cancer in the city by 8 percent.
description: The study, produced at Queens College by the Center for the Biology of Natural Systems, said the incinerators would create airborne concentrations of chemically contaminated dust that ''almost certainly would exceed the New York State Air Guide for dioxin in the air.''

title: All Bark and No Bite - Yet
description: They snarl. They show their teeth.

title: DRAFT PROBLEM FOR N.F.L. AS TALENT POOL IS DOWN
description: MICHAEL JANOFSKY

title: Arrows Win, 9-8
description: Mark Liveric's goal 17 seconds into sudden-death overtime capped a spectacular comeback by the New York Arrows as they defeated the Baltimore Blast, 9-8, this afternoon at the Civic Center. Liveric stole the ball from a Blast defender, Max Thompson, to get his fourth goal, which left their quarterfinal series in the Major Indoor Soccer League tied at one game each. The Arrows trailed, 7-4, when the final quarter began but quickly scored four of the game's last five goals to tie the score at the end of regulation time.

title: One Killed by a Tornado That Hit Four Churches
description: Four churches filled with worshipers were hit by a tornado today, as some parishioners sought shelter in closets and under pews. One person was killed here and 20 were injured.

title: Brewer and Casper Win by 3 Strokes
description: Gay Brewer made six birdies today, compensating for an off day by his partner, Billy Casper, as they teamed to win the $500,000 Liberty Legends of Golf by three strokes.

title: No Headline
description: Bridge:If a Part-Score Is Involved, Things Can Get Interesting

title: PLIGHT OF UNEMPLOYED GOES BEYOND FIGURES
description: For 32 years, Walter F. Patronik, a quiet man known as Whitey, was a slitter at the Bethlehem Steel plant at the end of this mill town on Lake Erie.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
description: LA PLACE DE LA CONCORDE SUISSE.

title: CONVERSION OF BRIG TO JAIL IS OPPOSED IN BROOKLYN
description: To the Koch administration, the city is acting swiftly and properly to add a badly needed jail to its correctional system.

title: ANOTHER KHAN IS SEEKING SQUASH RACQUETS TITLE
description: EDWARD B. FISKE

title: CELTICS ROMP BY 110- 92
description: SAM GOLDAPER

title: Olympic WomenWin 3 Exhibitions
description: The Olympic women's basketball team swept to victories Saturday over South Korea, China and Hungary in exhibitions at the training center here.

title: DIABLO CANYON REACTOR STARTS UP AMID PROTESTS AND INDUSTRY PRAISE
description: The first fission reaction at the much-delayed Diablo Canyon nuclear plant was produced without incident today shortly after midnight, nearly 10 years behind schedule. But hours later plant operators recorded a nonradioactive water leak within a coolant system that was quickly contained.

title: Lisa Pachter, Buyer, Weds Paul A. Metselaar, Lawyer
description: Lisa Pachter, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Pachter of New York, was married yesterday to Paul A. Metselaar, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Metselaar of Rye Brook, N.Y. and Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Jobless Rate Off in Britain
description: Britain's unemployment rate fell to 13 percent in April from 13.2 percent the previous month, with the first drop in four months in the seasonally adjusted jobless figures, the Government said Friday. The Department of Employment said there were 3,107,682 people out of work in April, down 35,093 from March.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Jet Sales Executive Named by Canadair
description: As part of what it characterized as a major reorganization of its marketing subsidiary for sales of its executive jet in the United States, Canadair Ltd. has named Charles G. Vogeley president and chief executive officer of Canadair Inc., of Westport, Conn. Mr. Vogeley brings to his post more than 40 years of experience in aircraft sales.

title: Venezuela Payment
description: Venezuela's largest private sector debtor, La Electricidad de Caracas, last week paid $40 million in overdue interest to foreign creditors, a company spokesman said today.

title: BILL STALLED ON GUIDELINES FOR STATIONS
description: A longtime effort to draft a compromise deregulation bill for radio and television stations has broken down amid charges that the broadcast industry's largest trade group, the National Association of Broadcasters, had taken an unreasonably hard line.

title: Gasoline Price Rises Cited
description: Gasoline prices are up more than 2 cents a gallon since the start of the year and could reach a record-high average of $1.35 a gallon by July 4, an oil industry analyst, Dan Lundberg, said today.

title: HOW THE SAMPLING WAS CONDUCTED
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted April 23 through 26 with 1,367 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii, of whom 990 said they were registered to vote.

title: 29 Killed in Uganda Accident
description: A truck loaded with mourners returning from a funeral overturned on a bridge in eastern Uganda, killing at least 29 people, the Uganda radio reported today. The radio said 29 bodies had been recovered from the truck.

title: MUSIC: CONTINUUM AT TULLY HALL
description: WHEN people first began singing songs, a creative tension between words and music emerged that no historical process in music has ever really reconciled. Each song, in other words, asks us the same question: Are words propelled by the energy of a musical phrase, or are the literal meanings in the end subsumed and devoured by the curve and color of the music?

title: TOO MUCH, TOO LITTLE
description: Seven years of above-average rain and snowfall have caused more than $30 million damage from flooding in the desert country of southeastern Oregon. The last three seasons have set records for precipitation, and formerly dry lakes have risen to inundate ranches.

title: ALUMNI FIND DIVISIONS AT HARVARD LAW SCHOOL
description: As a student in Harvard Law School's class of 1974, E. Mabry Rogers wore Army fatigues and wire rim glasses, tied his hair in a ponytail, drove to class on a motorcycle and spent much of his time questioning the authority of his professors.

title: CONNECTICUT UTILITY'S BACKLASH
description: When the Public Service Company of New Hampshire announced in 1971 that it would build twin nuclear reactors at Seabrook for $1 billion to provide cheap and abundant electricity for itself and neighboring electric companies, no utility was more enthusiastic than the United Illuminating Company, which quickly bought one-sixth of the project, the second-largest share.

title: Dr. Richard D. Fischer Weds Stephanie Ziffer
description: Stephanie H. Ziffer, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Herman Ziffer of Tenafly, N.J., and Dr. Richard D. Fischer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Fischer of Cresskill, N.J., were married yesterday. The Rev. Jack A. Haney, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University.

title: U.S.-CHINESE AGREEMENTS
description: Following are the basic details of the three agreements formalized here today by the United States and China: TAXES: The tax measure, which like all international treaties requires Senate approval, is an agreement based on model treaties the United States has with other countries. It provides rules for determining the kinds of taxes each country may impose on income earned by corporations within their borders.

title: Change in Rules
description: When the final candidates for the men's United States Olympic basketball team regroup May 10 for a camp at Bloomington, Ind., the players will have to think of more than the plans and philosophies of their coach, Bobby Knight. Before the players compete in the Los Angeles Games, they must first undo instinctive moves - some of which they have been doing more than 10 years - that are not allowed under international rules.

title: Japanese Protest U.S. Move
description: Four thousand mothers and children gathered in the port city of Yokosuka today to protest the scheduled deployment of Tomahawk cruise missiles on United States Navy ships, the police said. The battleship New Jersey, equipped with Tomahawk missiles, will reportedly begin stopping at Yokosuka in June. Japan's large pacifist groups argue that because the Tomahawks can be equipped with nuclear warheads they violate Japan's policy against introducing nuclear weapons into the country.

title: Fair Game for Politicians
description: Temperatures hit the high 70's yesterday, perfect weather for the street fairs that sprouted around town. And as fairgoers basked in the sun and ate, politicians were on hand to press the flesh.

title: The City by Cycle
description: Some were exhilarated. Others

title: Advertising; Belleek Pottery's Awakening
description: -PAGE four-color ads in the

title: Afghan Aides Inspect Troops in Battle Area
description: The Afghan radio reported today that two Government officials inspected troops in the Panjshir Valley, indicating that Government forces had seized at least part of the stronghold of Moslem rebels.

title: Deaths From Anesthesia Studied in Texas Hospital
description: The president of Baylor College of Medicine has acknowledged that one death and two cases of brain damage to patients at Ben Taub Hospital last year may have resulted from problems with anesthesia, it was reported today.

title: RACING NOW NO.2
description: For more than three decades, the Daily Racing Form has been conducting an annual survey of attendance at major sporting events. The results have hardly been surprising.

title: 'Front Line' Africans Open Tanzania Talks
description: Leaders of six black African nations opened a conference today to discuss the future of their so-called front-line movement against the apartheid policies of South Africa.

title: STATE OF EMERGENCY IS DECLARED IN SUDAN
description: President Gaafar al-Nimeiry declared a state of emergency throughout the country today, saying the ''enemies of Sudan have become active both inside the country and abroad.''

title: Washington Watch; Latin Business Lobbies for Aid
description: WASHINGTON ARNOLDO VILLAFUERTE, a business executive from El Salvador, had this message for a Congressional breakfast: trade credits, which had been as high $2 billion a year in 1979, have dried up. This means that anything his stricken country imports has to be financed with cash on the barrelhead.

title: ALBANY LEGISLATORS FACING ENERGY ISSUE AFTER A RECESS
description: Legislators will return from their spring recess this week with one eye on an agenda of unfinished work, including the redistribution of low-cost electric power and the cleanup of toxic waste, and the other on their hopes for re-election in the fall.

title: Maulers DismissPendry as Coach
description: Joe Pendry, coach of the Pittsburgh Maulers of the United States Football League, has been dismissed, a team spokesman announced today.

title: METS TRIUMPH TO TIE FOR FIRST
description: WILLIAM C. RHODEN

title: THE D.C. MULTICOLOR TANGERINE-FLAKE BALLOT
description: If Rube Goldberg had been asked to design a balloting procedure, the zany cartoonist would have been hard-pressed to devise a system more complex and confusing than the one voters will face here Tuesday in the District of Columbia's Presidential primary.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: An Italian Quake Injures 100; 2,500 Others Left Homeless
description: A strong earthquake jolted central Italy today and authorities said about 100 people were injured, 2,500 people were left temporarily homeless and hundreds of buildings were damaged.

title: Nancy Mundy Weds Walter Stugis Jr.
description: Nancy Heath Mundy, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Laurence Robert Mundy of Mendham, N.J., was married yesterday to Walter Constant Stugis Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stugis of Ocala, Fla. The Rev. Alfred M. Niese performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of St. John on the Mountain in Bernardsville, N.J.

title: POP: GRETCHEN LANGHELD
description: GRETCHEN LANGHELD'S concert Wednesday at Roulette was full of good intentions. Like other composers downtown, she has her ear to many of the styles in the air - funk, classical minimalism, jazz, performance art, salsa, rock.

title: YANKS WIN, 6-5, WITH 4 IN 13TH
description: Consider the circumstances: The Yankees had been shut out the previous two games; they had failed to score in four of the previous seven; they had scored a total of only 2 runs in the previous 37 innings and now they had suddenly fallen three runs behind the Milwaukee Brewers in the 13th inning.

title: TOWN STILL BEARS MARK OF TWAIN
description: You don't know about the adventures of Huckleberry Finn without you have read a book of that name by a man named Mr. Mark Twain. He told the truth, mainly. There was things which he stretched, but mainly he told the truth. But that ain't no matter.

title: NIGERIAN MILITARY REGIME IS REINING IN ONE OF THE FREEST PRESSES IN AFRICA
description: The military regime that seized power here on New Year's Eve has taken strong measures against the Nigerian press, jailing five journalists and, in the view of some, intimidating many others.

title: Polls Near Voting Places Banned in Minnesota
description: Gov. Rudy Perpich has signed a bill into law making it more difficult for television networks and other groups to conduct polls of voters as they leave voting places in Minnesota.

title: QUERIES OF UNIONISTS UPHLED
description: The National Labor Relations Board, reversing a 1980 policy decision, announced a ruling today that allows employers to interrogate workers about union organizing activity in some cases.

title: THE LIBYAN EMBASSY SIEGE: UNHEEDED WARNINGS?
description: The shooting of a police constable outside the Libyan Embassy here on April 17, the 11-day police siege that followed and the rupture in diplomatic relations between London and Tripoli has raised a large number of questions that politicians were reluctant to pose while negotiations were under way. Now prominent members of all parties are pressing for details from the Government of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. Following are some questions and answers about the crisis, its origins and the way in which it was resolved.

title: RITES MARK WARSAW GHETTO UPRISING
description: The lights in Temple Emanu-El were dimmed yesterday as 31 survivors of the Holocaust, all women dressed in black, slowly walked to 6 stands and lighted 216 candles in memory of the 6 million Jews who perished at the hands of the Nazis during World War II.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day on April 14 describing salary and bonuses given last year to executives of the General Motors Corporation failed to include bonuses paid in General Motors stock. The stock bonuses increased the total compensation of Roger B. Smith, chairman, to $1,490,000 and that of F. James McDonald, president, to $1,329,970. Executives also accrue undisclosed credits under a program that reserves as much as $60 million a year for bonuses for 500 executives based on long-term performance.

title: THE STREETS CAN BE EASILY DESERTED EVEN IN A NATION OF A BILLION PEOPLE
description: If China conjures up one single image abroad, it is that of a nation of one billion people. But the crowds have been oddly absent during President Reagan's visit here.

title: SHEET-MUSIC COLLECTORS DISCOVER PLEASURE IN THE PAST
description: A picture of a sleepy railroad station decorates the cover of the 1924 sheet music for the comic song ''Back in Hackensack New Jersey.''

title: ;  Steinberg Bid Increases Disney Chief's 'Bruises'
description: As an All-America tight end at the University of Southern California and later as a player with the Los Angeles Rams, Ronald W. Miller, chief executive officer of Walt Disney Productions, grew accustomed to heavy hitting.

title: STATE'S 2 TOP REPUBLICANS DIVIDE ON ENDORSING KOCH AGAIN
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato said yesterday that the Republican Party should consider endorsing Mayor Koch for re-election next year, as it did in 1981 when the Mayor, a Democrat, won a landslide victory for his second term with bipartisan support.

title: MUSIC: MONTREAL SYMPHONY AT CARNEGIE HALL
description: TIM PAGE

title: ISRAELI COURT BACKS CLOSING OF PRINTER
description: Israel's Supreme Court ruled today that the military censor had the right to close an Israeli newspaper's printing plant for four days after the editors published information without prior submission to censorship.

title: Private Bias, Public Justice
description: Not long ago a child-custody fight between a white parent and a former spouse who had married a black would have been big news, especially if it reached the United States Supreme Court. Questions of racial intermarriage remained too hot to handle for years after the 1954 school desegregation decision.

title: Market Place; Rally Is Linked To Short Sales
description: RAYS of sunshine are finally poking through the interest rate clouds that have hovered over Wall Street for most of this year. Is it perversity or foresight? There's no sure answer, but equity investors are not complaining.

title: NO INVOLUNTARY SERVITUDE FOR THE HOMELESS
description: To the Editor:

title: PROXMIRE CITES CHARGES ON GENERAL DYNAMICS
description: A former top official of the General Dynamics Corporation who is now a fugitive in Greece has told Senate investigators that he has evidence that top officials of his former company defrauded the Navy and then covered up the fraud, according to Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin.

title: NEW CHEMICAL WEAPONS REPORTED LESS EFFICIENT
description: New chemical weapons sought by the Reagan Administration may be less efficient as weapons and more conducive to arms proliferation and terrorist use than existing types, according to a study by a nonpartisan Congressional organization.

title: GENERALS TAKE 8TH, 31-21, BEFORE 50, 908
description: WILLIAM N. WALLACE

title: PETRY FOILED IN NO-HIT ATTEMPT
description: Dan Petry of Detroit came within four outs of joining his teammate Jack Morris as no-hit pitchers this season, as he led the Tigers to a 6-1 victory over the Cleveland Indians today.

title: A Brooklyn Girl Dies in a Fire That Severely Hurts 2 Others
description: A 3-year-old girl was killed and her mother and a 15-year-old neighbor were badly burned last night in a fire in their apartment building in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: OPERA: MANNES CAMERATA PERFORMS
description: BERNARD HOLLAND

title: PRINCETON CREATING INSTANT TRADITIONS
description: At Princeton University, freshmen steal the clapper from the bell tower each fall simply because the freshmen before them did so. And seniors hurl clay pipes into the central green each spring because seniors have been hurling them there for generations.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of April 30, 1984: MONDAY Allied CorpHershey FoodsArmstrong World IndIllinois Tool WorksCooper Tire & RubKennametal IncCrane CoKoppers CoFoster WheelerUnited TechnologiesGifford-Hill & CoWackenhut Corp TUESDAY Adams-MillisInterstate PowerAtlantic RichfieldKansas City P & LEmerson ElecKroger PropertiesGeorgia-PacificMCA IncGulton IndusNiagara Mohawk Pwr WEDNESDAY Axia IncGulf States UtilsBlue BellIngersoll-RandChesebrough-Pond'sMarion LabsDover CorpPeoples EnergyEagle-Picher IndPepsico IncGeneral FoodsPortland Genl ElecGt Northern Nekoosa

title: 'A GENERATION APART,' IMPACT OF THE HOLOCAUST
description: ''A GENERATION Apart'' explores the impact of the Holocaust on the families of the survivors. In a curious way, it finds none. The children of the survivors seem very much like the children of parents everywhere, their fears and desires similar to those of everyone else. The documentary will be seen on Channel 11 tonight at 9:30.

title: MUSIC: ITALIAN PIANO PIECES
description: MOST of Italy's important keyboard music seems to have come from expatriates - Domenico Scarlatti at the court of Spain and Muzio Clementi in England. Victoria Vesell's recital of Italian piano music old and new at Merkin Concert Hall Thursday evening tended to point out the spotty quality of their colleagues and compatriots in the field.

title: MCENROE DEFEATS CONNORS, 6-1, 6-2, 6-3
description: John McEnroe, the defending champion, overpowered Jimmy Connors with blistering serves and strong baseline shots today to win the $500,000 Buick World Championship of Tennis final, 6-1, 6-2, 6-3.

title: Fumes Kill 2 in Food Vat
description: Two workers died Saturday when they were overcome by ammonia fumes in a vat of chopped chicken parts.

title: TimesPrintsNationalEdition At a 5th Site, in Austin, Tex.
description: The New York Times began printing its national edition last night at a fifth location, in the plant of The Austin American-Statesman in Texas.

title: Bomb Derails Subway In Chile, Injuring 22
description: Urban guerrillas exploded 11 bombs within minutes of each other today, derailing a subway train and injuring 22 people in one of the most serious attacks in more than a decade of military rule, officials said.

title: Gianettino Wins Sweda And Chevrolet Dealers
description: Gianettino & Meredith Advertising of Mountainside, N.J., has been named agency for the Delaware Valley Chevrolet Dealers Association of Philadelphia, its third dealer association account. The association has not had an agency for at least two years, but it is talking about an ad budget of more than $1 million.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. White Sox , at Chicago. The teams had two games rained out two weekends ago in New York, and split the two they managed to play.

title: ON BAGELS AND CROISSANTS
description: Consider the croissant and the bagel.

title: JAZZ DEFEATS SUNS
description: Adrian Dantley scored 36 points and Thurl Bailey 26 as the Utah Jazz beat the Phoenix Suns, 105- 95, today in the opening game of their Western Conference playoff semifinal. The second game of the four-of- seven series is Wednesday night here.

title: AIDE TO HISPANIC COMMUNITY
description: Msgr. Robert J. Fox, associate pastor of St. Paul's Church in East Harlem and former coordinator of the Spanish Community Action program in the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, died Friday of circulatory disease at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 54 years old.

title: DOMINICAN AFTERMATH
description: Last week's riots in the Dominican Republic immediately damaged the country's political structure, but the resulting national and international shock may benefit it in the longer term, according to Dominican officials and foreign diplomats here. The three days of disturbances, which left an estimated 55 people dead and hundreds injured, came in response to sharp increases in the prices of food, medicines and imported goods. The price increases were the result of austerity conditions the International Monetary Fund imposed in the second year of a three-year, $400 million loan.

title: SALVADOR VOTE: HABIT OR ENTHUSIASM?
description: Next Sunday Salvadorans are once again likely to flock to the polls, this time to elect a president for a five-year term. But their reasons for voting in such numbers, and often under trying conditions, are not always clear.

title: ANDRE PREVIN TO JOIN LOS ANGELES ORCHESTRA
description: Andre Previn, who has served as music director of the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra since 1976, will assume the same position with the Los Angeles Philharmonic beginning with the 1986-87 season.

title: Serkin and Paul TaylorAid Symphony Space
description: Peter Serkin and the Paul Taylor Dance Company will be among the performers May 14 in a benefit for Symphony Space.

title: Computer Linkups Spurred by France
description: As treasurer of a small engineering company in this dour eastern French town, Hubert Swalduz used to call the bank every day to ask about his company's accounts. Since the start of this year, however, all the information he wants comes to him on a little television screen in his office by touching a key.

title: 4 DIE WHEN TRAIN TRAPS ILLEGAL ALIENS ON TRESTLE
description: A freight train plowed through a group of illegal aliens walking across a railroad trestle in the dark Saturday night, forcing some to jump into a shallow creek 31 feet below. Four were killed and at least seven were injured.

title: POLL SEES GAIN EQUALING LOSS IF DEMOCRATS PICK A WOMAN
description: Running a woman for Vice President, a growing hope of Democratic feminists, would gain about as many votes from women as it would lose from men, the latest New York Times/ CBS News Poll suggests.

title: Cemetery Damage Laid to 2 Youths
description: Two teen-agers have been charged with scattering cremated ashes from burial vaults and desecrating Jewish gravestones with anti- Semitic markings on March 7, the police said today.

title: OCCIDENTAL, CHINA IN COAL PACT
description: More than four years after it opened negotiations, the Occidental Petroleum Corporation today signed an agreement with China to begin developing what could become the world's largest open-pit coal mine.

title: Dr. Lisa Saiman Wed To Dr. David Goldfarb
description: The marriage of Dr. Lisa Saiman, a pediatric intern at Presbyterian Hospital, to Dr. David Goldfarb, a resident in medicine at the Manhattan Veterans Administration Hospital, took place yesterday at the Grand Hyatt Hotel in Manhattan. Rabbi David Moseson performed the ceremony.

title: CONTADORA'S FOCUS HAS 'A PERNICIOUS AND SOPORIFIC EFFECT'
description: It's a familiar refrain in Washington: Support the Contadora group, whatever its weaknesses. When it comes to politically negotiated solutions in Central America, Contadora is the only game in town. Moreover, the argument goes, one must be patient: The Contadora countries (Mexico, Venezuela, Panama and Colombia) have been in business only 15 months. Skeptics are reminded that the list of governments endorsing the Contadora peace effort is long and impressive - indeed, who opposes it?

title: BUCKS BEATEN BY 106- 100
description: ROY S. JOHNSON

title: A MEDIA INDUSTRY INNOVATOR
description: At Harte-Hanks Communications Inc., the newspaper-oriented media company that has announced plans to become a privately held concern by midsummer, top executives are fond of saying that Harte-Hanks represents the leading edge of change in the newspaper business.

title: Steven Douglas Hart Marries Clare Marie Verow
description: Clare Marie Verow, a daughter of Mrs. Earle Adrien Verow and the late Mr. Verow of Westbury, L.I., was married yesterday to Steven Douglas Hart of Mineola, L.I., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Hart of Westbury, L.I. The Rev. Paul H. Daniell performed the ceremony at the United Methodist Church of Westbury.

title: ; Newspaper Ad Bureau Elects Officer Slate
description: The Newspaper Advertising Bureau elected officers yesterday as the American Newspaper Publishers Association began its annual meeting, this time in Montreal.

title: Debra Schwartz Is the Bride of John E. Chester 3d
description: Debra Schwartz, an assistant manager in the Maxwell House division of the General Foods Corporation in White Plains, and John E. Chester 3d, an associate at Morgan Stanley & Company in New York, were married yesterday. Mayor Suzanne Oppenheimer of Mamaroneck, N.Y., performed the ceremony at the Wampus Lake American Inn in Armonk, N.Y.

title: THEATER: MOOD IN 'OLIVER' REVIVAL
description: FRANK RICH

title: DANCE: WAGONER COMPANY
description: DAN WAGONER'S dances have always been an odd blend of physical eccentricity and down-home charm. On Saturday at the Judson Church Mr. Wagoner celebrated the 15th anniversary of his company with a mini-retrospective that summed up those elements in one of the happiest performances in a choreographic career notable for its warmth and humanity.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BRITISH AUTHOR Although she may be best known here as the writer of the opening episodes of the television series ''Upstairs, Downstairs,'' Fay Weldon is a prominent novelist at home in England. She has written best sellers there and has won praise for her latest book, ''The Life and Loves of a She Devil,'' to be published this autumn by Pantheon in New York. She also caused a stir recently by denouncing British publishers for their treatment of authors.

title: ;  Service Merchandising Loses Its President
description: James E. Poole, president and chief operating officer of the Service Merchandising Company has announced his resignation from the company after less than a year on the job.

title: TOOL ORDERS ROSE 2.7% IN MARCH
description: Machine tool orders were up only slightly in March over the previous month, but were about two-thirds greater than in March 1983, according to an industry organization report.

title: OUTDOORS: WINNER'S CAST TOPS 676 FEET
description: NELSON BRYANT

title: Ellen Hexter Is Married To Investment Manager
description: Ellen Sue Hexter and Steven James Petrie were married yesterday at the Harmonie Club in Manhattan by State Supreme Court Justice Alfred M. Ascione.

title: Deborah Lynn Newman, Actress, Weds C. C. Illidge
description: Deborah Lynn Newman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph H. Newman of Little Neck, Queens, was married yesterday to Christopher C. Illidge, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Samuel C. Illidge of Stoke-on-Trent, England.

title: LIGHT ON CHILD SEX ABUSE
description: The American public may have been stunned by recent revelations of the sexual abuse of children in a California nursery school. But specialists who work with children - caseworkers, therapists, counselors at rape crisis centers and physicians - were not astonished at all. Neither were prosecutors who deal with such cases.

title: PACTS WITH CHINA SIGNED AS REAGAN ENDS PEKING VISIT
description: President Reagan, nearing the final leg of his six-day trip to China, formalized new agreements with Peking today on scientific and cultural exchanges, economic cooperation and the development of nuclear energy.

title: SHAMIR ASSERTS BUS PLOT ARRESTS FOILED DISASTER
description: Prime Minister Yitzak Shamir said today that Israeli security officers who foiled a purported plot by Jewish extremists to blow up Arab-owned buses in Jerusalem had saved the country from ''a disaster.''

title: Required Reading The Last Colony
description: Many of you know this city well. This city is a big city; it has many things to offer you. It has the spirit and winds of politics that are so much a part of all of our lives as elected officials. It has a culture to it that is going to someday replace that of New York City as the cultural center of America. It has something for everybody. We have all of the kinds of people which make up America here in Washington. Black people, white people, old people, young people. A few rich people, some poor people, middle-class people, male people and female people. We have places for everybody to go, so we're happy that you are here, and we hope that you will partake of that.

title: MUSIC: 'FESTIVAL OF VOICES'
description: CRAIG BURK and Christian Marclay opened the three- day ''Festival of Voices'' Thursday, presented at the 512 West 19th Street loft by Public Access Synthesizer Studios.

title: LECHERS' NEMESIS
description: To the Editor:

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: Tax-Exempt Bonds*9.94

title: TEXANS SEEM UNCERTAIN OVER CENTRAL AMERICA
description: A television commercial for Bob Krueger, a candidate for the Democratic senatorial nomination, shows a voter musing over his choices. An off-camera voice says Mr. Krueger was once ambassador at large for Mexican affairs and is an expert on Latin America.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * L.W. Biegler Inc. , a Chicago-based managing general agency specializing in unusual and high- risk insurance coverages, announced that Richard E. Stone is joining the firm as vice chairman.

title: Canadians Shop at Post Office
description: Canada's post office is getting into the mail-order catalogue shopping business. It is also negotiating to get involved in banking and a whole range of other businesses that spokesmen say must remain secret for now.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Broadway column in Weekend on Friday gave an incorrect date for the departures of Jeremy Irons and Glenn Close from ''The Real Thing.'' They will appear through June 30.

title: ORIGAMI: AN ART FOR ALL AGES
description: Here are a few of the things you might have folded from paper yesterday if you had attended the national origami convention at the American Museum of Natural History:

title: LABOR'S MYOPIA
description: When organized labor flexed its political muscle six months ago, union leaders thought they had a sure winner in Walter F. Mondale. That's one reason why the A.F.L.-C.I.O. broke precedent and endorsed him in advance of the Presidential primaries. The second reason was ideological compatibility. It soon became apparent, however, that while Mr. Mondale kept the faith, union muscle showed more flab than fiber. This was especially true in Massachusetts, Connecticut and, to some degree, even in Michigan and New York, all highly unionized states. What happened?

title: Swifter Deals for Back-Office Jobs
description: New York is probably building more office space than the rest of the country combined, but it's rising only in prime locations at high prices. To keep less glamorous but vital bookkeeping, computer and clerical jobs, New York needs the office equivalent of middle-income housing. Mayor Koch's team, trapped by high land costs and cumbersome governmental procedures, has so far failed to get it under way.

title: The U.N. Today April 30, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: EDDIE MURPHY AS POP SINGER
description: ROBERT PALMER

title: Parents File Suit In Cornell Slaying
description: The parents of a Morris County student shot to death in her dormitory room at Cornell University are suing the college, charging it was negligent in its failure to provide adequate security.

title: STEPHEN GREENBERG, FINANCIAL EXECUTIVE AND FUTURES EXPERT
description: Stephen Greenberg, president and chief executive officer of the futures affiliate of Deak-Perera and a leading figure in the commodities industry for two decades, died of a heart attack Saturday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 52 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: BERNSTEIN CONDUCTS MAHLER
description: JOHN J. O'CONNOR

title: SYLVIA ASHTON-WARNER, WRITER
description: Sylvia Ashton-Warner, a New Zealand writer who was best known for her books about teaching schoolchildren in her native country, died at her home Saturday in Tauranga. She was 75 years old.

title: Drives to Sign up Voters Are Reported Increasing
description: President Reagan's policies have galvanized both his friends and foes, and may cause a turnaround of a 20-year trend of decreasing voter participation, according to a study released today.

title: LIMITED'S BID REJECTED
description: Directors of Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc., the nation's sixth-largest retail chain, announced yesterday that they had unanimously rejected ''as inadequate'' a revised tender offer from The Limited Inc., another retailer. The directors took the action at a special meeting on Saturday.

title: MOSTEK RIDES HIGH ON COMPUTER CHIP
description: In just two years, the Mostek Corporation, based here in suburban Dallas, has grown into one of the biggest makers of an important computer chip. Now it faces the task of diversifying against the day of an inevitable market downturn.

title: FOR U.S. IN CAIRO, $3.5 MILLION DOWN BUT NO HOME
description: The house resembles a bombed-out building. The bedroom walls have gaping holes. The marble tiles of the entryway are sloped and cracked. Virtually every wire is exposed. The basement could be the site of an archeological dig.

title: BIRD'S ANKLE ' A BOO-BOO
description: BOSTON I F the Knicks somehow come back to win their Eastern Conference semifinal playoff with the Boston

title: Man Electrocuted Trimming Trees
description: A Long Island man trimming tree branches near high-tension wires was killed when his chain saw accidentally touched a live wire, sending 7,600 volts of electricity through his body, the Suffolk County police said.

title: Las Vegas Hilton Hotels Negotiate With 2 Unions
description: - Negotiators for the Hilton hotels and two unions today tried to reach an agreement that could lead to an end to the 28-day strike by workers against 29 casino hotels.

title: Letter: On Waste Disposal New York Must Control Its 'Hot' Dumps
description: To the Editor:

title: Futures/Options; Expert Points To 'Mass, Risk'
description: NO statistic better reflects the dramatic changes that are sweeping the futures industry than the monthly volume figures reported by the exchanges. When the April numbers are tallied in a few days, they will again show, for example, that trading in Treasury bond futures exceeded the combined total for corn, wheat and soybeans, traditonally the most active markets in the industry.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: In a college basketball game, an incorrect player shoots two free throws and misses both. The correct player is then sent to the line and makes the two free throws. He is allowed to reshoot the fouls because of the ''correctable error'' rule. What is a correctable error and when does it apply?

title: Lewis and Miss Ashford Fast in Debuts
description: Carl Lewis and Evelyn Ashford, America's top hopes for gold in the Olympic sprints this summer, opened their 1984 outdoor seasons today with victories at the Mount San Antonio College Relays.

title: OUTLOOK HAZY EVEN FOR DERBY
description: It is the norm rather than the exception for the Kentucky Derby outlook to be muddled, but this year's top 3-year- olds have a peculiarly erratic quality not limited to Devil's Bag and Swale, the favored entry. Their best prep races are of higher quality than in many seasons, but many of them have shown little consistency and others are in questionable physical condition.

title: Dr. Susan Spater Wed in RyeBrook
description: Dr. Susan Harriet Spater, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Herman W. Spater of Larchmont, N.Y., was married yesterday to Seth Allan Zimmerman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Zimmerman of Bayswater, Queens. Rabbi Irwin C. Lowenheim performed the ceremony at the Rye Town Hilton in Rye Brook, N.Y.

title: MONEY DATA BACKED AS GUAGE
description: Weekly announcements of changes in the nation's money supply are still closely watched in the financial markets, but recently traders and investors have been paying more attention to the impetus for higher interest rates that is coming from a rapidly expanding economy, growing credit demands, and increasing scarcity of bank reserves.

title: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.
description: Monday

title: Ferrari TriumphsIn Grand Prix
description: Michele Alboreto of Italy charged from the pole in his Ferrari and drove to an unchallenged victory in the Belgian Formula One Grand Prix today.

title: Lingering Bias
description: Since the color barriers were dropped and black players began competing with whites in athletics, researchers have been looking for signs of lingering discrimination.

title: CONFERENCE PONDERS WAYS TO PRESERVE OLD CHURCHES
description: A house of worship is a house, after all. The roof leaks. The plaster cracks. The windows break.

title: OHIO UTILITIES FACE NUCLEAR PLANT DOUBTS
description: Officials of the Ohio Edison Company and the Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company are trying to remain optimistic about the second reactor at the Perry nuclear power plant. But investors and opponents see serious trouble ahead for the project.

title: ILL-CHOSEN TARGET FOR A TAX INCREASE
description: To the Editor:

title: Saving the Worm
description: Fishing has long been regarded as an especially civilized sport, but not to those who shrink from putting a worm on a hook. It is an altogether squeamish business, and no picnic for the worm.

title: Seattle SwimmersExcel in Trials
description: Tracie Ruiz of the Seattle Aqua Club captured the solo championship today, less than 24 hours after she and her partner, Candy Costie, clinched the United States Olympic berth in duet competition at the synchronized swimming trials here.
